text: Imagine Facebook is like a really big playground where all your friends hang out! "Facebook Live" is like a super cool, brand new toy they just put on the playground, maybe like a giant slide or a bouncy castle that shows you fun things happening *right now*. Facebook wants *everyone* to come and play with this new toy because if you play with it, you'll have so much fun and want to stay on *their* playground for a long, long time! If you stay longer and watch all the cool live shows, you might see other fun things too, and maybe even some yummy snacks being sold (that's like the grown-up ads), which helps Facebook make money so they can keep their playground open and add even more fun toys. They just want to make sure their playground is the most exciting place to be, so you don't go play at another playground instead!

title: How does the U.S. government owe money to itself?
text: Imagine your family is like the big government, and they have different piggy banks! One piggy bank is for all the grown-ups who are old (it's called Social Security), and it's like their special savings account. Another piggy bank is for everything else, like building roads or paying for schools. Sometimes, the "everything else" piggy bank needs more money, but it's a little empty. So, the grown-ups (the government) might borrow some money from

title: Why is there an enzyme in the human body that breaks down methanol into formaldehyde? How does this enzyme exist in the first place?
text: Imagine your body has tiny, tiny helpers called enzymes, kind of like little toy sorters. This particular helper's *real* job is to sort and clean up other kinds of

title: Why can a psychological condition/state (like stress) cause physiological effects?
text: Imagine your brain is like the super smart boss of your whole body. It's in charge of everything! When you feel something big in your head, like when you're super worried about something or really scared (that's stress!), your brain thinks, 'Uh oh, something might be wrong!' Then, your brain sends super fast messages, like little alerts, all over your body. It tells your heart to beat faster, so you could run away if you needed to. It might tell your tummy to feel a bit funny, like butterflies, because it's busy getting ready for something. It's like your brain is trying to get your body ready to be super strong or super fast to help you, even if there's no real monster. So, your feelings in your head and what happens in your body are always talking to each other!

title: Why does the military insist on saluting?
text: Imagine you're playing with your friends, and you have a special secret handshake or a special way to say "hello" to your teacher to show them you respect them. Well, saluting is kind of like that for people in the military! When they raise their hand to their head, it's a special way to say "hello" to someone important, like their boss or a very brave person. It shows they respect that person and that they are all on the same team, working together to keep everyone safe. It's also a very old tradition, like a special rule they've had for a super long time, which helps them feel strong and united as a team. So, it's a fancy "hello" that shows respect and that they're all part of the same big, important family!

title: Why do colors combine to make other colors?
text: Imagine colors are like different kinds of special sprinkles your eyes can see! When you have red sprinkles and yellow sprinkles and you mix them all up in a bowl, your eyes don't just see red and yellow anymore, do they? They see a brand new color, orange! It's kind of like that with colors. When you mix paints, you're just putting lots of tiny, tiny pieces of different colored stuff together, and your eyes see all those mixed-up pieces as one new color. And when you shine different colored lights, like a red flashlight and a blue flashlight, their special lights actually *join up* and make a brand new light color, like purple! It's just how the special light pieces mix and make something new for your eyes to see, like magic!

title: how did humans survive the ice age?
text: Imagine the whole world got super, super cold, like a giant ice cream freezer everywhere! That was the Ice Age. It was really hard because there wasn't much food, and it was freezing

title: What's going on with "black money" in India?
text: Imagine grown-ups get money from their work, just like you might get stickers for being good. Now, there are special grown-ups called the government, and they use a little bit of everyone's money (we call it 'taxes') to build cool things like roads for cars, schools for kids, and hospitals when people are sick. 'Black money' is like when some grown-ups get money but don't tell the government about it. They try to hide it, like hiding a cookie so you don't have to share it. When they do this, the government doesn't get enough money to build all the nice things for everyone, and it's not fair to the grown-ups who *do* share their money. In India, a lot of grown-ups have been playing this hide-the-money game, and the government is trying hard to find it so they can build more good stuff for all the people.

title: what exactly does Obama care do? why do some people hate it so much and why do other people love it so much?
text: Okay, imagine you get a really big boo-boo or feel super sick and need to go to the doctor or hospital. That costs a LOT of money, like buying a whole toy store! Most grown-ups have something called "health insurance," which is like a special piggy bank that helps pay for those doctor visits so you don't have to give *all*

title: Why does a website with a recipe often include a long preface before you get to the actual recipe?
text: Imagine you have a big coloring book, and the person who made it wants to keep making new coloring books for you to enjoy. But making coloring books costs money, right? It's the same with the people who share yummy recipes on the internet! They love to share how to make cookies or pizza, but they need a little money to keep their website working and to keep sharing new ideas. So, *before* they give you the recipe for yummy cookies, they tell you a little story or give you some tips about the cookies. It's like they're making the page a little bit longer. Why? Because when the page is longer, there's more space for little pictures that are like tiny commercials (called ads!). And every time someone sees those ads, the website gets a tiny bit of money. Also, when they write more words, it helps computers find their recipe more easily when someone is looking for 'cookie recipe,' so more people come to their website and see the ads! It's how they earn enough money to keep sharing all those delicious ideas with everyone for free!

title: Why does scratching a bug bite feel so amazingly good when I'm obviously damaging my skin?
text: Imagine your skin has tiny little wires that send messages to your brain. When a mosquito gives you a little kiss, it leaves a tiny bit of special bug spit that makes one of those wires yell "ITCHY! ITCHY! ITCHY!" really loud! That's why it feels so wiggly and annoying. When you scratch it, it's like you're sending a *different*, much stronger message up to your brain, like "WHOOSH! SCRATCHY!" Your brain hears that big "WHOOSH!" message and gets super busy listening to it, so it kind of forgets about the little "ITCHY!" message for a bit, and that feels super good because the annoying itch goes away! But if you scratch too hard or too much, you can make tiny boo-boos on your skin, like little scrapes, and then your skin will hurt instead of just being itchy, and it takes longer to get all better. So, it feels good for a second, but it can make new owies!

title: If I'm thinking of a song, are my brainwaves moving at the frequency of the notes?
text: No, not really! When you think of a song in your head, it's like you're playing pretend music. Your brain uses its own special electricity, which we call brainwaves, to think and remember things. These brainwaves are much, much slower than how fast the sounds in a song wiggle. Imagine a super-fast high note buzzing thousands of times every second! Your brain's electricity for thinking only wiggles a few times or tens of times a second. So, your brain is just remembering what the song *sounds* like, like looking at a picture of a yummy cake, but it's not actually making the cake or the sounds of the song with its own wiggles. It just knows how it goes!

title: How can expired food grow mold/fungus on it if it's in a sealed container so any air carrying spores can't come into contact with it?
text: Imagine tiny, tiny, invisible seeds of mold are already hiding on your food when it gets put into the container, even before it's sealed up tight! They're like super tiny, sleepy babies already tucked in with their yummy food. When you seal the container, those little mold seeds are trapped inside with the food and a tiny bit of air that got sealed in too. They don't need any new air from outside to come in, they just use the little bit that's already there. And when the food gets old (that's what "expired" means!), it's been sitting for a long, long time, giving those tiny mold seeds all the time they need to wake up, eat the food, and grow big and fuzzy enough for us to finally see them!

title: Why does carbonated water (most notibly soda) build up pressure once shaked?
text: Imagine your soda has lots and lots of tiny, invisible party bubbles hiding inside the water. When you shake the bottle, these tiny bubbles get super excited and start bouncing all over the place, wanting to get out and play! But the bottle is closed, so they can't escape. All those excited bubbles push harder and harder against the inside of the bottle and the lid, trying to find a way out. That pushing is what makes the bottle feel tight and builds up pressure, like when you push on a balloon to make it bigger. If you open it too fast, all those excited bubbles rush out at once, sometimes bringing some soda with them in a big splash!

title: How exactly does an explosion kill you?
text: Okay, imagine a super, super big and loud 'BOOM!' When something explodes, it does a few mean things all at once. First, it makes a giant, invisible push of air, like a super-strong wind that can squeeze your insides too hard or throw you really far against a wall or the ground. Ouch! Second, all the things that exploded and are around it break into tiny, sharp pieces that fly super, super fast, like angry little rocks or splinters, and they can hit your body very hard. And third, it gets super, super hot, like touching a giant, invisible fire, which can give you very, very bad burns all over. All these big pushes, flying bits, and super hot feelings happen so fast and are so strong that your body just can't handle it, and it makes your body

title: Why is it that even though my car weighs almost 3,000 lbs it still gets blown around like a feather (mild exaggeration) when I'm driving on a windy day?
text: Your car is super heavy, like a giant toy block, and that's true! But wind is like a big, invisible bully that loves to push things. When the wind pushes on your car, it's not pushing on just a tiny spot, it's pushing on the *whole big side* of your car, like a giant hand pushing on a big door. Even though your car is heavy, if the wind pushes hard enough on that big flat side, it's strong enough to make your car wiggle and wobble, just like when you hold a big cardboard box and the wind tries to snatch it from you. The wind is just super good at pushing on big, flat things!

title: Can a planet stay hidden if it is placed in opposition of Earth in orbit and moving with the same speed ?
text: Imagine you and your friend are running around a giant, bright lamp (that's the Sun!), and you are Earth. Now, imagine another friend is trying to hide exactly on the other side of the lamp, always keeping the lamp between you two and running at the same speed. That spot is like a very wobbly tightrope! The big lamp's invisible pull (called gravity) and your own invisible pull would make your friend wobble and eventually drift out

title: What is 4-dimensional space?
text: Okay, imagine you live in a world where you can only go in three main ways: you can go forward and backward (like walking straight), you can go left and right (like wigg

title: Why did motorcycle sidecars become less popular?
text: Imagine you have a super fun bike, and sometimes you put a little wagon next to it to carry your teddy bear – that's kind of like a motorcycle with a sidecar! But then, big, comfy cars started to be made, like your dad's car, where everyone could sit inside, stay warm and dry, and carry even more toys and groceries. Lots of grown-ups chose those instead because they were super easy and safe for the whole family. Also, motorcycles got really, really good and fast all by themselves, like a super cool bike you just want to ride solo because it's so much fun and easy to steer. The sidecar made the motorcycle a bit slow and tricky to turn, like trying to push two shopping carts at once. So, people just didn't need them as much anymore, and they liked the new, fast motorcycles or the comfy cars better!

title: Why are American postboxes/mailboxes usually detached from the house itself?
text: Imagine our mail carrier is like a busy superhero delivering important letters and fun drawings to everyone! If they had to walk all the way up to every single front door, it would take them a super long, long time, like when you walk all the way around the block instead of just cutting across the grass. Sometimes there might be a big, friendly doggy that wants to play, or lots of stairs to climb, or a super long driveway. So, to make it super fast and super safe for them, we put the mailboxes right by the street. That way, the mail carrier can just drive their special truck, stop for a quick second, pop the mail in, and zoom to the next house. It's like having a special easy-access spot for their deliveries so they can bring everyone their letters much, much faster!

title: how and why did "Bee Movie" become a meme?
text:
Okay, imagine a movie so super-duper silly, it makes your belly giggle just thinking about it! *Bee Movie* is about a bee named Barry who can talk to humans, and then he gets very, very upset that humans are eating honey, so he tries to sue all the people! That's a super funny and strange idea, right?

Well, when bigger kids and even grown-ups watched it again, they thought, "Wow,

title: Why do we (in the USA) never seem to hear about left-leaning survivalist groups seizing a facility or something of that nature? Do such groups not exist? Or are they simply not covered by the MSM? Been curious since the Bundy incident in Malheur County, Ore.
text: Okay, imagine some grown-ups who really, really like to be ready for anything, like if the lights go out or the store runs out of food. They're called 'survivalists

title: Why are some video games or updates released with major problems instead of being delayed?
text: Imagine you're building a super cool LEGO castle, and all your friends are super excited to play with it! Building it costs a lot of money, like buying all the LEGO bricks. You told your friends, "It'll be ready by your birthday!" Sometimes, when it's almost birthday time, you realize a few towers are a bit wobbly or a door doesn't quite open right. But you've already spent so much money on the bricks, and your friends are SO excited and waiting! If you wait too long to fix *everything* perfectly, you might run out of money to buy more bricks, or your friends might get tired of waiting and find something else to play with. And sometimes, there's a special time, like Christmas, when everyone wants new toys, and if you miss that, it's a big problem! So, sometimes the grown-ups who make games decide to let you play with the castle even if a few towers are a little wobbly. They promise to come back later and fix those wobbly bits, because they really want you to play and they don't want to run out of money or make you wait forever!

title: How does our "new organ", the Mesentery, work?
text: Imagine your tummy has lots and lots of long, wiggly tubes inside, like a big bowl of spaghetti! The mesentery is like a special, see-through ribbon or tape that holds all that spaghetti neatly in place, so it doesn't get tangled up and messy when you run and jump. It also has tiny roads inside it that bring yummy food and important drinks (blood) to your spaghetti tubes so they can do their job and help you grow big and strong. For a long, long time, grown-ups thought this ribbon was just a bunch of little pieces, but now we know it's one big, clever ribbon helping to keep everything in your tummy happy and working right!

title: Why does our vision sometimes blackout when we stand up?
text: Okay, imagine your body has a special juice called blood, and this juice helps everything work, especially your eyes and brain so you can see and think! When you're sitting or lying down, the juice is all spread out nicely. But when you stand up super fast, it's like the juice suddenly wants to go down to your feet because a big invisible hand (called gravity) pulls it! For a tiny moment, your brain and eyes don't get enough juice, and it's like your TV screen goes black for a second because it doesn't have enough power. But don't worry, your body is super smart and quickly pushes the juice back up to your brain and eyes, and then you can see again!

title: How did Humans create perfectly flat objects prior to the invention of advanced tools/machinery?
text: Imagine you have a bumpy toy block and you want to make it super smooth and flat like your kitchen table, but you don't have any fancy tools! What people did a long, long time ago was really clever. First, they would find something that was already naturally flat, like the top of a very still puddle of water, or a very big, heavy rock that was already kind of flat. Water is always perfectly flat on top, like a perfect mirror! Then, they would get special tiny, sharp bits of other rocks, like sand, and put them on their big, flat rock. Now, they would take their bumpy block and rub, rub, rub it against the big flat rock with the sand in between! The tiny sand bits would scrape away all the little bumps on their block. They'd keep rubbing and rubbing, feeling it with their fingers to see if it was getting smooth, and sometimes putting it on the still water to see which parts touched and which parts still stuck up. They'd just keep grinding and rubbing until all the high spots were gone and it felt perfectly flat and even, just like the water or their big flat rock. It took a lot of patience and a lot of rubbing, but that's how they made things super flat!

title: Why do cars only visible smoke while in idle when engine is cold?
text: Okay, imagine your car's engine is like a busy little chef making power! When it cooks its special fuel, it also makes a tiny bit of water, just like when you boil water for noodles and see steam. When the car first starts, everything is cold, especially the long pipe at the back where the air comes out. So, that little bit of water turns into tiny, puffy clouds, just like when you breathe out on a very cold day and see your breath! But as the car drives and gets warmer, that pipe gets super hot, and the water quickly turns into invisible air that you can't see anymore. It only looks like 'smoke' when

title: How did they calculate votes in the early days of America without phones/Internet to convey the results. Wouldn't it lead to rigging?
text: Imagine you and your friends are voting for what game to play. Instead of phones, everyone wrote their game on a little piece of paper, or maybe even just said it out loud. Then, a grown-up would stand in front of everyone and count all the votes, one by one, out loud, so everyone could hear! They'd write down the numbers on a big piece of paper, like a scoreboard. To tell other towns who won, a trusted person would take that special paper with the numbers and ride a horse or walk a long way to deliver it. Because lots of people were watching the counting, and the grown-ups carrying the papers were very honest, it was much harder for someone to secretly change the numbers, like trying to sneak an extra cookie into your jar when everyone is looking!

title: What's the difference between a quicksave and a normal save in a video game?
text:
Okay, imagine you're building a super cool tower with your blocks!

A **normal save** is like when you carefully take a picture of your tower, write on the back of the picture "My awesome tower on Monday!" and put it in a big photo album. You can take lots and lots of different pictures of different towers or the same tower at different stages, and you can always go back to any picture you want. It takes a little bit of time to write on the back and put it in the album.

A **quicksave** is like when your mom calls you for dinner, and you just quickly snap *one* picture without writing anything on it, and you put it on a special hook by the door. It's super fast! But, there's only *one* hook. So if you build a *new* tower later and quicksave again, that new picture replaces the old one on the hook. You only ever have the *last* quicksave picture.

So, normal saves are slow and let you have many different memories, while quicksaves are super fast but only remember the very last thing you did!

title: Why do humans like to kiss each other?
text: Imagine you really, really like someone, like your mommy or daddy, or your best friend! When you give them a big hug, it feels warm and happy, right? Kissing is kind of like a very special, gentle hug, but with your lips! It's a way for grown-ups to show someone they love them a lot and that they feel super happy and close when they are together. It makes their hearts feel warm and fluttery inside, like a happy secret they share. Sometimes, it's also a way for grown-ups to pick their very best partner to share their life with, like finding a super special friend for always.

title: How long should one use bulb mode to get a good picture of the stars in a completely dark setting?
text: Imagine your camera is like a hungry little monster that eats light! When it's super dark outside and you want to take a picture of the sparkly stars, your camera needs to eat a *lot* of light to see them. 'Bulb mode' is like telling your camera, "Okay, keep your mouth open and keep eating light for a loooong time!" If you don't let it eat for long enough, the stars will just look like tiny, tiny dust. But if you let it eat for *too* long, something funny happens: because our big Earth is always spinning like a top, the stars will start to look like little lines instead of round dots, like they're drawing in the sky! So, to get them just right, like bright, pretty sprinkles, you usually want to let your camera eat light for about as long as it takes you to slowly count to 15 or 20, maybe even 30. It's like a little game: you try one time, then maybe a bit longer or shorter, until the stars look super happy in your picture!

title: What allows heat to cast a shadow?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big toy block. When you put it in front of a light, it makes a dark shadow because the block stops the light, right? Heat doesn't make a dark shadow like that because heat isn't a solid thing you can touch or hold. Heat is more like invisible warm air that wiggles and dances super fast! When light tries to go through this super-wobbly hot air, the hot air makes the light get a little bit confused and bend in funny ways, almost like looking through a wavy window. So, instead of a dark shadow, what you see is a blurry, shimmery spot, like things are wiggling behind the

title: How can Sony make an XBONE equivalent while being significantly smaller AND without a power brick?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car. A long time ago, toy cars were big and maybe needed a separate big battery pack. But now, new toy cars can be super small and still zoom really fast,

title: Why do essential oils dissolve paint?
text: Imagine paint is like a wall made of tiny, colorful LEGO bricks all stuck together with a very special, super-strong glue that gets hard when it dries. Essential oils are like a special kind of 'magic juice' that doesn't like water, but it *really* loves to make *that exact kind of glue* soft and squishy again! So, when the essential oil touches the paint, it starts to tickle and melt the glue holding all those LEGO bricks together, making them all unstuck and runny, so they can't stay on the wall anymore and just float away. It's like your play-doh getting super soft and messy!

title: Why does starchy food stick so hard onto kitchenware?
text: Imagine your pasta or rice is made of super tiny, dry little beads. When you cook them with water and get them all warm, those little beads drink up the water and get all soft and squishy. And when they get squishy, they also get super sticky, kind of like when you get sticky glue on your fingers! They love to hug onto anything close by, especially the warm pan. Then, when the food cools down, that sticky squishy stuff gets hard again, just like dried glue, and holds onto the pan super tight, making it a bit tricky to wash off!

title: What are each programming language's real-world function?
text:
Imagine programming languages are like different kinds of magic words you can tell a computer to do different jobs!

*   **Python** is like a very clever magic spell that can help your computer learn new things, like guessing what toy you want, or figuring out big puzzles. It's good for lots of different smart jobs.
*   **JavaScript** is the magic that makes websites *move*! When you click a button on a website and something happens, or a picture wiggles, that's JavaScript making the website come alive and do things.
*   **Java** is like the strong magic for building really big and powerful apps,

title: How does SSL Certificates work exactly?
text: Imagine you want to send a secret message to your friend, but first, you need to make sure you're talking to your *real* friend and not a sneaky stranger pretending to be them, right? An SSL certificate is like a special ID card for a website. When you visit a website, your computer asks, "Are you really Google.com?" The website then shows its special ID card, which is the SSL certificate. This card has been checked and signed by a very trusted grown-up (we call them a Certificate Authority) who makes sure the website is who it says it is. Your computer looks at the ID card. If it's a real card, signed by a trusted grown-up, your computer says, "Okay, I trust you!" Then, your computer and the website can start talking in a secret code (that's the 'encryption' part), so no one else can listen in on your secret messages or see what you're doing. If the ID card isn't real or is missing, your computer will say, "Uh oh! This might not be safe!" and warn you, just like you wouldn't tell secrets to a stranger without an ID.

title: Why do some people find things like dolls and clowns scary?
text: Imagine a doll or a clown. They look a bit like people, right? They have eyes and a nose and a mouth, just like you! But here's the tricky part: they don't move or act like real people. A doll just stares and doesn't blink, and a clown has a big painted smile that never changes, and you can't see their real face. Your super smart brain knows what real people look like and how they move. So when it sees something that looks *almost* like a person but doesn't act quite right – like it's frozen or has a fake, unmoving face – your brain gets a little confused. When your brain is confused about something that looks a bit like a person but isn't, it sometimes makes you feel a bit uneasy or even scared. It's like your brain is saying, "Hmm, this is strange, I don't quite understand it, so let's be careful!" That feeling of "not quite right" can make some people feel a bit jumpy or scared.

title: What is a Deep Space Radio Wave And How Does It Effect Us As A Species?
text: Imagine you're playing telephone, but the person talking is super, super far away, like on another planet or even another star! A deep space radio wave is like that tiny, invisible whisper coming from very, very, very far away in space. It's not sound you can hear with your ears, but it's like a special, invisible message that travels through space from things like stars exploding or galaxies far away. Does it affect us? Nope! These whispers are so incredibly weak by the time they get to Earth, they're like a tiny, tiny feather falling on your head – you wouldn't even feel it. They don't hurt us, they don't change us, and they don't do anything to our bodies at all. But even though they don't affect *us* directly, they are super important for grown-up scientists! They use giant listening ears (telescopes) to catch these tiny whispers, and those whispers tell us amazing secrets about how the universe started and what cool stuff is happening way out there. So, they help us learn, even if they don't touch us.

title: How is Voyager 1 still sending NASA information from interstellar space, 39 years after it's launch?
text: Imagine Voyager is like a super special toy car that NASA sent way, way out into space, even farther than the moon! It doesn't have batteries that run out like your toys. Instead, it has a special warm little power maker inside that keeps giving it energy for a super long time, like a tiny, magic oven that never stops cooking. When it wants to tell us something, it's like it shines a tiny, super strong flashlight beam, but instead of light, it sends secret beeps. NASA has a super-duper big ear, like a giant bowl in the desert, that can listen very, very carefully and hear those tiny beeps, even though they've traveled for many, many hours to get here because Voyager is so incredibly far away. And it was built super tough, like a superhero toy that doesn't break easily, so it just keeps going and going, exploring the big empty space and sending us little messages!

title: Where are everyone's passwords stored in websites?
text: Imagine you have a super-secret clubhouse, and to get in, you need a secret handshake. You don't write down the actual handshake on a piece of paper for everyone to see, right? Instead, the clubhouse has a special grown-up who knows *how* to check if your handshake is the right one. Websites do something similar with your secret word (your password). When you tell a website your secret word, it doesn't write down your exact word. Instead, it quickly changes your secret word into a super-duper mixed-up, jumbled-up, secret code, almost like a secret magic spell! This magic spell code is then kept safe in a giant, super-fast filing cabinet inside their special computer, called a server. So, your *real* secret word isn't sitting there for anyone to peek at. Only the mixed-up code is. When you want to get into the website again, you type your secret word, and the website quickly does the magic spell again to make a *new* mixed-up code. If the new mixed-up code matches the old mixed-up code in their filing cabinet, they know it's really you, and they let you in! This way, even if someone tried to peek at their filing cabinet, all they would see are jumbled-up magic spells, not your actual secret word!

title: How does the golden ratio follow the fibonacci sequence?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special counting game where you start with 1, then another 1, and then you just add the last two numbers to get the next one! So it goes 1, 1, 2 (because 1+1=2), 3 (because 1+2=3), 5 (because 2+3=5), 8, 13, and so on. That's our Fibonacci sequence. Now, imagine a super special number, like a magic number that helps make things look really pretty and balanced, like a perfect picture or a beautiful seashell. That's called the golden ratio, and it's about 1.618. Here's the cool part: if you take one of the big numbers from our special counting game (like 8) and divide it by the number right before it (like 5), you get 1.6. If you take an even bigger one (like 13) and divide it by the one before it (8), you get 1.625. The bigger the numbers you pick from our special counting game, the closer and closer the answer gets to that super pretty magic golden ratio number! It's like the counting game numbers are always trying to become the golden ratio number the bigger they get.

title: How does an LED change colors?
text: Okay, imagine your toy light that changes colors is like a tiny house, and inside this house, there are actually three super tiny, super special little lights! One tiny light only knows how to make red, another tiny light only makes green, and the third tiny light only makes blue. When you want to see red, the light tells the red tiny light to shine bright! When you want to see yellow, it tells the red tiny light AND the green tiny light to shine together, and because they're so close, their colors mix up in the air and look yellow to your eyes! If it tells all three tiny lights – red, green, and blue – to shine a little bit, or a lot, they mix their colors together like magic paint, but with light, and that's how you see all the different colors, like orange, purple, or even white!

title: What is an axiom?
text: Imagine you're playing a game, like building with LEGOs or playing tag! An axiom is like a super important rule or a basic LEGO block that everyone just knows is true, right from the very beginning. You don't have to prove it, or ask "why is that true?", it just *is*. It's the starting point that everyone agrees on, so we can then use it to build bigger things or play the whole game! So, in tag, everyone just knows if someone touches you, you're "it"—that's like an axiom for the game!

title: What causes irrational fear?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-smart captain of a ship, and it has a special alarm button to keep you safe! When there's a really big, scary storm, the captain pushes the alarm, and you know to hide. That's good fear! But sometimes, this alarm button gets a little bit sticky or confused. It might push the alarm really, really hard even when it's just a tiny little raindrop, or when the ship is perfectly safe. So, you feel super scared, even though there isn't really a big danger. It's like your brain is trying extra hard to protect you, but it's getting a little mixed up about what's *actually* dangerous and what's just new or different. Sometimes it's because something surprising happened before, or sometimes it just happens by itself. It's not your fault, it's just your brain trying its best, even if it gets a bit silly sometimes!

title: If your brain uses 20% of your calorie intake, and your brain uses more energy when used intensely, does this mean you can lose weight from using your brain more intensely on a regular basis?
text: Your brain is like a super busy little engine in your head that helps you think and learn, and it needs energy from the food you eat, just like a car needs gas! It uses a good bit of that gas all the time, even when you're just watching cartoons. When you think *really* hard, like solving a super tricky puzzle or learning new words, your brain engine works a little bit harder, so it uses a *tiny, tiny bit* more gas. But it's not a whole lot extra, like when you run and play outside all day long, which uses a *ton* of gas! So, while thinking hard is awesome for making your brain strong and smart, it won't make you lose weight like running around and playing would, because it just doesn't burn *that much* extra energy.

title: We have vast fields dedicated to satellite dishes listening for signals in outer space. Why can't they install dishes on the moon for both listening to space and for bouncing signals back?
text:
Imagine our big listening dishes are like giant ears trying to hear tiny whispers from very, very far away friends in space. Putting those giant ears on the moon would be super, super hard! First, getting all the heavy parts there costs a million zillion dollars, like buying all the toys in the whole world! And if one of the buttons broke on our moon-ear, no one is up there to fix it easily. It's much easier to keep our big ears here on Earth, in quiet places where grown-ups can take care of them.

Now, about bouncing signals, like playing catch with a ball: we *can* throw a signal ball all the way to the moon and catch it when it bounces back! But the moon is so far that the signal ball gets super tired and quiet on its way back, and it takes a long, long time, like waiting for your turn on the swing for

title: How does a OLED TV work?
text: Imagine your TV screen is made of millions and millions of super tiny little flashlights, like tiny stars all lined up. In an OLED TV, each one of these tiny flashlights can turn on and off all by itself! It's like having a giant wall of tiny stars, and each star can decide to shine bright with a color like red, green, or blue, or go completely dark. When a tiny flashlight wants to show a dark color, it just turns itself off, so it's super black, like the night sky with no moon or streetlights. Other TVs sometimes have one big light behind everything, like a big lamp shining through a window, so even the dark parts aren't truly dark. But OLED TVs don't need that big lamp; each tiny flashlight is its own little light maker, which is why the pictures look so super real and the dark parts are so, so dark!

title: Why in winter, on sunny days its really cold, and cloudy days its warm?
text:
Okay, imagine the Earth is like your bed, and you're sleeping in it. The sun is like a big, warm lamp far away.

When it's a sunny winter day, the sun is out, but it's not shining super strong because it's low in the sky, and there's no blanket covering your bed. All the warmth that your bed (the ground) tries to make just floats away into the big sky, making the air around you feel super cold, even though you can see the lamp.

But when it's a cloudy winter day, the clouds are like a big, fluffy blanket covering your whole bed! This blanket doesn't let all the warmth from your bed float away. It traps some of that warmth close to you, just like your real blanket keeps you cozy in bed. So, even if you can't see the sun, the blanket of clouds helps keep the air a little bit warmer for us.

title: How and why do almonds have a split directly down the middle?
text: Imagine an almond is like a tiny, sleepy baby tree, and its hard shell is like its cozy little bed. Inside that bed, the baby tree is waiting to wake up and grow big! The split you see right down the middle isn't a boo-boo; it's like a special little door or a zipper on its bed. When it's time for the baby tree to start growing roots and leaves, that little door helps it push its way out of its shell so it can reach the sunshine and dirt. It's just how nature made it, so the baby tree has an easy way to get out and say hello to the world!

title: Why it is more pleasant to watch big screen from big distance than small screen from small distance even though they are covering same amount of my field of view?
text:
Imagine you have two pictures. One is a giant painting on a wall, and the other is a tiny sticker.

If you put the tiny sticker *right up to your nose*, it fills up

title: Why September, October, November, December are 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th months of the year when in Greek (on which I guess it's based) it is more like Septa = 7, Octo = 8, Nona = 9, Deca = 10?
text: Imagine you have a train with lots of cars, and each car is a month! A super, super long time ago, the year started a little bit later, so September was the 7th car, October the 8th, November the 9th, and December the 10th, just like their names sound! But then, some smart people added two brand new cars, January and February, right at the very front of the train! Because those two new cars jumped to the front, all the other cars had to slide back by two spots. So, September, which used to be number 7, got pushed back to number 9. October, which was number 8, got pushed back to number 10. And it was the same for November and December! Their names are still like the old numbers, but their spot in the train changed because of the two new cars

title: Why are knives and swords curved?
text: Imagine you have a yummy banana! If you try to push a super straight ruler through it, it's a bit hard, right? But if you use a little banana-shaped knife, it just slides right through! Knives and swords are often a little bit curvy, not super straight like a stick, because that curve helps them *slice* things better. Instead of just pushing straight down, the curve lets the blade go *whoosh* through what you're cutting, like a tiny slide. It makes it easier for the knife to start cutting and then keep going smoothly, helping it cut through things like bread or even tougher stuff much, much faster and with less effort, like giving it a little helper to get the job done!

title: Why isn't American cheese called cheese, and instead called cheese product?
text: Okay, imagine you have a yummy apple, right? That's like real cheese, it comes straight from the tree (or the cow's milk for cheese!). Now, imagine you take that apple and you mash it up, and then you add a tiny bit of sugar and some water to make a smooth, sweet applesauce. It's still made from apple, but because you added other things and changed it, you

title: Are all planets revolutions made in the same direction?
text: Yes! Imagine you have a giant carousel, and all the horses are the planets. They all go around the middle pole (which is our Sun!) in the exact same direction, always following each other. That's just how our solar system works – all the planets travel around the Sun the same way, because everything started spinning together like a big swirly pancake when it was first made, and it just kept going!

title: Adderall and Xanax are both addictive substances. Why is it that Adderall causes mild withdraw symptoms, if any, while Xanax induces a potentially lethal withdraw?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a little car. Adderall is like pushing the "go faster" pedal. If you use it for a while and then stop, your brain car just goes back to its normal speed, maybe a little tired or grumpy, like after a long trip. It's not really dangerous, just feels a bit slow for a while. Now, Xanax is like pushing a "sleepy" button on your brain car, making it go super slow and calm. If you push that button for a long, long time, and then suddenly let go, your brain car gets really scared and tries to go super-duper fast all at once to catch up! It's like trying to go from sleeping to running a marathon in one second. This sudden burst can make your brain car get really confused and cause problems, like shaking a lot or even making your body not work right, which can be very, very dangerous, like a car crashing because it tried to go too fast too quickly. That's why it's so important to have doctors help when stopping Xanax, so your brain car can slow down its "sleepy" button very, very slowly and safely.

title: Why can't single cell organisms be huge? Why can't a single cell be the size of a person?
text: Imagine your tummy, where you eat food to get energy, right? And you also need to go potty to get rid of the yucky stuff. A tiny, tiny cell is like a very small

title: why does shaking (like in a train or bus) and rocking a baby's crib help us sleep?
text: Imagine you're a little boat floating on super calm water. When a grown-up rocks your crib, or you're in a train or bus that's gently swaying, it feels a lot like that! It reminds your body of when you were a tiny baby, safe and warm, being carried or rocked by your mommy or daddy. That gentle, rhythmic movement is like a soft, quiet hug for your brain. It tells your brain, 'Everything is okay, you're safe and cozy, so you can stop thinking about all your busy thoughts and just relax.' It's like a lullaby without singing, helping your body and mind calm down and drift off to sleep.

title: Why do kids need more sleep than adults?
text: Imagine your body is like a little plant that needs lots and lots of sunshine and water to grow big and strong! You, little one, are growing super-duper fast every single day. Your bones are getting longer, your muscles are getting bigger, and your brain is learning so many new words, games, and how to run and jump. All this growing and learning takes a *lot* of energy and hard work from your body, and most of that important work happens when you're sleeping! Your brain is like a super computer that needs to sort out all the new things you learned that day and build new connections, and your body needs to build itself up. Adults are already grown-up plants, so they don't need quite as much sunshine to get bigger, and their brains already know lots of things, so they don't need *as much* time to learn brand new things from scratch. So, you need extra sleep to become a big, strong, and super smart kid!

title: How and why does belly button lint accumulate overnight (or in general)?
text: Okay, imagine your belly button is like a super tiny, cozy cave on your tummy! Your shirt, the one you wear every day, is made of lots of tiny, tiny threads, like super thin hairs. When you move around, or even when you're just sitting or sleeping and wiggling, your shirt is always gently rubbing against your tummy. Each time it rubs, little, tiny bits of those threads break off, like when you rub two things together and tiny dust comes off. Because your belly button is a little cave with tiny folds, it's the perfect place for those tiny shirt bits to get stuck and hide! They all gather together in that cozy spot, making a little fluffy ball, like a tiny dust bunny. It happens all the time, but you see more of it in the morning because those tiny bits have had lots of time to gather in their secret cave while you were sleeping!

title: How does match fixing work?
text: Imagine you're playing your favorite game, like soccer or tag! Usually, everyone tries their very best to win, right? And it's super exciting because you don't know who will win until the end! Match fixing is when some grown-ups, who are being very naughty, don't want the game to be fair. They secretly tell some players, or even the grown-up who blows the whistle (the referee), to *not* play their best, or to make mistakes on purpose, so that one team *loses* on purpose, even if they could have won. They do this because these naughty grown-ups put a lot of money on the team they *know* will lose (or win), so they make lots of money by cheating. It's like if you knew the answer to a test before you even took it – you'd get it right every time! It makes the game not fun or fair for anyone who loves watching.

title: What prevents me from making a consumable product that is harmful to one's health and addictive, even though alcohol and tobacco have no medical benefits?
text: Okay, imagine there are grown-up rules about what new toys you can put in the toy store. The grown-ups say that any *new* toy has to be super safe and not make kids feel yucky or want it all the time. Now, alcohol and tobacco are like really, really old toys that were already in the toy store a super long, long time ago, before these new, strict safety rules were made. Even though the grown-ups now know these old toys aren't good for you and make people sick and want more

title: How were mathematicians able to calculate pi without accurate measurements?
text: Imagine you have a yummy round cookie, and you want to know how much "around" it is compared to how "wide" it is. But circles are wiggly, and it's hard to measure perfectly with a straight ruler! So, smart mathematicians didn't try to measure the cookie directly. Instead, they put other shapes, like

title: What causes body aches when fighting a fever?
text: When you have a fever, it's like your body is turning up its internal heater to cook away the tiny, invisible germs that are trying to make you sick! But fighting those germs is super, super hard work, kind of like when you run and play all day long and your legs get really tired. All that hard work makes your muscles feel a little sore and achy, because your body is busy trying its very best to get rid of the yucky germs and make you feel all better again!

title: Why are large mergers like T-mobile/ATT blocked on anti-trust concerns where smaller monopolies like Stanley/Craftsman go unchallenged?
text: Imagine you love candy! There are only a few super big candy stores in your whole town. If two of the super big candy stores become just *one* giant store, then there are hardly any

title: Why can the human eye not see infrared light?
text: Imagine all the different kinds of light are like a giant, super long rainbow, way bigger than the one you see after the rain! Our eyes are amazing, but they're only built to

title: Why do these pictures make people's brain hurt?
text: Okay, imagine your eyes are like little cameras that take pictures and send them to your brain to understand. Most of the time, it's super easy, like seeing your teddy bear. But some clever pictures are like a little magic trick! They show things that don't quite make sense, or they look like two different things at the very same time. So, your eyes send the picture to your brain, and your brain goes, "Huh? Wait a minute! Is that going up or down? Is that a duck or a rabbit?" Your brain gets a little bit confused because it's trying really hard to figure out the trick, and when it has to work so hard to understand something tricky, it can feel a little bit like it's "hurting" because it's thinking so much to solve the puzzle!

title: If autonomous vehicles are to be the future of transportation, what steps are being taken to ensure they function in extreme weather conditions such as blizzards or black ice?
text: Imagine your toy car has eyes to see the road and a brain to know where to go. But when it snows a lot, or the road is super slippery like black ice, it's hard for its eyes to see, right? So, clever grown-ups are teaching these car brains new tricks! They give the cars *extra* special eyes that can see even when it's foggy or snowy, like how you can sometimes feel your way in the dark. These special eyes bounce invisible waves or tiny lights, so the car can still feel where everything is, even if it can't see clearly with its regular camera eyes. Also, the car's brain learns to be super careful when it's slippery, going much slower and knowing exactly where the road should be from maps it already knows. They drive these cars in pretend snow and real snow lots and lots of times to make sure they learn how to be super safe, just like you learn to walk carefully on ice! If it gets *really* bad, the car might even decide it's too tricky and ask a grown-up for help or stop until it's safer, because being safe is the most important thing.

title: Why are some things 'oddly satisfying'?
text: Imagine you have a big box of crayons, all mixed up. Then you line them up perfectly, red with red, blue with blue, all neat and tidy! Doesn't that feel good? Or when you push a toy car into its special parking spot and it fits just right, *click*! That happy feeling is what 'oddly satisfying' means. Our brains really like it when things are organized, or when something that was messy becomes neat, or when something fits perfectly. It's like our brain says, 'Yay! Everything is in its right place!' and it gives us a little happy tingle inside. It's a quiet, calm happy feeling because everything just *works* or looks *just right*.

title: Why do clouds turn dark when they are about to start raining?
text: Imagine a cloud is like a big, fluffy cotton ball in the sky! When it's a happy, sunny day, the cloud has just a little bit of water inside, and the sunshine can easily shine right through it, making it look bright and white. But when a cloud is getting ready to make rain, it starts to drink up lots and lots of tiny water drops, like a super thirsty sponge! All that extra water makes the cloud much, much thicker and heavier. When it's so full of water, the sunshine can't push its way through as easily anymore, so it gets stuck inside the cloud, and the cloud looks dark and grey from underneath, almost like a big shadow in the sky. It's like trying to see through one thin curtain versus many, many thick curtains all piled up – the thick ones block more light!

title: How come there are so many companies offering free web hosting? What's the catch?
text: Imagine you want to draw a picture, and someone says, "Hey, you can use my special paper for free!" They let you do it because they want you to try their paper and maybe later, if you want bigger, fancier paper, you'll buy it from them. Or, they

title: Why is it that if you look at a word for long enough, your brain will question its spelling, despite it being a simple and familiar word that's normally spelt with ease?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-fast helper robot inside your head! When you read a word like 'dog,' your robot helper knows it super quick! 'Oh, that's a dog! Easy peasy!' But if you stare, stare, stare at 'dog' for a really long time, like 'dog, dog, dog, dog, dog...' your robot helper starts to get a little confused or bored. It's like if you say your own name over and over again – after a while, it might sound funny and not even sound like your name anymore, right? Your brain usually likes to zoom past words to understand whole sentences, like putting puzzle pieces together quickly. But when you make it stop and just look at *one* tiny piece for too long, it forgets what the whole picture is supposed to look like and starts thinking, 'Hmm, is this piece *really* right? It looks weird all by itself!' It's not that the word is wrong, it's just your brain getting a little tired of looking at the same thing in a super close

title: Why do public toilet seats have a gap in the middle and ones at home don't?
text: Okay, imagine the toilet at your house is like your very own special cup, and only you and your family drink from it. It's easy to keep clean just for you! But the toilets out in public, like at the park or a store, are like a big water fountain that *lots* and *lots* of people use. Because so many different people use them, the toilet seats have a little open part, like a tiny U-shape, at the front. This open part makes it super easy to quickly wipe clean, and it helps make sure everyone stays nice and neat when they use it, especially when grown-ups are helping clean up. It's just a special design to keep things extra tidy when lots of people share!

title: Why do we wake up in the middle of the night even when not triggered by dreams or external stimuli?
text: Imagine your body is like a little train that goes on a long journey through the night while you're sleeping! Sometimes the train goes super fast and deep into dreamland, that's when you're sleeping really, really deeply. But even on a long journey, the train needs to slow down sometimes, just for a tiny, tiny moment, to make sure everything is okay, like checking its wheels or if it needs more water. Your body does the same thing! It doesn't stay in the super deep sleep all night long. It naturally comes up to a lighter sleep for just a little bit, like taking a quick peek around. Most of the time, you're only awake for a blink, blink, second and then you go right back to sleep without even remembering it happened! It's just your body's way of making sure it's comfy, safe, and doesn't need to go potty or get a drink, before it chugs along back into deep sleep and dreams again.

title: Why does a company want to sell my personal info? To whom? For how much? What's the data even look like?
text: Imagine you have a favorite toy, like a big red car. A company that makes toys wants to know who likes big red cars so they can show *only* those kids new car toys, hoping they'll buy one! They sell this secret information, like a little note that says 'This kid likes red cars,' to *other* companies, like the toy store or the cereal company, so those companies know what to show you in their commercials. They don't sell *you*, but they sell little notes about what lots of people like, and they get a little bit of money for each note, which adds up to a lot! The notes aren't pictures of you; they're more like a checklist saying 'Likes dogs: Yes,' or 'Likes cartoons: Yes,' so they can guess what you might want to buy next.

title: when looking at the moon during the day, why is the dark side camouflaged by the blue sky?
text: Okay, imagine the moon is like a big, grey ball, and the sun is a giant flashlight! When the sun shines on one side of the moon, that side looks bright. The "dark side" is just the part the sun isn't shining on right then, so it's really, really dark, like a big dark rock in space. Now, during the day, our sky is super, super bright blue because the sun is shining on all the air around

title: Why are people swayed more by negative reviews than positive ones?
text: Imagine you really, really want a new toy! If someone tells you, "This toy is super fun!", you go, "Yay!" and you're happy. But if someone tells you, "Oh no, this toy broke right away and made me sad!", you get a big worried feeling in your tummy! That's because we really, really don't want bad things to happen, like our toy breaking or being sad. It feels like avoiding a boo-boo or a disappointment is a bigger deal than just getting a little extra happy feeling. Our brains are like little protectors, and they listen extra carefully to warnings about things that might make us sad or give us trouble, because we want to stay safe and happy the most!

title: Fluoride is added to water, but iodine is added to salt. What was the reasoning behind choosing these specific elements and where they should be added?
text:
Okay, imagine your teeth are like tiny, tiny houses, and sometimes little sugar bugs try to make holes in them! Fluoride is like a super-strong shield that makes your tooth-houses extra tough so the sugar bugs can't make holes easily. We put fluoride in water because everyone drinks water, so it's like painting everyone's tooth-houses with that super shield all at once when they take a drink!

Now, you have a special little helper inside your neck that helps you grow big and strong and smart, like a little engine. This engine needs a special fuel called iodine to work properly. A long time ago, many people didn't get enough iodine, and their little engines couldn't work well. People figured out that almost everyone uses salt when they cook food, so putting iodine in salt was like putting that special fuel into a secret ingredient that goes into almost all your yummy meals, making sure everyone's little engine gets what it needs to grow big and smart! So, fluoride goes in water to help teeth directly, and iodine goes in salt to be eaten and help that special part of your body.

title: Can someone explain how high profile people can not pay taxes? How would they not be audited or investigated if they're suspicious?
text: Imagine you have a big pile of yummy cookies, and the grown-ups say you have to put some of your cookies into a special "sharing jar" for everyone to use for things like building

title: . How do dowsers work? (E.g in the location of groundwater supplies)
text: Imagine someone holding two special sticks, maybe shaped like a Y, and walking very slowly on the ground. They are trying to find water that's hiding deep, deep under the dirt, like when you play hide-and-seek with your toys. They say that when they walk over water, the sticks will suddenly pull down towards the ground all by themselves, like the water is giving the sticks a little tug! It's like the sticks are saying, "Water here!" But here's the secret grown-ups have learned: the sticks don't actually feel the water, and the water doesn't really pull them. It's more like the person holding the sticks *thinks* they feel something, or sometimes they just get really good at guessing where water might be, like when you guess which hand has a treat. So, even if they sometimes find water, it's not the sticks telling them, it's just a clever guess!

title: If addiction is a medical condition, then why do many addiction programs require that their adherents take responsibility for their actions?
text: Imagine your brain can get a little bit tricked or sick, like when you have a tummy ache, and it makes you really, really want to do something that's not good for you, like eat too much candy even when you know it will make you feel yucky later. It's not your fault your brain got tricked,

title: Why do we have different sizes for audio jacks (like 2.5mm and 3.5mm)? Does it make any difference other then the size of the plug?
text: Okay, imagine you have different toys, some are big and some are small, right? Well, audio plugs are a bit like that! We have bigger ones (like the 3.5mm one you usually see on headphones) because they are strong and easy to plug in. But sometimes, when gadgets like really tiny phones or old walkie-talkies needed a plug, there wasn't much room inside for a big hole, so they made smaller plugs (like 2.5mm) to fit! It's just about making sure the plug fits in the right tiny spot on the toy. Does it make the music sound different? Nope! It's like having a big straw or a small straw for your juice – the juice still tastes the same, right? The important thing is that the plug fits snuggly into the hole so the music can travel from your music player to your ears. If it doesn't fit, no music can play, no matter if the plug is big or small!

title: Why is the top bun of a burger normally thicker than the bottom, when the bottom holds all the weight?
text: Imagine your burger is like a special friend you're holding! The bottom bun is like a sturdy little plate that holds all the yummy stuff inside, like the meat and cheese. It needs to be strong so nothing falls out! But the top bun is like a big, fluffy hat for your burger friend. It's thicker because it makes your burger look super important and yummy, and when you take a bite, that soft, fluffy bread feels really good in your mouth, like a soft cloud. It's just a special way to make the burger feel cozy and taste extra delicious!

title: Why does meth make users skin so ugly and old-looking?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super squishy, smooth balloon that needs lots of water to stay plump and yummy food to stay strong, and a good long nap every night to fix any boo-boos. When someone uses meth, it's like they forget to give their skin any water, so it gets all dry and wrinkly, like a shriveled apple. They also don't eat good food, so their skin doesn't get strong, and they stay up all night, so their skin never gets to rest and fix itself. Plus, sometimes meth makes them think there are invisible bugs crawling on them, even though there aren't any, so they scratch and scratch, making lots of little owies and bumps. All these things together make the skin look tired and old very, very fast, like it's rushing to be an old person's skin instead of staying young and fresh.

title: Why do sites like Youtube and Facebook (but especially Youtube) continuously modify their interface with new skin, color, and features, despite the negative reception of their userbase?
text: Imagine YouTube and Facebook are like really big toy boxes! Sometimes the grown-ups who own these toy boxes like to change how they look, or add new games, or move the toys around, even if you really

title: How does one die of depression?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little house where all your happy thoughts live. When someone has depression, it's like a big, dark cloud comes and covers that house, making it hard for the happy thoughts to come out. Everything feels heavy and sad, like you're wearing really heavy shoes all the time. This sadness can get so, so big that it makes it hard to do important things, like eating yummy food, drinking water, or even sleeping. Sometimes, the cloud gets so dark and the sadness feels so ouchy that people just want the ouchy feeling to stop, and they might do something that makes their body stop working forever, because they think it's the only way to make the big sadness go away. It's not because their body is sick with a cough or a fever, but because their brain feels so much pain inside that they can't see a way for the pain to stop.

title: how does sound escape an airtight room?
text: Imagine sound is like a little invisible wiggle! When you clap your hands in a room, you make the air inside wiggle, and those wiggles bump into each other, like a long line of kids playing tag. If the room is super-duper sealed and no air can get out, those air wiggles can't just walk out the door. BUT! The wiggles hit the walls, the floor, and the ceiling! Even though walls are strong, they can wiggle a tiny, tiny bit, just like when you push on a big toy block. These wall-wiggles travel all the way through the solid wall, and when they get to the other side, they start to make the air *outside* wiggle too! And that's how the sound tickles your ears from outside the room, even if the air inside can't escape.

title: Why do we feel relief after we hit or break something when we are mad?
text: Imagine when you get super-duper mad, it's like having a big, bouncy, hot balloon right inside your tummy! It keeps getting bigger and bigger and wants to pop out. When you hit or break something, it feels like you're letting a little bit of air out of that balloon with a big *whoosh*! For a tiny moment, it feels like the balloon isn't so full and about to burst, and that makes your tummy feel a little less squishy and tight. It's like taking a big breath and letting it out. But even though it feels a little better for a second, hitting or breaking things isn't a good way to let the air out because it can hurt things or make a big mess. It's much better to tell a grown-up how you feel, or run around, or draw a picture of your mad balloon instead!

title: How and why do our limbs feel fuzzy when they fall asleep?
text: Okay, imagine your arms and legs have super tiny, invisible phone wires inside them, called nerves, that send messages to your brain about how everything feels. When you sit or lie in a funny

title: - An Air Duct Company is using my cell phone number as "a mask" to call hundreds of people. Im now receiving hundreds of calls from these people. What should I do?
text:
Oh no, that sounds super confusing and not fun at all! Imagine your phone number is like your special name tag. Someone naughty is pretending to wear your name tag and calling lots and lots of people, like a trick! They do this so people will pick up their calls, but the people think *you* called them because they see *your* name tag. So, when those people call back, they're calling *you* because they think you're the one who called them first. It's like someone borrowing your toy without asking and then getting you in trouble for it!

Here's what you need to do:
1.  **Tell a grown-up right away!** Like your mommy, daddy, or whoever takes care of you. This is a grown-up problem, and they are good at fixing grown-up problems.
2.  **Don't answer calls from numbers you don't know.** If your phone rings and you don't recognize the number, you can just let it ring. You don't have to talk to strangers.
3.  Your grown-up will help you. They can talk to the phone company (the people who make your phone work) and tell them about the trick. They might also tell the police, who are like the helpers

title: Whats the difference between Computer Engineers, IT, and Computer Scientists?
text:
Imagine your computer is like a really cool toy house!

A **Computer Engineer** is like the person who builds the toy house itself. They figure out how to put all the little wires, bricks, and blinking lights together so the house stands strong and works properly, with electricity and everything. They make the actual parts of the house.

The **IT person** is like the grown-up who helps you play in the house and keeps it nice. If a light bulb breaks, or you can't find your way to the kitchen, or you want to connect your house to your friend's house next door so you can play together, they come and fix it or show you how. They make sure everything is running smoothly day-to-day.

A **Computer Scientist** is like the person who invents brand new, super cool things *for* the house, or even new kinds of houses! Maybe they figure out how to make a robot butler for your house, or invent a new game you can play inside it, or even design a house that can fly! They think of the big, new ideas and the special rules for how to make them happen.

title: When you have a cold, why do your symptoms feel worse right after you wake up?
text: Imagine your nose is like a little slide for your snot, and when you're lying down flat all night sleeping, the snot doesn't slide out very well. It just sits there and builds up inside your nose and throat, like a little puddle! You also don't swallow as much when you're sleeping, so all that sticky stuff just hangs around. When you first wake up and sit or stand, all that built-up snot suddenly starts to move and slide out because gravity helps, and that's why you feel extra stuffy and need to blow your nose a lot or cough out the yucky stuff. Plus, when you're busy playing during the day, you don't think about it as much, but right when you wake up, you notice everything!

title: Why does every human/household have a specific scent and why is everyone's different?
text: Imagine your body is like a little factory that's always making tiny, invisible smell-bits! These bits come from things like the food you eat, how much you run and play (which makes you sweat a little), and even the super tiny invisible friends (we call them germs, but most are good!) that live on your skin. These smell-bits stick to your clothes and float around your house, mixing with the smells of your yummy dinner, your toys, or even your pet, making a special smell just for your home! Everyone's smell is different because we all eat different foods, have different tiny invisible friends on our skin, use different soaps, and our houses have different things in them and different foods cooking, so all these little things mix together to make a unique smell, just like how your fingerprint is special and only belongs to you!

title: Why does walking on a broken escalator make us feel off balance? Arn't they just stairs?
text: You know how escalators are like super special stairs that move all by themselves to help you go up or down? Your brain gets super used to that feeling, expecting the ground under your feet to gently move you along. But when an escalator is broken, it's like the magic stops! The stairs are still there, but they're not moving anymore. Your brain gets a little tricked because it was all ready for that gentle push, and suddenly it's not there. It's like when you're playing a game and you expect something to happen, but it doesn't, and you go 'Whoa!' for a second. That surprise makes your body feel a little bit wobbly or off-balance, even though they're just regular stairs now. Your brain just needs a little moment to remember that the magic is taking a nap!

title: How do airplanes avoid issues with snow/ice on the runway when taking off or landing?
text: Imagine the runway where airplanes take off and land is like a super long road for them. When it snows, it's like a big, white blanket covering our playground! Airplanes don't like slippery roads, just like we don't like to slip when we run. So, what happens is, big, strong trucks with giant brushes and plows come out, like super-sweepers, and push all the snow away to make the road clear and flat. But sometimes, even after the snow is gone, the road can still be super slippery, like a frozen puddle! So, other special trucks spray a special kind of "magic juice" on the runway. This juice is like a super-salty water that helps melt the ice or stops new ice from forming, so the airplanes don't slip and can go super fast to fly up high, or stop safely when they come back down. Airport helpers work very hard to make sure the runway is always clean and safe for the big airplanes!

title: When a jar won't open, why does hitting it from the bottom, or tapping the lid on the edge of the counter, work to make it easier to open?
text: Imagine the jar lid is like a super-duper strong, invisible hug holding onto the jar really, really tight! Sometimes, the air inside the jar is pulling it down, making that hug extra strong. When you tap the bottom of the jar, it's like giving the jar a little surprise bounce! That bounce makes the invisible hug let go for just a tiny second, letting a little puff of air sneak inside. Once air gets in, the hug isn't so strong anymore, and the lid is easier to twist! Or, sometimes the lid is just super-duper stuck because it's screwed on too tight. Tapping the lid on the counter is like giving it a little wiggle-wiggle. That wiggle helps loosen it up just enough so it's not so sticky and can turn easily. Both ways help break that invisible hold or wiggle it free!

title: What happens if I own stock in a company and that company gets sold (or bought out) by another company?
text: Imagine you have a special toy car (that's your piece of the company, called stock!). One day, a really big toy company that makes robots and airplanes decides they want to buy the company that makes your toy car. So, they come and say, "We want all the toy cars!" They take your special toy car, but don't worry! They give you something else that's usually even better in return: sometimes they give you shiny play money instead, sometimes they give you a super cool robot toy from their own big company, or sometimes a little bit of both! So your old toy car is gone, but you get something new and exciting, and now you're a tiny part of the super big toy company family.

title: Why does string theory require that there be 10 dimensions?
text: Imagine everything in the world is made of super tiny, invisible rubber bands, so small you can't even see them! That's kind of what string theory is about. We know about directions like going up and down, left and right, and forward and backward, right? That's three directions. And time is like another direction, like watching a movie go forward. So we usually think of four directions. But for these special tiny rubber bands to wiggle and jiggle in just the right ways to make all the different things we see in the world, like light, gravity, and even you, they need more space to do their special wiggles. Scientists found that if these little rubber bands have exactly ten different directions they can move and wiggle in, all the math works out perfectly, like a puzzle snapping into place! If there are fewer directions, or more, the puzzle doesn't fit and things break. We don't see the other six directions because they are curled up super, super tiny, so small we can't even tell they're there, like a very thin hair that's actually a super long, curled-up rope if you zoom in enough.

title: How does the United States Treasury Department know how much money to produce, printing notes and stamping coins, each year?
text: Imagine you have a piggy bank, and sometimes your allowance money gets old and crinkly, right? The grown-ups who make our money at the big "money factory" (that's part of the Treasury Department!) don't just guess how much to make. They have special friends called "banks" (like where your parents keep their money) all over the country. These banks tell the money factory when their money is getting too old and yucky and needs to be replaced with fresh, new bills and shiny coins. They also look at how many people are in our country and how much stuff everyone is buying and selling, to make sure there's always enough money for everyone to use without running out, but not so much that it just sits around doing nothing. It's like checking everyone's piggy bank and making sure there's always enough allowance for treats and toys!

title: how come spicy foods make your nose runny? Also, how come cold weather causes the same effect?
text: Okay, imagine your nose is like a helpful little house for your breath! When you eat something super spicy, it has a special feeling, like a playful little tickle or a tiny "ouchy" surprise. Your nose thinks, "Uh oh! Something might be bothering me!" so it sends out a little bit of watery snot to try and wash away that surprise, just in case. It's like your nose trying to clean itself quickly! Now, when it's super cold outside, your nose is also very clever. It wants to make sure the air you breathe is warm and wet before it goes all the way down into your body, like putting a warm, wet blanket on the air. So, when cold, dry air comes in, your nose works extra hard to make lots of watery snot to warm up and wet the air. Sometimes it makes so much, it just drips out! It's just your nose doing its best to be a good helper and keep your insides warm and happy.

title: Why does soda make the spicy feeling worse after eating something hot?
text: Imagine that spicy feeling is like a tiny, invisible hot tickle monster dancing on your tongue. When you drink soda, it's like you're giving that tickle monster a bouncy trampoline! The bubbles in the soda make the tickle monster jump all around your mouth, touching even more spots and making them feel hot too, instead of washing it away. Also, the spicy stuff is kind of oily, and soda is mostly water, and oil and water don't mix very well. So the soda just pushes the spicy tickle monster around instead of picking it up and carrying it off your tongue. That's why milk is better, because it has special helpers that can grab the tickle monster and take it right off!

title: There are definitely exceptions to this, but I was talking to a friend recently and we noticed that the phrases "Momma's boy" and "Daddy's girl" are a lot more common than "Momma's girl" and "Daddy's boy". What makes a child more likely to bond to the parent of the opposite sex?
text: That's a super smart thing to notice! Imagine your mommy and daddy are like two different kinds of yummy treats. Sometimes, a boy might really, really love the special kind of comfy snuggles and gentle talks he gets from his mommy, like she's his softest blanket and best listener. And a girl might really, really love the special kind of fun adventures and big strong hugs she gets from her daddy, like he's her superhero who teaches her to be brave. It's not that they don't love their other parent just as much, but sometimes we learn different kinds of special things from different people. Boys might learn about being strong and brave from their dad, but they also learn about being kind and gentle from their mom. And girls might learn about being kind and gentle from their mom, but they also learn about being brave and having big adventures from their dad. It's like they get to practice being a well-rounded person by getting different kinds of love and lessons from each parent, making them feel super special and understood in different ways!

title: Why do we say that looks aren't important when we actually get attracted more by looks than personality?
text: You know how sometimes you see a super colorful, shiny toy in the store, and you go 'Wow!' and really want to pick it up first?
