title: How does a sound stimulate the brain?
text: Okay, imagine sound is like tiny, invisible wiggles in the air, like when you drop a pebble in water and it makes little ripples! When these wiggles reach your ear, they make a tiny drum inside your ear wiggle too. This wiggling drum then makes some even tinier, super-special hairs inside your ear dance. When these hairs dance, they send a secret, super-fast message, like a little zap of electricity, down a special road straight to your brain. Your brain is like the super-smart boss of your body, and it gets that zap message and instantly knows what the wiggles mean – "Oh, that's your favorite song!" or "That's your mommy talking!" And that's how you hear!

title: How come ancient Greeks, as depicted by their sculptures, were so heavily muscled despite not having optimal knowledge about nutrition and training by today's standards?
text: Imagine you're drawing your favorite superhero! You'd make them super strong and big, right? Well, the ancient Greeks wanted their gods and heroes to look super perfect and powerful too, like the best version of a person, even if real people didn't *always* look exactly like that. They wanted to show how important it was to be strong and healthy. And even without big gyms or special food like we have today, people back then were still very active! They walked everywhere, carried heavy things, farmed, built stuff, and played lots of running and throwing games all day long. All that moving around and working made them strong and fit, like how you get strong from playing and running around a lot! They ate simple, healthy foods too, like fruits, vegetables, and meat, which helped them grow big and strong. So the statues were showing what they thought was the most beautiful and strongest way a person could look, and people back then *were* quite strong from all their daily activities.

title: why is "night vision" green?
text: Imagine it's super dark, and you can't see your favorite toy. Night vision glasses are like magic glasses that help you see in the dark! They make everything look green because your eyes are really, really good at seeing the color green, even when there's just a tiny, tiny bit of light around. It's like green is the easiest color for your eyes to find and understand in the dark, so the night vision glasses pick green to make sure you can see everything clearly without making your eyes tired or hurting them.

title: What happens when you recycle something that isn't recyclable?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special toy box just for your clean, hard plastic blocks that can be melted down and made into new blocks! That's like recycling. Now, what if you accidentally put a squishy banana peel or a dirty sock in that block box? When the box goes to the big toy factory, the banana peel isn't a block and can't be melted down. It might get all squished and sticky, making the *other* good, clean blocks dirty, or even get stuck in the block-making machine! Sometimes, if there are too many banana peels or dirty socks, the people at the factory have to throw *all* the blocks away, even the good ones, because it's too hard to clean them all up. So, that banana peel and sometimes even the good blocks end up going to the regular trash instead of becoming something new, and it makes extra work for everyone! That's why it's super important to only put the right, clean things in the recycling bin.

title: Why do smoothies and drinks at juice bars cost so much?
text: Imagine you want a super yummy smoothie with lots of different colorful fruits like strawberries, bananas, and maybe even some spinach! Well, all those fresh fruits and veggies cost money at the store, especially when they're super good for you. Then, someone has to carefully wash them, chop them all up, put them in a big noisy blender, and make it just right for you. That person needs to get paid for their hard work, like when your grown-ups work. Plus, the smoothie shop needs money to keep the lights on, keep the blenders working, and have a nice clean spot for you to get your drink. So, because someone else does all the chopping and blending and cleaning up for you, it costs a little bit more than if you made it all by yourself at home!

title: How did America manage to amass so much power so quickly?
text: Imagine America is like a kid who grew up super fast and became really strong and good at everything! First, America had a *really* big backyard with lots of good dirt for growing food, lots of trees for building, and lots of special rocks and oil for making machines work. Then, lots and lots of people from all over the world came to America because they wanted a safe place to live and work hard, like when all your friends come over to help you build a giant sandcastle – many hands make big jobs easy! While other grown-up countries were sometimes having big fights in their own backyards far away, America mostly stayed safe and could keep building and making new things without getting its toys broken. People in America also had lots of super smart ideas for new inventions and new ways to make things faster and better. So, by having lots of good stuff, lots of helpful people, staying safe, and having smart ideas, America got really big and powerful super quickly!

title: How can fish be frozen, then be fully animated after thawing? Could this mechanism work with other large organisms?
text: Imagine some super special fish are like toys with a magical pause button! When it gets super duper cold, their bodies slow down almost to a stop, like they're taking a very long, cold nap. They have special tricks, like their blood has a tiny bit of anti-freeze in it, so not *all* of them turns into hard ice like a normal ice cube. Just a little bit might freeze, but the super important parts, like their brain and heart, stay safe or just go super, super slow. When it gets warm again, it's like someone pressing 'play,' and they wake up and swim away! But this doesn't work for big animals like us, or dogs, or elephants! Our bodies are like delicate houses, and if we froze, the water inside us would turn into sharp ice crystals, like tiny, pointy swords that would poke holes in everything important inside us. We don't have that special anti-freeze, so we'd get really hurt and couldn't wake up. Only a few very special tiny animals and some insects have a similar trick, but not big ones like us!

title: Why do people with psychosis go through cycles where sometimes they are OK and then they have a psychotic episode?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super important control room in your head, helping you see, hear, think, and feel everything. Most of the time, it works perfectly! But for some people, their brain's control room can sometimes get a little bit mixed up, like when a TV signal gets fuzzy. When it's fuzzy, that's a 'psychotic episode' – things might seem strange or confusing. But then, with help like special 'brain medicine' or by getting lots of rest and staying calm, the control room can get clearer again, and they feel much better, like the TV picture is perfect again! They might be okay for a long time. But sometimes, if they get super tired, or very worried, or forget their brain medicine, the control room might get a little fuzzy again for a while. It's like a wave, sometimes clear, sometimes fuzzy, and it's not their fault when it gets fuzzy again, but with help, it can often get clear once more.

title: If I see a face/thing that I am very familiar with (family member etc.) and then "study it", it can suddenly look weird or unfamiliar. What is this and is it common?
text: You know how sometimes you look at mommy's face for a long, long time, and then suddenly it looks a little bit funny or not quite like mommy? That's because your super-smart brain is usually busy looking for new things, like a squirrel running or a colorful toy! But when you stare at the *same* thing for a very long time, your brain gets a little bit tired of looking at the exact same picture. It's like when you say the same word, like 'apple,' over and over and over again. After a while, 'apple' starts to sound a little silly, right? Your brain does something similar with faces – it just takes a little break from seeing it the 'normal' way, and makes it look a tiny bit different for a moment. It's not *really* different, just your brain playing a little trick because it's been working so hard looking at the same thing! And guess what? Lots and lots of people feel this too! It's a very normal thing that happens to almost everyone.

title: What causes secondhand embarrassment?
text: Imagine your friend is trying to sing their favorite song really loud, but they forget the words and accidentally make a funny squeaky noise instead! They might feel a little "oopsie!" feeling inside, right? That's being embarrassed. Now, sometimes, when *you* see someone else do something silly or make a mistake like that, even *you* can feel a little bit of that "oopsie!" feeling too, even though *you* didn't make the noise! It's like your brain is pretending it happened to you for just a tiny second, or you just feel a little bit bad for your friend because you know how they must feel. It's like your heart is giving them a little hug because you understand it can be a bit yucky to feel embarrassed, and you don't want them to feel bad. So, your brain just goes "whoa!" for a moment, even though you're perfectly fine!

title: When rolling a ball on a flat surface, it produces a rolling noise (eg. Going bowling). What is actually causing this noise? Being a sphere, there isn't really an 'impact' while its rolling for the noise to be produced is there?
text: Imagine the floor and the ball are super, super smooth, but if you looked super close, they actually have tiny, tiny bumps, like a road with little pebbles. When the ball rolls, these tiny bumps on the ball rub against the tiny bumps on the floor really fast. Every time they rub, it makes the ball and the floor jiggle just a tiny, tiny bit. It's like when you rub your hands together really fast, you can hear a sound! These tiny jiggles are what make the air around them jiggle too, and that's the rolling sound you hear. So it's not one big *bonk*, but lots and lots of super tiny little rubs and jiggles happening all the time as the ball rolls along!

title: How come when you wake up your bed feels entirely more comfortable than when you initially try to go to sleep (or even throughout the night while you're sleeping)?
text: Imagine your body is like a toy that's been playing all day long and is super tired! When you first get into bed, your body is still a little bit awake and thinking about all the fun things you did, so it just feels like a regular, nice bed. But then, all night long, your bed is giving your body a big, soft hug and helping it rest and get strong again. So, when you wake up, your body feels super happy and relaxed because it had such a good, long rest! It's like your bed is saying, "Good job resting! Stay here for just one more cozy minute before you have to go play again!" You don't notice how comfy it is while you're sleeping because you're busy having dreams, but your bed is working hard to keep you comfy the whole time!

title: Why is the cure for the common cold so hard to find?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool playground, and sometimes tiny, invisible little troublemakers come to play and make you feel sniffly or coughy. The tricky thing is, there isn't just ONE kind of troublemaker that causes a cold – there are HUNDREDS of different kinds, like a giant box full of different toy monsters! If we made a magic spray to get rid of the red monster, it wouldn't work on the blue monster or the green monster. And these little troublemakers also like to change their outfits a little bit every year, so even if we made a spray for the red monster this year, it might not work on next year's red monster because he's wearing a different hat! Because there are so many different kinds and they keep changing, it's super hard to make just one special medicine that can catch all of them. Instead, medicines help you feel better and more comfy while your body's own superheroes fight off those tiny troublemakers by themselves.

title: If deep freezing only puts bacteria to sleep rather than killing them, then why does deep freezing sushi/sashimi fish makes them safe to consume raw?
text: Imagine a fish is like a big house, and sometimes, yucky little squiggly worms, like tiny, tiny snakes, can live inside the fish house. If we eat the fish raw, these worms might try to live in *our* tummy house, and that would make us feel very sick! Freezing is like making the fish house super, super cold, like a giant ice cube. This super cold makes the squiggly worms freeze solid and they can't live anymore, so they're gone! That's why it's safe to eat the fish raw after it's been frozen. You're right that tiny, tiny things called bacteria just go to sleep when it's cold, but for sushi fish, the super cold is mostly to get rid of those yucky worms, not just the sleepy bacteria.

title: When we say we've "mapped the human genome", what exactly does this mean?
text: Imagine your body is like a super special toy, and inside every part of you, there's a tiny, tiny instruction book that tells you exactly how to be *you*. This whole big instruction book for *you* is called your "genome." It has all the secrets for how to make your eyes blue, your hair curly, and even how your heart beats! Each little instruction on a page is called a "gene." When grown-ups say they "mapped the human genome," it means they looked at *every single page* in that super special instruction book. They figured out what order all the pages go in, and what each instruction says, from the very beginning to the very end. It's like they made a giant, super long list, or a treasure map, of *all* the instructions for building a human! This helps them understand how our bodies work and how to help us when we get sick.

title: Why is there so much got damn static electricity in the winter?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big sponge, and when you rub your feet on the carpet or touch things, you pick up tiny, invisible sticky bits. In the summer, the air has lots of water in it, like a misty cloud, and that water helps those sticky bits just slide right off you, so they don't build up. But in winter, the air is super, super dry, like a desert! Because the air is so dry, those sticky bits can't easily slip away from you. So, they pile up and pile up on you until they find somewhere else to jump, like a doorknob or your friend, and *ZAP!* you get a little surprise!

title: Why sometimes people have a single hiccup and at other times a never-ending series of hiccups?
text: Imagine you have a special muscle inside you, right under your lungs, that helps you breathe, like a trampoline that goes up and down. Sometimes, this muscle gets a little surprised or tickled, maybe because you ate too fast or laughed a lot! When it gets surprised just a tiny bit, it makes one quick "hic!" sound, and then it's all better, like a small sneeze. But other times, it gets really, really surprised or tickled, and it keeps jumping down over and over again, making "hic! hic! hic!" for a longer time, like when you can't stop giggling after someone tickles you a lot. Your body just needs a little while to tell that muscle to calm down and go back to its normal breathing job.

title: basic rules of Dungeons and Dragons?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends are playing make-believe, just like when you pretend to be a superhero or a princess! One friend is like the "storyteller" who makes up all the cool monsters, magic, and places you visit. Everyone else gets to pretend they are a special hero in that story, like a brave knight or a sneaky rogue or a powerful wizard. You tell the storyteller what your hero wants to do, like "I want to try and open that big, scary door!" Sometimes, you roll special dice with lots of sides to see if your hero is good enough to do that thing, like if they're strong enough to open the door or clever enough to pick a lock. The storyteller then tells you what happens next based on what you do and what the dice say, and you keep playing and making up your adventure together! It's all about using your imagination to go on amazing quests.

title: Why do some people get sick so often and I get sick only about twice a year?
text: Imagine that inside your body, and everyone else's body, there are super tiny invisible "yucky bugs" called germs that sometimes try to sneak in and make you feel sleepy or sniffly. But don't worry! Your body also has amazing "superheroes" that fight off these yucky bugs! Sometimes, some people get sick more often because maybe they are around more of these yucky bugs, like if they have lots of brothers and

title: ; if the human body requires calories (from food) for energy, how do energy pills like ProPlus and other caffeine and energy pills work if they're not providing us with calories?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a little car that needs special gas to go vroom! That special gas is called calories, and you get it from yummy food. When you eat, it fills up your gas tank, and that's how you get energy to run and play. Now, energy pills are not gas. They don't put more gas in your car. Instead, they're like a little friendly alarm clock that goes off inside your brain! When your body starts to feel sleepy or tired, it's like your car's "low gas" light is coming on. The energy pill just makes your brain think, "WAKE UP! Keep going!" It doesn't give you new energy, it just makes you *feel* like you have more because it tells your body to ignore the sleepy signals for a little while. So, food gives you real energy, like putting gas in the car, but energy pills just trick your body into *feeling* less tired, like a little wake-up call, but they don't give you new fuel!

title: how are english speaking kids taught to read?
text: Imagine letters are like little secret codes! First, grown-ups teach you about all the different letter shapes, like 'A' and 'B'. Then, they show you that each letter makes a special sound, like 'm' says /mmm/ and 'a' says /aaa/. They help you squish those sounds together, so 'm-a-p' turns into 'map'! Sometimes, there are special words you just learn to know right away when you see them, like 'the' or 'is', because they're a bit tricky. You also look at the pictures in books to help you guess what words might be, and you learn what the story is about. The more you practice reading little books and sounding out words, the better your brain gets at making sense of all the letters, and soon you'll be reading all by yourself!

title: What is the difference between sound, light and electromagnetic waves and how do they coexist without scrambling each other ?

It needs air or water to wiggle through, like a boat needs water to float. Light is super different! It's like tiny, super-fast invisible waves that don't need

title: Why do we, as humans, mostly stop crying from pain at a certain age? Usually around puberty.
text: When you're a tiny baby, crying is like your only special superpower to tell grown-ups everything! If you're hungry, you cry. If you're sleepy, you cry. If your tummy hurts, you cry! It's how they know what you need. But as you get bigger, like a big kid, your brain grows super smart! You learn how to use your words to say "ouch!" or "I'm sad!" or "I need a hug!" Your brain also learns to be a little bit stronger when things hurt, like when you bump your knee, it still hurts, but your brain remembers that it will get better. And you see big people don't always cry for every little ouchie, so you learn to be super brave too! So while it's still okay to cry sometimes when you're really, really sad or hurt, you just have lots of other ways to show how you feel now that you're a big kid!

title: Why do some customer support numbers say "except for Panama"?
text: Okay, imagine a big company has a special magic phone line that goes to lots and lots of houses all over the world, so people can call them. But some houses, like the ones in a country called Panama, have a super-duper special kind of door that the magic phone line can't easily open, or it costs a lot more magic dust to make it work just for them. So, instead of making everyone pay extra for that super-duper special door, or because it's just too tricky to connect, the company says, "If you live in Panama, please don't use this magic phone line! Please use our secret handshake (like a website) or a different special number to talk to us, because our main magic line doesn't quite reach your special house easily." It just means their

title: Why can't an operating system contain kernels from multiple operating systems, allowing programs from either OS to run?
text: Imagine your computer is like a big playground. The 'operating system' is like all the rules for playing on that playground – how to use the swings, how to share the slide, and what games

title: what happened in Dunkirk?
text: Imagine a very long time ago, there were lots and lots of soldiers, like grown-up superheroes, but they were stuck! They were on a big beach by the sea in a place called Dunkirk, and they couldn't get home because some not-so-friendly people were trying to stop them, and they were running out of time. It was a very scary situation. But then, something amazing happened! Lots and lots of boats, not just big army boats, but also little fishing boats, and even tiny boats like the ones your grandpa might have, all came across the sea from their home country. They were like a big parade of helpers! Everyone worked together, like a giant team, to pick up the soldiers from the beach and take them safely across the water, all the way back home. It was a super brave and clever plan to save almost everyone, even though it was very, very hard. They were rescued!

title: What does it mean when physicists say the universe is "flat"?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super, super big piece of paper that goes on forever and ever, much bigger than your living room! If you draw two perfectly straight lines next to each other on that

title: How can locks/padlocks be mass produced whilst still being unlockable only by their individual key?
text:
Okay, imagine your lock is like a secret house for tiny, tiny people called "pins." These pins are all different heights, like a bunch of friends standing on different steps inside the lock. Your key is like a special bumpy road with hills and valleys that matches *just* the right steps for *those specific* tiny people. When you put your key in, it lifts all the tiny people to the perfect height so they make a flat line, and then the lock can open!

When they make lots and lots of locks in the factory, they have a big basket full of tiny people (pins) of all different heights. For each new lock, they just grab a different mix of these tiny people and put them inside. Then, for each lock, they make a key that has the *exact* right bumps and dips on its road to lift *those specific* tiny people to the right spots. So, even though they make tons of locks, each one gets its own special set of tiny people inside and its own special key-road to make them happy and open the lock!

title: How does the black line on debit/credit cards work?
text: You know how sometimes you draw a secret picture, and only your best friend knows what it means? The black line on your card is a bit like that! It has a secret message, but instead of a picture, it's made of tiny, tiny magnets. This message holds your special card number, like your secret code. When you slide your card into a machine, the machine is super smart and can read all those tiny magnet messages really fast! It then sends that secret code to the bank to ask, "Is it okay for this person to use their money?" If the bank says yes, then you get to buy your yummy snack! It's like a tiny, secret messenger that helps you pay for things.

title: Does climate change lead to an increase in extreme cold weather as well as extreme warm weather? If so, why is the average yearly temperature continuing to get warmer?
text: Yes, that's a super smart question! Imagine our Earth is like a big house, and climate change is making the house's air conditioner and heater go a little bit crazy. So, sometimes it gets super-duper hot, like when the sun is extra strong and you need lots of water and ice cream. That's the extreme warm weather. But sometimes, it also gets super-duper cold! Think of it like this: way up north, where Santa lives, it's always, always freezing cold. Usually, there's like an invisible fence that keeps all that super cold air way up there. But when the Earth's weather gets all mixed up because of climate change, that invisible fence can get a little wobbly and broken sometimes. When it wiggles, some of that super-duper cold air from

title: How come some countries go from million to billion when counting, while other countries have an additional step?
text: Imagine you have lots and lots of LEGO bricks! A **million** is like having a super big tower of LEGOs. Now, some grown-ups (in some countries, like America) say: "If we make *one thousand* of those super big towers, we'll call that a **billion**!" So, a billion is 1000 super big towers. But other grown-ups (in other countries, like France) say: "No, no! If we make *one thousand* of those super big towers, we'll call that a **milliard**! And *then*, if we make a *thousand* of those **milliards**, *then* we'll call *that* a **billion**!" It's like they just have different names for some of the really, really big piles of LEGOs, even though the piles themselves are the same size. It's just different ways of saying the big numbers out loud, like how some people call a yummy sweet treat "candy" and others call it "lolly." Both are delicious, just different names!

title: Why are Hawaiians and other pacific islanders so much more prone to obesity than other people?
text: Imagine your body is like a super special piggy bank! A long, long time ago, people in Hawaii and other islands lived in a way where sometimes there was lots of food, and sometimes there wasn't much at all. So, their bodies learned to be super good at saving up energy from food whenever they got it, just like putting extra coins in your piggy bank for later. This helped them stay strong and healthy when food was scarce. But now, there's yummy food everywhere, all the time, and sometimes it's super sweet or has lots of fat, and people don't run and play as much as they used to. Because their bodies are still so good at saving energy, that extra food quickly fills up their "piggy bank" too much, making them bigger than other people whose bodies weren't built to save energy quite as well. It's not their fault; their bodies are just really good at something that was helpful a long time ago, but now it makes it easier to get too big with all the new kinds of food and less moving around.

title: Why do some foods taste much better hot, while others taste much better cold?
text: Okay, imagine your mouth and nose are like best friends who work together to figure out what you're eating! When some foods are hot, like a warm cookie or yummy soup, they send out lots of happy smells that fly up to your nose, and that makes your tongue say 'YUM!' Heat also makes some foods feel super soft and cozy in your mouth, which is just right for them. But then, other foods, like ice cream or a crunchy apple, are like little cool surprises! When they're cold, they feel super refreshing and make your mouth feel happy in a different way, especially when it's sunny outside. Cold also helps some foods stay nice and firm or extra sweet, which is how they like to be best. So, it's just like how some toys are fun to play with inside, and others are super fun to play with outside – different foods just like to show off their best yummy tricks at different temperatures!

title: How do certain parts of the world have so many undetonated landmines?
text: Imagine a very, very long time ago, like when your grandparents were little, there were big grown-up fights called wars. During these fights, some grown-ups put special, dangerous "toys" called landmines in the ground. These toys are like little sleepy bombs that wait for someone to step on them. When the big fight was finally over and everyone went home, a lot of these dangerous toys were still hiding in the dirt. Nobody picked them all up because there were so many, and they were very good at hiding, and it's super tricky and slow to find them all without getting hurt. So, in some places where those big fights happened, these sleepy, dangerous toys are still there, waiting, and that's why people have to be very careful when they play or walk in those places, even now.

title: My Mum hates it if I spend a few hours gaming, yet if I watch TV for the same amount of time, so doesn't mind. Myis this; how is gaming worse for you than watching TV?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is a little superhero! When you watch TV, your superhero brain is mostly relaxing, just watching the show and chilling out. But when you play games, your superhero brain is zooming around super fast, making quick decisions, pressing buttons, and solving puzzles! It's super fun, but it makes your brain work really, really hard for a long time. When your brain works that hard, it can get super tired, just like when you run around outside a lot. Your Mum just wants your brain to have different kinds of fun and rests, like building towers, drawing pictures, or playing outside, so it doesn't get too tired and can stay super strong for all the different adventures you have!

title: Tesla released all its patent on their car in 2014 so that anyone can use them. Why isn't there any other Car Co. using them ATM?
text: Imagine Tesla made a super cool toy car and then drew all the pictures of how they made it, like a secret recipe book, and said, "Hey everyone, you can look at my recipe book for free!" But other toy car companies already have *their own* ways of making cars. It's like they have their *own* favorite recipes that they've been using for a long, long time! It would be super, super hard and cost a lot of money for them to stop making their cars their way and start making them exactly like Tesla's, even if they have the recipe for free. Plus, Tesla's recipe might need special ingredients or special machines that other companies don't have, or they just like their own toys better. So they keep making their own cool cars in their own special way, even if they peek at Tesla's book sometimes for a tiny idea!

title: Why are younger children so picky about the foods that they eat?
text: Well, imagine seeing a brand new toy you've never seen before. Sometimes it's exciting, but sometimes you're not quite sure about it, right? Food can be like that too! Your tongue also has super-duper strong taste buds, way stronger than grown-ups', so some foods taste really, really strong to you, even if they don't taste that strong to us. Plus, your tummy is still pretty small, like a little balloon, so it gets full much faster than a grown-up's big balloon tummy. And sometimes, you just want to choose for yourself, like picking your favorite book, and choosing what you eat is one way you can do that! It's okay, your body is just figuring out what it

title: If text messages are encrypted, how can government agencies access them?
text: Okay, so your text message is like a super-secret note you put inside a special locked box before sending it to your friend. Only your friend has the magic key to open *their

title: If I had $10 trillion and wanted to pay off the U.S.'s national debt, whom do i pay?
text: Okay, imagine the U.S. government is like a super big grown-up who needed to borrow money to build roads, schools, and buy lots of important things for everyone. They didn

title: What would a videogame look like if you could see the world as it was loading?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing with your toy cars on the carpet, but the carpet isn't all there yet! As you push your car forward, *poof*, more carpet magically unrolls right in front of you. Sometimes, a toy car might just *pop* into existence right next to you, or a tree might suddenly grow out of the floor! Things far away might look like big, simple blocks, and then as you get closer, they suddenly get all detailed with windows and doors. It would be like the world is building itself around you, piece by piece, as you explore, with things appearing, getting clearer, and sometimes just popping up out of nowhere!

title: How does alcohol negate consent when the same argument can be used when to defend serious criminal offences when intoxicated?

title: Why is China so capitalist when the country is one of most well known communist states on Earth?
text: Imagine China is like a really, really big family, and a long, long time ago, the grown-ups in charge said, "Okay everyone, we're all going to share *everything*! All the toys, all the food, all the clothes. No one gets to have their own special stuff, the grown-ups will decide what everyone gets, and we'll all work together." That's kind of like communism. But then, they noticed that even though they were sharing, there weren't enough cool toys or yummy snacks for everyone, and sometimes things didn't get made very well. So, the grown-ups had

title: What does "Right-to-Work" mean?
text: Imagine you have a special playground where all the kids play with toys together. Sometimes, the grown-ups make a special club for all the kids who play there, called a "union," to help everyone share toys nicely and make sure playtime is fair. In some places, if you want to play on that playground and use the toys (that's like having a job), you *have* to join that club or at least give them a little bit of your candy for helping. But "Right-to-Work" means that even if there's a club for the kids who play with toys, you *don't* have to join it or give them your candy if you don't want to. You can still play with the toys and have your spot on the playground, all by yourself, without being part of the club. It means you have the right to work without being forced to join or pay a club.

title: Whats that called at the end of a commercial where the guy talks really fast about warnings and stuff?
text: You know how sometimes at the very end of a commercial, a grown-up talks super duper fast, like a race car? Vroom vroom! They do that because there are special grown-up rules that say if they're selling something, like a toy or medicine, they *have* to tell you all the tiny, important things, even if they're a bit boring, like 'don't eat the toy!' or 'ask your mommy first.' It's called a 'disclaimer' or sometimes 'legal jargon,' and it's like they're quickly reading the 'rules list' for the grown-ups so everyone knows all the important stuff, but they don't want to take up too much time from the fun part of the commercial!

title: Where does fear come from and why do different people fear different things?
text: Imagine your brain has a special little alarm inside, like the one on your toy car! This alarm's job is to keep you safe and make sure you don't get hurt. When your brain thinks something might be dangerous, like a big, growly dog or a super high slide, it rings that alarm, and that's what fear is! It's your brain saying, 'Woah, be careful!' Now, why do some kids think spiders are yucky and other kids think they're cool? Well, your brain learns things from what happens to you. If a dog once barked really loud and scared you, your brain might remember that and ring the alarm bell every time you see a dog. But if your friend only ever saw friendly, wagging-tail dogs, their brain learned dogs are fun! We also learn from our grown-ups; if mommy jumps when she sees a spider, your brain might learn to think spiders are scary too. So, everyone's brain learns different things from their own games and adventures, which makes their little safety alarm ring for different stuff!

title: Are food products that say "consume within 7-10 days after opening" basicslly a food poisoning gamble after day 7?
text: Imagine your food is like a party, and when it's fresh, it's a super fun party! But then tiny, tiny invisible guests called 'germs' start coming, and they love to eat your food too. The longer the party goes, the more germs come, and some of them aren't very nice and can make your tummy feel yucky. The 'eat within 7-10 days' rule is like a grown-up saying, 'After about 7-10 days, there might be too many not-nice germs at the party, and it's much more likely you'll get a tummy ache if you eat it.' It's not like a magic switch where on day 8 you *will* get sick, but it's like playing a game where the chances of getting a little sick monster in your tummy go way, way up after that time. So, to keep your tummy happy, it's best to finish the food before the germ party gets too big!

title: How is temperature measured and considered to exist in space?
text: Imagine you have a yummy ice cream and it's cold, right? And a warm cookie is warm. In space, it's a little tricky because there's almost no air for us

title: What is a memory?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super special photo album or a movie theater inside your head! Every time you see something cool, like a puppy, or hear a funny song, or learn how to draw a star, your brain takes a tiny picture or makes a little movie of it and puts it in that special album. That tiny picture or movie is a memory! Later, when you want to remember what a puppy looks like, or how to draw that star, your brain opens the right page in your album or plays the little movie, and poof! You remember. It's how you keep all your favorite moments and important things in your head, ready to look at again whenever you want.

title: . I heard that you burn quite a few calories when you orgasm. Is this true? How or what is burning all those calories? If say someone started masturbating/having sex multiple times a day would they lose weight?
text: Yes, when your body gets super excited and has that special happy feeling, your body *does* work! It's like when you run around or jump up and down. Your heart beats

title: Do cell phone companies limit/throttle data because there actually is a bandwidth shortage, or is it a cash grab?
text: Okay, imagine your internet is like a super fun slide at the park! Lots and lots of kids (that's your games, videos, and messages) want to go down the slide.

title: Why are bulletproof vests not reusable?
text: Imagine your special vest is made of many, many super strong, secret blankets all stacked up. When a super speedy zoomy thing (a bullet) tries to get you, these blankets work super hard to catch it! They stretch and pull and get all squishy and tired to stop the zoomy thing from hurting you. It's like when you pull a string really hard until it

title: Why can you become "blackout drunk"? Why can't you remember anything after?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super special camera that records everything you see and do, making it into memories you can look at later. When someone drinks too much yucky grown-up drink called alcohol, it's like that drink makes your special camera really, really foggy and blurry. Sometimes, if there's way too much fog, the camera just stops recording altogether for a little while! It's still on, and you're still walking around and talking, but it's not saving anything to your memory album. So, later, when the fog clears and the camera starts recording again, you can't find those missing pictures because they were never saved in the first place! That's why you can't remember what happened – your brain just didn't write it down. It's not a good thing to make your brain's camera stop working like that, so grown-ups try to be careful.

title: why we can't just siphon the excess CO2 causing global warming out of our atmosphere and into space?
text: Imagine the air around us, the stuff we breathe, has a tiny bit of invisible 'warm-up' gas called CO2, like a sprinkle of sugar in your milk. Now, imagine there's way, way too much sugar in the milk, making it too sweet (or in our case, making the Earth too warm). You want to take all that extra sugar out. First, it's not like a puddle you can just scoop up; it's mixed everywhere in the air, all over the world! Second, space is super, super far away – much, much further than the moon! To send even a tiny bit of air there, we need a giant, super-fast rocket, like the ones that go to the moon. Building and fueling just one of those rockets costs tons and tons of money and uses a lot of energy. To send ALL the extra CO2, which is everywhere around our whole big planet,

title: Why does shaking hard-boiled eggs in water make them peel so easily?
text: Imagine your egg has a hard house (that's the shell!) and a super thin, papery blanket right under it. When you cook the egg, the yummy inside gets a little bit smaller and pulls away from its blanket. Then, when you put it in cold water, it shrinks even more, making a tiny space. Now, when you shake it, you're breaking the hard house into lots of little pieces, and the water is like a super helper! The water sneaks into all those tiny cracks and gets *under* the hard house and *under* the papery blanket. It fills up those little spaces and helps push the blanket and the shell away from the yummy egg inside, making them slide off super, super easily, almost like magic!

title: If it takes two days for food to eventually be pooped out, why do some foods make me instantly have to go?
text: Okay, imagine your food takes a super long trip inside your body, like a little car driving for two whole days! It has to go all the way from your mouth to your tummy, then through long, twisty roads until it comes out as poop. Now, your tummy and those twisty roads are usually already full of other food cars making their journey. When you eat new food, it's like putting a *new* car at the very *start* of the road. This new car doesn't magically zoom to the end right away! Instead, it gives a little gentle push to *all the cars already on the road*. If there was an *old* food car already super close to the end, that little push from your new

title: Why do people still think the earth is flat?
text: Okay, imagine you're standing on a super, super big pancake! It looks flat, right? Even though you know a pancake is round, when you're standing on it, all you see is flat. Well, some grown-ups look out at the world and because it looks flat to their eyes, like a giant playground, they think it *is* flat. They might also hear other grown-ups say it's flat, and they choose to believe those people instead of the pictures from space or the people who fly planes all around the world and see it's really a giant ball, like a yummy orange! So, mostly, it's because it looks flat from where we stand, and they listen to other grown-ups who agree with them.

title: Why does room temperature not feel very cold to our bodies?
text: Imagine your body is like a warm, cozy little house inside, and it likes to be a certain temperature, not too hot and not too cold. Room temperature is usually just right, like a perfect comfy hug for your house! When it's super, super cold outside, your body house has to work extra hard to make more warmth and keep you toasty. When it's super, super hot, it has to work extra hard to cool you down. But at room temperature, your body house doesn't have to work hard at all because it's already a good temperature for you, so it just feels normal and happy, not cold!

title: How do airlines outside of the United States provide such a great experience at a lower cost than those in the U.S.?
text: Imagine your friend got a really cool, yummy ice cream cone with sprinkles and didn't have to pay as much for it as your plain one! It's a bit like that with planes. Sometimes, the grown-ups who run the whole country (we call them the government) really want their plane companies to be super good, so they give them special money or help to make sure they have nice planes and give you yummy food. Also, the people who work on the plane, like the pilots and the people who give you drinks, might not need as much money for their jobs in some other countries compared to here, so

title: Why are babies seemingly unfazed by vomiting as compared to someone older?
text: Well, imagine your tummy is like a little balloon, and sometimes babies drink a lot of milk! Their tummies are still very new, and sometimes the milk just comes back up, like when you burp really big. For tiny babies, it happens quite often, so it's not a big, surprising, or scary thing for them. They don't really remember that it can feel yucky or that it makes a mess like older kids and grown-ups do. When we throw up, it usually means our tummy feels really, really bad *before* it happens, and we remember that feeling isn't nice! But for babies, it's often just a little oopsie from their body, and then they're ready to smile and play again like nothing happened because they don't know it's supposed to be a big deal.

title: How does the Metal Grate on a Microwave Oven Keep all of the Microwaves in?
text: Okay, imagine the microwave oven makes special, invisible 'magic waves' that warm up your food. These waves are super, super tiny! Now, the metal grate on the door is like a special fence with lots of tiny, tiny holes. Think of the magic waves as little bouncy balls. The holes in the fence are much, much smaller than the bouncy balls, so the bouncy balls can't squeeze through them! They just bounce right back inside the oven. But light, which lets you see your food, is even tinier than the magic waves, so it *can* wiggle through the tiny holes, letting you watch your yummy snack get warm while keeping all the bigger magic waves safely inside the box.

title: What causes the reaction our faces have when we eat sour things like lemons?
text: Okay, imagine your mouth has tiny little taste detectors, like little helpers! When you eat something super sour, like a lemon, those helpers taste something that's a little bit *too* strong and zippy for them. It's like a tiny alarm bell goes off in your mouth! Your super smart brain gets this alarm and thinks, "Whoa! That's a powerful taste! Let's make a funny face to show everyone it's super sour, or maybe even tell ourselves to be careful and not eat too much of it!" So your face just automatically squishes up, like it's saying "Pucker up!" or "That's intense!" It's just your body's fast way of reacting to something really zippy and strong to protect you and tell others about it.

title: What is the difference between a director's cut and an unrated cut?
text:
Okay, imagine a movie is like a big storybook!

A **director's cut** is when the person who *made* the storybook (the director) gets to show it

title: What really happens when bread, cookies, chips, and other similar foods go "stale"?
text: Imagine your yummy bread is like a cozy home for tiny water drops. When you leave it out, those water drops get bored and sneak away into the air. Without their water friends, the bread gets all squished together and hard, like a dried-up sponge, and not bouncy anymore. Now, for crunchy things like chips, it's the opposite! They are super dry and crunchy because they don't have much water inside. But the air around us has tiny, invisible water bits floating in it. So when chips sit out, they get thirsty and drink up those tiny water bits from the air, making them soft and bendy instead of super loud and crunchy. It's just water moving in or out of your food, changing how it feels!

title: How is it that cannabis has so many different 'strains' which change the appearance and other characteristics of a particular plant? Do other plants share similar significant genetic variations?
text: Imagine you have a big box of crayons, right? All of them are crayons, but some are red, some are blue, some are long, some are short. Cannabis is kind of like that! People who grow cannabis are super good at choosing which 'parent' plants to have babies. They look for plants that make you feel a certain way – maybe sleepy, maybe giggly – or plants that smell a special way, or even plants that look a little different, like having purple leaves! They carefully pick the seeds from those special parents, and when they plant them, they get a new 'strain' that's a bit different, like getting a new color crayon. It's like having different kinds of apples – some are red and sweet, some are green and sour, but they're all apples! Yes, lots of other plants do this too! Think about all the different kinds of roses, some are red, some are white, some are big, some are small. Or all the different kinds of tomatoes you can find, big ones, little ones, red ones, yellow ones. Farmers and gardeners do a similar thing, picking special seeds to grow plants that give us yummy food or pretty flowers, just like choosing the best ingredients for a special cookie recipe!

title: I've heard you can't "catch up" on lost sleep. Does this mean I'm going to keep adding to the mountain of exhaustion that is my life until my dying day?
text: Imagine your body is like a little toy car, and sleep is like putting batteries in it. If you forget to put batteries in for a whole day, the car just sits there, right? Putting *extra* batteries in the *next* day makes the car run great *that* day, but it doesn't make up for the day it sat still. You can't go back in time to put those batteries in! That's a bit like lost sleep – you can't ever perfectly get back *all* the sleep you missed from a long time ago. BUT! This doesn't mean you'll be tired forever and ever! If your car is super slow because it only had a little bit of battery, putting in *new, full* batteries will make it zoom around and feel super strong and happy again! It's the same with your body. Even if you can't perfectly "catch up

title: What stops pharmaceutical companies from slightly tweaking competitors medicines and selling them as their own?
text: Imagine someone invents a brand new, super helpful medicine, like a special candy that stops your tummy ache! When they invent it, they get a special "no copying" rule, like a magic

title: What is preventing blue states from enacting single-payer/universal healthcare?
text: Imagine your state is like your backyard, and you want to build a super-duper playground for *everyone* in your neighborhood to play on, and your mom and dad (the state leaders

title: Why are so many invasive species in the US waterways from China?
text: Imagine your bathtub is full of your favorite toys. Now, imagine someone accidentally drops a bunch of new, different toys in there – maybe some from a friend's house. These new toys are super hungry and start eating all the food your old toys like, and they take up all the space! That's kind of what happens when animals or plants from one place, like China, accidentally come to live in the water here in America. Why China? Well, America and China are like two big friends who trade a lot of toys, clothes, and yummy snacks! To bring all these things, really, really big boats travel all the way across the ocean, like super long swimming pools. Sometimes, little baby animals, tiny plants, or even eggs hide on the bottom of these big boats, or even in the special water the boats carry to stay balanced. When the boats get to America, these little hitchhikers jump off and say, "Wow, new home!" But sometimes, they're not very good guests, and they cause trouble for the fish

title: If a soldier is captured, does that count as overtime?
text: No, sweetie, it's not like working extra hours for more money, like when mommy or daddy works overtime. Soldiers have a very important job to keep us safe, and they get paid for their job. But if bad guys catch a soldier, that's a very, very scary and dangerous situation, not part of their job they get extra pay for. It's a really hard thing that we hope never happens to them, and it's not like working extra for a bonus.

title: Why does eating a lot of sugar makes you sleepy? Shouldn't it be the opposite as sugar provides you energy?
text: Imagine sugar is like a super-fast rocket fuel for your body! A little bit helps you run and play. But if you eat a WHOLE LOT of sugar all at once, it's like putting too much fuel in your rocket too fast. Your body has a special helper, like a busy cleaner, that rushes in to clean up all that extra sugar really, really quickly. This cleaner works super-duper hard and fast to put all the sugar away. After all that hard work, the cleaner gets tired, and because all the sugar got put away so fast, your body suddenly doesn't have as much rocket fuel zooming around. That's why you feel all sleepy and ready for a nap, even though you just had a sweet treat!

title: How do some people with Dissociative Identity Disorder exhibit abilities while in some personas that there real self can't do?
text: Imagine your brain is like a big house, and inside this house, there are different friends who sometimes take turns being "the boss" of the house. Even though it's the *same*

title: Why is the Python language so heavily divided between two versions (2 and 3)?
text:
Imagine Python is like a super cool set of building blocks that grown-ups use to tell computers what to do.

First, there was **Python 2**, which was like the original, really popular set of blocks. Everyone loved it, and they built *tons* of amazing things with it, like huge castles and super fast race cars!

Then, the people who make the blocks said, "Hey, we can make an even *better* set of blocks! We can make some pieces stronger, some colors brighter, and make it easier to build even bigger and cooler things!" So they made **Python 3**.

The tricky part is, when they made Python 3, they changed some of the blocks a little bit. It's like if your old LEGO car needed square wheels, but the new LEGO car needs round wheels. You can't just take the old square wheels and put them on the new car; you have to change them!

Because so many people had already built *so many* things with the old Python 2 blocks, and it takes a lot of time and effort to change all those old square wheels to round ones, some people are still using their Python 2 blocks. But Python 3 is newer and better, and all the *new* cool instructions are being made for Python 3, so slowly everyone is moving to the new, improved set of blocks!

title: Why, when slowly opening a plastic soda bottle, does a little air come out when you Crack it a little open, but then more comes out when you open more?
text: Imagine the air inside your soda bottle is like a bunch of kids all squished together in a tiny room, and they really, really want to run outside to play where there's lots of space. When you just *crack* the bottle a tiny bit, it's like opening the door just a little bit, like a small crack. Only one or two kids can squeeze through that tiny crack at a time, so just a little bit of air (kids) rushes out with a little *psssst*. But when you open the bottle *more*, it's like opening the door much wider! Now, all the kids (air) see the big opening and can run out much faster and all at once! That's why lots more air comes out then, because there's a bigger path for it to escape.

title: Why are fire animations, fogs and shadows in video games so demanding for graphic cards?
text: Okay, imagine your computer's graphics card is like a super-duper fast artist drawing everything you see on the screen. When it draws a simple block, that's easy-pe

title: Why do humans have favorite colors?
text: Imagine you have lots of different yummy candies, like red ones, blue ones, and yellow ones! They all taste good, but maybe one kind just makes your tummy feel extra happy and giggly. That's kind of like colors! Our eyes see all the pretty colors in the world, like the green grass or the yellow sun. But inside our brain, which is like the super smart boss of our body, some colors just make us feel a special, warm, happy feeling more than others. Maybe a blue toy made you laugh a lot, or a red shirt always feels super comfy. So, your brain just picks the color that gives you the best, happiest feeling, and that becomes your favorite! It's like having a favorite song, it just makes you feel good!

title: An atomic bomb can fit in a briefcase,yet diplomatic pouches are flown into countries without check.What then is nuclear deterrence about?
text: Imagine a really, really super powerful firework that can make a boom bigger than anything you've ever seen, and it can fit in a special box, not a giant one!

title: Black bars across ones eyes and censorship?
text: Imagine you have a super secret, like what present you're getting for your birthday! Sometimes, grown-ups have secrets too, but they're not always about toys. Maybe it's someone's face they don't want everyone to know, or a grown-up word that's not for little ears. The black bar is like a magic sticker we put over that secret part. It just covers up a little bit, like putting your hand over part of your drawing so nobody can see it yet. We do it so that the secret stays safe, or so that person's face stays private, so only special people know, kind of like a surprise!

title: Why do radios stations from far away come on when it rains?
text: Imagine radio music is carried by tiny invisible messengers, like little sound-fairies. Normally, these fairies fly straight and can only go so far before they get tired and disappear. But when it rains, especially when there are big, dark clouds, it's like the clouds make the sky a bit bouncy! These big, wet clouds can sometimes act like a giant trampoline or a special mirror way up high. So, the music-fairies from really far away, that you usually can't hear, bounce off these bouncy clouds and zoom all the way down to your radio! It's like the rain helps them take a special shortcut to reach you.

title: How did ancient peoples make it to Hawaii and other geographically disparate islands centuries before reasonably modernized shipbuilding?
text: Imagine you have a really, really big toy boat, but it's made from a giant tree! People a super long time ago were very, very smart and knew how to make these big boats, called canoes, super strong so they wouldn't break. Sometimes they even tied two of them together, like twin boats with a big platform in the middle, so it was like a giant floating raft! They didn't have GPS like mommy and daddy's phone. Instead, they were like amazing nature detectives! At night, they looked at the twinkling stars in the sky, which were like their special map. During the day, they watched the sun, felt the wind, and even looked for birds flying, because birds mean land is close! They packed yummy food and lots of water for their long trip. It took a very, very long time, like a super long car ride that lasts many, many days and nights, but they were brave adventurers who wanted to find new homes and new places. So they sailed and sailed, using their smarts and their super strong boats, until they found new land!

title: what would happen if you never cut the umbilical cord?
text: Okay, imagine when you were inside your mommy's tummy, you had a special tube, kind of like a straw, that gave you food and air from her. That's the umbilical cord! When you come out, that straw is still there. Usually, a grown-up snips it because you don't need it anymore, like cutting the string on a balloon after you let it go. But if they didn't cut it, don't worry! It wouldn't stay forever. That special tube would just get dry and hard, like a crunchy leaf that falls off a tree. After a little while, maybe a few days or a week, it would just shrivel up and fall off all by itself, leaving your belly button behind. It's totally natural, and nothing bad would happen, it just takes a bit longer than getting it snipped right away.

title: Is it legal to pirate a game I own legitimately?
text: Imagine you have a super cool toy car, and it's all yours because your grown-up bought it for you from the toy store! Now, imagine you wanted another one, but instead of asking your grown-up to go to the store and buy it again, you found a secret box where lots of people put toy cars they copied, and you just took one from there without asking anyone. Even though you already own the *real* toy car, taking a copied one from that secret box without permission is like not following the rules. The people who made the toy car want you to get it the proper way, from their store, or from your grown-up who got it from their store. So, even if you already own the game, getting it from a 'pirate' place is usually not allowed because it's like taking something without asking, and that's not following the rules.

title: How can Navient, the student loan servicer in the news today, have a 100% negative reviews with the Better Business Bureau, but still be rated an A+?
text: Imagine Navient is like a big company that helps grown-ups pay back money for school. The BBB is like a special report card company for grown-up businesses. When people write reviews, it's like saying "I don't like this toy!" or "This game is super fun!" So, lots of grown-ups are saying "I don't like Navient!" which is why all the reviews are grumpy. But the BBB's A+ isn't just about if people *like* the company. It's mostly about how well the company *tries to fix things* when people have a problem and tell the BBB about it. So, even if many people are unhappy, if Navient is really good at saying "Oops, sorry! Let's try to make it better!" and helps fix the specific problem the BBB hears about, then the BBB gives them a good grade for *trying to solve* the complaints, even if there are a lot of complaints to begin with.

title: How do people get roms off of cartridges?
text: Imagine your game cartridge is like a special little toy box that has a whole fun adventure inside! To get that adventure out so you can play it on a different screen, grown-ups use a special copying machine. They put the toy box into the machine, and the machine carefully reads all the game's secrets and makes a perfect copy. It's like taking a picture of the whole adventure and saving it onto a computer. Then, you can play that copied adventure on other screens without needing the original toy box anymore!

title: White Hats of Reddit, what are simple steps everyone should be taking to preserve anonymity and security online?
text: Hey little friend! Imagine the internet is like a giant, super fun playground with lots of people. To keep yourself safe and happy, like a superhero, here are some easy tricks:

title: What does the chip on our cards do, why do we only now need it, and why can't every store/vendor mainstream the darn thing so we don't have to swipe?
text: Okay, imagine your card is like a special key to your piggy bank! The tiny shiny chip on it is like a super-secret spy living inside your key. When you put your key in the special slot, that spy talks to the store's machine with a brand new secret code *every single time* you buy something. This makes it super hard for bad guys to copy your key and steal your money, because the secret code changes like magic! We only started needing this super-spy key because, for a long time, the old way (swiping) was like just showing everyone your key, and some bad guys learned a trick to make copies of it. So grown-ups made the chip to be much, much safer and stop those tricky bad guys! Why don't all stores have the new keyhole yet? Well, getting a new keyhole machine for every store costs money, just like buying new toys!

title: Why do we tilt our head/eyes to one side when thinking or trying to remember about something?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a super-duper special toy box in your head that helps you think and remember! This toy box has two main parts, like two best friends working together. One friend is really good at remembering words and numbers, and the other friend is really good at remembering pictures and feelings. When you tilt your head or your eyes, it's like your brain is trying to listen really carefully or look a little harder with one of its special sides to find the right memory or idea! Sometimes, if you're trying to remember what a dog looks like, your brain might tilt to talk to the 'picture' friend. If you're trying to remember a new word, it might tilt to talk to the 'word' friend. It's just a little helpful trick your brain does to focus and find what it's looking for!

title: Why does water taste terrible when you're sick, even though you're supposed to be drinking lots of fluids to get better?
text: Imagine your body is like a little superhero when you're sick! It's super busy fighting off all the yucky germs that are making you feel bad. When your body is fighting so hard, it gets a bit tired and maybe a little grumpy, just like you might feel grumpy when you're tired. Your mouth and nose, which usually help you taste and smell yummy things, are also busy helping your superhero body fight, so they don't always taste things the same way. It's like when you have a stuffy nose and even your favorite food doesn't taste as good! The water itself is still good water, but your superhero body is just so focused on feeling icky that it makes the water seem less tasty. But even though it doesn't taste super yummy right now, your superhero body still really needs that water to help it win the fight against the germs and get you feeling strong and playful again! It's like giving your superhero a super power drink!

title: Why are sodas made with such strong acids?
text: Okay, imagine your soda is like a super sweet candy, right? But if it was *only* sweet, it might get a bit boring after a while, like eating just sugar! So, the people who make soda add a tiny bit of something special called 'acid'. It's not a scary acid that would hurt you, but more like the sour taste in a lemon or a green apple! This special 'zingy' stuff makes your soda taste exciting and not just sweet. It gives it that bubbly, tingly feeling on your tongue that we like, and it also helps keep your soda fresh and stops any yucky little germs from growing inside, so it stays yummy for a long time! So, they put it in to make it taste super good and stay safe to drink.

title: How do you read the pioneer plaque on the Pioneer spacecrafts?
text: Imagine you find a secret drawing from someone you don't know, and they don't speak your language! This special drawing on the Pioneer spaceship is like that, but for space friends far

title: Does the president really have 'Launch Codes', or is that a Euphemism for some other mechanism?
text: Okay, imagine the President has a super important, special backpack that a helper always carries, called the 'football' (but it's not for playing!). Inside isn't a giant red button like in cartoons. Instead, it has special cards and secret papers with super secret words and numbers, like a secret password for a very important game. When the President needs to make a really, really big decision about sending faraway rockets (the 'launch'), they use these secret words and numbers to prove it's really them and not someone pretending. But it's not just one person saying a magic word! Lots of other grown-ups, like generals, also have to check and use their own special secret codes to make sure everyone agrees and that it's the right thing to do. So, 'launch codes' is like a grown-up way of saying it's a whole bunch of secret steps and checks, not just one special button or a single magic word!

title: When taking a shower, why does using bar soap make my skin feel like it's more rough / has more friction after I wash it off?
text: Okay, imagine your skin has a super thin, invisible blanket of super smooth, slippery oil on it, like a tiny bit of butter that makes everything feel soft and easy to slide over. Bar soap is like a super strong cleaner that LOVES to eat up all that slippery oil and dirt! It does a really good job, so good that it cleans *all* the slippery oil right off your skin. When the slippery oil is all gone, your skin isn't as smooth anymore, and it feels a bit more "grabby" or rough, like when you try to slide on a carpet instead of a shiny floor. It's just because the super-duper cleaning took away all the things that made it feel smooth!

title: How am I able to daydream while driving and still arrive to my destination safely?
text: Imagine your brain is super, super smart, like a wizard! When you do something a lot, like walking or riding your scooter, you don't have to think about every tiny step, right? Your brain learns how to do it all by itself, like it puts it on "autopilot." Driving is kind of like that for grown-ups! When they drive the same road many times, their brain learns the way so well that a little part of it can steer and push the pedals all by itself, like a helpful robot. While that robot part of your brain is doing the driving, the other part of your brain can go off and play with fun thoughts, like what you want for a snack or a silly story. But don't worry! That little robot part is *always* watching the road, and if something surprising happens, like a red light or another car, it quickly taps the main part of your brain and says, "Hey! Wake up! We need you now!" And then your brain is back in charge, making sure everyone stays safe!

title: What's the hold up with the ability for residents to text 911 for emergencies? Is it a technology-related problem? Jurisdictional?

It's because some of the clubhouse's "listening machines" are old and only know how to hear voices, not read words. Also, there are *so many* different 911 clubhouses all over the country, and each one needs to get the new "reading eyes" machine and learn how to use it. It's like if all your friends had different kinds of walkie-talkies, and you all needed to get the *same new kind* to talk to each other. Plus, when you text, it's sometimes harder for the clubhouse to know *exactly* where you are, which is super important when someone needs help right away! And sometimes texts can get lost or take a long time to get there, like a message in a bottle floating across the ocean, which isn't good for emergencies. So, it's a mix of old machines, lots of clubhouses

title: Why do squatters in the UK have rights to where they are squatting? Why can't they be kicked out as soon as they are discovered?

title: Why do presidents wait until the very last week of their presidency to pardon convicted inmates, rather than doing it earlier on?
text: Imagine the president is like the boss of a big school, and sometimes kids get sent to the time-out room (that's like jail). The president can say, "Okay, you can come out of time-out now, you're not in trouble for that anymore!" That's called a pardon. Now, why does he wait until his very last week, when he's almost packing his bags to go home? Well, if he lets someone out of time-out earlier, some other grown-ups (people who voted for him) might get upset and say, "Hey, I don't like that decision!" But if he does it right before he leaves, he doesn't have to worry about those grown-ups being mad at him for a long time, because he won't be the boss anymore next week. It's like making a big, sometimes unpopular, decision just before he says goodbye and someone else takes over.

title: How do cemeteries work when it floods or they get a ton of rain? Do the caskets get wet or does embalming stuff seep into the ground?
text: Okay, imagine the ground is like a giant, super-thirsty sponge! When it rains a little, the sponge just soaks it all up. When it rains a lot, the sponge gets really, really full. When someone is buried, they go into a special box called a casket, and that casket usually goes inside an even *stronger* box made of concrete, like a super tough bathtub, before it goes into the ground. This strong bathtub-like box is designed to keep the casket safe and mostly dry, even if the ground around it gets very wet. It's like putting your toy in a sealed plastic container before putting it in a puddle – the toy stays dry inside! So, the caskets usually don't get all soggy. And that special liquid called embalming fluid, which helps keep the person looking nice for a while, stays inside the casket and that strong concrete box. Those boxes are made to keep everything sealed up tight, so the special liquid doesn't just seep out into the dirt. The ground and those strong boxes work together like a team to keep everything where it should be, even when there's a big splash!

title: Why do slugs dissolve/turn to sludge when exposed to table salt?
text: Imagine a slug is like a super squishy water balloon, full of water inside to help it move and stay happy. Now, salt is like a tiny, super thirsty sponge! When you sprinkle that super thirsty sponge (salt) on the water balloon (the slug), the salt gets really, really busy. It starts sucking all the water out of the slug super fast! The slug gets all wrinkly and flat because all its water is gone, and that's why it turns into a gooey, watery mess – it just lost all its water really, really quickly, like a balloon losing all its air and getting all saggy.

title: Why does cold water feel "wetter" than hot water?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a warm, cozy blanket! When cold water touches you, it's like a little chilly monster trying to steal your warmth! It really grabs onto your skin and tries hard to make you cold, and because it's working so hard to take your warmth away, you *feel* it there a lot, and it stays on you longer trying to make you colder before it finally warms up and flies away. That big, cold feeling and it sticking around makes it feel super "wet"! But when warm water touches you, it's like a friendly hug. It doesn't try to steal your warmth as much, or sometimes it even shares a little. It also gets warm from your body super fast and then quickly flies away into the air, like little invisible water fairies. Since it doesn't make you feel so cold and doesn't stay around as long, it doesn't feel as "wet" or clingy. So it's not really *wetter*, it just makes you *feel* colder and notice it more!

title: How can another persons hands feel colder to the touch than ambient room temperature?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super warm oven, always making heat to keep you toasty! Your hands are like little windows on your body. Sometimes, even if the air in the room isn't cold, your hands might let a little bit of that warmth escape into the air, or your body might be sending more warmth to your middle parts to keep them extra warm. So, when your warm hand touches someone else's hand, if their hand has let out a little more warmth, it's not as warm as *your* hand. And guess what? Warmth always wants to jump from the warmer thing (your hand) to the less warm thing (their hand)! So when your warmth jumps away into their hand, your hand suddenly feels chilly because it lost some of its heat, like when you give away a warm cookie! It's not that their hand is colder than the air, it's just not as warm as yours, and that makes *your* hand feel cold when you touch it.

title: Why do we tend to look worse in pictures than we see ourselves?
text: Imagine you have a favorite toy. You see it every day, and your brain knows exactly what it looks like from the front. When you look in the mirror, it's like seeing your toy's reflection in a puddle – it's the same toy, but it's flipped around! Your brain is super used to seeing that flipped version of you, so it feels very normal. But when someone takes a picture, it's like they're showing you your toy from a brand new angle you don't see all the time, or maybe the camera is like a special window that makes things look a tiny bit different from how your eyes see them. So it's still you, but it's not the "you" your brain sees every single day in the mirror, and that difference can make it feel a little strange, not necessarily worse!

title: Why does being/getting cold sometimes prevent vomiting, even if you're actually sick (not just overheated, carsick, etc)?
text: Imagine your tummy has a little alarm bell that rings when it feels yucky and wants to throw up. When you're sick, that bell rings very loud! But your whole body also has a big 'temperature' button. When you get really cold, your body gets super busy trying to warm you up, like a busy helper. Sometimes, that 'temperature' button gets pushed so hard, it's like it makes all the other helpers in your body pay attention to *that* instead. So, for a little while, your body gets so busy trying to get warm that it doesn't hear the 'yucky tummy' alarm bell as loudly, and it might forget to make you throw up for a bit. It's like if you were crying because you fell, but then someone showed you a super cool, noisy toy – you might stop crying for a bit because you're busy looking at the toy!

title: What makes our cells "stick" together and what stops them all from falling down into a giant splodge on the floor?
text: Imagine your body is like a super amazing house, and all your tiny cells are like the little bricks that build that house. To make sure the bricks don't just fall down into a big pile, they need to stick together, right? Your cells do too! They have special sticky bits on their outsides, like super-duper glue or tiny velcro patches, that grab onto other cells and hold them really, really tight. Sometimes they even link together like little LEGO bricks! All this sticking makes them hold hands so strongly that they form a tough team. Because all these cell-bricks are holding hands and glued so well, they make you a strong, solid person, instead of just a wobbly, squishy puddle on the floor!

title: Why is the safest thing to due during a tsunami climb a high tree or high building?
text: Imagine a super duper big wave, like when you splash in the bathtub but way, way bigger, comes rushing onto the land! This big water wants to push everything that's low down. So, just like when you want to stay dry and not get your feet wet in a big puddle, you would climb onto a chair or a table to get high up. A tall building or a very strong, high tree is like that super tall chair or table. If you climb way, way up high on them, the big rushing water will just go underneath you, and you'll be safe up above, kind of like a bird in its nest while the rain falls below. You want to be higher than where the water can reach so it can't push you or hurt you!

title: how do organizations (business or government) in general validate if a person's signature is real and not just a doodle?
text: Okay, imagine your signature is like your very own special secret drawing that says "This is me!" or "I promise!" Organizations like the bank or the government have a special picture of how your signature usually looks, like a photo album just for your name. When you sign something new, they take your new drawing and look very, very carefully at the old pictures. They don't just see if the letters are the same, but they look at how you draw them: if you make big swoops or tiny circles, if you push hard with your crayon or soft, and if it goes fast or slow. It's like comparing two drawings to see if the same person made them. If the new one looks super different from all your old ones, like someone else tried to draw it, they might say, "Hmm, is this really your promise?" and ask you to do something else to show it's really you.
