text: Imagine light is like tiny little bouncy balls trying to go through a wall. When something is transparent, like a window, it means there are lots of empty spaces inside, so the light balls can zoom

title: Why do all remote controls have squishy rubber buttons instead of proper hard keys like a keyboard?
text: Okay, imagine your remote control buttons are like soft, squishy play-doh, all stuck together in one big piece! It's super easy and cheap for the people who make remotes to just press out all the button shapes from one big sheet of rubber. When you push a squishy button, it just gently touches a special spot inside, almost like a little tap, to tell the TV what to do. Hard keys, like on a keyboard, are like tiny little Lego blocks that each need their own special spring and pushy part, which costs more money and is more complicated to put together. Plus, if you accidentally drop your remote (oopsie!), the squishy buttons are less likely to break because they're all connected like one strong rubber friend, instead of lots of tiny pieces that could pop off!

title: why are the majority of meteorites that hit earth mainly iron and not some other metal like gold?
text: Okay, imagine all the tiny bits of rock and dust floating around in space are like a giant bucket of LEGOs! Most of the LEGOs in that bucket are plain, strong, grey ones – that's like iron. There are so, so many of them everywhere! But the super shiny, special gold LEGOs? Those are very, very rare, like finding just a few sparkly gems in a whole big sandbox. When a space rock gets put together, it mostly grabs all the common, easy-to-find grey LEGOs because there are just so many of them. So, when a space rock comes to Earth, it's usually made of those common strong grey LEGOs (iron) because that's what most of the rocks in space are made of! It's super rare to find one made of the special gold ones.

title: How does the brain "release chemicals?"
text: Imagine your brain is like a super busy command center, and it's full of tiny little houses, which we call brain cells! When your brain wants to send a special feeling or instruction – like "be happy!" or "time to learn!" – it makes tiny little packages inside one of those houses. These packages are the "chemicals." When it's time to send the message, the house opens a little door and gently pushes the tiny package out. It then floats across a tiny gap to knock on the door of the next brain cell house, which picks up the package, reads the message, and then knows what to do, like making you feel excited or helping you remember something! That's how your brain sends all its important messages around.

title: How have Coca Cola remained the market leader for long?
text: Imagine Coca-Cola is like the most super popular kid in your class! Everyone knows them, and everyone wants to play with them. They've been the most popular for a super, super long time because of a few cool things: First, they have a secret yummy taste that no one else can make exactly the same. It's like your favorite

title: Skyrim got a revamped version. It is the same game but with better graphics. One of the new features is the 64 bit engine. What did the programmers have to do? Rewrite the whole game? What is the difference between 32 bit and 64 bit from that perspective?
text:
Imagine your game is like a super big toy box filled with all your dragons, swords, houses, and people!

*   **32-bit** is like having little sticky notes for each toy that tell the computer where it is. These sticky notes only have space for short addresses, so you can only have so many toys in your box before the computer gets confused and forgets where things are (and the game might crash!).
*   **64-bit** is like having much bigger sticky notes with space for super-duper long addresses. Now you can have a *ton* more toys in your box, and the computer can easily remember where every single one is, even if you have hundreds of dragons and thousands of swords!

What did the programmers have to do? They didn't have to throw away all the cool dragons and swords and build them again from scratch – those toys were already awesome! What they mostly did was change all those little sticky notes to the big, super-long address sticky notes. This meant going through many parts of the game's "brain" and teaching it how to use the new, bigger

title: From a strategic point of view, what do the Patriots do that makes them so dominant almost every season?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends are playing a game, like building the biggest block tower ever! The Patriots are really good because they have a super smart grown-up (their coach) who thinks about *everything*. He's like the grown-up who knows exactly what toys the other kids have and how they like to play. So, he makes a special plan for *each* game, like knowing if the other team likes to run with the ball or throw it far. Then, they have a really, really good player (like

title: How and why does motion sickness cause nausea and dizziness to an otherwise healthy person?
text: Imagine your brain is like the super smart captain of a ship, and that ship is your body! It gets messages from your eyes, your ears (which help you balance), and your body to know exactly what's happening. Sometimes, when you're in a car or a boat, your captain brain gets super confused because it gets mixed messages. Your eyes might see things inside the car that are staying still, telling your brain, "We're not moving!" But then, your ears deep inside your head, and your body, feel all the bumps and turns and say, "Whoa, we're wobbling and moving a lot!" Because your brain gets two totally different stories at the same time, it thinks something might be wrong or that you ate something bad. To try and fix what it thinks is a problem, it makes your tummy feel yucky (that's nausea) and your head feel wobbly (that's dizziness), just to tell you, "Hey, stop this! I'm confused!"

title: Why do they call it a Bachelor's degree?
text: Imagine when you go to school, you learn lots and lots of things! When you finish all the school you have to do when you're little, and then all the school when you're a bit bigger, you might want to go to another super big school to learn even more grown-up stuff. If you work really hard there for a few years, you get a special paper that says you learned all those things! They call it a "Bachelor's degree" because "bachelor" is a very old word that used to mean someone who was just starting out on a big adventure or learning something new, kind of like a young knight who's just beginning to learn how to be a hero. So, it's like your first big paper that shows you've started your grown-up learning adventure!

title: How did MS-DOS make Microsoft an OS power house?
text: Imagine your computer is like a toy car, and to make it go, stop, or turn, it needs a little brain inside to tell it what to do. A long, long time ago, a very big company called IBM made lots and lots of new computers, and they needed a simple brain for them. Microsoft had just the right simple brain, called MS-DOS. IBM decided to put Microsoft's MS-DOS brain into *all* their new computers! Because IBM made so many computers, suddenly almost every computer had Microsoft's brain inside. This made Microsoft super important because if you wanted a computer, it probably had their brain. It was like everyone suddenly needed to buy the same kind of special engine from Microsoft for their toy cars, and that made Microsoft very, very powerful, helping them later make even fancier brains like Windows that we use today!

title: How can scientists find out what others see? Like how color-blinded people see or how animals see.
text: Okay, imagine your eyes are like super special cameras that help you see all the colors! For people who are color-blind, it's like their camera has some buttons that don't work for certain colors, so they might see brown where you see green. We ask them, "What color do you see here?" and they tell us, and we also look very, very closely at their camera parts (their eyes) to see which tiny color-catching bits are missing or not

title: What does water actually taste of?
text: Water usually doesn't taste like much! It's kind of like air – you don't really taste air, do you? Water's job isn't to taste like yummy juice or candy. Its job is to help your body and make you not thirsty. Sometimes, water might taste a tiny bit different because of super tiny invisible things floating in it, like little sprinkles from the ground that aren't bad for you. Or, if you just ate a super strong tasting cookie, the water might taste different because your mouth is still remembering the cookie! But mostly, water just tastes like... water! It's plain and good for you.

title: How and why does the human body generates heat?
text: Imagine your body is like a little oven, but instead of baking cookies, it's making you! When you eat yummy food, it's like putting fuel into your oven. Your body then uses that food to get energy so you can run, jump, think, and play all day long. And guess what? When your body makes all that energy, it also makes a little bit of warmth, just like when you rub your hands together really, really fast and they get warm! Your body needs to stay at a special, cozy temperature, not too cold and not too hot, so all your inside parts, like your heart and your brain, can do their super important jobs perfectly. So, it makes its own heat to keep you nice and toasty and make sure everything is working just right, like keeping a special toy working perfectly!

title: Why are we so fixated on finding water on other planets, as a sign of life? Is it not possible that other life forms would function without water as we know it?
text: Imagine you're super thirsty after playing, and you need a drink of water to feel better, right? Well, everything alive on Earth, from tiny bugs to big trees and even you, needs water to live and grow, like it's our special juice! Water helps our bodies do all the important jobs, like moving things around inside us. So, when grown-ups look for alien friends on other planets, they first look for water because it's like a big sign that says, "Maybe life can live here, just like us!" It's true that maybe alien friends don't drink water and drink something totally different, like sparkly goo or invisible air! That's a super cool idea, and grown-ups think about that too. But it's hard to know what to look for if it's completely new, so we start by looking for the "juice" of life that we know best, because it's the easiest way to begin our big treasure hunt for alien buddies!

title: Why do people seem to bleed less during surgery?
text: When doctors do surgery, think of your body like a house with lots of tiny water pipes inside, carrying your special red juice all around! The doctors are super careful builders. They know exactly where all those pipes are, so they try really, really hard not to bump into them. If a tiny pipe does get a little hole, they have special tools, like tiny clamps or magic glue, to quickly pinch it closed or seal it up before too much red juice can leak out. Plus, sometimes they give you special sleepy medicine that makes all your pipes calm down and not push the red juice out so fast. So, even though they are fixing things inside, they are very good at keeping all your red juice safe and sound!

title: Is there real scientific evidence that marijuana can kill cancer cells? If so, to which degree?
text:
Okay, imagine your body has some naughty, runaway cells, like tiny bullies, and we call them cancer cells. Scientists, who are like super smart detectives, have been looking at a special plant called marijuana. In their tiny science rooms, in a little dish, sometimes they've seen parts of this plant make those naughty bully cells go away! It's kind of like if you put a special soap on a drawing, and the drawing disappears.

But here's the tricky part: this only happened in a little dish, not inside a whole person yet. We don't know if it would work the same way inside you, or if it would make you feel yucky or hurt your good cells too much. So, while it's a super interesting idea, and scientists are working really hard to learn more, it's not like a medicine you can take right now to make the cancer go away. It's like finding a tiny clue that *might* lead to a treasure, but you haven't found the big treasure chest yet!

title: Why do some sodas (like Coke) produce a lot of foam when it's poured into a cup, from say, a can, while other sodas (like Sprite) don't produce nearly as much?
text: Imagine your soda is full of tiny, tiny air bubbles, like little balloons! When you pour it, these balloons want to escape. In some sodas, like Coke, there are special things in the drink that make the little balloons sticky. So, when they try to escape, they all stick together and hold hands, making a big pile of bubbly foam on top! But in other sodas, like Sprite, there aren't as many sticky helpers. So, the little balloons just fly away much faster and don't hold hands as much, which means less foam. The sticky helpers in Coke are part of what makes it taste and look special, like its yummy dark color and other secret ingredients!

title: How can game key aglorithms be simultaneously strict enough that they can't be guessed and vague enough that millions of games can generate millions of single-use keys?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper giant box of special building blocks, like LEGOs! When the game makes a key for you, it's like building a very special, secret fort

title: Why did primitive humans (e.g. Neanderthal) disappear?
text: Imagine a long, long time ago, there were people a bit like us, called Neanderthals, living all over the place! They were super strong and good at hunting big animals. But then, our kind of people, *Homo sapiens*, started to come along too. It was a bit like when you have a favorite toy, and then a new, shiny toy comes out. Maybe our kind of people were a little better at finding all the yummy food, making warmer clothes, or even talking to each other to share ideas and help each other more. Because we were so good at these things, we started to have more babies and grow bigger families. The Neanderthals, even though they were tough, found it harder and harder to find enough food and places to live when there were more and more of our kind of people around. They didn't all disappear in a big fight; it was more like they slowly faded away over a very long time, until one day, only our kind of people were left. Sometimes, a tiny bit of them even stayed with us, because some of our ancestors played and had babies with them!

title: Why does going to sleep earlier affect your body differently than going to sleep later, even if you sleep for the same duration?
text: Imagine your body has a special invisible clock inside, just like the clock on the wall! This body clock loves the sun and knows when it's daytime for playing and nighttime for sleeping. When you go to bed when it's dark outside, your body clock is super happy because it's doing exactly what it's supposed to do, like a train running perfectly on its tracks. It uses that dark time to give your body the best, deepest rest and fix everything up so you wake up feeling super strong and bouncy. But if you go to bed much later, even if you sleep for the same number of hours, it's like you're trying to make your body clock work at a weird time. It gets a little confused because maybe the sun is already thinking about coming up, and it's not the usual time for the deepest fixing. So, even though you slept a lot, your body clock didn't get to do its best work at the perfect time, which can make you feel a little more tired or less bouncy, because it didn't get to follow its favorite schedule.

title: What does it mean if America pulls out of the TPP?
text: Imagine the TPP was like a big promise that lots of grown-up countries, including America, were going to make to each other. It was like saying, "Let's all agree to share our toys and snacks (which means selling and buying things) in a special, easy way!" When America "pulled out," it means America decided *not* to make that promise anymore. It's like America said, "Nope, I don't want to play by *those* special rules with *all* of you together." So, what happens? America isn't part of that big promise. The other countries might still make that promise and play by those rules together, but America isn't in their special club for that promise. America will now have

title: The double-slit experimet. How can simply "watching" the electron cause it to stop being a wave?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super tiny, invisible toy car, like a ghost car! When no one is looking, this ghost car can be really spread out, like a big cloud, and it can go through two doors at the same time, making a funny wiggly pattern on the wall behind. It's like it's not sure which door to pick, so it tries both! But if you want to know *which* door the ghost car goes through, you have to shine a tiny, tiny flashlight on it. That little flashlight beam is like a tiny poke!

title: Why is the French Revolution considered more important than the American one in world history when it came later and had many of the same themes?
text:
Okay, imagine two big parties!

The American party was like when a group of kids decided they wanted to build their very own treehouse far away from their old house and make their own rules in *that* treehouse. They said, "We don't like the rules from the grown-ups in our old house across the big ocean anymore!" And they built their own cool treehouse with new rules, and it was super exciting for them! It showed other kids that it *was* possible to make your own rules.

But the French party happened right in the middle of the *biggest* playground where *all* the other grown-ups and kids (kings and queens from other countries) were playing. The French kids didn't just want to move to a new treehouse; they were really, really mad at their *own* grown-ups (the king and queen) who lived right there with them. They said, "We don't want *any* grown-ups telling us what to do anymore! We want everyone to be equal, and *we* want to choose!" This was super scary for all the *other* grown-ups and kids on the playground because it meant that *anyone* could get rid of their *own* rulers, right there where everyone could see. It caused so much noise and so many changes right in the middle of everything that its ideas spread like a wildfire to all the other playgrounds and made everyone rethink how things should work, not just in one faraway tree

title: is there a definitive number of colours that humans can see?
text: Imagine you have a big box of crayons. You can see red, blue, green, and all the colors in between! It's not like there's a special number, like '10 colors' or '100 colors,' that we can count. Think of it more like a rainbow: the red smoothly changes into orange, then yellow, then green, and so on. There are so many tiny, tiny differences as one color blends into another that it's impossible to pick a single number. Our eyes are really good at seeing all those smooth changes, but it's not like counting individual things, so there isn't one definitive number.

title: Why is "Colonel" pronounced "Kernel"?
text: That's a super tricky word, isn't it? It looks like it should sound like "coal-o-nel," but it sounds like "kernel," like the inside of popcorn! Well, imagine words are like little toys that get passed around from one country to another a long, long, long time ago. Sometimes, when a word traveled, people in different places would say it a little bit differently, and sometimes words even got mixed up with other words that meant similar things. This word, "Colonel," actually came from two different old words that meant the same kind of army leader. One old word had an "r" sound in it, and another old word had an "l" sound. Over many, many years, people just started saying the "r" sound more often because it felt natural, and even though we still write it with the "l"s, we kept saying it with the "r" from that other old word. So now, it's just a funny word that sounds different than it looks, like a secret code!

title: Why isn't apple a popular ingredient in ice cream?
text: Okay, imagine your yummy ice cream is like a super soft, sweet, cold hug for your tongue! Apples are crunchy and sometimes a little bit sour, right? If you put crunchy apple pieces into that super cold ice cream, they would get REALLY hard, like little frozen rocks, and that wouldn't be fun to bite into! Plus, apples have a fresh, zippy taste that sometimes doesn't want to play nicely with the super sweet, creamy taste of ice cream as much as other yummy things like chocolate or strawberries, which are softer and sweeter even when they're cold. So, apples are super yummy for snacks or pies, but they just don't make the best friends with ice cream because they get too hard and their taste is a bit different from what ice cream usually likes!

title: Why does the water from a plastic bottle taste fine after being on the store shelf for months, yet the day after I put my own tap water in there it tastes of plastic?
text: Imagine your water bottle is like a brand new toy car! When it's at the store, the water inside is like a very quiet, gentle passenger, and the car is made super special so its "new car smell" stays tucked away inside, not bothering the water for a long, long time. But

title: ; why do we fall into "food comas" after eating a lot of certain foods (e.g pasta) and can do nothing but sleep for an hour or so following consumption?
text: You know how sometimes after you eat a really big yummy meal, like lots of pasta, you feel super sleepy, like you just want to cuddle up and nap? Well, that's because your body is like a little factory, and when you put lots of food in, especially yummy pasta that gives you lots of energy, your body needs to work super, super hard to break it all down and use it. It's like when you play really hard and get tired! Your body sends lots of its 'worker' blood to your tummy to help with the big job of breaking down all that food. And when more worker blood goes to your tummy, a little less goes to your brain for a bit. Your brain is like the boss, and when it gets a bit less 'energy juice', it makes you feel sleepy and want to rest, so your body can focus all its energy on the important job of digesting your yummy food. So, you feel sleepy because your body is busy doing a super important job inside!

title: What is happening when your eyes are open, but you're picturing something else in your head. How can you 'see' the thought, while also processing what's in front of you?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is super-duper smart and has two different screens inside it! One screen is like a camera that shows you everything your eyes see right now, like the wall or your toy. That's the 'real world' screen. But your brain also has another screen, a 'magic' screen, where it can make up its own pictures, like a purple dinosaur or your favorite ice cream! When you're picturing something in your head, your brain is just playing a movie on that magic screen, while the 'real world' screen is still showing what your eyes see, just a little bit quieter. Your brain is so good, it can watch both at the same time, deciding which one to listen to more, like when you listen to your mom talking while also looking at a book!

title: How does Facebook change its mobile layout and colors without having me update it on the App Store/play store?
text: Imagine your Facebook app is like a special coloring book on your tablet. When you get a whole new coloring book with new pictures and new stories, that's like when you have to go to the App Store to update it – you get a whole new book! But sometimes, Facebook can just send a little invisible message over the internet, like a magic whisper, that tells your coloring book, "Hey, today let's color the sky blue instead of yellow!" or "Let's put the sun on the left side of the page today!" It's not a new book, just new instructions on how to color the pictures that are already there. So, the app just listens to these little magic whispers when it opens up, and suddenly things look a bit different without you needing a whole new book!

title: Why is it considered treacherous for the US to restore relations with Russia?
text: Imagine you and your friend used to play together, but then your friend started being really, really mean to other kids, taking their toys without asking and not following the rules. Everyone got very upset with your friend, and you stopped playing with them because it wasn't fair. Now, some grown-ups are thinking, "Maybe you should play with that friend again." But lots of other grown-ups say, "Whoa, wait! That friend was just very mean! If you play with them again too soon, it might look like you don't care about the mean things they did. It might also make your other good friends sad because they're still upset with the mean friend. And what if that mean friend just starts being mean again? It feels like a very tricky thing to do, like walking on thin ice, because we don't want anyone to get hurt or for the mean friend to think it's okay to be mean."

title: How does the concept of Universal Basic Income work?
text: Imagine if every single grown-up, no matter if they have a job or not, got a special allowance from the government every month, just like how maybe your mommy or daddy gives you money sometimes. This money isn't a super lot, but it's enough for them to buy important things like yummy food, warm clothes, and a safe house to live in. It's called Universal Basic Income because "Universal" means everyone gets it, "Basic" means it's enough for the most important stuff, and "Income" means it's money they get regularly. The idea is that nobody has to worry about not having enough money for the super important things, even if they can't find a job right now or need to stay home to take care of someone.

title: why are funeral processions allowed to block traffic and display flashing lights?
text: Okay, imagine a long line of cars, like a family of ducks, following each other very, very carefully. When someone they loved very much has gone to heaven, these cars are all going to a special place together to say goodbye. They drive slowly and stick together so no one gets lost, and so everyone can be together for this sad and important trip. The flashing lights are like a gentle "shhh" or a special flag that tells all the other cars, "Please be quiet and careful, because we are doing something very important and sad right now, and we need to stick together." It's a way for everyone to show respect and help them stay safe as they go on this special journey.

title: Why does our singing sound better when listening to music?
text: Imagine you're coloring a picture, and sometimes your crayon goes a tiny bit outside the line. When you sing without music, it's like looking super close at your picture, and you can see every little wiggly line! But when you sing *with* music, the music is like a big, colorful, sparkly background that makes everything look awesome! The music is so fun and loud that it helps your voice know where to go, like a friendly guide, and if your voice wiggles a tiny bit, the music is like a big, happy blanket that covers up those little wiggles, making it sound super good and making you feel like a superstar!

title: Why do games need to restart in order to change certain graphics settings (e.g. resolution) but not certain other ones (shadows, etc.)?
text: Okay, imagine playing with your LEGOs! If you decide you want to build your LEGO house on a *bigger or smaller baseplate* (that's like resolution), you can't just magically make the baseplate change size while your house is still on it. You have to carefully pick up all your LEGOs, put away the old baseplate, get the new one, and then start putting your house back together. That's why the game needs to restart – it's like changing the whole "table" it's drawing on, and it needs to start fresh. But if you decide you want your LEGO car to have *darker windows* (that's like shadows) or use *bumpy bricks instead of smooth bricks* (that's like textures), you can just swap out those few pieces *while you're still playing* with your car. The game can just change those little things without needing to rebuild everything from scratch.

title: How do the rich help our economy?
text: Imagine some grown-ups have a *really* big piggy bank, much bigger than yours! When they buy super fancy toys, like a big boat or a really big house, the money from their piggy bank goes to the people who made those toys or helped build the house. Those people then have money to buy *their* own food and toys. Sometimes, these grown-ups decide to build a new toy factory or a special shop, and they need lots of helpers to work there, giving those helpers money for their time. A big part of their money also goes to the government's piggy bank, which helps pay for things like building our roads, keeping our schools open, and making sure we have doctors when we're sick. And sometimes, they even share their money to help other people who don't have as much. So, when their money moves around, it helps lots of other grown-ups get money too, which keeps our whole town working!

title: Why is it that rope does not unwind or untwist?
text: Imagine you have lots and lots of super tiny strings, like really thin hairs! If you just put them together, they would all fall apart, right? So, to make them strong, we first twist a bunch of those tiny strings together really tight, like you're twirling your finger around a bunch of spaghetti. Now you have a slightly bigger, stronger string. But even those might want to untwist a little bit. So, the clever trick is we take a few of those slightly bigger strings and twist *them* together, but this time, we twist them the *other way*! It's like they're giving each other a super strong hug. Because one part wants to untwist one way, and the other part wants to untwist the opposite way, they actually push against each other and get stuck, like two friends pushing on a door from opposite sides – the door stays shut! That's why your rope stays twisted and super strong, because all the twists are holding each other in place, like a big, never-ending hug.

title: What is the "Deep State" in the U.S.?
text: Okay, imagine our country is like a very, very big house, and the President is like the main grown-up boss who gets to decide some big things, like what we're having for dinner or what game we play. But in this big house, there are also lots and lots of other grown-ups who work there all the time, every single day, no matter who the main boss is. They're like the people who fix the lights, or make sure the water runs, or help the mail get to your house. The "Deep State" is a *story* some grown-ups tell about those everyday workers. The story says that some of those long-time workers might secretly have their *own* ideas about how things should be run, and maybe, just maybe, they try to make things go *their* way, even if the main boss wants something different. It's like if the person who always fixes the lights secretly decided to put up green lights instead of yellow, even if the new boss wanted yellow. It's a bit of a whispered secret, and not everyone believes it's true, but it's a story some people talk about when they think about how our country works.

title: How can you hear yourself when you think?
text: That's a super cool trick your brain does! Your ears are for hearing sounds from outside, like when a dog barks or your favorite song plays. But when you think, it's like your brain is talking to itself in a secret whisper, just for you! It makes up the sound of your voice inside your head, even though no sound actually comes out of your mouth or goes into your ears. It's like you're imagining the words, and your clever brain lets you "hear" them without making any noise at all, so no one else knows what you're thinking!

title: When you press the unlock button on your keys, how does it only work on your car?
text: Imagine your car is like a super special toy box, and your key is like a magic button! When you push the button on your key, it sends out a secret message, like shouting a special secret word. This secret word is super duper unique, just for *your* car! All the other cars have their *own* secret words, so when your key shouts *its* special word, only *your* car hears it and says, 'Oh, that's my friend!' and unlocks its doors. It's like your key has a secret password that only your car knows and understands, and no other car knows *that exact* password.

title: Since Jupiter is 95% hydrogen, could its atmosphere be lit on fire?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper big balloon filled with a special gas called hydrogen. Hydrogen *can* burn, like when you light a match and it goes poof! But for something to really catch fire and keep burning, like a campfire, it needs two things: the thing that *can* burn (like wood or that hydrogen gas) AND something else called oxygen, which is in the air we breathe. Jupiter has tons and tons of that hydrogen gas, but it doesn't have much of the oxygen it needs to make a big, roaring fire. It's like having a big pile of wood but no matches and no wind to help it burn. So, even though Jupiter has lots of hydrogen, it can't really light on fire because it's missing the other important ingredient for fire.

title: is sparkling water just as hydrating as plain water?
text: Yes! Sparkling water is just as good at helping your body drink up as plain water. Imagine you have a glass of water, and then you blow some tiny, tiny air bubbles into it. It's still water, right? Those bubbles are just a little bit of air that makes it fizzy and fun, but your body still gets all the water it needs from it, just like from plain water. So both are super good for making sure your tummy isn't thirsty!

title: How do they produce TV shows so much faster than movies?
text:
Okay, imagine you want to build a super-duper amazing LEGO castle!

**A movie** is like building *one giant, super special, fancy castle* that takes a really, really long time to make perfect. You want every single brick in the right place, all the flags flying perfectly, and it has to be the most amazing castle ever, because you're only making *one*. So, everyone takes their time to make sure it's just right.

**A TV show** is like building *lots of smaller, cool LEGO houses* in the same neighborhood. You build one house, then you quickly build another one right next to it, and then another! You use the same LEGO bricks and the same friends to help you build them, so you get really good and fast at it. You don't need *each* house to be absolutely perfect, because you're making a new one every week, and people are excited to see what the *next* house looks like! So, movies spend a long, long time on just one big, perfect thing, and TV shows quickly make lots of smaller, fun things over and over again.

title: How did Times New Roman become the 'standard' font for typing?
text: Imagine all the letters you write, like 'A' or 'B', wear different clothes, right? Some letters wear fancy clothes, some wear silly clothes, and some wear easy-to-see clothes. A long, long time ago, a very important newspaper in a big city wanted their words to wear clothes that were super easy to read, looked neat, and didn't take up too much space (like saving paper and ink!). So, they asked a clever person to design a brand new outfit for their letters. This clever person made a special letter-outfit called 'Times New Roman.' It was so good – clear, tidy, and just the right size – that everyone loved it! It was like when you find the perfect comfy shoes, and then all your friends want them too! Later, when computers came along, they needed to pick some good, reliable letter-outfits to put inside them. Because Times New Roman was already so popular and easy for everyone to read, it was one of the first ones they added. And because it was always there, like the first crayon you grab from the box, lots of grown-ups just kept using it for everything, making it super common and familiar!

title: Why does it seem like the worse for you the food is the better it tastes?
text: Imagine your body is like a little car that needs fuel to run and play! A long, long time ago, it was really hard for people to find food that gave them lots of energy, like sweet sugar for quick power, or fatty foods to store energy for later, and even salty things that help your body work right. So, your body learned to say, "YUMMY! EAT LOTS!" whenever it found these special ingredients because they were so important for staying alive and strong. Now, grown-ups who make yummy snacks know your body still thinks that way! They put lots of those super-exciting ingredients like sugar, fat, and salt into things like cookies, chips, and candy. Your tongue and brain get super excited and say, "WOW! THIS IS THE BEST EVER!" because your body remembers how important those things used to be, even though now we have plenty of them. Healthy foods like apples and carrots are also great fuel for your car, but they don't have as much of that super-duper exciting stuff, so your brain doesn't scream "YIPPEE!" quite as loud, even though they make your car run really well too!

title: What is the purpose of the turnable dial around the face of a watch?
text: You know that spinny ring around your watch face? It's like a special little timer helper! Imagine you want to know how long it takes to eat your yummy cookies. You can turn that ring so the little triangle or dot on it points to the big hand (the minute hand) when you start eating. Then, when you're all done, you look at where the big hand is now, and the numbers on the spinny ring tell you how many minutes went by! It helps grown-ups keep track of how long things take, like how long until snack time is over, or how long they've been playing in the water, so they don't forget!

title: Who/what is Anonymous?
text: Imagine a big group of kids playing a game, but none of them are wearing name tags, and they don't have a captain or a leader. They all just decide together to do something, like tell on a big bully, or maybe play a trick on someone who's being mean. Anonymous is kind of like that, but for grown-ups on the internet! It's not one person, but lots and lots of people from all over the world who decide to work together, often to tell big companies or governments when they are doing something unfair or wrong. Nobody knows their real names, and they don't have a boss, they just act as one big group to make noise about things they care about, sometimes by playing tricky computer games to get attention.

title: Why is it often difficult to stay awake while reading, but as soon as you put the book down and try to sleep, you feel wide awake?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a little worker inside your head! When you're reading a book, your worker is busy following the story, looking at the words, and thinking about what happens next. It's a calm, quiet job, especially when you're comfy in your bed, and it makes your worker feel a bit sleepy because everything is so peaceful. But then, when you put the book down, your brain worker suddenly doesn't have the story to think about anymore! Instead of just going to sleep, it starts thinking about *everything else*: what you did today, what you'll do tomorrow, or even just wondering "Am I asleep yet?" All that new thinking makes your brain worker busy again and wide awake, even though your body is tired and wants to rest!

title: When you close your eyes and "look" at the sun, why is it that you see a reddish yellow color even through closed eyes?
text: The sun is super duper bright, so bright that even when you close your eyes, some of its strong light can still peek through your eyelids! Think of your eyelids like a thin, special curtain that's a little bit red and orange. When the bright white light from the sun tries to get through this curtain, your eyelids act like a colored window, soaking up most of the other colors and only letting the warm reddish-yellow colors pass through to your eyes. So you're not really seeing the sun directly, you're seeing the sun's light after your eyelids have painted it a cozy reddish-yellow color, like looking through a red lollipop wrapper!

title: How does Google Maps and other GPS calculate my estimated time of arrival?
text: Imagine Google Maps is like a super smart friend who helps you plan a trip to a fun place! First, it looks at the road you want to take and figures out how long it is, like

title: Why do all the planets appear on one horizontal plane in diagrams?
text: Imagine you're making a big, round pizza, but instead of dough, it's made of super-duper tiny dust and gas, and in the middle, that's where

title: Why did each (manned) Apollo Mission have a different crew?
text: Think of it like a super important game where lots and lots of brave people (astronauts!) wanted a turn to fly the amazing spaceship all the way to the moon! If the very same three people went every single time, then lots of other smart and brave friends wouldn't get a chance to learn how to fly it or see the moon for themselves. So, the grown-ups in charge (NASA) wanted to let different friends play so everyone could learn, get super good at flying, and share the amazing adventure. Plus, going to space is super, super hard work, so the astronauts needed a rest while new, fresh friends took their turn to explore!

title: Why are some redirecting urls like URL_0 just as long as the origanal urls?
text: Imagine a URL is like the address to your friend's house, like "Billy's house, on Happy Street, number 5, with the blue door." Sometimes, when you try to go to that address, a grown-up tells you, "Oh, Billy moved! His *new* address is 'Billy's house, on Sunshine Lane, number 12, next to the big tree, with the red roof.'" See? The new address isn't shorter, it's just a different, very specific address to tell you exactly where to go now. The computer doesn't always give you a shortcut; it just gives you the right, sometimes still long, path to the correct place!

title: How come people can taste substances that have been injected intravenously?
text: Imagine your body has a super special road system called blood that goes everywhere, like a secret highway! When a grown-up gives you a shot, the special medicine gets put directly onto this blood highway in your arm. The medicine then rides the blood highway all around your body, visiting all sorts of places. One of the places the blood highway goes to is your tongue, where you have tiny little "taste feelers" called taste buds. Even though the medicine didn't go in your mouth, when it travels through your blood to your tongue, those taste feelers can still notice it and say, "Hey, I taste something!" That's why you can taste it, because it got to your tongue from the inside, riding the blood highway!

title: how do computers tell time?
text: Imagine your computer has a tiny, super-fast little friend inside it with an amazing stopwatch! When a grown-up first tells the computer what time it is, like "it's 2 o'clock!", that little friend starts its stopwatch. It doesn't ever stop! It just keeps counting, "tick, tick, tick" super fast, way faster than you can count, even when the computer is turned off because a tiny battery keeps that friend awake and counting. So, when you turn your computer back on, it just looks at its stopwatch and says, "Aha! So much time has gone by, it must be 3 o'clock now!" That's how it always knows what time it is!

title: what's the difference between triple A games and other types of games?
text: Imagine you want to build a really big, super fancy LEGO castle! **Triple A games** are like that giant castle. Lots and lots of grown-ups work on it – artists to make it pretty, builders to make it strong, storytellers to make it exciting – and it costs a whole lot of money to buy all those bricks and pay everyone. It's usually super shiny and has all sorts of amazing details, like a big movie! **Other games** are more like building a cool LEGO car or a small house with just a few friends. It doesn't need as many grown-ups or as much money, and it might look a little different, but it can still be super, super fun to play with, and sometimes those smaller games have really clever ideas you wouldn't expect! So the big difference is mostly how many people and how much money it takes to make them, like a huge movie versus a smaller, homemade play.

title: Why do we grunt, yell, swear, ball our fists, grit our teeth, etc. when we're in pain?
text: When you get an ouchy feeling, your body wants to tell everyone! Sometimes you make a big noise like a yell or a grunt, just like when you cry when you're

title: If fevers are part of our body's natural process to fighting off infection / viruses, why do we often take medication to take away the fever?
text: Imagine your body is like a warm house, and when you get sick, it turns up the heat to cook the bad guys (like germs or viruses). That's your fever, and it's super helpful because the bad guys don't like it when it's too hot! But sometimes, the heat gets turned up *so high* that it makes you feel really sleepy, achy, and just not good, even though it's still fighting. So, the medicine is like a gentle helper that just turns the heat down a little bit, so you feel much more comfortable and can rest better. Your body can still fight the bad guys because it's still warm enough, but you don't feel so yucky while it's doing its job!

title: Why is it that some people can climb tall mountains like Mt. Everest without oxygen, but most people can't?
text: Okay, imagine the air we breathe is like yummy juice! Down here where we live, there's lots and lots of juice, so it's super easy to drink and feel strong. But high up on a super, super tall mountain like Everest, it's like someone drank almost all the juice, and there's only a tiny, tiny bit left! Most people, like you and me, would get super tired and dizzy trying to drink just a tiny sip, and our bodies would say "No way!" But some very special people are like real-life superheroes! They train for a very, very long time, making their bodies super good at using just that tiny bit of juice. Their lungs get extra, extra strong, so they can breathe just enough even when there's hardly any juice left. It's still super, super hard and dangerous, even for them, because there's so little air. That's why most people carry a big bottle of extra juice (which is like an oxygen tank) so they can drink easily and stay safe!

title: Why are aquariums lit by blue lights?
text: Imagine you're a little fishy living deep, deep down in the big, big ocean! When the sun shines on the water, some colors, like red, get all tired very quickly and can't go very deep. But blue light is super strong and can go all the way down to where the fish and pretty corals live! So, when we put blue lights in an aquarium, it's like we're making it feel just like their natural home in the ocean! It helps the fish and corals feel happy and healthy because it's the kind of light they're used to, and it also makes them look extra sparkly and beautiful, just like they do in the sea!

title: Why are the health benefits of sunlight not replicated by other light sources?
text: Sunlight is super special because it's like a big, warm hug that helps your body make something called Vitamin D! Vitamin D is like a superhero shield for your bones, making them strong, and it also helps you feel happy and have lots of energy. Now, the lights in your house, like your lamp or the lights on your TV, are good for helping you see things, like when you play with your toys. But they don't have the *secret ingredient* that sunlight has. Sunlight has a special kind of light, almost like tiny invisible sprinkles, that can tickle your skin just right to make that Vitamin D superhero shield. So, even though other lights are bright and helpful, they don't have the sun's magic touch to make your body strong and healthy in that special way. They're like yummy regular candies, but the sun is like a super-duper candy that gives you a special power!

title: What is Altitude Sickness and why do people get it?
text: Imagine you're climbing a super duper tall mountain, way up high in the sky! Up there, the air around us, which is like a big invisible blanket, gets much thinner. Inside that air is something super important called oxygen, which is what helps your body run, jump, and play. When the air blanket is thin, there's not as much oxygen for your body to breathe easily. Your body gets a little bit confused and tired because it's not getting enough of that special air, and that's why you might start to feel a headache, a bit dizzy, or like your tummy hurts. That feeling is called altitude sickness!

title: How were the values of constants such as e and pi historically determined, and why do these constants find themselves in so many formulae?
text: Imagine you have a round cookie. To find out how much frosting goes all the way around the edge, people measured it and then measured straight across the middle. They found the edge was

title: How does working out in the morning give us *more* energy through out the day when our body is using energy to work out?
text: Imagine your body is like a toy car, and energy is the special battery juice. When you play with your toy car in the morning (that's like working out!), you use up some of its battery juice. But here's the cool secret: when your body sees you're using up juice, it gets super smart! It starts making *extra* special juice for the rest of the day, like a secret juice factory inside you just woke up and started buzzing. So, even though you used a little bit of juice in the morning, your body makes sure you have *more* for later, making you feel bouncy and ready to play and learn all day long, instead of feeling sleepy!

title: Why are birds (i.e. Parrots, Crows, Hawks, etc) so intelligent if they have such small brains?
text: You know how sometimes a small toy box can have tons and tons of tiny LEGOs packed inside, even more than a big messy box with just a few big blocks? Bird brains are a bit like that! Even though they are small, like a little grape or a walnut, they are super-duper packed with lots and lots of tiny, special "thinking cells" all squeezed together really tightly. It's like they have a super efficient little brain where all the brain helpers are working super close and fast, which makes them very smart and able to learn lots of cool things, even with a small brain!

title: Why do some foods taste better cold and some hot? Is it strictly cultural, or are certain tastes more apt to be pleasurable at a certain temperature biologically?
text: Okay, imagine your tongue and your nose are like super-duper detectives trying to figure out all the yummy secrets in your food! When food is warm, it sends up more little smell messages to your nose, which makes everything taste stronger and more exciting, like a warm chocolate chip cookie that just came out of the oven! The warmth also makes some parts of the food melt and feel soft and cozy in your mouth, like warm soup. But when food is cold, it can make some tastes, like super sweet or refreshing ones, feel extra special and tingly on your tongue, like a scoop of ice cream on a sunny day! Our bodies also just feel happy and comfy with warm things when it's chilly, and cold things when it's hot. So it's a little bit about how the food talks to your nose and tongue differently with hot or

title: How does 20th Century Fox, Universal, Sony Pictures and Lionsgate own rights to some of Marvel's characters in film even though Marvel made those characters originally?
text: Imagine you have a giant box of the coolest superhero toys ever, like Spider-Man and the X-Men! You love them so much, but a long, long time ago, you didn'

title: Joyful people are said to have a twinkle in their eyes, what physically changes in a depressed or sad person's eyes to create the "dead eye" effect?
text: Okay, imagine your eyes are like little shiny windows! When someone is super happy, their windows open really wide, like they're excited to see everything! And sometimes, a tiny bit of happy, super smooth water (not crying water, just shiny water) makes them extra sparkly. When light from the sun or a lamp hits those wide, smooth, shiny windows, it bounces off super bright, like a little star, and that's the twinkle! Also, when you smile, the happy muscles around your eyes make them look extra bright and alive. But when someone is very sad or tired, their eyes might not open as wide, like they're feeling sleepy, and they might not have that super shiny, smooth water on them. So, when the light tries to bounce off, it can't make a big, bright sparkle. It's like the windows are a bit closed and not super shiny, so the light just doesn't bounce back as much, making them look quiet, like the lights are turned down low and they don't have that happy sparkle.

title: How is the ink permanantly sticking onto the paper but can be erased from the hand?
text: Imagine paper is like a super thirsty sponge with lots and lots of tiny, tiny holes all over it. When you write with a pen, the ink quickly soaks deep down into all those little holes, like water going into a sponge. Once it dries, it's stuck in there really, really tight, like mud drying in cracks, and it doesn't want to come out! But your hand is different. Your skin is super smooth, like a shiny slide, and it doesn't have those deep holes for the ink to go into. So when you get ink on your hand, it just sits right on top, like a little puddle. When you wash your hands with soap and water, the water and soap just push that little puddle of ink right off, 'poof!', because it was never really stuck inside your skin like it was in the paper's holes.

title: Why do tennis players use stationary cycle right after a match?
text: Imagine you've been running super-duper fast and playing really hard, like when you chase your friends! Your legs get very, very tired. When tennis players play, their muscles work even harder! So, right after, they hop on a stationary bike, which is like a bicycle that doesn't go anywhere, and pedal super slowly. It's like gently walking after running really fast, instead of just stopping suddenly. This slow pedaling helps their muscles calm down nicely and also helps push out all the 'tired juice' that can make their muscles feel ouchy later. By doing this, their muscles don't hurt as much and get ready to play and run fast again tomorrow!

title: what is a superfluid?
text: Imagine your juice or honey. When you pour it, it goes *plop plop* and can be a bit sticky, right? It slows down because it rubs against the cup and itself. Now, imagine a special, super-duper magic juice called a superfluid! This juice is so slippery, it doesn't rub against anything at all. It can flow super fast forever, without ever slowing down, like it has no brakes! It's so amazing, it can even climb up the sides of its cup all by itself, as if it's trying to escape, because it's too slippery to stay put. It's like the slipperiest, fastest, never-stopping liquid you could ever imagine!

title: Why Do We Tend To Notice Things in Pairs? Or, why does there seem to be a general consensus that even numbers are more, "attractive"?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little helper that loves to make things neat and tidy! When you see things, your brain really likes to put them into groups that feel balanced and complete. The easiest way to make a balanced group is with two things, like your two shoes or your two eyes – they just *feel* right together. That's why we notice pairs so much, because our brain thinks, "Yay, a happy, balanced group!" And when we talk about numbers, "even" numbers (like 2, 4, 6) are special because you can always share them perfectly with a friend, or split them into two equal parts, just like cutting a sandwich in half for you and your friend so everyone gets the same amount. Things that can be split perfectly or come in nice, balanced pairs just make our brains feel happy and organized, like everything is in its right place and fair!

title: Why does a real person who is speaking right next to me sound so different from a person on TV, apparently speaking right in front of me?
text: Okay, imagine your friend gives you a high-five right here. You feel their hand directly, right? That's like when someone talks next to you – their voice waves fly straight from their mouth to your ears, super fast and fresh! But when you see someone on TV, it's like their high-five first goes to a special robot ear (a microphone), then that robot sends a message through long, wiggly wires and computers, and then your TV's mouth (the speaker) makes the sound for you. The voice takes a long adventure through all those machines before it comes out of the TV, so it changes just a little bit along the way, like a drawing that got copied a few times. It's still their voice, but it's been on a big trip!

title: How do fishermen on those large trawlers with nets catch the exact fish they are looking for?
text: Imagine you really want to find your favorite toy, like your red car. You know it's usually in your toy box, not in the kitchen, right? Fish are kind of like that! Different kinds of fish like to live in different special spots in the big, big ocean. Some like to play near the top, some like to play way down deep, and some like to hang out in warm water while others like cold water. Fishermen are like super smart detectives! They've learned over many, many years where their favorite fish like to swim and eat. They know the special 'fish neighborhoods.' They also

title: What is a Health Savings Account?
text: Imagine you have a super special piggy bank, but this piggy bank is only for when you need to go to the doctor, get medicine, or buy cool new glasses! Your grown-ups can put money into this special piggy bank, and it's like magic money because the government doesn't take a little bit of it away first, so more money goes in! Then, when you need to pay for your boo-boo cream or a check-up, you use the money from this special piggy bank. And the best part? If you don't use all the money this year, it stays there for next year and the year after, and it can even get bigger all by itself, like a little money tree! It's a special way for grown-ups to save money just for staying healthy.

title: How exactly did OJ Simpson get a not guilty verdict? The evidence seemed insurmountable
text: Imagine two teams of grown-ups telling a very important story to a group of other grown-ups called a jury. One team said, "O.J. did a very bad thing because we found his stuff there!" But the other team, O.J.'s lawyers, said, "Hold on! The police who found the stuff made big mistakes! They didn't follow all the rules, and maybe some of them didn't like O.J. and even made things look worse for him, or even put things there!" And then there was a special glove that was supposed

title: Why do we pee our beds as kids, but not as adults?
text: Okay, imagine your body has a special helper called your bladder, which is like a little balloon that holds your pee. When you're a tiny kid, your brain (the boss of your body) and your bladder are still learning how to talk to each other really well, especially when you're super sleepy at night. Your bladder is also a bit smaller, so it fills up faster, and sometimes you're just sleeping so, so soundly that your brain doesn't get the message saying, "Hey! Time to wake up and go potty!" As you get bigger, your brain and your bladder learn to be super good friends and talk perfectly all night long. Your bladder also gets bigger so it can hold more pee, and your brain gets really good at waking you up even if you're sleeping soundly, so you can run to the toilet before any accidents happen. It's just part of growing up and your body getting smarter!

title: Why does Rorschach hate Veidt's Plan while likes Truman's Hiroshima Bombing?
text: Okay, imagine Rorschach thinks the world is super simple, like a coloring book with only black and white crayons. He believes there are good people and bad people, and bad people *always*

title: Why are US congress member's allowed to retain their private careers and other outside business interests while serving the government?
text: Okay, imagine your friend has a lemonade stand, but they also help you build a super cool fort. They have two important things they do! A long, long time ago, when our country was just starting, the people who made the rules thought it would be good if the grown-ups who

title: Why does honey sometimes crystallise and go 'hard' in the jar?
text: Imagine honey is like a playground full of tiny, tiny sugar friends and a little bit of water. Usually, these sugar friends are floating all around, making the honey super drippy and runny. But sometimes, especially when it gets a bit chilly, or if they've been sitting in their jar for a long time, these sugar friends get a bit sleepy and decide to hold hands and cuddle up tight. When they all stick together like that, they make little tiny sugar castles. And when they build these tiny sugar

title: Why does a flight from London to Italy(2500km) cost about $70...but a flight from New York to Atlanta(800km) costs about $250 ?
text: Imagine airplanes are like big, flying buses! From London to Italy, there are lots and lots of different airplane companies that want to take you there. Because there are so many choices, they all

title: What does a virus or bacteria gain from making its host sick?
text: Okay, imagine tiny, tiny invisible little creatures, like super-duper small bugs that you can't even see! These bugs, called viruses and bacteria, want to do one super important thing: make more of themselves, like when you have baby toys! To do this, they need to live inside you, like you live in your house. Sometimes, when they're busy making lots and lots of baby bugs, it makes your body feel a bit yucky – maybe you get a cough, or a sneeze, or your tummy hurts. Those yucky feelings aren't fun for you, but they're like a special secret trick for the tiny bugs! When you cough or sneeze, little bits of them fly out into the air, helping them jump to a new friend's house so they can make more baby bugs

title: There's plenty of cow milk to buy, and some goat milk, but is there's a reason we don't produce and consume milk from other farm animals (like horses, pigs, etc)? What about cheese made from that milk?
text: You know how cows are super big and make lots and lots of yummy white milk for us to drink? They're like big, friendly milk machines, and they're usually happy to stand still while people milk them! Goats are a bit smaller, but they also give us good milk sometimes. But other farm animals, like oink-oink pigs or neigh-neigh horses, don't make nearly as much milk as cows do. Imagine trying to milk a piggy – they're small, have lots of tiny nipples, and they wiggle a lot! Horses are big, but they don't give a lot of milk, and it's mostly for their baby horses, not really for us. Also, their milk might taste a bit funny to us, not like the sweet cow milk we like. To make cheese, you need the milk to have special "clumpy bits" inside that stick together when you add a magic ingredient. Cow and goat milk have just the right kind of clumpy bits to make yummy cheese, but milk from pigs or horses doesn't have the same kind, so it's really hard to make it turn into cheese!

title: How do eyeglasses fix our vision?
text: Your eyes are like little cameras that take pictures of the world, but sometimes they get a bit confused and don't take a very clear picture, making everything look blurry, like a fuzzy drawing! Glasses are like magic windows that sit in front of your eyes. These special windows have a secret power: they gently push and pull the light that comes into your eyes, bending it just the right amount *before* it even reaches your eye-camera. This helps your eye-camera focus all the light perfectly, exactly where it needs to be, so that fuzzy drawing suddenly becomes super clear and easy to see! The glasses just help your eyes do their focusing job much, much better.

title: How does the UK justify that they have a reasonable claim over the Falkland Islands?
text: Imagine there's a special little island, like a tiny playground. The grown-ups in the UK say, "Hey, we found this playground a super long time ago, even before anyone else really knew about it!" And then, for a super, super long time, like since your great-great-grandparents were little kids, people from the UK have been living on that island, building houses and playing there. The most important thing is that the people who live on that island right now, the grown-ups and kids there, all really, really want to stay part of the UK's big family, like choosing which team they want to be on. They've told everyone very clearly that they want to be British, and the UK says, "Because they want to be with us, and we've been there for so long, it's our special island!"

title: Why are Americans so worried about losing jobs to other countries when their unemployment is at 4.5%?
text: Imagine almost all the grown-ups you know have a special job, like building houses or helping people. That's what having very low unemployment means – most people are busy working! But sometimes, a company that makes toys or clothes might decide it's cheaper to make those things very, very far away in another country. It's like if your favorite toy factory packed up and moved across the ocean. Even if lots of other grown-ups still have jobs, the people who worked at *that* toy factory would need to find new jobs, and that can be a bit scary. So, even when lots of grown-ups are working, people worry that *their* job, or jobs for their friends, might someday move far away. It's like how you might worry about your favorite crayon breaking, even if you have a whole big box of crayons.

title: Why does it take so long for death row inmates to be executed?
text: Imagine someone did something super, super wrong, like the worst thing ever, and the grown-ups in charge decided they should get the biggest, most serious punishment. But before that can happen, lots and lots of grown-ups, like very smart teachers and judges, need to check everything many, many times, like when you double-check your homework before giving it to your teacher. They want to be super, super sure they didn't make a mistake, because once it's done, it can't be undone, like when you spill juice and can't put it back in the cup. They keep asking, "Are we absolutely, positively sure?" and sometimes new clues come up, so they have to look again. All this careful checking and re-checking takes a very, very long time, sometimes even longer than you've been alive!

title: What is a "sigh," exactly, and why do we do it when we're sad or exasperated? Does every culture sigh?
text: A sigh is like taking a really, really big breath, much bigger than your normal little breaths, and then letting all that air out slowly with a sound like "whoooosh!" When you're sad, maybe your chest feels a little tight, like there's a big feeling stuck inside. A sigh helps stretch out your chest and lets out a little bit of that sad feeling, like letting a tiny bit of air out of a balloon so you can feel a little lighter. When you're exasperated, which means you're a bit frustrated or annoyed because something isn't working or someone is bothering you, a sigh is like blowing out that grumpy feeling, like saying "Oh brother!" without using words. It helps you push out that annoyance. And yes, people all over the world, no matter what language they speak or where they live, do sighs when they feel these big feelings, just like everyone smiles or cries!

title: how do big hotels keep their showers so hot and high pressured?
text: Imagine your house has a little kettle to make hot water for your bath, and maybe a small pump for your shower. Hotels are like super-giant houses! They have *enormous* kettles, like a swimming pool full of hot water that they keep warm all the time, just waiting for you. And instead of a little pump, they have super-duper strong pumps, like a giant muscle, that push the water *really* hard through big, thick pipes, so it zooms out of your shower head with lots of oomph! They have so much hot water and so many strong pumps because they know lots and lots of people want to take a shower at the same time, and they want everyone to have a super comfy one!

title: Why is quartz so useful in making watches?
text: Imagine you have a tiny, special rock called quartz. This rock is super neat because when you give it a little tickle with electricity, it starts to wiggle, wiggle, wiggle! But here's the magic part: it wiggles *exactly* the same number of times every single second, like a perfect little dancer who never misses a beat. Your watch has a tiny brain inside that counts these perfect wiggles. When it counts a super big number of wiggles (like 32,768!), it knows exactly one second has gone by. Because this special rock wiggles so perfectly and reliably, it helps your watch keep time super, super accurately, so you always know when it's snack time or bedtime!

title: If the Keystone Pipeline is approved, but the US withdraws from NAFTA, what will this mean in terms of oil trade through the pipeline?
text: Okay, let's pretend the Keystone Pipeline is like a super long, giant straw that goes from Canada to America to carry black, sticky oil. If it gets "approved," it means the grown-ups say, "Okay, you can build that big straw!" Now, NAFTA was like a special "best friends" rulebook for Canada, America, and Mexico that made it super easy and cheap for them to share toys, like that oil. If America says, "No more best friends rulebook!" and withdraws from NAFTA, it means they ripped up that special book. So, if the straw (pipeline) is built, it can still carry the oil from Canada to America. But because the "best friends" rulebook is gone, it might not be as easy or cheap anymore. The grown-ups might have to pay extra money (like a special fee) or follow new, trickier rules to send the oil through the straw. The oil can still move, but it just won't be as simple or free as before, like if you still share toys with your friend but now your parents make you pay a penny for each toy you give them.

title: Given that x-rays have more energy than visible light and radiowaves have less energy than visible light, how come visible light can't penetrate walls but x-rays and radiowaves can?
text:
Okay, imagine a wall is like a fence made of lots and lots of tiny, tiny sticks all super close together.

*   **X-rays** are like super tiny, super

title: If water and ice both have transparent properties, why is snow white?
text: Okay, imagine a giant, clear window. You can see right through it, right? That's like water or a big, smooth piece of ice – light just zips straight

title: Why is it colder at higher altitudes even though hot air rises?
