title: Can the POTUS issue Executive Order on withdrawing from NATO?
text: Imagine NATO is like a super big club where many countries are friends and promised to help each other if one of them ever gets into trouble. The President is like the grown-up leader of our

title: There are a surprising amount of people who believe any moon landings were a hoax. Why can't we use telescopes/powerful cameras to prove there was activity on the moon?
text: Okay, imagine the moon is like a super, super big playground that's really, really far away, like way up in the sky. When people went to the moon, they left some small toys there, like a little car (that's the rover!) and a flag. Now, if you're standing on the ground and looking at that playground way up high, you can see the whole playground, right? But can you see a tiny little toy car or a small flag on it from super far away? No, they're just too tiny! Even the biggest, fanciest spyglasses (that's what telescopes are) are like looking at that far-away playground. They can see the big playground (the moon) really well, but the little toys (the flags and cars) are just too small and too far away for us to spot them from Earth. It's like trying to see a tiny ant on a giant soccer field from a flying airplane – impossible!

title: Why do women's breasts get bigger before they have their period?
text: Imagine your body is like a very clever house that gets ready for things! Before a period, your body sends out special little 'messages' called hormones. These messages tell different parts of your body to get ready, just in case a tiny baby starts to grow inside. For your breasts, these messages tell them to drink a little extra water and get a tiny bit bigger and softer, almost like a sponge soaking up water. They are practicing for making milk, which they would do if there was a baby. It's just your body getting everything prepared, and then after your period, it realizes no baby is coming this time, so everything goes back to normal until the next practice run!

title: What is the recent ruling about the UK Parliament and Brexit mean for the people of the UK?
text: Imagine your country is like a big house, and the grown-ups who make all the rules for everyone are called Parliament. A while ago, our country decided it wanted to leave a big club of

title: What causes those random shudders that happen seemingly for no reason?
text: Sometimes your body just does a little wiggle, like a quick shake! It's super normal. Sometimes it's because your body feels a tiny bit chilly, even if you don't notice it much. Or, it's like your muscles are just doing a super fast little stretch, like when you stretch your arms after a nap. Your body is just doing its own thing, having a quick little 'boop!' moment, and it's totally okay!

title: What is Net Neutrality and why is there a lot of controversy surrounding it?
text:
Imagine the internet is like a big, magical playground where all your favorite games, videos, and websites live. Net Neutrality is like a special rule that says the playground owner (your internet company) can't make some games super fast and easy to play because someone paid them extra, while making other games really slow and boring, or even hiding some games from you completely! It means every game is equally available and fast for you to play with, no matter who made it or if they paid the playground owner more money.

The big argument about it is like this: Some people say, "Yay! This rule is great! It means everyone gets to play fairly, and the playground owner can't make me pay extra just to play with my favorite game quickly!" They like it because it keeps the internet open and fair for everyone, from big companies to small new websites. But other people (and the playground owners themselves) might say, "Hmm, maybe we should be allowed to make some games faster if someone pays us more, because then we'll have more money to build even cooler new parts of the playground for everyone!" They think they should be able to manage their playground how they want, and that without being able to charge extra, they might not build new, faster playgrounds. So it's a big disagreement about who should decide how the playground works and if everyone should always be treated exactly the same.

title: Why would you ever need to know the anything beyond the 2nd derivative of an equation?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing with a toy car! The first number tells us *where* your car is right now on the floor. The next number tells us *how fast* your

title: What makes blue ink more memorable than black ink?
text: Imagine you have a big pile of black socks, and almost all your socks are black. But then, you get one pair of bright blue socks! When you put on the blue socks, they feel special and different from all the other black socks, right? You notice them more! It's kind of like that with ink. Most grown-ups use black ink for lots and lots of things, like writing in books or on papers. So, when you see something written in blue ink, it's like those special blue socks. Your eyes notice it more because it's not the usual color. It stands out from all the black words, and our brains are good at remembering things that are different or pop out. That's why the blue ink can feel more special and easier to remember!

title: Why is it important to preheat the oven before you cook?
text: Imagine your oven is like a super cozy, warm blanket for your food! If you jump into a cold bed, it takes a long time to get warm, right? And maybe you shiver a bit first. But if you jump into a bed that's already nice and toasty, you feel warm right away! It's the same for your food. When the oven is already hot, like that warm blanket, your food starts cooking perfectly and evenly all over, right away. This helps your cookies get yummy and crispy, and your chicken cooks all the way through without being raw inside or burnt outside. If you put food in a cold oven, it takes a long time for the oven to get hot, and by then, maybe one part of your food is cooked too much while another part isn't cooked enough. So, we preheat the oven to make sure it's super warm and ready to give your food a perfect, cozy cooking hug from the very start!

title: How does rolling upon impact with the ground after a long fall save you from bodily harm?
text: Imagine you're running really fast and then you try to stop *super* quick, like running into a wall! *Ouch!* That would hurt a lot because all your fast energy has to go away in a tiny, tiny second. Your body doesn't like that. But if you're running fast and then you slide on your knees or roll on the grass, it takes a little longer for you to stop, right? When you roll after a fall, it's like that! Instead of your body hitting the ground *bam!* all at once and stopping super fast, which can break bones or make big boo-boos, rolling helps you slow down over a little bit more time and lets different parts of your body touch the ground one after another. It's like spreading out the "ouch" over more time and more of your body, so no one spot gets hurt too much at once, and it feels much softer and safer!

title: when muscles get stronger they grow. How do our lungs get stronger if you go for a long run?
text: Imagine your muscles are like little toy cars. When you play with them a lot, you add more parts, and they get bigger and stronger! But your lungs are more like super smart balloons inside you. When you run and play a lot, your lungs don'

title: Why can't touchscreens recognize a touch while a finger is being held on it in another location?
text: Imagine your tablet screen is like a special drawing board that has lots and lots of tiny, invisible sensors, like little eyes. When you put your finger on it, it's like you

title: How did universities and hospitals and such charge so little for services in the past and still turn a profit when they struggle today even charging so much?
text: Imagine a long, long time ago, hospitals and schools were like simple toy shops. They had basic wooden blocks and simple dolls. These things didn't cost much to make, so

title: Why is it that a 10 minute 720p video I record with my phone is 700mb, yet a 720p 1.5 hour long movie uses less data?
text: Imagine your videos are like drawings, and 720p means both your drawing and the movie's drawing are made on the same size paper. When your phone draws, it uses a *lot* of crayons and draws every tiny detail, even if it's just a short drawing, making it a very thick and heavy stack of paper. But when the movie people make their long movie drawing, they are super clever! They look for parts that are the same, like a big blue sky, and instead of drawing every single tiny blue dot, they just say "it's blue here" and save a lot of crayon. They also might only draw the really important stuff and skip tiny details you might not even notice. So, even though their movie drawing is much, much longer, because they're so good at making it light and simple, it ends up being a much smaller stack of paper than your phone's super detailed but short drawing!

title: How does an air fryer work?
text: Okay, imagine you have your yummy chicken nuggets or french fries. An air fryer is like a super-duper special oven that's also a bit like a very powerful hair dryer! Inside, it has a heater that makes the air super hot, like when the sun warms up the playground. Then, there's a little fan, like the one that cools you down, but this one is extra strong and blows all that super hot air really, really fast all around your food in a special basket. This hot air zoom-zooms everywhere, cooking your food nice and evenly, and because it's so hot and fast, it makes the outside of your food wonderfully crispy and crunchy, just like magic, without needing lots of oil! So, it's just hot air blowing fast to make yummy, crispy food.

title: Who physically writes out things like Executive Orders?
text: Imagine the President is like a very busy grown-up with lots of big ideas for our whole country, just like your mommy or daddy has big ideas for your family. He doesn't sit down with a pen and write all the words himself, because he has so many other important things to do! Instead, he has many very smart helpers who work for him, kind of like super-smart teachers or big brothers and sisters who are good at writing. He tells them exactly what his big idea is, and these helpers use their computers and special paper to carefully write down all the important words, making sure everything is just right. Then, the President reads it to make sure it's perfect, and he uses his special pen to sign his name, which makes it a real rule for everyone.

title: How can I know if a News Source is biased or providing 'Alternative Facts'?
text: Imagine someone tells you a story about what happened at the playground. Sometimes, that person might only tell you the part of the story that makes *them* look good, or only talk about

title: In the age of computers, why do traffic cops take ages to write a traffic ticket by hand? Why not have the system that scans your drivers license and creates a ticket for the next available court date?
