title: If the Earth experienced heating and cooling all the time before humans were around, what triggered the switch to cooling when it got too hot and heating when it got to cold all on its own and why won't that happen with the current climate changes?
text: Okay, imagine Earth is like a giant house, and it has some super slow, natural ways to keep itself warm or cool, like a very sleepy thermostat. When it got too hot, things like rain would slowly wash some of

title: Who is Ajit Pai and why is he such a threat to net neutrality?
text: Imagine the internet is like a big road where all your favorite cartoons and games live. Net neutrality was like a super important rule that said all the cars (websites) on this road had to go the same speed, and no one could make some cars go super fast because they paid extra, or make other cars go super slow. Everyone was treated fairly! Ajit Pai was like a grown-up who was in charge of making the rules for this big internet road. He was a "threat" to net neutrality because he decided to change that fair rule. He thought it was okay for the internet companies to make some cars go super fast if they paid extra money, and maybe make other cars go super slow or even block them, unless *they* paid too. So, he wanted to take away the rule that made everything on the internet equal for everyone, and let the internet companies pick favorites.

title: How are syringe needles made?
text: Imagine you have a super long, super skinny metal straw, like the tiniest straw ever! First, grown-ups take that long, skinny straw and make one end super, super pointy, like the tip of a very sharp pencil, so it can make a tiny hole easily. Then, they make sure the whole straw is super, super clean and smooth, like a shiny new toy, so it doesn't hurt and no yucky germs can get inside. Finally, they put a little colorful plastic hat on the other end of the straw, and that's the part that connects to the medicine squirty toy. That's how they make those tiny, shiny needles!

title: Why, when you get a "oh crap I have to pee now moment", does the feeling get worse the closer you get to the toilet?
text: Imagine your bladder is like a little balloon inside you, and when it gets full, it sends a message to your brain saying, "Hey! I need to let some water out!" When you have that "oh crap" moment, your brain knows the balloon is super full and really wants to empty. Then, as you run closer and closer to the toilet, your brain gets super excited, like when you're almost at the playground! It sees the toilet and thinks, "YAY! We're almost there! Freedom for the balloon!" And because your brain is so excited and knows help is *right there*, it makes the feeling of needing to pee even *louder* and *more urgent*, almost like it's saying, "Hurry up! We're so close! Let's go, let's go, let's go!" It's not that there's suddenly *more* pee, it's just your brain making the "need to go" feeling much, much stronger because it knows you're finally going to make it.

title: What protects The United States from becoming a dictatorship?
text: Imagine our country is like a big playground, and we have lots of grown-ups who help run it. To make sure no one person can be a super bossy dictator and make all the

title: How is this light effect created in 90s cartoon animation?
text: Okay, imagine your favorite cartoon character is drawn on a super special clear plastic sheet, kind of like a see-through paper! If they need to glow or have a cool light effect around them, the artists don't draw it right on the character. Nope! They get *another* clear plastic sheet, and on *that* one, they carefully draw just the glowy light part, sometimes using paint that's a bit see-through or sprayed on to make soft

title: Why are clouds flat on the bottom or appear this way?
text: Okay, imagine the sky is like a giant house with different floors! Clouds are made of tiny, tiny bits of water, like super-duper small raindrops. These little water bits only like to get together and make a cloud when it's cold enough. Down low, closer to us, the air is usually warm, so the water bits are too shy to come out. But as you go higher and higher in the sky, it gets colder and colder, like when you go outside on a chilly day. There's a special invisible "floor" in the sky where it suddenly gets *just* cold enough for all the water bits to say, "Okay, let's make a cloud now!" Since all the clouds find this same "cold enough" floor, they all start forming at that exact same height, making their bottoms look super flat, like they're sitting on an invisible table!

title: Why are our eyes spherical?
text: Imagine your eye is like a special camera that helps you see! It's round, like a bouncy ball, for a few super good reasons. First, being round helps it collect light from *everywhere* around you, like a

title: Why is the 40-yard dash the magical number for gauging a football player's speed (as opposed to some other metric)?
text: Imagine you're playing a game of tag or running to catch a ball your friend threw! In football, players run a lot, but they don't usually run *super* far in a straight line without stopping, like all the way across the park. They often run for a certain amount of space to catch a ball, or to get away from someone trying to tag them. Grown-ups who watch football noticed that 40 yards is like the perfect 'quick run' distance! It's not too short, like just taking a few steps, which wouldn't show how fast you *really* are when you need to zoom. And it's not too long, like running a whole mile, because players don't usually do that in one quick burst during a game. It's just right to see how fast someone can go when they really need to run fast to catch a ball or get past the other team, like a perfect little sprint for what happens a lot in football!

title: How does our brain "edit out" our nose from our line of sight?
text: Your nose is actually always right there in front of your eyes! But your brain is super, super smart, like a very helpful friend inside your head. It knows that your nose isn't the interesting part when you're looking at your favorite toy or a yummy cookie. So, your brain just decides to be a little bit sneaky and not show you your nose, kind of like when you're really focused on building a tall tower and you don't even notice the floor you're sitting on. It just shows you all the fun and important things you want to see!

title: Your net worth is a billion. Where do you get your spending money?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper, ginormous toy box, bigger than your whole house! Inside, you don't have a billion dollars in coins, because that would be

title: Why do so many fast food drive thrus have 2 windows, but always have you pull to the second window?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing with your friends, and you all want ice cream! The first window is like where you tell the grown-up what flavor you want and give them your pocket money. While they're getting your ice cream ready, another grown-up at the second window is already giving the *last* kid their ice cream. So, they have two windows to help lots and lots of cars get their yummy food super-duper fast! You always go to the second window to get your food because that's where the grown-ups give you your warm, fresh food, and it helps the line move quicker so everyone can get their snacks without waiting too long!

title: Is it true that smoke from incense and candles is more harmful than cigarette smoke?
text: That's a super interesting question! Imagine smoke is like tiny, tiny invisible dust that floats in the air. When you breathe it in, those tiny dust bits go into your lungs, which are like balloons inside you that help you breathe. Now, smoke from candles and incense also has these tiny dust bits, and if you breathe *lots and lots* of it, it's not super good for your lungs, just like breathing a lot of regular dust isn't great. But cigarette smoke is different! It has those tiny dust bits *plus* a whole bunch of extra, super sticky, super yucky stuff mixed in, like special bad glue that sticks to your lungs and makes them very, very sick over time. Think of it like this: a little bit of regular dust isn't great, but a big cloud of special, super sticky, super yucky, *poisonous* dust is much, much worse. So, even though no smoke is really good for you, the smoke from cigarettes has way more extra bad things that make it much more harmful for your body, especially if you breathe it a lot.

title: What is Phagocytosis?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool playground, and sometimes tiny, tiny messy things or yucky germs try to sneak in. But don't worry! Your body has special little helpers, like hungry little Pac-Men! When these helpers, called 'phagocytes' (say that 'fag-oh-sites'), see something yucky or something that shouldn't be there, they open their mouth really wide, gobble it up, and make it disappear! *Munch, munch, munch!* They eat all the bad stuff so your body stays super clean and healthy, just like how you eat your food to grow big and strong, but they eat the bad guys instead!

title: How important is the moon to life as we know it?
text: The moon is super, super important, like a best friend for our Earth! Imagine the moon is like a big magnet for the ocean water. It pulls the water up and down, making the ocean go high and low, which we call tides. These tides are really important for lots of sea animals to find food and places to live. Also, the moon helps our Earth spin nice and steady, not too wobbly. If our Earth wobbled too much, the weather would be super crazy, sometimes too hot and sometimes too cold, and it would be really hard for plants and animals and even us to live happily. So, the moon helps keep our world just right, making it a good home for everyone!

title: considering all factors, is there a more environmentally safe alternative to pipelines?
text: Imagine you have a super-long invisible straw that carries your juice from the kitchen all the way to your bedroom without you having to carry it. That's kind of like a pipeline! It's a big tube that goes underground and moves a lot of stuff, like oil, from one place to another. Now

title: How do composers write music?
text: Imagine a composer is like a chef, but instead of cooking yummy food, they cook up beautiful sounds! They get ideas from everywhere – maybe they see a happy bird, or feel a little sad, or imagine a big adventure in space. They have a special "sound brain" that can hear whole songs inside their head, even before anyone plays them. Then, they use special "music letters" called notes, and write them down on "music paper" – it's like a secret code for sounds! They decide which sounds go high or low, fast or slow, loud or quiet, to make it sound just right and tell their sound story. Sometimes they try different sounds until it's perfect, like building with LEGOs until your castle looks amazing. And when it's all written down, other people can read their "sound code" and play the music for everyone to enjoy!

title: Why are penny smasher machines at national parks, amusement parks, etc. allowed when when destroying or defacing currency is illegal?
text: Okay, imagine money is like your favorite drawing. Usually, you shouldn't rip it up or draw all over it because it makes it hard for grown-ups to use to buy things like yummy snacks or cool toys. But pennies are a little bit special! They are so, so tiny, and the metal they're made of actually costs more than the penny itself. So, the grown-ups who make the rules about money know that when you squish a penny to make a fun souvenir, you're not trying to be naughty or trick anyone. You're just making a special flat coin to remember your trip, and because pennies are so small and not worth much, they say it's totally okay to squish them!

title: Why do the almonds in Hershey's w/ Almonds, taste unlike any other almonds?
text: Okay, imagine a plain almond is like a little nut that lives on a tree. When Hershey's makes their chocolate bar, those almonds go on a special adventure! First, they get a warm hug, kind of like when we toast bread to make it yummy and crunchy. This makes them smell extra nutty and gives them a special crunch. Then, they get a *big*, warm, sweet hug from the melted chocolate! The chocolate is so sweet and creamy, and it gets all over the almond. When the chocolate hugs the almond, it changes how the almond tastes, just like when you dip a plain cookie in milk – it tastes different and extra yummy, right? The chocolate's sweetness and creaminess mix with the almond's nutty taste to make a super special flavor that's just for Hershey's, and it's not like any other plain almond you might eat!

title: How possible is it to have a helicarrier (like the one from Marvel's Avengers) and how would it work or why wouldn't it?
text: Imagine a super-duper big boat that can fly, with lots of airplanes on top, like a giant flying island! That's a helicarrier. Is it possible for real? Well, it's like trying to lift a whole house into the sky with just a few toy balloons – it's super, super hard and probably impossible right now! In the movies, it works because it has giant, super-strong fans underneath, like the biggest helicopter blades ever, that spin super fast and push air down really, really hard to lift the whole thing up. It would need engines stronger than all the rocket ships put together to make those fans work! But in real life, it wouldn't work because it's just too, too heavy, like trying to lift an elephant with one finger. We don't have engines strong enough to lift something that big, and it would need so much fuel, like drinking an entire ocean of juice every minute, that it couldn't stay up for long. Plus, the wind would push it around like a tiny feather, and it would be super expensive, costing more money than all the toys in the world! So, it's a super cool

title: Why would a president not choose cabinet members with longtime experience in that's cabinet's area of governance?
text: Imagine you're building a super big fort! You need helpers to make it awesome. Sometimes, you pick someone who's super good at building forts because they've built lots of them before – that's like choosing someone with lots of experience. But sometimes, the president might pick someone who hasn't built forts their whole life. Why? Maybe that person has a *brand new* idea for a secret tunnel you never thought of, or they're really good at making sure everyone plays fair and works together, even if they don't know every single fort-building trick. Or maybe the president just really trusts that person to help them build *their* kind of fort, exactly how they want it, and listen to all their ideas!

title: How is it that the words "comb", "bomb", and "tomb" spelled similarly but all sound very different?
text: That's a super smart question, like you've found a secret code in our words! You see, English words can be a bit silly sometimes. Even though "comb," "bomb," and "tomb" look like brothers because they have the same letters at the end, they actually say their names very differently. Imagine the letters are like friends playing together. In "comb," the 'o' makes a long 'oh' sound, and the 'b' at the end is super quiet, like it's hiding! In "bomb," the 'o' makes a short 'ah' sound, like when you open your mouth wide, and the 'b' is loud and clear. Then in "tomb," the 'o' makes a long 'oo' sound, like a ghost, and the 'b' is quiet again, just like in "comb." It's because English words don't always follow the same rules, and sometimes letters team up to make all sorts of different sounds, even when they look the same! It's tricky, but you just learn them one by one.

title: Why does water not catch fire?
text: Okay, imagine fire is like a super hungry monster that loves to eat special food, like wood or paper, to get super hot and big. Water is *not* that kind of food for the fire monster! Think of it this way: water is made from two things, hydrogen and oxygen, that already had their own big, hot "fire party" a long, long time ago to become water. So, water is already like the "leftovers" or the "finished party" – it can't have another fire party and burn again because it's already done that! Instead of food, water is like a big wet blanket that makes the fire monster cold and helps put it to sleep, so it can't eat any more.

title: What are the benefits of consuming alkaline (pH > 7) food and drink? Does it have any merit?
text: Imagine your body is like a super smart house, and it really likes to keep the temperature just right, not too hot and not too cold. It has special helpers that always make sure the temperature stays perfect! Some grown-ups talk about "alkaline" food, which is like food that isn't sour, like some veggies. They think eating lots of these foods can make your body less "sour" (we call this pH) and help it be healthier. But here's the cool part: your body is so, so clever! Your tummy has super strong "sour" juices to break down all your food, no matter what you eat. And your blood, which goes everywhere in your body, has its own special helpers that always, always keep it at just the right "temperature" or "sourness" level, no matter if you eat a sour lemon or a non-sour cucumber. So, while eating yummy fruits and veggies is super good for you because they have vitamins that make you strong and help you grow big, it's not because they change how "sour" or "not sour" your body is. Your body does a fantastic job of keeping itself balanced all by itself!

title: Why is the night sky more clear after it rains?
text: Imagine the air is usually a bit messy, like a room with lots of tiny, tiny dust and other invisible bits floating around, making it a little hazy and harder to see things far away, like the stars. When it rains, it's like the sky is taking a big, wonderful shower! The raindrops are like tiny cleaning sponges that fall through the air and grab all those dusty, hazy bits, pulling them down to the ground. So, after the rain shower, the air is super clean and clear, just like when you wash a dirty window, and because there's nothing in the way anymore, you can see all the twinkling stars much, much better and they look extra bright!

title: My science teacher said, in physics 5x5=30 but in traditional mathematics 5x5=25. However in physics 5.0x5.0=25. why?
text:
Okay, imagine you have some yummy cookies!

*   **When you do regular math and say "5 x 5 = 25",** it's like saying you

title: How did ancient people know why were planets and what weren't?
text: Imagine you're looking up at the night sky, full of tiny sparkly lights! Most of those lights are like stickers stuck on a giant black ceiling – they always stay in the same spot next to each other, even as the whole ceiling slowly turns. But ancient people, who spent a lot of time looking up, noticed something super special: a few of those lights were a bit naughty! Instead of staying put like the other stickers, these special lights would slowly, slowly move from one spot to another over many nights, like little bugs crawling across the ceiling. They called these special moving lights "wanderers" (which is what "planet" actually means!), and they knew they were different from all the other lights that stayed still. They didn't know *what* they were made of like we do now (big round rocks!), but they knew *how* they behaved was different because they saw them wiggle and wander across the sky while all the other stars stayed put.

title: What does the EPA freeze actually affect?
text: Imagine we have a special helper called the EPA, and their job is like being a superhero for our planet! They make sure grown-ups and big companies don't make too much yucky stuff that goes into our air and water, so we can all breathe fresh air, have clean water to play in, and animals can be safe. A "freeze" means our superhero helper is taking a nap or being very quiet. They're not making new rules right now to keep things clean, and they're not checking as much to make sure everyone is following the old rules. So, when the helper is napping, it means there might be more chances for some grown-ups to make the air a little dirtier or the water a little yuckier, because no one is reminding them to be careful, and our planet doesn't get as much protection from the messy stuff.

title: What about military training SO good at creating early risers?
text: Imagine you have a super important game to play or a really fun trip to the park with all your friends, and it starts super early, even before the sun is fully up! Everyone has to be there on time, ready to go, otherwise the game can't start or you might miss the bus. In the military, the grown-ups have very important jobs to do, like protecting people or helping others, and these jobs often start super early. They practice waking up early *every single day*, just like you practice drawing or riding your bike. Because they do it so much, and because it's so important for everyone to be ready together at the same time, their bodies and brains get really, really good at it. It becomes a habit, like brushing your teeth, so their bodies just know it's time to pop up when the alarm rings, ready for their big day!

title: Why do we feel strong emotions in our chest?
text: You know how sometimes when you're super happy, or really sad, or maybe a little scared, you feel a funny wobbly or tight feeling right in the middle of your chest? That's because your brain, which is like the super smart boss of your whole body and all your feelings, wants to let everyone know there's a big feeling happening! When your brain has a really strong emotion, it sends out little invisible messages, like tiny helpers, all over your body. Lots of these messages go to your heart and the muscles around it in your chest. These messages make your heart beat a little bit faster or even sometimes squeeze a tiny bit, and that's what makes you feel that funny fluttery or tight feeling. It's just your body's way of showing how big your feelings are!

title: How does a hacker get caught? Couldn't they just go buy a $200 laptop, install their hacking tools from a cd or thumb drive, and then take it to a public wifi place (library, Starbucks, etc)? Then burn their stolen hacking data to a CD when they get home?
text: Imagine you're playing hide-and-seek, but everything you do leaves tiny, invisible glitter! Even if you buy a new toy (the laptop) with your allowance money, the store might have a camera that sees you, or your mom might remember you bought it. When you go to the library or Starbucks to play on their computer internet (their Wi-Fi), it's like going to a big playground. Even if you don't tell anyone your name, the playground always remembers *who* was there and *when* – like special grown-up eyes watching the computers. Every time your computer talks to another computer, it's like leaving little "I was here!" notes. Even if you try to hide these notes, grown-up detectives have super-duper magnifying glasses and special tools to find them. They can see where those notes came from, which computer made them, and sometimes even follow the path all the way back to you, even if you try to hide it on a CD. It's really hard to be totally invisible when you're playing with computers because they remember almost everything!

title: Why is there little to no atheist representation in US congress?
text: Imagine you're picking a captain for your play group, and most of your friends really, really love playing with cars. When it's time to pick a captain, lots of kids will probably

title: How do broken bones fuse together?
text: Imagine your bone is like a strong, hard stick, and sometimes, oops, it breaks! When that happens, your body is super smart and knows just what to do. It sends tiny little helper cells, like busy construction workers, right to where the break is. First, they clean up any messy bits. Then, they start building a soft, squishy bridge, kind of like Play-Doh, to connect the two broken ends. This squishy bridge isn't strong enough yet! So, special bone-building workers come next. They take lots of tiny building blocks (like calcium from your milk!) and slowly turn that soft bridge into new, super-hard bone, making it strong again, just like it was before. It takes a little while, and you have to keep it still so the workers can do their best job, and then your bone is all fixed up!

title: If musical scales of the same type (e.g. the major scales) sound the same but a different pitch, why are complex scales used over the simplest one?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super happy song, and you can sing it high up like a bird or low down like a big bear, but it's still a happy song! That's like using different major scales – they all sound happy, just higher or lower. But what if you want to sing a *sad* song? Or a *super exciting* song? Or maybe even a *little bit spooky* song? You can't make all those different feelings with just the happy notes, can you? Different kinds of scales are like having different flavors of ice cream! A happy major scale is like vanilla, but a minor scale is like chocolate (a bit darker!), and other fancy scales are like strawberry or mint chip.

title: How are dictionaries compiled? How do words get picked to be in a dictionary? How do they not 'forget' to put in a word?
text: Imagine a dictionary is like a super-duper big book that knows almost all the words! People called "word detectives" or "language explorers" make these books. They don't just sit in one place; they listen very carefully to what grown-ups say, they read lots and lots of books, newspapers, and even look at things on the internet, always searching for words. When they find a word that many, many people are using, and it's not just a silly made-up word that disappears quickly, they write it down. It's like if everyone in your class starts saying a new funny word, the word detectives notice! They also write down exactly what that word means, like explaining what "happy" means. They have really big lists and computers that help them remember all the words they've found and all the words that are already in the book, so they don't forget any important ones. They're always adding new words that become popular and checking the old ones, making sure the dictionary is always super smart and knows almost all the words we use!

title: What ist the deal with this “alternative facts“ thing everyone is talking about? What is it and where did it come from?
text: Imagine you're looking at a blue ball, and everyone agrees it's blue, right? But then someone says, "No, it's actually a red ball! That's my 'alternative fact'." It's a grown-up way of saying something that isn't really true, even when everyone can see what *is* true. Like pretending the sky is green when we all know it's blue. This idea came from a lady who worked for a very important person. People were talking about how many people came to a big party, and some pictures showed not many people. But the lady said, "No, there were lots and lots of people! You're looking at 'alternative facts'." She meant that what *she* was saying was true, even if it looked different to everyone else, even if it wasn't really true.

title: How can solids keep its form if the atoms that make it up are constantly moving?
text: Imagine you and your friends are playing a game where you all stand in your own special spot and hold hands really, really tight. Even though you're holding hands and staying in your spots, you can still wiggle and jiggle and dance a little bit, right? You're not running all over the room, but you're not totally still either. That's kind of like how the tiny, tiny little pieces (atoms) that make up your toy block or a rock work! Each little piece has its own special spot, and they're all holding onto each other super, super strong, like they're glued together. This makes the block keep its shape, so it doesn't fall apart. But even though they're holding on tight and staying in their spots, they're still wiggling and jiggling and vibrating a tiny, tiny bit all the time, like you dancing in your spot. They just can't wiggle far enough to let go of their friends and move to a new spot, so the block stays a block!

title: If a spider falls onto the web of another spider's, will it be able to walk normally?
text: Imagine a spider's web is like a super sticky playground made of bubblegum! If you or a fly tried to walk on it, you'd get stuck right away. But the spider who made the web has super special shoes on its feet, like magic shoes, that let it walk all over its own sticky playground without getting stuck. If another spider falls onto that web, guess what? It also has those super special magic shoes! So, yes, it can usually walk around pretty normally on the other spider's web too, because its feet are made to not get stuck to that kind of sticky stuff, just like the web-maker's feet.

title: Why do cars have two controls for parking?
text: Imagine your car wants to take a nap and stay perfectly still, so it doesn't roll away! It has two special ways to make sure it stays super-duper still. One way is like putting a big, strong block right inside the car's wheels so they can't even try to spin – that's when

title: Physicists, How do we know that the fundamental forces used to all be one force at the start of the universe?
text: Imagine you have different types of games you play. Sometimes you push a toy car, sometimes you pull a wagon, and sometimes you stick two LEGOs together really tight. These are like the

title: How do random number generators work on the most fundamental levels in programming or otherwise?
text: Imagine you want to pick a number, but you don't want to pick the same one every time, and you want it to feel like a surprise! A computer can't really *think* of a number out of nowhere like you can. It needs a little help. So, what it does is like having a super-secret recipe book. First, it looks for something that's always changing, like the exact time on the clock right now, or how long it's been since you turned the computer on. We call this the 'seed' – it's like picking the very first ingredient for your recipe. Once it has that special starting number (the seed), it uses a special math recipe, step-by-step, to make a whole long list of other numbers. These numbers look all jumbled up and different, so it *feels* like they were picked randomly, even though the computer just followed its recipe perfectly! If you started with the *exact same seed* again, you'd get the *exact same list* of 'random' numbers. But because the seed changes all the time (like the clock ticking),

title: What makes prostitution illegal, while acting in porn for money not?
text: Okay, imagine two different kinds of grown-up jobs. One is when a grown-up gives another grown-up money for a very private grown-up hug. Many grown-ups

title: What is happening on a neurological level when you get dizzy?
text: You know when you spin around and around really fast, and then you stop, but the world keeps feeling like it's spinning? That's because inside your head, in a special little room in your ear, there's a tiny swing set with some jelly-like water. When you spin, the water and the swings move and tell your brain, "Woohoo, we're spinning!" But then you stop, and your eyes tell your brain, "Hey, we're standing still now!" But the jelly water in your ear is still sloshing around a little bit, telling your brain, "No way, we're still spinning!" So your

title: What is being written on my boarding pass right before I get in the security line?
text: Imagine your boarding pass is like a super special ticket for a fun adventure! Right before you go through the big gate (that's security!), the grown-up looking at your ticket is usually just

title: Why is the American credit system such a mess?
text: Imagine money is like toys, and sometimes grown-ups need to borrow a special toy from a friend or a big toy shop (that's like a bank!). To know if you're good at giving toys back nicely, they have a special game with rules. Our game is a bit messy because it's super hard to

title: How did we come to know which mushrooms we could and couldn't eat?
text: Long, long ago, before there were grocery stores, people had to find all their food outside! They were very hungry and saw all sorts of plants and mushrooms growing. So, they started to try them, very carefully. When someone ate a mushroom and it made their tummy feel good and strong, they remembered it was okay to eat. But sometimes, someone ate a different kind of mushroom, and it made them feel very, very sick, or even stopped them from playing forever. That was a very sad way to learn! So, people started telling their children and their friends, "Don't eat the red spotty ones!" or "The brown ones with the flat top are yummy!" They remembered what made them sick and what made them strong, and they passed that secret down from grown-up to grown-up, for a very, very long time, until we all knew which ones were safe to eat and which ones were just for looking at.

title: How do doctors know or decide what antibiotic to prescribe for an illness?
text: Imagine your body is like a big castle, and sometimes tiny, invisible "bad guys" called germs try to sneak in and make you feel yucky! Doctors are like super detectives. First, they try to figure out *what kind* of bad guy is making you sick. There are two main kinds: some bad guys are called "bacteria" (and antibiotics can fight them!), and other bad guys are called "viruses" (and antibiotics can't fight those, they need different magic). The doctor looks at you, asks how you feel, maybe peeks in your ears or throat, like looking for clues! Sometimes, if they're not sure, they might take a tiny little tickle with a cotton swab from your throat or nose and send it to a special lab. That lab is like a super-duper magnifying glass that can see *exactly* which bad guy it is. Once they know the exact bad guy, they pick a special medicine called an antibiotic. Think of antibiotics like different kinds of superheroes! Some superheroes are really good at fighting the "red monster" bad guy, and others are better at fighting the "blue monster" bad guy. The doctor picks the *right* superhero antibiotic that is super strong against *your specific* bad guy, so it can go in and kick it out of your castle and make you feel all better!

title: In typical office-pen ink tubes, what is that yellow wax-like stuff at the top of the ink?
text: You know how sometimes your juice box has a little straw, and if you leave it open, the juice might dry up or spill? Well, your pen ink is a bit like that juice! That yellow gooey stuff at the top is like a special, squishy plug, kind of like a tiny cork. It's there to make sure your ink doesn't dry out and get all yucky, and it also stops the ink from leaking out the back of the pen and making a mess. Plus, it gently pushes the ink down the tube as you write, so you always have fresh ink ready to make cool drawings and letters!

title: Does the president even have the power to gag employees of federal agencies and the agencies themselves? Don't we pay for their research, expertise, and information?
text: Imagine the President is like the grown-up in charge of a very big house, and all the people working in different rooms (like the kitchen, the garden, or the library) are the federal agencies. Sometimes, the grown-up boss might tell the people in the kitchen not to talk about a surprise birthday cake they're making, because it's a secret for now. But if the people in the garden find out something really important, like a dangerous bug, it's usually super important for them to tell everyone so we can be safe! It's a bit tricky because the boss can tell people what to do, but grown-ups also believe it's important for people to share what they know, especially if it helps everyone. We give money (like our allowance for chores) to these people so they can learn cool and important things, and usually, when they find something out, we want to hear about it! So, while the boss can sometimes say "shhh," it's often not good if they try to keep important stuff secret that we all paid for and need to know.

title: If the petroleum industry receives over $4 billion in annual government subsidies (on average), why is there a tax on fossil fuels? Wouldn't these cash flows 'cancel out?'
text: Imagine the government is like your grown-up helper. Sometimes, they give money to companies that make gas for cars. This is like giving you extra blocks to build a really big LEGO castle, because they want to make sure there's always enough gas for everyone's cars and trucks to go places. But then, when people buy the gas, a tiny extra bit of money is added to the price, which is called a tax. This is like when you buy a yummy snack, and a little bit of that money helps pay for

title: Why does toilet paper clean my glasses 100 times better than any shirt, tissue or sometimes even glasses cloth?
text: Okay, imagine your glasses have tiny, tiny invisible sticky bits and little dust monsters on them! When you use your shirt or a regular tissue, it's like trying to push those

title: If successfully extracted, could ATPs be used as efficient fuel?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool toy robot, and ATP is like the tiny, tiny special battery that makes its arm wiggle for just a second. Your robot makes new ATP batteries super fast from the yummy food you eat, which is its real big fuel, like how a car uses gasoline to go far. ATP is already the *last little zap* of energy your body uses inside itself, not the big fuel source we can collect. It's like trying to power a big truck with a million tiny watch batteries – it just wouldn't work very well because they'

title: why does North America get so many more tornadoes than the rest or the world?
text: Imagine North America is like a special playground where all the things needed to make a tornado just love to meet up! We have big, warm, wet air that comes from the super warm ocean down

title: What exactly will an Exascale supercomputer be used for, and how will it benefit humanity?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper brain, way smarter and faster than anyone else's brain in the whole wide world! An Exascale supercomputer is like that, but for grown-ups' really, really hard problems. It's going to help us figure out super tricky puzzles like guessing the weather much, much better, so we know if a big storm is coming and can be safe. It can help doctors find new medicines much faster to make sick people feel better, like a super-smart detective finding clues for cures. It can even help scientists understand how big stars work in space, design super strong new materials for buildings or toys, or make cars and airplanes go super fast using less gas. So, it helps us stay safe, get healthy, learn amazing new things about our world and space, and make everything around us work even better for everyone!

title: Why do colored pencils sharpen like crap in most sharpeners?
text: Imagine your colored pencil has a super soft, yummy chocolate inside, and the wood is like its wrapper. But a regular pencil for writing has a much harder, stronger candy inside. Most sharpeners are made for those tough, hard candy pencils. So, when you try to sharpen your soft chocolatey colored pencil, the sharpener is a bit too rough and strong for it! It's like trying to peel a super soft banana with a peeler made for hard apples – the soft part just squishes or breaks off instead of making a nice, smooth point. Your colored pencil's soft inside isn't as tough as the sharpener expects, so it breaks instead of getting a pretty, pointy tip.

title: why did we start roasting and drinking coffee beans instead of the much sweeter fruit?
text: Imagine coffee is like a little red cherry, and inside that cherry are two tiny seeds, which we call coffee beans. Now, grown-ups found out that if they just ate the red cherry part, it wasn't super yummy like a strawberry or a banana; it was a bit sweet but not that exciting. But guess what? The special "wake-up magic" that helps grown-ups feel energetic and not sleepy is mostly hiding inside those little seeds! So, instead of eating the not-so-sweet fruit, clever people learned to take out those seeds and make them warm and toasty, like when you make popcorn or toast bread. This makes the seeds smell and taste really, really good to grown-ups. Then, they grind them up into tiny pieces and mix them with hot water to make a special brown drink that helps grown-ups wake up and feel ready for the day, because that's where all the yummy taste and "wake-up magic" is!

title: At what point do humans become different species?
text: Okay, imagine you have a dog and your friend has a dog. Even if one dog is big and fluffy and the other is small and smooth, they are both still dogs, right? And they could even have puppy babies together! That means they are the same "species." Now, imagine a cat. A cat is very different from a dog, and a cat and a dog can't have babies together. So, a cat is a different "species" than a dog. Guess what? All people in the whole wide world are like the dogs! Even if some people have different colored hair, or different skin, or are taller or shorter, we are ALL still humans. We can all have human babies together. So, that means all of us are the SAME species. We don't ever become different species; we are all just one big human family!

title: How would a scientist identify the key differences in the body between a 18 year old and a 16 year old female?
text: Imagine your body is like a special building that's still growing bigger and stronger! When you're 16, your body's building might still be adding a few last tall parts and getting everything super sturdy. But when you're 18, your body's building is pretty much all done with its big growing up; it's mostly about making sure everything inside is working perfectly and strong. A scientist would take special pictures of your bones, like X-rays, to see if the "growing lines" in your bones are still a little bit open, which means you could still grow a tiny bit more at 16, or if they're all closed up, like a door that's shut because the growing is finished, which usually happens by 18. They might also look at little messages inside your body, called hormones, to see if they're still super busy telling your body to grow up, or if they've settled down more because most of the growing is done. So, it's mostly about checking if the body is still busy with its last bits of growing taller and stronger, or if it's mostly finished its big growing job.

title: Why is buying a house considered an investment?
text: Imagine you have a special piggy bank, and you put your money in it. When you buy a house, it's kind of like putting your money into a super big, real-life piggy bank that you can also live in! Sometimes, the house gets more popular, like a cool toy everyone wants, so its value goes up and it's worth more money. Or maybe you paint it and make it super pretty, and then it's worth even more! You can even let other people live in your house for a little while, and they pay you some money, like sharing your toys for a fee. So, when you decide to sell your house much later, you might get back even *more* money than you first put in, which means your money grew bigger, like planting a tiny seed and getting a huge flower!

title: Why do all the planets in space appear so perfectly spherical?
text: Imagine you have a giant pile of sand or play-doh floating in space. There's a special invisible force called 'gravity' that acts like a super big hug, pulling all those tiny pieces of sand or play-doh together. This hug pulls everything towards the very middle, equally from every single side. Think of it like when you squish a big ball of play-doh – it naturally wants to become a nice, smooth, round ball because the squeeze is coming from everywhere. Planets are super, super big, so gravity's hug is super, super strong, pulling all their rocks and gas into the most perfect, comfy, round shape it can make, like a giant cosmic beach ball!

title: How can a border wall be authorized/built by an executive order?
text: Imagine the President is like the grown-up in charge of a very big house, which is our country. Sometimes, the President can write a special note, called an "executive order," which is like a bossy instruction just for the people who work for them. It's like when your mom or dad says, "Go clean your room!" They don't need to ask you first, they just tell you to do it because they're the boss. For a wall, the President can write this special note and tell the people who work for them, "Hey! I want a wall built!" And then they can tell them to find money that was already put aside for other things, like "fixing broken stuff" or "keeping us safe," and use that money to start building the wall instead. It's like if your parents had a jar of money for "house repairs" and they decided to use some of it to build a new fence in the backyard because they think it's important for safety. They don't get new

title: What Would it Take for Cable Companies (in the US) to be Accused of Violating Antitrust Laws?
text: Imagine you and your friends all want to play with toys. Grown-up rules, called antitrust laws, are like making sure one kid doesn't try to take *all* the toys for themselves, or stop other kids from playing, or make unfair rules so they always win. If cable companies (the grown-up companies that bring TV and internet to your house) start doing things like buying *all* the other companies so they're the only ones left, or secretly agreeing with other big companies to charge *lots* of money for TV even if it's not fair, or stopping new, smaller companies from even trying to sell TV and internet, then it's like they're taking all the toys and not letting anyone else play fairly. That's when grown-ups would say they're breaking the fair-play rules!

title: Why do we get the urge to hurt ourselves when we're extremely stressed out?
text: Imagine you have super-duper big, yucky feelings inside you, like when you're really, really mad and sad and scared all at the same time. It's like

title: What exactly would it be like to live or visit the fourth dimension (4D)?
text: Okay, imagine you live in your room, right? You can go left and right, forward and backward, and up and down. That's three directions! If you were a tiny drawing on a flat piece of paper, you could only go left and right, and forward and backward on the paper – you wouldn't even know "up" existed

title: How will the proposed wall solve any of America's problems?
text: Imagine our whole country is like a very big house with a very big yard. Sometimes, grown-ups worry about things coming into our yard that shouldn't, like people who didn't get an invitation or bad stuff like yucky candies that aren't good for anyone. So, some grown-ups think if we build a super-duper long and tall fence, like a big wall, around part

title: How exactly is recycling good for the environment when it almost always requires a source of fuel to break down and re-purpose the materials(in turn creating more air pollution and also requires the excavation of more fossil fuel)?
text: Imagine you have a favorite toy car, and it's old and broken. If we want a new car, we can either go dig up all the stuff from deep in the ground to make a brand new one from scratch, which takes *lots* of big noisy machines, *lots* of special energy juice (like gas for cars!), and makes a big mess and some smoky air. Or, we can take your old broken car, melt it down (which still uses some energy juice and makes a little bit of smoky air, but not as much!), and turn it into a new car. Recycling is like that second way! It helps us not have to dig up so much new stuff from the Earth, which keeps the Earth happier and cleaner, and even though it still uses some energy, it uses way, way less energy and makes less mess than if we had to start all over again from scratch every single time. It's like taking a shortcut to make new things, which is better for everyone!

title: How do torches burn so long?
text: Imagine your favorite snack! If you have a tiny little crisp, you eat it super fast, right? But if you have a big, chewy cookie, it takes much longer to eat. A torch is like a big, big cookie for the fire! It has lots and lots of special 'fire food' inside, like wood and sticky stuff, all packed together really tight. The fire can only take tiny little bites of this 'food' very, very slowly, even though there's a whole lot of it. Because it eats so slowly and there's so much 'food', the torch can keep burning and making light for a long, long time before all its 'food' is gone!

title: Why are boats in drydock propped up in the air with blocks of wood? How is that stable?
text: Imagine your super-duper big toy boat needs a little fix on its tummy, but you can't fix it if it's floating in the bathtub, right? You need to take it out! Grown-ups do the same thing with real, giant boats. They bring them out of the water onto a special big floor, and to fix the very bottom, they need to lift it up a little bit. They use big, strong wooden blocks, like giant LEGO bricks, to hold the boat up. They use wood because it's super strong but also gentle so it doesn't hurt the boat's tummy. "How doesn't it fall over?" you ask! Well, they don't just use one or two blocks. They use *lots* and *lots* of blocks, all spread out everywhere under the boat, like how your bed has many legs, or how a big table has many legs. Each block pushes up a little bit, and all together, they make a super strong, steady stand so the boat can't wiggle or fall down. The boat is so heavy it just sits right on top of all those blocks, pushing them down and making them very, very stable, like when you sit on a sturdy chair!

title: What is happening in this gif with droplets of gallium?
text: Okay, imagine you have a very special kind of shiny metal, like a silver toy, but it's super, super soft, so soft it melts just by holding it in your warm hand, like an ice cube! That's called gallium. In the picture, those little shiny balls are tiny drops of this special melty metal. Normally, they like to stay in nice round balls, like little marbles. But then, something else is put in the water around them, like a tiny bit of secret magic! This magic makes the outside of the metal drops feel all funny and wobbly. It's like they suddenly get super excited and want to wiggle and dance! So, you see them stretching out, changing their shape, maybe splitting into smaller pieces, and then sometimes even joining back together like they're giving each other a hug. They're just having a big, wiggly, melty dance party because that secret magic makes them want to move!

title: Given that becoming the president doesn't lawfully require any career politics experience, what's "a day in the life" of the president if anyone is allowed to be it?
text: Imagine you're the grown-up in charge of the whole country, even if you used to just build forts and play with cars all day! When you wake up, important helpers tell you about everything happening, like what's on the news but way more serious. Then you spend all day in a big house called the White House, talking to lots and lots of smart people about big problems, like how to make sure everyone has food or how to keep everyone safe. You have to listen carefully and then choose what you think is the best thing to do, kind of like when your mom or dad decides what's for dinner or where you're going for the day, but for everyone in the whole country! You might also visit places to see how things are going or give speeches to tell people what's happening. It's a super busy job with lots of thinking and talking, even if you didn't have a 'practice president' job before!

title: How does canning food increase its shelf life so much?
text: Okay, imagine your food gets yucky because tiny, tiny invisible little helpers, like super small bugs you can't see, come to eat it and make it not good anymore. When we can food, we do two super clever things! First, we cook the food super, super hot. This is like giving all those tiny invisible helpers a giant, hot bath that they really don't like, and it makes them all go away, poof! Then, we quickly put the food into a special jar and close it up super tight, like putting a magic shield around it. This magic shield stops any new tiny invisible helpers from getting inside to make the food yucky again. So, because all the old tiny helpers are gone and no new ones can get in, the food stays yummy and safe to eat for a very, very long time, even without the fridge! It's like putting the food in a super safe, cozy bed where no one can bother it.

title: The Dow hit 20,000. What is the Dow and what does this mean?
text: Imagine the Dow is like a special scoreboard for some of the biggest toy companies, candy makers, and other grown-up businesses in our country. It tells us if these important companies are making lots of money or not. When the Dow hits 20,000, it's like all those companies just got a super high score in their game! It means that, on average, these big businesses are doing really, really well, and lots of people are buying their things. When the scoreboard shows such a big number, it's usually a good sign that many grown-ups have jobs and are earning money, which often means things are going pretty well for lots of people in our country.

title: Why do so many actors end up directing some of the episodes of the tv show they are starring on?
text: Imagine you're playing a really fun game with your friends every single day, like building with LEGOs or playing pretend in a big house. You know all the rules, all the characters, and exactly what everyone likes to do because you're always there! Well, actors on a TV show are like that; they've been "playing" in that show for a very, very long time, so they know the characters, the stories, and how everything usually works better than almost anyone. Sometimes, the grown-ups who make the whole show happen need someone to help guide everyone for a specific part of the game – like telling the other actors where to stand or how to say their lines. Since the actor already knows the game inside and out, they're perfect for helping out! It's like they get to be the "game leader" for a little while, which is a new and exciting way for them to help make the show even more awesome, and they learn new things too!

title: What would happen if the US stopped giving aid to foreign countries?
text: Imagine your house has lots of yummy snacks, and sometimes you share some with your friends who don't have as many, or you help a friend build a really tall block tower when they're having trouble. That's kind of like what America does for other countries – it shares help, like food, medicine, or even money to build schools and hospitals. If America suddenly stopped sharing all that help, some countries would be very sad and might not have enough food or medicine for their people, just like your friend would be hungry without snacks. Those countries might get sicker or stay poor, and they might not feel as friendly towards America anymore. It could make the world a bit sadder and harder for everyone to get along and solve big problems together, like stopping bad germs from spreading or keeping everyone safe.

title: Why did relatively nearby cities like Philadelphia and Boston not grow to the size and importance NYC did?
text: Imagine cities are like little plant seeds, and they grow super big if they get the best sun, water, and good soil! NYC had the absolute best spot for growing into a super-duper giant city. It had a giant, deep bathtub (that's its harbor!) where the biggest boats from all over the world could park easily, and there was always room for more. Plus, it had a super long, flat river (the Hudson River) that went really, really far inland, like a super highway for boats to carry toys, food, and clothes to many, many other towns and farms. It was also easy to build lots and lots of houses and shops there because the land was mostly flat. Philadelphia and Boston were great cities too, with good spots for boats and rivers, but NYC just had *all* the best things together – the biggest boat parking lot, the longest boat highway to the most places, and lots of easy space to build – which helped it grow into a super-duper giant city!

title: Why we don't see full black in night/close eyes but see random noise moving around?
text: Imagine your eyes are like super special cameras and your brain is like the person watching the TV screen. Even when it's super dark outside or you close your eyes really tight, your cameras and TV screen are still "on" and trying to see something! They don't just turn completely off. Sometimes, when there's no real picture to look at (because it's so dark), your eyes and brain still get little tiny messages or "sparkles" inside them, like when a TV shows little fuzzy dots if there's no show playing. These little sparkles and wiggles are just your eyes and brain being busy and making up tiny pretend pictures because they don't have real light to show them a clear one!

title: Where does an electron "go" once it enters a piece of electronics? Whathappens to it?
text: Imagine electrons are like super tiny, invisible balls! When you put one of these tiny balls into a long tube, like a slide, it doesn't really zoom all the way through and

title: Why is isolationism bad for the United States?
text: Imagine our country, the USA, is like a big kid in a playground with lots of other kids (those are other countries). If the USA always just sat by itself, never played with anyone, never shared its toys, and never helped other kids when they fell down, what would happen? Well, first, we wouldn't have many friends. If we got lonely or needed help building a super big sandcastle, no one would want to help us because we never helped them! Also, if we only played with our own toys, we might miss out on playing with cool new toys from other kids, like a super fast race car or a doll that sings! And if we don't share our yummy snacks, other kids won't share their yummy snacks with us, which means we might not get to try new tasty things. So, it's much better to play with everyone, share our toys, help our friends, and learn new games together, because then everyone has more fun, gets more help, and has more cool stuff to play with!

title: Why did the U.S savings account interest rate go down to almost 0%, compared to the '80s and '90s, when it was much higher?
text: Imagine your money is like your toys, and you let the bank keep them safe for you. Sometimes, when you let the bank hold your money, they give you a little extra money back as a tiny "thank you" gift! That extra money is called interest. A long time ago, when your mommy and daddy were little, the grown-ups in charge of all the money in the country wanted people to save more because things in the shops were getting expensive super fast, like candy prices kept jumping up! So, they told the banks to give a *big*

title: If I get eight hours of sleep, when my alarm rings I feel like death warmed over. If I get six hours of sleep, when my alarm rings I feel chipper and ready to get up. Why is this?
text: Imagine your sleep is like a little train going on a trip, and it stops at different kinds of stations. Some stations are "light sleep" where it's super easy to open your eyes and get off. Other stations are "deep sleep" where you're really, really sleepy and snuggled down, and it's hard to wake up. Your train goes around and around on its trip, stopping at all these stations. When you sleep for six hours, maybe your alarm rings when your train is at one of those "easy to wake up" stations, so you pop right up! But when you sleep for eight hours, sometimes your alarm might ring when your train is still at a "deep sleep" station, even though you got more sleep. That makes you feel super tired and grumpy, because your body was having a really deep rest and didn't want to get off the train yet! It's all about where your train is when the alarm goes *ding-ding*!

title: Why is lightning typically yellow in entertainment (the flash, he-man, etc) even though we perceive it as blue in real life?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super-duper hot light bulb that's brighter than anything you've ever seen! Real lightning is like that – it's super, super hot and bright, and when things get that hot and powerful, they usually glow a color like white or a little bit blue, which is what we see in the sky. But in cartoons and movies, like when Flash runs super fast or He-Man uses his power, they often make lightning yellow! This is because yellow is a really happy, bright color that stands out super well on the screen, so you can always easily see the special power zap! It looks exciting and makes it clear that it's a powerful energy bolt, and it's also a fun way to make it look different from the real lightning outside, so it feels more like a cool cartoon trick.

title: Why do Apple consumers stay devoted to Apple products and have a hard time switching to anything else?
text: Imagine you have a favorite set of building blocks, and they all fit together perfectly every time, like magic! You know exactly how to build a tall tower or a cool car with them. Apple products are kind of like that: all your phone, tablet, and computer blocks work together super easily, like best friends who know each other really well. You get used to how they look and feel, and everything just makes sense. It's like having a special secret club where all your toys understand

title: How does Twitter censorship work? And how are governments involved?
text: Imagine Twitter is like a big, big playground where everyone can shout out their ideas and share pictures. But just like your playground has rules (no pushing, no yelling mean things), Twitter has rules too

title: Why does drinking fluids help when you're sick?
text: Imagine your body is like a little plant, and just like plants need water to grow big and strong, your body needs water too! When you're sick, your body is like a superhero fighting off tiny little bad guys (germs) that are trying to make you feel yucky. This superhero work makes your body use up lots and lots of its water, like when you play super hard and get thirsty. Drinking water, juice, or warm soup is like giving your body a special magic potion! It helps your body clean out the bad guys, makes your snot and cough easier to get out, and keeps all your body's little parts working smoothly so you can feel better and get back to playing much, much faster. So, keep drinking, little plant!

title: Why do some actors that imo were pretty good, start making straight to dvd/netflix crap?
text: Okay, imagine your favorite grown-up has a job, right? Sometimes, they get to do the super-duper exciting jobs, like building a giant castle (those are the big movies everyone sees!). But even grown-ups need to work to get money for food and toys, so sometimes they take other jobs that might not be as super-duper exciting, like building a smaller house, or helping a friend build a fence. It's still a job, and they still get to use their skills! So, actors sometimes pick these "straight-to-TV" movies because they need to work, or maybe they want to try a new kind of story, or work with a friend, or sometimes they just think it will be fun, even if it's not the biggest, shiniest movie ever. And what one person thinks is "not so good," another person might actually really love, just like how you might love carrots and your friend might not!

title: Why do people tell their children that they are adopted?
text: Imagine your family is like a super special team, and everyone on the team loves each other very, very much! Sometimes, a mommy and daddy might not be able to have a baby grow in the mommy's tummy. But they still have so much love to give, like a big, warm hug! So, they find a special baby, like you, who needs a loving team, and they choose you to be part of their family forever! It's like a special way of becoming a family. Grown-ups tell you this story because it's a very important and happy part of how you joined their team, and grown-ups always want to tell their kids the truth about everything, so there are no yucky secrets. It means you were chosen with extra love, and it's a wonderful, special story for your family!

title: Are the McDonalds in all countries around the world connected to one main 'headquarter' ?
text: Imagine McDonald's is like a super big family, and every McDonald's restaurant in the world is a different house in that family. Even though they are in different places, like your house and your grandma's house, they all have one super important 'main house' or 'big boss' place. This main house, called the 'headquarters,' is where all the grown-ups decide things like what kind of yummy burgers to make, what the Happy Meal toys will be, and how all the restaurants should look. So yes, even if a McDonald's is super far away, like in a country you've never been to, it's still connected to that one big boss house, making sure all the McDonald's everywhere are part of the same big family and mostly taste the same!

title: What do the values of the Dow, Nasdaq, and S & P actually mean?
text: Imagine you have different report cards for different groups of grown-up companies, and the "value" is just their score! The **Dow** is like a special report card for about 30 really big, old, and famous companies, like the ones that make your favorite yummy snacks or big airplanes. If its score goes up, it means those big companies are generally doing a super

title: each time a new wireless standard comes out, it seems better and faster than before. Any reason we couldn't have accomplished this sooner? What are the enablers we now have that we didn't have before?
text: Imagine your internet is like a road where tiny cars carry your messages and videos really fast. A long, long time ago, we only knew how to build small, bumpy dirt roads, so only a few cars could go slowly. Each time a new wireless standard comes out, it's like we learned how to build a bigger, smoother, super-duper highway! We couldn't do it sooner because we first had to learn how to build *any* road, then make it a little bit better, and a

title: Why are many trades jobs, such as sanitation and street sweeping, unionized and highly paid?
text: Imagine our town as a big house, and those grown-ups who clean the streets and take away our trash are like the people who keep our house super tidy! If they didn't do their job, our house would get really stinky and messy, and we might even get sick! So, their job is super, super important for everyone. Now, imagine you and all your friends want to ask for more cookies from your mommy. If just one of you asks, maybe she says no. But if all of you stand together and ask in a big, strong voice, she's more likely to listen, right? A "union" is like that big group of grown-ups who do the same important job, and they all stick together like best friends. Because their job is so important, and because they all stick together to ask for fair money and good rules, the people who hire them know they *really* need them. So, they make sure to pay them well and treat them nicely, because if they didn't, those grown-ups might say, "No thanks!" and then who would clean up our town? So, they get good pay because their job keeps us all safe and clean, and because they work together like a super-strong team!

title: Why does our immune system not develop a strong resistance against the common cold although we get it many times throughout our lifetime?
text: Imagine your body has a team of superheroes inside that fight off tiny bad guys making you feel yucky, like when you have a cold! When you get a cold, it's like one specific tiny bad guy shows up. Your superheroes learn *exactly* how to fight that one bad guy and kick him out! But here's the tricky part: there isn't just *one* kind of cold bad guy. There are hundreds and hundreds of different kinds! It's like one day you meet a fuzzy blue cold monster, and your superheroes get really good at beating *him*. But then next month, a spiky green cold monster shows up, and even though your superheroes are super good at fighting the blue one, they have to learn all over again how to beat the green one. So, every time you get a cold, it's usually a new kind of bad guy your body hasn't met or learned to fight yet, which is why you keep getting colds even though your body is getting stronger!

title: Why is it so difficult to finish sentences when we hear our voices with a delay?
text: Imagine your brain is like the boss of your talking. When you say something, your ears usually hear it *right away*, like a super-fast helper telling your brain, "Yep, that word just came out!" This helps your brain know everything is going smoothly and helps you keep going. But when there's a delay, it's like your ears hear your own voice *a little bit later* than when your mouth actually said it. It's like hearing two of your own voices at once, one from now and one from a tiny bit ago! Your brain gets super confused because it doesn't know which voice to listen to, the one that's happening now or the old one that just arrived. It's like trying to listen to two people talk to you about different things at the very same time – it's too much! So, your brain just tells your

title: Why do we suddendly lose motivation when close to finishing a task? The last 20% is always the hardest to me.

title: What is so bad about your country having a trade deficit?
text: Okay, imagine your country is like a big house, and other countries are like other houses on the street. "Trade" is when you swap things, like if your house makes yummy cookies and another house makes cool robots, and you swap! A "trade deficit" is like if your house buys lots and lots of robots and other cool stuff from the other houses, but those other houses don't buy many of your yummy cookies or other things you make. It can be a bit bad because it means your house is sending lots of its money to the other houses to buy their stuff, and not as much money is coming back to your house. This means your house might not be making enough of its own cool things, so the people in your house who *could* be making things might not have jobs, and sometimes your house even has to borrow money from the other houses just to keep buying all their stuff, which means you owe them later!

title: If 2 waves coincide perfectly that there's complete destructive interference everywhere, where did their energy go?
