title: How do traffic jams occur with accidents NOT being the cause?
text: Imagine you and your friends are all trying to walk through a doorway at the same time. If there are too many of you, you all have to slow down, right? It's the same with cars! When lots and lots of cars try to drive on the road at the very same time, there isn't enough space for everyone to go super fast. So, if just one car in front slows down for a tiny bit (maybe because they saw a bird, or someone changed lanes), the car behind them has to slow down too, so they don't bump. Then the car behind *that* car has to slow down, and it keeps going like a chain reaction all the way back! Soon, lots of cars are all slowing down, and even stopping, because of that tiny little slowing down at the front, even though nothing is broken or crashed. It's just too many cars trying to fit in the same space, like too many toys in a toy box!

title: What causes the "helicopter noise" when you roll the backseat windows down in a vehicle, while the front are still up?
text: Okay, imagine your car is like a big balloon, and when you're driving, lots of wind is trying to push on it. If you only open the back windows, it's like making a little hole in the back of the balloon. The fast wind outside rushes *into* that hole, but it can't easily get out the front because those windows are closed. So, the air gets squished inside your car, then it quickly pushes itself back out, then rushes in again, over and over, super fast! This makes the air inside your car wobble and bounce around really quickly, like a big, invisible drum, and that fast wobbling makes the "thump-thump-thump" sound, just like a helicopter's big blades pushing the air around really fast!

title: How do ad blockers work?
text: Okay, imagine you're looking at a fun picture book on your tablet, but every few pages, someone tries to show you a boring picture of a toy they want you to buy, even if you don't want to see it! That's kind of like ads on the internet. Your computer has a special helper, like a superhero called an "ad blocker." When you ask your computer to show you a fun website with games or videos, lots of things try to come to your computer's screen. Some are the fun things you want, but some are those pesky ads trying to jump in. The ad blocker superhero stands at the door, like a bouncer at a party. It has a secret list of all the known ads. As everything tries to come in, the ad blocker looks at it really fast. If it sees something on its "no-no" list (an ad!), it quickly says, "Nope! You're not invited!" and sends it away before it even gets to your screen. So, you only get to see the fun stuff, and all those annoying ads are gone, like magic! You don't even know they were there because your superhero stopped them.

title: Why is reading a chore for some, but relaxing for others?
text: Imagine your tummy and food! Sometimes, your grown-ups make you eat broccoli when you really want candy, and eating that broccoli feels like a big, yucky chore, right? It's hard work to chew it all up! That's how reading feels for some people. Maybe the words are too hard, or the story isn't exciting to them, or they *have* to read it instead of choosing a book they think looks fun. It makes their brain work really, really hard, like lifting heavy blocks. But then imagine eating your favorite yummy ice cream – that's super easy and makes you feel happy and relaxed! That's how reading feels for others. They love the story, the words are easy peasy, and they picked the book all by themselves because it sounds like a wonderful adventure. It makes their brain feel calm and happy, like snuggling with a soft blanket, because they get to go on an amazing adventure inside their head!

title: Why isn't the foliage cut off the top of a pineapple?
text: Imagine the green spiky leaves on top of a pineapple are like its superhero cape and its mouth all in one! The cape helps protect the yummy fruit inside from getting too much sun, like when you wear a hat on a sunny day. And those leaves are also super important because they help the pineapple drink up all the sunshine and make food, so the fruit can grow super big and super sweet for you to eat. If we cut them off too early, the pineapple might not get all the food it needs to be yummy! Plus, seeing the green leaves helps us know it's a fresh pineapple, and you can even plant the top to try and grow a new one, which is super cool!

title: why do humans perceive numbers in a logarithmic way instead of a linear way?
text: Imagine you have zero cookies. If someone gives you ONE cookie, that feels like a SUPER big deal, right? You went from nothing to something! If they give you another cookie, so you have two now, that also feels like a big jump – you doubled your cookies! But now, imagine you have a giant pile of 100 cookies. If someone gives you just ONE more cookie, so

title: What are arguments against sustainable energy?
text: Okay, imagine we want to use special machines that catch the sun's tickles or the wind's pushes to make electricity for our lights and toys! That's super cool! But sometimes, these new machines cost a lot of grown-up money to build at first, like buying a really, really big new toy. Also, the sun goes to sleep at night, and sometimes the wind takes a nap, so the machines don't always make power when we need it most, like when it's dark and we want to read a book, and we need power all the time! And sometimes, these big sun-catchers or wind-spinners need lots and lots of space, like a giant park, and grown-ups worry about where to put them all without bothering animals or other important things. Plus, even making these special machines needs some materials and takes a little bit of energy, and when they get old, we have to figure out what to do with them. So, while they're really good, these are some of the things grown-ups think about when we talk about using more sunny-power and

title: Why does vision become grainy in the dark?
text: Imagine your eyes are like super special cameras! When there's lots of sunshine or bright lights, your camera eyes take a super clear, crisp picture, like a perfect drawing. But when it gets dark, there's not much light for your camera eyes to grab onto. They try super, super hard to find even the tiniest little bits of light to make a picture for your brain. Because they're working so hard with almost nothing, the picture they send isn't perfectly smooth and clear anymore. It looks a little bit fuzzy or 'grainy,' like a drawing you tried to make when it was too dark to see your pencil clearly. It's just your eyes doing their very best with only a tiny whisper of light!

title: what are SNP? And RFLP?
text: Imagine your body is like a super long instruction book, full of tiny letters that tell it what to do. A **SNP** (which sounds like "snip") is like if most people

title: Are nuclear bomb launchers really trained to "launch the nukes at a moment's notice"?
text: Imagine grown-ups who have a super important job, like firefighters who need to be ready to put out a fire really, really fast if there's an emergency. These special soldiers are kind of like that. Their job is to know exactly what to do and how to do it super quickly, like they've practiced it a million times, in case someone *really* mean tried to hurt our country. But it's not just one person who can do it; lots of very important people have to agree, and there are many, many steps to make sure it's safe and only happens if it's super, super necessary. Most of the time, they just practice and make sure everything is working perfectly, like having a fire drill but no actual fire.

title: Why do some solids dissolve in water?
text: Imagine your sugar or salt is like a big pile of super tiny LEGO bricks all stuck together. Water is like a whole bunch of super tiny, super busy little helpers that love to dance and move around! When you put the sugar in the water, these water helpers get really excited. They zoom around the sugar LEGOs, find all the tiny cracks and edges, and start pulling them apart, one by one, like they're trying to give each tiny sugar LEGO a big hug and carry it away. Because the sugar LEGOs are small and not stuck together super strong, the water helpers can easily pull them apart and carry them off to dance with them in the water. Soon, all the sugar LEGOs are separate and dancing with the water helpers, so you can't see them anymore, but they're still there, just mixed up! But if you put a rock in water, its LEGOs are stuck together super, super strong, and even the busiest water helpers can't pull them apart, so the rock just stays a rock.

title: Why would Mexico pay for a wall on our mutual border?
text: Imagine you want to build a fence around your house to keep your dog in. You would buy the fence, right? You wouldn't ask your friend who lives next door to pay for it, because it's *your* fence for *your* house. Well, some people in our country said they wanted a big wall on *our* side of the border with Mexico, like a fence. And they said, "Hey Mexico, you should pay for our wall!" But Mexico said, "No way! That's *your* wall on *your* land, so if you want it, you have to pay for it yourself." Countries usually pay for things they want to build on their own land, just like you pay for your own toys.

title: Everyone talks about "curing cancer", but how can you simply cure cancer when there are so many types of cancer?
text: Imagine your body is like a big LEGO castle made of tiny, tiny blocks called cells. Most of the time, these blocks are super good and build everything perfectly. But sometimes, a few blocks go a little bit naughty! Instead of staying where they should, they start making copies of themselves really, really fast and don't stop, making a big messy pile that can cause trouble for the whole castle. That's cancer. Now, the naughty blocks can happen in different parts of the castle – maybe some go wild in the kitchen part (that's like stomach cancer), or some in the roof

title: How does bank interest work?
text: Imagine the bank is like a super big, super safe piggy bank for everyone! When you put your pocket money in your piggy bank and leave it there for a long, long time, the bank is really happy you let them keep your money safe. Because they use your money to help other people (like letting grown-ups borrow some to buy a house!), they say "thank you!" by adding a tiny, tiny bit *more* money to your pile! So, your money grows bigger all by itself, like magic! That's called 'interest' when you save. Now, sometimes a grown-up wants to buy something big, like a car, but they don't have all the money right now. The bank lets them borrow some money. But because the bank let them use *their* money for a while, when the grown-up gives it back, they have to give a little

title: What does it mean that the US dollar is backed by silver/gold?
text: Imagine you have a special ticket, and that ticket says it can be traded for a real, shiny toy car. So, your ticket is 'backed by' that toy car – it means the car makes the ticket valuable because you can swap them! A long, long time ago, money (like the dollar bills your grown-ups use) was like that ticket! People could take their paper money to the bank, and the bank would give them a real piece of shiny gold or silver for it. So, the dollar was 'backed by' gold or silver, meaning gold or silver made the paper money valuable because it was a promise you could trade it for the real shiny stuff. But guess what? Not anymore! Now, your dollar bills are special because everyone trusts them. The government says they are worth things, and all the grown-ups believe it and use them to buy snacks and toys. So, it's not backed by gold or silver anymore; it's backed by everyone trusting that it's real money!

title: What is the difference between doublethink and cognitive dissonance?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a little house. "Cognitive dissonance" is when your brain feels a little bit squirmy or "ouchy" because two ideas inside your house are bumping into each other and fighting, like when you really want to eat a cookie but you also know it's almost dinner and you shouldn't. Your brain feels confused and a little uncomfortable until you pick one idea or make them stop fighting. "Doublethink" is when a very, very bossy grown-up tells you,

title: Why do people feel the urge to roam the house while on the phone?
text: Imagine your body is like a little car that loves to move! When grown-ups are talking on the phone, sometimes their brain is busy thinking, but their body isn't doing anything else, so it gets a little bit wiggly inside. It's like when you have lots of energy and want to run around, even if you're just talking to a friend. Sometimes, walking around helps their brain think better, like when you walk around when you're trying to remember where you put your favorite toy. Other times, they just want to find a quiet, secret spot where no one else can hear their chat. So their feet just get a little excited and decide to go on a tiny adventure all around the house while their mouth is busy talking!

title: Is saturated fat bad or not? (Bacon for example). All the studies I find seem to contradict each other.
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super cool car, and food is the fuel it needs to run and play! Fats are one kind of fuel, and they help give you energy and keep you warm. Saturated fat, like the yummy white bits on bacon, is a special kind of fat. It's a bit like candy – a little bit is okay and tastes super good, but if you eat too much candy all the time, it can make your tummy hurt or make your teeth sad. In the same way, if you eat too much saturated fat every single day, it can make your heart, which is like the engine of

title: What is the point of the anaphylaxis reaction. Why would the body try to protect itself by essentially committing suicide?
text: Imagine your body has tiny little guards inside, like in a castle. Most of the time, they know what's safe and what's not. But sometimes, a little peanut or a bee sting comes along, and your body's guards get SUPER confused! They think it's the biggest, scariest dragon ever, even if it's just a tiny bug or a yummy snack for other kids. So, what do they do? They yell, 'DRAGON ATTACK! EVERYONE FIGHT NOW!' And all the little soldiers, and even the doctors and nurses inside your body, rush out all at once, super fast, to fight

title: What does E = MC[squared] mean?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special toy, like a little LEGO brick. That LEGO brick is 'M' – it's the 'stuff' that makes up things. Now, 'E' is like the 'go-go-go' power that makes things happen, like when you run around or when a light bulb glows. 'C' is a super-duper fast number, like the fastest car in the whole wide world, and 'squared' just means you make that super-duper fast number even bigger! So, what the grown-ups' special riddle 'E = MC squared' means is that a tiny, tiny bit of 'stuff' (like your little LEGO brick) can be turned into a HUGE amount of 'go-go-go' power! Because that 'C squared' number is so, so, SO big, even a little bit of 'stuff' can make enough power to light up a whole city, or even make the sun

title: What is the U.S. State Department? what does it do? Why is it such a big deal that it's senior members just resigned?
text: Imagine America is a big kid, and the U.S. State Department is like America's special team of friendly grown-ups who talk to all the other grown-ups in charge of other countries around the world. Their job is to help America be friends with all the other countries in the big playground of the world. They talk to them, share toys (like helping each other with things), and try to make sure everyone plays nicely and doesn't get into fights. If an American kid gets lost in another playground, the State Department helps them get home! Now, when the very experienced grown-ups, like the coaches and the best players on that team, all decide

title: Why does the Chinese Super League suddenly have so much money to buy foreign players? (football)
text: Imagine China is like a big playground, and the grown-ups in charge really, really want their football teams to be super amazing, like the best in the whole world! So, they tell all the big companies, "Hey, you guys have lots of money, why don't you spend some of it on football to make our teams famous?" These companies, who have giant piggy banks from selling things like cars or building houses, think, "That's a great idea! If we have a super cool football team, everyone will know our company, and maybe more people will want to buy our stuff!" So, they open their piggy banks and use that money to buy the very best football players from other countries, who are like superheroes with the ball. These players cost a lot because they're so good, but it makes the games really exciting and helps China's football get better and better!

title: How can I find real, unbiased news?

title: What is that super weird dizzy feeling we get sometimes while stretching?
text: Okay, imagine your body has special juice inside (that's your blood!) that needs to go all over, especially up to your brain in your head so you can think and see clearly. Sometimes when you stretch really big, or bend down low, a lot of that juice goes to your arms or legs. Then, when you stand up super fast, all the juice in your body tries to rush down to your feet really quickly, like water going down a slide! For just a tiny, tiny second, your head doesn't get quite enough juice. That's why you feel all wobbly and dizzy, like your head is floating! But don't worry, your body is super smart and quickly sends more juice back up to your head, and then you feel all better again!

title: If every action has an equal and opposite reaction, why can a bullet do tremendous damage to someone, while the recoil from the gun cannot?
text:
Okay, imagine you and your friend are going to push something. The rule is, no matter how hard you push, the thing you push pushes back on you with the exact same strength! It's like a perfectly fair pushing game.

Now, a bullet is super tiny and goes super-duper fast, like a tiny little speedy zoom! When that tiny, super-fast thing hits someone, all that strong push is squished into one tiny, tiny spot, and it makes a really big ouchie, like a super hard poke that can break things.

But the gun is much, much bigger and heavier, and when it pushes back on your shoulder, it moves much slower, like a big, gentle shove.

title: How do companies like Valve which have a "flat" organizational structure work, seemingly without bosses or direction?
text: Imagine a big playroom, like a giant toy store, filled with all sorts of cool toys and games! Instead of one grown-up telling every single kid, "You *must* play with the red ball now!" or "You *have* to build a tall tower!", everyone gets to pick what they want to do. If you love building blocks, you go to the block area and start building. If your friend loves building blocks too, they might join you, and you both decide together what kind of amazing castle or rocket to build. Maybe someone says, "Hey, let's make a really big fort!" and lots of kids who like that idea will come together and help make the fort, deciding together how it should look. There isn't one boss telling everyone what

title: If sound travels better through water, why is it always quiet under water ?
text: Okay, imagine sound is like a little runner trying to pass a message! In the air, there's lots of space, so the runner has to run a bit to get to the next person. But in water, all the tiny water bits are squished super close together, like a really crowded elevator! So, when the sound runner passes the message, it goes super fast and super far because there's always someone right next to them to grab the message immediately. That's why sound travels better in water! But your ears are like special listening cups made for air, not water. When you go underwater, it's like putting those cups inside a big, soft pillow. The water pushes on your ears in a funny way, making all the sounds fuzzy and quiet, even if there are lots of sounds zooming all around you! Your ears just aren't built to hear clearly in water, so it feels quiet to you.

title: What does sunlight consist of, and why do some parts pass through windows while other parts don't?
text: Sunlight is like a big mix of super tiny, super fast sprinkles! Some of these sprinkles are the colors we can see, like red, yellow, and blue. But there are also other kinds of sprinkles we *can't* see with our eyes, like ones that make you feel warm (like a cozy blanket hug!) and others that can give you a sunburn if you stay outside too long. Now, your window is like a special magic gate. It has tiny, tiny holes, but only *some* of

title: What does the state department's senior management section do? How will them leaving affect the US government?
text: Imagine America is a big kid, and the State Department is like America's "friend-making" club. Their job is to help America talk to all the other kid-countries around the world, like France, Japan, or Canada, to make sure everyone is friends and plays nicely. The "senior management section" are like the very grown-up helpers and coaches in this friend-making club. They're the ones who know all the rules for playing fair, how to share toys, and what to say when someone is being a bit grumpy. They help plan all the big playdates and make sure America knows how to be a good friend and keep things safe. If these grown-up helpers and coaches suddenly decide to leave, it's like if all the teachers left your school at the same time. It would be really hard for America to talk to its friends, make new ones, or figure out what to do when there's a problem. Things would get messy and confusing, and it would be much harder to play nicely with all the other kid-countries because there wouldn't be enough grown-ups to help plan and guide everyone. It would be hard to keep America's friendships strong and solve problems in the world.

title: Why is it so difficult to desalinate water?
text: Imagine you have a big glass of water, and someone accidentally put a whole bunch of tiny, tiny sprinkles (that's the salt!) in it. Now, you want to drink the water, but you don't want any sprinkles! It's really, really hard to get all those super tiny sprinkles out, right? They're mixed everywhere

title: Why is it so difficult to achieve and maintain an erection while standing?
text: Imagine your pee-pee needs to fill up with lots and lots of blood, like a water balloon, to get big and hard. Now, you know how when you drop a toy, it always falls down to the floor? That's because of a super strong invisible pull called gravity that pulls everything downwards. When you're standing up, gravity is trying to pull all that blood *down* towards your feet, away from your pee-pee. It's like trying to fill up a water balloon while someone is gently pulling the water out at the bottom! Your body has to work extra, extra hard to push all that blood *up* and keep it inside your pee-pee, fighting against that big pull. But when you're lying down, gravity isn't pulling the blood away so much, so it's much easier for your body to keep the blood in your pee-pee and make it big and strong. That's why it's a lot harder for your pee-pee to stay big and hard when you're standing up!

title: Why does grilled cheese taste so much better than a plain cheese sandwich?
text: Okay, imagine your plain cheese sandwich is like a sleepy bear, just chilling out. It's nice, but nothing super exciting. Now, when we make a grilled cheese, it's like we give it a warm, cozy hug in a pan! First, we put yummy butter on the bread, and when it gets warm, the bread turns super crispy and golden, like a happy little sun, which tastes super good. Then, the cheese inside gets all warm and melty and gooey, like yummy lava! When cheese gets warm and melty, its flavor wakes up and gets much bigger and happier, making it taste extra special and delicious. So, the warm, crispy bread and the super melty, happy cheese together just taste like a big party in your mouth!

title: What is the Libertarian plan for roads, police/fire departments, and schools?
text: Okay, imagine your grown-ups usually decide everything, right? Libertarians think it's better if you and your family get to choose more things yourselves, and fewer things are decided by all the grown-ups together (that's like the government). So, for **roads**, instead of the government building all the roads, maybe different companies or groups of people would build their own roads, and if you want to use a really nice one, you might pay a tiny bit of money, like for a special bouncy castle. For **police and fire**, instead of one big group of helpers for everyone, your family or your neighborhood might pay a special company to help keep you safe from bad guys or put out fires, just for your street. Or maybe all the neighbors would agree to help each other out. And for **schools**, instead of everyone going to the same big school the government runs, your

title: How does taxing Mexican imports 20% to build a border wall not just pass the costs on to American consumers?

title: I'm a better person when I'm drunk. Why is this?
text: When grown-ups drink special grown-up juice, it makes their brain feel a little bit sleepy and fuzzy, like when you're super tired and things feel silly. Sometimes, when your brain is fuzzy, it makes you *feel* like you're super brave, or super funny, or don't worry about things you usually worry about. You might *feel* like you're the bestest person ever because you're not shy or you're having so much fun and laughing a lot! But really, the grown-up juice doesn't actually make you a *better* person inside. It just changes how your brain feels for a little while. It's like when you put on a silly hat and *feel* like a superhero, but you're still you underneath! Being a truly good person comes from being kind and thoughtful when your brain is wide awake and not fuzzy.

title: At what point would it be too far along to worry about climate change?
text: Imagine our Earth is like a big house, and sometimes it gets a little too warm, like when you have a fever. Climate change is like that fever getting a bit worse over time. Now, when you have a fever, you always try to feel better, right? You drink water, rest, and maybe take some medicine. It's the same for Earth! Even if the fever has been there for a while and made some things a bit tricky, like making some places too hot or having bigger storms, it's never too late to try and help our Earth feel better. We can always do things like planting more trees, using less electricity, and walking instead of driving, to help cool it down and make things a bit nicer for everyone. So, we always worry and try to help, because even a little bit of good can make a big difference!

title: Why is it entirely possible to fall asleep while listening to music, but very difficult to fall asleep while listening to someone snore?
text: Imagine your brain is a little sleepy puppy trying to curl up for a nap. When you listen to calm music, it's like a soft, gentle hum or a quiet lullaby that helps the puppy feel safe and cozy, so it can drift off to sleep. The music is often steady and pretty, making your brain feel relaxed and happy to rest. But when someone snores, it's like a big, rumbly, sometimes sudden and loud noise that makes the puppy's ears perk up! It's not a calm sound; it's often surprising and uneven, making your brain wonder, "What was that? Is everything okay?" That keeps your brain awake and alert, because it's hard to relax when there's a funny, loud, and sometimes startling noise happening, even if you know it's just someone sleeping.

title: Why do gyms put cardio equipment in front of windows?
text: Imagine you're running super fast on a pretend bike, but you're not actually going anywhere! That can get a little bit boring, right? So, gyms put those bikes and running machines by the windows for a few reasons! One big reason is so you can look outside and see cars, or people walking their dogs,

title: Why is America pro spending billions on a wall but against spending billions on universal health care?
text: Imagine our country is like a very, very big house with a huge yard. Some grown-ups who make the rules think it's super important to build a tall fence all around the

title: Why do lakes freeze but rivers don't, in the same temperature?
text: Okay, imagine your bathtub full of water. If you leave it there when it's super cold outside, the cold air just sits on top and slowly makes the whole top of the water turn into a hard, slippery ice sheet, like a big, solid blanket. That's like a lake! It just sits there and lets the cold make it hard. But a river is like water going down a slide, always rushing and wiggling around! Even if it's super cold, the water keeps mixing and moving too fast for the cold air to make it all turn hard. It's like trying to give a cold blanket to someone who keeps running away and wiggling – it's much harder for them to get totally cold and still enough to turn into a hard, frozen statue! So, lakes are still and let the cold freeze them, but rivers wiggle and run away from the cold, making it harder to freeze.

title: Where does the mustard from "mustard gas" come from?
text: You know how sometimes we give things names because they remind us of something else, even if they're not really that thing? Like a 'butterfly' isn't made of butter, right? Well, 'mustard gas' is a very, very yucky and dangerous chemical that bad people made a long, long time ago. It's not made from the yummy yellow mustard you put on your hotdog or sandwich – absolutely not! It just got its name because it smells a little bit like mustard, or sometimes like garlic or onions. It's a special kind of invisible cloud that was cooked up in a factory, not grown in a field like mustard seeds. So, the 'mustard' part is just a name because of its smell, not because it's food or comes from the mustard plant.

title: How does a tax on imports work? How does this tax shake down to consumers?
text: Imagine your favorite toys! Some toys are made right here in your town, and some come from far, far away, like from another country. When a toy comes from far away to be sold here, it's like a special rule says, "If you want to bring this toy into our toy store, you have to pay a little extra money to the grown-ups who run our town first." This extra money is called a tax on imports. Now, the person who brought the toy here doesn't want to lose money, right? So, they just add that extra money they paid *onto the price tag* of the toy. This means when you go to the toy store to buy that toy that came from far away, it costs *more* money for you to buy it than if there was no extra tax. So, you end up paying a little bit more because of that rule!

title: Cross-pollination by hand. To be more blunt, how can you make sure two plants have "sex"?
text: Okay, imagine plants want to make baby plants, just like how you might want a little brother or sister! But plants can't run around and play together like people. Instead, they have special parts. Some flowers have a fluffy yellow powder, like magic dust, called 'pollen' – that's like the boy part. Other flowers have a sticky spot inside, like a tiny bed where a baby can grow – that's like the girl part. Usually, a busy bee or the wind helps carry the magic dust from one flower to the sticky bed of another flower. But if we want to help two *specific* plants make a baby together, we can be like a super helper bee! We take a tiny, soft paintbrush or a cotton swab, gently tickle the fluffy magic dust from one flower, and then gently brush that same dust onto the sticky bed of the *other* flower. If the magic dust lands just right on the sticky bed, and the plants like each other, they can start to make a baby seed together! We're just helping them share their special dust to make new plant friends.

title: How are all-you-can-eat buffets profitable?
text: Okay, imagine you have a giant toy box full of yummy snacks! You buy all those snacks in super, super big bags, which makes them much cheaper for you than buying tiny little ones. Now, you invite all your friends over, and they each pay you a little bit of money to eat as much as they want. Some friends might eat a whole lot, like a hungry bear! But other friends might only eat a little bit, like a tiny bird. The grown-ups who own the buffet know that even if one person eats a lot, another person will eat less, and on average, everyone pays a price that is more than what it cost them to buy all that food in the first place. Plus, you get your own food, so they don't need as many helpers running around, which saves them even more money! So, they buy food cheap, people eat different amounts, and they save on helpers, and that's how they make their money!

title: How can humans die of electrocution from wires yet survive lightning bolts?
text: Okay, imagine electricity is like a very strong tickle that can hurt you. When you touch a wire with electricity, it's like the tickle machine keeps running and running and running through

title: How does an import tariff on items from Mexico make Mexico pay for the wall?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friend Mexico are playing, and Mexico makes super cool toys that you want to buy. But you say, "Hey Mexico, if you want to sell your toys in my house, you have to give me a little extra money for each toy first!" So, Mexico's toy company pays that extra money to you. You then say, "Look! Mexico is giving me money for my new big fence!" But here's the secret: Mexico's toy company doesn't want to lose money, so they just make their toys a tiny bit more expensive for *you* to buy. So, when you buy the toys, you're actually paying that extra money, and that's the money you use for your fence. So, it looks like Mexico is paying, but really, the people buying the toys are helping pay for your fence.

title: Why do people from the US say that they are the most free in the world, even compared to first world European countries?
text: Imagine you have a big toy box, and you can pick almost any toy you want to play with, and your grown-ups don't tell you *too* much what to do with it, as long as you're safe. That's how some people in America feel about freedom! They believe they get to make lots and lots of choices for themselves, like what job they want, what kind of house they live in, or what ideas they want to share, and that the government doesn't tell them what to do very often. In some other places, like countries in Europe, grown-ups might have a few more rules that everyone has to follow, like what kind of health doctor you go to or how much money you pay for certain things, so that everyone is helped more evenly. Both ways are good, but people in America often feel extra special because they think they have the most choices and the fewest rules about their own lives, like having the biggest toy box to pick from!

title: What does stretching do?
text: When you stretch, it's like you're gently telling your muscles, "Wake up and get a little bit longer!" Imagine your muscles are like little sleepy rubber bands that got a bit squished up while you were sleeping or sitting still. When you stretch, you gently pull them a little longer, not too much, just enough so they can move more easily. This helps your body feel less stiff, like when you first wake up and give a big yawn, and it makes it easier for you to run, jump, and play without feeling all tight and stuck. So, stretching helps your body feel happy and ready to move!

title: What Caused the Great Depression?
text: Imagine everyone got really, really good at making lots and lots of toys, more toys than kids even wanted to play with! But then, grown-ups didn't have enough money in their pockets to buy all those new toys. So, the toy stores had too many toys and couldn't sell them. Then,

title: How does chat applications knows when the other person is typing before sending the message?
text: Imagine you and your friend are both drawing pictures for each other. When you start to pick up your crayon and make the first little scribble, your phone quickly sends a tiny, secret note to your friend's phone that just says, "Hey, I'm starting to draw my picture!" Your friend's phone gets that little note and says, "Oh! My friend is drawing!" and shows those little bouncy dots. It's not showing your actual drawing yet, just a super-fast "I'm busy!" signal, like a tiny whisper that travels through the air to let them know you're getting ready to send something cool. When you stop drawing (or typing), your phone stops sending those "I'm busy!" notes, and the dots go away.

title: Why is it common practice to bury our dead in the ground?
text: When someone dies, their body stops working, like a toy when its batteries run out. If we just left them out, after a while, they would start to smell yucky, and it wouldn't be very nice to see, and it could even spread tiny germs that make other people sick. So, we dig a hole in the ground and gently put them inside, like putting a special treasure in a safe box. It's a way to keep everything tidy and clean, and it helps us feel better when we're sad because we know they are resting peacefully and safely. Plus, people have been doing this for a very, very long time, so it's a special way we say goodbye and remember them.

title: Why do kernels of microwave popcorn pop individually rather than in groups?
text: Imagine each popcorn kernel is like a tiny, tiny house with a little drop of water inside. When you put them in the microwave, it's like turning on lots of little suns inside the oven. Each tiny house starts getting hotter and hotter. The water inside each house wants to turn into a big, fluffy cloud, but it's stuck inside! It keeps pushing and pushing on the walls. Some houses get hot enough faster than others, or maybe their walls are a little bit weaker. So, when one house gets super hot and its water turns into a super strong cloud, *POP!* it bursts its walls and turns into yummy popcorn. Its neighbor might still be getting warm, or its walls might be a bit stronger, so it waits a little longer. They don't all pop at the same time because each little house has to get hot enough *by itself* for its own water to make its own big burst, like how you have to push each button on a toy separately, not all at once!

title: Why were the Repubs allowed to block Obama from appointing a new Justice-- for over a year?
text: Imagine your principal (that's like President Obama) wanted to pick a new special teacher for the whole school (that's like a Justice, who helps make big rules). But there's

title: - What is actually happening when you get water stuck in your ear?
text: Imagine your ear is like a tiny, twisty slide! When you go swimming or take a bath, sometimes a little bit of water decides to go down that slide. But instead of sliding all the way out, it gets stuck in a little dip or corner inside your ear. It's like if you poured water into a tiny, curvy cup and it just sits there, wiggling around because it can't find the way out easily. It makes a funny sloshy sound because the water is bouncing around a bit, and it feels weird because your ear is usually nice and dry. It's not hurting you, it's just a little water visitor that got lost on the slide and needs a little jiggle to find its way back out!

title: Why is the Midwest called the Midwest?
text: Imagine you have a super big map of our country, like a giant puzzle! A super duper long time ago, most people lived on one side, kind of like the right edge of the puzzle. When they started moving away from that side, going towards the middle, that area felt like the "west" to them because they were moving west from where they started. But then, people kept going even further, all the way to the other side of the puzzle! So, that first "west" place wasn't the *most* west anymore; it was kind of in the *middle* of the whole country, but still a little bit west of where everyone started. So, they called it the "Midwest" because it's in the middle, and it used to be considered the west part when people first moved there!

title: How does imposing a 20% tax on Mexican imports, WHICH will be paid BY American Citizens, make Mexico pay for the wall?

title: why is cancer so fucking prevalent?
text: Imagine your body is like a giant castle made of tiny, tiny LEGO bricks called cells. These bricks are always busy building, fixing, and making more bricks so your castle stays strong and grows bigger. Most of the time, they do a perfect job! But sometimes, just like when you're building with LEGOs, one little brick might get a bit wonky or broken, or it might try to make a copy of itself and make a mistake. Usually, your body's special helpers come and fix that broken brick or throw it away. But sometimes, a broken brick keeps making more broken bricks, and they don't stop growing when they should, even when there's no more space. Because your body has SO many bricks and is always building and fixing them all the time, it's a bit like playing a game where you have to build a million things every day – sometimes, a little mistake just happens and slips by. That's why lots of grown-ups hear about it, because our bodies are always working super hard, and sometimes those tiny mistakes just happen.

title: What makes plastic surgery look so obviously overdone?
text: Okay, imagine your face is like a puzzle, and every piece fits perfectly to make *you*. When grown-ups get plastic surgery, it's like they're asking a doctor to change a few puzzle pieces, maybe make one a different shape or size. But sometimes, the doctor changes them *too* much! Like making a nose super tiny when it used to be bigger, or making lips super puffy. Then, those new pieces don't quite fit with the rest of your face puzzle anymore, and your brain notices it looks a bit *off*. Also, your face needs to move and squish when you smile or talk, right? If the doctor pulls the skin too tight, it's like putting a really stiff mask on your face – it can't make all those happy or surprised shapes easily, so it looks frozen or a bit like a doll, and that's why it looks obviously overdone, because it doesn't move or fit like a real, natural face.

title: Is it possible to be depressed without knowing it yourself? Without even suspecting it? If yes, how does that work exactly?
text: Yes, it's totally possible! Imagine if you always wore shoes that were a tiny bit too tight, but you've worn them for so long that you don't even remember what comfortable shoes feel like. You just think, "Oh, this is how shoes are!" It's kind of like that with feeling sad or yucky inside (that's what depression can feel like). Your brain might feel a bit yucky for a long, long time, and because it's been like that for so long, it starts to feel normal to you. You might just think, "This is just how I am, this is just how life is." You don't realize that other people might feel sunny and happy more often, or that your

title: Why does the speed of sound increase again after a certain altitude?
text:
Okay, imagine sound is like a game of tag between tiny invisible balls that make up the air.

When you go up high in the sky, like in an airplane, two things usually happen:

title: Why does school food tend to be awful?
text: Okay, imagine your school has to feed *lots and lots* of kids, like all your friends and more! But they don't have a giant piggy bank full of money, so they have to buy food that's not super expensive. Also, there are grown-up rules that say the food has to be healthy, even if healthy food sometimes tastes a little boring to kids. And because they have to cook so much food for so many kids, really fast, it's super hard to make every single bite taste like your favorite yummy treat from home. It's like when your grown-up tries to cook for a big party – sometimes it's good, but not *always* as special as the food made just for you!

title: Why do most Ameican homes in TV shows have fly screens, but they're uncommon elsewhwre?
text: Imagine you want to open your window to let the fresh air in, but you don't want yucky flies or buzzy mosquitoes to fly into your house and bother you! In America, lots of places get super warm and have many bugs flying around, especially in summer. So, people put up special see-through nets called fly screens on their windows and doors. It's like a tiny fence that lets the air in but keeps the bugs out! Other places might not have as many bugs, or maybe they keep their windows closed more often, so they don't always need those special bug fences.

title: What happens to our bodies to cause sleep walking?
text: Imagine your body is like a big house, and when you go to sleep, most of the lights turn off so it can rest. But sometimes, when you're sleepwalking, it's like the lights in the "moving around" part of your house (your legs and arms) accidentally turn on, even though the lights in the "thinking and knowing where you are" part of your house (your brain) are still mostly off and sleepy! So your body gets up and walks, but your brain is still dreaming and not really awake to tell your body what to do or where to go. It's like your brain is still in dreamland, but your body decided to go on a little adventure without it, because sometimes our sleepy brains get a tiny bit confused about whether it's time to dream or time to wake up and move.

title: If web browsers treat Javascript consistently, why can't they do the same with CSS?
text: Okay, imagine web browsers are like different friends who all have to draw a picture using the same instructions. JavaScript is like telling your friends, "Draw a circle right here!" or "

title: What does "/16 or /24" after an IP Address mean?
text:
Okay, imagine your computer has a special house number, like 192.168.1.10. That's its unique address! Now, the little number like "/16" or "/24" after it is like telling us how big the "neighborhood" or "street" that computer lives on is.

If it says "/24", it means only the houses on *just that street* can easily talk and play together. It's a small, specific group of friends.

But if it says "/16", it means all the houses on *that street AND the next street AND maybe even the street after that* can all talk and play together! It's a much bigger neighborhood or a whole block of friends.

So, the bigger the number after the slash (like /24), the smaller and more specific the group of computers. The smaller the number (like /16), the bigger and wider the group of computers that are all part of the same big family. It just helps computers know who their nearby friends are!

title: Why are humans the only creature that needs help in giving birth?
text: Imagine a baby's head is like a big, round watermelon, and mommy's tummy exit is a bit like a small, twisty slide! Humans are super smart, so our brains are big even when we're tiny babies, which means our heads are big. Also, because human mommies stand up and walk on two legs, their hips are shaped a bit differently, making the exit path narrower and curvier than most animal mommies. So, when the big watermelon head tries to go through the small, twisty slide, it's a bit tricky and sometimes needs a helpful hand to guide it just right. Most animal babies have smaller heads compared to their mommies' exits, and their path is usually wide and straight, so their babies just slide right out easily all by themselves!

title: How does a war neutrality work? For example, why didn't Germany just invade Switzerland and ignore its neutrality?
text: Imagine two kids, Bob and Sue, are having a big argument and pushing each other. Being neutral is like if you say, "I'm not going to help Bob, and I'm not going to help Sue. I'm just going to play with my own toys over here, please don't pull me into your fight!" Countries do this because they don't want to get hurt or have their homes broken in a big war. They say, "We won't help anyone fight, so please don't fight us!" Now, why didn't Germany just go into Switzerland? Well, Switzerland is like a very special house built high up in the mountains, with lots of secret tunnels and strong doors. It's

title: What limits our speed in space?
text: Imagine you're running as fast as you can! Even if you run super, super fast, there's a special, super-duper speed limit in the whole universe that nothing can ever go past, not even the fastest spaceship! It's like a big rule for everything. This super speed limit is called the "speed of light." To go fast, you need a lot of push, like how a rocket uses fire to zoom up. The faster you try to go, the more and more push you need, and it gets harder and harder, like trying to push a giant sleepy elephant! You'd need so much push that you just can't get past that special speed of light, no matter what. So, the universe itself has a fastest speed, and that's what stops us from going even faster.

title: why do a lot of businesses push me towards downloading their app?
text:
Imagine your favorite toy store wants to be super good friends with you! They want you to have their special secret clubhouse (the app) on your tablet or grown-up's phone.

1.  **They can talk to you directly:** It's like having a special walkie-talkie just for them! They can send you little messages (like a secret whisper!) to tell you when new, cool toys arrive or when there's a party.
2.  **They learn what you like:** When you play in their clubhouse (the app), they can see which toys you look at most. That helps them know what kind of candy or toys you love, so they can get more of *those* things just for you!
3.  **It's super easy for you:** It's like having their whole store in your pocket, always ready, so you don't have to wait or type in long names to find your favorite teddy bear. It's quicker!
4.  **They want you to visit them more:** If you have *their* special game (the app), you'll probably play with *their* game more often than going to a big playground (the internet) where lots of other games are. They want you to remember *them* first!

So, they push

title: How big are human intestines and why?
text: Okay, imagine your tummy has two super important tubes inside! The first one, called the 'small intestine,' is super, duper long – if you unrolled it, it would be longer

title: How porn can "hurt everyone"?
text: Imagine you're playing with your toys, but some other grown-ups are making a pretend video with *their* toys. Sometimes, the grown-ups making those videos aren't being kind to the people in them – maybe they make them do things they don't really want to do, or they don't pay them fairly, and that makes those people sad or hurt.

title: Why are the Terms used in Anatomy and other Sciences usually derived from Latin or Greek?
text: Imagine you and your friends from all over the world are playing with new toys. If everyone named their toys something different in their own language, it would be super confusing! "My *gloop* is shiny!" "My *flibber* is fast!" No one would know what anyone was talking about. A long, long, long time ago, when smart people started learning about our bodies and how the world works, they decided to use special words that everyone could understand, no matter where they lived. These special words came from two old, old languages called Latin and Greek. It was like a secret code language just for science! They picked these languages because lots of smart people knew them back then, and also because words in Latin and Greek don't change their meaning very much. English words can sometimes mean different things, but Latin and Greek words stay the same, like a rule that never changes. So, when a scientist names a part of your body 'femur' (which means 'thigh bone' in Latin), everyone, everywhere, for always, knows exactly what bone they're talking about. It makes sure everyone is on the same page and nobody gets confused!

title: How do transportation apps like Moovit or Navigation in Google Maps know exactly when buses are arriving late, where exactly are they, at what time will they serve, etc?
text: Imagine each bus is like a special toy car that has a tiny little walkie-talkie inside! This walkie-talkie is always telling a super-duper big grown-up, "Hey, I'm right here now!" It's like the bus is saying, "I'm at the park!" or "Now I'm at the store!" All these messages from all the buses go to that big grown-up who has a giant map and sees exactly where every single bus is at that very moment. Your phone, when you open the app, is like you asking that big grown-up, "Where's my bus? Is it coming soon?" And because the grown-up knows where all the buses are *right now* and where they are supposed to go (like their schedule), they can tell your phone, "Oh, that bus is a little bit late today because there were too many cars on the road, but it will be at your stop in 5 minutes!" So, it's like the buses are always talking, a grown-up is always listening and watching, and your phone is asking that grown-up for the latest news!

title: What is the white foam that forms on top of the water when you cook pasta ?
text: You know how sometimes when you play with soap and water, you get lots of bubbles? Well, pasta is made from something called flour, and inside the flour are tiny, tiny little bits we call starch. When you put the pasta in the hot water, some of that starch comes off the pasta and goes into the water. When the water gets super hot and starts to bubble and boil (like when you blow really hard into your drink!), those tiny starch bits help the bubbles stick together and not pop right away. So, instead of just regular water bubbles, you get a big, fluffy white cloud of bubbles on top because the starch is helping them hold hands and stay together! It's just the pasta's way of saying "hi" to the water!

title: How come Digg died but Reddit thrived?
text:
Imagine two big playgrounds, Digg and Reddit, where kids could share their favorite toys (like cool videos or funny pictures) and everyone would vote for the best ones to play with.

Digg was like a playground where, one day, the grown-ups decided *they* would pick all the best toys, and only let the *biggest, loudest kids* put things in the main toy box. All the regular kids got really sad and felt like their toys didn't matter anymore, so they stopped playing there and went home.

Reddit was another playground, and it was super good at letting *everyone* vote for their favorite toys. It also had lots of *little rooms* inside, like one room just for dinosaurs, and another just for building blocks, so everyone could find their friends who liked the same things. Because Reddit listened to what all the kids wanted and let them pick their own toys, more and more kids came to play, and it became a super big, happy playground!

title: How do most companies monitor their employee's internet activity?
text: Imagine your computer at work is like a special crayon box that belongs to your grown-up boss, not you. When you draw pictures (which is like going on the internet), your boss can see everything you draw with *their* crayons and *their* paper. They might have a little 'spy' program living inside the computer that watches what websites you look at, what games you try to play (even though you should be doing work!), and what words you type. It's also like all the internet roads for the company go through a special 'toll booth' in their building, and they have a grown-up standing there watching all the cars (which are like your internet visits) go by. They do all this to make sure everyone is doing their jobs and to keep all their computers safe from bad guys or messes.

title: People when they get old seem to be shorter than when they were young with at least a few inches. Why??
text: Imagine your body is like a tall tower made of lots of building blocks, and between each block, there's a little soft, squishy pillow. When you're young, these pillows are plump and bouncy, making your tower nice and tall! But as people get super, super old, like Grandma or Grandpa, those little pillows get squished down a bit from all the years of running, jumping, and just standing up. They aren't as fluffy anymore, and sometimes the blocks themselves can get a tiny bit squished too. So, if the pillows are flatter and the blocks are a little bit smaller, your whole tower ends up being a little bit shorter than it used to be! It's just what happens when you've been a tower for a very, very long time.

title: Why is Social Media so addictive?
text: Imagine you have a magic toy box that sometimes makes a little *ding!* When it dings, it means there might be a new, super fun toy inside, or a picture of your favorite friend playing! You open it, and sometimes there's a shiny new toy (like someone liked your picture!) and it makes you feel happy, like getting a yummy cookie. So, you want to keep looking in the box, just in case another ding happens, or maybe there's an even cooler toy just a little further down! Sometimes, you look because you don't want your friends to play with all the fun toys without you knowing. And because it feels good to see new things and feel happy, your brain starts to really like that feeling, so you want to keep checking the magic toy box again and again, even when you should be playing with your real toys or eating your dinner. It's like your brain gets used to that happy feeling and wants more and more of it!

title: What will happen to someone if they die in space? Will they keep orbiting? Will they decay?
text: Okay, imagine space is like a giant, super-duper cold, empty room with no air. If someone dies there, their body wouldn't get squishy and disappear like a banana peel on Earth because there are no tiny bugs to eat it up, and no air to help it break down. It would just stay frozen and hard like an ice cube, maybe even a bit dry! If they were already going around and around our Earth

title: Why does local anaesthetic have adrenaline in it?
text: Okay, imagine you have a boo-boo, and the doctor gives you a special sleepy medicine so you don't feel any ouchies while they fix it, like when they fill a tooth. Now, this sleepy medicine wants to spread out and go everywhere, but we only want it to make *one* spot sleepy, right? Adrenaline is like a tiny helper friend that tells the little rivers inside your body (we call them blood vessels) right where the sleepy medicine is to squeeze tight! When these little rivers squeeze, they can't carry the sleepy medicine away so fast. This makes the sleepy medicine stay exactly where the doctor put it, making it work super-duper well and last a long, long time. So you stay comfy and don't feel any ouchies for the whole time the doctor is fixing you up!

title: Teeth grinding at night and how it can be so loud. Also how can our jaws clench that hard unconsciously but not awake?
text: Okay, imagine your teeth are like two sets of super strong little blocks in your mouth. Sometimes, when you're fast asleep and dreaming about superheroes or puppies, your mouth muscles, which are super strong because they help you chew all your yummy food, start to push those blocks together and rub them! It's like when you rub two toy cars together, and they make a sound. Your teeth are very hard, like little stones, so when they rub and grind, it can make a really loud, scratchy noise, almost like a little earthquake happening inside your head! It sounds so loud because the sound travels through your bones and can even make your pillow shake a tiny bit. Now, why can you squeeze them so hard when you're asleep but not when you're awake? Well, when you're awake, your smart brain is like a grown-up watching over you, and it says, "Hey! Don't bite down too hard, you might hurt your teeth!" But when you're asleep, your brain is busy dreaming and not paying as much attention to your mouth muscles, so they can get super tight and squeeze much harder without your brain telling them to stop. It's like your muscles are having a secret workout while you're sleeping!

title: why must I first dial 1 before calling this number?
text: Imagine your phone knows all the phone numbers that live in your neighborhood really well, like they're all in one special toy box. But if you want to call a friend who lives in a different neighborhood, in a totally different toy box far away, your phone needs a little extra help to know where to look! The "1" is like saying, "Hey phone, this number isn't in our usual box,

title: What is the difference between serotonin and dopamine?
text:
Imagine your brain is like a super important control room in your head, and it has tiny little messengers that run around to help you feel different things!

One messenger is called **serotonin**. Serotonin is like the messenger that helps you feel calm, cozy, and happy when everything feels just right, like when you're snuggled up in your warm bed or have a full tummy after a yummy snack. It helps you feel peaceful and content.

Another messenger is called **dopamine**. Dopamine is like the messenger that makes you feel excited and want to go get things, like when you see your favorite toy and really, really want to play with it, or when you're about to get a special sticker for being a good helper! It makes you feel like "yay, I want that!" or "I did it!"

So, serotonin helps you feel calm and happy *now*, like a warm hug, and dopamine helps you feel excited and happy when you *want something* or *get something* you like!

title: If radiation exposure can cause cancer how does it cure it?
text: Imagine your body is made of tiny, tiny building blocks, like LEGOs. Sometimes, if a few invisible rays (which are called radiation) bump into one of your good blocks by accident, that block can get a little bit confused and start making lots and lots of other confused, naughty blocks that grow into a big, messy pile we call cancer. But here's the clever part! When doctors find one of those naughty piles of blocks, they can use special, super-strong invisible rays, like a super-powered laser pointer, to zap *just* the naughty pile. These strong rays are really, really good at smashing and breaking apart only the naughty, confused blocks so they can't grow anymore and disappear, while trying very, very hard not to hit your good, healthy blocks around them. So, a little bit of radiation can sometimes make a block confused, but a lot of *carefully aimed* radiation can smash the already confused, naughty blocks away!

title: What would happen if we detonated an atomic bomb in the eye of a hurricane?
text: Okay, imagine a hurricane is like a super, super giant spinning top made of air and water, so big it covers many cities! And an atomic bomb is like the biggest, loudest, hottest firecracker you can ever imagine, making a huge flash and a big push of air. If you set off that super-duper firecracker right in the quiet middle part of the giant spinning top, it would make a HUGE flash and a super-hot bubble of air for just a tiny, tiny second. It would make a big push of air, like a giant sneeze, right where it went off. But the giant spinning top (the hurricane) is so, so, so much bigger and stronger than even that super-duper firecracker. It would be like trying to stop a giant train with a tiny little pebble – the pebble makes a little noise, but the train just keeps on going! The hurricane would just keep spinning and blowing, almost like nothing happened. It wouldn't stop the storm or make it go away because it's just too huge and powerful for one big boom to stop.

title: What is the benefit to a company to enact a policy that prohibits promotion of employees from within?
text: Imagine you have a super fun game you play with your friends every day. You're all really good at it! But sometimes, your grown-ups want to make the game even *more* exciting or maybe play a brand new game that needs someone who knows a special trick. So, instead of picking one of your friends who already plays the old game, they might invite a *new* friend from another neighborhood who knows all sorts of amazing new tricks or has cool new ideas no one thought of before! This way, the company (which is like the game) gets fresh, super smart people who can bring brand new ways of doing
