title: Why do we need discipline?
text: Imagine your grown-ups tell you it's time to brush your teeth, even if you'd rather keep playing with your toys. Discipline is like remembering to do that important thing, even when it's not the most fun, because you know it helps you have a healthy, happy smile! It helps you learn to do things that keep you safe, like holding hands when crossing the street, and it helps you learn new things, like how to draw or count, because you stick with it. When you have discipline, it helps you be a kind friend, listen to your teachers, and grow up strong and smart by making good choices, even when nobody is watching.

title: Scientists figured a way to transform hydrogen into metal. Why is this important?
text: Imagine hydrogen is like super light, invisible air, like what makes balloons float way up high! And metal is like your shiny spoon or your strong bike, something you can hold that's hard

title: Why does a 16oz bottle soda cost $1.79 while a 32oz fountain soda costs $.99?
text: Okay, imagine your favorite juice box. The little bottle of soda is like that juice box! Someone had to make the special bottle, fill it up in a big factory far away, put a lid on it, put a sticker on it, put it in a big box, and then put that box on a giant truck to drive it all the way to the store. All that special work and traveling costs more money. Now, the big fountain soda is like if the store just has a big tank of super-duper sweet juice, and they just mix it with water right there in the store when you want it, and put it in a simple cup. It's much easier and quicker for them to make it right on the spot, so even though it's bigger, it doesn't cost as much because it didn't have to go on a long trip in its own fancy bottle!

title: What do Negative Ion bracelets actually do?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special bracelet on your arm. Some grown-ups think this bracelet has tiny, invisible "happy air" bits inside called negative ions, and they believe these bits can make you feel super strong, super healthy, or super calm, like magic! But really, most grown-ups who are super smart scientists say that the bracelet is just a nice thing to wear, like a pretty sticker. It doesn't actually make your body do anything different, even if it feels like it does because you *think* it's helping. So, it mostly just looks cool!

title: How could NAFTA be terminated by a single country?
text: Imagine you, your friend from Canada, and your friend from Mexico all made a special promise to share your toys (which are like things countries buy and sell) without having to pay extra candy for them. This special promise was called NAFTA. But even though you all agreed, the rules of your promise say that if one of you, like the USA, decides they don't want to keep that promise anymore, they just have to tell the other two, "Hey, I'm not going to play by this NAFTA rule anymore!" After they say that, they usually have to wait a little bit, like six months, and then that special promise just stops working for them. They can then make new promises or just go back to playing however they want, even if the other two friends keep playing by the old promise for a little while.

title: Why is it that Autism affects males more than females?
text: Okay, imagine boys' brains and girls' brains are like two different kinds of yummy cookies – both are great, but they're a tiny bit different, right? Sometimes, when a brain works in a special way called autism, it shows up differently in boys than in girls. For boys, it's often easier for grown-ups to notice because they might do things like really, really love one toy and only want to talk about it, or get super upset by loud noises, or flap their hands when they're excited. Girls' brains are also special, and when they have autism, sometimes they're really good at trying to act like their friends to fit in, or they might be super quiet, or their special things they love might look more like what other girls like, but in a very, very focused way. So, it's not always that way more boys have it, but sometimes it's just easier for grown-ups to *see* it in boys because of how their special brains show it. Grown-ups are getting much better at looking for it in girls now too!

title: Why does time go so slowly when we're little, yet as we age, time seems to get shorter?
text: When you're little, like 5 years old, every single day is full of amazing new things! You learn new words, play new games, see new toys, and explore new places. Your brain is like a super sponge, soaking up so many firsts and new memories. When so much exciting stuff happens every day, it feels like those days stretch out really long, because your brain remembers so much happening in them. It's also because one year is a HUGE part of your whole life so far, like a giant slice of pie! But when grown-ups get older, their days often become more similar – they go to work, cook dinner, and do routines. Not as

title: Why do you stop being hungry after many hours of not eating?
text: Imagine your body is like a toy car that needs special batteries to go zoom! When you eat food, it's like putting fresh, quick batteries in your car. After a few hours, those quick batteries start to run low, and your tummy makes rumbling noises, like your car saying, "Hey, I need more batteries!" That's being hungry. But your body is super clever! If you don't put new batteries in right away, it has a secret storage box of special, super-long-lasting batteries it saved up, like an emergency stash. When your body starts using those secret batteries, it feels like it has energy again, so it stops yelling "Feed me!" for a little while. It's still using power to play and think, but it's using its saved-up power instead of needing *new* power right away. It's like your car switched to a backup fuel tank!

title: Is there anything that tastes salty but isn't salt?
text: Yes! That's a super good question! You know how salt is that white sparkly stuff we put on fries to make them yummy? Well, sometimes your tongue tastes 'salty' even when it's not that exact white salt. Like, if you run really fast and sweat, your sweat tastes a little salty, right? Or if you cry, your tears are salty too! And the big ocean water, it's super salty, but it's not just a giant bowl of the salt from our kitchen. This happens because there are other tiny, tiny things that can make your tongue feel that 'salty' feeling, even if they aren't the same salt we eat. It's kind of like how a red apple and a red ball are both red, but they're different things! Your tongue is just really good at telling you when something feels salty, even if it's a different kind of salty.

title: How does plastic thrown in the garbage, which is destined for a landfill, make its way to the ocean?
text: Okay, imagine you have a giant mountain of all the garbage people throw away, like a super-duper big pile of your toys outside. Sometimes, when it's really windy, a light plastic bag or a wrapper might fly right off the top of that big garbage mountain, woosh! And when it rains, the water can wash little bits of plastic down the side of the mountain. These flying plastics and washed-away pieces can then get into little puddles, which flow into small streams, and those streams flow into bigger rivers. And guess where all those big rivers go? Splash! Right into the giant, blue ocean! So, the plastic takes a long, long ride with the wind and the water all the way to the sea.

title: Why is Apple suing Qualcomm?
text: Imagine Apple makes super cool toy cars (iPhones), and Qualcomm makes a very special engine (a phone chip) that helps the car talk to other cars and find its way. Apple buys these special engines from Qualcomm. But Qualcomm says, "Okay, you pay for the engine, AND you have to pay us extra money, like a big tax, just for using our *idea* of how engines work, and that tax will be based on how fancy your *whole toy car* is, not just our engine!" Apple thinks this extra "idea tax" is too much and not fair, because they only bought the engine, not the whole car! Apple also says Qualcomm isn't giving them promised money back. So

title: How do teachers quickly tell which students are intelligent over ones who are not?
text: Your teacher is like a super good watcher! They don't have a magic wand to say "this kid is smart" or "this kid is not." Instead, they watch how your brain works all day long! They see if you ask lots of "why?" questions because you're super curious and want to learn everything. They see if you understand new games or stories really fast when they explain them. They see if you try hard to figure out a tricky puzzle, even if it takes a while, or if you can explain something to a friend so they understand too! It's not about being perfect or knowing every answer, but about how much you love to learn, think, and try your best. Everyone's brain is super special, and teachers just look for all the different ways your brain shows it's growing and learning new things!

title: How is the US not facing human rights violations for closing the Flint, Michigan case?
text: Imagine your drinking water from the tap was yucky and made you feel sick for a long, long time. That's what happened in Flint, and it was very, very sad because everyone needs

title: How is it safe/ sanitary not to wash black cast iron cookwear between uses?
text: Imagine your special black pan is like a superhero with an invisible shield made of oil, called 'seasoning'! This shield keeps food from sticking and makes the pan super strong. When you cook yummy food, the pan gets super, super hot, and that heat is like a magic broom that sweeps away all the tiny, invisible germ cooties – poof! They're gone. So, instead of washing it with bubbly soap and water (which the superhero shield doesn't like because it washes away its power!), you just use a paper towel or a little scraper to gently wipe away any leftover food bits. Because it gets so hot and you wipe it clean, it stays safe and happy for next time, ready for more yummy food with its invisible shield all strong!

title: What specifically allows some people to hold their breath longer than others?
text: You know how your body needs air all the time, just like a car needs gas to go? When you hold your breath, your body starts to feel a little bit like, "Hey! I want some air now!" Some people can hold their breath longer because they practice a lot, just like you practice riding your bike or drawing! When they practice, their body gets really good at using the air it already has inside, so it doesn't get that "I want air!" feeling as quickly. Also, their body learns to be super patient and doesn't get scared as fast when it doesn't have air, kind of like how some kids can wait longer for a cookie than others. Their body

title: Why can't huge companies like Google and YouTube beat ad blockers?
text: Imagine you're watching your favorite cartoon show, and suddenly a little commercial pops up about a toy. Google and YouTube are like the TV station that shows you the cartoons for free, but they show you the toy commercials so they can earn money. An ad blocker is like a super-fast helper that sits next to your TV. The moment a toy commercial tries to pop up, this helper quickly presses a magic button to make it disappear before you even see it! Google and YouTube try to hide the commercials better, like putting them in a secret spot, but the ad blocker helpers are very smart and always learn new tricks to find them and make them vanish again. It's like a never-ending game of hide-and-seek, and it's hard for Google to completely stop the ad blockers without also accidentally breaking your favorite cartoon show too, because sometimes the commercials are cleverly mixed in with the show itself!

title: How exactly do the different settings on dryers (i.e. "Permanent Press") affect clothes?
text:
Imagine your dryer is like a big, warm hug for your clothes to make them dry! Different settings are like different kinds of hugs.

When you pick "regular" or "heavy duty," that's like a super warm, strong hug for clothes that are tough, like your jeans or towels. They can handle a lot of heat and get dry super fast.

But some clothes, like your nice shirts or pretty dresses, don't like super hot hugs because they get all grumpy and wrinkly, or sometimes even shrink! So, for those, we use "Permanent Press." That's like a gentle, warm hug that isn't too hot, and it even cools down slowly at the end. This makes sure your clothes don't get all squished and wrinkly, so they look nice and smooth when they come out, almost like they've been ironed a little bit! It's just a special way to be kind to certain clothes so they stay happy and un-wrinkly.

title: Why do small injuries (like paper cuts) seem to hurt so much more than more serious injuries?
text: Okay, imagine your skin has super tiny little alarm bells all over it, especially on your fingers and hands! These alarm bells tell your brain, "Ouchie!" when something hurts. A

title: Could an identical twin get off on a technicality if we can't know that it wasn't their twin that committed a crime?
text: Imagine you have a brother or sister who looks *exactly* like you, like two peas in a pod! Even mommy and daddy sometimes have to look super close to tell you apart. Now, imagine someone did something naughty, like taking a cookie from the jar when they weren't supposed to, and someone saw a person who looked *exactly* like you do it. But because your twin also looks *exactly* like you, the grown-ups who are trying to figure out who took the cookie can't be super, super sure if it was *you* or your twin who did it! They have

title: Sometimes when I'm driving and I squint, the traffic and car lights turn into rays, why?
text: When you squint your eyes, you're making your eyelids squeeze them just a tiny bit, which makes super, super small little gaps for the light to come through, like tiny cracks. Imagine

title: How are NCAA players not being paid?
text:
Imagine you're playing soccer with your friends at school, and you're super good! Lots of people come to watch you play, and the school sells tickets and cool t-shirts with your team's name on them. The school makes lots of money because everyone loves watching you. But you don't get money in your pocket just for playing, right?

The NCAA is like a very, very big club for grown-up kids who go to college. These grown-up kids are super, super good at sports like basketball and football. When they play, lots and lots of people watch on TV and buy tickets to see them. The colleges and the NCAA make a lot of money from these games because everyone loves to watch!

But the grown-up kids who play don't get a paycheck, like a grown-up job. Why? Because the old rules said they are *students* first, there to learn and get smart for their future. So, their "pay" is getting to go to college for free (which costs a lot of money!), and sometimes even getting free food and a place to sleep. It's like a special prize for being so good at sports and helping their school look awesome. They get to learn and play, but they don't get money directly in their hands from the school for playing the game, because they're supposed to be learning, not working a job.

title: Why do some wounds get just stitches or staples to heal while others get packed with sterile gauze?
text: Okay, imagine your skin is like a piece of cloth. If you get a little tear, like a straight line cut, we can just sew the edges together with tiny strings (stitches) or little metal clips (staples). This helps the two sides hug each other tight so they can grow back together super fast and make a new strong piece of cloth. But sometimes, a boo-boo is like a deep hole, not just a line. If we just closed the top of a deep hole, yucky stuff could get trapped inside, like germs, and it wouldn't heal properly from the bottom. So, for those deep holes, doctors put a soft, clean cloth (gauze) inside. This keeps the hole open and clean, letting it heal slowly from the very bottom all the way up to the top, like filling a pot with dirt layer by layer until it's full again. It helps make sure all the bad stuff can come out and new, healthy skin can grow nice and strong.

title: Who would build roads under a Communist ir Anarchist regime?
text: Imagine you and all your friends live in a very big neighborhood, and you all need smooth paths (roads!) to ride your bikes to the park or to each other's houses. If everyone shares

title: If monitors only have 3 colored pixels: red, green, and blue, how do we see colors like yellow on our computers/phones?
text: Imagine your screen is made of super-duper tiny little flashlights, even smaller than a ladybug! Some are red, some are green, and some are blue. That's it! When you see a color like yellow on your screen, what happens is the screen turns on the tiny red flashlight and the tiny green flashlight right next to each other, super close. They are so incredibly close that your eyes can't tell them apart! Your eyes and your brain then get a little tricked and mix those two lights together in your head, making you see yellow! It's kind of like if you put a red dot and a green dot right next to each other and then took a step back, your eyes would just blend them into one yellow spot, even though there's no actual yellow light there.

title: Why is this pigeon the most common bird of cities? What allows the pigeon to thrive in cities?
text: Pigeons are like super-duper old friends of people! A long, long time ago, people actually kept pigeons near their homes, so pigeons learned that living close to us means lots of yummy food and safe spots. That's why they aren't scared of us like other birds might be. Cities are like a giant playground and snack bar for them! There are always crumbs and dropped food for them to eat, like a never-ending picnic. All the tall buildings with their ledges and roofs are just like the tall cliffs where their ancestors used to live, so they find lots of perfect, safe places to build their nests and have their babies. And in the city, there aren't many big, scary animals that want to eat pigeons, so they feel pretty safe to just waddle around and enjoy all the free snacks and comfy homes!

title: Why does your flesh appear to glow red when you hold a bright light against it?
text: When you push a bright light, like a flashlight, against your finger, the light doesn't just stop on top! It's like a tiny explorer that goes *inside* your finger. Guess what's inside your finger? Lots and lots of super tiny tubes filled with your red blood, like yummy red juice! The light explorer goes in, sees all that red blood, and then when it comes back out, it brings some of that red color with it. So, your finger looks red because the light is showing you the red color of your blood from *inside*!

title: If sitting is so bad for us, how bad is the third of our lives we spend lying down (sleeping)?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a superhero! When you sit for too long, it's like your superhero is just sitting on the couch, not going on adventures. Its muscles get a little sleepy and forget how to be super strong. But sleeping? That's totally different! When you sleep, it's like your superhero goes to a special repair shop and gets all charged up and fixed. Your brain gets to sort out all the fun things you learned, and your muscles get stronger and grow. So, even though you're lying down, it's doing super important work to make you big, strong, and smart for tomorrow's adventures, not just being lazy!

title: How does Gintama get away with having parts of so many other anime series in it?
text: Imagine Gintama is like a very silly friend who loves to tell funny jokes about *other* cartoon characters! They don't take the whole cartoon and say 'this is mine now!' That would be like taking your friend's favorite toy and pretending it's yours forever. No, no! Instead, Gintama just borrows a tiny little idea, like a funny costume or a silly saying, to make *their own* show even more giggly. It's like when you draw a funny picture of a superhero you like, but everyone knows you didn't *make* the superhero, you just drew a funny picture! The grown-ups who make the other cartoons usually understand that Gintama is just being silly and making everyone laugh, not trying to trick anyone. So it's okay for them to play dress-up and make jokes because everyone knows it's all just for fun!

title: Why is it blurry when we look straight into water but clear when you wear goggles?
text: Okay, imagine your eyes are super-duper special cameras made to take pictures in the air, like when you're playing outside! When you open your eyes underwater without goggles, it's like the water is a big, wobbly, jiggly window right in front of your camera lens. The water messes up the light that's trying to get to your eyes, making everything look blurry and fuzzy, like a picture that didn't focus right. But when you put on goggles, they make a tiny bubble of air right in front of your eyes! So now, your special camera eyes are looking through *air* again, even though you're underwater. The goggles are like a super clear, flat window that keeps the water away from your eyes, letting the light come in nice and straight, just like when you're on land, so you can see all the cool fish clearly!

title: sometimes when I'm listening to music through headphones and I yawn, the pitch of the music shifts down a semitone or so for the duration of the yawn. Why does this happen?
text: Okay, imagine your ear is like a tiny tunnel, and the music from your headphones is like a little invisible car driving through that tunnel to get to a special drum inside your ear. When you yawn, your mouth opens super wide, and that makes all the muscles and air inside your head and around your ear tunnel move and change shape a little bit. It's like the walls of your tunnel squish and stretch! This squishing makes the sound car take a slightly different, longer, or wigglier path to your drum, which makes the drum hear the sound a little bit slower or stretched out, so it sounds like the music goes "booooing" down for a moment. The music itself didn't change, it's just your ear tunnel playing a trick because it's moving!

title: Why do the Flamingo exhibits at zoo's look very easy to escape from?
text: You know how flamingos are so tall and pretty? Sometimes it looks like they could just flap their wings and fly right over the little fence, right? Well, even though flamingos *can* fly super high in the sky, the people who take care of them at the zoo do a couple of things. Sometimes, they give their wing feathers a tiny, tiny haircut, like when you get your hair trimmed! It doesn't hurt them at all, but it makes it so their wings can't get enough lift to fly way up high and far away. And another big reason is, why would they want to leave? They have all their yummy food, their nice water to splash in, and all their flamingo friends right there in their special home. They're happy and safe, so they don't feel like flying off on an adventure!

title: How do institutions like the ACT and the SAT come up with their standards?
text: Imagine the ACT and SAT are like big games that older kids play to show they're ready for a super-duper big school called college. The "standards" are like the rules of the game, or the list of things you need to know to play well, kind of like knowing your colors or how to count to ten before you go to kindergarten. How do they make these rules? Well, the people who make these games talk to lots and lots of grown-up teachers from all the different schools – both the schools kids go to now and the big colleges. They ask them, "What do kids *really* need to know to be smart and ready for college?" They look at all the books and lessons kids learn in school, and they listen to what clever teachers say is super important. They want to make sure the game checks if you've learned the stuff that will help you learn even more when you're a grown-up! So, they make a list of important ideas, like reading stories, doing math puzzles, and knowing about the world, because those are the things grown-ups need to know for big school.

title: if cocaine and meth release dopamine, why do they feel good?
text: Okay, imagine your brain has a little magic sprinkle machine that makes you feel happy! This happy sprinkle is called dopamine. When you do something fun, like eat a yummy cookie or get a big hug, your brain sprinkles a little bit of happy dust, and that makes you feel good and warm inside. Cocaine and meth are like naughty tricks that tell your brain to dump *all* the happy sprinkles out *super fast* all at once, instead of just a little bit. So, for a tiny bit, your brain feels *super-duper* happy and excited because it's swimming in happy sprinkles! But then, all the sprinkles are gone, and your brain feels very sad and tired because it used them all up too quickly.

title: What is the difference between an expat and an immigrant?
text: Okay, imagine you have two friends who move to a new neighborhood. One friend, let's call her Lily, moves because her mommy got a special job for a few years in the new neighborhood. Lily knows she'll live there for a while, go to a new school, but her old house and her old neighborhood are still her "real" home, and she knows she'll go back there someday. Lily is like an "expat" – someone who lives somewhere else for a bit, but plans to go back to their first home. Now imagine another friend, Tom. Tom's family moved to the new neighborhood because they love it so much, and they decided they want to live there forever and ever. They bought a new house, and this new neighborhood is now their "forever home." Tom is like an "immigrant" – someone who moves to a new place to make it their new permanent home. So, the big difference is if you're just visiting for a long time but planning to go back, or if you're moving there to make it your brand new home forever!

title: Why does time asleep feel the exact same whether it's four or eight or ten hours?
text: When you're asleep, your brain is super busy doing important work, like charging up your body and sorting out all the fun things you did that day! But because you're all snuggled up and your eyes are closed, you're not really *there* to watch the clock or feel the minutes go by. It's kind of like when you close your eyes for a game of hide-and-seek, and then open them again – you don't know if your eyes were closed for just a tiny bit or a long, long time, right? Your brain only starts to feel time passing when you're awake and playing. So whether you sleep for a little while or a really long while, it just feels like you blinked, and suddenly it's morning!

title: Why does density decide what sinks and what floats?
text: Imagine water is like a big, soft bed that tries really hard to hold everything up. Everything has its own "how heavy it is for its size" number. If your toy, like a little rock, is super heavy for its size, it's too much for the water bed to hold up, so it pushes right through and sinks! But if your toy, like a big, empty boat or a light piece of wood, is very light for its size, the water bed is strong enough to push it back up and hold it on top, so it floats! So, if your toy is heavier for its size than the water is, it goes down. If it's lighter for its size than the water, it stays up!

title: Why are things wrapped in aluminium foil to keep them warm but never cool?
text: Imagine heat is like tiny, invisible wiggles! When your food is warm, it's making lots of these wiggles and wants to send them out into the room. You wrap it in shiny foil, and the foil is like a super special mirror for these heat wiggles. All the wiggles hit the shiny foil and bounce right back into your food, keeping it

title: How can the president issue an executive order like the Muslim Ban without it the other 2 branches approval?
text:
Imagine the President is like the head grown-up of a super big house, which is our country! Sometimes, the head grown-up needs to tell the other grown-ups who work in the house (like the people who help with the mail or keep things safe) how to do their job better. These special instructions are called executive orders. The President doesn't have to ask the other important grown-ups, like the rule-makers (that's Congress) or the judges (that's the courts), *before* giving these instructions, because it's their job to make sure their team is working.

BUT! Even though they don't ask first, the other grown-ups can still look at the instructions *after* they are given. If the rule-makers think the instructions are really bad, they can try to make a new, bigger rule to stop it. And if the judges think the instructions break one of our country's super-important, big rules (like saying everyone has to be treated fairly), then the judges can say, "No, President, you can't do that!" and make the

title: Why are some animals noses wet?
text: You know how your nose helps you smell yummy cookies? Well, some animals have wet noses because it helps them smell *even better*! Imagine their nose is like a little sticky magnet for all the tiny smells in the air, like when you try to catch bubbles. The wetness helps them grab onto those smells so they can find their food, their friends, or where they need to go really, really well. It's also a tiny bit like how you sweat to stay cool when it's hot; the wetness can help their nose feel a little cooler. And sometimes, it helps catch little dust bits or tiny germs, so they don't breathe in yucky stuff! So, a wet nose is like a super helper for smelling, staying cool, and keeping clean!

title: Why is it that with old Christmas tree lights if one bulb went out the entire strand stopped working but with new lights if one goes out the others stay on?
text: Okay, imagine old Christmas lights were like a long, long train where all the cars were connected one after the other. If one train car broke down, the whole train couldn't move past it, so all the cars behind it would stop too! That's what happened with old lights: if one bulb went sleepy and stopped working, it broke the path for the electricity, and all the lights after it went dark. But new lights are super smart! They're like a playground where each swing has its own rope. If one swing breaks, all the other swings still work perfectly fine because they each have their own special path to get electricity. So, if one new light bulb goes sleepy, all the other lights still have their own way to get power and keep shining bright!

title: How does call audio to the other side of the world take 0-5 seconds, when it would take sound about 18 hours to get their?
text: Okay, imagine your voice is like a tiny little bird that wants to fly all the way across the world. That would take forever, right? Your voice, as sound, is just wiggles in the air, and those wiggles get tired really fast and disappear. But your phone is super-duper smart! When you talk, your phone doesn't send your voice's wiggles. Instead, it quickly turns your voice into super-fast secret messages, like tiny little electric sparks or flashes of light! These tiny sparks and flashes are like super-speedy rockets that zoom through special invisible tubes (wires) under the ground and under the big ocean, or even bounce through the air really, really fast, way faster than any bird or sound wiggle could ever go. When these rocket-fast messages get to your friend's phone, their phone quickly turns them back into your voice so your friend can hear you! It's like magic, but it's just super-fast electricity and light doing all the hard work, so you can chat with someone far away almost instantly!

title: Why do every (most) games start with one having to "press a button" to get to the game menu?
text: Imagine you have a super fun toy, and it's all ready to play, but it doesn't know *you're* ready! So, when you see "Press a button," it's like the game is saying, "Hey! Are you there? Are you ready to pick what we're going to do?" You press the button to say, "Yes! I'm here and I'm ready!" It also helps the game wake up completely and get ready to show you all the cool choices, like starting a new adventure or playing with a friend. It's just a little "hello" to let the game know you're ready to dive in!

title: Why does a temperature like 18 degrees Celsius feel so cold inside a house that I would start to shiver and need a blanket or sweater, but when it's 18 degrees Celsius outside, it's easily T-shirt and shorts weather and considered nice outside?
text: Imagine your body is like a little heater! When you're inside the house at 18 degrees, there's no big sun shining on you to give you extra warm hugs, and you're probably sitting still like a quiet mouse, so your heater isn't working super hard. The walls and floor of the house are also 18 degrees, so they don't give you any warmth, and they actually make you feel a bit chilly, like they're gently trying to take your warmth away. But when you're outside at 18 degrees, the big, warm sun is usually shining right on you, giving you lots of extra warmth! Plus, you're probably running, jumping, and playing, which makes your body heater work much harder and make even more warmth. So, with the sun helping and you moving around, 18 degrees outside feels perfectly nice and warm for a t-shirt!

title: Why are my taxes so high, even with a high withholding amount?
text: Imagine all the grown-ups put a little bit of their money together in a big pot. This pot helps pay for things we all use, like the roads you ride your bike on, the school you go to, and the fire trucks that keep us safe! Now, when grown-ups get their "work money," they usually put some of it straight into that big pot, a little bit at a time, all year long. That's called "withholding," and it's like putting a lot of coins into your piggy bank every week so you have enough to buy a toy later. Sometimes, even if you put a *lot* into your piggy bank (which is your high withholding), maybe the toy you want (which is how much you owe for all the roads and schools) costs even more than you thought! Or maybe you got extra allowance money (you earned more money) this year, and so the grown-ups decided you needed to put even more into the big pot than you planned. So, even though you put a lot in already, you still need to put a little bit more to cover everything. It just means the grown-ups decided you needed to contribute more to the big pot this year for all the roads and schools!

title: Is the sound we hear when we speak how we actually sound?
text: No, not exactly! It's a little bit like when you hum with your mouth closed – you can feel it buzzing inside your head, right? When you talk, your voice makes sounds that travel through the air to other people's ears, but it also makes vibrations (like tiny wiggles) inside your head bones and muscles, and those vibrations go straight to your own ears. Because your voice travels two ways to your ears (through the air *and* through your bones), it sounds a bit different and often deeper to you than it does to everyone else who only hears it through the air. That's why when you hear yourself on a recording, it might sound a little surprising, because that's how *everyone else* hears your super special voice!

title: Why is it easier to dwell on upsetting moments rather than happy moments?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little guard for you! When something happy happens, like getting a yummy cookie or a big hug, your guard thinks, "Yay! Everything is good and safe!" and then it's happy and moves on to the next fun thing. But if something sad or upsetting happens, like you fall down and get a boo-boo, your guard gets very busy and thinks, "Uh oh! What happened there? How can we make sure that doesn't happen again?" It keeps looking at the sad thing over and over, like trying to learn a lesson, so it can keep you safe and not get another boo-boo. It's not that it *likes* the sad things, but it worries about them more because it wants to protect you, while happy things just feel good and don't need fixing!

title: In a democracy, what is supposed to stop hypothetical 90% majority from literally killing off minority 10%?
text: That's a super important question! Imagine you and your friends are playing, and most of you want to play one game, but a few friends want to play something else. In a democracy, we have really special rules, like the most important rules in any game, that say "Everyone gets to be safe and treated nicely, no matter how many of you there are." These rules are called "rights," and they're like a magic shield that protects everyone, even the small groups. Even if almost everyone wanted to do something mean to a few people, these big, strong rules say "No! You can't do that." We also have special grown-ups, like judges, who are like referees in a game, and their job is to make sure everyone, especially the small groups, follows these super important rules and stays safe. So, it's these strong rules and the grown-ups who make sure they're followed that stop bad things from happening, because everyone deserves to be safe and happy.

title: What would happen if I followed one of those "Shoot the target to win a new iPhone" pop-ups on a webpage to the very end?
text: Okay, imagine you see a picture of a super cool toy, and it says "Play this game and it's yours for free!" You click it, and it looks like a

title: When a pot of water boils, where does the air in the bubbles come from?
text: That's a super smart question! You know how water is usually sleepy and stays in the pot? Well, when you make it super, super hot, the water gets so excited and wiggly that it wants to fly away! Those bubbles you see aren't air that came from outside. It's actually the water itself getting so hot that it turns into a kind of see-through cloud, like water magic! It gets so light that it floats up and out of the pot. So, the bubbles are just the water changing its shape from a liquid to a gas, like it's putting on its flying clothes, and zooming up!

title: How do auroras in the night sky work? How do they form? Why do they occur? Why do they only show up near the poles?
text: Imagine the sun is like a big, happy, fiery ball in the sky, and sometimes it sneezes out tiny, invisible sprinkles! Our Earth has a special invisible blanket around it, like a giant magnet, that catches most of these sprinkles and keeps us safe. But at the very top and very bottom of our Earth, where the North Pole and South Pole are, this blanket is a little bit open, like a funnel. So, when the sun's tiny sprinkles zoom down these funnels and crash into the air way, way up high, they make the air glow, just like when you turn on a light or crack a glow stick! Different kinds of air glow different colors, which is why we see pretty greens, pinks, and blues dancing in the sky. It only happens near the poles because that's where our Earth's invisible blanket lets the sun's sprinkles come close enough to make the air light up and put on a magical show for us!

title: Why is chickenpox worse as an adult?
text: Imagine your body has little superhero fighters inside that protect you from germs! When you're a little kid and get chickenpox, your superheroes meet this specific germ for the first time. They fight it, and even though you get spots and feel a bit yucky, they usually learn how to beat it pretty quickly and easily. It's like a small practice fight for them. But when you're a grown-up and get chickenpox, it's a much bigger surprise for your superheroes! Maybe they've forgotten how to fight this particular germ because they haven't seen it in a long, long time, or maybe they're busy fighting other germs already. So, when chickenpox shows up, your superheroes get confused and have a much harder time figuring out how to fight it. They might fight too hard, make a bigger mess, or take a very long time to win. That's why grown-ups feel much, much sicker, get more spots, and it takes them a lot longer to feel better when they get chickenpox – it's a much tougher battle for their superheroes!

title: Why do we vocalize our thought process by saying, "um"?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super busy little chef in your head, trying to cook up all the right words to say! Sometimes, when you're talking really fast, your chef brain needs just a tiny second to find the next perfect ingredient (the next word or idea). Instead of just stopping completely and making a big quiet space, which feels a little weird, your chef brain just makes a little "um" sound. It's like a tiny "Hold on a sec, I'm still thinking!" noise that tells your friends you're not done talking, you're just looking for the very best words to say next. It helps your brain keep going smoothly so you don't forget what you wanted to tell everyone!

title: Why do the hand rails on escalators not go at the same speed of the escalator itself?
text: Imagine the steps are like little toy cars on a train track, and a big engine pulls them all at a steady speed. The handrail is like a long, rubbery rope that also gets pulled, but it has to slide through a bunch of tiny tunnels and around little wheels to get around. When it slides and rubs, it gets a tiny bit sticky and might slow down a little, or sometimes the escalator tries to make it go a tiny bit faster to make up for that stickiness. It's really hard to make two different things go *exactly* the same perfect speed all the time, just like it's hard for you and your friend to run side-by-side without one of you getting a little ahead or behind!

title: How do mobile companies like Verizon and Sprint decide on data charges? Does using more data really cost them more money?
text: Okay, imagine mobile companies are like people who build big, invisible roads in the sky for your phone's internet cars to drive on. They decide how much to charge for driving on these

title: Why do different parts of the world have different emergency numbers?
text: Imagine your house has a special secret knock to get a cookie, right? But your friend's house might have a different secret knock to get a cookie! It's because your grown-ups picked what was easiest for *your* family to remember, and their grown-ups picked what was easiest for *their* family. Well, countries are like really, really big houses, and each country picked its own special secret number, like a magic button, to call for help when there's an emergency. They picked numbers that were easy for the people living *there* to remember and dial really fast, like 911 or 112 or 999. They all did it a long, long time ago, before everyone could talk to each other so easily, so each big 'house' just picked what worked best for them! It's just their special way to make sure everyone inside their big house knows exactly how to get help super quickly.

title: why can you eat a pound easier than you can drink a pound?
text: Imagine your tummy is like a balloon! When you eat a pound of yummy snacks or a big sandwich, it's like putting lots of little building blocks in your balloon. They stack up, and you can usually fit quite a bit before your tummy feels super full. But when you drink a pound of water or juice, it's like pouring water right into the balloon. Water fills up *all* the space really fast and makes your balloon feel full and heavy much quicker, even if it's just one big cup! So, even though it's the same "pound" of stuff, the solid food sits nicely and takes longer to make your tummy feel bursting, while the liquid rushes in and makes your tummy feel full and heavy right away, like you can't fit any more!

title: Why do internet browsers fail to prevent "add extension" advert pages from locking up the browser?
text: Imagine your internet browser is like a friendly little car that drives you to different houses (websites) on the internet road. Most houses are nice and let you play. But sometimes, a naughty house will jump out and say, "Look at this special new toy (that's an extension)! You HAVE to look at it right now!" And it puts the toy right in front of your car's window. Your car is super polite, so it stops and waits because the naughty house told it to. It doesn't know if the toy is good or bad, it just knows the house said "

title: Why do birth certificates have the adoptive parents instead of the birth parents?
text: Okay, imagine when a baby is born, they get a first special "hello" paper that says who their tummy-mommy and daddy are. But sometimes, those tummy-mommies

title: Who decides on the currency exchange rate?
text: Imagine you have your favorite LEGOs, and your friend has their favorite Hot Wheels. If you want to trade, you both have to agree how many LEGOs are worth one Hot Wheel! That's kind of like money from different countries. No one boss person just picks a number. It's more like a super big, busy playground where lots and lots of grown-ups are trying to buy and sell money all day long. If many grown-ups want to buy money from a different country (maybe because they want to buy a cool toy made there), that money becomes a little more popular and costs a bit more. If not many grown-ups want it, it might cost less. So, it changes all the time, kind of like how the price of a yummy cookie at the store might change if lots and lots of kids want it! Sometimes, the grown-ups who help run a country (like the government or big banks) might try to make their money a little more or less popular, but mostly it's just all the people buying and selling that decide together.

title: How the ban of americans on Iran will affect american fight attendants and pilots that fly there?
text: Okay, imagine you drive a super big sky bus, or you're one of the helpers inside, like a grown-up giving out snacks. Now, imagine there's a special playground far, far away called Iran. If the grown-ups in charge say that people from where you live, like America, can't go to that specific playground anymore, then you just can't drive your sky bus there or help people on a bus going to that playground. You won't lose your job, you'll just drive your sky bus or help on it to a different, *other* playground instead, to a different place where you *are* allowed to go!

title: What is the biological process of building muscle, and why is protein so important?
text: Imagine your muscles are like strong, stretchy rubber bands inside your body. When you run, jump, or play, sometimes these rubber bands get tiny, tiny little tears – like super small boo-boos you can't even see! Your body is super smart and wants to fix these boo-boos and make the rubber bands even stronger so they don't get hurt next time. It's like building a LEGO tower: after you play with it, you might add more LEGOs to make it bigger and sturdier. That's what your body does with your muscles! Now, protein is like the special magic LEGOs or super strong glue your body uses to fix those tiny boo-boos and add new parts to your muscle rubber bands. When you eat yummy foods like chicken, eggs, milk, or beans, you're giving your body all the protein "building blocks" it needs. If you don't eat enough protein, your muscles won't have enough of that special glue or LEGOs to get bigger and stronger after you play, and they'll stay the same or take longer to fix themselves. So, protein helps your muscles grow from those tiny boo-boos into big, strong muscles!

title: How do video game servers differ from web servers?
text: Imagine you have two special friends that live inside computers and help you with things! One friend is like a librarian at a big picture book library (that's a web server!). When you want to see a picture of a cat or read a story, you ask the librarian, and they just *show* you the picture or the words. They don't really care if other kids are looking at the same picture; everyone just gets their own copy to look at. The other friend is like a super important referee or a game master on a playground (that's a video game server!). When you're playing tag or soccer with your friends in a video game, this referee friend makes sure everyone sees the same ball, knows who's "it," and where everyone is running *right now*. If you kick the ball, the referee tells everyone else, "Hey, the ball just moved here!" very, very fast, so it feels like you're all really playing together in the same place at the exact same time. So, one just shows you things, and the other helps you *play* things together with friends in real-time!

title: Why is NYC so much cleaner and safer than it was in the 80s and 90s?
text: Imagine New York City was like a really messy playroom a long, long time ago. There was lots of trash everywhere, like when you forget to put your toys away, and sometimes, big kids would do mean things, like push or take toys, and there weren't enough grown-ups watching to make sure everyone was safe. But then, the grown-ups who live there decided they wanted the city to be a super nice place, like a tidy playroom where everyone plays nicely. So, they hired more people to pick up all the trash, like putting all the toys back in their boxes, and they made new rules, like "don't throw your candy wrapper on the floor!" They also got more friendly police officers, like more grown-ups watching to make sure everyone was playing fair and not being mean, and made rules to stop people from doing naughty things. Because of all these new grown-ups helping, and everyone trying to be good, the city slowly became a much happier, cleaner, and safer place to live and play!

title: How does salt used for melting ice/snow work? Also, is there a temperature at which it is no longer effective?
text: Imagine ice is like a bunch of tiny water friends holding hands super, super tight because it's so cold outside! They don't want to let go and be all wiggly. When you sprinkle salt on them, the salt is like a little mischief-maker that runs right in between the water friends. It makes it really hard for them to hold hands tightly anymore, even though it's still cold! So, they have to let go and turn back into splishy-splashy water instead of hard ice. But yes, if it gets super, super, super cold (like, colder than your freezer at home!), even the salt can't make them let go anymore. It's just too cold for the salt to break their super-strong hold, so the ice stays ice.

title: When a new POTUS and his family move into the White House, how much can they change? How are the personal tastes of each president balanced with historic preservation?
text: Imagine the White House is like a super old, super special shared toy box that many kids (Presidents) have played with before. When a new President and his family move in, they get to make some parts of it feel like *their* very own home! They can change the paint in their private bedrooms upstairs, pick new curtains, and bring their own favorite toys and pictures for those rooms, just like you might do in your own room! The President can also choose new furniture or pictures for his special office, the Oval Office, to make it comfy for him to work. They can even pick new plates for dinner parties! But, they can't change the outside of the big white house – it has to stay looking the same because it's super famous and important. And there are lots of very old, beautiful rooms downstairs, like the big dining room or the room where famous people meet. Those

title: What process(es) is/are my body going through once an antibiotic is introduced to my system?

title: Why is coffee/pepper that you grind at home better than coffee/pepper ground at the factory?
text: Imagine you have a super yummy cookie. If you eat it right after it comes out of the oven, it's warm and smells amazing, right? But if you leave that cookie out on the counter for a whole week, it gets a bit sad and doesn't taste as good. Coffee and pepper are a bit like that cookie! When they are whole beans or whole peppercorns, all their super yummy smells and tastes are locked safely inside, like a secret treasure chest. When a factory grinds them, it breaks open all those little chests. The yummy smells and tastes start to float away into the air right then, and by the time you open the bag at home, some of that magic has already escaped! But when *you* grind them at home, you break open those treasure chests *just* when you're about to use them. So all those amazing smells and tastes are super fresh and ready to jump into your cup or onto your food right away, making it taste extra special and delicious! It's like having a fresh, warm cookie every single time!

title: The first basic fusion that will happen in a star is two hydrogen atoms fusing and becoming helium. We know that other elements will be produced by fusion, like Neon, Iron, etc. What is the sequence after the atom is helium for subsequent fusion... H > He ...?
text: Imagine a star is like a giant, super-duper hot cooking pot in space! First, it takes tiny little building blocks called hydrogen and squishes them together to make slightly bigger building blocks called helium. This makes lots of heat and light! When the star runs out of hydrogen to squish in its middle, if it's big enough, it gets even hotter! Then it starts squishing the helium blocks together to make even bigger blocks like carbon and oxygen. If the star is super, super strong and hot, it keeps going! It squishes carbon to make things like neon, then neon to make more oxygen, and oxygen to make silicon. The very last big building block it can make by squishing is iron. Once it makes iron, it can't squish anything more to make heat, and that's when really big stars have a giant, spectacular 'pop!'

title: Can someone please explain how Jurassic Park (1993) was visually so ahead of its time, it seems almost comparable todays visual effects?
text: Okay, imagine you have your toy dinosaurs, right? In the Jurassic Park movie, they made those dinosaurs look so real, like they could actually walk off the screen and say 'ROAR!' They did a super clever trick. Sometimes, they built *giant robot dinosaurs* that could move their heads and blink their eyes, like amazing, super-duper puppets! And sometimes, for the running and big scenes, they used computers to make the dinosaurs move. But they were super, super careful to make the computer dinosaurs look like they had real skin and muscles, and moved just like real animals. They made sure the light on the computer dinosaurs matched the light in the movie, like when the sun shines on your toys. Because they used a mix of these super real robot dinosaurs and very carefully made computer dinosaurs, your brain thought *all* of them were real! They were like super smart chefs who knew exactly how much of each ingredient to put in to make the most yummy and real-looking dinosaur soup ever, which is why it still looks so good even today!

title: How does wet canned food (like soup) not spoil when bacteria thrives in moisture?
text: Okay, imagine tiny, tiny invisible little creatures called germs that love to eat your food and make it yucky, like when milk goes sour. You're right, these germs love water, just like you love juice! But when we put soup in a can, two super important things happen. First, we make the soup super, super hot, like a really, really hot bath. This hot bath makes all the tiny germs inside fall asleep forever, so they can't make the food yucky anymore. Poof! No more germs. Then, super fast, we put a lid on the can and seal it up super, super tight. This makes a special shield so that no new germs can sneak in from the outside, even if they try really, really hard. So, inside the can, there are no bad germs to make the food yucky, and no new germs can get inside to start a party. That's why your soup stays yummy and safe to eat for a long, long time, even though it's wet!

title: In regards to post-secondary tuition inflation, why can't new or even perhaps existing Universities/Colleges just lower their tuition costs to compete and set a trend in motion?
text:
Imagine universities are like super special big schools for grown-ups, where they learn to build bridges or become doctors! To make these schools really good, they need lots of things: super smart teachers (who need to be paid), big buildings with lots of rooms, cool science stuff, and lots of books. All these things cost a lot of money, like when your parents buy you a big, fancy toy. The money for these things comes from what the grown-ups pay to go there, which is called tuition.

Now, if a university made its tuition much, much cheaper, it might not have enough money to pay the super smart teachers, or fix the old buildings, or buy new cool stuff for learning. It would be like a toy store trying to sell toys for almost no money – soon, they wouldn't have any money to buy new, fun toys for you! Also, sometimes grown-ups think that if something costs more, it must be better, like a super special, shiny toy. If a school is very cheap, some grown-ups might think it's not as good or won't teach them as well, even if it tries its best. So, it's tricky! They need enough money to be really good schools, and sometimes, being really good means costing a bit more, which makes it hard for them to just lower their prices without changing how good they are.

title: What is chaos theory?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big tower of blocks. If you just touch one tiny block a little bit, sometimes the whole tower falls down in a super messy way! Chaos theory is like that. It means that sometimes, a super-duper tiny push, like a little butterfly flapping its wings far, far away, could make a really, really big difference later, like making a big storm happen! It's about how little, tiny changes can make things turn out totally different and super hard to guess what will happen way in the future, even if it looks like things are just bouncing around randomly.

title: If I always feel mentally and physically better after exercising, why do I still avoid it like a whiny toddler?

title: Why do clouds get extremely dark before a tornado?
text: Imagine the sun is a giant flashlight in the sky! Clouds are like big, fluffy blankets made of tiny, tiny water drops. When a storm is coming that might make a tornado, the cloud gets super, super big and puffy and thick, like taking a million blankets and piling them all on top of each other! The sun's light tries to shine through, but because there are so many water drops and the cloud is so incredibly thick, the sunlight can't push its way through to the bottom of the cloud. It's like when you're under a big, thick blanket and it gets dark, right? The cloud gets so dark because it's blocking almost all of the sun's light, making it look all gloomy and dark, telling us that there's a really big, strong storm up there!

title: Despite feeling better at before completing the therapy, we are told to fully finish our 10 day antibiotic treatment to prevent risks of developing resistant bacteria. Why can't we instead let our immune system finish the job?
text: Imagine your body is a house, and little tiny bad guys (germs!) are making a mess and making you feel yucky. The medicine you take is like a team of superhero cleaners that come into your house to help your body's own cleaners (your immune system) kick out the bad guys. When you start feeling better, it means most of the bad guys are gone and your house looks much cleaner! But some really sneaky, tough bad guys might still be hiding under the bed or in the closet. If you stop the superhero cleaners too early, those sneaky bad guys can come out, invite all their friends, and learn how to fight the superhero cleaners even better next time, so the cleaners won't work anymore! So, we keep taking all the medicine until every single bad guy is totally gone, even if you feel super good, to make sure they can't come back stronger and cause trouble again. This way, your house stays clean and healthy, and the superhero cleaners can always help you if you need them later!

title: What are tennis players looking for when they are choosing a ball for their serve?
text: Imagine you have a bunch of bouncy balls, but some feel a bit old and squishy, and some feel super new and fluffy! When a tennis player picks a ball for their serve, they're looking for the one that feels just right in their hand – nice and fluffy, not too worn out. It's like picking your favorite crayon that helps you draw the best picture, because when the ball feels good and bouncy, it helps them hit it really strong and make it go exactly where they want it to!

title: Why is the YouTube video player so much better than other sites (For instance ESPN, Netlfix, SlingTV, etc)?
text: Imagine YouTube is like a super special race car that was built just to go fast, fast, fast on a really smooth track. Lots and lots of smart people have been working on it for a very long time, making sure it always goes zoom without any bumps or stops, and that all its little buttons (like pause or skip) work perfectly every single time. Its main job is just to show you videos, and it's super good at it because that's what it practices all day! Now, other places like ESPN or Netflix are like different kinds of cars. ESPN might be a big truck that has to carry lots of extra things like live scores and different camera views, and sometimes it has to stop for a quick commercial break

title: Why has USA not included Saudi Arabia in their banned countries list?
text: Imagine some countries are like kids your grown-ups say you can't play with because they don't follow the rules or are mean. The USA has a list of those kids. Now, Saudi Arabia is like a grown-up friend of the USA. Even if that friend sometimes does things that make other people sad or mad, like when your friend takes a toy without asking, they are still friends because they help each other with very important stuff. Saudi Arabia has lots and lots of special juice called oil, which helps cars go and powers many things, and the USA needs that oil. They also help the USA with other grown-up problems, like finding bad guys. So, even if the USA isn't happy with *everything* Saudi Arabia does, they stay friends because they help each other with these very big, important things like sharing oil and keeping everyone safe. It's like you might not like everything your friend does, but you still play with them because they share their best toys or help you when you're stuck.

title: Since cancer stems from irregular cell multiplication, would damage from exercise increase your chances of getting it?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool house made of tiny, tiny LEGO bricks called cells. When you run and play really hard, sometimes your muscle LEGO bricks get a little bit tired, like they've done too much work. But that's okay! Your body is super smart and sends special repair LEGO bricks to fix them right up, making them even stronger! This is a good kind of fixing that helps your house stay healthy and strong. Cancer is different. It

title: Historically, what happens to people of country X who live in country Y, when X and Y go to war?
text: Imagine you're at your friend's house for a sleepover, but then your mommy and your friend's mommy get into a really, really big fight, like a war! Even though you didn't do anything wrong, your friend's mommy might get very scared or angry. She might tell you to go home, but it could be too dangerous outside because of the fight, so you can't go. Sometimes, she might even make you stay in a special room or a different house, just to be sure you don't help your mommy in the fight, and she might even take your toys. It's a very confusing and scary time because you're stuck in the middle of a grown-up fight that isn't yours, and it makes people feel very sad and alone.

title: why do we sometimes hear someone call our name, but no one is there?
text: Sometimes your brain is like a super busy detective trying to figure out all the little sounds around you, like the fridge humming or the wind outside. Your ears hear lots of tiny noises, and your brain is always trying to make sense of them. So, sometimes, when it hears a sound that's just a *little bit* like your name, but not quite, your brain gets super excited and *thinks* it heard your name because it's always listening for important things, like when someone calls you! It's kind of like when you see a cloud that looks a little bit like a bunny, even though it's just a cloud. Your brain just made it look like a bunny! It's just your clever brain working super hard, and it happens to grown-ups too!

title: How can hypochondriacs make themselves feel ill and exhibit symptoms if there's nothing actually wrong with them physically?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper boss of your whole body! If your brain keeps thinking and thinking, "Oh no, I'm going to get a tummy ache!" even if there's no bad food inside, sometimes your brain is so powerful it can actually make your tummy *feel* a little bit achey. It's like when you're really scared because you think there's a monster under your bed, even if there isn't one, your heart might beat super fast and your hands might get sweaty. For some grown-ups, their brain worries so much about being sick, it makes their body feel tired, or gives them a little headache, or even a pretend cough, just because the brain is *so good* at listening to all those worried thoughts. It feels very, very real to them, even if a doctor checks and says, "Nope, everything is perfectly fine inside!"

title: How can malware get installed on your computer just by openning up a website and without the user getting notified about a download?
text: Imagine your computer is like a special toy box where you keep all your games and pictures. When you visit a website, it's like opening a door to look into someone else's room. Usually, if you want to bring a new toy from their room into your toy box, you have to ask, and it comes in a big box you can see (that's like a download pop-up). But sometimes, some naughty grown-ups make websites that have a super tiny, secret, broken window or a hidden crack that nobody can see. When you just open the door to look, a tiny, invisible, mischievous little bug or imp can quickly sneak through that secret crack without making any noise or letting anyone know it's there, before you even have time to blink! It doesn't come in a big box; it's so small and fast, it just zips right into your toy box without you ever seeing it happen. Once it's inside, it might try to hide and mess with your toys or look at them without you knowing. That's why it's super important to have a strong lock on your toy box (like special computer guards called antivirus) and only visit rooms (websites) that your grown-ups say are

When Obama was the grown-up in charge, there were already some rules from a long time ago, like after 9/11, that said grown-ups from certain countries needed to have extra careful checks and paperwork before they could come in, to make sure everyone was safe. It was like saying, 'We need to ask you more questions and look at

title: Quintuplets, how does a woman hold that many babies all the way to term?
text: Imagine your tummy is like a super stretchy balloon! When you have one baby, it's like one little teddy bear inside. But with five babies, it's like putting five little teddy bears in there! Your tummy gets super, super big and stretchy to make room for all of them. It's very hard work for mommy's body, and sometimes the babies come out a little bit early because it gets too crowded, like a very full bus! Doctors help mommy a lot by watching her and the babies all the time to make sure everyone is safe and healthy, helping them stay inside as long as possible.

title: Why does 'cornstarch mud' become solid when impacted and remain liquid at all other times?
text: Imagine you have lots of tiny, tiny little bouncy balls (that's the cornstarch) floating in a swimming pool (that's the water). Normally, they have lots of space to swim and wiggle around, so the whole pool feels squishy and runny, like water. But if you try to splash the water really, really fast and hard, all the little bouncy balls get pushed together super quickly! They can't move out of the way fast enough, so they all pile up and get stuck, making it feel hard like a wall for a little bit. Once you stop splashing, the water comes back around them, and they can wiggle and swim again, making it squishy once more!

title: Why is Justin Trudeaus approval rating so low?
text: Imagine Justin Trudeau is like the leader of our playgroup, and an approval rating is like how many kids raise their hands and say, 'Yay, I like what he's doing!' When it's low, it means not as many grown-ups are saying 'yay' right now. Why? Well, sometimes things cost a lot more money, like your favorite candy or a new toy, and that makes grown-ups feel a bit sad or worried about their pennies. Other times, maybe he promised to build a really big, amazing fort, but it's taking a long time, or it's not quite as amazing as they hoped, so they're a little disappointed. And sometimes, people just feel like he's been the leader for a very, very long time, and they want to try someone new, like wanting a different story at bedtime. So, it's a mix of these things that makes fewer people clap for him right now.

title: what is it about apples that makes us have so much variety compared to other fruits?

title: How does bill Gates keep getting richer if he's not with Microsoft and keeps giving his money away?
text: Imagine Bill Gates had a super-duper big piggy bank full of coins because he helped build the amazing computer company, Microsoft! Now, even though he's not working at Microsoft anymore and is busy giving away lots and lots of those coins to help people, he didn't just put all his coins under his bed. Instead, he took most of them and planted them like magic seeds in a special garden. These magic seeds are like putting his money into other good ideas and companies. And guess what? Those magic seeds grow! They make even more coins all by themselves, even when he's sleeping or playing. So, even though he gives away a lot of his coins, the rest of his planted "money seeds" keep growing and making new coins, making his piggy bank even bigger over time! It's like having a magic money tree that keeps growing new leaves.

title: What is the difference between Chrome & Chromium, and who owns Chromium?
text:
Okay, imagine you have a big box of special building blocks, like LEGOs!

Chromium is like that big box of all the basic, plain LEGO bricks. Anyone can take those bricks and build whatever they want with them. Lots of smart people from all over the world help make sure those bricks are good and work well together, like a big team sharing their toys. So, no one person really "owns" all those basic bricks; it's like a shared project that lots of people help make better, with Google being the main helper who started it.

Now, Chrome is like if Google, a big company, took those basic LEGO bricks from the Chromium box and added some extra special, shiny, secret pieces to them, put it in a fancy box with their name on it, and gave it to you. It has all the basic bricks from Chromium, but also some extra special Google-only things, like a special logo, or tools that help it talk to other Google toys, and it updates all by itself!

So, Chromium is the shared, basic building blocks, and Chrome is Google's special version of those blocks with extra Google stuff!

title: Why US Telecos still use CDMA technology, when majority of the world uses GSM for the communication?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends want to talk on your play phones! Most countries in the world decided it was best if everyone took turns talking, like saying "My turn!" and then "Okay

title: Why do we have to cook food in the oven for 20 minutes, but we can cook it in the microwave for 3 minutes?
text: Okay, imagine your food is like a big, sleepy teddy bear. When you put it in the **oven**, it's like giving the teddy bear a big, warm blanket. The blanket makes the air around the teddy bear warm, and that warm air slowly, slowly makes the teddy bear warm all over, starting from its fur and slowly getting to its tummy. That takes a long time because the warmth has to travel all the way inside. But when you put your food in the **microwave**, it's like the microwave has a special magic finger that tickles all the tiny water bits *inside* the teddy bear's tummy all at once! All those water bits start wiggling and dancing super fast, and when they wiggle fast, they get hot very quickly, everywhere inside the teddy bear at the same time! That's why it's so much faster – no waiting for the warmth to travel from the outside in!

title: Why do hangovers get markedly worse as we get older?
text: Imagine your body is like a little house, and when grown-ups drink special grown-up juice (that's alcohol), it makes a bit of a mess inside. When you're little, your body is like a super-fast cleaning crew! It can zoom around and clean up all the mess really quickly, so you don't feel too bad the next day. But as grown-ups get older, their cleaning crew isn't quite as zippy anymore. Maybe they're a bit tired, or their cleaning tools aren't as shiny and new. So, it takes them much, much longer to clean up all the mess. Plus, older grown-ups sometimes don't have as much water in their house (which helps wash the mess away), and they might not get as much sleep to help them recover. So, because the cleaning takes longer and isn't as good, the mess just sits there for longer, making grown-ups feel extra yucky and tired when they're older after drinking that special juice.

title: How do our ears "focus" on one sound over another when there are multiple things happening at once?
text: Imagine your ears are like two super cool listening dishes that hear *all* the sounds around you, like every giggle, every car, every bird. But your brain is like a very smart light bulb with a special spotlight! When lots of sounds are happening, your brain doesn't make your ears focus, but it shines its listening spotlight on the sound you want to hear, like when Mommy is telling you a story. It helps you listen extra hard to *her* voice, and makes the other sounds around you seem a little quieter, even though they're still there. It's like your brain is saying, "Shhh, I want to hear *this* one!" and helps you pay

title: How is being dyslexic in symbol languages (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) different from being dyslexic in English?
text:
Okay, imagine reading is like building with LEGOs!

In English, our LEGOs are letters, and each letter makes a sound, like 'kuh' for C, 'ah' for A, 'tuh' for T. When you put them together, you hear 'cat'! For kids with dyslexia

title: If there are fewer leaves in the winter, does it mean we have less oxygen then?
text: That's a super smart question! It's true that trees make the air we breathe, called oxygen, using their leaves. When winter comes, many trees lose their leaves and take a nap, so they don't make as much oxygen then. But don't you worry, we still have plenty of oxygen to breathe! That's because there are lots and lots of other plants and trees all over the world that still have their leaves, especially in warm places, and they keep making oxygen all the time. Plus, there are super tiny plants in the ocean that make even more oxygen than all the trees combined! And the air around our whole Earth is so, so big, like a giant invisible balloon, that even if some trees are napping, there's always enough air for everyone to breathe. We never run out!

title: Why are airplanes able to get struck by lightning yet keep flying?
text: Imagine the airplane is like a big metal toy car, and lightning is like a super quick, very bright spark of electricity trying to say 'hi!' to it. When lightning touches the airplane, the plane is built super smart! It has a special skin, like a superhero suit, that lets the electricity zoom all the way around the outside of the plane, almost like it's sliding on a slippery slide. It doesn't go inside where the pilot or the engines are, because that's where all the important buttons and wires are. The electricity just glides across the outside and then jumps off the other side, back into the sky. So, the plane is totally fine, because the lightning never got to touch anything important, it just went for a quick ride on the outside and then zoomed away!

title: How is a bank "too big to fail"?
