When someone is really, really good at their job, the grown-ups think they can help other grown-ups learn to be super good too, and make sure everyone is working together to build the best "towers" (or whatever they do at work) as a team.

title: If fish "breathe" dissolved oxygen in the water, why do they die once they exit the water?
text: Imagine fish have special feathery brushes inside their heads called gills, which are super good at catching tiny air bubbles from the water, like a special net. When a fish is in the water, the water keeps all the little feathers on the brush spread out and wet, so they can catch lots and lots of air bubbles to help the fish live. But when the fish comes out of the water, there's no water to keep the feathery brushes spread out and wet anymore, so they all stick together, like when your wet hair dries and clumps up. When the brushes are stuck together, they can't catch enough air bubbles from the air, even though there's lots of air all around us. It's like trying to drink juice with a straw that's all squished flat – you can't get enough! So, they can't get enough air to live and eventually stop moving.

title: How can a man be raped by a woman?
text: Imagine someone wants to tickle you, but you say "no, I don't want to be tickled!" If they tickle you anyway, even if they're smaller or seem not as strong, it still feels yucky and not okay because you said no and they didn't listen. It's the same with grown-ups and their private parts. If a lady touches a man's private parts, or makes him touch hers, and he says "no" or feels really scared and doesn't want to, but she makes him do it anyway, that's called rape. It's about someone doing something to your body that you don't want, and it makes you feel really sad and scared, no matter if it's a boy or a girl doing it.

title: Why does it feel more uncomfortable when cold water touches our stomach area but it feels fine when cold water touches our hands?
text: Okay, imagine your hands are like super brave little helpers that are always out exploring and touching things, so they've felt cold water many times before and they're used to it! They're like, "No big deal!" But your tummy is like a very cozy, warm blanket fort inside your body. It likes to stay super warm and snuggly all the time. So when cold water suddenly splashes on your tummy, it's a big surprise! Your tummy isn't used to feeling cold at all, and it goes, "Brrr! That's too cold for my warm fort!" That's why it feels yucky on your tummy but just okay on your hands, because your hands are more used to being chilly.

title: What's the point of a chiropractor to crack your bones when the pain/ache will eventually come back?
text: Imagine your back is like a tower made of little building blocks, and sometimes one or two blocks get a tiny bit stuck or pushed a little crooked from all your playing and running, which can make your body feel uncomfortable or a little "ouchy." A chiropractor is like a helpful friend who gently nudges those blocks back into a happy place so they can move smoothly again. The "crack" sound is just air bubbles popping, like when you open a fizzy drink, not your bones breaking! When your body moves better, it feels much happier and less ouchy. But just like you have to tidy your room again after you play, or brush your teeth every day, your body can sometimes get a little stiff or out of place again from all the running, jumping, and sitting you do. So, going to the chiropractor is like giving your body a little helpful tune-up to keep it feeling comfy and moving well, even if it needs a little help again later on to stay happy!

title: Why do all of the actual pictures of Saturn appear to be digitally render and sorta fake?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper special camera, way better than your mommy's phone! Saturn is super, super far away, like if you tried to see a tiny ant from the other side of your house. But this special camera can zoom in *really* close, closer than your eyes ever could. Because it's so far and the camera is so good, it takes a picture that shows every little detail, super clear and crisp, almost like a perfect drawing! Also, in space, there's no messy air like there is on Earth to make things blurry, so the pictures come out extra, extra sharp. Sometimes, scientists make the colors a little bit brighter or different so we can see all the cool stripes and rings even better, like when you color in a picture and make the colors pop! That's why it looks so amazing and almost *too* perfect to be real, even though it totally is!

title: Why is it that when we eat something too much we start to dislike it?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super smart chef! It knows it needs lots of *different* kinds of ingredients to make you strong and healthy, just like you need different colors of crayons to make a beautiful drawing. If you eat the *same* yummy food every single day, over and over, your smart body says, "Hmm, we've had enough of *this

title: How does toothpaste actually whiten our teeth? Does it even do that or is it just marketing?
text: Imagine your teeth are like a white toy car that got a little bit dirty with mud or crayon marks from playing outside. Toothpaste is like a special soap with tiny, tiny little scrubbing brushes that you use to clean the car. It doesn't paint the car a new color, but it washes all the mud and crayon marks off, making the car look shiny and white again, just like it was when it was new! So, yes, it really does help your teeth look whiter, but mostly because it's super good at cleaning off all the sticky, colored stuff that makes them look a little yellow or dull. It's like making them sparkle by getting them super clean!

title: Why is Windows 8.1 Considered the 'Worst' Microsoft OS?
text: Imagine your computer is like your toy box! Usually, there's a special button, like a 'Start' button, that's super easy to push to find all your games and tools. But with Windows 8.1, it was like someone hid that special button! Instead, when you opened your toy box, you saw a whole new screen with big, colorful square pictures everywhere, like a giant puzzle. It was a new way to play, but it made it tricky to find your favorite things you knew how to use before, like your drawing apps or your storybooks. It was confusing because sometimes you were in the old toy box, and sometimes you were in the new one, and it was hard to jump between them. So, many grown-ups felt it was just too different and made everything harder to use, even though it looked bright and new!

title: how do car dealerships make money when they claim the markup on new cars is only a few hundred dollars?
text: Imagine a toy store! When they sell a brand new toy car, they might only make a tiny bit of extra money, like just one shiny penny for each car. But if they sell a *lot* of toy cars, all those pennies add up and become a big pile of money! They also make money by buying old toy cars from grown-ups, cleaning them up, and selling them to new grown-ups for a little more. Plus, they have a special garage where they fix broken cars, and grown-ups pay them to make their cars all better and to buy new parts like tires or oil. They also help grown-ups find money from the bank to buy the car, and the bank gives them a tiny thank you for helping. And sometimes, the big company that *makes* the cars gives the dealership a secret bonus later if they sell tons and tons of cars,

title: Why do we like things we don't have but once we have them they start losing their worth?
text: It's like when you see a super-duper amazing new toy in the store! You think about it all the time, imagine all the fun you'll have, and it feels like the most special, best thing ever. Your brain gets super excited just thinking about it! But then, yay, you get the toy! You play with it and it's fun, but after a little while, it's not *new* anymore

title: Why does charcoal work so well at absorbing things? I.E. stomach pumping and water filters?
text: Imagine charcoal is like a super-duper special sponge, but instead of for water, it's for tiny, invisible bad guys! When we make charcoal from wood, it gets lots and lots and LOTS of itsy-bitsy holes and tunnels inside, like a giant house with a million tiny rooms. When those tiny bad guys (like yucky stuff in water or bad things in your tummy) try to pass by, the charcoal's tiny rooms are like little traps. They grab onto the bad guys and hold them tight, so they can't get out and can't make you or your water yucky anymore! It works so well because it has so many places to catch all those tiny bad guys.

title: How does physics work in calculus?
text: Imagine physics is like watching your toy car zoom across the floor. Physics helps us understand how fast it goes, if it bumps into something, or how high a ball bounces. It's all about

title: If the House always wins, how come most casinos go broke?
text: Okay, imagine the casino is like a giant candy store, and when you play a game, the store owner always has a tiny little trick that lets them win just a tiny bit more candy than you over a super, super long time. That's what "the house always wins" means – they just slowly collect tiny bits of candy from lots and lots of games. But running that giant candy store costs a *lot* of money! They have to pay for the big building, all the lights, the yummy food, and all the people who work there to keep everything clean and fun. So, even though they win tiny bits of candy often, if not enough people come to play, or if one super lucky person wins a *giant* pile of candy all at once, the store might not make enough money to pay for everything, and then they run out of candy and have to close their doors, even with their tiny trick!

title: Why does cheese taste better (or seem to taste better), melted or grated than it does normally?
text: Okay, imagine your cheese is like a solid block, like a big toy! When you melt it, it gets all warm and super gooey, like yummy, stretchy play-doh, but edible! It spreads out more easily on your tongue, so every part of your mouth gets to taste it. Plus, when it gets warm, it lets out more of its yummy cheese smell, like when you bake cookies and the whole house smells so good! That smell helps your taste buds know it's extra delicious. When you grate cheese, you make lots and lots of tiny little cheese sprinkles! Because there are so many tiny pieces, they can cover more of your tongue all at once, so you taste cheese everywhere! And if you heat those tiny sprinkles, they melt super, super fast, making them gooey and yummy even quicker than a big block would.

title: If the wavelength of light corresponds to its energy, and space expanding lowers the wavelength of light, where does the light's energy go?
text: Imagine light is like a tiny, super springy jumpy toy. When it's squished really tight, it has lots and lots of energy to jump high! Now, imagine the whole universe

title: So there's a independence referendunn going on in Catalan, and I'm wondering why it is occuring since it was outlawed by the Spanish govermnent. What's the point in voting when their govermnent says it's unlawful?
text: Imagine you really, really want to play with a specific toy, but your grown-up says, "No, you can't play with that right now." Even if they say no, you might still tell all your friends how much you want to play with it, or maybe even try to play with it a little bit anyway, just to show everyone how important it is to you. In Catalonia, it's a bit like that. Lots of people there really want their own special country, separate from Spain, like having their own house instead of living in a big shared house. The Spanish grown-ups (the government) said, "No, you can't vote to have your own country." But the people who want it still vote anyway, even if it's not "allowed," because they want to show everyone, especially the Spanish grown-ups, just how many people feel this way and how much they want it. They hope that if enough people show how much they want it, maybe the grown-ups will listen and change their mind later.

title: The pain from a headache or migraine. Is it 'real' or perceived and what's causing it?
text: Yes, the pain from a headache or migraine is super-duper real, just like when you bump your knee! It's not pretend at all. What's causing it is a bit like your brain feeling tired or upset. Sometimes, with a regular headache, the muscles around your head can get a little tight, like when you squeeze your fist really hard, or your brain just needs a little rest. But with a migraine, it's like the special wires and signals inside your brain get a bit mixed up and start making a big, loud alarm noise, which makes your head hurt a lot and sometimes makes you not like bright lights or loud sounds. Your brain is just telling you it needs some quiet time and a rest!

title: why is kitty litter dangerous for humans (particularly pregnant women) but does not harm the animals that use it?
text: Okay, imagine there's a super tiny, invisible little bug that some cats might have inside their tummies. When these cats make a poopie in their litter box, sometimes these tiny bugs come out with the poopie. For the cat, usually, it's no big deal, they're strong and can fight it off! But if a grown-up, especially a mommy with a tiny baby growing in her tummy, accidentally touches the poopie (even just a tiny bit you can't see!) and then puts their hand near their mouth, that tiny bug can get inside them. For a regular grown-up, it might just make them feel a little bit yucky, or they might not even notice. But for the tiny baby inside a mommy's tummy, that little bug can be very, very dangerous and make the baby super sick. That's why mommies with babies in their tummies need to be extra careful and let someone else clean the kitty's litter box!

title: How does the Atkins Diet work?
text: Imagine your body is like a little car that usually loves to run on sweet, sugary fuel, like candy, bread, and pasta. But when you do the Atkins diet, you tell your car, "Hey, let's try a different kind of fuel today!" So instead of giving it lots of that sugary fuel, you eat more yummy foods like meat, cheese, and green veggies. When your body doesn't get much of its usual sugary fuel, it starts to look for other fuel to keep running and finds the fat stored in your body! It says, "Aha! I can use this fat to run!" And when your body uses up that fat for energy, it helps you get a little bit smaller.

title: How can the car industry be so diverse, and still be so successful?
text: Imagine you have lots of friends, and they all like different things, right? Some like superheroes, some like princesses, some like building with blocks! Cars are just like that. There are so many different kinds of cars, like big ones for families, speedy ones for fun, strong ones for working, and fancy ones that look super cool. And lots of different companies make them, like different shops selling different kinds of toys. This is good because everyone needs a car for something different! If you have a big family, you need a big car. If you just need to go to the store, maybe a small car is perfect. Because there are so many choices, everyone can find the *perfect* car for what they need or what they like best, just like finding your favorite toy. When everyone can find a car they love, lots and lots of people buy them, and all the car companies are super happy and make lots of money, which means they are very, very successful! It's like having a giant toy box with something for everyone!

title: How did my new HP printer connected itself to my wifi network without me giving it its name and password?
text: Imagine your internet box (that's the thing that gives your house Wi-Fi) is like a special club. To get into the club, you usually need to know a secret word (that's your Wi-Fi password). But sometimes, there's a super-duper easy way! Your new printer and your internet box have a special 'magic button' trick. When you set up your printer, you probably pushed a button on the printer, and maybe even a button on your internet box, too. Pushing that button is like saying, 'Hey club, this new friend (the printer) wants to join! Let them in without asking for the secret word this time.' It's like they did a secret handshake all by themselves, and your internet box said, 'Okay, come on in!' without you having to spell out the secret word for them.

title: When deleting data off hard drives to cover your tracks, why do we often see the drives physically destroyed?
text: Imagine your computer is like a big toy box, and all your secrets (your data) are like special toys inside. When you "delete" a toy, it's not really gone!

title: Why do we need IP address to be connected to internet? Don't we have MAC address already?
text: Imagine your toy train has a special sticker with its name on it, like "Choo-Choo Train #123". That's like a MAC address! It's super unique to *just your train*. If you want to find your train *in your room*, you just look for that sticker. But what if you want to send a drawing to your friend who lives in a different city? You wouldn't just write "Choo-Choo Train #123" on the envelope, right? That wouldn't help the postman find their house! You need their house number and street name. That's like an IP address! It tells the internet where your computer's "house" is in the big, big world. So, the MAC address is good for finding things *very close by*, like inside your own house, but the IP address is like the house number that helps the internet mailman deliver your message to the *right house* anywhere in the whole wide world, even if it's super far away. They both work together: the IP address gets the message to the right house, and then the MAC address makes sure it goes to the right toy (or computer!) *inside* that house.

title: Why are most cigarettes white with an orange butt? What/Who set this standard and why?
text: Imagine a little paper tube filled with dried leaves. The paper is usually white because that's just the color paper naturally is, like how your drawing paper is white! It's clean and simple, and it's easy to print pretty pictures or names on it. Now, the little part you put in your mouth, the "butt" you call it, is a special filter, like a tiny sponge that tries to catch some of the dusty bits. It's often made to look like a pretty brown-orange color, kind of like the bark of a tree called cork. They made it that color a long, long time ago because it looked fancy and natural, and it also helped to hide the brownish stuff the filter catches so it didn't look too yucky. No one person said, "Let's make them this way!" Instead, lots of grown-up companies just started doing it because it looked good, and then everyone else just copied it because that's what people expected cigarettes to look like, just like how most cars are shiny and have four wheels!

title: Why does it feel so much better when another person massages your head as opposed to when you use your own hand to massage your head?
text: Imagine your head is like a little sleepy puppy! When *you* try to pet the puppy, your arm is busy, your brain is busy telling your hand what to do, so it's not as relaxing because you're doing all the work! But when *someone else* pets your puppy, your arm can just relax and hang down. Your brain doesn't have to think about *how* to pet, it just gets to enjoy the nice feeling! It's like a happy surprise, and you don't have to do any work at all, which feels extra special and comfy.

title: My microwave has little holes that allow me to see the food as it cooks. How are those little holes sufficient to block microwaves?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big bouncy ball, like a beach ball, and a tiny, tiny little bouncy ball, like a marble. Your microwave door has lots and lots of super tiny holes, like a special net. The big bouncy ball (that's like the microwave magic that cooks your food) is much, much too big to squeeze through those little holes, so it bounces right back inside to stay with your food. But the tiny bouncy ball (that's like the light you see) is so super small that it can easily zip right through the holes! So the holes are like a clever gate: they're big enough for your eyes to see the light, but way too small for the big cooking magic to get out and tickle you.

title: Why are mass shootings more common in the U.S. than any other country?
text: Imagine some grown-ups have special, really powerful tools that can make a lot of noise and hurt people very quickly. In America, it's much easier for grown-ups to get these kinds of tools, even the really big and fast ones. Other countries have very strong rules, like a grown-up telling you, "No, you can't have that big, sharp scissor," to make it super hard for just anyone to get those powerful tools. Because it'

title: 2017 Las Vegas Strip shooting is not an 'act of terrorism' according to the Police. Can someone explain why killing 50+ innocent people isn't considered terrorism?
text: Imagine when someone does something super, super mean, like breaking your toys. That's very sad and bad, right? But sometimes, someone does something mean not just because they're angry or sad, but because they want to make *lots and lots* of people scared so that those scared people will change their minds about something big, or make the grown-ups in charge do what the mean person wants. That special kind of mean, where you hurt people to send a scary message to everyone else, is what we call terrorism. When the police looked into what happened in Las Vegas, they saw that a very, very mean man hurt many people, which was incredibly sad and wrong. But they looked and looked for that special reason – if he was trying to make everyone scared to change big things, or to make grown

title: Why do TV series' from cable/streaming services like HBO, Netflix or Hulu seem to be so much higher quality than network TV?
text: Imagine you have two kinds of playtimes! For shows on HBO or Netflix, it's like they have a super big toy box with lots and lots of money-toys, so they can build really fancy sets, have special effects, and hire the best storytellers. They also don't have as many grown-up rules about what kind of stories they can tell or what words they can use, so they can be a bit more exciting and tell stories just for older kids or grown-ups. For shows on regular TV channels, it's like they have a smaller toy box, and they have to follow lots more rules because *everyone* is watching, even little babies! They also have to stop playing every few minutes to show you commercials for toys or snacks, which breaks up the story, and they try to make stories that *everyone* will like, which sometimes means they can't be as super unique or adventurous. So the big toy box shows often feel extra special because they have more shiny things, fewer rules, and can tell their stories all the way through without stopping!

title: How do American Zip Codes work?
text: Imagine you're sending a drawing to your friend across town or even far away! The mailman has a super important job to make sure your drawing gets to the right house. A Zip Code is like a special secret number for a whole neighborhood or a group of houses. It's usually five numbers, like 12345. The first few numbers tell the mailman to go to a really big area, like a whole big city or a part of a state. Then, the last numbers tell him to zoom in even closer, to a smaller street or just a few houses. So, instead of reading every single address, the mailman just looks at the special Zip Code number and knows exactly where to go much, much faster! It's like a super helpful shortcut so your letters and birthday cards always find their way home.

title: why do people care about the difference between shaken and stirred?
text: Imagine you have a cup of juice! When you *shake* it really hard with ice, it's like a wild dance party for your drink! It gets super, super cold and a little bit bubbly and foggy, because tiny air bubbles get mixed in. But when you *stir* it gently with a spoon, it's like a slow, smooth dance. It still gets cold, but it stays very clear and smooth, without all those little bubbles. Grown-ups care because some drinks taste best when they're super frosty and a little bubbly from shaking, and other drinks taste much better when they are smooth and clear from stirring. It's like choosing if you want a fizzy drink or a smooth drink – both are yummy, but they feel different in your mouth!

title: If someone passes out from pain, does that mean they've already experienced the worst pain they could ever experience?
text: Imagine your body is like a little car, and pain is like a super loud alarm going off because there's a big problem (a really, really big boo-boo!). Sometimes, when the alarm is just too loud and too much for the car to handle, the car's engine just decides to take a little nap so it doesn't get too overwhelmed. That's kind of like passing out. It means the boo-boo was so big and hurt so much that your body said, "Whoa, that's too much! I need a time-out!" and pressed a "sleep" button for a little while to protect itself. It was definitely a *huge* boo-boo, but maybe not the absolute biggest one your body could *ever* feel, just one that was big enough to make it need a nap and a break from all that feeling.

title: Why do meal-in-a-box (like Hamburger Helper) recipes require hot water when you are just going to boil all of the ingredients anyway?
text: Imagine you have two cups, and you want to melt a tiny ice cube in each. If one cup has really hot water and the other has cold water, which one will melt the ice cube faster? The hot water, right? It's already warm and ready to do its job! It's the same with your box meal. Even though you're going to make everything super bubbly (that's boiling!) anyway, starting with hot water is like giving everything a big head start. It makes the pasta or rice start cooking much faster, and it helps the yummy sauce powder mix and dissolve quickly so it doesn't get clumpy. If you used cold water, it would take a long, long time for the water to get hot enough to start cooking and mixing, and your food might not turn out as perfectly yummy. So, hot water helps everything get going faster and makes sure your meal cooks just right!

title: Why does stimulation of the prostate make the penis hard or ejaculate without directly touching the penis?
text: Imagine your body has lots of secret buttons and switches! Your penis is like a sleepy water hose, and it has a special little friend inside your body called the "prostate." The prostate is like a secret control button that's *super* close to the water hose, like two best friends holding hands. When someone presses or tickles that secret control button, even though they're not touching the hose directly, it sends a super-fast message right to the hose saying, "Wake up! Get big and strong!" or "Time to squirt out your special water!" It's like pressing a remote control for a toy car – you don't touch the car, but it still moves because of the secret signal from the button!

title: What gives a person their own unique tone or pitch in their voice, and why are men and women voices so vastly different?
text: Imagine you have two tiny rubber bands inside your throat, called vocal cords! When you talk, these rubber bands wiggle super fast, like a tiny guitar string. How thick and long your rubber bands are, and how fast they wiggle, makes your voice sound special and unique, just like your own unique song! Everyone's rubber bands are

title: Why does brushing your teeth or having a mint make citrus taste so sour/bitter?
text: Okay, imagine your tongue has tiny little helpers called taste buds, and some of them are really good at finding yummy sweet things, and others are good at finding zippy sour things. When you brush your teeth with toothpaste or eat a mint, there's a special ingredient inside (like a tiny bit of magic soap for your mouth, or a cool minty feeling) that makes your sweet-finding helpers take a little nap or hide for a bit. They can't do their job very well! But your sour-finding helpers are wide awake and super excited. So, when you eat something like an orange that has both sweet and sour in it, your sleepy sweet helpers can't tell you about the sweet part, and all you can hear is the super loud sour part. It's like turning down the volume on the sweet music so only the sour music plays really loud!

title: Why do men feel sick when punched or kicked in the testicles?
text: Okay, imagine your testicles are like super important, super soft little factories that make special "daddy seeds" for when you're a grown-up. They don't have a

title: How are adept music players able to just start playing along to anything that someone else plays and have it sound good?
text: Imagine music is like a big, fun puzzle! Grown-up musicians have played so many puzzles that they know all the different shapes and colors of the pieces. When someone starts playing a song, it's like they've put down the first few puzzle pieces. The musician listens really, really carefully to those first pieces to figure out what kind of puzzle it is – is it a happy one? A calm one? A bouncy one? Because they've played so much, their ears and brain quickly remember all the other puzzle pieces that usually fit with those sounds. They've also practiced so much that their fingers or voice just *know* how to find the right notes super fast, almost like their hands have their own special map. So, they're not just guessing; they're like super puzzle solvers who know all the musical patterns and how to make their own pieces fit perfectly to make the whole picture sound wonderful together!

title: Why does drip coffee make me much more jittery than espresso, even when using the same amount of coffee beans for each?
text:
Imagine coffee beans are like little toys that have "wake-up power" inside.

When you make **drip coffee**, it's like letting a big cup of water slowly wash over many of these toys for a long, long time. The water has lots of time to grab *all* the wake-up power from the toys and put it into your big cup. So, when you drink that big cup, you get a *lot* of wake-up power all at once, which makes you super jumpy!

But when you make **espresso**, it's like pushing a tiny bit of water super fast over just a few toys. The water goes so quickly that it only grabs a *little bit* of wake-up power from each toy, and it's in a tiny cup. Even if you started with the same amount of toys (beans) for both, the way you made the drip coffee lets it pick up way more wake-up power into the drink you actually sip, making you much more jittery!

title: What is risk premium for a stock?
text: Imagine you have two ways to get some yummy candy. One way is super easy: you just sit still for a minute, and your grown-up *promises* to give you one candy. That's like putting your money in a super safe piggy bank where you know you'll always get a little bit more back. The other way is a bit like doing a tricky jumping jack! If you do it perfectly, maybe your grown-up will give you *two* candies, but if you wobble and fall, you might get no candy. When you decide to do the tricky jumping jack for the *chance* to get two candies instead of just sitting still for one, that *extra* candy you're hoping for (the second one!) is called the 'risk premium.' It's the extra treat you want because you're taking a little bit of a chance or doing something a bit harder, instead of just picking the super easy, super safe option.

title: How do radio stations determine who is listening and how many people are tuning in daily?
text:
Imagine you're shouting a story out into a big, big park. You don't have a special button that lights up every time someone hears you, right? Radio is kind of like that! The songs and stories just fly out of a giant tower into the air, and the radio station doesn't have a magic eye to see *you* listening in your car or house.

Instead, they have a secret club of special helpers! These are grown-ups who promise to listen to the radio a lot. Some of them write down in a special notebook, like a diary, exactly what stations they listen to and when. Other helpers have a tiny little box, like a robot ear, that sits in their house and quietly listens to the radio with them, remembering which station is playing.

Then, all these special helpers send their notes or the information from their little boxes back to a big company. That company counts up all the information from these few helpers. And then, they make a really smart guess! They say, "If these few helpers listened to our station a lot, then probably lots and lots of *other* people, who aren't in our secret club, are listening too!" It's like if you ask 10 friends what their favorite color is, and 5 say blue. You might guess that about

title: Why does saliva sometimes shoot from a person's mouth when they're yawning?
text: When you yawn, your mouth opens super, duper wide, like a big tunnel! And you take a really big breath in. Inside your mouth, you have special wet water called saliva (that's just spit!). When your mouth opens so big and then closes a little bit, all the muscles around your mouth and throat squeeze really hard, just like when you squeeze a tube of toothpaste or a water balloon. This big squeeze can sometimes push a little bit of that wet saliva right out, like a tiny little squirt gun! It's just your mouth muscles giving your spit a little push.

title: In cases of mass shootings with one perpetrator, why do witnesses often report seeing multiple attackers?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing hide-and-seek, but suddenly a big, loud thunderclap happens right next to you! You'd be super, super scared, right? When something really scary and loud happens, like a big bang, our brains get all mixed up and go super-fast. Our eyes might only see quick blurs or shadows moving really fast, and because we're so scared and trying to understand what's happening, our brain sometimes accidentally thinks it saw more than

title: How do plants crack rock and concrete?
text: Imagine a tiny, tiny baby plant root, like a little worm, trying to find water. It wiggles and wiggles until it finds a super-duper small crack in a big, hard rock or the sidewalk, almost like a secret door! The root is very clever because it starts to drink water and eat food from the ground, and just like you grow bigger when you eat your veggies, the root starts to get bigger and bigger inside that tiny crack. It's like blowing up a balloon inside a small, tight box – the balloon pushes and pushes on the sides. The growing root pushes and pushes on the sides of the crack, making it a little wider. More roots come, and they all keep growing bigger, pushing and pushing even more, little by little, for a very, very long time. Eventually, all that gentle but constant pushing makes the crack get bigger and bigger until *CRACK!* The rock or concrete breaks a little bit. Plants are super strong and patient, even if they look soft!

title: why are eggs lumped in with dairy?
text: That's a super smart question! You see, 'dairy' stuff, like milk, cheese, and yogurt, all comes from cows! A cow makes milk, right? But eggs come from chickens! Cluck cluck! Chickens don't make milk. So, eggs are not dairy at all, even though they often sit next to the milk in the grocery store fridge because lots of people like to buy them together, maybe for breakfast, but they come from totally different animal friends!

title: How does our odor sensation differ in state of weightlessness?
text: Imagine your nose is like a little vacuum cleaner for smells! On Earth, when you smell a yummy cookie, the tiny invisible cookie-smell bits float all around and gravity helps them bounce and spread, so lots of them go right into your nose. But in space, there's no gravity to help those smell bits move around and float into your nose easily. They just kind of hang there! So, it's like your nose vacuum has to work harder to suck them in, and sometimes not as many smell bits get inside. Plus, in space, your face can feel a bit puffy and your nose can feel a little stuffy, like when you have a tiny cold, because the liquids in your body float up to your head. When your nose is stuffy, it's harder for the smell bits to get to the special smelling parts inside. So, because the smell bits don't move around as much and your nose might be a bit stuffy, smells in space can seem weaker or even a little different to astronauts!

title: Why aren’t we accessing Dark Fiber?
text: Okay, imagine there are super-duper fast, empty roads built all over the world, just sitting there, but no cars are driving on them. That's "dark fiber"! We don't use them because, first, we'd have to buy our very own, super special, super expensive car that can go super fast, and then we'd need lots of smart people to drive it and make sure it doesn't crash! It's much easier and cheaper for us to just hop into a taxi or a bus (that's your internet from companies like Xfinity or AT&T) that's already running and has all the drivers and cars ready to go. Only really, really big delivery companies, like Google or Amazon, who need to send millions and millions of packages all day long, find it worthwhile to buy their own roads and their own super big, super fast cars. For everyone else, it's just too much work and too much money!

title: I have just seen a Cambodian food market on a travel program; in this market a stall was skinning and de-heading live frogs. The frogs were then seen, headless, hopping around directionally, continuing with normal full body movement. What is the process that allows this to occur?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like the main captain of a big ship, telling everything what to do. But for frogs, it's a little different! They have lots of tiny little helpers

title: Why do you need to pee after sex?
text: When grown-ups play or cuddle very close, sometimes tiny invisible little germs or yucky stuff can try to sneak into a special little tube inside your body where your pee comes out. If those little germs stay there, they can make that part of your body feel ouchy or sick, like when you have a cold. So, when you pee right after playing or cuddling, it's like a super special flush! The pee rushes through that tube and washes all those sneaky little germs right out, down the toilet, so they can't make you feel bad. It's like cleaning up to keep your body healthy and happy!

title: Why was there such a debate between Edison's DC and Tesla's AC?
text: Imagine you have a special juice called electricity that makes your lights glow and your toys work! Edison said, "Let's send this juice straight from the juice box to your house, just one way!" (That was DC). But the juice got tired super fast and couldn't go very far, so they'd need a tiny juice box on almost every street corner! Then Tesla came along and said, "No, no! Let's make the juice wiggle back and forth, like a seesaw!" (That was AC). This wobbly juice was super clever because it didn't get tired easily and could travel a super, super long way from one big juice box to many, many houses! Edison got a bit grumpy and tried to say Tesla's wobbly juice was scary, but Tesla showed everyone it was much better for sending power to lots of people far away. That's why today, almost all the electricity that comes to your house is Tesla's clever wobbly juice!

title: why does our nose get stuffy when we lay down for the night but clear up when we are out and about?
text: Okay, imagine your nose has special little squishy sponges inside, like tiny pillows! When you're running and playing, gravity (that's the invisible force that keeps you on the ground) helps pull your blood down to your legs and tummy. So, those little pillows in your nose are nice and small, making lots of room for air to zoom in and out. But when you lie down flat in your bed, gravity isn't pulling your blood down as much anymore, so more of it goes up to your head, like water filling up a bathtub! When there's more blood near your nose, those squishy pillows get a little bit bigger, like tiny balloons puffing up, and they take up more space, making it harder for air to get through. It's also harder for your snot to drip out when you're flat. But then when you stand up and start moving again, gravity helps pull that blood away from your head, and those pillows

title: Why do birds leave a white residue whenever they hit a window?
text: Okay, imagine you get a super big surprise, like when someone jumps out and says 'BOO!' really loudly! Sometimes when that happens, your body might accidentally let out a little pee, right? Well, when a bird flies super fast and bumps into a window, it's a HUGE surprise and it hurts a little! Their bodies get so scared and surprised that sometimes they just can't hold their poop and pee anymore, and it all comes out. The white part is like their pee, but bird pee is special – it's all solid and white, not watery like yours. So when they get a big fright, that white pee and their regular poop sometimes just plop out!

title: How can anyone survive as an 'out of work actor' in New York City or LA when people with full time degree-required jobs can barely afford to live there?
text: Imagine New York and LA are like super popular playgrounds where everything costs a lot of pretend money, even a tiny snack! Actors want to play make-believe there, but they don't always get a job doing it right away. So, what do they do? Well, they often have other jobs, like being a helper in a restaurant, or walking puppies, or watching kids, that let them earn money and still go try out for plays! They also share their homes with lots of friends, like having a big sleepover every night, so the house money gets split into tiny pieces for everyone. And they are super good at saving their pennies and not buying too many new toys, so their money lasts a long, long time until they get their big make-believe job!

title: Do fish drink water and if so, how?
text: Yes, fish do drink water, but it's a little different depending on where they live! If a fish lives in a river or a lake (that's not salty), they actually don't drink much water with their mouth. Their skin and gills are like little sponges, and water just soaks right into their bodies all by itself, so they don't get thirsty the way we do. They even have to pee a lot to get rid of all the extra water! But if a fish lives in the big, salty ocean, they *do* drink water with their mouth, just like you would when you're thirsty. This is because the salty ocean water tries to pull water *out* of their bodies, so they need to drink to stay full of water. They even have special ways to get rid of all the extra salt they swallow, so it doesn't make them sick!

title: Why does single-serve water typically come in plastic bottles, single-serve soda typically come in aluminum cans, and single-serve beer come in either aluminum cans or glass bottles?
text:
Imagine bottles and cans are like different kinds of coats for your drinks!

Water wears a simple plastic coat because water is super strong and doesn't mind if it gets a little warm or sees the

title: Why is natural sugar healthier than added sugar?
text:
Okay, imagine sugar is like a little energy sparkle for your body!

When you eat **natural sugar**, like in an apple or a banana, it's like the sparkle comes with a whole bunch of its best friends: fiber, vitamins, and water. These friends help your body get the sparkle slowly and steadily, so you have energy for a long time, and they also help your tummy feel full and happy. But when you eat **added sugar**, like in candy or a fizzy drink, it's often just the sparkle all by itself, without any friends. It gives your body a super-fast burst of energy that goes away quickly, and it doesn't help your tummy feel full, so you might want more and more! That's why the sparkle with all its friends is much better for your body.

title: Why can't people who have had cancer in the past donate blood?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super-duper strong castle, and your blood is like the special magic potion that keeps it all working! When someone has had cancer, it means some tiny little building blocks inside their castle went a bit wonky and made them feel poorly. Doctors gave them special medicine to make those wonky blocks go away. Now, even though they feel much better, their body might still be a little bit tired from fighting the wonky blocks and taking the special medicine. If they gave away some of their magic potion, they might get too tired or feel poorly again, and we want them to stay super strong! Also, doctors want to be extra, extra careful and make sure that the magic potion they give to someone else, especially someone who is already very sick, is the very best and healthiest potion possible, with no tiny worries at all. So, it's like saying, "Let's keep all your magic potion in your castle to make sure you stay super strong, and let's get potion from someone else who hasn't had to fight those wonky blocks, just to be super-duper safe for everyone!"

title: what’s the difference between hand soap and dish soap?
text: Imagine you have two special cleaning helpers! Hand soap is like a gentle, soft helper for *your* hands. It's made to be super nice to your skin, like a warm hug, and helps wash away all the invisible germs so your hands are clean and smell yummy. Dish soap is a super strong, brave helper for *plates and cups*! It's made to fight really sticky, greasy food messes, like a superhero fighting a monster. It's so strong for the food goo that it's not very nice to your skin, so we let it do its big job on the dishes instead of our hands. So, one is gentle for you, and the other is tough for food!

title: Why does it always feels like gaming graphics can't get any better?
text: Imagine when you first learned to draw a person. First, you drew a stick figure, right? Then maybe you drew a person with a round head and a square body. Each time you learned something new, your drawing got *way* better, and you could really see the big difference! Now, imagine you're a super-duper artist, and you can draw a person that looks almost exactly like a photo. If you try to make it even *more* real, maybe by adding one tiny little eyelash, it's really hard to even tell the difference, even though you worked super hard! Gaming graphics are kind of like that. A long, long time ago, the games looked like super simple stick figures, so every time they made them a little better, it felt like a HUGE change, like going from a stick figure to a full cartoon! Now, the games already look so, so good, almost like real life! So when they make them even a tiny bit better, our eyes are super smart and they can still tell it's not *perfectly* real, but the *

title: How do people in courtrooms, depositions, parliaments and what not type everything being typed up so quickly?
text: You know how when you want to write 'cat', you have to press the 'C' button, then the 'A' button, then the 'T' button? Well, the grown-ups in courtrooms have a super special keyboard that's different! Instead of pressing just one letter at a time, they press *lots* of buttons *all at once* to make whole sounds or even whole words. It's like if your keyboard had a magic button that, when you pressed it, instantly wrote 'dinosaur' instead of you having to press D-I-N-O-S-A-U-R. They learn a secret way of pressing these buttons to make sounds like 'shhh' or 'th' or even entire common words super fast. Their special machine then writes down a kind of secret code, and later, a smart computer or they themselves turn that secret code into all the regular words everyone can read. They practice a *lot* to be so quick!

title: When you're standing up you have 14.7PSI of atmosphere (weight of the air above you) pressing down on all the surfaces perpendicular to this force; shoulders, top of head. Lay down and you expose much more surface area to this force. How does a scale not reflect this change in surface area?
text: Imagine you're a little toy boat in a bathtub. The water pushes on your boat from all sides, right? From the top, from the bottom, and from the sides! Air is kind of like that water, but it's all around us, pushing on us from *everywhere*. It pushes down on your head, but it also pushes up from underneath you, and in from your sides, and out from your chest! All these pushes are super balanced, like when you push a door from both sides at the same time and it doesn't move. A scale only cares about how much the Earth is pulling *you* down, like how much you weigh because the Earth wants to keep you close. The air pushing on you from all those balanced directions doesn't change how much the Earth pulls you, so the scale just sees *you*, whether you're standing tall or lying down for a nap!

title: How come when you're ill it hurts slightly to go to the toilet, like a sort of uncomfortable burning sensation?
text: Oh, that's a yucky feeling, isn't it? Imagine your pee is like a little river that carries away all the yucky stuff from inside your body. When you're sick, sometimes you don't drink as much water, or your body is busy fighting the sickness, which makes your pee river have less water and more of the yucky stuff all squished together. It's like when you have a super strong juice instead of regular juice. The skin where your pee comes out is super duper sensitive, like your tongue when you eat something a little spicy. So, when that super strong, squished-together pee touches your super sensitive skin, it can feel a little bit ouchy or burny, just like a tiny bit of spice. The best way to make it feel better is to drink lots of water, so your pee river gets more water and isn't so strong anymore!

title: If men are required to register with Selective Service, why not automatically have men registered when they turn 18?
text: Imagine the government needs a special list of all the grown-up boys who turn 18, just in case they ever need help for our country, like a superhero team. But the government doesn't have a magic eye that knows *exactly* when every single boy turns 18 or where they live all the time! So, it's like a grown-up rule that when a boy turns 18, *he* needs to go tell the government, 'Hey, I'm 18 now!' This helps make sure the list is super correct and shows that the grown-up boys understand their big job to remember to do this important thing for our country.

title: So air canada just told me to put away my AirPods because they don’t allow Bluetooth headphones of any kind, what is the reason why?
text: Okay, imagine your AirPods talk to your phone using tiny, invisible walkie-talkies. Airplanes also have their own super important walkie-talkies that talk to the control tower on the ground and help the pilot know where to fly safely. Sometimes, if too many little walkie-talkies are talking all at once, they might accidentally talk over the big, important airplane walkie-talkies and make it hard for the airplane to hear its messages clearly. To make sure the airplane always hears everything perfectly and stays super safe for everyone, the grown-ups ask you to turn off your little walkie-talkies. It's like asking everyone to be quiet so the pilot can concentrate really hard!

title: [X-Post /r/Argentina] What does it mean for a country to have the amount of debt Argentina has?
text:
Okay, imagine Argentina is like a kid who wanted to buy a really cool, big toy, like a giant playground for everyone to play on, or a big hospital to help sick people. But they didn't have enough money (which is like toy tokens) themselves. So, Argentina went to other grown-ups or other countries (who have lots of tokens) and said, "Can I borrow some tokens? I promise I'll pay you back later, maybe with a little extra candy for letting me borrow!"

Now, Argentina has borrowed *a lot* of those tokens over many years, so many that it's sometimes really hard to find enough tokens to pay back everyone they owe. It's like if you borrowed a toy from Tommy, a toy from Sarah, and a toy from Max, and now all three of them want their toys back *plus* a little piece of candy, but you only have one toy left yourself!

When a country has too much debt, it means they have to spend a big chunk of their own tokens just paying back what they borrowed, instead of using those tokens to buy new, important things for *their own* people, like fixing schools, building new roads, or getting more medicine. And because they owe so much, sometimes other grown-ups or countries get worried and don't want to lend them *more* tokens, because they're scared they might never get them back. This can make it really hard for Argentina to get new, important things done or fix old problems, because they're always busy trying to pay back old promises.

title: What is terrorism? What are the boundaries of terrorism, and how is it classified?
text: Imagine someone is really, really mad about something and they want the grown-ups in charge to listen to them and do what they want. Instead of just talking, they do something very scary and dangerous, like making a big loud noise or hurting people, not just one person, but trying to make *lots* of people feel scared. They do this because they want to make everyone so scared that the grown-ups will *have* to listen and change things. That scary thing they do to make everyone afraid and get their way is called terrorism. It's different from just a regular bully being mean to one kid, or two big countries fighting each other with armies. For it to be terrorism, it has to be about trying to scare many, many people on purpose to make big changes, not just a small fight or someone being mean for no big reason. Grown-ups figure out if something is terrorism by looking if someone did something scary to lots of people, and if they did it because they wanted to make the government or other grown-ups change their minds, and if it wasn't an army fighting another army. If it fits those things, then they say it's terrorism, so they know how to talk about it and

title: Why do US based airlines lag behind in service and quality, especially in their premium cabins?
text: Imagine you have a few big toy stores in your town, and they're the *only* ones. They know you'll probably buy your toys from them because there aren't many other

title: My kids Dinosaur book said scientists don't know what skin color they were, but it said scientists had good guesses but didn't go into detail. How and why would they make these guesses? What are they?
text:
Imagine you have a super old coloring book, but all the pages with the dinosaur pictures are blank! That's kind of like dinosaur skin – it's usually too squishy to turn into a hard fossil like bones do, so we don't have many actual "pictures" of their colors. But scientists are super-smart detectives!

They make guesses by looking at animals today. Think about it: a tiger has stripes to hide in the tall grass, and a chameleon can change colors to blend in with leaves. So, if a dinosaur lived in a jungle, scientists might guess it was green or brown, like the plants, to hide from big chompy dinosaurs or sneak up on its dinner. If it lived in a big open desert, maybe it was sandy brown.

Sometimes, super rarely, they get a tiny, tiny peek! They find a very special fossil that has little bits of skin or feathers. And inside those tiny bits, they can find even tinier dots, like tiny paint pots, called melanosomes. These little dots tell us if a dinosaur might have had black, brown, or even reddish colors! It's like finding a single crayon that fell out of the coloring book.

They also think about how some dinosaurs might have wanted to show off! Like a peacock has a super bright tail to look pretty, maybe some dinosaurs with big frills or horns had bright, flashy colors like red, orange, or even rainbow colors to attract friends or scare away enemies. So, they guess dinosaurs were mostly camouflaged like greens, browns, and grays, but maybe some had stripes, spots, or even super bright colors for showing off!

title: How does the Home Owners Association (or HOA) Function?
text: Imagine your whole neighborhood is like a big, super special playground with lots of houses, and the Home Owners Association, or HOA, is like a club for all the grown-ups who live there! When your grown-ups buy a house in one of these neighborhoods, they agree to join this club. This club has two main jobs: first, they make some friendly rules, like "let's all keep our front yards neat and tidy, just like you clean up your toys," or "everyone should paint their house a nice, happy color so all the houses look good together." These rules help make sure the whole neighborhood stays pretty and everyone is happy. Second, everyone in the club puts a little bit of their money into a special piggy bank every month. This money is used to take care of all the things everyone shares, like fixing the swings at the park, making sure the swimming pool is super clean, or cutting the grass in the big field where you can play. So, the HOA is just a way for all the grown-ups in the neighborhood to work together, follow some simple rules, and share the cost of keeping their special neighborhood looking nice and having cool shared stuff like parks or pools!

title: Why does touching my face a lot cause pimples but the rest of my body isn't affected the same way?
text: Imagine your skin has tiny, tiny holes, like little doors. On your face, you have lots of these little doors, and some of them make a special oily juice to keep your skin soft. When you touch your face with your hands, sometimes you accidentally push invisible dirt and tiny germs from your hands right into those little doors. If a door gets full of the oily juice, and then you push dirt and germs in there too, it's like the door gets all clogged up and y

title: How did we measure the speed of light so precisely?
text:
Imagine light as a super-fast runner! For a long, long time, people thought light was so fast it was like it was everywhere instantly.

The first clever trick to measure it

title: Why has MH370 not been found?
text: Imagine a big, big airplane, like a giant metal bird, that was flying high in the sky with lots of people inside. One day, it flew away and didn't land where it was supposed to – it just disappeared! The problem is, the place where we think it might have fallen is like a super-duper giant bathtub, bigger than all the bathtubs in the world put together, called the ocean. And when it went missing, it stopped sending any signals, like when your walkie-talkie runs out of batteries, so we don't know exactly where in that giant bathtub it splashed down. It's also super, super deep down there, darker than your room at night, and no one can see it. So, even with big boats and special underwater robots, it's like trying to find one tiny lost toy car in a playground that's bigger than your whole town, in the dark, without knowing which way it rolled. It's just a very, very big and dark place, and we don't have enough clues to know exactly

title: Why are bodies able to create an entire body with it's own lifetime supply of regenetive cells, but is itself unable to prevent gradual decay over a lifetime?
text: Imagine your body is like a super amazing toy factory that makes all sorts of cool toys, like new skin for your scraped knee, or new blood when you get a little cut, or even new

title: The universe is expanding, but where is the center of the expansion? is that the point in which the big bang happened? And where are we relatively to it?
text: Imagine you have a yummy loaf of raisin bread dough, and it has lots and lots of raisins mixed all through it. When your mommy bakes it in the oven, the bread gets bigger and bigger, right? All the raisins in the bread move away from each other, no matter where they are! If you were a tiny ant on one of those raisins, you'd see all the other raisins moving away from *you*, but none of them would be the special 'center' where it all started getting bigger. The whole bread is getting bigger everywhere at once! That's kind of like our universe. It's like the bread, and the galaxies (where lots of stars live, like our sun) are like the raisins. Everything is moving away from everything else, but there's no special 'center' where the Big Bang happened like a firecracker going

title: What exactly does seeding a torrent do?
text: Okay, imagine you want to build a super cool LEGO castle, but it's so big that no one person has all the LEGO bricks. Instead, lots of your friends have *some* of the bricks. When you're "downloading" a torrent, it's like you're going around to all your friends and asking for the LEGO bricks you need to build your castle, getting different pieces from different friends. Now, once you've got all your LEGO bricks and you've built your awesome castle, "seeding" is like *you* becoming one of those friends who has bricks to share. You let other kids who want to build the same castle come to you and get copies of the bricks you have. So, when you "seed" a torrent, it just means that after you've gotten all the pieces of a file (like a movie or a game) from other people, you then let *your* computer share those pieces with *other* people who are still trying to get them. It helps everyone get their full file faster, like sharing your LEGOs helps everyone build their castles!

title: Why does buying stuff (non-essential) make us happy?
text: Imagine you get a brand new toy! It feels super exciting, right? Your eyes get wide and you can't wait to play with it. When grown-ups buy new things, especially things they don't *really* need but just think are cool, it's a little bit like that. It makes their brain feel happy for a little while, like when you get a yummy cookie or watch your favorite cartoon. It's fun to have something new and shiny, and it feels like a little treat or a surprise just for them, making them smile!

title: What is regulatory capture and how does it work?
text: Imagine there's a big game, like soccer, and there's a referee whose job is to make sure everyone plays fair and follows the rules. Now, imagine one of the

title: Why is the economic value of a task different in different countries?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friend live in different houses, even though you both love to help! If you clean your room, your grown-ups might give you 5 shiny stickers.

title: What chemical reactions happen when you start fearing for your life?
text: When you're really, really scared, like if a big, loud dog suddenly barks at you, your body has tiny little helpers inside, like chefs in a kitchen! They quickly make special "superhero juice" called adrenaline! This juice makes your heart beat super fast, like a drum, to pump blood everywhere. It makes your muscles strong so you can run really, really fast or push something hard. It also makes you breathe faster and makes your eyes super wide so you can see everything clearly. Another helper makes a "stay-strong juice" that helps you keep going for a little bit longer. All these juices are your body's way of giving you superpowers to be brave and safe when you're in a scary situation, helping you run away or fight!

title: Why do we tend to "like" negative news/information more than positive one?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little superhero watching out for you! If everything is happy and sunny, your brain just thinks, 'Yay, all good!' and doesn't need to do much. But if there's a loud 'BOOM!' or someone shouts 'WATCH OUT!', your superhero brain goes, 'WHOA! What's that?! Is it dangerous? Do I need to run away or help?' It pays super close attention to the not-so-good stuff because it wants to keep you safe and know if there's a problem it needs to tell you about. So, when we hear about something tricky or sad, our brains perk up and listen extra hard, just in case it's something important for us to know or learn from, even if it doesn't feel super happy. Good news is nice, but bad news often makes our superhero brain work harder to understand and protect us!

title: Voices usually sound tired early in the morning. What's the best way to "wake up" our voices quickly?
text: Imagine your voice is like a little puppy that's been sleeping all night long! When you first wake up, your puppy is still a bit sleepy and doesn't want to run and play super fast, right? Your voice is like that too. The tiny muscles in your throat, which make your voice, are still a bit sleepy and stiff from resting. To help your voice puppy wake up quickly, you can do a few things! First, give it a drink of water, just like you might need water after sleeping – it helps everything feel better. Then, you can make some quiet, gentle humming sounds, like a little sleepy bee, or a soft 'oooh' sound. This is like stretching your voice puppy's legs. You can also try yawning a big yawn, which helps open up your throat muscles. Don't try to shout right away! Start with soft talking, and soon your voice puppy will be wide awake and ready to play all day!

title: Why are animals with slightly different genetic traits considered separate species but humans with slightly different genetic traits are not?
text:
Okay, imagine you have different kinds of toy cars. A red car and a blue car are still both cars, right? They can race together and play the same games. But a toy car and a toy truck are different; they might look a little alike because they both have wheels, but they are clearly different kinds of toys.

Animals are a bit like that! When we say animals are different "species," it means they are so different that they can't have babies together that can then grow up and have their own babies. Like a dog and a cat are different species because they can't have babies together at all. Or a horse and a donkey can have a baby (called a mule), but that mule can't have its *own* babies, so the horse and donkey are still different species.

Now, with humans, even though some people have different hair colors, different eye colors, or their skin looks a little different, we can *all* still have babies together! And those babies grow up and can have their *own* babies too! Because we can all do that, it means we are all the *same* kind of human, the *same* species. We're all just different people in the big human family, like a red car and a blue car are both still cars!

title: Why do we routinely screen for some cancers (e.g. colon, breast) and not others (e.g. stomach, brain, etc.)?
text: Imagine your body is like a super special house, and sometimes tiny, naughty little "mess-makers" (that's what cancer is, like a tiny problem) can try to start growing inside

title: When does mutation mean that there is a new species?
text: Okay, imagine all the dogs in the world are friends and can have puppy babies together, right? That makes them one big dog family, or a "species"! Now, sometimes when a new puppy is made, there's a tiny, tiny change in its special instruction book, like a little typo. That's a "mutation." Most times, these little typos don't change much, maybe the puppy gets a slightly curlier tail. But if lots and lots of these tiny typos happen over a super, super, *super* long time, like millions of years, and all the new puppies keep getting more and more different typos, eventually they might change so much that they can't be friends and have puppy babies with the original dogs anymore! They've become so different that they're like a brand new kind of animal, a whole new "species" that can only have babies with other animals just like them, and not with the old ones.

title: Why is it safe to eat veggies/fruit grown in rain water/waste water - but not drink the water by itself?
text: Imagine water is like a big puddle outside. Sometimes that puddle has little invisible cooties or dirt in it that would make your tummy feel ouchy if you drank it straight. But plants are like super clever filters! When they drink the water, they only take the good, clean parts to help them grow big and strong, like how you only pick the yummy sprinkles off your cupcake. All the yucky cooties and dirt stay in the ground, far away from the fruit or veggie. So, when you eat a carrot or an apple, you're eating the super clean, yummy parts the plant made, not the dirty water it drank. That's why the fruit is safe and yummy for you!

title: Why does something having no face/minimal features make it cute?
text: Okay, imagine you see a toy or a drawing that doesn't have a big, clear face, maybe just a smooth round head or tiny little dots for eyes. Your brain, the smart part inside your head, gets to play a game of 'fill in the blanks'! It's like when you see a cloud and you imagine it's a bunny or a car. When there's no grown-up face, your brain often pretends it's a baby! And babies, whether they're human babies or little fluffy animal babies, have soft, round heads and don't have super strong, grown-up faces yet. They often look very simple and squishy. Because babies are super-duper cute and make us want to cuddle them and keep them safe, your brain thinks, 'Oh, this must be a cute baby thing!' So, when there's not much of a face, your brain makes it into something small and sweet that needs your hugs, and that's why it feels so cute!

title: How do so many different games have GOTY editions?
text: You know how you might get a sticker for being a good helper, and your friend gets a sticker for sharing, and another friend gets a sticker for drawing a nice picture? Lots of different grown-

title: How can vegetables and fruits grown hydroponically contain all the micro-nutrients we need in our diets?
text: Imagine plants are like little kids who need special food to grow big and strong. Usually, plants get their food, which is like tiny vitamins and minerals, from the dirt, like digging in a big yummy snack box! But sometimes, we grow plants without dirt, in a special way called hydroponics. It's like we give them a special drink of water instead. In that water, we carefully put *all* the tiny vitamins and minerals they need to be super healthy, just like we know exactly what snacks to put in your lunchbox so you grow big and strong! So, even without dirt, the plants still get all the important little bits to be full of good stuff for you to eat.

title: why do some people with depression lose their appetite and not eat much, while others eat more than usual?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little control center for your whole body, and sometimes when someone is feeling super sad inside (we call this depression), their brain gets a bit mixed up. For some people, their sad brain feels so busy and worried that it forgets to tell their tummy, "Hey, it's time to eat!" It's like when you're playing a really fun game and forget to drink your juice – your brain is just focused on the sadness. So their tummy just doesn't feel like eating much. But for other people, their sad brain tries to find something to make itself feel a tiny bit better, even if it's just for a little while. Eating yummy food can sometimes feel like a warm, cozy hug for their brain, so their brain asks for more and more of those yummy things to try and feel less sad. So it's like how some kids want to sleep when they're tired, and other kids get super hyper – everyone's brain is just a little different in how it shows it's feeling not-so-good.

title: Why can't humans break the N2 molecule but some microorganism can?
text: Imagine nitrogen is like two super strong LEGO bricks stuck together, but with super-duper glue! It's so strong, you and I can't pull them apart with just our hands or even with normal tools. Our bodies just aren't built to do that; we have other jobs to do! But some tiny, tiny bugs that live in the dirt, so small you can't even see them, have a special magic tool inside them. This tool is like a super strong LEGO-breaker machine that can *actually* pull those super-glued bricks apart! They do this because when they break the nitrogen LEGOs, they make special food that helps plants grow big and strong, which is super important for all the yummy fruits and veggies we eat!

title: Why is happening psychologically in a murder suicide when the victims are not even people the killer knows? Why would somebody who intends to take their own life want to kill others before doing so?
text: Imagine someone is feeling super, super sad and lost, like their favorite toy broke and they can't fix it, and it makes their brain feel very, very mixed up and broken too. They feel so much pain inside that they want it to stop forever. But sometimes, when their brain is feeling this broken and they're also very, very angry, they might think that everyone else is part of what made them so sad, even people they don't know. It's like when

title: How comes people who get concussion or memory loss can remember how to speak but not other things?
text: Imagine your brain is like a giant toy box, and all your memories are different toys inside. Speaking is like your very favorite teddy bear that you play with every single day, all day long! It's super special and you know exactly where it is, even if the toy box gets a little shaken up. Other memories, like what you ate for breakfast yesterday or what your friend told you, are like other toys that you don't play with quite as often, or maybe they got buried a little deeper in the box. When your brain gets a bump, like a concussion, it's like the toy box got a really big shake! Your favorite teddy bear (speaking) is so important and so often used that it usually stays right on top, easy to find. But some of the other toys (other memories) might get jumbled up or fall to the bottom, making them harder to find for a little while. So, speaking is like a super-strong, super-practiced memory that usually stays safe even when other things get mixed up!

title: Falconry Experts - What methods do you use to teach a bird of prey to hunt alongside humans?
text: It's kind of like making a new friend and teaching them a fun game! First, we spend lots of time with our super cool bird, being very gentle and giving it yummy snacks so it knows we're not scary and we have the best food. We make sure it's a little bit hungry, like when you're ready for lunch, because that makes it want to work for its treat! Then, we teach it to fly to us for a snack, first from a little bit away, then further and further, so it always knows to come back to its human friend. Next, we play a game where we swing a special toy that looks like a little mouse or bird on a string, and the bird chases and catches it, just like practice! Finally, when we go outside, the bird sees a real bunny or squirrel, and it remembers all its practice. We help by showing it where the little animal is hiding, and when it catches it, we give it a special piece of the food as a big "good job!" treat. So, it's all about being friends, having yummy snacks, and playing together to catch things!

title: Why is it easy to hold your pee in overnight but difficult during the day?
text: Imagine your body is like a little house! When you're sleeping at night, your whole house goes quiet and sleepy too. Your brain, the boss of your house, is sleepy and doesn't tell your pee balloon (your bladder) to squeeze as much, and the parts that make pee (your kidneys) slow down making it. It's like the pee factory workers are also sleepy and only make a tiny bit of pee. So your pee balloon just stretches out and holds it nice and quiet. But in the daytime, wow! Your house is wide awake and super busy! You're running and playing and drinking lots of water and juice, so your pee factories are making lots and lots of pee. And your brain, the boss, is wide awake and paying attention to everything, so it tells your pee balloon much faster that it's time to go!

title: What is pseudoprime numbers?
text: Okay, imagine we have special numbers called 'prime numbers'. They are super shy and only like to be divided by 1 and themselves, like the number 5 (you can't share 5 cookies perfectly with 2 friends, right?). Now, sometimes we have a little game or a test to try and find these shy prime numbers. Most of the time, the game works perfectly! But sometimes, *very* rarely, there's a tricky number that *fools* our game. It looks like a prime number when we play the game, like it's wearing a prime number costume. But if we really, really check, we find out it's actually a regular number that can be made by multiplying other numbers, like how 9 is just 3 times 3. So, a pseudoprime is a number that *looks* like a prime when you do a special test, but it's really just pretending and isn't a prime number at all!

title: What is happening to your body when you become more flexible?
text: Okay, imagine your muscles are like little pieces of Play-Doh inside your body. When you first try to stretch, they're a bit stiff and don't want to go very far, kind of like cold Play-Doh. But when you gently stretch them a little bit every day, two things happen! First, your muscles themselves start to get a tiny bit longer and softer, just like if you warm up and pull the Play-Doh. They learn to reach further without feeling so tight. Second, your brain, which is the super-smart boss of your whole body, learns that it's safe to let your muscles stretch more. It's like your brain says, "Okay, we can go a little further now!" So, your muscles get longer and happier, and your brain lets them move more, making you super bendy and able to touch your toes!

title: How is the observable universe 46.6 billion light years wide if the universe is only 13.7 billion years old? Should we only be able to see 13.7 billion light years away since that's all the light that could possibly reach us in that time?
text: Imagine the universe is like a giant, super-stretchy balloon that started blowing up a long, long, long time ago, about 13.7 billion years ago. When a

title: Why do apartment buildings use vertical blinds?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really big window, or a door that slides open, like in many apartments. Those vertical blinds are super good at covering those big spaces because they're long and swing open easily, letting in just the right amount of sunshine! Plus, for the grown-ups who own the building, they're usually not too expensive to buy a lot of them, and they're pretty strong so they don't break easily when people are moving in and out. If one little strip gets a boo-boo, it's super easy to just pop a new one in without getting a whole new blind, which saves money and makes everyone happy! It also makes all the windows look nice and neat from the outside, like they're all wearing the same uniform.

title: Before modern times, how were brothels able to function w/o women being constantly pregnant?
text: Imagine a special house where grown-ups would go to be close to other grown-ups for a short time, like giving special hugs or company for money. When grown-ups are very close, sometimes a tiny baby can start growing in a tummy. Back then, they didn't have the good medicines we have today to stop babies from starting. So, people tried different things: sometimes they tried to be careful about *when* they were close, hoping a baby wouldn't start then. Other times, they used special plant teas or things they thought would make a baby not start, but
