That's kind of what 'bureaucracy' is – it's like having all those grown-ups and their rules to help run very, very big things, like a big city or even a whole country! How does it work? Well, if you want a new swing on the giant playground, you can't just put it up. First, you might have to ask one grown-up, who then tells another grown-up, who then checks if there's enough space, and then they might ask you to fill out a special drawing (like a form) to show exactly where you want it. There are lots of steps and lots of different grown-ups, each with their own little job, like one who just checks if the drawing is neat, and another who just checks if it's

title: What is the advantage of having "custom silicon" on your hardware products (like that popular smartphone does)?
text: Imagine you have a super cool toy car! Most toy cars use a brain that you can buy from a big store that sells brains for all kinds of toys. It works okay for lots of cars. But some very special toy cars, like that popular smartphone, decide to *build their very own brain*! Why is that super cool? Because when they build their own brain, they can make it *just right* for their toy car, like making shoes exactly for *your* feet – they fit perfectly and help you run super fast! This means their toy car can do special tricks that other toy cars can't, like driving super fast without getting tired, or taking really clear pictures, or understanding your voice better, because its brain was built to do *those specific things* perfectly. Plus, it's really good at saving energy, so your toy car can play much, much longer without needing a nap (charging). So, having a custom brain means your toy is extra special, super-fast, and really good at its job because its brain was made just for *it*!

title: Does Moore's law protect us from the singularity? I understand both a little, but not enough to know the answer.
text: Imagine your computer is like a special toy car. Moore's Law is like a magic rule that says every couple of years, someone makes your toy car twice as fast and twice as good, without making it bigger or more expensive! So, our computers keep getting faster and smarter at doing things. Now, the Singularity is like when a super-duper smart robot makes an even smarter robot, and that one makes an even smarter one, faster and faster, until robots are so incredibly smart they change everything in the world in ways we can't even guess! So, does the magic rule about faster toy cars stop the super-duper smart robots from happening? Not really! Actually, the magic rule (Moore's Law) is what helps the computers get fast enough to *become* those super-duper smart robots that might lead to the Singularity. It's like saying, "Does having a really fast bicycle stop you from going too fast?" No, the really fast bicycle *helps* you go too fast! So, Moore's Law doesn't protect us; it's actually one of the things that people think might help the Singularity happen sooner.

title: Why Is It Called a "Blow" Job When The Chick Is Actually Sucking?
text: Sometimes words are a little tricky and can mean different things! Like when you "blow a kiss," you're not really blowing air, you're just doing a special kind of kiss.

title: Why do some people float on water easily when others a similar size can't?
text: Okay, imagine water is like a friendly big hand trying to push you up when you get in! Now, some people are like big, puffy balloons inside – they have more air in their lungs (like when you take a deep breath!) or more squishy, light parts (which is called fat). These parts make them take up more space without being super heavy, so the water's hand can push them up really easily, and they float like a cork! Other people are more like a small, heavy rock inside – they have lots of strong muscles and bones, which are super good for running and playing, but they don't take up as much space for how heavy they are. So, the water's hand has to work much harder to push them up, and they might sink a little more. It's all about how big and puffy you are inside compared to how heavy you are!

title: What makes chips/cookies/cereal go stale?
text: Okay, imagine your yummy chips, cookies, and cereal are like little happy houses! When you leave them out, the air around us, which has super tiny, invisible water drops floating in it (like the smallest rain ever!), starts to visit. For crunchy things like chips and cereal, those tiny water drops jump onto them and make them soft and bendy instead of crunchy. It's like how a dry paper towel gets soft if it gets a little wet. For soft things like cookies, it's a little different! Cookies are soft because they have some water inside them. When you leave them out, that water starts to fly away into the air, making the cookies hard and crumbly. So, the air and the tiny water in it change how your snacks feel and taste when they sit out for too long!

title: How do spicy foods like wasabi kill bacteria?
text: Imagine there are tiny, tiny invisible critters called bacteria, some good and some naughty, floating around. Wasabi has a special "ouchie" juice inside it, like a super strong, tingly feeling for your tongue. When that "ouchie" juice touches those tiny bacteria critters, it's like a big, loud, uncomfortable surprise for them! It makes their little bodies feel so broken and messed up that they can't live anymore. So, the wasabi helps get rid of some of those tiny, naughty critters because it's just too much for them to handle.

title: how do telescopic sight or scope in sniper rifle work? The scope is few inches higher than the bullet line so how are the bullet hit the mark in the scope?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super cool toy car, and you want to see a tiny bug way, way across the room. A scope is like a magic spyglass for your toy car's gun! It makes the bug look super close and big so you can aim really well. Now, your question is super smart! The scope sits on top of the gun, like a tall hat. But when the bullet comes out of the gun, it's lower than the scope. It's like when you throw a ball – it doesn't go perfectly straight forever, right? It goes up a little then starts to fall down to the ground. Bullets do that too! The grown-ups who make these scopes are very clever. Even though the scope is higher, they make it look *down* just a tiny bit. It's like the scope knows the bullet is going to fly out, go up a little bit, and then start to fall down. So, when you look through the scope and put the little dot right on your target, the scope is actually telling the

title: Why is it that nail polish stays liquid in the bottle, but dries in minutes after it’s applied to the nail?
text: Imagine nail polish is like a special juice with two parts: a colorful, sticky part and a "flying away" part. When the nail polish is in its bottle, it's like the bottle has a super tight lid, so the "flying away" part can't get out! It stays trapped inside, keeping the colorful part all wet and squishy. But when you paint it on your nail, it's like you let the "flying away" part out into the open air! The air quickly grabs it and carries it away, up into the sky, making it disappear. What's left behind is just the colorful, sticky part, which gets hard and dry because its "flying away" friend is gone! That's why we put the lid back on the bottle really fast, so the "flying away" part doesn't escape inside the bottle!

text:
Okay, imagine you have a favorite toy, like a soft, brown teddy bear!

The 'sign' is like the whole idea of your teddy bear – how you know what it is.

title: How do doctors detect Down Syndrome in pregnancy?
text: Imagine your baby is like a special puzzle growing inside mommy's tummy, and all the pieces need to fit just right. Sometimes, a baby gets an extra puzzle piece, and that's called

title: What do people find uniquely rewarding about listening to live music that they don't get from recorded music? What is cognitively or emotionally different about the experience?
text: Imagine your favorite song! When you hear it on a speaker or your tablet, it's super fun, right? But going to a live show is like getting to be *inside* the song! Instead of just hearing a picture of the music, you're right there. You can feel the music wiggle in your tummy and make your whole body tingle because it's so loud and real. You get to watch the musicians make the sounds with their hands and voices right in front of you, like magic! And everyone around you, all the other grown-ups and kids, are smiling and dancing and feeling happy together, like a big, shared secret party. It feels extra special because it's happening just for you, right now, and it's a unique show that you get to share with everyone there, making it feel super exciting and warm inside.

title: How does the police choose what cars to use as patrol cars?
text: Imagine you're picking a toy car to play with. You wouldn't pick a tiny, slow car to race, right? You'd pick a strong, fast one! Police cars are a bit like that. The police want cars that are big and strong so they can carry all their special lights, radios, and sometimes even a helper or a person who did something naughty to take to the station. They also need cars that can go super fast if they need to catch someone, and cars that are tough so they don't break easily. And, just like your mommy and daddy look for good deals when they buy things, the police also try to pick cars that aren't too, too expensive to buy and fix, because they have to be smart with their money. So, they look for cars that are strong, fast, roomy, and don't cost a whole lot!

title: If the eustachian tube is conected to the pharynx why cant we breath through our ears?
text: Okay, imagine your ear has a super tiny, secret little straw that goes to the back of your throat. This little straw is called the Eustachian tube, and it's mostly there to let just a tiny puff of air in and out of your ear, like a little air vent, so your ear drum can wiggle happily and you can hear all your favorite sounds! But when you breathe, your body needs *lots* and *lots

title: If font 'points' are a fixed size (1/72"), why does one font at 10 pt (e.g. Calibri) look appreciably smaller than another (e.g. Verdana) at the same point size?
text: Imagine you have a special invisible box for every letter you want to write. When you say "10 points," it means that invisible box is always the exact same size, like a little square on

title: When you're about to fall or spill something what is that feeling in your belly?
text: You know that funny little tickle or fluttery feeling deep down in your tummy when you almost trip or almost drop your juice? That's your super-smart body's way of saying, 'WHOA! Let's be extra ready!' Imagine your body is like a little superhero, and when it sees something might fall or you might wobble, it quickly sends a tiny alarm message to your tummy. This alarm just makes your tummy feel a bit squiggly because your body is getting ready super fast to help you catch yourself or fix whatever almost happened. It's just your body being a really good helper, making sure you stay safe and sound!

title: Why can’t/don’t ATMs give you money in denominations smaller than $20 these days?
text: Imagine an ATM is like a special toy box that gives you money! This toy box has different sections inside, like little shelves, where it keeps different kinds of money. Now, the grown-ups who put money in the box want to make sure it has the *most popular* kind of money so lots of people can get what they need. Most grown-ups usually want bigger chunks of money when they go to the ATM, like a big, yummy cookie instead of lots of tiny crumbs. So, they fill the shelves with $20 bills because those are like the medium-sized, super popular cookies. If they put lots and lots of $1 or $5 bills in there, the shelves would fill up super fast with not much money in total, and then there wouldn't be space for the bigger $20 bills that most people want! It's like making sure the toy box has the most fun toys that everyone wants to play with, so they pick the $20s to fill it up. If you need smaller money, like for a gumball machine, you can usually get that from a grown-up at a store or inside the bank building where they have lots of different kinds of money.

title: What is the difference between cosmology, astrophysics and astronomy?
text: Imagine the sky is a giant playground! Astronomy is like being a curious kid who points up and says, 'Look! There's a big, shiny ball (a star!)' or 'Wow, the moon looks like a banana tonight!' Astronomers are the people who watch the sky, find all the cool things like stars, planets, and galaxies, and make maps of where everything is. Now, astrophysics is like asking 'WHY?' about those things. It's like saying, 'Why is that star so hot?' or 'How does the moon stay up there?' Astrophysicists are super-smart detectives who use science to figure out how stars make light, how planets move, and what they're made of. And then there's cosmology, which is the biggest question of all! It's like asking, 'Where did this whole giant playground (the universe) come from in the first place? How did it start, and how is it growing and changing?' Cosmologists try to understand the whole big story of *everything* in

title: If spiders' webs are the strongest fiber in the world. Why are not used as a material to build or create artifacts?
text: You're so right, spider webs are super-duper strong, like tiny superhero ropes! That's amazing! But imagine you wanted to build a whole house out of yummy candy. A spider web is like one tiny, tiny piece of candy. Spiders are very small, and they only make a little bit of their special string at a time, just enough for their own little web. To build something big, like a house or even a shirt, we would need *mountains* and *mountains* of that super-strong string, way more than all the spiders in the world could ever make! Plus, it's super sticky and hard to collect all those tiny threads without breaking them. We don't know how to tell spiders to make a giant ball of string for us, and we haven't learned how to make it ourselves in big factories

title: How are blood cells formed inside the bone marrow?
text: Imagine your bones are like a super special, cozy house, and deep inside them is a squishy, soft part called bone marrow. It's like a tiny, secret factory! In this factory, there are super special "baby" cells, like tiny little magic seeds. These seeds are amazing because they know how to grow up into all the different kinds of blood cells you need. Some seeds grow up to be red circles that carry air all around your body so you can run and play. Others become white protectors that fight off bad germs and keep you from getting sick. And some become little helpers that make a sticky patch when you get a boo-boo, so you don't leak all your blood. The factory just keeps making new ones all the time, so you always have fresh, strong blood to keep you healthy and happy!

title: Asvab scores and what they mean. How do they affect desirability for recruitment?
text:
Imagine you want to join a big grown-up team, like a special club that helps people! Before you can pick what job you want to do in the club, like flying a plane or fixing a big truck, the club leader wants to know what you're good at.

The ASVAB is like a big puzzle game they give you. You answer questions about words, numbers, and how things work. Your ASVAB "scores" are like the points you get in that puzzle game. More points mean you're really good at understanding those things!

If you get lots and lots of points, it's like the club leader sees you're super smart or really good with your hands, and they say, "Wow! We really want *you*! You can pick almost any cool job you want, because we think you'll be amazing at it!" But if you get fewer points, it doesn't mean you can't join the team! It just means the club leader might say, "Okay, you're still great, but maybe the pilot job isn't the best fit right now. How about this other super important job, like helping keep all our special gear ready, or driving our cool trucks?" So, higher scores mean the team wants you for more kinds of special jobs, because they think you'll be extra good at them!

title: How can we get money out of politics when all the people in charge of the rules are swayed by money?
text: Imagine you and your friends want to play a game, and one friend brings the teacher a really big, yummy cookie. The teacher might then listen more to the friend with the cookie when deciding what game to play, even if all the other kids want to play something else! That's kind of like how money works in grown-up rules. Some grown-ups give the rule-makers lots of 'cookies' (money), so the rule-makers listen

title: How do Hawaiian fire dancers grab/eat fire?
text: It looks super cool, but fire dancers don't actually eat the *hot* fire! Imagine fire is like a little hungry monster that needs air to stay alive, just like you need to breathe. When a fire dancer looks like they're eating the fire, they use a special trick. They put the fire near or quickly into their mouth, and then they close their mouth really, really fast. This takes away all the air the fire monster needs, so it goes "poof!" and goes to sleep because it can't breathe anymore! It's kind of like blowing out a candle really fast. For grabbing, they move their hands super quickly, sometimes even wetting their skin a little, so the fire doesn't have enough time to make them hot. They practice a lot to be very careful and safe with their fire monster tricks!

title: If plants can convert Carbon Dioxide into Oxygen, why can't we create machines to do the same thing to control the amount of CO2 in the environment?
text: Plants are like super-duper clever green friends that have been practicing eating yucky air (carbon dioxide) and burping out fresh air (oxygen) for a super long, long time! They have special tiny parts inside them that know exactly how to do this trick with just sunshine and water. Making a machine do the same thing is like trying to build a toy car that can fly to the moon – it's super hard! Our machines would need lots and lots of electricity (like making them eat tons of yummy food all the time!) and they would have to be really, really, really big to eat as much yucky air as all the trees and grass in the whole world. It's much easier and smarter for us to let our amazing plant friends do their job and help them grow more, because they're already the best at it!

title: Where do you find the number for pay phones? Like in movies a boss would call the exact phone you’re walking by on the street.
text: Yes! Payphones do have their own secret numbers, just like your mommy or daddy's phone. But it's super tricky to find them because they're not written down anywhere easy, and most people only use payphones to call *out*, not to get calls *in*. So, in movies, when a boss calls the exact payphone someone is walking by, that's usually just movie magic! Maybe the boss already knew the person would be at *that specific* payphone, or maybe they had to try calling a bunch of payphones until they got lucky. In real life, it would be very hard to guess which one to call!

title: why does ice crack when it's put in drinks??
text: Imagine your ice cube is super, super cold, like it just woke up from a long nap in the freezer! When you put it in your drink, your drink is much warmer, like a cozy blanket. The outside of the ice cube feels the warm drink first and wants to stretch out and get bigger very, very quickly. But the inside of the ice cube is still super cold and wants to stay small. When the outside tries to get big fast and the inside is still trying to stay small, it pulls and pushes on itself so hard that it makes little cracks and "pop!" sounds, like the ice cube is sighing and stretching to get comfortable in its warm new home.

title: Why does everyone say to drink lots of fluid when you have a cold?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a little superhero, and when you have a cold, some tiny, yucky germs come to try and make you feel sleepy and stuffy! Drinking lots of water, juice, or even soup is like giving your superhero body a super special power-up drink! It helps make the runny stuff in your nose thinner so it can come out easier, like when you add water to thick mud to make it flow. It also keeps your throat wet and happy so it doesn't feel scratchy, and it gives your body extra strength to fight off those yucky germs and get back to playing super fast!

title: What led to the creation of the Knights Templar and what was their MO?
text: Imagine a super, super long time ago, many grown-ups wanted to go on a very special trip to a far-away land where amazing stories happened. But the road was super dangerous! Nasty robbers and bad guys would hide and try to hurt people and steal their things. So, a group of very brave, strong knights – like real-life superheroes with shiny armor and big swords – said, "We will protect these travelers!" They promised to keep everyone safe on their long journey. They were called the Knights Templar because they lived near a really old, special building called the Temple. Their main job was to be like super bodyguards, riding their horses, fighting off the bad guys, and making sure the people going on the special trip arrived safely. Because they were so good at protecting people, others gave them money and land, which helped them build strong castles and even become like a special bank, keeping people's money safe too!

title: Why do our imaginations die when we grow up?
text: Your imagination doesn't really die, it just changes how it plays! When you're little, everything is super new, and you don't know how a lot of things work, so your brain uses its imagination like a super fun toy to make up all sorts of exciting stories and pretend games to help you understand the world. It's like your brain is always asking "What if?" and making up answers! But as you get bigger, you learn more and more real things about how the world works, like how clouds are made or why birds fly. So, your brain doesn't need to make up as much to fill in the gaps. Your imagination is still there, helping big people think of new ideas for inventions, write amazing books, draw cool pictures, or figure out how to solve problems, but it's just not always playing dress-up or pretending the floor is lava anymore. It's like your favorite toy that you still love, but you play with it in a different way as you grow.

title: If houseflies only live for a few days, how do they survive winter in colder areas?
text: That's a super smart question! You're right, the grown-up flies you see buzzing around only live for a little while, and they don't like the cold at all. When winter comes and it gets chilly, those grown-up flies usually die. But before they go, the mommy flies lay tiny little eggs in warm, secret places, like deep in the ground, inside cracks in houses, or in piles of dirt and leaves. These eggs turn into baby flies that look like tiny worms, and then they make a little sleeping bag for themselves called a pupa. They hide in their sleeping bags and take a very, very long nap all winter long! It's like they're pressing a pause button. When the sun comes back and the weather gets warm again in spring, they wake up from their long nap, wiggle out of their sleeping bags, and turn into new grown-up flies ready to fly around again.

title: Why do Catholics have confession, but not Protestants? Could a Protestant confess to a Catholic priest?
text:
Okay, imagine you did something a little bit wrong, like maybe you took a cookie without asking, and you feel a little bit yucky inside.

For **Catholics**, when they

title: Why people can spell a word for years then all of a sudden go "Did I spell that word right?" even though it's correct?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper toy box, and all the words you know are like your favorite toys, each with its special spot. Most of the time, when you want to spell a word, your brain just grabs that toy from its spot super fast, without even thinking! It knows exactly where it is. But sometimes, even when you're really good at something, your brain gets a tiny bit tired or maybe it's thinking about what snack you'll have later, or a fun game. And just for a second, when it goes to grab that word-toy, it might go 'Hmm, is this *really* where this toy goes?' It's like your brain is just double-checking itself, even though the toy is in the right place all along! It's not that you forgot, it's just a little brain hiccup, like when you blink and wonder if you just saw a butterfly, even if you know what a butterfly looks like. Your brain just gets a little funny for a moment, then it remembers, 'Oh yeah, that's right!'

title: How do certain medications evoke a physical change in the body such as reducing inflammation?
text: Sometimes, when you fall down and get a scrape, or when you get a little sick, a part of your body gets all puffy, red, and warm. It feels a bit ouchy, like your body is saying, 'Hey, something's not right here!' That's called inflammation. Now, medicine is like a very special helper that you swallow or that a grown-up puts on your skin. Imagine your body is like a big house, and inside your house, there are lots of tiny little workers doing jobs. When your body is inflamed, some of those workers are making too much noise and making that spot feel extra ouchy and puffy. The medicine helper goes on a mission! It travels right to where the boo-boo is and finds those noisy workers. Then, the medicine helper gently tells them, 'Shhh! Calm down! You don't need to make so much noise or make things so puffy anymore.' It's like the medicine gives those workers a little reminder to stop making things so sore and red. So, the workers listen to the medicine helper, they calm down, and soon the puffiness goes away, the redness goes down, and that ouchy spot starts to feel much, much better!

title: Does having a random alpha+numeric+symbol password reduce exposure in compromised email data breaches?
text: Imagine your email is like your special room, and your password is the secret key to open the door. Sometimes, bad guys try to steal a big list of everyone's room names (emails) and some of their keys from a big book. If your key is super long and jumbled up with big letters, little letters, numbers, and funny squiggles (like "Gato!7$Rz"), it's like having a super strong, super weird key. Even if the bad guys get your room name from the big book, they won't be able to guess your super weird key! They'll try the easy keys first, like "dog" or "123", because those are simple. But your super weird key is too hard for them to figure out, so they'll probably give up on trying to open *your* room. So, yes, having a super weird, jumbled-up key makes it much, much harder for the bad guys to get into *your* room, even if they know your room's name. It keeps your toys and secrets safe inside!

title: Why do some people shake their legs when sitting down? What are the benefits?
text: You know how sometimes you have so much energy inside you, like when you're super excited, and you just want to wiggle and move, but you have to sit still? Well, sometimes grown

title: How does satellite communications constantly work since it's not always lined up with your location and could be on the other side of the earth?
text: Imagine you want to talk to your friend across a big playground, but sometimes they run behind the slide, and you can't see them. Satellites are like super-duper walkie-talkies high up in the sky, helping us talk to people far away! The secret is we don't just have *one* satellite.

title: Why is the average height so much greater in certain parts of the world? Why aren't people in general about the same height?
text: Imagine your body is like a little seed, and it wants to grow into a big plant! To grow really big and strong, a seed needs lots of good sunshine, yummy water, and healthy soil

title: Why do different types of alcohol cause different drunk feelings/behaviors?
text:
Imagine all the grown-up sleepy drinks have the same special "sleepy magic" inside them, like a tiny little sleepy toy. It's always the same kind of sleepy toy that makes your brain feel a little wobbly and tired. But, these sleepy drinks come in different kinds of cups, right?

Some sleepy drinks have lots of yummy sugar or fizzy bubbles mixed with the sleepy magic. When you drink those, the sleepy magic gets to your brain *super fast* because the sugar and bubbles help it rush! When it rushes really fast, your brain gets surprised and might feel extra silly, excited, or super wobbly all at once.

Other sleepy drinks don't have as much sugar or bubbles, or they have more water. So, the

title: Why is Yellowcake uranium a sulfur yellow color when normal uranium is lead colored?
text: Imagine uranium is like a special, shiny grey block, just like a metal toy car. That's what pure uranium looks like when it's all by itself. But grown-ups need to clean it up and change it a little bit before they can use it for power. When they do that, it turns into a special powder. It's like when you bake a cake: the flour is white, but when you add eggs and mix it all up, the batter turns yellow! So, yellowcake is still uranium inside, but it's been changed

title: Oftentimes my grandma will tell me eating certain specific combinations of fruits and other foods will enhance sourness or sweetness. Has my grandmother developed a supreme mastery of flavors over the years or is there a trick to this?
text: Your grandma is super smart and knows a cool trick foods do! It's not magic, but it's like when you have a quiet toy and a loud toy. If you play the quiet toy by itself, it's just quiet. But if you play the loud toy right after, the quiet toy might seem even *quieter* when you go back to it! Foods are like that with tastes. Some foods have a little bit of sourness or sweetness, and when you eat them together, they can make the other tastes pop out even more, like making a sweet apple taste even *sweeter* because of something else you ate. It's how all the different flavors play together on your tongue to make new yummy feelings, and your grandma has definitely learned how to make them have the best party!

title: Why are tuning forks...fork shaped?
text: Imagine you have two special arms, like the letter 'U' or a tiny slingshot. When you gently tap one of those arms, they both start wiggling back and forth *together*, like two friends on a seesaw pushing each other. This special way of wiggling, where both arms move at the same time in the same way, makes a super clear and steady sound that lasts a long, long time! If it was just one arm, it would wiggle all over the place and stop singing its sound very quickly. So, the two arms help the sound stay perfect and sing clearly, and the bottom part is like a handle to hold it while it makes its special music.

title: Why do no carb and all fat diets work? Shouldn't they become fat from eating fat?
text:
Okay, imagine your body is like a super smart little car! Usually, your car loves to run on super quick and easy fuel, like gasoline (those are carbs, like bread and sweets). But if you don't give it much gasoline, your smart car says, "Hmm, no gasoline? No problem! I can learn to run on this special, slower-burning fuel instead, which is fat!" So, when you eat very few carbs and lots of fat, your body starts to burn all that fat for energy instead of carbs, and it gets really good at it, even burning the fat stored on your tummy!

And no, eating fat doesn't automatically make you chubby! Think of it like this: if you put fuel in your car (eat food), but then you drive your car a lot (run, play, think), you use up all that fuel. It's only if you put *too much* fuel in your car and don't drive it enough that the extra fuel just sits there. When your body is using fat as its main fuel, it's like it's really good at driving and using up all the fat fuel you give it, so it doesn't just store it all away.

title: Could I get a cold in a sterile environment?
text: No! Imagine getting a cold is like catching tiny, invisible tickle-monsters that make your nose runny and make you cough. These tickle-monsters are called germs, and they have to jump from someone else or something else onto you to make you sick. A sterile place is like a super-duper clean room, so clean that there are no tickle-monsters (germs) hiding anywhere! If there are no cold tickle-monsters in the room, then they can't jump onto you, and you can't catch a cold there. So, no, you couldn't get a cold in a super clean, sterile place!

title: How do Doctors keep up to date with new information/techniques?
text: Imagine doctors are like superheroes who always want to be the best at helping people feel better! Even after they finish their 'doctor school,' they never stop learning new things, kind of like how you keep learning new words or how to draw better. They read special grown-up books and magazines, but instead of stories about dinosaurs, these books tell them about new medicines or new ways to fix a boo-boo inside your body. They also talk to their other doctor friends a lot! They share secrets and new ideas, just like you might tell your friend about a cool new game. Sometimes, doctors go to special 'doctor parties' or 'grown-up school' where other super-smart doctors show them new tricks and machines that can help people – it's like a big show-and-tell for doctors! And when they learn something new, they practice it very carefully, just like you practice riding your bike or drawing a perfect circle, so they always know the very best and newest ways to keep everyone healthy and happy.

title: How do the food industry determine the expiration date on their products?
text: Imagine food companies have special food doctors, like scientists, who want to make sure your yummy snacks and food stay super good and safe for your tummy! They take a bunch of the food, like your favorite cereal or milk, and watch it very, very carefully over many days and weeks. They put some in warm places and some in cold places, just like your kitchen. They look at it to see if it still looks nice, they smell it to make sure it still smells fresh, and they even use tiny special tools to check if any super tiny, invisible bad guys (germs!) are starting to grow inside that could make your tummy feel yucky. Once they see the food start to change and not be as perfect anymore, they pick a date *before* that happens. That date is like a special promise from the food company saying, 'This food will be super yummy and safe for you to eat until this day!' It's their best guess to make sure your food is always just right for you.

title: how can you determine if a potentially valuable signature is authentic?
text: Imagine you have a drawing made by your best friend. You know it's theirs because you've seen them draw so many times, right? You know how they hold the crayon and how their lines look. Well, figuring out if a special signature is real is kind of like that, but for grown-ups who are super good at looking at tiny details! They are like signature detectives! First, they find lots and lots of *real* signatures from the person who supposedly signed it. Like looking at many pictures of your friend's drawings. Then, they put the new signature right next to all the real ones. They look super, super close at everything: how fast the pen moved (was it smooth or shaky?), how hard they pushed (was it light or dark in places?), and all the little bumps and loops and curves. Does it look like the person just wrote it naturally, or does it look like someone tried very, very hard to copy it slowly? They also look at the paper and the ink to make sure they are old enough to be from when the person was alive. If everything matches up perfectly, like all the puzzle pieces fit, then they can say it's a real, authentic signature!

title: What causes drunk munchies?
text: When grown-ups drink their special sleepy juice (alcohol), it makes their brain a little bit confused, like when you're super tired and things feel fuzzy. Usually, your brain is really good at telling you when you're hungry and when you're full. But when it's confused, it sometimes forgets and thinks, 'Whoa, I need lots and lots of energy right now!' So it tells your tummy, 'Let's eat all the yummy snacks!' And because everything feels a little different, those salty chips or sweet cookies taste extra, extra super good and make your brain happy, even if you just ate dinner. It's like your brain just wants to have fun and eat all the snacks it can find!

title: Why does "night air" smell/seem different to day air?
text: Imagine the sun is like a giant warm lamp in the sky! When the sun is out during the day, it makes everything warm and bright. But when the sun goes to sleep and it gets dark, the air gets cooler, like when you open the fridge door. This cooler air can make smells travel a little bit differently, and sometimes you can smell flowers that only open up at night, or maybe even animals that come out to play when it's dark. Also, because it's quieter at night when most people are sleeping, you might hear different sounds too, like crickets singing their songs. So, the air feels and smells different because the big warm sun isn't there, and different things are happening all around us!

title: Why can't we replace limbs like we replace organs?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool robot! When we put in a new heart or a new kidney, it's a bit like putting in a new simple battery or a new little water pump. We just need to connect the big tubes (like hoses for water) so they can work. But your arms and legs are super-duper special! They have millions and millions of tiny, tiny magic strings called 'nerves' that go all the way from your brain to your fingers and toes. These strings help you wiggle your fingers, feel a tickle, or run really fast! When we try to put a new arm or leg on, we can connect the big tubes for blood, but it's super, super hard to connect all those millions of tiny, tiny magic strings perfectly so your brain can talk to the new arm and make it move and feel things. It's like trying to

title: What is that old people smell?
text: You know how everything has its own smell? Like cookies smell yummy and flowers smell pretty. Well, when people get really, really old, like your grandma or grandpa, their bodies start to make a tiny, special smell that's just for old people. It's not a dirty smell or a bad smell, it's just a natural smell that happens when your body gets very, very old, kind of like how a very old book smells different from a brand new one. It's just one of the ways our bodies change as we grow and get older, and it's totally normal, like how hair turns grey!

title: What happens when you quit the military during training?
text: Imagine you're going to a special new school where everyone wears the same clothes and learns how to be super strong helpers. You pack your bag and go, but after a few days or weeks, you realize it's just not the right school for you – maybe it's too loud, or you miss your bed, or you just don't like the games they play. If you haven't promised for a super long time yet, or if you're still in the very beginning "learning the rules" part, you can usually tell the grown-ups that you want to go home. It's not like you get in big trouble or have to stay there forever! They'll usually say "okay," and help you pack your bags again so you can go back to your family. It might take a little bit of time to sort everything out, like waiting for the bus, but then you get to go home and try something else instead.

title: Why do you always get sick over night and not throughout the day?
text: You know how when you're playing all day, running around and having fun, you don't even notice a little scratch on your knee? But then when you sit down quietly, suddenly you see it and it feels more ouchy! Being sick is a bit like that. During the day, you're busy playing and learning, so your body is distracted and you don't feel the yucky germs as much. But when it's nighttime and you're lying down quietly in your bed, there's nothing else to think about, so your body notices all the little owies and sniffles way more. Also, when you lie flat, the snot and yucky stuff in your nose and throat can't drain out as easily as when you're standing up, so it just sits there and makes you feel more stuffy and coughy. It's not that the sickness only comes at night, it's just that you feel it more when everything is quiet and still!

title: Why does cold water help burns?
text: Imagine your skin got a super hot kiss from something, and it's still really, really hot and a bit angry, like a stove that's still warm even after you turn it off. That heat keeps trying to make your skin more ouchy! When you put cold water on it, it's like giving your skin a nice, cool drink or a gentle, cool hug. The cold water quickly takes all that extra hotness away, so your skin stops getting more hurt and starts to feel less ouchy and angry. It's like blowing on a hot marshmallow to make it cool down faster so it doesn't burn your mouth!

title: How is gravity both the "strongest and weakest force in the universe"?
text: Imagine you have a tiny toy car. You can easily pick it up with your hand, right? Your little hand is stronger than the whole giant Earth trying to pull that car down with its gravity! Or, a tiny fridge magnet can pick up a paperclip, even though the whole giant Earth is trying to pull it down. See? For small things, when you're really close, gravity

title: How does a throwing knife or tomahawk always manage to land blade first and not the handle?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special toy that you throw, and it spins in the air, like a pinwheel! When big people throw a throwing knife or a little axe called a tomahawk, they make it spin on purpose. Now, the trick is that the sharp part of the knife or axe is usually a little bit heavier than the handle part. Because it's heavier, it really wants to be the first part to hit something, like a target! So, the person throwing it practices a lot to know exactly how much to make it spin. They throw it so it spins *just the right amount* of times in the air. That way, when it gets to the target, the heavy, sharp part is perfectly pointing forward, ready to stick in! It's like the heavy, sharp part is a smart little nose that always wants to lead the way and boop the target first. If they don't spin it just right, it might hit with its bottom (the handle) instead!

title: This is gross but would a human egg taste like a chicken egg if it was scaled up in size?
text: Okay, that's a super funny and interesting question! Imagine a chicken egg is like a whole lunchbox packed with yummy food for a baby chick to grow inside – that's the yellow yolk and the clear white part that we cook and eat. Now, a human egg is super, super tiny, like a tiny dot you can barely see! It doesn't have all that extra lunchbox food inside, because when a human baby grows, it gets all its food and snacks directly from its mommy's body, not from a big lunchbox inside the egg. So, even if you could make a human egg super big, like a chicken egg, it wouldn't have that big yellow yolk or the thick white part that makes a chicken egg taste like a chicken egg. It would mostly just be the tiny, tiny part where a baby starts, and that part doesn't have much taste at all. So, no, it wouldn't taste like a chicken egg, because it's built differently for a different kind of baby!

title: Why is it so much easier to focus our eyes on something far away than it is to focus on something right next to us?
text: Imagine your eyes have tiny, squishy lenses inside them, like clear jelly. When you look at something far, far away, those jelly lenses are nice and relaxed, just like when you're taking a nap. They don't have to do any work! But when you want to look at something super close, like your finger right in front of your nose, those jelly lenses have to squeeze really hard, like when you make a fist. Tiny muscles pull on them to change their shape so you can see clearly. And just like when you hold a heavy toy for a long time, your hand gets tired, those tiny eye muscles get tired faster when they have to squeeze for things close by. So, looking far away is easy because your eyes are just chilling out, but looking close up means your eyes have to do lots of little exercises!

title: From a business POV, why would McDonalds only give out 20 packets of Szechuan sauce and at limited locations only?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super, super special toy, like a magical action figure, but there are only a tiny few of them in the whole wide world! Everyone would want one, right? And they'd talk about it all the time, "Wow, did you hear about that magical action figure?!" McDonald's does something similar with the Szechuan sauce. They make it super rare, like that special toy. This makes everyone get really, really excited and talk about it a lot. "OMG, Szechuan sauce is back!" People will get so excited they'll rush to McDonald's just to try and get some. Even if they don't get the sauce, they might buy a Happy Meal or some fries while they're there. And because everyone is talking about it, lots more people think about McDonald's, and that makes more people want to visit their restaurant, even if it's just to see what all the fuss is about. It's like a big game where they make everyone super curious and excited about their food!

title: why does the higher number of Frames per second equal to slow motion. Like why is 60fps a “normal speed” but 240fps considered Slow Motion. Why is 120fps not slower motion than 60?
text: Imagine you're watching a super cool flipbook! Each page is like a "frame" or a tiny picture. "Frames per second" (FPS) is just how many tiny pictures you flip

title: What are all those pop ups about binary trading options etc? Are they viruses/phishing scams?
text: Imagine you're looking at a picture book, and suddenly a super bright, noisy advertisement pops up on the page, like someone yelling "Hey! Look at me!" Those pop-ups are like that. They're trying to get grown-ups to play a really fast and tricky game with their money, where you either win a little bit or lose a lot, super quickly. Most of the time, these are like a sneaky person trying to trick grown-ups into giving them their candy by promising them a whole toy store, but then they don't give them anything back. They're not usually like a sick bug that makes your computer feel bad, but they are definitely tricky tricks (we call them scams!) trying to get grown-ups' money in an unfair way. It's always best to just tell your grown-up to close them right away, like closing a door on someone you don't want to talk to!

title: Why when there are 2 people shooting a machine gun, does one person have to hold up the belt that the machine gun feeds from?
text: Imagine your toy train needs to eat a super long chain of LEGO bricks to go zoom! If that long chain of LEGO bricks is just laying on the ground, it might get tangled up, or get dirty with mud or sand. It could also be so heavy that it pulls down on your toy train, making it hard for the train to eat the bricks and go fast. So, a friend helps by holding up that long chain of LEGO bricks. They keep it nice and straight and clean, and make sure it doesn't pull on your train. This way, your toy train can eat all the bricks super fast and easy, without getting a tummy ache and stopping!

title: What's the big hurdle in getting people to Mars? Haven't the major obstacles to doing so already been solved?
text: Imagine you want to go visit a friend who lives super, super far away, like across the whole ocean! We know how to build a boat to get there, but the *really* big

title: How do physicists know that they don't know where 95% of the universe is?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing with a toy car. You can see the car, right? That's like the stars and planets we can see in space. But then, you see

title: Why do we get the urge to move around when we have to pee?
text: Your pee-pee place inside is like a little balloon that holds your pee. When it starts to get really full, it feels a bit squishy and stretchy, like when you try to hold too many toys in a small bag. When it's super full and telling you it's time to go, your body sometimes makes you want to wiggle or bounce around! It's like your body is trying to gently make a little more space in there, or maybe it's just trying to distract you from the squishy feeling for a tiny bit longer, or even just saying, "Hey! This is getting uncomfortable, let's go to the potty right now!" It's just your body's way of telling you loudly, "Hurry up and find a toilet!"

title: Why is it when giving OTC medication to children, the directions specify dosage by weight, but medication for adults does not?
text: Imagine your friend Lily is super tiny, and your friend Ben is super big, even though you're all the same age! When you need a little bit of juice, Ben needs more than Lily, right? Medicine is a bit like that. Kids come in all sorts of different sizes, so the grown-ups need to give them just the right amount of medicine for *their* body, not too much and not too little. The best way to know exactly how much medicine your body needs is by how much you weigh, because it helps the grown-ups give you the perfect amount so you feel better safely. Grown-ups, though, are usually more similar in size when it comes to medicine, so their medicine bottles often say the same amount for everyone, like one cookie for all the grown-ups, because that amount is usually just right and safe for most of them.

title: What are those marks on your skin when you take a watch or a pair of socks off?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super soft, squishy pillow or a piece of playdough! When you wear your watch or your socks, they give your skin a gentle hug, pushing down on it a little bit. Just like if you push your finger into a soft pillow, it makes a little dent, right? Your watch or socks do the same thing! They press on your skin, and because your skin is so soft and squishy, it makes a little dent in the shape of the watch or the sock. It's like your skin remembers for a tiny moment where the watch or sock was pushing. But don't worry, your skin is super clever and bouncy, so after a little while, it just smooths itself out again, like magic! It's totally normal and just means your watch and socks were giving your skin a little squeeze.

title: how did clocks and time pieces work before batteries/electricity?
text: Imagine your toy car that you pull back, and then it zooms forward! Or maybe it has a little key you turn, and then it rolls all by itself. Old clocks were kind of like that, but much slower and for telling time! Instead of batteries, they had a special 'engine' inside. Sometimes this engine was a heavy block of metal, called a 'weight,' that really wanted to fall down, down, down. Other times it was a squiggly metal 'spring,' like the one in your slinky toy, that you wound up super tight. When you 'wound' the clock, you either pulled that heavy weight up high or made the spring super squished. Then, very, very slowly, the weight would fall, or the spring would uncoil. As they did that, they turned little tiny wheels, called 'gears,' inside the clock, just like gears in your Lego machines! These gears were connected to the clock's hands, making them move around the clock face, telling everyone what time it was. So, no batteries needed, just a push from a falling weight or an unwinding spring – you just had to remember to give it a little 'wind' every day or so!

title: How does faking confidence, "fake it til you make it" actually help?
text: Okay, imagine you want to build a super tall block tower, but you feel a little bit like, "Uh oh, I don't know if I can do it!" But instead of looking sad or giving up, you stand up straight, put a big smile on your face, and say, "I'm gonna build the best tower EVER!" When you *act* like you're super good and brave, two things happen: First, other grown-ups and kids around you see you looking happy and strong. They might think, "Wow, that kid is good at building!" and they might even cheer you on or give you a cool block, which makes it easier. Second, your own brain gets a little trick! When you *pretend* to be brave and strong, your brain starts to think, "Hey, maybe I *am* brave and strong!" And because you'

title: Why is our current world map, the Mercator Map, not to scale? It represents the US as gigantic is reference to South America and Africa. In reality both of continents dwarf the US in size.
text: Imagine the Earth is like a big, round ball, like your toy globe! A map is like trying to draw that whole ball on a flat piece of paper. That's super hard to do without squishing or stretching things! Think about trying to flatten an orange peel perfectly – you can't do it without ripping or making some parts bigger than they are, right? The Mercator map is one way we try to flatten our Earth ball, but it has to stretch some parts a lot, especially the countries near the very top and bottom of the map. So, on that map, countries like the US and Canada look super-duper big, even though they're not as big as they seem. Places like Africa and South America are actually much, much bigger than the US in real life, even if the map doesn't always make them look that way! It's kind of like looking at yourself in a funhouse mirror – some parts look big, some look small, but it's not really how you look.

title: What is happening when a website goes down because of too many people try trying to access it?
text: Imagine you have your favorite toy car, and you want to play with it. That's like a website! Now, imagine *everyone* from your whole school, and all their brothers and sisters, suddenly wanted to play with *your exact same toy car* at the *exact same time*. There would be too many hands trying to grab it, too many people wanting to push it around, and your little toy car would get totally overwhelmed! It couldn't move, it might even break, and no one would really get to play with it properly. That's what happens to a website when too many people try to visit it all at once. The website's computer (like your toy car) gets too many requests from everyone, gets super busy, and just can't show you the pictures or words anymore because it's too overwhelmed. It just stops working until some people leave, or until it can get fixed to handle more friends!

title: How are we able to manufacture super small objects?
text: Imagine you want to build a house, but it's so tiny, tinier than an ant! Your fingers are way too big to even touch the little pieces. So, we use special helpers, like super tiny robot arms that can pick up the itsy-bitsy blocks and put them in just the right spot. Other times, it's like we have a magic light beam, almost like a super thin pencil made of light. This light can draw the tiny shapes or even make new tiny pieces appear, layer by layer, building up the super small object. It's like having super precise, super tiny tools that can do the work our big hands can

title: Why do you sharpen things like knives, planes or chisels, and yet you peen a Scythe?
text: Okay, imagine you have a pencil. When you want to draw a super thin, sharp line, you sharpen it to a very pointy tip, right? That's like sharpening a knife or a chisel – you make the very end super thin and pointy so it can push things apart and cut them really well, like slicing paper or wood easily. But a scythe is different! It cuts lots of soft, bendy grass, which is like tiny hairs. Instead of making it super pointy like a needle that might break off, you tap its edge gently with a little hammer. This squishes the metal at the very, very edge, making it super thin but also a tiny bit wider, kind of like flattening play-doh with your hand. This makes the edge strong and bendy, so it can sweep through all that wiggly grass without breaking its tiny tip off, but it's still super thin to cut!

title: If an American astronaut smoked weed on the international space station, could he be prosecuted? Would it make a difference in which state he left earth from?
text: Okay, imagine the International Space Station is like a super important clubhouse high up in the sky where grown-ups from different countries work together. Just like you can't bring a toy into class that's not allowed, there are very strict rules about what you can and can't do up there, and smoking weed is a big no-no. Even though the astronaut is super far away, America is still like their grown-up. So, if an American astronaut broke that rule, America

title: What is the marketing strategy of continuing to send unwanted emails and making it extremely hard to unsubscribe from them?
text: Imagine a shop that sells yummy cookies. They want everyone to remember their cookies, so they send you little pictures of them in your email box, like sending a drawing to your house. Even if you don't want more pictures, they keep sending them because they hope that *one day* you'll see a picture of a cookie that looks so super yummy, you'll ask your grown-up to buy it! Making it super tricky to stop getting the pictures is like them trying to say, "Please don't forget us! We're still here, and maybe next time we'll show you a cookie you *really* want!" They just want to stay in your mind, like a little reminder, because even if you don't open them, just seeing their name makes you remember their yummy cookies, and maybe you'll buy one later.

title: Why do we walk into a room and then forget what we went in there for?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper busy helper inside your head, always thinking about lots of things! When you want to get something, like your favorite toy, your brain holds that idea in its "front pocket" so it doesn't forget. But then, when you walk into a new room, it's like starting a new adventure! Your brain sees all the new things in the room – maybe a window, or a different toy, or mom's shoes – and it gets a little bit distracted by all the exciting new stuff. Sometimes, when it gets distracted, it accidentally puts the idea from its "front pocket" into a "back pocket" for just a second. And *poof*! You forget for a tiny moment what you came in for. But usually, if you go back to where you were before, or just think for a moment, your brain finds that idea in its "back pocket" again!

title: Why does glass appear to shatter quicker than the projectiles that are hitting them are moving in these clips?
text: Imagine you have a big, flat, yummy cookie (that's like the glass!). When you tap it with your finger (that's the bullet), the cookie breaks super, super fast, right? Faster than you can even blink your eyes! The bullet is going really fast, like a zooming race car. But the *breaking* part of the glass is even faster! It's like the glass just goes "poof!" and breaks into many pieces almost at the exact same moment the bullet touches it, spreading out super quick. Our eyes are a little bit slow, so in real life, it just looks like it's broken already. But in those videos, they use a special super-duper fast camera that takes thousands of pictures in just one second! Then, when they play it back slowly, we can finally see all the tiny steps of the glass breaking, which usually happens too fast for our eyes to catch. So it's not breaking before the bullet, it's just breaking *so incredibly quickly* that the special camera lets us finally see how fast it truly is!

title: How did we find out our brain was the thinking organ?
text: Long, long ago, people weren't sure where our thinking happened! Some thought it was in their heart, like when you feel happy or sad. But then, smart doctors started watching very carefully. They saw that when someone got a big boo-boo on their head, sometimes they would forget things, or talk a little funny, or couldn't move their arm or leg right. But if they got a boo-boo on their arm or leg, they could still think perfectly fine! It was like the head was the special control room. Doctors also saw that lots of tiny wires, called nerves, went from the brain all over our body, telling our hands to wave and our legs to run. So, they figured out that the squishy brain inside our head is like the super-duper boss that tells our whole body what to do and where all our smart ideas and feelings come from!

title: Why do police tell you to recite the alphabet backwards as a test for drunk driving?
text: Imagine your brain is like the boss of your whole body, telling your hands what to do and your mouth what to say. When grown-ups drink special grown-up juice (alcohol), it makes their brain a little bit sleepy and fuzzy, like when you're super tired and can't think clearly. Knowing the alphabet is something you know super well, like singing your ABCs! But doing it *backwards* is a little trickier, even for a grown-up with a wide-awake brain. When the police ask someone to say the alphabet backward, they want to see if their brain is still working super clearly and sharply, or if it's too sleepy and fuzzy from the grown-up juice to do something tricky like that. If it's too hard, it means their brain isn't awake enough to drive a car safely and remember all the rules of the road.

title: How I'm productive at the library as opposed to being lazy and drowsy at home?
text: Imagine your home is like your super cozy bedroom, full of all your favorite toys and your soft bed. When you're there, your brain sees all those fun things and thinks, 'Yay, time to play or take a nap!' It's hard to do your serious thinking work when your brain just wants to have fun. But the library is like a special quiet schoolroom, just for grown-ups and big kids doing their important work. There are no toys, no TV, and no comfy beds to make your brain want to play or sleep. Everyone there is quiet and focused, so your brain gets a signal, 'Oh! This is a place for serious work,' and it helps you put on your 'thinking cap' and get lots of things done!

title: Why is collecting rainwater illegal in certain countries & in certain US states?
text: Imagine rain is like a big, shared drink for everyone, not just you! Some places have rules about collecting rainwater because of a few reasons. One big reason is that the water that falls

title: What causes us to like/dislike certain tastes?
text: Imagine your tongue has tiny little helpers called taste buds, and they are like little spies that send messages to your brain! When you eat something sweet, like a yummy strawberry, your brain gets a message saying 'YAY! This is good for energy to run and play!' because a long, long time ago, sweet things often meant good food that gave us energy. But if you taste something super bitter or sour that might not be good for you, your brain gets a message saying 'WHOA! Stop! This might make you feel yucky!' because your body is trying to keep you safe like a superhero. Sometimes, if you eat something and get a tummy ache, your brain remembers and says 'Nope, not that one again!' Even what your grown-ups cook for you a lot can become a favorite because you get used to it! And guess what? Everyone's little taste helpers are a tiny bit different, so what one person thinks is super yummy, another might not like as much, just like how some kids love broccoli and some don't!

title: Why do most suburban areas with a front garden, use it to display plants and flowers, rather than planting fruits and vegetables for consumption? I live in Australia - is this the case in other countries? Why?
text:
Imagine your house is like a person getting dressed up! Flowers are like pretty, colourful necklaces or sparkly hats that make your house look super nice and welcoming for everyone who walks by. Grown-ups often want their house to look neat and tidy and happy from the front, and flowers do that job perfectly with their bright colours and sweet smells.

Growing yummy food like strawberries or carrots is a bit like a big, busy job! You have to water them a lot, make sure tiny bugs don't eat them, and pick them at just the right time. Sometimes, food plants can get a bit messy, or they might not look pretty all the time, especially when they're growing or when the fruit is picked. Plus, hungry birds or possums might try to sneak a snack from

title: Usage of muscles and broken bones recover stronger, why does muscle, ligament and tissue damage recover weaker?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big LEGO castle! When you use your muscles a lot, or if they get tiny little boo-boos from playing hard, your body is super smart! It fixes them by adding even more strong LEGO bricks, making those muscles bigger and tougher, like building a tower even taller and stronger than before. When a bone breaks, it's like a big crack in one of your castle walls. Your body sends lots of special builder cells to fix it, and sometimes they make the wall even thicker right where the crack was, so it's super strong there, like putting extra strong glue on a broken toy to make sure it doesn't break again. But ligaments, which are like the stretchy rubber bands that hold your castle walls together (like your knee or ankle), and other soft tissues are different. When they get hurt, your body tries to fix them with a quick patch, like using sticky tape on a broken rubber band. It holds it together, but the tape isn't as stretchy or as strong as the original rubber band, so that spot might not be quite as good as new.

title: How are Nuclear Missiles Safely Decommissioned?
text: Imagine a really, really big toy rocket that has a super special, super powerful firework inside it – not the fun kind, but one that's too big and dangerous to ever use. When

title: What's the subconscious drive that gets you motivated to do something your conscious brain doesn't want to do?
text: Imagine you have a super smart little helper friend living deep inside your head, who knows all the important things your body needs even when you're busy playing and not thinking about them! Sometimes, *you* (the part of you that thinks and talks) might really want to keep playing with your toys because it's so much fun. But your little helper friend might notice that your tummy is rumbling because you haven't eaten, or that your eyes are getting super droopy because you need to sleep, or that you're about to touch something hot and need to pull away fast! Even if *you* don't want to stop playing, or you want to keep your hand there, your little helper sends a tiny push or a feeling, like a gentle nudge, to make you feel hungry so you go get a snack, or feel super tired so you lie down for a nap, or makes your hand jump back super quick. It does this because it knows what's good for your body, like keeping you strong, healthy, and safe, even when the "you" who wants to play doesn't quite want to yet!

title: How can colleges see what you post on social media if you are private?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special toy box, and you put a lock on it so only *your* friends can see your toys. But what if one of your friends takes a picture of your favorite toy with their phone and shows it to *their* mommy? Now mommy knows about your toy, even though she's not one of your special friends and didn't open your toy box! Social media is kind of like that. Even if you put a 'private' lock on your pictures and words, your friends can still see them. And sometimes, your friends might show those pictures to *their* friends, or even take a screenshot (like a picture of your picture!) and share it. Or maybe you forgot to put the lock on for a little while, and someone saw it then! So, even with a lock, things can sometimes still get out, like when a secret travels from one friend to another until lots of people know.

title: what exactly is an algorithm and how is the algorithm for detecting fake news on Facebook failing?
text: Imagine an algorithm is like a super-duper special recipe or a step-by-step instruction list for a computer to do a job, just like how you follow steps to build a LEGO tower or make a peanut butter sandwich! For example, an algorithm tells the computer exactly how to add two numbers, or how to show you a picture. Now, Facebook has one of these robot helpers (an algorithm) that tries to find stories that aren't true, like when someone says the moon is made of cheese. This robot helper looks for clues, like if a story sounds super wild or comes from a website that often tells made-up things. But the robot helper isn't perfect, because sometimes the people who make fake stories are very clever and try to make them look *very* real, like a toy dog that looks so much like a real dog you might get confused! So, the robot helper gets tricked, or it just can't keep up because there are so many stories on Facebook, like trying to find one specific red crayon in a giant box of a million crayons. This means some not-true stories still get through, and lots of people see them before the robot or a human can say, "Oops, that's not real!"

title: How does coding actually work?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper clever robot friend, but this robot only understands very, very simple instructions, like 'walk forward,' or 'pick up the blue block.' It can't guess what you want; you have to tell it *exactly* what to do, step-by-step. Coding is like writing a super special list of instructions for your robot friend. You write things like: "Go to the toy box," "Pick up the red car," "Drive the red car to the mat," "Stop." When you're done writing your list (that's your 'code'), you give it to your robot (that's the computer!). The robot then reads your list, one instruction at a time, and does *exactly* what you told it to do. So, coding is just telling computers what to do, step-by-step, so they can do cool things like show your favorite cartoons or let you play games!

title: Why does resetting my phone often fix bad signal strength?
text: Imagine your phone is like a little friend trying to talk to a big radio tower to get the internet, kind of like how you talk to your friends. Sometimes, your phone friend gets a little bit confused or sleepy, and it forgets which tower is the closest or best one to talk to, or maybe it gets stuck trying to talk to a tower that's too far away. When you reset your phone, it's like your phone takes a quick little nap and then wakes up super fresh! When it wakes up, it opens its eyes and says, "Okay, where's the *best* tower for me to talk to right now?" It then looks for the strongest, clearest signal again, and this helps it talk much better to the tower, making your signal strong and happy again. It's like giving it a fresh start to find its way!

title: Why do we eat snails (escargot), but not slugs?
text: Imagine snails have a little hard house on their back, like a turtle! That house helps keep them a bit cleaner and safer. When grown-ups cook snails in a special way, they can taste quite yummy, like a special treat. But slugs don't have a house; they're always out in the open, and they're usually much, much slimier and taste really, really yucky and bitter if you tried to eat them – like a super gross vegetable that no one wants! So, we eat the ones that taste nice and have a little house, and leave the yucky, homeless ones alone.

title: Is there a reason we ejaculate in spurts rather than a continuous stream like peeing?
text: You know how when you pee, it's like opening a faucet and the water just flows out smoothly? That's because the door for your pee just opens wide. But when a grown-up ejaculates, it's like squeezing a tube of ketchup or toothpaste. You give it a little squeeze, and *poof*, a tiny bit comes out! Then you squeeze again, *poof*, another tiny bit! That's because special muscles around the tube are giving it little pushes, like a pump. They squeeze, relax, squeeze, relax, to help push the tiny "swimmers" out really fast, like a little race car speeding out of a garage!

title: How does oily skin cause acne on face?
text: Imagine your skin has tiny, tiny little holes, like mini tunnels, all over it. Your skin also makes a special, slippery oil to keep it soft and happy. But sometimes, your skin makes *too much* oil! When there's too much oil, it can mix with super tiny bits of old skin that flake off (you can't even see them!) and get stuck, like a little jam, in those tiny tunnels. Then, super, super tiny invisible 'germs' that live on your skin love to eat that stuck oil. When they eat and grow inside the blocked tunnel, it makes the tunnel get red and puffy, like a little bump. That's a pimple! So, too much oil helps make the tunnels get stuck and causes those bumps.

title: Why is the Human neck so fragile and even poorly constructed, when it harbors such a valuable payload?
text: Imagine your head is like a super special, super-smart pumpkin, and your neck is like the stem that holds it up! That stem needs to be strong enough to hold the pumpkin, but also super bendy so you can look all around – up, down, left, right – to see your toys, your friends, and what's for snack. If your neck was super thick and stiff like a tree trunk, you wouldn't be able to wiggle your head to look for hidden candies! The most important part, your brain, is tucked safely inside your hard head, like a helmet, so your head is the really strong box. Your neck's job isn't to be a super-duper strong fortress, but more like a flexible highway for all the important messages to go from your brain down to your body, and it lets your head turn so you can see everything. It's strong enough for most of the fun things we do, and the bendy part helps us explore the world!

title: When my gums are sore in a particular area, why does it feel sort of... good... to scrape it or continue to injure it?
text: Okay, imagine your gum has a little boo-boo, like a tiny owie that feels a bit grumpy all the time. It's a soft, dull ache. Now, when you touch it or scrape it, it's like you're giving that owie a quick, sharp poke! For a super quick second, your brain gets really busy feeling that new, sharper poke, and it almost forgets about the grumpy, dull ache for a moment. It's like if you have a little itch, and you scratch it really hard – that strong feeling of scratching makes your brain pay attention to *that* instead of the little itchiness. It feels a bit like relief because it's a *different* feeling that takes over, but it's not really helping your gum boo-boo get better. It's just tricking your brain for a tiny bit!

title: What does it mean for the body to ‘fight’ a virus?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool castle, and you are the king or queen of it! Sometimes, tiny, tiny little invisible bullies called viruses try to sneak into your castle. They want to make trouble and make you feel yucky. But guess what? Your castle has its very own team of brave knights and superheroes inside, called your immune system! When these brave knights see the sneaky viruses, they say, "Oh no, you don't!" They start chasing the viruses, trying to catch them and kick them right out of your castle. Sometimes, when your knights are fighting super hard, you might feel a little tired or warm, or get a cough. That's just because they're working super, super hard to protect you! But usually, your body's brave knights are super strong, and they win the fight! They get rid of all the meanie viruses, and then you feel all better and strong again. Yay for your body's superheroes!

title: What exactly are "frames" in video games, and how do you quantify them?
text: Imagine you have a super cool flipbook, like the ones where you draw little stick figures and then flip the pages really fast to make them dance! Each one of those little drawings on a page is like a "frame" in a video game. Your game is just showing you a whole bunch of these pictures, one after another, super, super fast! When the game shows you lots and lots of these pictures every single second, it looks really smooth, like a real movie. If it shows you fewer pictures, it might look a bit jumpy, like when you flip your book slowly. How we count them is by saying "frames per second," or "FPS" for short. It just tells us how many of those little pictures the game can draw for you in just one tiny blink of an eye! So, if a game is 60 FPS, it means it's drawing 60 different pictures for you every single second, which makes everything look super duper smooth and fun to play!

title: What is the link between the neurotransmitter GABA and anxiety disorders?
text: Imagine your brain is like a busy playground with lots of kids running around super fast and making lots of noise. Sometimes, those kids get really excited or scared, and they just can't stop running and shouting – that's kind of like when you feel anxious, where your brain feels too worried or scared and can't calm down. Now, GABA is like a special, gentle grown-up on that playground. Their job is to tell the kids, "Okay everyone, let's slow down, take a deep breath, and maybe play quietly for a bit." GABA helps your brain put on the brakes and feel peaceful. So, if you don't have enough of that gentle grown-up GABA, or if they're not very good at getting the kids to listen, then the playground (your brain) stays too noisy and too fast all the time, making those worried and scared feelings stick around a lot more, which is what happens with anxiety.

title: What are the differences between a highway, freeway, expressway, tollway, interchange, and interstate?
text: Okay, imagine you're driving your toy car! A **highway** is just a big, long road that connects different towns, and sometimes you have to stop at red lights on

title: what is Ngnix ? when and why should you use it for your app? And how would you integrate it with the cloud-hosting services such as heroku?
text: Imagine your app is like a super cool toy store, and people (your users) want to come in and play with your toys. Nginx (say 'engine-x') is like a super

title: Why do we not become dehydrated when we sleep?
text: When you're awake, you run and play and talk a lot, right? Your body uses up lots of water doing all those fun things, kind of like a car uses gas when it's driving. But when you're sleeping, your body is like a car parked quietly in the garage. It's not running around or playing big games, so it doesn't need to use nearly as much water! Your body still uses a tiny, tiny bit to keep everything working softly inside, like a little nightlight. But because you're not moving much and you usually drink some water before bed, you have plenty to last until you wake up and can drink more in the morning. So, you don't get super thirsty or need more water until playtime starts again!

title: what is the difference between the reasons we get thirsty when we eat something too sweet and something too salty?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big house with tiny little water balloons all over the place! When you eat something super salty, the salt is like a tiny little magnet that pulls water *out* of those balloons. So your balloons feel empty, and your body says, 'Uh oh, I need more water to fill these back up!' and makes you thirsty. But when you eat something super sweet, your body needs to clean up all that extra sugar and send it away when you go potty.
