It just so happens that this ant juice smells a little bit like some grown-up cleaning sprays or bug sprays, like Raid, because those sprays also have strong smells. So, it's not actually Raid, it's just the ant's own special 'ouchie' smell!

title: What happens to the chewing gum people spit out everywhere?
text: Okay, imagine your yummy chewing gum, once you're done chewing it, if you don't put it in the trash can like a good kid, it just sits there! It can stick to the sidewalk, or under a table, or even on a wall. At first, it's soft and sticky, but then other people walk on it, and it gets flat and squished. Dirt and dust stick to it, making it look all yucky and brown or black. Over time, it gets really, really hard, like a tiny little rock that's stuck forever. It doesn't just disappear like magic! It stays there for a super long time, making the ground look messy until someone, usually a grown-up, has to work really hard to scrape it off with special tools, which is no fun at all. That's why it's always best to wrap your used gum in a tissue and toss it in the bin!

title: Why do people not get electrocuted when touching a charger?
text: Imagine electricity is like water! The water coming from the big pipe in the wall is super strong, like a giant firehose, and if you touch that, it can give you a very big ouchie – that's like getting electrocuted! But your charger is like a special little toy that takes all that super strong water and makes it into a tiny, gentle trickle, like from a small drinking straw. When you touch the charger, you're only touching that tiny, gentle trickle of electricity, which is just enough to make your phone happy and charge it up, but not enough to ever hurt you. It's like a friendly little tickle, not a big scary push!

title: Why do "download speeds" and actual update/install speed differ drastically?
text:
Imagine your computer is like a super busy LEGO builder, and a new game or update is like a giant box of LEGOs you ordered!

When you see the "download speed," that's just how super fast the delivery truck brings the big, sealed box of LEGOs to your doorstep. It can zoom really, really quickly! But once the box is there, your LEGO builder (that's your computer!) still has a lot, *lot* of work to do inside. It has to carefully open the box, take out all the tiny little pieces, sort them by color, find the right instructions, and then slowly and carefully click all the pieces together to build that awesome castle or spaceship. Sometimes it even needs to move your old LEGO creations around to make enough space for the new one! All that opening, sorting, and building takes extra time, even after the fast delivery. That's why it feels slower than just getting the box.

title: Does the universe have a center? Can you go out in any direction and return back at Earth?
text: Okay, imagine you have a yummy chocolate chip cookie, and the chocolate chips are like all the stars and planets in the universe. When you bake the cookie, it gets bigger, and all the chocolate chips move farther away from each other. No single chocolate chip is the "middle" that everything moves away from, right? They all just get farther apart from each other. That's kind of how the universe is; it's getting bigger everywhere, so there isn't one special center. Now, imagine you're a tiny ant walking on a giant, super-duper big ball, like a huge apple. If you walk and walk and walk in a straight line, you'll eventually walk all the way around the apple and come back to where you started! Some smart grown-ups think the universe might be a bit like that giant apple, but even bigger than you can ever, ever imagine. So, if you could fly in a spaceship for a super, super, super long time, always in a straight line, maybe, just maybe, you would eventually come back to Earth! But it would take longer

title: Who controls how much money there is in the world?
text: Imagine money is like special golden tickets! There isn't just one person who controls all of them. First, there are very important grown-ups, like the **government** and a super special

title: Why do humans have wisdom teeth? Do any other species have wisdom teeth that would benefit them to have them removed?
text: Imagine your mouth is like a little house for your teeth! A super, super long time ago, people ate really tough food, like crunchy roots and raw meat, because they didn't have yummy soft foods or blenders like we do now. Their mouths were bigger back then, and they needed extra strong teeth at the very back to help them chew all that hard stuff. These extra back teeth are what we call wisdom teeth! Now our food is much softer, and our mouths are a bit smaller, so sometimes these wisdom teeth try to grow where there isn't enough room, and that's when they can be a bit cheeky and cause trouble. Other animals, like some monkeys and apes who are a bit like us, also have teeth that grow in at the back of their mouth when they get older, just like our wisdom teeth. But usually, their mouths are big enough, or their teeth grow in a way that doesn't cause problems. So, they don't usually need a special animal dentist to take them out

title: What are the references being used to describe higher dimensions in Maths and Physics?
text: Imagine you have a super special balloon. You can make it go left or right, up or down, and forward or backward. Those are like the three main ways (we call them dimensions!) we

title: Is light directly affected by gravitation, like objects with mass, or is it indirectly affected through the bent space?
text: Okay, imagine space is like a big, super-stretchy trampoline. When you put a heavy bowling ball (that's like a big star or planet) on the trampoline, it makes the trampoline dip down, right? Now, if you roll a little toy car with wheels (that's like things that have weight) on the trampoline, it rolls right into the dip because the bowling ball is pulling it. But light is super-duper fast and doesn't have any weight, so the bowling ball doesn't pull it directly like it pulls your toy car. Instead, light is like a tiny ant walking on the trampoline. When the ant walks near the bowling ball, it just follows the dip and goes down into the curve that the bowling ball made in the trampoline. So, light doesn't get pulled *by* the star, but it follows the *curvy road* that the star made in space!

title: how is more wealth created?
text: Imagine you have some dirt, and there are no yummy carrots yet. If you put a tiny seed in the dirt, give it some water and sunshine, and wait, soon you'll have a big, crunchy carrot! You just made more 'wealth' because now there's a delicious carrot where there wasn't one before, and it's something good to eat. Or think about a big pile of wood. If someone uses tools and their clever ideas to turn that wood into a cool new toy car or a comfy chair, they just made more 'wealth'! They took something simple (wood) and made it into something much more useful and wanted. So, more wealth is created when people make new things that other

title: Why does there seem to be more forest fires in the State of California every year than in other States?
text: Imagine California is like a big backyard that gets super hot and sunny for a long, long time, making all the grass and trees really, really dry and crunchy, like potato chips! When things are that dry, even a tiny spark, like from a campfire or a hot car, can easily start a little flame. And sometimes, a strong wind comes along, like when you blow really hard, and it helps that little flame grow super fast and run all over the crunchy trees. Because California gets so hot and dry often, and has so many trees and people, it just has more chances for those crunchy trees to

title: If humans have domesticated animals like wolves, why haven't we done the same for other large predators like bears?
text:
Okay, imagine puppies! A super long time ago, some wild doggies, kind of like wolves, were a little bit friendly and liked to be near people because we had yummy food. We picked the nicest, friendliest ones, and those friendly ones had friendly babies. Over many, many, many years, like how old your grandpa's grandpa's grandpa was, we kept picking the friendly ones, and they learned to live with us, help us hunt, and guard our homes. They liked being part of our 'pack' and listening to us.

Now, think about a big

title: Why do some people become really prone to "motion sickness" when travelling on a boat, ship or plane, while others seem they haven't had those problems even in their younger years?
text: Your brain is like a super smart boss that gets messages from all over your body! Your eyes tell your brain what you see, like the seats inside a car or plane. But deep inside your ears, there are special sensors that tell your brain if you're moving, wobbling, or spinning. When you're on a boat or plane, sometimes your eyes see everything *inside* staying still, but your ears *feel* the boat rocking and moving a lot! Your brain gets two different messages: "We are still!" and "No, we are moving!" This makes your brain super confused, like when

title: Why have newspaper comics gotten so abysmal these days?
text: Imagine you have an old toy, like a teddy bear that's been in your house for a very, very long time. It's still there, and some grown-ups like it because it reminds them of when they were little, but maybe it's not as exciting or new as your shiny new action figures or robots, right? Newspaper comics are a bit like that. Many of them are super old, even older than your parents! The people who draw them are often old too, and what they think is funny might not be the same as what you think is funny today. Newspapers keep these old comics because grown-ups are used to seeing them, kind of like how you always have the same breakfast cereal.

title: You lose energy in cold weather because heat leaves your body, but why do you not gain energy in hot weather?
text: Imagine your body is like a warm, cozy house that always wants to stay just right, not too cold and not too hot. When it's super cold outside, the warmth (that's your energy!) from inside your house tries to sneak out to the cold air, like steam leaving a hot cup. Your body does the same thing, trying to keep warm, which uses up a lot of your energy to make more heat. But when it's super hot outside, your house doesn't get *more* warm just because it's hot outside. Instead, your house works super hard to *push away* all that extra heat from

title: Why do almost all world maps have North America on the left and Asia on the right?
text: Imagine our big round Earth is like a giant bouncy ball! When grown-ups want to make a flat picture of it, like a map you hang on the wall, they have to decide where to "cut" the ball open to lay it flat. A very long time ago, many smart map-makers lived in a place called Europe. So, when they drew their maps, they often put *their* home, Europe, right in the middle, because that made the most sense to them, just like you'd draw your own house in the middle of a picture of your street! If Europe is in the middle, then North America is usually on the left side and Asia is usually on the right side, because that's just where they are on the big bouncy ball compared to Europe. It's just one very popular way people decided to draw our world, and lots of maps copied that idea!

title: if someone was bleeding out why couldn’t they have a constant flow of new IVs to keep them “stabilized “?
text: Imagine your body is like a special house, and your blood is like tiny delivery trucks that drive all around, bringing important food (like oxygen) and building blocks to every room to keep it strong and working. When you get a boo-boo and bleed, it's like some of your delivery trucks are driving out of the house! Uh oh! An IV is like giving your house a big drink of water. It's good because it helps fill up the roads where the trucks used to be, and keeps the house from getting too dry. But here's the tricky part: the water from the IV isn't the same as your special delivery trucks (blood). The water can't carry the important food (oxygen) to all the rooms. If you keep pouring in only water, the few delivery trucks you have left get really spread out and can't do their job very well, because there's just too much water on the roads. So, even though we give IVs to help a little bit and keep the roads wet, it's not like getting new delivery trucks. To really fix the problem when too many trucks are driving out, you need more actual delivery trucks (real blood) that can carry all the important food around, not just more water.

title: How come we can sometimes "draw a blank" when trying to remember something, even when the answer is "on the tip of our tongue?"
text: Imagine your brain is like a super big closet filled with all your toys and books, which are like your memories! When you try to remember something, it's like you're looking for a special toy. Sometimes you know exactly which toy you're looking for, and you know it's *right there* in the closet, you can even almost feel it in your hands, but it's hiding behind a pile of other toys or maybe a big box is blocking the way. Your brain knows the toy exists and where it should be, but the little path to grab it is just a bit stuck or messy right at that moment. It's like your brain is saying, "I know that toy! Just a second while I move these other things out of the way!" And then, sometimes later, when you're not even trying so hard, poof! The path clears, and your brain hands you the toy, and you remember it!

title: How are those who use card skimmers and other means of fraud not immediately traced and prosecuted?
text: Imagine bad guys are playing a very sneaky game of hide-and-seek! When they put a fake thing on a machine to steal your grown-up's money numbers, or use a computer far, far away, they are trying very hard to hide their tracks so no one knows it was them. It's like they leave very tiny, hard-to-see footprints, or they wear a mask so cameras can't see their face. The police, who are like super-smart detectives, have to look for lots and lots of tiny clues – like finding where the fake thing came from, or following the money numbers to see where they went, which can be to many different places all over the world! It takes a long, long time to find all the clues and put them together like a big puzzle before they can find the bad guys and make them stop. It's not like magic where they know right away!

title: KA, pKA and pH. How do they all relate to each other and what does each mean?
text:
Okay, imagine you have a special toy that tells you how sour something is!

**pH** is like that toy's number. If the number is small (like 1 or 2

title: What is the difference between Red Ocean Strategy and Blue Ocean Strategy?
text:
Imagine you and your friends want to play with toys!

**Red Ocean Strategy** is like when everyone is trying to play with the exact same few toys in the middle of the living room. Everyone is pushing and trying to grab the best toy, maybe even bumping into each other a little. It's really crowded, and sometimes the toys get broken because everyone wants them. It's hard to have fun because you're all fighting for the same thing!

**Blue Ocean Strategy** is like someone saying, "Hey, instead of fighting for these old toys, let's go outside and build a giant fort, or maybe find some brand new toys no one has ever played with before!" You go to a new, empty place where no one else is, and you get to invent new games and play exactly how you want, without anyone else trying to take your things. It's a peaceful, happy place where you can make something totally new and special!

title: Why do toddlers love to hand you things?
text: Imagine you have a super cool toy and you want to show it to your friend! Toddlers do that because they want to share their fun things with you. When they hand you something, it's like they're saying, "Look at this! Let's play!" They love it when you smile and say "Thank you," because it makes them feel special and important. It's also their way of trying to be a helpful little helper, and they're learning that when they give you something, you might give it back or do something fun with it. It's all a game to learn about the world and connect with you!

title: How far away is the 'drop off' of vision?
text: Imagine you're standing on a super-duper giant beach ball, even bigger than your house! Your eyes are like magic binoculars and can see really, really far. But because the Earth is like that big, round beach ball, when you look straight ahead, the ball starts to curve down away from you. So, things look like they disappear into the distance, not because there's a real "drop off" like a cliff, but because the round Earth is getting in the way! If you're standing on the ground, you can usually see about as far as you could walk for a little while, maybe 3 miles, before the curve of the Earth hides things. But if you go way up high in an airplane, you can see much, much further because you're looking over more of that big, round ball!

title: What keeps attorneys protected from being an accomplice when they're defending someone who committed a crime and found guilty?
text: Okay, imagine someone colored on the wall, even though they weren't supposed to! An attorney is like a special grown-up helper who comes *after* the coloring is done. Their job isn't to help the person color on the wall (that would be naughty and make them an accomplice!), but to make sure that when everyone talks about it, all the rules are followed. They help the person who colored tell their side of the story, and make sure the judge or other grown-ups listen carefully to everything and play fair, like a referee in a game. They just make sure the talking part follows the rules, no matter what happened before.

title: Steven Hawking has ALS since 1963. How is his body able to surivive this disease for such a long time?
text: Imagine your brain is like the boss of your body, telling your arms and legs and even the parts that help you breathe what to do. ALS is a tricky problem where the messages from the boss to your muscles get lost, so your muscles forget how to work. Most of the time, this tricky problem spreads super fast, like a race car, and makes people very sick quickly because the messages for important things like breathing stop working. But for Mr. Hawking, his tricky problem was super, super slow, like a tiny snail that took a very, very long time to move around his body. Because it was so slow, doctors and nurses had lots and lots of time to help him with special machines to help him breathe and special ways to eat, and even a special computer to help him talk, which meant his body could keep going for a very, very long time even though the messages were getting lost, because the problem wasn't moving fast enough to stop everything all at once.

title: How is it that babies have more bones then adults?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of tiny LEGO bricks. When you're a tiny baby, your body is like that box, full of lots and lots of little, soft bones! They're like many small pieces. As you grow bigger and bigger, like when you're 5 and then a grown-up, some of those little bones start to stick together and become one bigger, stronger LEGO brick. Your body does the same thing! Many of your tiny baby bones grow together and fuse into fewer, but much bigger and stronger bones, which helps you stand tall and run around. That's why grown-ups have fewer bones, but they're super strong!

title: What is the difference between HIV and AIDS?
text: Imagine your body has a team of superhero friends inside that fight off all the bad germs and bugs trying to make you sick. **HIV** is like a tiny, naughty bug that gets into your body and starts to quietly make those superhero friends tired and weak. You can have this naughty bug (HIV) for a long time, and your superhero friends might still be strong enough to fight off other things. But if the naughty HIV bug makes your superhero friends too tired and too weak over a very long time, that's when it becomes **AIDS**. AIDS means your superhero team is so weak that other regular bad germs can easily make you very, very sick because your tired superheroes can't fight them off anymore. So, you have HIV first, and then if it makes your body's superhero team too weak, that's when it becomes AIDS.

title: How does the resonance in a certain room make just a single string of stringed instruments vibrate and get louder and louder?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special toy car, and it really, really likes to go fast when you push it in a certain way. Now, imagine a big room is like a giant, friendly monster that can hum. The room has a special hum that it really likes to make. If the room starts humming its favorite hum, and that hum is *exactly* the same as the special way your toy car (which is like one string!) likes to be pushed, then the room's hum gives little, gentle pushes to your toy car. Because the room keeps pushing *just right*, over and over again, your toy car gets more and more excited, wiggles faster and faster, and makes a bigger noise, even though nobody is touching it directly! Other toy cars don't like that special hum, so they just sit there. That's how a room can make just one string on a guitar dance and sing really loud!

title: What does the silica packets in boxes of shoes do and why?
text: You know those little tiny bags you sometimes see in shoe boxes? They're like super thirsty little helpers! Sometimes, there's tiny invisible water in the air, kind of like when you breathe out on a cold day and see a little cloud. If that tiny water gets inside the box and sits on your shoes for a long time, it can make them feel yucky, maybe even a little bit squishy or smelly. So, these little bags drink up all that tiny invisible water from the air, like a super sponge! They keep your new shoes nice and dry and fresh until you put them on, so they're perfect for your feet.

title: Why does fresh, cold air help with nausea?
text: When your tummy feels yucky and like it wants to throw up (that's nausea!), your brain is a little bit confused and worried. Imagine your brain is like a busy little control room, and right now it's getting too hot or too noisy in there. When you go outside and breathe in fresh, cool air, it's like opening a window in that control room! The cool air feels nice on your face and in your nose, and it sends a message to your brain saying, "Hey, everything's okay, calm down!" It helps distract your brain from the yucky feeling in your tummy and makes your whole body feel a little more awake and refreshed, which helps your tummy feel less upset and more settled.

title: How do humans and animals produce so much saliva (water) ?
text: Okay, imagine your mouth has tiny, tiny water factories inside it! These aren't like big factories, but they're super special. Your whole body is full of water, kind of like a big water bottle. These little factories grab some of that water from your body. Then, they make it a bit special and gently squirt it out into your mouth! They're always working, like little helpers, because this special mouth water helps you chew your food, swallow it easily, and even talk. And when you think about a super yummy cookie, or when you're about to eat, these little factories get extra excited and make even more! So, you always have enough of that helpful mouth water.

title: What exactly is an anxiety disorder and how is this linked to the sympathetic nervous system? Why do antidepressants work on anxiety?
text: Imagine sometimes you feel a little scared, like when it's dark or when you hear a loud noise – that's normal! But an anxiety disorder is like having your "scared alarm"

title: What does it mean to be non-sentient?
text: Okay, imagine you can feel happy or sad, and you can think about what toys to play with or what to eat for snack time. That's called being "sentient"! But "non-sentient" means something *can't* do those things at all. It's like your favorite teddy bear; it doesn't feel warm when you hug it, and it doesn't think about anything. Or a rock outside! A rock doesn't know anything, feel anything, or think any thoughts. It just *is*. So, non-sentient means something doesn't have feelings or a brain to think with, like you do.

title: How is it possible to remember entire song lyrics but find it difficult to remember text in other forms?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super cool toy box where you keep all your memories! When you hear a song, the words are like they're dressed up in a special, super fun costume. They have music, which is like a bouncy trampoline that helps them jump right into your toy box! Songs also have a beat, like when you clap your hands, and sometimes words rhyme, which makes them stick together like LEGOs. Plus, you often hear your favorite songs many, many times, and each time is like planting a little seed in your brain that helps the words grow bigger and stronger. Other words, like from a book, don't have that special music costume or get repeated as much, so they don't bounce into your memory toy box quite as easily!

title: is it possible to see within pixels?
text: Imagine your TV screen or your mom's phone screen is made of super tiny LEGO bricks! Each one of those tiny LEGO bricks is called a "pixel." When you look at the screen, all those tiny bricks work together to make a big picture, like your favorite cartoon. Now, can you look *inside* one single LEGO brick to see an even smaller picture hiding in there? Not really! That LEGO brick *is* already the smallest piece. If you zoomed in super, super close with a magic magnifying glass on just one pixel, it would just look like one big, solid colored square, not a bunch of tiny other pictures inside it. So, you can't really see "within" a pixel because the pixel itself is already the teeniest, tiniest little dot that makes up the whole big picture!

title: Why when pulling an all-nighter do we go through a period where we're extremely tired and if we push through it wide awake?
text: Imagine your body has a special clock inside that tells it when it's sleepy-time and when it's wake-up-time. When you stay up super late past your bedtime, your body's sleepy-time alarm goes off super loud, saying 'HEY! It's time for bed! You need to sleep NOW!' That's why you feel so, so tired, like your eyelids are made of heavy rocks and you just want to flop down. Your body is trying its very hardest to make you go to sleep because it knows sleep is good for you. But if you keep playing and don't go to sleep, after a little while, your body gets a bit confused. It's like it says, 'Hmm, they're not listening to my sleepy alarm. Okay, new plan!' So, your body starts making some special 'wake-up' juice, like a little energy boost, to help you stay awake. That's why you suddenly feel less sleepy and more wide awake for a little while, even though

title: What is Fibromyalgia and how is it caused? What are the leading theories derived from studies?
text: Imagine your body has a special alarm system that tells you when something hurts, like when you bump your knee. For people with fibromyalgia, it's like their alarm system is super sensitive or

title: Why do rats get cancer very often?
text: Imagine your body is made of tiny, tiny building blocks, like LEGOs! Sometimes, one of these building blocks gets a little bit broken and starts making too many copies of itself, like a copier machine gone wild, and those extra blocks can make you feel yucky. That's kind of like cancer. Grown-ups watch rats super, super closely because rats are

title: what actually happens to your bones when they crack?
text: Imagine your bones are like super strong, hard sticks inside your body that help you run and jump! When a bone cracks, it's like if one of those strong sticks got a tiny, tiny little line or a small boo-boo on it, or maybe a bigger line going partway through. It's not usually broken all the way into two pieces, but it's got a little split or a chip in its super strong material. It still mostly holds together, but it needs a little rest and time for your body to send special helper cells to glue it back together and make it strong again, just like new!

title: Why do cockroaches always die belly up?
text: Imagine a little toy car that's upside down – it's super hard for it to flip itself back over, right? Well, cockroaches are a bit like that when they get sick or eat special bug medicine. When they're not feeling well, their legs get all wobbly and confused. Sometimes, the yucky medicine makes their leg muscles get really tight and twitchy, which makes them accidentally flip onto their backs. Once they're upside down, their legs are designed to help them run forward and cling to things, not to push themselves back over from their back, especially if the floor is super smooth and there's nothing for them to grab onto. So, they get stuck like a little upside-down boat and can't flip back, and that's why we usually see them like that when they've stopped moving.

title: Whyvare some digital watches faster or slower than others?
text: Imagine your watch has a tiny, tiny little heart inside that goes "tick-tock, tick-tock" to count the seconds, just like your own heart beats! All the watches try to make their little hearts beat *exactly* the same speed, but sometimes, a watch's little heart beats just a tiny, tiny bit faster than it should, or a tiny, tiny bit slower. If it beats a little too fast, it counts to 'one minute' quicker than other watches, so it gets ahead! If it beats a little too slow, it takes longer to count, so it falls behind. It's just like how some kids run a little faster or slower than others, even if they all try their best!

title: (kinda gross) what is pus, and why is it coloured the way it is?
text: Okay, imagine you have a little cut or a bump, and some tiny, invisible "bad guys" (we call them germs!) sneak inside. Your body has special "superhero" cells that rush to the boo-boo to fight these bad guys and clean up! Pus is like the leftover mess from that big superhero fight – it's full of dead bad guys, dead superhero cells that gave their all, and some other bits from the fight. It's yellow or green because those superhero cells are kind of yellowy-white, and when they mix with all the other stuff from the fight, that's the color it turns. It just means your body is working hard to get rid of the bad guys and make your boo-boo better!

title: How is a timetable for frequent rail service (e.g. the London Tube) made, with trains arriving every few minutes and sometimes different lines?
text: Imagine you have lots and lots of toy trains, and a really big train set with many tracks, some even crossing over! A grown-up, like a super-smart train conductor, sits down with a giant map of all the tracks. They have to decide exactly when each little train leaves its station and when it gets to the next one, making sure no two trains try to be on the same piece of track at the same time – that would be a crash! They give each train a special 'go' time, and they make sure there's just enough space between them so people can get on and off without rushing too much. If different colored tracks (like different Tube lines) meet, they make sure one train goes first, then the other, like taking turns. It's like a super careful dance for all the trains, planned out very, very precisely so everyone gets where they need to go safely and on time!

title: Does water in spaceships short circuit anything?
text: Imagine electricity is like tiny invisible zoomy cars driving super fast on special roads inside the spaceship. Water is like a big puddle. If the roads get wet and the water touches the zoomy cars, they can get confused and crash into other roads, making a big mess and stopping everything from working! That's called a "short circuit." But don't worry! The grown-ups who build spaceships are super smart. They put special plastic jackets on all the electricity roads so the water can't touch them, and they are super, super careful not to spill anything. If a tiny bit of water does escape, like when you spill your juice, they clean it up super fast with special towels so it doesn't cause any trouble. So, usually, water in a spaceship doesn't short circuit anything because everything is protected and they are very, very careful!

title: How is that extremely spicy foods can cause coughing?
text: Imagine your mouth and throat have little alarms, just like a fire alarm in your house! When you eat something super spicy, there's a special little 'spicy' chemical in it, like a tiny pepper superhero. This superhero doesn't actually burn you, but it tricks your alarms into thinking there's something *really* hot or something that shouldn't be there, like a tiny bit of smoke. When your throat's alarms go off, especially if the spicy feeling gets close to your breathing tube, your body wants to quickly push out whatever it thinks is bothering it! So, it makes you cough, like a big 'WHOOSH!' sound, trying to clear away that tricky spicy feeling and make sure nothing yucky gets where it shouldn't go, especially near your breathing tube. It's like your body saying, 'Hey! Get that spicy feeling out of here, quick!'"

title: Can screws/rods that are in your body get rejected?
text: Imagine your arm or leg is like a favorite toy that broke, and the doctors put in special little metal helpers, like tiny screws or rods, to hold it together while it heals. You know how sometimes you don't like a new food and your tummy says 'no thank you!'? For grown-ups, sometimes their body can do that with new things inside, and it's called 'rejection.' But the super cool thing about these metal helpers is that they are made from very special, super-friendly metal that your body usually *loves*! It's like your body gives them a big hug and says, 'Welcome! Thanks for helping!' So, almost all the time, your body doesn't try to push them out or say 'no thank you.' Very, very rarely, a tiny invisible germ might make things a little yucky around the metal, or the metal might wiggle a tiny bit, and then a doctor might need to take it out. But it's usually not because your body didn't like the metal itself, it's because of something else. Most of the time, those metal helpers stay happy inside you and do their job perfectly!

title: Why does grass look lighter when you cut it one way than the other?
text: Okay, imagine your hair! If you comb it one way, all the hairs lie down flat and smooth. If you comb it the other way, some might stand up a bit. Grass is just like that! When the big noisy machine cuts the grass, it pushes all the little grass hairs to lie down in one direction, just like you combed them. When the grass hairs are lying *towards* you, they catch the sun's light in a way that makes them look a little darker, like a shadow. But when they are lying *away* from you, they catch the sun's light on their shiny sides, and it bounces right back to your eyes, making them look much brighter, like a happy sunbeam! So it's all about how the little grass hairs are leaning and how the sun shines on them!

title: Can jury nullification work the other way too? As in, is it possible for a jury to purposely convict a provingly innocent person resulting in a legal conviction?
text: Imagine a jury is like a group of grown-ups who are trying to figure out if you broke a rule, like taking a cookie. Sometimes, even if you *did* take the cookie

title: Why do our ears ring?
text: Imagine your ears have super-duper tiny, special hairs inside them that are like little dancers who wiggle and jiggle when sounds come in, helping your brain know what you're hearing. Sometimes, if a sound is super-duper loud, like a big bang or a really noisy toy, it makes those tiny hair dancers get a little bit tired or even a tiny bit wobbly. When they're tired or wobbly, they might accidentally send a "fake" wiggle signal to your brain, even when there's no real sound outside. Your brain then hears this fake wiggle as a little "zzzzzz" or "weeeeee" sound, which is the ringing! It's like when your tummy makes a funny gurgle sound even when you're not eating, just because it's doing its job. Usually, it goes away when your ears get to rest, but it's like your ears saying, "Phew, that was a bit too much noise for me!"

title: How do computer board designers change and update parts like GPUs and motherboards to be compatible with all types of new and old standards, and make them faster, so quickly?
text: Imagine computers are like big LEGO sets, and the people who make them are super smart LEGO builders! When they want to make a new, faster part like a graphics card or the main board, they don't start from scratch. They have lots of old LEGO plans and ideas stored on their own computers. They change just a little bit at a time, like making a car wheel spin faster or making a door open in a new, clever way. To make sure new toys work with old toys (and sometimes old toys work with new ones!), they make sure that even a brand new, super-duper LEGO car still has the same kind of bumps and holes as your old LEGO road, so it can drive on it! Or, if they make a totally new kind of LEGO, they give you a special connector piece so it can still attach to your old LEGO castle. They know all the rules for how

title: What makes non-native English speakers sound foreign when they have good grammar?
text: It's like when you try to sing a song you know, but you sing it with a *different* tune! Even if all the words are exactly right, the song just sounds a little different. People from different places learn to make sounds in their mouths a little differently, like how a cat says "meow" and a dog says "woof." So, even if someone knows all the right English words and puts them in the perfect order, sometimes the sounds they make are a tiny bit like the sounds from their first language, or the "song" of their words (how they go up and down or which words they say louder) is a little bit different from the English "song." That's what makes it sound special and sometimes a little new to our ears!

title: When companies/academics do drug research for say an anti-viral drug, where do they start? Do they simply throw a million different chemical compounds at pirti dishes hoping one of them will show dead viruses? How do they narrow down where to start?
text: Imagine the virus is like a tiny, invisible bad guy trying to mess things up inside your body. We don't just throw every single toy we own at the bad guy hoping one will stop it! That would be silly and take forever. Instead, smart scientists first study the bad guy very, very carefully, like detectives. They look at pictures of it, figure out what it needs to grow, and what special tiny "hands" or "mouths" it uses to make more bad guys. Once they know the bad guy's secrets and weak spots, they try to imagine a special "shield" or a "sticky trap" that would fit perfectly into one of those weak spots to stop it from working. They have big libraries of tiny chemical "building blocks" and "toys," and they try to pick and choose the ones that look like they could build that perfect shield or trap. So, instead of a million random toys, they pick a few hundred or a few thousand *smart* toys that they think have the best chance, and *then* they try those in little dishes to see which ones actually work to stop the bad guy. It's like knowing what kind of key you need for a lock before you start trying every key in the world!

title: How can taking too many showers be bad for your health?
text: Imagine your skin is like a special, invisible shield all over your body, just like a superhero's shield! This shield has tiny, invisible, soft oils that keep your skin happy, smooth, and strong, and help keep little bad germs from sneaking in. When you take a shower, especially with warm water and bubbly soap, it's like a big cleaning crew comes to wash away dirt and yuckiness, which is super good! But if you take *too many* showers, or stay in for a very long time, the soap and water start to wash away your skin's special invisible shield oils too much. Then, your shield gets a little bit weak and thin. When your shield is weak, your skin can feel dry and itchy, like when your lips get chapped in the winter. And sometimes, if your shield is too weak, those tiny bad germs might find it a little bit easier to sneak past and try to make you feel yucky. So, we shower enough to be clean, but not so much that we wash away our skin's super strong shield!

title: Why do some games/apps use huge numbers instead of small numbers?
text: Imagine you're collecting stickers. If you get just one sticker, that's okay. But if you get a super-duper giant pile of a million stickers, wow! That feels so much more exciting and like you've done something really, really big, right? Games do the same thing! Instead of just saying 'you got a little bit of money,' they want to say 'you got a TRILLION coins!' or instead of 'you hurt the bad guy a little,' they say 'you hurt the bad guy for a GAZILLION damage!' It makes you feel like a super powerful hero or like you've won a super big prize. It's just a fun way for the game to show you that you're doing awesome stuff and getting lots and lots of good things, making it feel extra special and exciting!

title: how do the chips on credit cards provide extra security?
text: Okay, imagine your old credit card was like a special sticker with your name on it. If someone peeked at your sticker, they could easily make a copy of it and pretend to be you to buy toys. But your new credit card has a tiny, super-smart brain (that's the chip!) inside it. When you put it into the store's machine, your card's brain and the store's machine have a secret chat. They make up a brand new, super-secret password *just for that one purchase*. It's like they whisper a new secret code every single time you buy something. So, even if a sneaky bad guy tries to listen in and copy that one secret code, it won't work for the next time you buy something because your card and the machine will make a *different* secret code! It's super hard for bad guys to copy because the secret changes every single time, making it much safer for your money.

title: Elements want 8 electrons in their valence shell to become stable. Why do atoms want exactly 8 valence electrons, and why is it impossible to have 9 valence electrons?
text: Imagine an atom is like a tiny house, and the electrons are like little kids running around inside. These kids like to play in different rooms, called shells. The most important room for making friends (and making the house strong) is the very outermost room. Most atoms want to have exactly 8 kids playing in that outermost room. It's like having a perfect team of 8 players for a game – it makes them super happy and stable, so they don't want to change or make new friends

title: do screws used in surgery truly turn to bone? If so, how?
text: No, silly! Screws used by doctors to fix bones don't magically turn into bone, like a toy turning into a cookie! That would be super weird! What happens is even cooler: Imagine your bone is like a yummy growing plant, and the screw is like a tiny, super-special stick you put next to it. Your clever body sees the special screw and thinks, "Oh, this is a nice, safe place!" So, your bone starts to grow tiny, tiny new bone cells all around the screw, like the plant growing its roots around the stick to hold onto it tight. The screw is made of special stuff that bone really likes, so it feels happy growing close to it, making everything strong again while your bone gets better. So, the screw stays a screw, but it gets hugged super tight by your new bone!

title: Why does scratching the fork and the knife while cuting food or scratching the fork onto the plate make the human body cringe really hard and feel uncomfortable even minutes after it has happened?
text: Imagine your ears are like super-duper sensitive microphones, and your brain is like a super-smart computer! When a fork scrapes a plate, it makes a really sharp, high-pitched, *screechy* sound. It's like someone yelling a very loud, super-duper annoying 'EEEEEEEEEK!' right into your ears! Your ears don't like it because it's so sudden and pokey, and they send a message to your brain that says, 'WHOA! That's a really uncomfortable sound!' Your brain then makes your whole body feel a bit wiggly and shiver-y, like when you hear something spooky or feel a bad feeling, even if it's not actually dangerous. It's just your body's way of saying 'YUCK! Make that sound stop!' And sometimes, your brain remembers that yucky feeling for a little while, just like how you remember not to touch a hot stove after you've felt it once, because it wants to help you avoid that super-uncomfortable sound again!

title: if the immune syatem attacks/kills foreign bodies, how is it possible that bacterias are thriving in our bodies in great numbers?
text: Imagine your body is like a big house, and your immune system is like the security guard. Now, some tiny little bugs called bacteria are like your friendly helpers or even pets that live in your house and do good things, like helping you eat your food or keeping the bad guys out! Your security guard knows these friendly helpers are good, so he lets them stay and doesn't fight them. He even likes them! But if a mean, naughty bug tries to sneak in and make trouble, your security guard has a special list and knows *that* one is bad, so he quickly chases it away to keep you safe and healthy. So, lots of bacteria are actually your friends, and your body knows the difference between the good ones and the ones that try to make you sick!

title: How do we know what colors animals can see and not see?
text: You know how you can tell me what color your favorite toy is? Animals can't talk like us, so we can't just ask them! But we are like super-duper detectives! First, we look inside their eyes, not with our fingers, but with special science tools. Inside your eyes, and animal eyes too, there are tiny little 'color catchers.' Some animals have lots of color catchers for red, some for blue, and some don't have many catchers for certain colors at all! If an animal doesn't have the red catcher, it means they probably can't see red very well, and it might just look like a dark muddy color to them. Then, we also play games with them! Imagine we show a dog two bowls. One bowl has a yummy treat inside, and it's on a bright blue mat. The other bowl is empty, and it's on a

title: How can wrist-scan age tests determine your age?
text: Imagine your bones are like little building blocks that grow bigger and harder as you get older, just like a plant grows from a tiny seed! When you're a little kid, your bones have special soft spots, kind of like growing lines, that help them stretch and get longer. Your wrist is super helpful because it has lots of small bones that grow and change a lot. A doctor takes a special picture, like a magic camera that can see inside your hand, to look at these bones. They check if those soft growing lines are still there, or if they've all turned into hard bone. They have a special book with pictures of what other kids' bones look like at different ages, and they compare your bone picture to the ones in the book to see which age your bones look most like! It helps them make a good guess about how old your body is.

title: Reproduction - how can two parents, who both have their own unique genetic composition that stays the same throughout their entire lives, can develop children where each one may have their unique genetic combination too?
text: Imagine mommy and daddy each have a big, super special box of LEGOs. Daddy's box has all his special LEGOs, and mommy's box has all her special LEGOs, and these boxes never, ever change! When they want to make a baby, it's like they each reach into their own box and pick *half* of their LEGOs to put into a new pile. Then, they mix all those picked LEGOs together to build a brand new, unique LEGO creation – that's the baby! It's not exactly like mommy's original LEGO collection, and not exactly like daddy's; it's a special mix of both. And guess what? If they make another baby, they reach into their boxes again, but they might pick *different* half-sets of LEGOs this time! So, even though they start with the same two big boxes, each new baby is built with a different mix of LEGOs, making every single one super special and unique!

title: When consuming hot sauce why does it get hotter by adding more hot sauce?
text: Imagine your mouth has tiny little sensors, like lots of little buttons. Hot sauce has special invisible "spicy dust" inside it. When you eat a tiny bit of hot sauce, a few pieces of this spicy dust touch a few of your buttons, and those buttons tell your brain, "Whoa, it's warm in here!" But if you eat *lots* of hot sauce, there's way, way more spicy dust! So, way more of your buttons get pressed all at once, and they all yell to your brain, "Whoa, it's SUPER warm in here!" That's why it feels much, much hotter – more spicy dust means more buttons yelling!

title: How does a wind turbine contribute co2 to the environment?
text: Okay, imagine a big toy that spins in the wind! That toy, the wind turbine, doesn't make any yucky smoke or invisible air called CO2 when its big arms spin around. It's super clean when it's just doing its job. But, before that big toy can even start spinning, people have to make all its pieces, like the tall pole and the long arms, in big factories. Then, big trucks and big boats have to carry all those pieces to the special spot where it will live. And then, super big cranes lift all the pieces up to build it! All those big machines, trucks, boats, and factories often need to burn special fuel, like gas, to make them go. When that fuel burns, it makes a little puff of that invisible CO2 air go up into the sky. So, it's not the wind turbine itself making the CO2 when it's spinning, but all the work and big machines needed *before* it starts spinning that might make some.

title: How do small animals not get hurt by rain drops?
text: Imagine you're a giant, super-duper big person, and someone throws a tiny, tiny speck of dust at you. Does it hurt? Nope! You barely even feel it, right? Well, for a tiny bug or a little mouse, a raindrop is kind of like that speck of dust! Even though a raindrop looks big to *us*, to a really, really small animal, it's just a little splashy tap. The raindrops are actually super light and full of air, and when they hit something tiny, they just splat and break apart, spreading out their gentle push. Plus, these little animals are built super strong for their size, and some even have special fuzzy fur or waxy skin that helps the water just roll right off, making it feel like a soft tickle instead of an ouchy hit. So, it's like getting a tiny, gentle water hug, not a big bonk!

title: When one drinks a glass of water, how is it absorbed into the human body?
text: Okay, imagine you drink your water, *gulp, gulp*! First, it slides down a slide (your throat) into a mixing bowl (your tummy). Your tummy doesn't keep the water for long. It quickly pushes the water into a very, very long, squiggly tunnel called your 'small intestine'. This tunnel is super special because its walls are like a soft, thirsty sponge! It just soaks up all the water, like when you spill juice and use a paper towel to clean it up. Once the sponge walls soak up the water, it jumps into tiny, tiny rivers inside your body called 'blood'. These blood rivers are like delivery trucks that rush all the water to every single part of your body – your arms, your legs, your brain, even your wobbly toes! Every part of you is like a little flower that needs water to grow big and strong and play all day!

title: Why do some people feel temperature differently to others?
text: Imagine your body has tiny little special sensors, like little detectives, all over your skin! These detectives tell your brain if something is hot or cold. But guess what? Everyone's detectives are a little bit different. Some people's detectives are super good at finding even a tiny bit of cold, so they might feel chilly really fast! Other people's detectives might be more focused on the warm, or just not as sensitive to cold, so they feel perfectly fine. It's kind of like how you might really love a certain toy, but your friend likes a different one – both are great, but you just feel things in your own special way! So, some people just have detectives that are more sensitive to hot, and some to cold, and that's perfectly normal because everyone's body is unique.

title: Why does it not get dark before a snowstorm like it does before heavy rains?
text: Okay, imagine the sun is a big flashlight in the sky! When it's going to rain a lot, the clouds are like super thick, big, grey blankets that come really close to the ground and gobble up all the flashlight's light, making everything look dark and shadowy. But when it's going to snow, the clouds are often like big, fluffy, white or light grey blankets. Even though they're full of snow, the tiny, tiny ice bits inside are like little sparkly mirrors that bounce the sun's light all around instead of eating it up. So, the light gets spread out and makes everything look bright, sometimes even a soft white glow, instead of dark before the snow starts falling!

title: How do testicles make sperm?
text: Okay, imagine your testicles are like two tiny, super-duper special factories working all the time! Inside these factories, there are lots and lots of tiny, tiny pipes and amazing little worker cells. These worker cells are like incredible little chefs who take simple building blocks from your body (just like you use building blocks to make a tower) and carefully mix them up and shape them into super tiny, wiggly swimming guys called sperm. They keep making new ones all day and all night, like a toy factory that never stops making new toys, so there are always lots of them ready to go help make a baby when a grown-up is ready.

title: How does a seemingly healthy symptom-free person get diagnosed with a terminal “Stage V” cancer and be given a few months to live?
text: Imagine your body is like a big house with lots of tiny, helpful worker cells that do their jobs to keep you healthy and strong. But sometimes, a few of these worker cells go a little bit

title: How do workers get the last crane off the top of a skyscraper when they finish building it?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super-duper tall LEGO tower, and a giant robot crane helped you build it all the way to the clouds! When the giant robot crane is all done, it can't just fly away. So, the really big robot crane has a little helper robot crane. The big robot crane starts taking *itself* apart, piece by piece, and the little helper robot crane helps carry the big pieces down, down, down to the ground. Once the really big robot crane is completely gone, only the little helper robot crane is left up high. But guess what? The little helper crane is small enough to fit *inside* the building! So, the workers carefully take the little crane apart, piece by piece, right inside the building. Then, they put all those smaller pieces into the building's elevator, or a special lift, and bring them down to the ground, just like bringing toys down from your bedroom. Ta-da! All the cranes are gone!

title: Why isn’t our pee coloured after drinking certain drinks?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a little house, and it makes some yucky, yellow "trash water" (that's your pee!) to clean itself. When you drink yummy juice or milk, those drinks are mostly just like super clean water! So, when you drink lots and lots of that clean water, it mixes with the little bit of yellow trash water your body makes. It's like having a tiny drop of yellow paint in a big, big glass of clear water – the paint gets so spread out, you can barely see it anymore! Your body is still cleaning, but because there's so much clean water helping out, your pee just looks clear instead of yellow. It means you're doing a great job drinking!

title: If you roll down a hill or are in a car crash you become incredibly disoriented until you've collected yourself and find which way is up. If this happened in space, what would be your reset to stop feeling so disoriented?
text: Okay, imagine you're spinning around super fast, like when you roll down a hill! Whoa, everything gets blurry and you don't know which way is up or down, right?

title: How is language taught to people who never learnt a language when they were younger without a base language to relate back to?
text: Okay, imagine someone who is like a grown-up baby, and they don't know *any* words at all, not even "mama" or "ball"! How do we teach them? Well, it's a bit like how you learned your very first words when you were a tiny baby. We don't use other words to explain, because they don't know any yet! Instead, we *show* them everything. We hold up a yummy apple and say "apple!" many, many times while they look at it. Then we might pick it up and say "eat!" while we pretend to eat it. We point to a dog and say "dog!" and make a "woof woof" sound. We play games where we say "ball!" and roll a ball to them, so they connect the sound to the round toy. We use our hands, our faces, and our voices to show if we're happy or sad, and use simple words to match. It's

title: Why can't pilots see when a laser hits them?
text: Imagine someone shines a super, super bright flashlight right into your eyes! Even for a tiny second, your eyes would get all fuzzy and bright, and you wouldn't be able to see anything clearly, right? A laser is like that, but way, way brighter and super focused, like a tiny, powerful light beam. When that super bright beam hits a pilot's eyes, it makes their whole view turn bright green or fuzzy for a little while, and they can't see the instruments, other planes, or where they're going. It's like trying to ride your bike with your eyes closed for a moment, and that's very, very dangerous when you're flying a big airplane because they need to see *everything* all the time to keep everyone safe!

title: Why after one receives a shot (to the arm, for example) makes the insertion area/muscle sore?
text: Imagine your arm is like a super important house, and when you get a shot, a tiny, tiny, super thin straw pokes a little hole, and then some special liquid medicine goes inside your house. Your body is like a very smart guard for that house! It notices, "Hey, what's this new thing?" So, your body sends out tiny little helpers, like little worker ants, to go look at the medicine and figure out what it is. They start working really hard to understand the new medicine and learn how to use it to keep you super healthy and strong. All this working and learning makes that part of your arm feel a little bit tired or grumpy, like when your legs feel tired after you run a lot! It's not a bad tired, though. It's a "I'm working hard to make you super strong!" tired. And soon, it feels all better!

title: Why do men and women look so mature in the 20th century despite being late teens/early twenties compared to now?
text: Imagine your mommy and daddy, but a super long time ago, when your grandparents were kids! Back then, people who were just a little older than your big brother or sister often had to start acting like grown-ups much sooner. They would get jobs, get married, and have their own babies when they were still quite young. This made them feel and act more like grown-ups. Also, their clothes were different, and their hairstyles were different, which sometimes made them look a bit older than kids their age today. It's like they put on their 'grown-up' costumes and responsibilities earlier, making them seem more mature

title: Why are pain meds like vicodin so much different from OTC drugs like ibuprofen?
text: Okay, imagine you have a little boo-boo, like when you scrape your knee playing outside. Ibuprofen is like a little hug for that boo-boo – it helps the part that hurts feel a bit better

title: How do you “crack” a game? Why can’t you just send the files of the game to someone so they can play it?
text: Imagine a super fun toy car that you really want to play with! When you buy it from the store, it comes in a special box with a tiny, magical lock on it. Only the person who bought the toy gets the special key that opens that lock, and that key also tells the toy, "Hey, this person paid for me, so let them play!" The game files are like the toy car itself, sitting in its box. If you just give your friend the toy car (the files) without that special key, they can look at it, but they can't *play* with it because the lock is still shut and the toy won't move! "Cracking" the game is like someone super clever finding a secret way to trick the toy car's lock into thinking it has the key, even when it doesn't. They don't actually get the *real* key, but they figure out how to make the lock *believe* it's been opened, so the toy car starts zooming around and can be played with. It's like finding a secret button on the box that bypasses the lock, so anyone can open it and play with the toy, even without buying the actual key from the store.

title: If every matter is of a chemical composition, can't we in specific ways chemical produce almost any matter?
text: Imagine everything around you, like your favorite toy car, your juice, or even you, is made of tiny, tiny special building blocks, like LEGO bricks! These special LEGO bricks are what we call "chemicals." You're super smart for asking if we can just build anything! And you're right, we can take some of those LEGO bricks and connect them in different ways to make new things, just like you can use red and blue bricks to make a house, then take them apart to make a car. Scientists do this all the time in their labs, making new medicines or new materials! But here's the tricky part: we can't just *make* a brand new LEGO brick out of nothing, or easily change a red LEGO brick into a super shiny gold LEGO brick. Some LEGO bricks are just what they are, and it's super, super hard, or even impossible, to change one kind of fundamental LEGO into another. And making something super complicated, like a whole new puppy or a real tree, is much, much, much harder than just building a simple toy, even with all our special LEGO bricks!

title: In trading, what is a buy/sell wall? What is the strategy behind them?
text: Imagine we're all at a big playground, and everyone wants to trade their cool toy cars! A "buy wall" is like when a super-duper lot of kids all line up and say, "I want to buy that red toy car

title: When you hydraulic press an object, does all the force come from the press, or does any of it come from the stationary part?
text: Yes! Imagine you have a piece of play-doh on a table, and you push down on it with your hand. Your hand is pushing the play-doh down, right? But the table underneath the play-doh is also pushing *up*! If the table wasn't there, the play-doh would just fall and wouldn't get squished. So, for the play-doh to get really squished, your hand pushes down, and the table pushes back up. It's the same with a hydraulic press! The big pushy part comes down very hard, and the strong, flat part at the bottom pushes back up just as hard. Both sides are squeezing the object together to squish it!

title: not sure how dumb this sounds but since we are running out of oil it seemed worth it - plants use CO2 and water (+sunlight) to make energy in their chloroplast... what's there stopping us from making large chloroplast generators that would generate energy for us ?
text: Imagine a plant is like a super clever baker! Inside its leaves, it has tiny, tiny ovens called chloroplasts. These little ovens are magic because they can take sunshine, air (that's CO2), and water, and bake yummy food for the plant to grow tall and strong. But here's the tricky part: these tiny ovens only know how to make special plant food, not electricity for our lights or TVs. And even more, these little ovens need the whole plant to help them work – like how a baker needs their whole kitchen, not just one oven, to make a cake. If we just took out one tiny oven all by itself, it wouldn't know what to do! It's super hard for grown-ups to copy what plants do, even though we think plants are amazing for their special magic.

title: Why does the turning radius of a car increase the faster the car goes?
text: Imagine you're running really, really fast across the playground! If you want to turn a corner, you can't just suddenly spin around, right? You have to make a big, wide curve so you don't fall over or skid. But if you're just walking slowly, you can turn super sharp, almost on the spot! Cars are a bit like that. When a car goes fast, it really wants to keep going straight, just like you want to keep running straight. Even when the wheels try to make it turn, it's going so fast that it takes a lot more space and time to change its direction. So, it has to make a much bigger circle to turn around safely, because it's so busy wanting to go straight!

title: When do I stop being related to my descendants?
text: You know how your mommy and daddy are related to you, and your grandmas and grandpas are related to them? It's like a super long, super cool family story, and everyone is a special character! When you have children, they become new characters in *your* story, right after you. And then *their* children become new characters after them, and so on, and so on! You never, ever stop being related to your descendants because you are always the special beginning part of *their* story, like the very first page of their very own chapter. You're always connected, like a big, never-ending family hug, even if they

title: Why do we get “butterflies” in our stomachs when thinking about a crush?
text: You know that funny, wiggly, tickly feeling deep down in your tummy sometimes? Like tiny little happy butterflies are fluttering around in there! Well, when you think about someone you like a lot, your brain gets super duper excited, almost like it's saying "Yay!" very loudly. This excitement isn't just in your head; your brain sends those happy, zingy messages all over your body, and your tummy is one of the places that feels it first. It's kind of like when you're about to get a really special present, or go to a super fun party – your body gets all geared up and excited, and that feeling often shows up as those happy tummy wiggles. It's just your body's way of showing you how special and exciting that person makes you feel!

title: Why is it that sometimes when we get cut or burned really bad it takes a second to register what happened?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big house, and your brain is like the boss in the main office. When you get a boo-boo, like a cut or a burn, it's like a special messenger needs to run from where the boo-boo happened all the way to the boss's office (your brain) to tell it what happened! If it's just a tiny little pinch, the messenger runs super fast because it's a very short trip. But if it's a really big boo-boo, like a deep cut or a big burn, the messenger has a much longer road to run, and sometimes there are lots of messengers trying to get through! So, it takes a tiny bit of time for those messengers to run all the way to your brain to say "Hey! Something bad happened here!" That's why you sometimes see the boo-boo first, and then a tiny second later, your brain gets the message and says "Ouch! That hurts!" It's just the messengers doing their job, but they can only run so fast.

title: How come musicians in rock bands don't typically use sheet music like they do in an orchestra?
text: Okay, imagine a big, big kitchen with *lots* of chefs all trying to make the *exact same cake* at the exact same time! To make sure everyone does it perfectly and at the same moment, they all need a special recipe book (that's the sheet music) to tell them every single step. If one chef does something different, the whole cake might get messy! That's like an orchestra. But in a rock band, it's more like just a few friends playing with their toys. You might already know how to play your favorite game together without needing a book, or you make up a new game as you go along, listening to what your friends are doing. Rock bands often learn songs by listening and remembering them in their heads, or they make up their own cool parts as they play, so they don't need a recipe book right in front of them!

title: If you somehow broke a bone in space, would your bones be floating in your body? What would happen to the blood?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super squishy, comfy blanket, and your bones are the strong sticks inside that help you stand up. If a stick (bone) broke in space, the

title: How do domains work, like .com .ru? Why can sites like discord use a custom domain like .gg?
text: Imagine the internet is a giant, giant city with millions and millions of houses, and each house is a website! Every house has a super long, secret number address that's really hard to remember, like "192.168.1.1". So, instead of remembering those numbers, we give each house an easy name, like "google.com" or "youtube.com". That easy name is called a domain! The ".com" part is like a neighborhood sign, telling you what kind of house it is – ".com" is usually for companies, and ".ru" is like the neighborhood where houses in Russia live. There are lots of these neighborhood signs, like ".org" for organizations or ".net" for networks. Now, sometimes people want to make a brand new, special neighborhood! Like the people who made ".gg" – they thought it would be super cool for gaming websites, because "gg" means "good game"! So, sites like Discord, who are all about games, decided to put their house in that cool new ".gg" neighborhood because it fits them perfectly. When you type in a domain name, a special helper on the internet

title: How do companies determine the cost of acquiring a customer?
text: Imagine you have a lemonade stand! To get kids to come and buy your yummy lemonade, you have to do things, right? Maybe you make a big, colorful sign that says "LEMONADE!" (That costs you a crayon and paper!). Maybe you shout "Yummy lemonade here!" (That costs your voice!). Or maybe you give a tiny free sip so they know how good it is (That costs a little bit of lemonade!). All those things you do to get new friends to buy your lemonade cost you some money or effort. Companies do the exact same thing! They spend money on things like making fun TV commercials, putting pictures of their toys on the internet, or having people in stores tell you about new games. They add up *all* the money they spent on *all* those things to get new people to buy their stuff. Then, they count how many new people actually bought something because of all that effort. They take that big pile of money they spent and divide it by the number of new people who bought something. So, if they spent $100 to get 10 new people to buy a toy, each new person "cost" them $10 to get. That's how they figure out how much it costs them to get just *one* new customer! They want to make sure they don't spend too much money to get a new friend to buy their things.

title: Why does looking through the side window in cars make it seem like you’re going much faster than looking out the front?
text: Okay, imagine you're on a playground swing! If you look at your hands or the ground right under your feet, it goes super-duper fast, 'whoosh!' But if you look way, way up at the clouds or a tall tree far away, they don't seem to move much at all, even though you're swinging the same. It's the same in the car! When you look out the side window, you see all the trees and fences and cars right next to you, and they zoom past really, really fast because they are so close to your eyes. But when you look out the front window, you see things that are far, far away, like the road way ahead or the big sky, and those things don't look like they're rushing past as much. Your car is going the same speed the whole time, it just feels faster when the close things whiz by!

title: Why is mixing alcohol bad?
text: Imagine your body is like a little car, and grown-up drinks are like special fuel. If you put just one kind of special fuel in your car, it drives okay. But if you try to put *lots of different kinds* of special fuel in at the same time, like gas AND diesel AND juice all mixed up, your

title: what determines whether a #2 will be a sinker or a floater?
text: Imagine your poop is like a little boat or a heavy rock! If your poop has lots of tiny air bubbles trapped inside it, kind of like when you blow bubbles in your milk, those air bubbles make it lighter, and then it floats on top of the water like a little boat. But if your poop doesn't have many air bubbles and is more squishy and packed together, it's heavier, and then it sinks to the bottom like a rock. So, it's mostly about how much "air" got mixed into your poop when your tummy was making it!

title: If I'm driving at a constant speed of 60mph and get rear-ended by a vehicle which is moving at a constant 80mph, would the force of impact be the same as if I were sitting at 0mph and got rear ended by someone driving 20mph?
text: Imagine you and a friend are playing a game. In the first game, you're both running super fast, like zoom-zoom, but your friend is running just a tiny bit faster than you and bumps into your back. That little push you feel is because your friend was only going a little bit faster. Now, in the second game, you're standing still, and your friend runs and bumps into you, but they run at the *exact same* tiny bit faster speed as they were running compared to you in the first game. The push you feel in your back would be the same in both games! It's all about how much *faster* the other car is going compared to your car, not how fast you're both going compared to the trees outside. So yes, the big push would feel the same.

title: How did people figure out Absolute Zero when it's practically unreachable?
text: Imagine your toys are little tiny people, and when it's hot, they're running around super fast and wiggling a lot! When it gets colder, they slow down and wiggle less

title: Why do our eyes make tears when we are tired?
text: Imagine your eyes are like little windows that need to stay wet and shiny, just like when you wash your hands! Usually, every time you blink, it's like a tiny magic sponge that wipes fresh, clear water all over them to keep them happy and comfy. But when you're super, super sleepy, your eyes get a bit tired too, and they don't make as much of that good, thin water, and you don't blink as often. So, your eyes start to feel a little bit dry and scratchy, like when your mouth gets dry if you don't drink water. Because they feel grumpy and dry, your eyes then try to make *extra* tears, like an emergency splash of water, to try and wash away that dry, scratchy feeling and make them feel better until you can finally close them and go to sleep!

title: How do potholes form and how do they hurt my tires?
text: Imagine the road is like a super big, flat cookie. Sometimes, tiny little cracks, like thin lines, get into the cookie. When it gets really cold outside, water sneaks into those cracks. This water turns into ice, and ice is like a strong, growing monster that pushes the cookie road apart from the inside, making the cracks bigger! When the ice melts, it leaves a little empty space. Then, when big cars drive over that weak spot again and again, the cookie road breaks and crumbles away, leaving a big hole – that's a pothole! Now, your car's tires are like

title: Given the fact that the human heart has the sole job of moving blood through every inch of every extremity in the body, how is it able to accomplish this in morbidly obese individuals or is there something else happening there that picks up the slack for the heart?
text: Imagine your heart is like a little water pump that sends water (blood) all around your house (your body). If your house gets really, really big, with many more rooms and a much bigger garden, that little pump has to work much, much harder to get water to every single tap and flower. It tries its best! It gets a bit bigger and stronger, like when you play a lot and your muscles get stronger. But if the house gets super, super big, the little pump has to work so hard all the time, every second, that it starts to get tired and worn out. There isn't another secret pump hiding somewhere to help it out; it's all up to your heart to push that water everywhere, and when it gets too tired, it can't do its job as well anymore.

title: What are chemtrails?
text: You know how sometimes when you see a big airplane way up high in the sky, it leaves a long, white line behind it? Well, some grown-ups call those "chemtrails" because they think it's special chemicals that the government or other grown-ups are spraying on purpose, maybe to change the weather or for secret reasons. But really, what almost all the smart people who study planes and the sky say is that those white lines are just like when you breathe out on a super cold day and you can see your breath! The airplane engine makes hot air, and when that hot air mixes with the super-duper cold air way up high, it makes tiny little clouds of water vapor, which is like steam. They're called contrails, and they're totally normal clouds made by the plane, not secret yucky stuff!

title: Why does mold on food grow in spots rather than relatively even across the surface?
text: Imagine tiny, tiny little seeds, so small you can't even see them! These are like the babies of the fuzzy stuff (mold). They float all around in the air, like tiny dust. When your food is sitting out, some of these tiny mold babies float down and land on your food. But they don't land everywhere at once, do they? They just land in a few random spots, like when you drop sprinkles on a cookie – they land here and there, not perfectly all over. Once a mold baby lands on a yummy spot on your food, if it's warm and wet enough, it starts to get super hungry! It eats the food and gets bigger and bigger, making a little fuzzy circle, like when you draw a dot with a crayon and then color outwards. Because

title: If the heart is a muscle, why is it weakened by being overworked?
text: Your heart is like a super special, super strong pump muscle that sends blood all around your body! Imagine if you had to carry a really heavy backpack all day, every single day, without ever taking it off. Your arm muscles would get super, super tired, right? Maybe they'd even start to hurt or get too big and floppy, and then they wouldn't be as good at carrying things anymore. Your heart is a bit like that. If it has to work super, super hard all the time, pumping blood against something really tough or trying to push blood to a body that needs too much help, it gets really tired. Instead of getting stronger like when you play a little bit, if it works *too* hard for *too* long, it can get stretched out or too thick and stiff. When that happens, it's not as good at squeezing the blood nicely anymore, and it gets weaker, like that tired arm that can't lift well. It needs a good balance of work and rest to stay super strong!
