title: How can someone (Bill Gates) go and just build a city? How would he get the permission to do that?
text: Imagine you want to build a super-duper big LEGO city, bigger than any you've ever seen! First, you need a huge, empty space to build it on, right? You can't just build on your friend's carpet, you need your own big floor. Bill Gates has lots and lots of money, so he can buy a giant piece of land, like a whole big field that nobody else is using. But even after he buys the land, he can't just start building houses and roads anywhere he wants. He has to go to the big grown-ups in charge (that's the government, like the mayor or the state people) and show them his drawings and tell them his plan. They have rules, like where the roads should go, how tall buildings can be, and where the parks need to be so everyone is safe and happy. If Bill Gates promises to follow all their rules and makes sure his new city will be a good place for people to live, then the grown-ups will say "Okay, you can build your amazing city!" It's like asking your mom if you can build a fort in the living room – if you promise to clean up and not make a big mess, she'll probably say yes!

title: When bacteria die, for example when boiling water, where do their corpses go?
text: That's a super good question! You know how sometimes when you play with your LEGOs, a big castle can break into lots and lots of tiny little LEGO bricks? Well, bacteria are like super, super tiny little bugs, way smaller than even your smallest LEGO brick, so small you can't even see them without a special magic glass. When you make the water super hot, like when Mommy boils it for your noodles, it's too hot for these tiny bugs, and they stop wiggling and die. But because they are so, so tiny and don't have bones or skin like us, their little bodies just break apart into even tinier, tinier pieces, like invisible dust! These super tiny pieces just float around in the water, but they are so incredibly small that you can't see them, and they can't make you sick anymore. So, they don't really go anywhere; they just become invisible, harmless dust mixed in with the water!

title: If you didn’t swallow your own saliva would your mouth just fill completely with saliva or would you just stop salivating?
text: Okay, imagine your mouth is like a tiny swimming pool, and your body is like a little water fountain that's always making a special kind of water called spit (we also call it saliva!). Your body keeps making this spit all the time because it helps you chew your food and keeps your mouth nice and wet. If you decided not to swallow any of it, it would be like that fountain just keeps running and running into your little swimming pool mouth. The pool would get super full, fuller and fuller, and eventually, just like when you fill a cup too much, the spit would start to dribble out of your mouth, down your chin! Your body wouldn't just stop making it because it's a super important job it has to do, like how your heart keeps beating even when you're not thinking about it.

title: how, in cases such as schizophrenia, does the brain create such realistic audible and visual hallucinations while the person is conscious?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a super special storyteller inside your head! Most of the time, it tells you all the true stories about what's happening around you, like when you see

title: Why do grey hairs appear to be very thick and strong, aren't they dying?
text: Imagine your hair is like a long string growing from a tiny factory under your skin. When you're little, this factory puts a special color, like brown or yellow, into your hair string. But as you get older, sometimes the factory forgets to put the color in, so the string grows out white or grey! It's not dying, because hair isn't alive like you are; it's just a string that grows. Sometimes, as the factory gets older, it also changes how it makes the string itself, making it a little bit thicker or a bit more like a strong wire. So, the grey hair isn't strong because it's "dying"; it's just that your hair factory changed two things at once: it forgot the color, and it also decided to make the hair string a little bit different, all because you're getting older and your body is changing!

title: Why do sites like PirateBay and WatchSeries constantly change domains?
text: Imagine you have a secret club where you share all your toys with your friends, even toys that belong to other people and you're not supposed to share for free. The grown-ups (like your parents or the police) find out about your secret club in your backyard and they say, "Hey! You can't do that here!" and they try to make you stop or even close down your backyard. But you still want to share your toys! So, you quickly pack up all your toys and move your secret club to your friend's backyard, or to the park, or even to a different house. That new place is like a new website address. The grown-ups find that new place and try to stop you again, so you move again! Those websites are like that secret club; they share movies and games that grown-ups (the people who made them) don't want them to share for free. When the grown-ups find their 'house' (their website address) and try to shut it down, they just quickly build a new 'house' somewhere else (a new

title: why do some medicines hurt your stomach if not taken with food?
text: Imagine your tummy is like a cozy room where your food goes to get squished up. Some medicines are like a very strong, super active helper that needs to get to work! If this strong helper comes into an empty room, it might accidentally bump into the walls of your tummy a little bit, and that can make your tummy feel a bit 'ouchy' or 'grumpy'. But if you put some food in your tummy first, it's like putting a big, soft pillow all around the room. So when the strong medicine helper comes in, it lands softly on the pillow (the food) and doesn't bump into your tummy walls at all! That way, your tummy stays happy and doesn't get that owie feeling. Not all medicines are strong like that, some are gentle and don't need a pillow, but for the strong ones, food is like a superhero shield!

title: What is the point of those wooden honey-dipper things?
text: You know how honey is super sticky and drippy, and a regular spoon can make a big mess? That special wooden stick, called a honey dipper, is like a magic spoon just for honey! It has all these little bumps and rings, like tiny pockets. When you dip it in the honey and spin it around, the sticky honey gets caught in all those little pockets and doesn't want to drip off as much. It's like it's holding onto the honey super tight! Then you can easily carry the honey from the jar to your yummy toast or into your warm milk without making a big sticky mess all over the table. It helps you get just the right amount of honey right where you want it!

title: Why do people get addicted to drugs but not to stuff like work and studying?
text: Okay, imagine your brain has a special "happy button." When you do fun things like play with your toys or get a hug, that button gets a little push, and you feel good! Now, drugs are like a super-duper strong finger that pushes that happy button *really, really hard* and *super fast*, much more than anything else. Your brain gets confused because it feels *so* good, *so* quickly, that it starts to think it *needs* that strong push to be happy, and it forgets how to make its *own* happy feelings. It's like your brain gets tricked! But when you work hard at school or learn new things, you also feel happy and proud, right? That's a different kind of happy, like a warm, gentle hug for your brain. It's not a super-duper strong push that tricks your brain into *needing* it, so your brain still remembers how to make its own happy feelings without those things.

title: How do chlorofluorocarbons create holes in the atmosphere?
text: Imagine our Earth wears a super special, invisible blanket way, way up high in the sky. This blanket is like a superhero sunscreen, and it's called the ozone layer. Its job is to protect us from the sun's super strong, ouchy rays that could give us really bad sunburns! Now, a long time ago, people used to make some special invisible bubbles called CFCs for things like old fridges and spray cans. These little naughty bubbles would float, float, float all the way up past the clouds, higher than any airplane, until they reached our special blanket. When they got way up there, the sun would break these CFC bubbles into even tinier, naughtier pieces. These tiny pieces were like little monsters that would poke and eat tiny holes in our sky blanket, making it thinner and weaker. When the blanket got thinner and had holes, more of those ouchy sun rays could sneak through and give us bad sunburns, and even hurt plants and animals. That's why we learned not to use those naughty CFC bubbles anymore!

title: How are companies able to lower the costs of items on Black Friday?
text: Imagine your toy box is super full, and you want to make space for new toys, or you just really want all your friends to come over and play! Companies are a bit like that with their stores. On Black Friday, they make some toys (or clothes, or TVs) super, super cheap, like saying, "This yummy candy is usually $10, but today it's only $5!" They do this for a few reasons. First, they know if they make things very cheap, lots and lots of people will come to their store to buy them, and even if they make a tiny bit less money on each one, they sell SO many more that they still make lots of money overall. Second, sometimes they have too much of one thing, and they want to sell it all to make space for new, shiny things. And third, they hope that once you're in their store for the super cheap thing, you might also see other cool things that aren't on sale and buy those too! So it's like a special game to get everyone excited and buying lots of stuff.

title: How do anti-anxiety medications work?
text: You know how sometimes you get a really big worry, like a monster in your tummy, and your brain feels super speedy and loud, like a race car? Well, inside your brain, you have tiny little helpers, like messengers, who send signals all around. When you're super worried, sometimes these messengers get too excited and send too many 'worry' signals, making your brain feel like it's running too fast. Anti-anxiety medicine is like a special, gentle helper that tells some of those messengers to slow down a little bit, or helps them make more 'calm' signals instead of 'worry' signals. It's like giving your brain a warm, cozy blanket or a dimmer switch to turn down the super bright, noisy worry lights, so your brain can feel more peaceful and not so scared anymore. It helps your brain remember how to feel calm and safe, so that big worry monster feels much smaller.

title: Why animals don't do warm-up before hunting?
text: You know how when you're going to run super fast or play a big game, your grown-up might tell you to stretch a little first? That's to make your body ready so it doesn't get a boo-boo. Animals are a bit different! Their bodies are like they're *always* ready to go, go, go! They don't sit on a comfy couch watching TV like we sometimes do. They're always moving around a little bit, looking, sniffing, even when they're resting. So, their muscles are already wiggly and ready for action most of the time. And guess what? When an animal sees a yummy snack (like a gazelle for a lion) or needs to run away from something scary, they can't wait! They have to go *right now*! If they stopped to stretch, their dinner might run away, or they might become someone else's dinner! Their bodies are just made to be super quick and ready all the time, like a spring that's always coiled up, waiting to bounce.

title: Why do objects that are wet look shiny?
text: Okay, imagine light is like tiny, tiny bouncy balls! When you look at something dry, its surface is a little bit bumpy, so the light bouncy balls hit it and bounce off in all sorts of different directions, like when you throw balls at a bumpy wall. But when something gets wet, it gets a super thin, super smooth blanket of water all over it. This smooth water blanket is like a perfectly flat slide for the light bouncy balls! Instead of bouncing off everywhere messy, all the light bouncy balls hit the smooth water and bounce off together, in the same direction, right into your eyes! When all that light comes to your eyes at once, it looks super bright and "shiny," just like a little mirror!

title: Why are some large batteries (like Tesla's) made up of smaller cells?
text: Imagine you have a super big toy car that needs lots and lots of energy to zoom around! Instead of putting one giant, super-duper battery inside, engineers put in many, many tiny little batteries, like a big handful of marbles all working together. Here's why: If one tiny marble battery gets sleepy or stops working, it's okay because all the other tiny marble batteries are still awake and working hard, so your toy car can still zoom! If you only had one giant battery and it got sleepy, the whole car would stop. Plus, little things are easier to keep safe – if one tiny battery gets a little too hot, it's not a big deal because it's so small, but one giant battery getting super hot could be a bigger problem. So, lots of little batteries together make a super strong, super safe, and super reliable big battery for big cars like Tesla's!

title: Why do people want to sleep after they finish eating?
text: When you eat yummy food, your tummy gets a super big job to do! It's like your tummy has to work really, really hard to break down all the food and find all the good energy inside it for your body. To help your tummy do this big job, your body sends lots of helpers (like little energy trucks!) to your tummy. When your body is busy sending all these helpers and working so hard on the food, your whole body can feel a little tired, just like when you play super hard all day long! So, feeling sleepy after eating is your body saying, "Whew, I'm busy doing

title: Why are there so many centenarian in Japan compared to other countries?
text: Imagine some people eat lots of yummy fish and colorful veggies, like broccoli and carrots, instead of too many sugary treats or greasy chips. And they also love to walk and play outside every day, keeping their bodies strong, instead of just sitting on the couch. Plus, they have really good doctors who help them stay healthy, and they have lots of friends and family who make them feel happy and important. When you do all these things, like eating good food, moving your body, seeing the doctor, and having fun with friends, it helps you live a super-duper long time, like in Japan!

title: What's the difference between a trademark, copyright and patent? Could they not just be one broader thing?
text: Okay, imagine you have lots of special things! A **trademark** is like a special name tag or a unique sticker for your favorite toy company, like how your juice box always has the same special picture and name. It tells everyone who made it, so no one else can pretend their juice is yours. A **copyright** is like saying "I made this!" for a super cool drawing you drew, a song you sang, or a story you wrote. It means only *you* get to decide if someone else can copy your drawing or sing your song for everyone. And a **patent** is for a brand new invention,

title: why do animals taste different?
text: Okay, imagine you have different kinds of yummy snacks, like a strawberry, a banana, and an apple. They're all fruit, but they taste different because they're made a little bit

title: A person gets in a bad accident that requires and gets a blood transfusion. Shortly after, that person commits a crime, gets wounded, and leave blood trace at the scene they fled. Who's blood would show up on the DNA analysis?
text: Imagine your body has a special instruction book, like a recipe, that tells it exactly how to make *you*. Every part of you, from your toes to your hair, uses this instruction book, and it's called DNA. When you get a blood transfusion, it's like someone gives you a big cup of *their* juice, which has some of *their* tiny little cells floating in it. But your body's main instruction book, the one that tells *your* body how to make new blood and everything else, is still *your* instruction book. So, even though you had some of someone else's juice for a little while, when you bleed later, it's *your* body's blood cells, made from *your* instruction book, that come out. So, the DNA found would be *your* DNA.

title: Why is the Sahara a desert when other places at the same latitude are tropical rainforests?
text: Okay, imagine our big round Earth, and the sun gives it a warm hug around its middle, where both the Sahara and those super rainy places are. Even though they're on the same "belt" around the Earth, they're different because of a few things! Think of the wind as a big truck carrying water. For the rainforests, the truck is full of water and it rains a lot! But when the wind truck gets to the Sahara

title: Why when some people are about to engage in a physical altercation do they start to shake, heart pump and lose peripheral vision?
text: Okay, imagine your body has a super special alarm bell inside! When it thinks something big and maybe a little scary is about to happen, like if a big dog barks at you, that alarm goes off. Your heart starts to pump super fast because it's like a special pump sending extra energy juice to all your muscles so you can run really fast or be super strong. You might shake a little bit because your muscles are getting all wiggly and ready to move quickly, like a car engine revving up before a race! And your eyes get super focused, like when you're looking really hard at just one toy, so you don't see things on the sides as much. That's because your brain wants you to only look at the most important thing right in front of you, so you know exactly what to do! It's all your body's way of getting ready to be super quick and safe.

title: What is the difference between Anti-Malware and Anti-Virus?
text: Imagine your computer is like your toy box, full of all your favorite toys. Sometimes, naughty little things try to sneak into your toy box to cause trouble. A **virus** is like a tiny, super specific germ that gets into *just one* of your toys and makes it sick. It's very good at making that one toy not work right. An **Anti-Virus** program is like a special doctor who knows exactly how to find and fix *just those specific little germs* that make your toys sick. Now, **malware** is a bigger word for *all sorts* of naughty things, not just the tiny germs! It includes those germs, but also other tricky bad guys like sneaky peekers who try to look at your secret drawings, or messy monsters who try to hide your toys. An **Anti-Malware** program is like a bigger superhero team! It has the germ doctor inside it, but it also has other superheroes who can find and stop *all* the different kinds of naughty things – the germs, the sneaky peekers, and the messy monsters. So, Anti-Malware is like a bigger, stronger protector for your whole toy box!

title: How does the brain store information/memories?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a super special closet or a big toy box in your head! Inside this toy box are millions and millions of tiny little helpers, like little busy workers. When you learn something new, like the name of your favorite dinosaur or what you ate for breakfast, these tiny helpers quickly connect to each other and build a special, invisible string or a little road just for that new memory. Each memory is like a little story or a picture that lives on one of these strings. The more you think about that memory, or talk about it, the stronger and easier to find that string becomes. So, your brain keeps all your memories safe by making these tiny connections between its little helpers, like making special paths for all your amazing stories and facts!

title: since people with higher metabolisms are turning more energy stores into usable energy, do they have more energy?
text: Imagine your body is like a toy car, and food is like the batteries that make it go. Some toy cars use their batteries really, really fast – they zoom around and do lots of things quickly! That's kind of like having a high metabolism. But just because the car uses its batteries fast doesn't mean it *has* more batteries inside it than another car. It just means it uses the batteries it *does* have much quicker. So, people with a higher metabolism burn through their 'food batteries' faster, which means they might get hungry sooner or feel warmer because their body is working hard, but it doesn't mean they have an endless, super-duper amount of energy stored up forever, or that they never get tired. They just use up their fuel faster than someone whose body uses its 'food batteries' more slowly.

title: Why do stationary cars shake from high speed passing traffic, yet pedestrians barely feel a breeze?
text: When a super-duper fast car or truck zooms by, it pushes a LOT of air out of its way, like a giant invisible wave! This air wave is big and strong enough to give your car a little push because your car is big and sits on bouncy wheels

title: When someone dies from burns, is it a direct result of the burns or complications caused by the burns?
text:
Imagine your skin is like a superhero suit that keeps all your important body juice inside and keeps tiny invisible bad guys (germs) out. When someone gets a super big burn, their superhero suit gets really broken.

Sometimes, the burn is so big and hot that it hurts the body so much right away, like when a toy gets smashed really hard and can't work anymore.

But most of the time, it's like the broken suit lets out all the important body juice, so the person gets super thirsty and their insides can't work right. And also, those tiny invisible bad guys can sneak into the broken suit and make the person very, very sick.

So, it's usually not just the fire itself, but all the big problems that happen because the superhero skin suit is broken that makes the body too tired to keep going.

title: What exactly causes this sharp pain we feel during wound contact with eq. alcohol, salt or citric acid?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super strong blanket that keeps all your squishy insides safe and sound. When you get a little cut, it's like a tiny tear in your blanket, and now some of the super sensitive "ouchy" wires underneath are peeking out. These "ouchy" wires are usually tucked away and quiet, but when they're exposed, they're listening very, very closely. When things like alcohol, which is like a super strong tickly cleaner, or salt, which is like tiny thirsty monsters that suck up all the water around the wires, or even citric acid, which is like a mischievous little poke, touch these exposed "ouchy" wires, they get super excited and send a very, very loud and fast message to your brain that screams "OUCH! Something is wrong here!" That's why it feels so sharp and hurts so much – your body is trying to tell you to be careful and protect that little boo-boo!

title: Why is Bing so much worse than Google?
text: Imagine you want to find your favorite toy! Google is like your super smart big brother who has played with all the toys in the house for a very, very long time. He knows exactly where everything is, and even if you just say "red car," he probably knows *which* red car you mean because he's seen everyone play with it and knows which one is the most popular. He's had lots and lots of practice finding things! Bing is like your younger brother. He's trying his best, and he can find some toys, but he hasn't played with them as much, and he hasn't watched as many people play. So sometimes, when you say "red car," he might show you a different red car, or maybe even a red truck, because he's not quite as good at guessing exactly what you wanted yet. He's still learning how to be as super smart as your big brother Google!

title: How can other animals survive on one type of food but humans need a balanced diet?
text:
Okay, imagine your body is like a super cool house you're building! To make your house strong and pretty, you need lots of different things: bricks for the walls, wood for the roof, glass for the windows, and paint for the colors. If you only had bricks, your house wouldn't have a roof or windows, right? That's kinda like us! Our bodies need all sorts of different "building blocks" from different foods – yummy fruits and veggies give us energy to run, milk helps our bones grow strong, and meat helps our muscles. We need a little bit of everything to be super healthy and strong all over.

Now, imagine a super special animal, like a panda bear! A panda's body is like a super special house that only needs *one kind* of special brick: bamboo! Its body is *so good* at turning just bamboo into everything it needs – walls, roof, windows, everything! Or a koala that only eats eucalyptus leaves. Their bodies learned over a super, super long time (like forever!) to be experts at using just *that one thing* to get all their special building blocks. Our bodies are different because we're good at eating lots of different things to get all our different building blocks and stay super strong!

title: 'Modern humans' have existed for 130 to 300 thousand years. Why then do nearly all modern cultures seem to stem back no more than 6,000 years in origin?
text: Imagine you've been around for a super, super long time, even before you could talk or write your name! That's kind of like how humans were. We looked just

title: What is the slime that remains on clothes soaked for a long time?
text: Imagine your clothes have tiny, tiny bits of dirt, food, and even little pieces of your skin stuck to them, like invisible sprinkles! When you put them in water for a long, long time, these tiny sprinkles start to fall off into the water and float around. And guess what? Even tinier, invisible little friends called 'germs' or 'bugs' (they're super small, you can't see them!) love to eat those sprinkles and make sticky houses in the water because it's nice and wet. So, all those fallen sprinkles and the tiny bugs making their homes together make the water feel all gooey and slimy, like a yucky soup!

title: What physically ARE radio waves and what keeps different frequencies from interfering with one another?
text: Imagine you're playing with a jump rope. If you wiggle it, it makes waves, right? Radio waves are kind of like invisible wiggles, but they happen in the air all

title: Why do french fries taste bad after they’re cold?
text: Okay, imagine your french fry is like a happy, warm little stick when it's hot! It's super crispy on the outside because of the yummy oil, and soft and fluffy inside. But when it gets cold, that yummy oil gets sleepy and hard, like butter from the fridge, and it doesn't feel nice and smooth in your mouth anymore. Also, the outside stops being crunchy and gets a bit soft and bendy, and the inside potato part gets kinda hard and dry instead of fluffy. It's like the magic disappears when it's not warm anymore, making it not taste as good!

title: How are you able to hear where footsteps or gunfire are coming from in videgames?
text: Okay, imagine you have two ears, just like in real life! When someone claps their hands right next to your left ear, it sounds super loud in that ear and quieter in your other ear, right? Your brain uses that trick to know the clap came from the left. Video games do something super similar! When a monster walks on your left side in the game, the game makes the walking sound louder in your left headphone and quieter in your right one. If the monster is far away, the game makes the sound quiet overall, like it's really far. If it's close, it makes it loud! The game is just super smart and knows exactly where everything is, and it plays the sounds in your headphones just right to trick your ears into thinking the sound is coming from a certain direction, even though it's all coming from your headphones.

title: Can atoms touch?
text: Imagine atoms are like super tiny, invisible balloons, but instead of air, they have a little puffy cloud around them, like a fuzzy shield! When two balloons try to touch, their puffy clouds don't really squish together and disappear. Instead, the clouds bump into each other and gently push away, like when you try to push the same sides of two magnets together – *boop!* They just can't get *right* next to each other because their invisible puffy shields are always pushing back. So, when you touch a toy, it feels solid because all those tiny atom clouds are pushing back against your hand's atom clouds, never truly letting them 'touch' like you touch your teddy bear.

title: Why is it illegal to use tear gas on enemy combatants, but not on civilians in the US?
text: Okay, imagine tear gas is like super-duper strong onion juice that makes your eyes sting and cry a lot! When countries are having a big, serious fight (like a war), all the grown-up countries made a special rule that says you can

title: Why do people sometimes throw up/feel like throwing up after intense exercise/physical activity?
text: When you run super-duper fast or play really, really hard, your body needs lots and lots of energy right away! Your blood is like tiny delivery trucks that carry food and

title: Either the universe continues indefinitely, or it has an edge somewhere, both boggle the mind to imagine, which is correct?
text: Imagine the whole universe is like a super, super, super big room, bigger than all the houses and parks put together! You're asking if this giant room just keeps going and going forever

title: Why does regular water taste different from water that has melted from ice?
text: Imagine your regular water is like a happy playground with tiny, invisible air bubbles and super tiny, invisible sprinkles floating all around – these make it taste a certain way! When water gets super cold and turns into ice, it's like the ice pushes out a lot of those tiny air bubbles and some of the sprinkles, making them leave or get stuck in different spots. So, when the ice melts back into water, it doesn't have as many of those playful air bubbles or sprinkles anymore, which makes it taste a little bit different, sometimes a bit flatter or super clean, because it's lost some of its tiny, invisible friends!

title: How does new money enter circulation in the United States?
text: Imagine the government is like a grown-up who has a special magic printer for money, but they don't just print it whenever they want to give it away, because then everyone would have too much, and things would get super, super expensive! Instead, they print new money when they need to buy important things for everyone, like building new roads for cars or paying teachers to teach kids in school. They also give some of this new money to special big piggy banks called "banks." These banks then let other grown-ups borrow the money to buy new houses, or start a new toy store, or make a new kind of candy. When people borrow and spend this money, it goes around and around, from one person's pocket to another, helping everyone buy and sell things they need and want. So, new money comes out when the grown-ups in charge buy things for everyone, or when banks lend it to other grown-ups to help new ideas and shops start up!

title: Why is it that the area of a sphere (4 pi r^2) and the area of a circle (pi r^2) differ by a factor of 4?
text: Okay, imagine you have a flat, round cookie. That's like the circle we're talking about, and its "area" is how much yummy stuff is on top! Now

title: Why does water taste so terrible after eating an apple?
text: Okay, imagine your mouth and your tongue are like a little party place! When you eat a yummy apple, it brings lots of sweet and sometimes a little bit of sour party flavors that dance all over your tongue. Your tongue gets super excited and all its little taste helpers are still looking for those fun apple tastes. Then, when you drink plain water, the water doesn't have any of those strong party flavors – it's just plain and quiet. Because your tongue was expecting more of the big, exciting apple party, the plain water feels a little bit boring or even a little yucky because it's so different from all the fun apple tastes that were just there! It's like when you're listening to a super loud, happy song and then suddenly it gets very, very quiet – the quiet can feel strange at first.

title: Why do siblings (especially sisters) often have very similar-sounding voices?
text: Imagine you and your sister are both like little building blocks made from the same special recipe from your mom and dad. This recipe tells your body how to grow, like what color your eyes will be or how tall you might get. It also tells your body how to make the little "singing strings" inside your throat, called vocal cords, and the little box they sit in. Since you both got almost the same recipe from the same parents, your singing strings and voice box are often built very, very similarly! When these similar strings vibrate, they make sounds that are super alike. Girls' singing strings usually stay a pretty similar size as they grow up, which helps keep their voices sounding like each other. Plus, you live together and hear each other talk all the time, which can make you sound a little bit like you're singing the same song too!

title: Why is it important to do stretches before exercising (i.e. pull-ups, push-ups, weightlifting, etc)?
text: Imagine your muscles are like little rubber bands inside your body. If you try to stretch a cold, stiff rubber band really fast, *snap!* it might break, right? Or maybe it's like play-doh that's been in the fridge – hard and crumbly. When you do stretches before you run, jump, or lift things, it's like gently warming up those rubber bands or squishing the cold play-doh. You're telling your muscles, "Hey, wake up! It's time to play!" They get warm, soft, and super stretchy. When your muscles are warm and stretchy, they can move much bigger and stronger without getting hurt. It helps you do your pull-ups, push-ups, or lift weights better, and it stops your body from feeling ouchy or getting a boo-boo. So, stretching helps you play harder and stay safe!

title: If carbon dioxide is bad for you to inhale, and people provide it when you breath out, Wouldn't the carbon dioxide do any damage to the person getting mouth to mouth?
text: That's a super smart question! Imagine your breath like a yummy juice box. When you take a big sip, you drink most of the juice, but there's always a little bit left in the box, right? When you breathe out, you let go of some 'used air' (that's carbon dioxide), but there's still lots and lots of 'good air' (that's oxygen!) left in your breath too, just like the little bit of juice in the box. So, when someone gives mouth-to-mouth, they're not blowing *only* used air. They're blowing mostly good air with just a tiny bit of used air mixed in. The person who needs mouth-to-mouth needs *any* air so badly to help their body work, that getting even a little bit of mostly good air is super important and much, much better than getting no air at all!

title: When a tree grows, where does it's matter come from?
text: Imagine a tree is like a hungry, thirsty giant! It drinks lots and lots of water from the ground, just like you drink juice. But it also "eats" something you can't see – the air all around it! It has tiny mouths on its leaves that suck in the air. Then, with a little help from the sun, which is like a big magic light, the tree mixes the water and the air together inside itself. This mix turns into new wood, new leaves, and new branches, making the tree bigger and bigger! A tiny bit also comes from the dirt, like yummy vitamins for the tree.

title: Why does a higher air humidity cause us to sweat more?
text:
Okay, imagine your body is like a little oven that gets warm. To cool down, your body makes sweat, which is like tiny drops of water on your skin. When these water drops float away into the air (like water drying up from a puddle), they take some of your warmth with them, and that makes you feel cooler!

Now, humidity means the air is already full of water, like a big, fluffy cloud all around us. Think of it like a sponge that's already soaking wet. On a dry day, the air-sponge is empty and thirsty, so it

title: Since our bodies aren't 100% efficient at absorbing nutrients from food, wouldn't the nutritional information found on most food packaging be inaccurate, as not all of the calories, protein etc. are absorbed?
text: Imagine you have a big jar of yummy candies, and the label on the jar tells you there are 100 candies inside! That number is super true for *all* the candies

title: Does Speaking A Foreign Language Change Your Personality?
text: Imagine you have your favorite teddy bear. Your teddy bear is always the same teddy bear, right? But sometimes you might give it a little hat, or pretend it's a superhero, or make it talk in a funny voice! It's still the same teddy bear, but it acts a little different for the game. Speaking a different language is a bit like that for you. You are still YOU inside, with all your feelings and ideas. But when you talk in a different language, it's like putting on a different "talking hat." Maybe in one language, people talk a bit louder or use their hands more, so you might do that too. Or maybe some words in that language make you feel a little shyer or a little sillier. It's not that your personality *changes*, it's just that you show a slightly different side of yourself, like wearing a different outfit for a different game. You're still the same wonderful person underneath!

title: How does fast charge in mobile phones work?
text: Imagine your phone's battery is like a tiny cup that needs to be filled with juice (that's the electricity!). When you charge your phone normally, it's like pouring juice into the cup slowly, drip by drip. It takes a while, right? Fast charging is like having a bigger jug and pouring the juice much, much faster into the cup! Your phone and its special charger are super smart friends. The charger says, "Hey phone, I can give you a lot of juice really fast!" And the phone says, "Okay, but only pour super fast when I'm really empty!" So, when your phone's cup is almost empty, the charger pours the juice really, really fast. But as the cup gets fuller and fuller, the phone tells the charger, "Whoa, slow down now, or it will spill!" So the charger starts pouring slower and slower until the cup is full. That way, your phone gets full of juice much quicker when it's super hungry, but it's still safe because it slows down before it gets too full!

title: Is there another type of wave besides the fluctuations in the electromagnetic field and the ones in the "physical one"?
text: Okay, imagine waves! You know how if you splash in the bathtub, the water makes wiggles? Or if you shake a jump rope, it makes wiggles? Those waves need something to wiggle, like water or the rope. And then

title: Why can't the asteroid belt accumulate into one rocky planet?
text: Imagine you have a giant box full of LEGO bricks that want to build a super-duper big castle. Normally, if you leave them alone, they might bump into each other and stick together, and then more and more LEGOs would join until you have one giant castle. That's how planets are usually made! But in the middle of our space neighborhood, there's a big line of rocks called the asteroid belt, and they just can't make one big planet-castle. That's because there's a super-duper giant kid named Jupiter nearby. Jupiter is so, so big and strong that he keeps pulling on all those little rocks. It's like he's shaking the whole box! Every time the rocks try to get close enough to stick and build their planet-castle, Jupiter's big pull makes them zoom past each other too fast, or even crash and break into smaller pieces. So, instead of one big planet, you just have lots and lots of little rocks zooming around forever because Jupiter won't let them stick together.

title: How do automatic windshield wipers know when the windshield is wet?
text: Okay, imagine your car has a super special little eye, kind of like your own, that's really good at seeing water! This little eye is usually hidden on your windshield, and it's always looking at the glass. It shines a tiny, invisible light onto the window. When the window is dry, the light bounces back to the eye in one way. But when rain starts to fall and water gets on the glass, the water makes the light bounce back differently! The special eye notices this change and thinks, "Aha! Water!" Then, it quickly tells the wiper arms, "Quick, time to clean!" And *whoosh*, your wipers start moving to make the window clear again, just like magic!

title: How does the human body know when to go into labor?
text: Imagine mommy's tummy is like a super cozy little room where the baby grows and grows! When the baby has gotten big enough and strong enough, and it's time to come out and meet everyone, the baby actually sends little secret 'I'm ready!' messages to mommy's body! Mommy's body also has its own special calendar and clock that says, 'Okay, it's been about this much time, the baby should be ready now.' So, when both the baby's 'I'm ready!' messages and mommy's body's clock agree that it's the perfect time, mommy's body starts to get everything prepared for the baby to come out and say hello! It's like everyone, even the baby, knows exactly when the big day is here.

title: Why do we feel elated when we help someone?
text: When you help someone, like sharing your toy or picking up something they dropped, you make *them* feel happy! And guess what? When you see someone else happy because of *you*, it makes a super warm, bubbly feeling start in *your* tummy and spread all over. It's like your brain gives you a little high-five and says, "Yay, you did something good!" because being kind and helping others makes everyone feel better and makes the world a nicer place to play in. It's a happy secret your brain knows!

title: Why not grow brain-dead babies to harvest their organs?
text: Imagine a little baby, just like you were when you were super tiny. Sometimes, babies get very, very sick, and their special thinking part, their brain, stops working forever. Even if their heart is still beating for a little while, it means the baby isn't really *there* anymore, like when a light bulb burns out and doesn't light up the room. We don't grow people like we grow flowers in a garden, because people are special and have feelings and dreams. When a baby's brain stops working forever, it means they can't ever wake up, or laugh, or play, or feel anything at all. Taking parts from someone, even when they're very, very sick, is something we only do if they can't ever be alive again,

title: How come a few feet can make a difference in signal strength even when the signal is coming from miles away?
text: Imagine your friend is trying to whisper a secret to you from way, way across the park, like miles away! By the time their voice gets to you, it's super-duper quiet, almost impossible to hear. Now, if you just put your hand over your ear, or a big tree is right next to you, or even if your teddy bear is sitting right in front of your face, that already super-quiet whisper might not make it the last few steps to your ear at all! It's not that their voice got *more* tired in those few feet, but those little things right next to you can block it because it was already so quiet from traveling so far. Signals are just like that tired whisper; they're very weak when they get to you from far away, so even a little wall, a big chair, or even your own body can block them completely in those last few steps!

title: Why do some objects melt when heated and others just burst into flames?
text: Okay, imagine you have two different toys! One is like a yummy chocolate bar, and the other is like a piece of paper. When you put the chocolate bar near something warm, like the sun, it gets all soft and turns into a gooey puddle, right? It's still chocolate, just melty chocolate! That's because the tiny, tiny pieces that make up the chocolate just get wiggly and move apart, but they are still the same chocolate pieces. Now, if you put the paper near a super hot fire, it doesn't turn into a puddle. Instead, it gets really hot, makes a bright light, turns into

title: What does the quote "He who fights with monsters should be careful lest he thereby become a monster. And if thou gaze long into an abyss, the abyss will also gaze into thee" mean?
text: Imagine you're trying to stop a big, grumpy monster from doing mean things. This quote says that if you spend all your time fighting that monster, you have to be super careful not to start acting like a monster yourself, like yelling or being grumpy, even when you just want to help! And it also means that if you look at something really, really sad or scary for a long, long time, like a super dark, deep hole, that sadness or scary feeling can start to sneak into you and make you feel sad or scared too. So, it's like a grown-up way of saying, be careful when you're around bad or sad things, because they can sometimes make you feel or act that way too, even if you don't mean to.

title: How did we settle on twelve pitches to be the musical notes? What is the pattern behind 1,3,5 major chord/triad?
text: Imagine music is like a big, magical ladder where each step makes a different sound. When you go all the way up the ladder and then start again, the sound is the same,

title: How does currency exchange work exactly?
text: Imagine you have a big bag of yummy chocolate coins, but your friend from another country has shiny silver coins that taste like mint! You both want to try each other's coins, but you can't just use your chocolate coins in their candy store, and they can't use their mint coins in your chocolate shop. So, what do you do? You go to a special grown-up place, like a bank or a money shop, and they help you swap! You give them some of your chocolate coins, and they give you some of your friend's mint coins. But it's not always one-for-one! Sometimes, a grown-up decides that your chocolate coins are super popular right now, so for one of your chocolate coins, you might get *two* of your friend's mint coins! Or maybe their mint coins are super special, so you have to give *two* of your chocolate coins to get just *one* of theirs. That's how it works! You give your country's money, and you get the other country's money, and how much you get depends on how much grown-ups think each kind of money is worth that day, kind of like trading toys!

title: Why do certain drugs make your pupils change size?
text: Imagine your eye has a little black window in the middle, called the pupil. This window gets bigger when it's dark, so more light can come in and help you see, and it gets smaller when it's super bright, to protect your eyes from too much sun. Your brain is like the boss that tells this little window what to do. Now, when some special medicines (drugs) go into your body, they can go up to your brain and whisper funny messages to it. Some drugs might trick your brain into thinking it's super dark, even if it's bright, so your brain tells your pupil-window to open really wide! Other drugs might trick your brain into thinking it's super bright, so your brain tells your pupil-window to close up tiny. It's like the drugs are playing a trick on your brain's light switch for your eyes!

title: What causes dandruff & why are some people more susceptible to it than others?
text: Imagine your head skin is like a busy little factory that makes new skin cells all the time, like making new LEGO bricks. And it also cleans up the old ones, like throwing away old broken LEGOs. Usually, it does this nice and slow, so you don't even notice. title: How do CRT displays have the ability to display video below the maximum resolution without the use of interpolation?

But if the show isn't super detailed, or wants to make a less detailed picture, the TV doesn't try to guess or make up extra dots. No, no! It just uses its magic pen to draw *fewer* dots, or maybe makes each dot a little bit bigger, and those dots still perfectly fill up the whole drawing board. It's like drawing with a thick crayon instead of a super-thin one; you're just drawing the picture directly with the dots you have, without trying to make them look like something they're not.

title: What is it about cyanide that kills you within seconds on oral contact? What are other compounds more potent than this?

When the oxygen helpers are tied up, they can't do their job anymore, so all the lights in your house go out everywhere, really, really quickly, and your house just stops working. That's why it makes you very, very sick and stops your body so fast. Even though cyanide is a super mean villain, there are even *meaner* villains out there, like ones called botulinum toxin or ricin. They are like super-duper-villains because they can tie up the oxygen helpers even faster or with even smaller amounts, causing big trouble in your body's house even more quickly.

title: Why are human eye colours restricted to brown, blue, green, and in extremely rare cases, red, as opposed to other colours?
text: Imagine your eyes are like a special window, and inside that window, we have tiny, tiny sprinkles, just like on a birthday cake! Most people have brown eyes because they have lots and lots of these brown sprinkles. The more sprinkles, the browner your eyes look. Some people have fewer sprinkles. When there aren't many brown sprinkles, something cool happens! The light that shines into your eye bounces around in a special way, and it makes your eyes look blue or green, even though there aren't actually blue or green sprinkles in there! It's like how the sky looks blue, but there's no blue paint in the sky, right? It's just how the light plays a trick. Green eyes are like having a tiny bit more brown sprinkle mixed with that light trick. Very, very, very rarely, some people have almost no sprinkles at all, and then you can sometimes see the tiny red lines that carry blood, like little red roads in your eyes, making them look a little red. We don't have purple or yellow eyes because our eyes only have that one kind of brown sprinkle. We don't have different colored sprinkles like purple or yellow ones, and the light only plays those specific blue or green tricks with the brown sprinkles we do have. So, our eyes only come in those yummy brown, blue, and green colors, and sometimes a tiny bit of red!

title: Whats with the crazy head jerking movements with chickens and some other types of birds when they walk?

So, what they do is a clever trick! They quickly push their head forward, and then they hold it super, super still for a tiny moment, like they're freezing a picture. While their head is still, their eyes can look around and see everything perfectly clear. Then, their body catches up, and they quickly push their head forward again to freeze another clear picture. It helps them make sure they don't miss anything important while they're walking!

That's why some pimples take many days to show up. Other times, the traffic jam starts right at the very, very top of the tunnel, super close to the outside! So, it only takes a tiny little bit of gunk to get stuck there, and *poof!* – a little bump appears super fast, sometimes in just a few hours, because it didn't have to travel far at all.

title: How "cancer cells" appear?

These naughty, rule-breaking bricks that keep growing and growing even when they shouldn't are what we call cancer cells. title: How do we know that trees and plants do not experience pain when we cut them?

title: Why does food taste differently depending on its temperature?
text: Okay, imagine your tongue has tiny helpers called taste buds, like little doors that open for yummy flavors! When your food is warm, the tiny flavor pieces inside the food are super excited and wiggle around a lot! They bump into those taste bud doors really fast and open them up, so you taste all the yummy flavors super well. But when your food is cold, those tiny flavor pieces get sleepy and slow. They don't wiggle as much or knock on the doors as hard, so your taste buds can't always find all the flavors, and some tastes, especially sweet ones, might hide a little bit. That's why a warm cookie tastes so strong and yummy, but a cold one might taste a little less sweet, because the flavors are being a bit shy!

title: Why do we feel exhausted after thinking all day?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super special toy car that needs batteries to go zoom! When you play with your toy car all day, making it zoom, zoom, zoom, the batteries get all used up, right? And then the car stops or goes really, really slow. Your brain is a bit like that! When you think all day long – learning new things, solving puzzles, remembering names – it's like your brain is doing lots and lots of zooming. All that thinking uses up a special kind of energy, like the batteries for your toy car. When your brain's energy gets low, it feels tired, just like your legs feel tired after running all day. It's your brain's way of saying, "Phew! I need a rest now to recharge my batteries so I can zoom again tomorrow!" So, you feel sleepy and want to relax so your brain can get all its energy back.

title: Why are brains in the vulnerable head rather than in the thorax with the other vital organs?

title: When you are holding in a pee, why does it feel UNBEARABLE at times and then 45 seconds later it's subsided?

Time to go potty!" That's why you feel like you need to pee. Sometimes, when it's super, super full, that message gets really, really loud, like a big alarm bell ringing in your head, making it feel like you just can't wait anymore! But then, your super smart body knows you can't always go right that second. So, sometimes, your brain tells that little balloon to calm down and relax just a tiny bit, or it changes how it's sending that "go pee!" message. It's like the alarm bell gets a little quieter for a short time, saying, "Okay, I'll wait just a little bit longer, but don't forget me!" It doesn't mean the pee is gone from your balloon, just that your body figured out how to make it feel a little less urgent for a moment, but you still need to find a potty soon!

title: Why do some cysts and zits appear to have multiple chambers?
