title: Why do limbs get all fuzzy feeling when you lay on them or leave them in a weird position?
text: Imagine your arm or leg has tiny roads inside, and little cars (that's your blood!) drive on them to bring food and energy. There are also tiny telephone wires (those are your nerves!) that send messages to your brain, like 'move my hand!' or 'this is tickly!'. When you lay on your arm funny, it's like putting a big, heavy pillow on those roads and telephone wires. The little cars can't drive as well, and the telephone wires get squished and can't send messages properly. So, your arm feels a bit sleepy! When you move and take the pillow off, the cars start driving again, and the telephone wires wake up and start sending messages super fast all at once, which makes that funny, fuzzy, tingly feeling. It's just your arm saying, 'Yay, I'm awake again!'

title: How did David Bowies eyes, one dilated, affect his visual perception?
text: Imagine your eyes are like two little windows that let light into your head so you can see! The black dot in the middle of your eye is like a curtain for the window. Usually, when it's super sunny, both curtains close a little to let just enough light in, so you don't get blinded. And when it's dark, both curtains open super wide to let lots of light in so you can see better. For David Bowie, one of his curtains got stuck! It was always open wide, like it was dark, even when it was bright outside

title: why are credit/debit card authorizations painfully slow?
text: Imagine you're at the store with Mommy, and she wants to buy you a treat. When she puts her card in the machine, it's like the store's computer needs to ask a whole bunch of grown-ups far away if it's okay. First, it asks a big company (like Visa or Mastercard) if the card is real. Then, that big company sends a message all the way to Mommy's bank, which is like her special piggy bank where all her money lives. Mommy's bank quickly checks to make sure she has enough money for the treat, or if she's allowed to borrow a little bit. After checking, Mommy's bank sends a message *all the way back* to the big company, and then *back to the store's computer* to say "Yes!" or "No!" All these messages travel super fast, like tiny

title: why do female praying mantises eat their mates?
text: Okay, imagine a mommy mantis is going to have lots and lots of baby mantises, like you might have a whole bunch of toys! Making all those babies takes a *lot* of energy, like when you run around and play all day and then you're super hungry. Sometimes, after the daddy mantis helps her make the babies, the mommy mantis is *so* hungry and needs all the food she can get to be strong and make sure her babies grow up healthy. And guess what? Daddy mantis is a really big, yummy meal for her! So, she eats him to get all that power and food inside her tummy so her babies can be super strong when they hatch. It's like she's getting a giant snack to help her do her very important job!

title: How does the body stay warm?
text: Imagine your body is like a super special house, and it always wants to stay warm and cozy inside, even when it's chilly outside! How does it do it? Well, when you eat yummy food, it's like putting special fuel into your body's little heater. Your body uses that food to run, play, and even just think, and all that work makes a little bit of warmth, like a tiny fire burning gently inside you. Your skin is like a snuggly blanket that wraps all that warmth up and keeps it from floating away. And sometimes, if you get a little too cold, your body does a quick little wiggle dance called shivering, which is like turning up your tiny heater for a moment to make even more warmth super fast!

title: What would happen to an aeroplane trying to land while there was an earthquake? Would it have to wait until the earthquake has finished to land? Or would it land anyway?
text: Imagine your toy airplane is flying high up in the sky, ready to land on its special long road called a runway. But suddenly, the ground starts to wiggle and shake, shake, shake really hard, just like when you wiggle a blanket! That's an earthquake. Landing an airplane on a wiggly, shaky road would be super, super tricky and could be dangerous because the plane might bounce too much or the road might even have cracks. The pilot, who is in charge of keeping everyone super safe, would say, 'Whoa! Not safe to land right now!' They would fly the airplane around in big circles in the sky, like a bird waiting for the ground to be still again. Or, if the shaking is going to last a long time, they might even fly to a different airport far, far away that isn't shaking at all. They would definitely wait until the earthquake is all finished, and grown-ups on the ground have checked to make sure the runway is perfectly smooth and safe again for the airplane to land.

title: Why does biting aluminum foil feel unpleasant but biting on a metal spoon or fork doesn't?
text: Okay, imagine your mouth is all wet with your spit, right? Aluminum foil is a super thin, special kind of metal. Now, when that aluminum foil touches your teeth and your wet spit all at the same time, it's like a tiny, tiny science trick happens! It makes a super tiny, quick "buzz" or a little "zap!" It feels really yucky and makes your teeth feel funny, almost like a little "ouchie," because it's a tiny electric tingle. Spoons and forks are made of a different kind of metal that doesn't do this special "buzz" with your spit, so they don't give you that funny, yucky feeling.

title: Around what prevalence rate would it be appropriate to consider a disorder "rare"?
text: Imagine you have a really, really big school, with so many kids, maybe like 10,000 children all together! If only a tiny, tiny handful of those kids – like just 5 of them – have a super special kind of tummy ache or a funny way their body works that makes them different, then we would say that special tummy ache is "rare." It means almost nobody has it, and it's super uncommon, like finding a purple crayon in a box of only red ones! So, if it's less than 5 kids out of that huge group of 10,000, we call it rare.

title: why does a 1080p movie, on a 1080p screen, have black horizontal bars at the top and bottom?
text: Imagine your TV screen is like a rectangle drawing paper, and it's always the same shape. Now, movies are like different drawings, and sometimes the people who make the movies decide to draw their picture in a *different* rectangle shape – maybe it's a lot wider than your TV's paper. Even though both your drawing paper (TV) and the movie drawing have lots and lots of tiny dots (that's what 1080p means, just how many dots!), their *shapes* can be different. So, when a movie drawing is wider than your TV's paper, your TV tries to show the whole wide picture, but because it can't stretch its own paper to be *that* wide, it just puts black stripes at the top and bottom where there's no movie picture to fill. It's like trying to fit a very long, skinny toy car into a regular shoebox – there's extra space at the top and bottom of the box!

title: What does our brain experience when we try to understand really large numbers or the size of the universe, and what causes this limitation?
text: When you try to think about how many stars there are, or how big the whole universe is, your brain feels a little bit like when you try to count all the tiny sprinkles on a giant birthday cake – it just goes 'Whoa! That's too many!' It gets a little bit tired and confused because it can't make a clear picture in your head. That's because our brains are super good at counting things we can touch, like your fingers or your toys, or even all the kids in your class. But when numbers get so, so, *so* big, bigger than anything you've ever seen or touched in real life, your brain doesn't have a picture for them. It's like trying to imagine a color that doesn't exist – your brain just doesn't have a spot for it because it's never seen anything that huge before. So it just understands it as a really, really, *really* big 'LOT!'

title: Why is cat5 wire used for data? Could regular 18/2 wire do the same thing?
text: Imagine you want to send a super fast secret message to your friend! Cat5 wire is like a special road with lots of tiny, twisty paths inside, like little tunnels that go around and around. These twisty tunnels are super good at keeping your secret message from getting mixed up with other noises, and because there

title: how does general anesthesia make a person fall asleep?
text: Imagine your brain is like the super important boss of your whole body, and it's always listening to everything, especially if there's an "ouchie" feeling or if it needs to tell your hands to wiggle. When you get special sleepy medicine, called anesthesia, it's like someone gently puts a soft, cozy blanket over your brain and tells it, "Shhh, time for a super deep nap!" This sleepy medicine makes your brain take a really long, quiet rest. While your brain is taking its nap, it can't hear any "ouchie" messages from your body, and it can't tell your body to move or feel anything at all. It's just sleeping soundly, almost like you're dreaming, so the doctors can do their important work without you knowing or feeling a single thing. Then, when the medicine slowly goes away, your brain gently wakes up from its nap, and you're back to playing!

title: If you stay up long enough, why do you stop feeling tired?
text: Imagine your body is like a toy car that needs batteries to run. When you play a lot, your batteries start to get low, and your body tells you, "I'm tired, I need to rest!" That's when you feel sleepy. But if you keep playing with the toy car even when the batteries are super, super low, sometimes for a little while, the car finds a tiny, secret bit of extra power to keep going just a *little* longer, like a tiny emergency boost! Your body does something similar. When you stay up *super* late, past when you should be sleeping, your body gets a little confused and tries to help you by giving you a tiny, temporary boost of energy. It's like your body saying, "Okay, one last push!" This makes you feel less tired for a little bit, but it's not real energy, and your body still really, really needs to go to sleep to recharge those batteries properly!

title: Why do we get those weird wrinkles/lines on our faces or body after sleeping?
text: Imagine your face is like a super soft, squishy marshmallow! When you sleep, you snuggle your face or body into your comfy pillow or mattress. It's like pressing your hand into a soft piece of playdough – it leaves a mark, right? Your pillow gently pushes on your soft skin and makes little squishy lines, just like when you fold a piece of paper and it gets a crease. But don't worry! Your skin is super bouncy and smart, so after you wake up and move around a bit, those funny lines usually smooth out and disappear all by themselves, just like a squished marshmallow slowly puffing back up!

title: What does the "Night Shift" feature on an iPhone actually do? What are it's benefits?
text: Imagine your phone screen is like a magic window. During the day, it shines with bright, blue light, kind of like the sun in the sky! That blue light is good for helping you stay awake and play. But when it gets dark outside and it's almost time for bed, your phone can be a bit tricky. The bright blue light can trick your brain into thinking it's still daytime, making it harder for you to feel sleepy and go to sleep. So, "Night Shift" is like putting a special warm blanket over your phone screen! It makes the screen look a little bit more yellow or orange, like a cozy campfire or the sunset. This warmer light doesn't trick your brain as much. It tells your brain, "Hey, it's getting dark, time to get ready for sleep!" This helps your eyes feel less tired when you look at your phone at night, and it helps your brain get ready to fall asleep more easily, so you can have nice dreams!

title: What is the feeling of semi-weakness people sometimes get when they are cold?
text: Imagine your body is like a warm, cozy blanket for your muscles. When it's nice and warm, your muscles are super happy and can run and play really fast! But when it gets cold, your muscles get a little bit like play-doh that's been in the fridge – a bit stiff and harder to squish and move. Your body also uses a lot of its special energy to try and keep you warm, like a tiny heater inside you. So, it doesn't have as much energy left over to make your muscles feel super strong and ready to zoom, which makes you feel a little bit tired and not as bouncy as usual.

title: How do our bodies know when to make blood and when to stop making blood?
text: Imagine your body is like a super important water park, and blood is like the water that fills all the pools and slides to keep everyone happy and moving! Your body has tiny, super-smart helpers, like little managers, who are always checking how much water there is. If you get a little boo-boo and some water splashes out, or if your body just needs more water to grow big and strong, these helpers send a special message, like a secret signal, to the 'blood making factory' deep inside your bones! This factory then gets busy making more fresh, red blood, like a baker making more yummy cookies when the cookie jar is

title: How do the people that transcribe court proceedings live do it? Looks like they have a minimal typewriter.
text: Imagine there's a grown-up whose job is to write down *every single word* that people say in court, like a super-fast secret keeper so nobody forgets anything important! They have a very special little typing machine, like a tiny piano, that's not like your mom's computer keyboard. Instead of typing one letter at a time, like 'c-a-t', they push a few buttons at once that make *sounds* or parts of words. It's like they've learned a secret code where one push can mean a whole sound like 'shhh' or 'ing'. Because they can press many buttons at the same time to make these sound-codes, they can type super-duper fast, way faster than anyone can write with a pen! Then, a smart computer helps turn all those special sound-codes into real, understandable words later, so we have a perfect story of everything that was said.

title: How does an ISP plug into the internet?
text: Imagine your house is like a little toy car garage, and you want your toy car (your computer!) to drive all over the world to visit other garages and play. But your garage only has a little driveway. Your ISP (that's the company that gives you internet) is like a special road-building company! They build a bigger road from your driveway, and then they connect *their* big road to an even *bigger* super-duper highway. This super highway is like the main part of the whole internet, where all the other ISPs and all the other roads from all the other houses meet up. So, your ISP just builds a really long, special road from your house all the way to the giant internet highway, letting your toy car zoom wherever it wants to go!

title: How does modern recycling work? How are containers filled with food handled? What percentage of recyclables are actually thrown out?
text: Imagine you have a special bin at home where you put your empty juice boxes, plastic bottles, and old papers. A big truck comes and picks them all up, taking them to a super busy place

title: How does an animal adapt its skin colour to its environment?
text: Imagine your favorite toy could change its color all by itself! Well, some clever animals can do that with their skin. They change their color so they can play the best game of hide-and

title: If any distance can be halved, at what point do you stop touching something?
text: That's a super smart question! It's kind of like thinking about walking to your teddy bear. You can always take a step that's half the way there, then another step that's half of *that* tiny bit, and then another step that's half of *that* super tiny bit! It feels like you'd never get there because the steps get so, so small. But even though the steps get super duper tiny, they still add up and make you reach the teddy bear! So, you stop touching something the very moment you move your hand away from it. All those little half-steps just help you get your hand right onto it, and then you're touching it until you decide to lift your hand off.

title: How do constellations stay the same in such a violent place like our galaxy?
text: Imagine you have a big picture of dots on a super, super giant wall, so big you can barely see the whole thing! Now, imagine those dots are actually tiny little lights that are moving

title: How do earphones produce adequate bass despite their size?
text: Imagine you have a big drum. When you hit it, it makes a big "boom" sound that shakes the air, and you can feel it even far away. That's like big speakers making bass! Now, imagine you have a tiny toy drum, and you put it right against your ear. Even if you tap it softly, you can hear that little "boom" sound really well, right? Earphones are like that tiny toy drum! They don't need to make a super big shake of air because they are right inside your ear, like a secret little room just for the sound. Your ear is a small tunnel, and when the earphone makes even a little push of air inside that tunnel, it feels like a much bigger push because the sound has nowhere to go but right into your ear. It's like whispering a secret right into your ear – you hear it clearly even if it's not loud. So, even though they are small, they are super close to your ear, making the low "boom" sounds feel just right!

title: They say 70% of taste is smell. When we smell, let's say a public restroom, are we actually inhaling and "tasting" particles?
text: Imagine your nose and your tongue are best friends who always work together to figure out what things are! Your nose is like a super helper for your tongue, telling it lots of important secrets about food. That's why when you have a stuffy nose, food tastes a bit boring, because your nose can't whisper those secrets. When you smell something, like a flower or a stinky restroom, tiny, invisible pieces of that thing float up into your nose. Your nose has special sniffers that catch these tiny bits and send a message to your brain, like 'Mmm, flower!' or 'Yuck, stinky!' So, yes, you are breathing in those tiny bits. Your brain then uses that smell information, and because your nose and tongue are such good friends, your brain might make you *feel* like you're tasting

title: Why are anti viral drugs only used for life threatening viruses?
text: Imagine your body is like a big house, and viruses are like tiny, sneaky bad guys who hide inside your rooms. Anti-viral medicines are like special police trying to catch these bad guys. But because the bad guys hide *inside* your rooms, the police might accidentally bump into your furniture (your healthy body parts) while trying to get them, which can sometimes make you feel a little bit yucky. For most little sniffle-bad-guys, your body's own superhero cells are super good at kicking them out all by themselves! So, we only use the special police (the strong medicine) when the bad guys are super, super strong and dangerous, and your body really needs extra help to win the fight and keep you safe and healthy. We don't want to use the strong medicine when your body can do it on its own, because it's strong stuff!

title: Is there such a thing as conscious and subconscious brain?
text: Yes! Imagine your brain is like a super-duper clever house with lots of rooms and helpers inside. One room is where *you* are right now, making choices and thinking about what to say or play. That's your "conscious" brain – it's the part you use when you're awake and deciding things. But then there are lots of other helpers in the house doing super important jobs all the time without you even having to tell them! They make your heart beat, help you breathe, and remember how to walk or ride your bike without you thinking about every single step. That's your "subconscious" brain – it's like the quiet, hardworking helpers doing things in the background so you don't have to worry about them. So, it's not two separate brains, but one amazing brain doing different kinds of jobs, some you think about and some you don't!

title: Why does being outside in the cold cause a runny nose/other cold like symptoms? I was under the impression that cold weather causing a cold was a myth.
text: Imagine your nose is like a warm, wet cave that helps get the air ready for your lungs! When you go outside and it's super cold, your nose tries extra hard to warm up

title: What would the real world consequences of things the privates did in Full Metal Jacket be? (spoilers)
text:
Okay, imagine you're playing a very serious game, like when you have to follow big rules, but it's called "war."

First, when Pyle hurt his boss,

title: Why do we get bored? What is the psychological reasoning behind it?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little explorer, always wanting to see new things and go on fun adventures! When you're doing something that isn't new or exciting anymore, or if you're just sitting still with nothing much to do, your brain explorer starts to get a little bit grumpy. It's like your brain is saying, "Ho hum, this isn't very interesting! I want to find something new to learn or play!" That grumpy feeling is what we call boredom. It's actually a clever signal from your brain telling you, "Hey! I'm ready for a new challenge! Let's go find something exciting to make me happy again!" So, boredom isn't bad; it's just your brain's way of telling you it's time to go find a new game or a new adventure!

title: How do music/video editing programs isolate vocals, frequency, pitch, etc.?
text: Imagine a song is like a big, yummy soup with lots of different ingredients, like carrots, potatoes, and peas, all mixed together! The singer's voice is like the carrots, the

title: Why is it that almost all microsoft pc's start their drives with C? Why not A?
text: Imagine your computer is like a big toy box! A very, very long time ago, when computers were just little babies, they had two small, special toy boxes called "A" and "B". These were for tiny, flat disks, like thin pizzas, that held just a few toys. Then, computers got a much, much bigger toy box *inside* them, where they could keep ALL the toys forever! Because A and B were already taken by the little pizza disks, this big, main toy box got the next letter: "C". Now, we don't really use those little pizza disks (A and B) anymore, but C is still the main big toy box because everyone got used to it, and it just stuck that way! So your computer always starts looking for its toys in the C toy box first.

title: Why do non-clinical people (receptionists, etc.) in doctor’s offices wear scrubs?
text: Imagine your doctor's office is like a big team, kind of like your favorite sports team! Everyone on the team wears a special uniform, right? Scrubs are like that special uniform for the grown-ups who work at the doctor's office, even the ones who just say hello at the front desk. It helps everyone know they are part of the same helpful team, and it's also really comfy clothes to wear all day long, and super easy to wash if they get a little smudge on them. So it's like their comfy, team-spirit clothes!

title: What is Nitrous Oxide and how does is it make cars go faster?
text: Nitrous Oxide is like a special, super-duper strong air that some race cars can drink. You know how when you eat your yummy food, you get lots of energy to run and play? Well, when the car's engine 'drinks' this special air, it gets a HUGE burst of energy! It helps the engine make much bigger, stronger pushes inside, which makes the wheels spin super-duper fast, like when you push your toy car really hard. So, the car zooms ahead much, much quicker!

title: Why do we wake up starving the morning after a night of binge eating?
text: Imagine you ate a super, super big feast, like a giant pile of yummy snacks and treats, right before you went to sleep. Your body, like a busy little worker, had to work extra hard all night long to sort through all that food. A lot of those yummy treats had a lot of 'fast energy' (sugar), which made your body's special helper (insulin) come out in a big rush to clean it all up super quickly. After that big rush and quick clean-up, your body suddenly looks around and thinks, 'Whoa! Where did all the energy go so fast?' Even though you ate a lot, your body used up the easy energy so quickly and got a little confused, making it send you a message saying, 'Hey! I need more food RIGHT NOW!' And that's why you wake up feeling super hungry, even after eating so much!

title: Why do ads load first, rather than the content of the site itself?
text: Imagine you're going to a super fun playground, but the people who built the playground need money to buy new swings and keep it tidy. So, they let other grown-ups put up little picture signs (those are the ads!) all around the playground. The playground builders want to make *super sure* those signs are showing first, because that's how they get their money to keep the playground open and get more cool stuff for you to play with! So, the website (which is like the playground) makes sure the ads (the signs) are ready first, even before all the fun stories and pictures (the swings and slides) are perfectly in place, just so they can keep showing you all the cool stuff for free.

title: Why do we struggle so much to learn how to ride a bike for the first time? Furthermore, why do we never forget how to ride a bike, regardless of how many years have passed?
text: Imagine a wobbly toy, like a tall block. It's hard to keep it standing up, right? That's kind of like you on a bike for the first time! Your body isn't used to balancing on two skinny wheels, and your brain is trying to tell your feet to pedal, your hands to steer, *and* your whole body to stay up all at the same time! It's like trying to juggle three balls while standing on one foot – super tricky! You fall down a lot because your brain and body are having a big meeting to figure out this new, super-duper balancing trick. But once they finally figure it out and teach each other, it's like they write that trick down in a very special, super-strong secret notebook in your brain and muscles. It's not like remembering a story or a name; it's a *doing* memory! So even if you don't ride for a long, long time, your body remembers that special trick, kind of like how you never forget how to walk or run. It's just there, ready for you to use whenever you hop back on!

title: purchasing power parity (GDP)?
text: Imagine you have a magic allowance of five gold coins. In your town, those five coins can buy you a really big, yummy ice cream cone. Now, imagine if you went to a different town, super far away. Maybe in that town, those same five gold coins can only buy you a tiny scoop of ice cream, or maybe they can buy you two big ice cream cones! 'Purchasing power parity' is like a smart grown-up way to

title: Why does someone with verbal Tourette’s often use swear/crude words? Society is the only thing that makes those words taboo, so why does it seem people with Tourette’s get stuck saying them?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little boss that helps you do everything, like run and talk. Sometimes, this boss gets a tiny hiccup, just like when your tummy hiccups! When your brain hiccups, it makes your body do things you didn't mean to, like blink your eyes super fast, or make a little sound. Sometimes, the brain hiccup makes you say words you didn't mean to say. Now, some words are like "forbidden cookies"—everyone knows you're not supposed to say them, and they make grown-ups pay a lot of attention. Because these "forbidden cookie" words are so special and get so much attention, your brain's little hiccup sometimes picks them out because they're extra "sticky" or "loud" in your head. It's not because the person wants to be naughty or rude, it's just that those words are like bright, shiny toys that the brain's hiccup grabs onto without meaning to.

title: If I lift a pile of book and carry it towards another table, is work being done on the books?
text: Yes! When you first lift the books up, you are definitely doing work! It's like when you push your toy car up a little hill – you're making it go higher. But then, when you just walk with the books and keep them at the same height, even though your arms might feel tired, you're not actually doing "work" *on the books themselves* in the way a grown-up scientist thinks about it. That's because you're not making the books go higher, lower, or faster on their

title: Why do we suddenly have to pee in times of great stress?
text: Imagine you're playing, and suddenly a super big, loud dog barks right at you! Your body has a special alarm that goes off, and it gets ready to either run super-duper fast (like a superhero!) or stand very, very still. When this alarm rings, your body thinks, "Oh no! I need to be as light and quick as possible!" It starts to do things like make your heart beat fast and make your muscles strong. But it also thinks, "Do I really need to carry this pee around right now if I have to run away? Maybe I should just get rid of it so I'm lighter and faster!" So, your brain, which is usually very good at telling your bladder (that's like a little balloon that holds your pee) to hold on tight, gets so busy with the "run away!" alarm that it sometimes forgets to tell the balloon to hold so tightly, and suddenly, you feel like you really, really have to go!

title: Why isn't cancer contagious?
text: Imagine your body is made of billions of tiny little building blocks, like LEGOs. Cancer is when some of your own LEGOs get a bit mixed up and start growing too fast and in a messy way, instead of neatly building your body. Now, these mixed-up LEGOs are *your* special LEGOs, made just for *your* body. If someone else tried to put your special, mixed-up LEGOs into *their* body, their body would be like, "Hey! These aren't mine!" and would quickly get rid of them, just like how your body fights off a little cold germ. It's like your body has a special security guard that only lets *your* LEGOs stay. So, cancer is a problem that only happens inside one person's body and can't jump to another person, because everyone's body is super good at knowing what belongs to them and what doesn't!

title: How does "Whataboutism" differ from giving context to information?
text:
Okay, imagine your friend says, "Hey, you took my crayon!"

**Whataboutism** is like when you say, "But what about *you*? You took *my* block yesterday!" You're not talking about the crayon you took right now; you're trying to point to something *they* did to make your action seem okay, or to make them stop talking about your crayon. It's like trying to change the subject to someone else's boo-boo.

**Giving context** is like when your friend says, "Hey, you took my crayon!" and you say, "Oh no! I picked it up because it rolled under the table and I was going to give it back to you!" You're still

title: How does it feel falling through a cloud while skydiving? Is it safe to perform such a feat?
text: Imagine you're a superhero flying super fast! When you zoom through a cloud, it feels a little bit like when you run through a very light sprinkle of rain, or when you walk into a steamy bathroom after someone took a hot shower. It's not like hitting a wall, because clouds are just tiny, tiny drops of water floating in the air, like super fine mist! So, it feels cool and wet on your face for just a second, and everything gets a little bit blurry, like looking through a foggy window, then poof! You're out the other side. Is it safe? Yes, the cloud itself won't hurt you at all! It's just water. But grown-up skydivers need to be super careful to make sure they can always see the ground and other airplanes, like when you're playing hide-and-seek and need to see where your friends are. So, they usually only jump when the clouds aren't too big and thick, or they fly above them, so they can always see where they're going. It's safe as long as they can see clearly, just like you need to see clearly when you're riding your bike!

title: Why do hot and steamy showers feel so comfortable but not hot weather?
text: Okay, imagine you're a little bit cold, like when you just woke up! A hot shower is like a super warm, steamy hug that makes you feel all cozy and soft. The steam wraps around you like a friendly, invisible blanket, and you can step out whenever you're perfectly warm. But hot weather outside is like a hug that's *too* hot and never stops! You're already warm, and the sun keeps making you even warmer, which makes you feel sticky and sweaty, and you can't just turn off the sun or walk away from all that heat.

title: Why are most pencils painted yellow? Why not a different color?
text: Imagine a long, long time ago, people found super good, super dark stuff to put inside pencils, and it came from a far-away land called China. In China, the color yellow was a very special, fancy color, like for kings and queens! So, when they made these amazing pencils, they painted them bright yellow to show everyone how special and fancy they were, and that they had the best dark stuff inside. Everyone loved these yellow pencils because they worked so well! Soon, other people who made pencils saw how much everyone liked the yellow ones, so they started painting *their* pencils yellow too, even if their dark stuff wasn't from China. It was like saying, "Hey, my pencil is good too, just like those famous yellow ones!" And that's why, even today, lots and lots of pencils are still yellow – it's a super old tradition!

title: Why do heat waves distort your vision?
text: Okay, imagine the sun makes the ground super-duper hot, like a giant oven! This hot ground makes the air right above it super hot too, and this hot air starts to dance and wiggle, like happy invisible dancers! Higher up, the air is still a bit cooler. So you have hot, wiggly air and cooler, calmer air all trying to mix together. Light, which usually travels in a perfectly straight line to your eyes, has to go through all this dancing, wiggling air. When light tries to go through wobbly air, it gets pushed around a little bit, like if you tried to walk in a bouncy castle. Because the light isn't coming to your eyes perfectly straight anymore, everything looks a little blurry or wavy, like you're looking through water!

title: In the US, when a product is specified as freshly cooked or freshly baked, what does that mean and what is the lowest standard to classify as "fresh"?
text: Imagine when Mommy bakes cookies, and they just came out of the oven, still warm and yummy! When a store says something is "freshly cooked" or "freshly baked," it means it was just made, like those cookies! It wasn't made a long, long time ago and then kept in a box for days. There isn't a super strict rule that says *exactly* how many minutes ago it had to be made, but it means it was made very, very recently, usually today, and not yesterday or the day before. It's like your snack was just made for you, not left out since last night!

title: How can the chlorine in tap water kill microorganisms, but not the cells in our bodies?
text: Okay, imagine there's a tiny, invisible superhero helper in your tap water called 'Chlorine'! He's super good at finding tiny, bad guys called germs. Germs are like little, squishy balloons with very thin skin, and Chlorine is like a tiny, tiny pin that can easily pop them! *POP!* That's how he cleans the water to make it safe for you to drink. But our body cells? They are like big, strong bouncy castles with super thick walls and lots of protection inside. Chlorine is so tiny, and there's only a *teeny-tiny* amount of him in the water, that he's like a little speck of dust trying to break a big, strong castle wall. He just can't do it! So, he can easily pop the weak, tiny germs, but he can't even tickle our big, strong body cells, so we stay safe and healthy!

title: How did Cinderella's shoe come off if it was the perfect fit?
text: Imagine your favorite comfy shoes! They fit just right, not too big and not too small, which means they feel super nice on your feet. But even a shoe that fits perfectly isn't glued on! Cinderella was running super-duper fast down the steps because she was in such a hurry, and sometimes when you run really, really fast, especially down stairs, a shoe can wiggle off, especially if it's made of slippery glass! Plus, those shoes were magic, and maybe the magic helped it fall off just a little bit so the Prince could find her later and they could live happily ever after!

title: How does an antihistamine work against an alergie?
text: Imagine your body has little security guards, and sometimes they get confused. When something harmless like pollen (which is like tiny dust from flowers) or a pet hair comes along, your body's guards sometimes think it's a big, scary monster! So, they start ringing a loud alarm bell called "histamine." This alarm bell makes your nose runny, your eyes itchy, and you sneeze a lot, because your body thinks it's fighting that "monster." An antihistamine is like a special little helper that comes and puts a big, soft blanket over that alarm bell. It doesn't let the alarm ring loudly anymore, or it makes it super quiet. So, even though the "monster" (like pollen) is still there, your body's security guards don't hear the alarm bell ringing, and they calm down. That's why your sniffles and itchiness go away – because the alarm bell has been quieted!

title: Do spiders ever forget where their webs are located? They leave but is it memory or something else they use to find their way back?
text: No, spiders don't really forget where their web is, like you don't forget where your bed is! They're super clever. When a spider walks on its web, it leaves little tiny strings of silk behind, like a special road it built just for itself. They can feel these strings with their little legs and use them like a map to find their way back home. Plus, their silk has a special smell, like your favorite blankie has your smell, so they can sniff their way back too. So it's not just remembering in their head, but also feeling their way along their silk roads and sniffing their own special scent that helps them find their way back to their cozy web!

title: What causes sleep paralysis??
text: Imagine your body and your brain are like two best friends that go to sleep together. When you sleep, your body gets really, really still, like a statue, so you don't accidentally kick your blanket or run around while you're dreaming. It's like your body puts on its 'sleep-still' pajamas. Usually, when it's time to wake up, your brain gives your body a little nudge and says, "Okay, time to take off the sleep-still pajamas and move!" But sometimes, your brain wakes up super-duper fast, like it just drank a juice box, and it's ready to go, but your body is still snuggled deep in its 'sleep-still' pajamas and hasn't gotten the message yet. So your brain is awake and looking around, but your body is still stuck being a statue for a little bit. And sometimes, because your brain is half-awake and half-dreaming, it might play a little trick and make you think you see or feel something that isn't really there, just like when you have a dream! But don't worry, it's not scary for real, it's just your body taking a tiny bit longer to wake up than your brain.

title: Why is water 'harder than concrete' if you fall into it from a great height?

This makes your tattoo fade a little bit quicker. But if your clean-up superheroes aren't as strong or don't work as fast (a weak immune system), they won't be as good at carrying away the paint. title: When doing the same amount of physical labor, why do some people sweat a lot while others don't?
text: Imagine your body is like a little engine, and when you run and play, your engine gets warm! To cool down, your body has a special sprinkler system called sweat. Everyone's body engine is a little bit different! Some people's engines just naturally get hotter faster, so their sprinkler system needs to squirt out a lot of water to keep them nice and cool. Other people's engines might not get as hot, or their sprinkler system just doesn't need to squirt as much water. It's just how their special body is made, like how some cars use more gas than others! Sometimes, if you're used to playing a lot or it's super hot outside, your body learns to turn on the sprinklers really quickly to be extra good at staying cool. So, it's totally normal for some friends to get super drippy and others to stay a bit drier!

title: Why do mood swings occur?
text: Imagine your feelings are like a swing set! Sometimes you're way up high and super happy, and sometimes you're way down low and a bit sad or grumpy. Mood swings are just when that swing goes up and down *really fast* or *really suddenly*. It happens because inside your body, you have tiny little helpers (like invisible buttons or switches) that control how you feel, and sometimes those helpers get a little bit mixed up or push the wrong button for a moment! Also, things around you can make your swing go up or down – maybe you're super hungry, or super tired, or someone said something that made you giggle, or something made you a little bit mad. All these things can make your feelings change quickly, like when your tummy rumbles and you suddenly feel grumpy, but then you get a snack and you're happy again! It's totally normal, and everyone's feelings swing sometimes.

title: What is protein folding and why does running simulations of it take so much compute power?
text: Imagine proteins are like super long strings of tiny LEGOs that are all connected. When they're first made, they're just floppy strings. But to do their special job in your body, like helping you run or making your hair grow, they have to fold up into a very specific, perfect little shape, almost like a tangled-up headphone cord that magically untangles itself into a tiny, useful robot. That's protein folding – the string of LEGOs finding its one special shape! Now, why does a computer need to be super-duper smart and powerful to figure this out? Well, that long string of LEGOs can wiggle and jiggle and bend in so many, many, many different ways, like trying to fold a super long piece of spaghetti into a tiny, exact knot without breaking it. The computer has to try out almost *every single possible little wiggle and bend* that each tiny LEGO piece can make, millions and millions of times, until it finds the one exact way it folds to become that perfect little robot. There are just so many choices and tiny movements to check, it takes a really, really big computer brain a super long time to find the right answer!

title: How did the Game Genie from Galoob work as a cheat device?
text: Imagine your video game is like a super long storybook, and your console is like a grown-up who reads the story and makes all the pictures and sounds happen on the TV. When you play, the storybook tells the grown-up things like 'give the hero 3 lives' or 'make the bad guy really strong.' The Game Genie is like a clever little helper who sits right between your storybook game and the grown-up console. Before the grown-up reads a part of the story, the Game Genie quickly looks at it. If you've told the Game Genie a secret code, it knows exactly what to look for! So, when the storybook says 'give the hero 3 lives,' the Game Genie quickly changes that part to say 'give the hero 99 lives' *before* the grown-up even sees it! Or if it says 'make the bad guy strong,' the Game Genie might change it to 'make the bad guy super weak.' The grown-up console just reads the *changed* story and does what it says, making you a superhero in the game without even knowing the story was secretly changed!

title: What’s a manifold?
text: Imagine you're a super tiny ant walking on a giant, giant bouncy ball. Right where you're standing, the bouncy ball feels super flat, like the floor of your room. A manifold is just a fancy word for things that look flat when you're super close to one spot, but might be curvy or wiggly when you look at the whole thing from far away, like our big bouncy ball or even the whole Earth!

title: Why does our body subconsciously lean forward or stand when there is an intense moment happening (Like during a hard boss fight in gaming)?

title: Why can some people match pitches (music vocal) naturally and some can't?
text: Imagine your ears are like super listening machines, and your voice is like a tiny speaker. When you hear a sound, like a "ding!", your ears tell your brain exactly how high or low that sound is. For some people, their brain is really good at telling their voice's speaker to make *that exact same* "ding!" sound right away, almost like they have a perfect copy machine inside their head! They just naturally know how to make their voice match what their ears hear. For other people, their ears hear the "ding!" just fine, but their brain and voice need a little more practice to figure out how to make their speaker sound *exactly* like the "ding!". It's not that they don't hear it, it's just harder for their voice to make the right shape or height of the sound. But guess what? With a little practice, almost everyone can get much, much better at making their voice sound just like the sounds they hear, like learning to draw a perfect circle!

title: how’s come sometimes when your leg falls asleep it doesn’t hurt, and other times it tingles with intense pain?

We're awake!" and the snack trucks are rushing to deliver all the snacks they missed. This big, loud rush and shout feels like those strong tingles and sometimes

title: Is it possible to carbonate a flammable liquid such as naphtha or kerosene? If so; what would happen?
text: No, you can't really make fizzy bubbles in special grown-up liquids like naphtha or kerosene, because they're not like water. Water loves to hold fizzy bubbles, but these other liquids are more like oil, and bubbles don't really want to stay and play in oil – they just float right out! Even if you tried really hard, it wouldn't make a fizzy drink. And more importantly, it would be super, super dangerous because those liquids are like sleepy fire-monsters that can get very, very hot if they wake up, so we never, ever play with them or try to put bubbles in them!

title: Why haven't we gone back to the moon?
text: Imagine going to the biggest, most awesome playground ever, but it's super, super far away, like way past the clouds! title: Why does the sky turn green before a tornado?
text: Okay, imagine the sun sends out light that has all the colors of the rainbow in it, like a big crayon box! Usually, when the sky is blue, it's because the blue light from the sun bounces around a lot in the air. But when there's a super duper big storm that might make a tornado, the clouds get really, really tall and thick, like a giant, dark fluffy mountain. These big clouds are so full of water and so dark that they gobble up most of the sun's colors, especially the blue ones. What's left, when the light tries to peek through the bottom of those super dark clouds, can sometimes look a little bit greenish or yellowish. It's like the dark cloud is making the sky look a bit like a spooky green monster because only those colors can push through the thick, dark storm!

title: How does our body get used to the temperature of a cold pool or a hot tub over time?
text: Imagine you jump into a cold pool! Brrr! Your body goes "Whoa, that's cold!" and sends a quick message to your brain. Your brain then tells your body, "Okay, let's try to get used to this!" and makes your blood move around a little differently, or makes your muscles shiver a tiny bit to make some warmth. It's like your body is trying to give itself a little hug to feel better. If it's a super hot bath, your body goes "Phew, that's warm!" and tries to cool down by sending blood closer to your skin or making you sweat a little. After a little while, your body's special "thermostat" inside slowly changes its mind and says, "Oh, okay, this temperature isn't so surprising anymore!" It gets used to the new feeling, and suddenly, it doesn't feel so shocking or uncomfortable, but just right!

title: Submariners, from the point of view of the crew aboard. Once submerged, do subs ever experience "rough seas"?
text: Imagine you're in a bathtub and you splash around on top – that's like rough seas with big waves! But if you put your toy boat deep under the water, way down low, it doesn't get pushed around by your splashes anymore, right? It just floats smoothly. A submarine is like that toy boat! When it goes deep, deep, deep under the ocean, it goes past all the big waves and the wind that makes them bouncy on top. Down there, the water is super calm and still, so the submariners don't feel any rough seas at all, it's actually very smooth and quiet, like being in a still pond.

title: Why do we have headaches when we are dehydrated?
text: Imagine your brain is a super important squishy toy living inside your head, and it loves to float in a little swimming pool of water! This water keeps it safe and happy, so it doesn't bump into the sides of your head. But when you don't drink enough water (that's being dehydrated!), that little swimming pool starts to get smaller, like when you let some water out of a bathtub. Because there's less water for your brain to float in, it can't quite float as nicely. It might even shrink just a tiny, tiny bit and pull on the little stretchy strings that hold it in place inside your head. When those strings get pulled, it makes your head feel a little ouchie, and that's your headache! So, drinking water helps fill up your brain's swimming pool again, and then it can float happily without pulling, and the ouchie goes away!

title: Why are my photos horrible and professional photos look amazing? I used to think it's because I don't have a nice professional camera but I've seen pro photos taken with a cell phone and they make mine look like garbage in comparison. What's the deal?
text: Imagine your camera is like a box of crayons. You can just scribble with one crayon, or a grown-up artist can use the *same* crayon to draw a beautiful picture! It's not just the crayon, right? title: What happens to a nerve in your finger when it is cut and medical treatment is not performed?
text: Okay, imagine your finger has tiny, tiny telephone wires inside it, called nerves. These wires usually send messages to your brain, like "ouch, that's hot!" or "this is soft and squishy!" If one of these wires gets cut, it's like someone snipped your telephone cord. If a doctor doesn't come to carefully put the two ends of the wire back together again, the ends just stay apart. Because the wire is broken, the messages from that part of your finger can't travel all the way to your brain anymore. So, that part of your finger won't be able to tell your brain anything, and you won't be able to feel things there anymore, like it's asleep forever.

title: Why does our left hand move in sync with our right hand and vice versa when we walk/run?

title: If computers are lightning-fast at running calculations and performing tasks, why does "freezing" take seconds or even minutes?
text: Imagine your computer is like a super-duper fast helper! When you ask it to do one thing, like draw a picture or show you a video, it's like asking it to play with just one toy. It can do that super fast, zoom, zoom! But sometimes, you ask it to do too many things all at once – like asking it to play with ALL your toys, and build a big tower, and color a book, and sing a song, all at the very same second! Your computer gets really, really confused. It tries to figure out what to do first, or maybe it's waiting for one special toy that isn't there, or one of its toys broke and it keeps trying to play with it. It gets stuck thinking, 'Uh oh, what do I do now?' It takes a little bit of time for your computer to realize it's stuck and needs a moment to catch its breath, just like it takes you a second to figure out what to do when you have too many things to play with at once.

title: Why do we remove starch by soaking potatoes in order to make crispy fries but coat chicken in starch for super crispy fried chicken?
text:
Okay, imagine potatoes are like a sponge full of super sticky glue inside! When we want to make crispy fries, we want the outside to get super dry and crunchy, like a cracker. If we leave all that extra sticky glue on the outside, it just gets gooey and soft when it cooks, not crunchy. So, we give the potatoes a bath to wash away some of that extra sticky glue from the outside so it can get nice and hard.

Now, chicken is different! It doesn't have that super sticky glue inside like potatoes. So, we give the chicken a tiny sprinkle of a special magic powder (that's the starch!) on the outside, kind of like putting a thin, crispy jacket on it. This special jacket gets super, super crunchy and hard when it cooks, making the chicken extra yummy and crispy!

So, for potatoes, we take away the *extra* sticky stuff that makes it gooey, and for chicken, we add a *little bit* of special sticky stuff to make a perfect crunchy shell!

title: why does ALT CTRL DEL sometimes fail?
text: Imagine your computer is like a busy little robot. Most of the time, the robot wakes up and says 'Okay!' But sometimes, the robot is *so* busy, or *so* stuck, that it can't even hear your poke! It's like it's wearing earmuffs and is completely focused on its stuck task, or it's just too tired to move. Or, sometimes, the robot is just too broken in that moment to understand what you want. So, when ALT CTRL DEL doesn't work, it means your computer is either too busy to listen, or it's so tangled up in its own thoughts that it can't respond to your special button push. It needs a bigger reset, like when you have to turn a toy off and then back on again to make it work right!

title: If Forbes says a person is "worth" $1bn, how does that translate in terms of that person's bank balance? Do they have $1bn to spend?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper big piggy bank, but it's not just full of coins! When Forbes says someone is "worth" a lot of money, it's like saying they have a giant pile of super cool stuff. It's not just money in their actual bank account (like your piggy bank), but also their big house, their fancy cars, their companies (like owning a whole toy store!), and even special papers that say they own parts of other big companies. title: Why can't we harvest blood from a dead person like we do organs?
text: Okay, imagine your blood is like super-duper fresh juice that helps you run and play. This juice needs to be really, really fresh and alive to help someone else feel better. But some other parts, like a heart or a kidney, are like bigger, stronger toys. Even if they stop for a little bit, doctors can carefully clean them up and put them in a super cold special fridge to keep them good for a little while longer, so they can help another kid play again. title: How come when we close one eye, we see “nothing” out of that eye, but when we close both, we see black?
text: Okay, imagine your eyes are like two little cameras that send pictures to your brain, which is like a super smart TV inside your head. When you close just *one* eye, the other camera is still wide open and sending lots of bright pictures to your TV! Your super smart TV is so busy watching the good pictures from the open camera that it doesn't even really notice the closed one, so you don't see "nothing" from it, you just see what the open eye sees. But when you close *both* eyes, it's like turning off *both* cameras! Now, no pictures are coming to your super smart TV at all, so it just shows you a dark screen, which is that black you see. It's like when all the lights go out in your room and it gets dark!
