title: How do air breathing sea animals like dolphins or whales not drown during violent seastorms?
text: Imagine you're playing in a bathtub and someone makes super big splashes and waves! It gets really bouncy! Dolphins and whales are like the best swimmers in the whole wide ocean. They are super strong and know just how to wiggle their bodies to swim *through* or *over* even the biggest, bounciest waves. The most important thing is they can hold their breath for a super, super long time – way longer than you or me! So, when a big wave comes crashing, they just take a deep breath, hold it, and swim right under it. They're also very smart, so they look for a calm spot, quickly pop their blowhole (that's like their nose!) out for a quick gulp of air, and then dive back down until the storm calms. Their bodies are made just right for the ocean, helping them be safe even in big storms!

title: Why do older video games look so angular, like they were pasting faces on the blocks of wood? What changed?
text: Imagine building a castle with your biggest, chunkiest LEGO bricks or wooden blocks. You can make a house, but it looks a bit pointy and not very smooth, right? Old video games were like that! The computers back then were like little kids who could only use a few big, chunky blocks to build their pictures on the screen. So, if they wanted to make a person's face or a round ball, they had to use just a few big flat sides, which made everything look all sharp and angular, like a diamond or a block of wood with a picture stuck on it. It was just too hard and slow for those old computers to draw lots and lots of tiny little pieces. But then, computers got super, super smart and super, super fast! They learned how to use not just a few big blocks, but zillions of super-tiny, tiny little pieces, like making things out of clay or play-doh instead of just big blocks. This meant they could make everything super smooth and curvy, like real faces and round balls, and they could even paint super fine details on them to make them look almost real! So now, instead of pointy blocks, everything looks soft and bouncy, like a perfect sculpture.

title: Where do the bubbles come from when boiling water?
text: Imagine water is made of super tiny, tiny friends that you can't even see! When you put the pot on the stove and make the water really, really hot, these tiny water friends get super excited and start dancing around really fast! They get so bouncy and wiggly that they can't stay close together anymore. They start pushing each other apart really hard, and when they do, they make little empty spaces, like tiny air balloons, deep inside the water. These are the bubbles! They're actually the super excited water friends trying to jump out of the water and fly away as an invisible cloud (that's steam!). Since these bubbles are lighter than the water, they float all the way up to the top and pop, letting the excited water friends escape into the air.

title: Why do we not feel food go down our bodies?
text: You know how when you swallow your yummy food, it just seems to disappear? That's because inside your body, there are special helper muscles, like a secret slide, that gently push your food all the way down to your tummy! Imagine if you squeeze a long balloon, and the air moves along – that's kind of what these muscles do. They are super smart and work all by themselves, without you even having to think about it. Your body is so busy doing lots of important jobs, like making your heart beat and helping you breathe, that it doesn't need to tell your brain every single time food goes on its trip. It just quietly takes care of it, so you can keep playing and thinking about all the fun things you want to do!

title: I'm getting my first glasses at the age of 27, what are some things i should do/know?
text: Imagine your eyes are like super special cameras that take pictures of the world, but sometimes those pictures come out a little bit blurry, like when you shake the camera! Glasses are like a magic, clear window that helps your eye-camera take really, really sharp pictures. When you first put them on, the world might feel a little bit funny, like everything is a bit wobbly or too bright, kind of like when you first jump into a swimming pool and everything looks different. That's totally normal! Your brain is just surprised because it's never seen the world so clearly before. The most important thing is to wear your new glasses almost all the time, like your favorite superhero mask, so your brain and eyes can learn to work together with them. You'll want to keep them super clean, so use a special soft cloth and sometimes a little spray, not your shirt, because shirts can make tiny scratches. And always put them in their special box when you're not wearing them, so they don't get squished or broken. Soon, everything will look super clear and bright, and you'll wonder how you ever saw without them!

title: what physically changes in a computer when you save something?
text: Imagine your computer is like a big toy box. When you're playing with your toys (like drawing a picture or writing a story on the computer), those toys are out on the table in front of you. This is like the computer's 'thinking space' where it keeps things it's using right now, but if you put them away, they're gone! When you click 'save,' it's like taking those toys and carefully putting them inside a special, permanent drawer in your toy box. For really old computers, tiny little magnets inside that drawer flip around to remember your toys, like tiny little 'yes' or 'no' signs. For newer, super-fast computers, it's like tiny little light switches getting turned on or off to remember your toys. So, when you save, your computer is just moving your important 'toys' from the temporary play table into a safe, permanent drawer so they're always there when you want to play with them again later!

title: why is math (statistics, calculus, etc) so important for a strong programmer?
text: Imagine a programmer is like a super builder who makes amazing things for computers, like fun games or clever robots. Math, like special counting games (statistics) or thinking about how things change (

title: Why do chia seeds soaked in water spread uniformly throughout instead of settling at the bottom?
text: Hey little friend! Imagine chia seeds are like tiny little superheroes! When they get wet, they put on a special, invisible, sticky jelly suit all around them. This jelly suit makes them a little bit bigger and helps them float and bounce around in the water, kind of like tiny little balloons or tiny jellyfish! Because they have this sticky jelly suit, they don't just want to fall all the way to the bottom like a heavy rock; instead, they love to hang out everywhere in the water, all mixed up, having fun.

title: Why do you sometimes have to use the bathroom immediately after you eat or drink even if you didn’t need to before?
text: Imagine your tummy is like a big, squishy balloon! When you put yummy food and drinks inside, your tummy starts to get full. It's like when you try to put a new toy

title: If temperature is defined by the movement or jiggling of particles like atoms and molecules and if a vacuum is defined by an absent of those particles. How can a vacuum have a temperature?
text: Okay, imagine temperature is like how much your toys are wiggling and jiggling in your room. If they wiggle a lot, it feels warm! Now, a vacuum is like a room that's super, super empty – no toys, no air, nothing to wiggle around inside it. So, how can it feel warm or cold? Well, even if there are no toys *in* the room, sunshine can still shine *through* the room, right? And sunshine makes things warm! So, a vacuum can have a 'temperature' because of invisible 'sunshine' or 'heat rays' that are always flying through it, even when there's nothing else there. These invisible rays carry warmth from hot things, like the sun, and when they hit something else, like a spaceship or your hand, they make *that* thing wiggle and get warm, even though the space they traveled through was totally empty!

title: if downloading a youtube video violates the terms of service, how do people get other creator's videos to comment on?
text: Imagine YouTube is like a giant toy box full of videos! When you *download* a video, it's like trying to take one of the toys out of the box and bring it home to play with by yourself forever. YouTube doesn't like that because those toys belong in the box for everyone to share and watch together. But when people *comment* on a video, it's like they're just pointing at a toy in the box and saying, "Look at that cool car!" or "I like this doll!" They're still looking at the toy *inside* the box, and they're not taking it home. YouTube lets you do lots of things *inside* its toy box, like watching, sharing links, or even making a little video next to another video to talk about it, without ever taking the original toy out of the box. So, they're just playing nicely with the toys right where they are!

title: How is music remixed?
text: Imagine you have a big box of LEGOs and you've built a really cool castle. That castle is like the original song! Now, someone wants to "remix" your castle. What they do is carefully take some of the pieces apart – maybe they take out the flag, or a special window, or even a whole wall. Then, they might add some *new* LEGO pieces that weren't there before, like a new shiny roof or a super fast car. They can also put the old pieces back in a different order, or make some parts bigger and some smaller. So, they end up with a brand new creation – maybe it's still a castle, but it looks very different, or maybe it's turned into a rocket ship! It uses some of the same LEGO pieces from your original castle, but it sounds and feels like a totally new thing because someone played with all the parts, took some out, and put new ones in. That's how music gets remixed – someone takes the "pieces" of a song (like the singing, the drums, or the melodies), moves them around, adds new sounds, and makes a brand new version that's exciting and different!

title: If I boil a kettle does everything inside become sterile? if so how long does it stay sterile?
text: When you make the water in the kettle super, super hot, it's like magic! Almost all the tiny invisible bugs (we call them germs) that were swimming in the water or hanging out on the inside of the kettle get too hot and go "poof!" So, yes, for a little while, the water and the inside of the kettle become super clean from those bugs. But it doesn't stay clean like that for very long. As soon as the water cools down, or if you open the lid, new tiny invisible bugs from the air or even your hands can float right back in and make new homes. So it's only super clean for a short time, just until new bugs decide to visit!

title: Why do companies (Google, Apple, etc.) that have billions of dollars worth of debt not pay it off when they have the money for it?
text: Imagine you want to build the coolest, biggest LEGO fort ever! You have lots of LEGOs (that's like their money), but you can also borrow some extra LEGOs from

title: Why does orange juice taste awful after brushing your teeth ?
text: Imagine your tongue has little tiny superheroes called 'taste buds' that tell your brain if something is yummy sweet or yucky sour. When you brush your teeth, the toothpaste is like a special cleaning potion. This potion has a secret ingredient that makes things foamy and helps clean, but it also tells your 'sweet' superheroes to take a little nap! So, when you drink orange juice right after, your sweet superheroes are still sleeping, and they can't tell your brain how yummy and sweet the juice is. Instead, the potion also makes the 'sour' superheroes much, much stronger, so the juice tastes super sour and yucky, not yummy. But don't worry, it only lasts a little while until the toothpaste washes away, and then your sweet superheroes wake up again!

title: Why are bugs attracted to light?
text: Imagine you're a little bug flying around at night. Bugs usually use really big, far-away lights like the moon or the stars to help them fly in a straight line, kind

title: Why do most song lengths seem to fall between 2 and 4 minutes?
text: Imagine you're listening to a story. If the story is too, too long, you might get a little wiggly and want to play with your toys, right? Songs are a bit like that! Most songs are between 2 and 4 minutes long because that's just the right amount of time to hear a fun musical story without getting bored. It also helps the people who play music on the radio fit in lots of different songs for everyone to enjoy, and it used to be that the special round records songs came on could only hold a little bit of music at a time. So, it's just the perfect length to be catchy and fun for your ears!

title: why do tongues get weird bumps when burnt or after eating something really sweet or really salty?
text: Your tongue has super-duper tiny helpers called taste buds, and they're like little antennas that tell your brain if something is yummy! When you eat something too hot, it's like giving those tiny helpers a little burn, like when you touch something hot and say "ouchie!" They get a little bit puffy and sore, like a tiny bruise, and that's the bumps you feel. And when you eat super-duper sweet candy or super-duper salty chips, it's like those little helpers get really, really tired or a little bit grumpy because there's just too much sugar or salt for them to handle! So, they puff up a tiny bit too, saying "Whoa, that's a lot!" But don't worry, those clever little helpers heal super fast and are ready to taste yummy food again soon!

title: How do we know that interstellar asteroids, rogue planets, cool brown dwarfs, and pockets of gas don't account for the remainder of the mass in the universe?
text: Imagine you have a big, invisible friend holding onto a toy car. You can see the toy car moving, and it moves really fast, but it doesn't fly off the track! That

title: Why do our brains feel "fried" after a period of concentration?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper toy car with a special battery inside! When you concentrate really hard, like trying to build a tall tower of blocks or learn a new song, your brain car is driving super fast and using up lots of its special battery juice! It's also like your brain is building lots of things, and sometimes it makes little tiny messes or uses up all its special building blocks. So, after a long time of driving super fast and building, your brain car's battery gets low, and it feels tired and a bit messy, like it needs to stop, recharge its battery, and clean up all the little tiny messes. That's why it feels "fried" – it's just telling you it needs a little rest to get all its energy back and be ready to play again!

title: Why does cannibalism cause kuru...but not when you eat other species unless they're infected cows?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super squishy computer that helps you think and move. Kuru is a sickness that makes tiny parts of your brain get all messy and stop working right, like

title: Is drinking 8 cups of any liquid (i.e. pop, juice, coffee, beer, etc) pretty much the same as drinking 8 cups of water in terms of hydrating your body since the primary ingredient in any drink is water?
text: Imagine your body is like a thirsty little flower that needs a drink to stay fresh and strong! Plain water is like the perfect, clean rain for your flower – it just soaks it right up and makes it super happy. Now, if you give your flower a cup of fizzy pop, or super sweet juice, or coffee, or even beer, it's like giving it water with lots of extra stuff mixed in. Some of that extra stuff, like too much sugar, can make your flower a little bit sticky or make it work harder to use the water. And some drinks, like coffee or beer, are a bit sneaky because they make your flower actually *lose* some of the water it just drank because they make it 'pee' it out faster! So, even though all those drinks have water in them, they're not all the same for helping your body be its best hydrated self. Plain water is always the champion for making your body feel super happy and wet inside!

title: How can the sum of all natural numbers be negative?
text:
Okay, imagine you have a bunch of yummy candies: 1 candy, then 2 candies, then 3 candies, and you keep getting more and more candies forever! If you try to count them all normally, you'd never finish, right? You'd have SO many candies, more than you could ever imagine – we call that 'infinity' in grown-up words, and it's a super big positive number.

But sometimes, very clever grown-up mathematicians play a special kind of 'math game' with different rules. It's not like counting your toys or real candies. It's like a magic trick with numbers! In *that* special game, using very fancy rules that are hard to understand even for big kids, they found a way to make all those numbers (1 + 2 + 3 + 4 and so on forever) pretend to add up to a tiny, tiny negative number: minus one-twelfth! It doesn't mean you *really* have negative candies or

title: What stops pop up ads and viruses from simply making the "no" or "cancel" button take users to the same place as the yes button?
text: Imagine you have a special toy car, and it has a 'go' button and a 'stop' button. Sometimes, a naughty person (that's like the pop-up ad or a virus) wants you to keep going, even if you want to stop! They might try to draw a *fake* 'stop' button on *their own* picture of a car, and if you touch *their* fake button, it might still make you go. But your mommy and daddy (that's like your computer's special rules and helpers, called the browser or operating system) put a *real*, super strong 'stop' button on the *actual* toy car, like a little 'X' in the corner or a real 'cancel' button that belongs to the computer itself. No matter how much the naughty person tries to trick you with their fake buttons, your mommy and daddy's real 'stop' button *always

title: Today I saw maternity menstrual pads for pregnant women, what are they for?
text: Okay, imagine mommy's tummy was a super cozy house where the baby lived for a long, long time. After the baby comes out, the house needs to get all clean inside, like when you clean your room after a big playdate! Sometimes, when the body cleans itself up after making a baby, there's a little bit of stuff that comes out, kind of like when you get a little boo-boo and it bleeds a tiny bit, or like when you clean up your toys and there's some dust. Those special pads are like big, soft towels that catch all that extra stuff so mommy stays comfy and clean while her body gets all better and strong again! It's a very normal part of being a new mommy.

title: What is defamation and how can you be sued for it in a country like the US where there is free speech?
text: Imagine you told all your friends that Timmy stole your cookies, but Timmy *didn't* steal them! He was actually helping his mom. Now all your friends think Timmy is

title: Why are octopi classified as mollusks? I always thought they were cephalopods and TIL they’re not.
text: Imagine animals are like different big clubs. The 'Mollusk Club' is a really big one, and all the animals in it have soft bodies, and sometimes they have a hard shell to protect them, like snails or clams. Now, inside that big 'Mollusk Club,' there's a super cool, special smaller club called the 'Cephalopod Club.' These are the super smart, super fast ones with lots of wiggly arms on their heads, like octopuses and squids! So, an octopus is definitely in the 'Cephalopod Club' because it has all those special things. But because the 'Cephalopod Club' is *inside* the bigger 'Mollusk Club,' that means the octopus is also a Mollusk! It's like how you might be in the 'Soccer Team' at school, but you're still part of the whole 'School' too!

title: Why does the urge to pee increase the closer you get to a toilet?
text: Your brain is super smart! When you need to pee, your brain usually helps you hold it in, like a superhero keeping the water in your tummy safe. But then, when your brain sees or knows a toilet is super close, it gets all excited! It's like your brain says, "Yay! We're almost there! It's safe to let go now!" So, even though the pee in your tummy isn't suddenly getting bigger, your brain just gets really ready to let it out, and that makes you feel like you *really, really* need to go *right now*! It's like when you're waiting for a yummy cookie, and then you see it on the table – you suddenly want it even more!

title: Why does Apple not build its own manufacturing plants?
text: Imagine Apple is like a super smart toy designer who draws pictures of awesome new toys, like a cool robot or a fast race car. But building all those toys takes a *lot* of special machines and grown-ups who are super good at putting tiny pieces together very, very fast. Instead of building their *own* giant toy factory, Apple asks other companies that already *have* huge factories and lots of people who are experts at making things. It's like asking a friend who has a giant LEGO collection and is really good at building things to make your special design. This way, Apple can focus all their energy on thinking up the coolest new toy ideas, and the other companies can focus on building them perfectly. It helps Apple make lots of different cool things without having to worry about all the machines and workers themselves!

title: Why some clouds sit very low to the ground while others sit extremely high up?
text: Imagine clouds are like different kinds of fluffy friends! Some clouds are like big, soft blankets that like to stay very close to the ground, especially when the air down here is cool and has lots of tiny water drops floating around, like a morning mist. They just like to hug the earth! Other clouds are like tiny, sparkly feathers made of ice. They fly super, super high up in

title: What’s the purpose of a distress signal on submarines, if we can’t locate them once it’s been used?
text: Imagine you're playing hide-and-seek, and you get stuck behind a big couch! You shout "Help me!" really loud, right? Even if your friend can't see you right away because you're behind the couch, they hear your shout and know *where* to start looking for you. A submarine's distress signal is just like that! It's a special "help me!" shout that it sends out into the big, big ocean. Even if the submarine then goes super deep or can't be seen anymore, that shout tells everyone *where* it was when it started having trouble. So, while they might not see the submarine right away, they know *something is wrong* and *where to rush to* to start looking for it in that giant area. It helps them know *where to begin* their search for their friends.

title: Why do humans need their tonsils removed?
text: Imagine your throat has two little bouncy castles called tonsils. Their job is to catch yucky germs before they go further into your body, like tiny superheroes! But sometimes, these bouncy castles get really, really tired from fighting too many germs, or they get so big they block the door. When they get tired, they get sick themselves, making your throat hurt a lot, like a big owie, and you get sick over and over again. Or, if they get too big, it can be hard to swallow your yummy food or even breathe when you're sleeping. So, sometimes the doctor says, "Let's take these tired or too-big bouncy castles out!" because even without them, your body has lots of other amazing superheroes to help you fight germs, and then your throat won't hurt so much, and you can eat and breathe much better!

title: Why do we get itchy?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super-duper sensitive blanket that covers your whole body. Sometimes, a tiny little bug, or a tiny bit of dust, or even just when your skin feels a bit dry, it's like a tiny little tickle or a funny feeling is happening on your blanket. Your skin has special tiny little messengers that quickly run to your brain and say, "Hey! Something is here! We need to get it off!" Your brain then sends a message back to your hand saying, "Go scratch that spot!" When you scratch, it's like you're shooing away the funny feeling or the tiny bug, so your skin can be happy and clean again. It's your body's way of telling you to pay attention to that spot!

title: How can a person be in "critical but stable condition"?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car got into a really big crash! "Critical" means the car is super, super broken, like the wheels are off and the roof is squished – it needs a lot of fixing right away! But "stable" means it's not getting *more* broken right this second. It's still very, very damaged, but it's not falling apart even more while the grown-ups are trying to put it back together. So, a person in critical but stable condition is very, very sick or hurt, like the super broken car, but the doctors have stopped them from getting worse for now, and they're working hard to help them get better.

title: Could someone explain network encapsulation and how data is split up into frames and packets?
text:
Imagine you want to send your friend a really long, awesome drawing!

First, your drawing is too big to fit in just one tiny envelope, so you cut your big drawing into many small pieces. These small pieces are like your "data."

Now, each small piece of your drawing goes into its own little envelope. On each little envelope, you write *your house number* and *your friend's house number* so it

title: How air fresheners like febreeze actively remove bad odours not just cover them up and how do they decide what is a bad odour?
text: Imagine bad smells are like tiny, super stinky invisible monsters floating all around your room! They make your nose go 'ewww!' Febreze has special tiny little cups, like magic donuts, inside it. When you spray Febreze, these tiny cups fly out and look for those stinky monsters. When a stinky monster floats near a cup, the cup quickly gobbles it up and holds it tight inside! So, the stinky monster is trapped in the cup, and it can't make your nose say 'ewww!' anymore. It's not like Febreze just puts a yummy candy smell on top of the stinky monster; it actually catches and hides the monster away so you can't smell it at all! Now, how does it know what's a bad smell? Well, those little magic cups are a bit picky! They are like special catcher mitts that are just the right size and shape to grab the *stinky* monsters. Good smells, like the yummy flower smell Febreze has, are different kinds of invisible things, and they are either too big or the wrong shape for the cups to grab. So, the cups just let the good smells float by, but they are super good at catching and hiding the yucky, st

title: Why does a pencil look like it is made of rubber when you wiggle it between two fingers?
text: Imagine your eyes are like super-duper fast cameras, taking lots and lots of tiny pictures every second! When you wiggle the pencil really fast, it moves a tiny, tiny bit in between each of those pictures your eyes take. Your brain sees all these slightly different pictures of the pencil moving, and it tries to connect them all together super quickly. But because the pencil is moving so fast, your brain gets a little mixed up and thinks the pencil is still in all those places at once, making it look all bendy and wiggly, like it's made of rubber! It's just a fun trick your amazing eyes and brain play.

title: Do bacteria have bacteria?
text: No, not really in the way you have bacteria on you! Imagine you are a giant, and you have tiny little friendly bugs (bacteria) living on your skin and inside you. Now, imagine one of those tiny little bacteria. Is there enough room on *that* tiny bug for *even tinier* bugs to live on *it*? Not really! Bacteria are already super-duper small, so they don't have other bacteria living on them like you have bacteria on you. But guess what? Even bacteria can get sick! They can get little ouchies from even, *even* tinier things called viruses, which are like super-duper mini-me germs that only make bacteria sick. Or, sometimes, a bigger germ might come along and eat the bacteria for lunch! So no, bacteria don't have bacteria, but they can still get sick from things that are even smaller, or get eaten by things that are bigger.

title: Difference between microbiology and molecular biology?
text:
Okay, imagine there are super tiny little creatures all around us that you can't even see without a special magnifying glass called a microscope!

**Microbiology** is like being a detective who studies all those different kinds of tiny, invisible living things, like little bugs or plants that live in dirt or inside you. They want to know where these tiny creatures live, what they eat, and what they do, like if they're friendly or make you sick.

**Molecular biology** is like being a super-duper detective who looks *inside* those tiny creatures (or even inside you!) to see the even tinier, invisible building blocks that make up everything, like tiny LEGO bricks. They want to know how those super-tiny bricks fit together and what secret instructions they follow to make the tiny creature (or you!) alive and working.

So, microbiology is about the whole tiny creature, and molecular biology is about the super-tiny pieces *inside* the creature!

title: How can simulated flavors (such as fruit) be made without even having real flavoring in it?
text: Imagine your favorite strawberry candy or drink! Even if there are no real strawberries in it, it still tastes like one, right? That's because real strawberries have tiny, invisible smell-pieces, kind of like little LEGO bricks, that float up to your nose and tell your brain, "Hey

title: How does observation collapse the wave function?
text: Imagine you have a magic toy car that, when nobody is looking, is like a blurry ghost car that's everywhere at once – it's in the toy box, under the bed, and on the table, all at the same time! That's kind of like what the "wave function" is for tiny things, like saying all the places it *could* be. But the moment you peek and *look* for your car (that's the "observation"), it stops being a blurry ghost and instantly snaps into just *one* real spot, like suddenly it's definitely only in the toy box. It can't be everywhere anymore once you've seen it. So, "observation" is just you looking or measuring, and "collapse" is when all those possibilities of where it *could* be suddenly pick just *one* real place to be. It's like the universe decides, "Okay, time to be real!" when someone looks.

title: Do animals ever get sick of eating the same thing everyday?
text: You know how sometimes you really want to eat pizza every day, but then your grown-up says you need to eat other things too? Well, animals are a little different! Most animals don't get bored of their food because their tummies and bodies are made to eat just one or a few special things. A panda only wants bamboo, and a lion only wants meat, because that's what makes them strong and healthy and helps them grow big. They don't think about trying new foods like we do for fun; they just know what keeps them alive and happy, and that's usually the same yummy food every single day!

title: Why did Mao and Stalin kill all those people?
text: Imagine if there were two very bossy grown-ups named Mao and Stalin, and they wanted to be the *only* boss of their whole country, like being the only boss of all the playgrounds and all the houses! They had a very special idea of how everyone should live, and they wanted *everyone* to follow *their* rules, and only *their* rules. If anyone said, 'Hey, maybe

title: Why some people can grow beards and others can't? (even if people seem to be the same build ie similar testosterone)
text: Imagine your face is like a special garden! Some people's gardens have tiny seeds that are super good at growing big, bushy plants called beards when they get sunshine and water. Other people's gardens have different kinds of seeds that only grow tiny, soft plants, or maybe no plants at all, even if they get the exact same sunshine and water! It's not really about how strong someone is or how much "special food" for hair they have inside their body (that's like the sunshine and water), but more about the secret instructions inside their body, like a special map for their hair. Some maps say "grow a big, fluffy beard!" and others say "just grow a little fuzz!" Everyone's map is a little bit different, and that's why some people can grow a big beard and some can't, even if they seem very similar!

title: What exactly stops our bodies from defecating and urinating as we sleep? What acts as an "alarm" that jolts us awake when we do need to do these things?
text: Okay, imagine your body has special little doors inside, like the doors on your house. When you're awake, you can choose to open them when you need to go to the potty. But when you're sleeping, these doors are usually closed and locked up tight! They're like sleepy guards making sure nothing comes out. Your brain, which is also a bit sleepy, tells them to stay shut. But if your tummy or your bladder (which is like a balloon inside that holds your pee) gets super, super full, it starts to push on those doors really hard. It's like a balloon that's about to pop! This pushing sends a special "wake-up!" signal, like a little alarm bell, all the way up to your brain. Even though your brain is sleepy, this alarm is so strong it nudges your brain awake just enough for you to feel it and know you need to get up and go to the potty before those doors open by themselves. Then you can go, and your body can go back to sleep feeling much better!

title: Is the huge dust from an massive building implosion (like the Georgia Dome in Atlanta this week) harmful to humans?
text: Imagine a giant building falling down, *poof*! And a super-duper big cloud of dust appears, like when you drop your cookie and it makes a little puff of crumbs. That big dust cloud is made of tiny, tiny pieces of the building – like super fine sand, but also bits of the concrete and metal and old paint that were part of the building. If you were to breathe in just a little bit, it might make you cough or sneeze, like when you get a tickle in your nose. But if you breathe in *lots* and *lots* of that dust, especially the really tiny pieces, it's like tiny little pokey things going into your lungs, which are like the sponges inside you that help you breathe. Some of those tiny pokey things aren't very friendly, and they can make your lungs get sad or even sick if you breathe them in for a long, long time. That's why grown-ups make sure people stay far away when a building comes down like that, or they wear special masks to keep the dust out of their noses and mouths, so their lungs stay happy and healthy!

title: Picasso and Cubism. How does Cubism work? What's the idea behind it?

title: Why do small, superficial wounds heal faster on certain areas of the body, like the mouth, than in other areas?
text: Imagine your body is like a special house, and when you get a little scratch, it's like a tiny crack in the wall. Your body has amazing little construction workers that rush to fix it! In your mouth, these workers are super-duper fast because it's always wet with your spit, which helps keep the crack soft and clean, like wet clay is easier to fix than dry dirt. There's also lots of yummy blood food nearby for the workers, so they have lots of energy to build quickly. Plus, the skin in your mouth doesn't get pulled and stretched as much as, say, your knee when you run and bend. So, on your knee, the workers are still great, but it might be a bit drier, and every time you move, the crack might get pulled a little bit, making it take just a tiny bit longer to build that wall strong again.

title: Why does antimicrobial treatment start only after blood cultures are negative?
text: Okay, imagine you feel super yucky because some invisible tiny bad guys are making you sick! The doctors want to help you feel better *right away*. They take a little peek at your blood (

title: What is a medium? Why is air and water mediums?
text: Imagine you want to send a toy car across the floor – the floor is like a path for your car. Well, a "medium" is kind of like the special "stuff" or "path" that helps other things move or travel from one place to another. It's the "road" or the "helper" that things like sound or light use to get around. Air and water are mediums because they are those helpers! When you talk, your voice travels through the air to your friend's ears, so the air is helping your voice move. When a bird flies, it pushes through the air. And when a fish swims, it moves through the water. The water helps the fish move, and it's also how sounds travel if you're underwater. So, air and water are just the "stuff

title: How do they stop a large gas main fire?
text: Imagine a really, really big hose that brings gas to lots of houses, and it breaks and the gas catches fire! It's like a giant, roaring fire that just keeps getting bigger

title: When food goes stale, does it also become less nutricious?
text: Imagine your food has little tiny power-up stars inside that help your body grow big and strong, like a superhero! When food gets old and goes stale, like when your cracker isn't crunchy anymore or your bread gets hard, some of those power-up stars can get a little sleepy and fade away. So, while it still has *some* stars, it doesn't have *as many* as when it was super fresh and new. It's still usually okay to eat, but it won't give your body quite as much superhero fuel as when it was just made.

title: Why do police officers not always wear kevlar as an occupational precaution?
text: Imagine a police officer has a special, strong shirt called a 'vest' that's like a superhero shield! It's super good at helping to keep them safe if something yucky, like a really fast rock, tries to hit them. But this special shirt is also kind of heavy and hot, like wearing your big warm winter coat on a sunny day when you're just playing inside. So, police officers don't wear it *all* the time, just like you don't always wear your helmet when you're not riding your bike. They wear it when they think they might need extra protection, like when they're going to a place where there might be a naughty person or something that could hurt them. When they are just helping a cat out of a tree or saying hello to people, they might not wear it because it's more comfy without it, and they are very smart and know when it's important to put their superhero shield on!

title: Why was salt so valuable? Couldn’t coastal communities just evaporate ocean/sea water?
text: Imagine your yummy food, like meat or fish, going yucky and stinky super fast! Salt was like a magic dust that made it stay good for a long, long time, so people wouldn't be hungry, especially in winter. It also made boring food taste yummy! Yes, people who lived right next to the big, big ocean *could* put ocean water in big, flat puddles and let the sun bake it until only the salt was left, like making a sandy castle but with salt! But not everyone lived by the ocean. Some people lived far, far away, in the middle of the land. So, to get that super important salt, they had to trade for it or travel a super long way. And sometimes, the people who *did* make the salt wanted lots of other valuable things (like shiny gold or yummy food) for their hard work and their special salt, because everyone needed it and it was hard for many to get!

title: Why is lead used to protect against radiation?
text: Imagine radiation is like a lot of super speedy, invisible little bouncy balls trying to zoom everywhere! Now, lead is like a super, duper heavy and thick blanket, or a really, really strong wall made of special, heavy stuff. When those super speedy little bouncy balls (radiation) try to fly through, they hit the lead wall. Because the lead is so heavy and so thick, it's like trying to run through a giant mud puddle that's also made of super glue! The lead just catches all those tiny, speedy bouncy balls and stops them right in their tracks, so they can't get past it to touch you. It's like the best catcher in the whole wide world for those invisible, speedy balls!

title: We do we feel tired after thinking/focusing for a while? Are we expending energy in our brain?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super special muscle, just like the ones in your legs that help you run! When you run really fast for a long time, your legs get tired, right? Well, when you think super hard, like trying to figure out a tricky puzzle or learn new words, your brain is doing lots and lots of work! And just like your legs need yummy food energy to run, your brain needs its own special energy to think. When it uses up a lot of that energy, it gets tired, just like your legs. It needs a little rest, maybe a snack, or even a nap, to fill up its energy tank again so it can be super smart and ready to think some more!

title: in light of the current US political climate, how is America still tied to a two party system?
text: Imagine America is like a big playground, and when it's time to pick someone to be in charge, there are usually two very big teams playing the game: the red team and the blue team. Even if these two teams are sometimes grumpy with each other, it's still hard for a brand new, small team to win because of a few things. First, when we vote, it's like picking just one winner in a race, and usually the two biggest teams have the most friends cheering for them, so one of them almost always wins. If you cheer for a really small team, it's like your cheer might not help them win the race, and it might even make it harder for the big team you like a little bit more to win. Also, the big teams have lots and lots of money and helpers to tell everyone about their ideas, like having the loudest megaphones and the most toys. New, smaller teams don't have as many megaphones or helpers to tell everyone they want to play. So, even if the red team and the blue team are fighting over the ball, they're still the two main teams who know how to play the game and have all the stuff to try and win.

title: Prions and prion disease; how can a protein be infectious?

title: How can I get electroshocked while building a computer, even when it's all turned off?
text: Imagine you're running around and rubbing your feet on the carpet really fast! Sometimes, when you then touch a metal doorknob, you feel a tiny 'ZAP!' right? That's called 'static electricity,' and it's like a tiny, invisible spark. Even when your computer is totally turned off and unplugged, you can still have some of that static electricity hiding on your hands or clothes. If you touch the computer's delicate parts with that tiny zap, it's like a big surprise for the computer, and it can make it sick or break it, even though you don't feel much. That's why grown-ups try to touch something metal first, like a big table leg, to let all those tiny invisible sparks go away before they touch the computer parts!

title: What stops our body from defecating when we pass gas? How does flatuce exit below a solid?
text: Okay, imagine your bottom has two special jobs, and it's super smart! It has muscles that are like strong little doors. When you have a fart, which is just air from your tummy, your body knows to open just the 'air door' a tiny bit to let it sneak out. It keeps the 'poop door' closed very, very tightly so no poop comes out by accident! Now, how does the air get out if there's poop waiting? Think of the air as tiny, bubbly explorers. Even if there's solid poop sitting there, which is like a big rock, the air bubbles are super good at finding little cracks and spaces all around it. They're light and pushy, so they just wiggle and squeeze their way past the poop, finding a path to get out. Your body is really good at making sure the air can escape without the solid stuff coming along for the ride!

title: What's the difference from an Ethernet Switch and the extra Ethernet Ports on the back of my router?
text:
Okay, imagine your internet is like a big box of super cool toys that come into your house. Your router is the special *main toy box* that brings all those toys into your room from outside! It has a few special doors (those extra ports on the back) where your favorite toys, like your computer or TV, can plug in to play with the internet toys. The router also makes sure all your toys in the house can talk to each other and play nicely.

Now, what if you have lots and lots of friends who also want to play with the internet toys, but all the doors on your main toy box (router) are full? An Ethernet switch is like a *helper toy box*. You plug the helper toy box into just *one* of the doors on your main toy box, and suddenly, the helper toy box has *many, many more doors* for all your new friends to plug into! The helper toy box (switch) doesn't bring the toys into the room itself; it just helps your *main toy box* (router) share its toys with even more friends when it runs out of doors. So, the router is the boss that brings the toys and shares them, and the switch just helps the boss share even more.

title: why do nuclear detonations rest in the infamous “mushroom cloud”?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper powerful firecracker, but like, a million billion times bigger! When it goes BOOM, it makes a giant, super-hot bubble of air right away. Hot air is like a balloon that wants to float up, up, up into the sky really, really fast because it's lighter than the cold air around it. As this super-hot air zooms up, it sucks all the air and dirt from the ground and sides with it, like a giant vacuum cleaner pulling up dust. This makes the long, skinny "stem" of the mushroom. But when it gets really high, it bumps into other air that's not as hot and can't push through it anymore, so it has to spread out sideways, like a pancake getting squished. That spreading-out part is the big, fluffy "cap" of the mushroom! So you get a tall stick of rising air and dirt, with a big flat cloud on top, just like a yummy mushroom you might see in a storybook.

title: I've noticed that women I know who have 1 C-Section seem to have C-Sections for every child thereafter. Can someone explain to me 1) Is this a necessity, or just coincidental in the particular women I've known, and 2) Why would that be necessary?

title: Why do beer bottles fizz out of the bottle when someone smacks the top with another beer ?
text: Okay, imagine your beer has lots and lots of tiny, sleepy bubbles of gas hiding inside, like little kids in a big pool. The cap on top is like a lid keeping them all squished down and asleep. When someone gives the bottle a really big *bonk* on the head with another bottle, it makes a super big shake all the way through the liquid. This big shake *wakes up* all those sleepy bubbles super fast, all at the same time! And when they all wake up at once, they all want to jump out of the bottle right now, like a whole bunch of kids suddenly running out of the pool at the same time, which makes the fizzy drink go *whoosh* right out!

title: Why do we feel less need to pee when we are walking?
text: Imagine your pee is like a little balloon inside your tummy! When it gets full, it tells your brain, "Hey! I need to let go!" But sometimes, when you're busy walking and playing, your brain is thinking about all the fun things you're doing, like looking at trees or running. It's like when you're super focused on your favorite cartoon, you might forget you're even hungry for a little while! Also, when you're sitting still, sometimes the way you sit can give your balloon a little squeeze, making it feel like it needs to go *right now*. But when you're walking, your body is moving around, so your balloon gets a little more space and isn't squished as much, making it feel less urgent. It doesn't make the pee disappear, your brain just gets busy with other things and the balloon is a bit comfier, so it waits a little longer to remind you.

title: How do (usually paid for) fake social media likes, favorites, and followers actually happen?
text: Imagine you have a drawing you're super proud of, and you want lots and lots of people to say "I love it!" But maybe not many real friends have seen it yet. So, some grown-ups decide to pay a special "magic shop" on the internet. This shop doesn't sell toys, but it has lots of pretend friends, like little robots! These robots don't have real feelings or brains, but they are very good at clicking buttons on a computer. So, when someone pays the magic shop, the shop tells

title: If the moon's orbit around Earth is 27 days, what does that means for how often the moon is visible to me, a person on earth?
text: Imagine the moon is like a big ball that goes around our Earth, just like you might run around a tree! It takes about 27 days, which is almost a whole month, for the moon to make one complete trip around us. The moon doesn't make its own light, it's like a giant mirror that bounces light from the sun. As it goes around, we see different amounts of its sunny side. Sometimes we see a big bright circle, sometimes just a little sliver like a banana, and sometimes its sunny side is facing away from us completely, so it looks like it's hiding and we can't see it at all! But it's always there, going around and around, so we get to see it shine and change its shape almost every night, and sometimes even during the day, as it keeps travelling on its path.

title: Why is the Internet governed the way it is? .... How did it become controlled by a handful of companies? And also isn’t there a way to get internet without these big companies and their contracts?
text:
Imagine the internet is like a giant, magical playground where everyone can play and share their toys (information) and stories (websites). There isn't one single boss of the whole playground. Instead, lots of different grown-ups and helpers from all over the world work together to make sure the rules are fair, like making sure every toy has a unique name so we don't get confused, and that all the paths connecting our houses to the playground work. It's like everyone agreeing on traffic lights so cars don't crash, but no one person owns all the roads.

Now, getting to this amazing playground from your house needs a special road. These roads are super, super long and go under the ground or through big towers in the sky, and building them costs a *lot* of money, like building a whole castle! Only a few very big companies had enough money and big trucks (special tools) to build these super important roads for almost everyone. So, most people use the roads built by these big companies to get to the internet playground, and these companies charge a little bit of money each month to use their roads and keep them working, like paying for the special bus that takes you to the playground every day.

It's really hard to get to the internet playground without using these big companies' roads. You *could* try to build your *very own* tiny road just from your house, but that would be super, super hard and cost a mountain of toys and all your building blocks! Some clever people try to make small, shared roads just for their neighborhood, where everyone helps build a little piece, but even those small roads usually need to connect to the bigger, main roads that the big companies built to reach the *whole* big internet playground. So, for most of us, it's just much easier and cheaper to pay the big companies a little bit to use their amazing, far-reaching roads.

title: How are people so influenced by music, what influences people’s tastes, and what separates good from bad music?
text: Music is like a special magic that makes your feelings dance! When you hear a happy song, it makes your feet want to wiggle and your face want to smile. If it's a calm song

title: I'm told that if you delete data from a computer, it isn't *actually* gone, and is recoverable - so if the freed up memory can be used for new data, how is it possible given storage capacity limits?
text: Imagine your computer is like a giant coloring book with lots of pages. When you "delete" a drawing, you don't actually rip the page out of the book! Instead, you just put a little sticky note on that page that says "EMPTY! You can draw something new here!" The old drawing is still there underneath the sticky note, right? Your computer thinks that page is empty and ready for a new picture. So, if you

title: Why is the most accurate and precise way to read a babies’ temperature is through the rectum?
text: Imagine your body is like a warm house, and we want to know how warm it really is inside your house. If we just touch the outside wall or the window, it might feel a little cooler because of the wind or the air around it. But if we go deep inside your house, like into the living room, we get a much better idea of how warm the whole house truly is. For babies, their bottom (we call it the rectum) is a very safe and deep place inside their body where we can feel the real warmth of their insides, which helps doctors know exactly how they are feeling, much better than just touching their forehead!

title: How do "text x to xxxxx" numbers work?
text: Okay, imagine your phone is like a little magic box! When you text your mommy or daddy, it's like sending a message right to their own special box. But those short numbers, like when you text "VOTE" to "22222," aren't for a person's box. They're like a special doorbell for a super-smart robot computer! This robot computer is waiting to hear certain words. So when you text "VOTE" to its special number, the robot sees it and says, "Aha! Someone wants to vote!" and it quickly counts your vote or does whatever special job it's programmed to do, like sending you back a fun picture. It's like pressing a special button on your phone that makes a computer do something specific, instead of just talking to a friend!

title: what exactly is this committee announcement trying to say?
text: Okay, imagine a bunch of grown-ups, like your teachers or your parents' friends, all sitting together and talking about something important, like what rules to have for playtime or what new snack to buy. That group of grown-ups is like a "committee"! When they finally decide something, like "everyone needs to put their toys away before snack," and then they tell everyone about it, that's their "announcement." So, a committee announcement is just when a group of grown-ups tells everyone what they talked about and decided. I don't know *which* announcement you're thinking of, but usually, it's them saying "This is what we decided, and this is what we're going to do!"

title: If/do our bodies swell in certain areas to protect a hurt or damaged area. Why do we use things like ice packs to reduce swelling of that area?
text: When you get a boo-boo, your body is super smart! It sends lots of special little "doctor" helpers and "fixer" helpers to that spot. They bring lots of "medicine" and "building blocks" to make it better. All these helpers and building blocks make the area puff up a little bit, like a soft pillow around your boo-boo. This pillow helps protect it so you don't hurt it more, and it helps the helpers do their job faster. But sometimes, your body sends *too many* helpers and building blocks, and the pillow gets *too big*! When it's too big, it can push on other parts and make it feel even more ouchy. So, we use an ice pack! The ice is like a little "shhh, slow down" signal that tells some of those extra helpers to take a break or go back home for a bit. It makes the pillow a little smaller, which helps the ouchy feel better and gives the *right amount* of helpers space to work without making it too uncomfortable.

title: How do we know the Zodiac Killer’s cypher isn’t just complete BS that he made up?
text: Okay, imagine you have a secret message, but instead of writing "hello," you draw a star for 'h', a heart for 'e', and so on. That's a secret code! But if you just draw a bunch of random squiggles that don't mean anything, that's not a code, that's just drawing. When smart grown-ups look at a secret message, they look for patterns! Like, if the star shows up a *lot*, they might guess the star means 'E', because 'E' is a very popular letter in words. If it was just silly squiggles, no letter or symbol would show up more than any other, it would all be mixed up and random. But with the Zodiac's message, the grown-ups saw these patterns! They saw some symbols showing up a lot, and they started to guess what those symbols might mean. Like putting together a puzzle, once you figure out one piece, it helps you figure out the next. Because they found these patterns and could start to guess words, they knew it was a real secret code, not just a bunch of nonsense drawings!

title: What's special about CO2 that we add it to water/soda and not other gasses? Why not use compressed air or another gas?
text: Imagine your soda is like a special swimming pool for tiny, tiny bubbles! The gas we put in there, called CO2, is like a super friendly guest that loves to swim in the water and then pop out to tickle your nose and make that fun fizzy sound. CO2 is really good at staying hidden in the water until you open the bottle, and then it makes lots and lots of small, happy bubbles that taste yummy and make the drink special. Other gases, like the air we breathe, are not as friendly to water; they don't like to stay inside the drink for long, so if we put air in your soda, all the bubbles would run away super fast, your drink would go flat and yucky very quickly, and it might even taste a bit weird! So, CO2 is the best bubble friend for your soda because it makes the fun last and tastes great!

title: Why ejaculation feels better the longer you last?
text: Okay, imagine you're blowing up a balloon, but you're going super slow. The more air you put in, the bigger and fuller it gets, right? It's getting all ready to let out a big pop! Your body is kind of like that balloon. When you're getting excited and playing, your body slowly fills up with a special happy feeling, like the air in the balloon. The longer you wait and the more that happy feeling builds up inside, the more full and ready your body gets. So, when it's finally time for the big "whoosh" (that's the ejaculation!), it's like the balloon letting out all its air with a really big, satisfying pop! Because there was so much happy feeling built up, letting it all out feels extra, extra good and super relaxing, like a big happy sigh after a long, long wait.

title: What happens to our feces in the sewers?
text: When you flush the toilet, your poop goes on a big adventure! It slides down a pipe, like a secret slide, right under your house. Then, that pipe connects to even bigger pipes, like underground roads, where it meets all the other poops and water from your neighbors

title: In networking, what is the difference between a router and a hub?
text:
Okay, imagine you have a bunch of toys in your room that want to talk to each other.

A **hub** is like a very simple walkie-talkie that just shouts *everything* you say to *everyone* in the room. If you want to tell just one toy something, all the other toys hear it too, even if it's not for them! It's not very smart and can get very noisy.

A **router** is like a super smart postman for your room. It knows exactly which toy wants to talk to which other toy, so it sends the message *only* to the right one. And even cooler, your router is the special door that lets your toys talk to other toys in other rooms, or even toys all the way across the world on the internet! It connects your house to the big outside world. So, a hub just shouts, but a router is a smart messenger who knows where everything goes and can even send messages far away.

title: How does cyanide kill people?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big, busy factory, and all the little worker machines inside need special air, called oxygen, to keep running and doing their jobs. Little tiny trucks in your blood carry this oxygen all over the factory, bringing it to every single machine. Cyanide is like a super mean, sticky monster that jumps onto those little trucks and won't let go! When the monster is stuck on the trucks, they can't pick up the oxygen anymore. So, all the worker machines, especially the super important ones like your brain and your heart, don't get their air, and they get super tired and stop working, and then the whole factory stops working too.

title: How is it possible that ISP's can see what your up to online? I thought HTTPs encrypted your traffic so it can't be read?
text: Imagine you're sending a secret letter to your friend. HTTPS is like putting your secret message inside a special magic box that nobody can open. So, your ISP (who is like the mailman) can't read what's *inside* your letter, which is great! But, the mailman still needs to know *where* to deliver the box, right? So, you still have to write your friend's house address on the *outside* of the box. The mailman sees that you sent a magic box to "Disney World's house" or "Netflix's house," even if they don't know what toy you asked for or what show you're watching inside the box. So, they know you're visiting Disney or Netflix, but they don't know *what exactly* you're doing there.

title: How has the US ISP market become the duopoly it is today?
text: Imagine the internet is like a super-duper fast slide that brings you all your cartoons and games! A long, long time ago, when people first wanted these slides, it cost a super lot of money to build them all over town, like building giant roller coasters to every single house. Only a few really big, rich companies had enough money to build those special internet roads and pipes. Once they built their roads, it was super hard and super expensive for *new* companies to come along and build a *whole other set* of roads right next to them. Sometimes, a big slide company would even buy a smaller slide company, making them even bigger! So now, in many places, there are only one or two big companies that built those first expensive roads, and it's just too tricky and costly for anyone else to start building new ones from scratch. That's why you often only have two main choices for your internet slide.

title: why do we have trouble falling asleep when we felt extremely sleepy two hours prior to going to bed?
text: Imagine your body is like a little train. When you feel super, super sleepy, that's your sleepy train pulling into the station, ready to take you to Sleepytown! It's the perfect time to hop on board and go to sleep. But if you don't get on right away, and you stay up playing or doing other things, the sleepy train says 'choo-choo!' and leaves the station without you. After it leaves, your body gets a little burst of energy, like it found a tiny bit of candy to wake it up a little. So when you finally get into bed later, the sleepy train isn't there anymore, and you have to wait for the next one to come around, which can take a little while. That's why it's hard to fall asleep, because you missed your first sleepy train!

title: Considering the huge profits to be had from cannabis, how does it "hurt big pharma"?
text: Imagine there's a really big candy store that sells special "feel better" candies when grown-ups have a boo-boo or feel sleepy. They make a lot of money because lots of grown-ups buy their candies. Now, imagine there's a special plant, like a happy flower, that can also make some grown-ups feel better or help them sleep, and it's cheaper or works differently for them. If lots of grown-ups start using the happy flower instead of buying the "feel better" candies from the big candy store, then the big candy store won't sell as many candies and won't get as much money. It's like when you choose a new toy instead of an old one – the old toy shop might feel a little sad because you're playing with something else instead of their things.

title: Can someone please explain Marxism?
text: Imagine you and your friends are playing in a big toy room. There's one kid, let's call him Bossy Bob, who says, "These are all MY toys! You can play with them, but only if you build me a super tall block tower, and I'll decide which toys you get to use." So, you and your friends work super hard, building the tower and cleaning up, but Bossy Bob keeps all the best, newest toys for himself and only gives you the old, broken ones. You might think, "That'

title: Why does breathing in through the nose and out through the mouth help with relaxation?
text: Imagine your nose is like a special gentle door for air, that helps clean it and warm it up before it goes inside your body, like a cozy blanket for your lungs! When you breathe in slowly through your nose, it tells your body to take a nice, long, calm breath, like you're smelling a yummy flower very carefully. Then, when you breathe out slowly through your mouth, it's like blowing out a candle very, very gently. This helps you let go of any wiggles or worries and tells your body, "Shhh, time to be super relaxed!" Doing both together is like giving your body a big, soft hug that makes you feel peaceful and sleepy, just like after a big play.

title: Why is blue light in electronic devices bad before falling asleep?
text: Okay, imagine your body has a special clock inside that tells it when it's daytime and when it's sleepy time. When it gets dark outside, your body's clock starts getting ready for sleep. But the bright blue light from your tablet or phone looks a lot like the sunshine to your body! So, if you look at it right before bed, your body's clock gets confused and thinks, "Hey, it's still daytime! No sleepy time yet!" This makes it much harder for your body to get tired and for you to fall asleep, even if you're really snuggled up in bed.

title: Why do animals have different types of tails?
text: Imagine you have different tools for different jobs, right? Like a spoon for eating soup and a fork for eating noodles! Animals are a bit like that with their tails. Some animals have long, skinny tails, like a monkey, and that helps them swing from tree to tree and keep their balance so they don't fall down. Other animals, like a fish, have a big flat tail, and that helps them push through the water super fast, like a paddle on a boat! A dog wags its tail to show it's happy, like you smile when you're happy. And a kangaroo has a big strong tail that helps it stand up straight and jump super far! So, animals have different tails because each tail helps them do something special that's important for their life, like walking, swimming, climbing, or even talking to other animals.

title: What do Singing coaches/lessons actually do to help their students' voices?
text: Imagine your voice is like a little car, and when you first start singing, you might not know how to drive it perfectly! A singing coach is like a super friendly driving teacher for your voice car. They teach you how to fill your car with just enough air, like gas, so you don't run out of breath in the middle of a song. They show you how to steer your voice gently so it doesn't crash into high notes or stumble on low ones, making it sound smooth and pretty instead of shaky. They also help you make your voice strong so it can sing loud happy songs without getting tired or hurting itself, and they teach you fun little games and warm-ups, like stretching before you run, to get your voice ready to sing beautifully and safely every time!

title: How do Car Keys hold their charge? Do they get charged by the car?
text: Your car key has a tiny, tiny battery inside, just like how your toy remote control or a small flashlight needs batteries to make it work! This little battery has all the power it needs stored up, like a tiny tank of juice. It doesn't get filled up again by the car, no. When the juice runs out, a grown-up just puts a brand new, fresh battery inside the key, and then it works great again, just like putting new batteries in your toy!

title: How do yeast/bread starters stay alive for years at a time?
text: Imagine your bread starter is like a tiny, sleepy pet living in a jar! This pet loves to eat flour and drink water. When it eats, it gets really happy and bubbly, and that's when it helps make your bread fluffy. If you want it to stay alive for a very, very long time, you can put it in a cold bed, like your fridge. When it's cold, it gets super sleepy and takes a long nap, just like a bear hibernating. While it's sleeping, it doesn't need to eat much food at all, maybe just a tiny snack every week or two to stay cozy. When you want to bake bread, you wake your pet up, give it lots of fresh food and water, and it gets all bouncy and strong again! Then, after it helps with the bread, you can put it back to sleep in the fridge until next time. So, it mostly sleeps and only wakes up for snacks and to play when you need it, which is how it can stay alive for many, many years!

title: Why do young children laugh differently than adults?
text: It's like this: when you're little, your body is still growing, just like a tiny puppy! Your voice box, which makes all your sounds, is super small, like a tiny little whistle. When you laugh, you get so excited that all that happy air comes out really fast and high-pitched because everything is still so little! Grown-ups have bigger bodies and bigger voice boxes, so their laughs sound a bit deeper and sometimes a little more controlled, because they've had lots and lots of practice with their big voices. But both kinds of laughs are super happy and fun!

title: How do agricultural markets function with supply and demand along with prices?
text:
Imagine Farmer John grows yummy apples!

**Demand:** Sometimes, lots and lots of kids want apples for snack time because they are so red and sweet! That's like "demand" – how many people want something. If everyone wants apples, demand is high!

**Supply:** But Farmer John only has so many apple trees, and each tree only grows a certain number of apples. That's like "supply" – how many apples Farmer John actually has to sell. Sometimes he has tons, sometimes not so many.

**Prices:** Now, here's the trick! If Farmer John has SO MANY apples (big supply) but not many kids want them right now (low demand), he might say, "Okay, apples are just 5 cents each!" because he wants to sell them all before they go bad. He makes them cheaper so more people buy them. But if Farmer John only has a FEW apples (small supply) and EVERYONE wants them (high demand), he might say, "Wow, everyone wants my apples! I'll sell them for 25 cents each!" because he knows people really want them and there aren't many. Most of the time, it's somewhere in the middle, and the price is fair for everyone.

So, the "agricultural market" is just like the big imaginary store where all the farmers bring their food, and all the people come to buy it. The price of food changes based on how much

title: What causes the sticky, frictional feeling you get on your hands after using bar soap?
text: Okay, imagine your hands have tiny, invisible little bits of dirt and oil, like tiny crumbs. Soap is like a special cleaner that comes along and grabs onto those crumbs, making them ready to be washed away with water. But sometimes, if you don't splash *all* the water to wash *all* the soap and *all* the crumbs completely off your hands, a tiny, tiny little bit of them stays behind. This little bit isn't really sticky like honey, but it makes your skin feel a little bit like it's grabbing onto itself when you rub your hands together, instead of being super-duper smooth and slidey. It's just a tiny bit of leftover soap and the things it grabbed, waiting for a little more water to completely disappear!

title: When things are transparent (like a window, thin piece of paper), do the photons of the light source actually move through the object?
text: Yes, they totally do! Imagine light is made of super tiny, super fast little balls, like the smallest bouncy balls you've ever seen. And a window is like a giant fence made of even tinier, invisible sticks, but with lots and lots of space in between them. When the light-balls hit the window, most of them just zoom right through the big spaces between the invisible sticks, like you running through a big empty playground. Some might bounce off (that's why you sometimes see your reflection!), but lots and lots just keep going on the other side, which is why you can see right through it!

title: Why do our ears need to "pop* when we change elevations, and how does yawning make it happen?
text: Imagine your ear has a tiny, secret room inside, and this room has a little door. When you go up high in an airplane or down low in a car, the air outside your ear pushes differently. Sometimes the air in your secret ear room gets stuck and pushes too hard or not hard enough compared to the air outside, which makes your ear feel funny or squished. The "pop" is like that little door opening up to let the air in your secret room match the air outside, making everything feel comfy again! When you yawn, it's like you're giving a big stretch to the muscles around that little door, pulling it wide open for a second. This lets the air rush in or out of your secret ear room, making the air inside match the air outside, and *POP*! Your ears feel normal again, like letting the air out of a balloon that's too full.

title: Why do snails ‘melt’ when you pour salt over them?
text: Imagine a snail is like a super squishy water balloon, mostly made of water! Salt is like a very, very thirsty little magnet for water. When you sprinkle salt on the snail, that thirsty salt quickly sucks all the water right out of the snail's body, like a super-fast straw! It's like popping lots of tiny holes in the water balloon, and all the water rushes out really, really fast. The snail gets all shriveled up and turns into a little wet mess because it's lost all its water, not because it's melting like an ice cube, but because the salt drank it all up!

title: In extremely cold weathers, why is it that we layer 3-4 and sometimes more pieces of clothing for our upper body, but not do the same for our lower body?
text: Imagine your body is like a warm, yummy cookie, and the cold air outside wants to make it chilly! Your clothes are like blankets for your cookie. When you put on lots of shirts, one on top of another, each shirt traps a little bit of your warm air, making tiny warm bubbles all around your top half, like many small blankets keeping you extra toasty. We do this for your top half because that's where your super important parts are, like your heart and your lungs, and they need to stay extra, extra warm to work their best! Your top half also has a bigger, flatter surface that can lose heat faster. Your legs and bottom half are busy running and playing, which helps them make their own warmth! Plus, your pants are usually like one really thick, good blanket for your legs, and because they're always moving, they don't always need as many tiny warm bubbles as your very important, less-moving top half. So, your legs usually stay cozy enough with just one warm pair of pants, while your top needs more layers to protect all those important bits and keep you super warm where you need it most!

title: Are flu shots an "all-or-nothing" protection, or do they also lessen the severity if you do get sick?
text: Imagine your body is like a castle, and the flu germs are like tiny, yucky monsters trying to get in and make you feel sleepy and sniffly. The flu shot is like giving your castle a special shield! It's not like the shield *always* stops every single monster from ever getting near, like an 'all or nothing' super-duper force field. Sometimes, a few sneaky monsters might still get past the shield. BUT, here's the cool part: if a monster *does* get past, the shield makes them much, much weaker and smaller. So, instead of a big, scary monster making you super sick, it's just a tiny, sleepy monster that makes you feel only a little bit yucky, and you get better much faster! So, it helps a lot, even if it doesn't stop every single tiny germ.

title: Why does boiling water stop rolling when you stir it?
text: Imagine the water is having a super bubbly party because the bottom is getting super-duper hot, making big bubbles that want to zoom up! This makes the water roll and tumble. But when you stir it with your spoon, you're like a little helper who mixes all the hot parts from the bottom with the not-so-hot parts from the top. It's like you're spreading the hotness all around, so the water isn't *as* excited in one spot anymore. It still wants to boil, but because you've mixed everything up, it calms down its rolling dance for a little while until the bottom gets super hot again.

title: Why is processed food significantly cheaper than unprocessed food?
text:
Imagine you want something yummy to eat!

Think about a fresh, crunchy apple. That apple grew on a tree, and someone had to pick it carefully. It needs sun and water to grow, and it can only stay fresh for a little while before it gets soft. Because it's special and takes a bit of work to grow and get to you, it costs a bit more.

Now think about a yummy cookie or a bag of chips. These are made in a big, busy factory! They use things like flour, sugar, and oil, which are like building blocks that are easy to get a lot of. Machines mix them all up super fast, and they can make millions of cookies or chips every day. Because they can make so much so quickly, and the ingredients are easy to find, they don't cost as much to make. Plus, these factory foods can sit on the shelf for a very, very long time

text: Imagine you're playing, and suddenly, someone claps their hands super, super loud right next to your ear, and at the exact same time, someone shines a super bright flashlight right into your eyes! When it goes off, it makes a giant, super bright light that makes your eyes feel all confused, so you can't see properly for a little bit, like when you look at a really bright light. And it makes a super, super loud noise that makes your ears feel all confused, so you can't hear very well for a little bit, like when a big balloon pops right next to you. It doesn

title: Salt water oceans, but fresh water ice caps?
text:
Okay, imagine the ocean is like a giant, super old bathtub! When rain falls on the land, it washes tiny, tiny bits of salt and other stuff from the rocks and dirt, and all that water flows into rivers that carry it to the ocean. The sun shines on the ocean and drinks up some of the water, making it go "poof" into the sky, but it leaves all the salt behind. Over a super, super long time, lots and lots of salt has piled up, making the ocean taste salty!

But when it gets super, super cold and the water wants to turn into ice, it's like the water says, "No thank you, salt! I only want to be *just* water when I freeze!" It pushes all the salt away, so only the clean, fresh water gets to turn into the big ice caps. That's why they're made of fresh water, because the freezing process cleans out all the salt!
