title: why do our recorded voices sound different to us but normal to everyone else?
text: Okay, imagine your voice is like a little bouncy ball! When you talk, that bouncy ball goes out into the air, and that's how everyone else hears you – like they catch the ball after it bounced through the room. But *you* also hear your voice in a super special way! Some of your voice travels right through the bones inside your head, like a secret tunnel! This secret tunnel makes your voice sound a little bit bigger and deeper to *you* than it really is when it just bounces through the air. Now, when you record your voice on a phone or a tablet, the phone only catches the bouncy ball that travels through the air, just like everyone else does. It doesn't have your secret bone tunnel! So, when you listen back, you're only hearing the air-bouncy-ball version of your voice, without that extra deepness from your secret tunnel. That's why it sounds a little bit different to *you* – because you're used to hearing *both* the air sound and the secret tunnel sound at the same time! But for everyone else, that recorded voice is exactly how they always hear your voice.

title: Why is it that blowing on a lit candle causes it to flicker but not go out, but a single puff of air is more effective at extinguishing the flame?
text: Imagine the candle flame is like a tiny, warm friend dancing! This friend needs two things to keep dancing: yummy warm air from the candle wax (that's its food!) and fresh air all around it (that's like its breathing air!). When you blow on it *gently*, it's like giving your dancing friend a little tickle! The tickle brings *more* fresh air for it to breathe, and it gets super excited and dances even faster and wiggles a lot (that's the flickering!). It also cools it down a tiny, tiny bit, but not enough to make it stop. But when you make a *big puff* of air, it's like a giant whoosh! This big whoosh blows away all the yummy warm air food that the flame needs to eat, and it also pushes away all its warmth very, very fast. Without its food and without being warm, the dancing friend can't dance anymore and just goes to sleep! Poof!

title: What part of our brain controls our internal clocks and what is happening when it seems to be “out of sync” for some people on long holiday weekends?
text: Imagine you have a tiny little boss inside your brain, super small, that has a special clock just for you! This boss is called the "suh-pruh-kai-az-MAT-ik noo-klee-us," but let's just call it your "sleepy-wakey boss." This sleepy-wakey boss helps your body know when it's time to be sleepy and go to bed, and when it's time to wake up and play. When you have a long holiday weekend, you get to stay up later and sleep in more, which is super fun! But it makes your sleepy-wakey boss a little confused because you're not following the usual schedule. It's like if your toy clock usually says it's bedtime at 8 o'clock, but for a few days, you get to stay up until 10! Your sleepy-wakey boss gets mixed up and thinks the new, later time is the right time, so when school or regular days start again, it's still telling your body to be sleepy later or wide awake earlier than it should, making you feel all out of sorts until it remembers the old schedule.

title: Why are the pockets on brand new suits and some other types of clothing sewn shut?

Once you take the suit home, you can ask a grown-up to carefully snip that little thread, and then your pockets are ready to hold your important grown-up things, like a very small secret note or a shiny coin.

title: Europes AC electricity has a frequency of 50hz instead of 60hz. Is it still possible to get 60fps on televisions and monitors?

It doesn't care how fast the electricity snake wiggles to *power* it, like how you don't care if your food was cooked in a fast or slow oven as long as it gives you energy. Your screen has its *own* special artist inside that draws new pictures super, super fast, many, many times a second, all by itself! So, even if the electricity snake wiggles 50 times, your screen's artist can still draw 60 new pictures every second (that's 60fps!) or even more, making everything look super smooth! So yes, it's totally possible!

title: Why does freezing certain foods lower the quality of it?

Some foods have stronger 'juice houses' and don't get poked as much, but others, like the strawberry, are very delicate and get messed up easily!

title: Why is solar power quite common here in Northern England when we have very low solar potential and are one of the windiest places on the planet?

Grown-ups in Northern England like them because even a little bit of sun power helps, and sometimes other grown-ups give them a little help to buy and put them on their houses, which makes it easier. Plus, they want to be super kind to our Earth and use the sun's power instead of making yucky smoke. So even though it's windy (which is great for big wind spinners!), the sunny plates still do their job quietly on the roof, catching all the light they can!

title: Why isn't 900p common like 1080 or 720p?

The 900p paper is kind of in the middle. It's a little bit bigger than the small paper, but not as big and clear as the really big paper. So, most toy companies and TV makers just focus on making things for the small paper or the super big paper because those are what most people want and understand easily. The middle size just doesn't get picked as often because it's not as cheap or quick as the small one, and not as super special or clear as the big one!

title: What causes death by shock?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super busy city, and your blood is like all the little delivery trucks bringing yummy food and fresh air to every single house (which are your body parts like your brain, heart, and hands) so they can work and play. They get super, super tired and stop working. If your most important houses, like your brain and your heart, stop working for too long because they didn't get their food, then your whole city stops working forever, and that's what we call death.

title: Why do loud noises actually damage our hearing?
text: Okay, imagine inside your ear, you have lots and lots of super tiny, super delicate little hairs, like the softest feathers you can imagine. When sounds come into your ear, these little hairs gently wiggle and dance, and that's how your brain knows there's a sound! Now, if a sound is too, too loud, it's like a giant, super strong wind blowing really hard on those tiny hairs. If the wind is too strong for too long, those delicate hairs can get bent, broken, or even fall off! When they're broken, they can't wiggle anymore, so your brain doesn't get the sound message for those sounds. That's why things sound quiet or you can't hear them anymore – because some of your little sound hairs got hurt by the big, loud sound!

title: How does tuberculosis make scars on lungs? Do these scars have any effect on lungs?
text: Okay, imagine your lungs are like two big, soft sponges inside your body that help you breathe air. When tiny, naughty germ bugs called tuberculosis get into your lungs, they start making little holes and messes, like tiny invaders. Your body's good guy 'soldier cells' rush in to fight these naughty bugs! When the soldiers win and clean up the mess, they put down special 'patches' or 'band-aids' to fix where the fight happened. These patches are what we call scars. They're like little old battle zones that got fixed up, but they're not as soft and stretchy as the normal sponge. Because these scar patches aren't as stretchy, your lungs might not be able to fill up with as much air as easily as they used to, or they might have to work a little bit harder to breathe. It's like trying to blow up a balloon that has some sticky tape on it – it still works, but it's not quite as easy or as big as it would be without the tape.

title: the marketing strategy behind limited time only foods at fast food restaurants?
text: Okay, imagine your favorite toy store gets a super-duper special new toy, but only for a few days! The fast-food places do something similar with their yummy special foods. They want you to get super excited and say, "Wow, a new burger or shake! I *have* to try it before it's gone!" Because it's only there for a little while, it feels extra special and makes you want to go right now, so you don't miss out on the fun new taste. It's like a special surprise party for your taste buds, and they want everyone to come try the new thing and maybe even get their favorite fries while they're there! Sometimes, they're also checking if everyone loves it so much they should bring it back again someday.

title: why do laptop and PC manufacturers install all of this useless software that slows the computer down so much?
text: Imagine your super-duper fast new computer is like a shiny, empty lunchbox ready for your favorite sandwich and snacks! But sometimes, before you even get it, other grown-ups put in extra little snack bags you didn't ask for, like tiny bags of carrots or a juice box you don't really like. Why do they do it? The problem is, all those extra, sometimes yucky, snacks make your lunchbox heavy and leave less room for your favorite things, and it takes longer to find what you really want. That's why your computer can feel slow, because it has to carry all those extra, unasked-for programs around, even though the computer makers got some money for putting them there.

title: Are plants spatially aware? How do they know which direction is the best to grow?
text: Plants are super cool! They don't have eyes or brains like you, so they don't "know" which way is best to grow in the same way you know where your toys are. Instead, they have special ways to "feel" things around them, like little sensors! Imagine the sun is like a giant yummy cookie. Plants have a special superpower to feel where the sun's light is. Their leaves and stems want to reach that light so they can eat it and grow big and strong, just like you eat food. So, they stretch and grow towards the sun! And guess what? They also feel gravity! Gravity is like an invisible hand that always pulls things down, like when you drop a ball. Plant roots feel this pull and know they need to grow *down* into the dirt to find water to drink and to hold the plant steady. At the same time, the plant's stem feels gravity too, but it knows it needs to grow *up* towards the sun. It's like they have an internal compass! Sometimes, roots also smell water, just like you can smell yummy food, and they grow towards it. So, plants don't "think" about it, but their amazing bodies just know how to find what they need to live and grow big!

title: Why do your muscles get so sore when you have the flu??
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big castle, and sometimes a tiny, yucky bug (that's the flu!) tries to sneak inside and cause trouble. Your body has special superhero helpers, like little soldiers, who rush out to fight that bug and kick it out! When these superhero soldiers are fighting really hard, they send out lots of little messages all over your castle to tell everyone to help. Sometimes, these messages and all that hard work make your muscles feel tired and a little bit achy, like they've been running a big race even though you were just sitting still. It's just your body working super duper hard on the inside to get rid of the yucky bug so you can feel all better!

title: Why is it relieving to exhale a little bit of air [at a time] while I'm holding my breath?
text: Imagine your tummy is like a balloon, and when you hold your breath, you're trying to keep all the air inside that balloon. It gets bigger and bigger and starts to feel a bit tight and uncomfortable, like it wants to pop! When you let out just a tiny *pffft* of air, it's like letting just a little bit of air out of the balloon. It doesn't make it empty, but it makes it feel a little less tight and a little less full for a moment, which feels like a tiny "whew!" because it's not pushing so hard anymore. Your body still wants to breathe normally, but that little *pffft* gives it a quick, tiny break from feeling so squished.

title: What exactly is psychedelic music?

This music might sound a bit wobbly, or like colors are swirling around your head, or like you're floating on a fluffy cloud. Sometimes it has funny echo sounds, like when you shout in a big empty room, or it feels like you're flying on a magic carpet through a super interesting, make-believe world. It's music that tries to make your ears and your imagination go wild, like you're seeing new things just by listening!

title: What exactly is the true north?
text: Imagine our Earth is like a giant, giant spinning ball, just like when you spin a basketball on your finger! When it spins, it spins around a special, invisible line that goes right through its middle, from top to bottom. The very tippy-top spot where that invisible line comes out of the Earth is called True North! It's like the real, actual top of the world, and it never ever moves, always staying in the same exact spot in space. Your compass has a little needle that points north, but sometimes that needle is just a tiny bit silly and points to a big magnet inside the Earth instead of the *actual* top spinning spot. So True North is the *real* north, the one that's always in the same place, right at the very top of our spinning Earth.

title: Why exactly are female mammals generally physically weaker than their male counter parts?
text: Okay, imagine boys and girls are like two different kinds of superheroes! Boys have a special "super strength juice" inside them called testosterone. This juice helps their muscles grow really big and strong, like when you eat your veggies to get strong. Girls have some of this juice too, but not as much as boys. Girls have other special juices that help them grow in different ways, like making them ready to have babies when they're grown-ups. So, because boys usually have more of that "super strength juice" for their muscles, they often end up being a bit stronger for things like lifting heavy toys or running super fast. But both boys and girls are super important and good at lots of different things!

title: If testicles are so vital and important to reproduction, why are they so sensitive?
text: Imagine your testicles are like super special little factories that make tiny, tiny baby seeds! These seeds are super important for making new babies, so we want to keep the factories safe and working perfectly. Now, these factories need to stay a little bit cool to do their job, so they hang outside your body where it's not too warm, unlike your tummy. Because they are so important and also hanging out where they could accidentally get bumped, your body gave them a super-duper sensitive alarm system! When they get even a little bump, that alarm system yells "OUCH!" really loud to your brain. This big "OUCH!" makes you want to protect them right away, maybe by crossing your legs or moving, so they don't get hurt. It's like your body's way of saying, "Hey, these are super important! Be extra careful with them so they can keep making those baby seeds!"

title: Why are some cheeses made into wheels but others in blocks?
text: Imagine cheese is like a special kind of dough that needs to grow up! Some cheeses, the ones that need to get super yummy and strong over a very, very long time, like a year or more, are shaped into big round wheels. This round shape helps them stay strong and not break apart while they're getting old, and it's easy for the cheese helpers to roll them over and take care of them. Other cheeses, the ones we want to eat a bit sooner, are made into big square blocks. That's because it's super easy to cut those blocks into nice, neat slices or smaller squares, like cutting a big sandwich, so they're ready for you to eat right away!

title: How come when we close both of our eyes, our eyes can still perceive darkness, but when we only have 1 eye open, we can no longer "see" the darkness out of our closed eye?
text: Imagine your eyes are like two little cameras that send pictures to your brain. When you close both eyes, both cameras are off, so your brain just sees a big black picture – that's the darkness. But when you open just one eye, that camera turns on and sends a bright, colorful picture of the world to your brain! Your brain is super smart and it wants to see the most exciting picture. So, even though the other camera (your closed eye) is still off and sending a dark picture, your brain gets so busy looking at the bright, fun picture from the open eye that it doesn't really pay attention

title: What happens when a person forgets a simple task, by walking from one room to the next?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper helper that keeps track of all your plans, like "I want to get my teddy bear!" When you're in one room, your helper brain is focused on that room and your plan. But then, you walk through a door into a *new* room! It's like your helper brain suddenly sees a whole new set of toys and interesting things to look at in this new place. "Wow, look at all these new things!" your helper brain thinks. Because it's so busy looking at the new room, sometimes the old plan, like "get the teddy bear," gets a tiny bit lost for a moment, like it went hiding behind a couch. It's not gone forever, just a little bit hidden because your brain got a little distracted by the new view! It happens to everyone, even grown-ups, because our brains are always looking for new things.

title: If identical twins were to be given a paternity test (if one were suspected of being a child’s father), given they have identical DNA, is there a medical test that could determine which twin is the father?
text: Imagine twins are like two cookies baked from the exact same recipe. They look exactly alike, right? Your DNA is like your own special secret recipe that tells your body how to grow. A test to find out who the daddy is checks the baby's recipe and compares it to the grown-up's recipe. But if the two daddies are identical twins, they have the *exact same* secret recipe! So, when the test looks at the baby's recipe and then at the twin daddies' recipes, it sees a perfect match for *both* of them. It's like trying to figure out which identical cookie was baked by which identical baker when they both use the same recipe – you just can't tell them apart from the cookie itself. So, no, a regular test can't tell which twin is the daddy because their recipes are identical.

title: How does Thyroid Malfunction make a person fat?
text: Imagine your body has a special little helper called the 'thyroid' (tie-roid). This helper is like the gas pedal for your body's engine. It tells your body how fast to use up the energy from the food you eat, so you can run, play, and grow. When your thyroid helper is working perfectly, it helps your body use just the right amount of energy, like a car driving at a good speed. But sometimes, this special thyroid helper gets a little bit sleepy or broken, and it tells your body's engine to go super, super slow. So, when you eat yummy food (which is like the car's fuel), your body doesn't use it up fast enough to make you zoom around. Instead, because it's going so slow, your body starts to save all that extra energy. And when your body saves extra energy, it turns it into squishy fat, which makes you get bigger and heavier.

title: What are the mechanics of throwing? Why do we point our non-throwing arm at the target then drop it as we move our other arm forward?
text: When you throw a ball, you want to make it go super far and super fast, right? Imagine your body is like a big rubber band ready to snap! First, you point your other hand (the one not holding the ball) right where you want the ball to go, like you're aiming a pretend laser. This helps your whole body know exactly where to look, and it helps you stretch out really long, getting ready to twist. It also helps you balance so you don't wobble! Then, as your arm with the ball starts to zoom forward, that pointing hand quickly drops down and goes behind you. This is like when you spin around in a circle – if you pull your arms in close, you spin super fast! Dropping your arm helps your body twist even faster and gives a huge push to the arm holding the ball, making it fly even further and stronger, like a super-powered slingshot! All that twisting and pulling helps all your body's power go right into the ball to make it soar!

title: why do you fall asleep better when its dark than when its light?
text: Imagine your body has a special little clock inside it, just like the clock on the wall! This clock helps your body know when it's time to play and when it's time to rest. When the sun goes down and it gets dark, your body's clock says, "Hooray! It's nighttime! Time to get sleepy." It then makes a special sleepy dust that helps you close your eyes and drift off to dreamland. But when it's bright and sunny, your body's clock says, "Whoa! It's daytime! Time to wake up and play!" The light tells your body to stay awake, so it doesn't make as much sleepy dust. That's why it's easier to fall asleep when it's dark and cozy, because your body knows it's the right time for sleeping!

title: . What happens when rubbing alcohol expires?
text: Okay, imagine your rubbing alcohol is like a special helper liquid that makes boo-boos feel better and cleans away tiny invisible germs! It has super powers that help it do that. But just like a superhero needs to rest, or a toy car that gets old and doesn't go as fast, the rubbing alcohol's special cleaning powers get a little bit tired over a very, very long time. It doesn't turn into something yucky or dangerous to touch, it just doesn't work as well anymore to fight those invisible germs or clean your skin. Some of the strong cleaning stuff slowly floats away into the air or changes into something not as strong, so it becomes more like plain water and isn't as good at its job!

title: Why do some people think that two certain individuals look alike, while others may think they do not?
text: Imagine your eyes are like little cameras and your brain is like a super smart detective! When you look at two people, some detectives (brains) might only focus on a few big things, like if both people have brown hair and a happy smile. If those big things match, their brain says, "Whoa, they look the same!" But other detectives (brains) might look super, super close at *everything*. They might notice one person's nose is a tiny bit wider, or their ears are a different shape, even if they both have brown hair. Because those detectives look for all the little tiny differences, their brain says, "Nope, they're actually different!" So, everyone's brain is just a little bit different in what it decides is important to notice!

title: Why is it as kids, we could eat candy/sweets all day long, but as an adult, I'm done after a single cookie?
text: It's like this: when you're a kid, your body is like a little car that's always zooming around, playing, running, and even building new parts (that's how you grow big!). Candy is super-duper fast fuel, and because your body is so busy building and zooming, it needs lots and lots of that fast fuel to keep going and growing strong. But when you're a grown-up, your body is already big like a grown-up car. It doesn't need to build new parts anymore, and maybe it doesn't zoom around quite as much as a kid car. So, a grown-up car still needs fuel, but just one cookie is often enough super-duper fast fuel to keep it going smoothly for a while, because it's not building or zooming as much as your busy kid car!

title: Why does pain seem to shoot through our body in waves sometimes, why is not a consistent feeling?
text: Imagine your body wants to tell your brain, "Ouch! Something's wrong here!" It sends a quick message, like a little zap! Sometimes, the thing that makes you say "ouch

title: What would happen if 2 supercomputers played chess at against each other? Would the game end in seconds?
text: Imagine two super-duper smart robots playing chess! They are super, super fast at thinking, way faster than any grown-up or even a regular computer. So, they would make their moves super quick, zip, zap, zoom! But here's the funny part: because they are *both* so incredibly smart and fast, they would *never* make a silly mistake. They would always pick the very best move possible, like they both know all the secrets to chess! So, instead of finishing super fast like you might think, they would actually play for a really, really long time. Each would keep making perfect moves, and neither would get a chance to beat the other easily. It would probably end up being a "draw," which means neither one wins, because they were both just too good to ever mess up! It wouldn't be seconds, it would be many, many perfect moves until they couldn't find a way to beat each other.

title: why are the displayed prices in some countries not including taxes ?
text: Imagine you see a toy car you really, really want! The sticker on the toy car says it costs 5 shiny coins. But when you go to the grown-up at the counter

title: Why do all the biggest chunks of cereal come to the top when you shake it after opening a new box?
text: Imagine you have a box of your toys, some big blocks and some tiny little beads. When you shake the box, the tiny beads are really good at sneaking and wiggling their way down into all the little empty spaces at the bottom. But the big blocks are too chunky to fit into those tiny spaces, so as the little pieces go down, the big blocks get pushed up and stay on top! Your cereal box does the exact same thing! The tiny crumbs are like the beads, and the big yummy flakes are like the blocks. When you shake the box, all the little crumbs fall through the tiny gaps, pushing the big pieces up to say hello at the top.

title: Why do we call handmade cooking "From scratch"?
text: Imagine you're going to draw a picture. If you start with a completely empty paper, with no lines or colors on it at all, that's like starting 'from scratch.' It means you're starting right from the very beginning, with nothing already done for you. When grown-ups cook 'from scratch,' it's kind of the same! Instead of using a box mix that already has a lot of things mixed together inside, they get all the super basic things, like flour and eggs and sugar, all by themselves. They start with those simple ingredients and put everything together step-by-step to make something yummy, just like you start with a blank paper and draw every line yourself to make your drawing. It means they did all the work from the very, very first step!

title: How do fighter jet pilots eat whilst on long journeys?
text: Imagine you're in a super-fast, tiny car way up in the sky, like a rocket! You can't stop to get snacks, and there's no kitchen in your little car. So, pilots have special food that's super easy to eat. Think of it like yummy squeezable pouches of applesauce or yogurt, or little candy bars that are easy to open with one hand. They can also drink water from a straw that goes right into their helmet, like you might drink juice from a box. Everything has to be super neat and easy because they are busy flying their amazing jet and can't make a big mess!

title: When the entire world is driving electric cars, is the risk of batteries exploding greater due to larger capacity?
text: Imagine your toy car's battery – it's tiny, right? Electric cars have a super-duper big battery, like a giant box of LEGOs that holds a lot of power to make the car zoom far. Grown-ups who make these cars are super smart, and they put lots and lots of special shields and safety rules inside every single battery, even the big ones, so they almost never get too hot or grumpy and try to pop. It's like having a special coat and helmet for each LEGO brick! So, even if lots and lots of people have these cars, and even if their batteries are big, the people who make them always make sure they're super, super safe, just like your seatbelt keeps you safe in any car. They want everyone to be happy and safe, so they keep making the batteries better and safer all the time, no matter how many cars there are or how much power they hold.

title: why do your gums and teeth feel weird when you don't get enough sleep?
text: When you don't get enough sleep, your whole body gets a little bit tired and grumpy, just like you do! Your body has special helpers, like tiny little superheroes, that usually keep your mouth clean and fight off tiny invisible sugar bugs that live there. But when you're sleepy, these helpers are sleepy too and can't work as well. Also, your mouth might not make as much "super spit" (that's saliva!) to wash away those bugs and keep everything feeling smooth and happy. So, because the helpers are sleepy and there's less super spit, your gums might feel a little bit grumpy or swollen, and your mouth might feel dry, which makes your teeth feel all weird and sensitive. It's your body telling you it really needs a good, long sleep to be strong and feel normal again!

title: Why do so few plants make up so much of our food?
text: Imagine you have a big toy box, and some toys are super easy to play with and super fun, and you have lots of them! Other toys are a bit tricky or you only have one. It's kind of like that with plants! Some plants, like corn, wheat (which makes bread!), rice, and potatoes, are like the super easy, super fun toys because they grow really, really big and give us so much food from just one little seed. They also have lots of yummy energy inside that helps us run and play, and they can wait a long time before we eat them without getting yucky. So, farmers, who are like the grown-ups who help us get our food, choose to grow lots and lots of these special, easy, and very yummy plants because they feed so many people and animals! Other plants might be too hard to grow, or don't give much food, or go bad super fast, so we don't eat as much of those.

title: Why can’t two phone numbers calling each other be connected instead of being prompted with a busy line? Is this something that could be fixed easily?
text: Okay, imagine your phone is like a little toy car, and when you call someone, your car drives on a special road to their house. When someone calls *you*, their toy car drives on the special road to *your* house. Now, imagine you and your friend both get your toy cars out at the *exact same time* and try to drive them to each other's houses on the *very same little road*. What would happen? The cars would crash in the middle! Or, the road would get all stuck because both cars are trying to go to different places on the same path at the same time. The phone system is like a very smart grown-up who sees this happening. It

title: How does the Twin's Paradox work?
text: Imagine you and your twin brother, Timmy, are playing together, and you both have a special clock that shows how old you are. Timmy gets into a super-duper fast rocket ship, like a race car that goes all the way to a faraway star! You stay here in your house, playing with your toys. Timmy zooms very, very, very fast to the star and then zooms very, very, very fast back home. When Timmy gets out of his rocket, you run to hug him! But wait, something funny happened: even though you both started at the same age, your special clock shows you've played for many, many more days and gotten a little bit bigger. But Timmy's special clock, because he was going so super fast, only counted a few days for him! So, he's still a little bit younger than you, even though you were born at the exact same time. It's like his time went slower because he was zooming so fast through space!

title: Which country's alcohol laws apply on an international flight?
text: Okay, imagine the airplane is like a big flying bus! It's a bit like having different rules depending on where you are. First, the bus has a "home country" where it got its special flying license, and those rules about grown-up drinks usually apply first. But mostly, the grown-ups who work on the bus (the flight attendants) are

title: is a p value of .53 significant or not?
text: Imagine you're playing a game, and you want to know if something special happened because of a trick, or if it just happened by accident. The "p-value" is like a little report card that tells you how likely it was to just happen by accident. If the number on the report card is super, super tiny (like smaller than 0.05, which is like 5 small pieces), it means "Wow! That probably didn't happen by accident, there must be a special trick!" We call that "significant." But if your p-value number is big, like 0.53 (which is 53 small pieces), it means "Hmm, that could have totally happened by accident, we can't be sure there was a special trick." So, a p-value of 0.53 is not significant, because it's much bigger than the tiny little number we look for to say something is special.

title: Why does opening the oven door while a cake is baking ruins the cake?
text: Imagine your cake is like a sleepy little cloud trying to puff up and get big and fluffy, just like when you blow up a balloon. It needs to stay super warm and cozy inside its oven bed to do this, like a warm hug all around it. If you open the oven door, it's like opening the window on a very cold day – a big gust of cold air rushes in! This cold air makes the sleepy cloud cake get a big shiver, and it gets scared and stops puffing up. Sometimes, it even gets so scared it falls down flat and doesn't get to be a big, strong cake anymore. So, we keep the door closed to let it finish its warm nap and get big and fluffy all by itself!

title: How does hydroplaning work?
text: Imagine your car's tires are like your shoes, and they want to hold onto the road very tightly, like when you run and your shoes grip the ground. When it rains, there's water on the road. If your car goes too fast through a big puddle, the water doesn't have enough time to get pushed away by your tires. Instead, the water gets *under* your tires, lifting them up a tiny bit, so your tires are actually floating on a thin layer of water instead of touching the road! It's kind of like when you slide on a wet floor in your socks – your feet aren't touching the floor properly, so you just glide. When your car's tires are floating on water, they can't steer or stop very well because they're not connected to the road anymore, and that's called hydroplaning.

title: I just put cream cheese in the microwave to soften it. Within seconds it was crackling and popping. What was happening?
text: Imagine your cream cheese is like a thick, creamy blanket, but inside that blanket, there are tiny, tiny drops of water hiding. When you put it in the microwave, the microwave is like a magic tickler that only tickles the water drops to make them super-duper hot, really, really fast! When water gets that hot, it wants to turn into invisible steam, which is like tiny little air bubbles. These steam bubbles try to push their way out of the thick, creamy blanket. It's hard for them to get through, so they push and push, and when they finally get big enough and pop out of the cream cheese, that's the little 'pop pop pop' sound you hear! It's just the water bubbles saying 'whee, I'm free!' as they escape.

title: What's the difference between bacteria, viruses, fungi and pathogens?
text:
Okay, imagine your body is a super cool playground!

**Pathogens** are like all the different kinds of 'bad guys' or 'troublemakers' that might try to sneak onto your playground and make you feel not so good. They are just a big word for *anything* that can make you sick.

Now, there are different types of these bad guys:

**Bacteria** are like tiny, tiny living creatures, almost like invisible mini-animals. Some are good friends and help you, but some are meanies that can make you sick, like when you have a sore throat.

**Viruses** are even tinier than bacteria! They're like super sneaky little robots that can't do anything by themselves. They have to jump inside one of your body's cells (like taking over a house on your playground!) to make more of themselves and then they can make you feel sick, like when you have a cold or the flu.

**Fungi** are like tiny, tiny plants, but not the green kind. Think of really, really small mushrooms or molds. Most of them are harmless, and some are even helpful, but a few can make you itchy or give you yucky spots, like when you get athlete's foot.

So, pathogens is the big group name for anything that can make you sick, and bacteria, viruses, and fungi are just different kinds of those tiny troublemakers!

title: Why do our brain get tired of eating certain foods after a few bites even though we enjoy what we're eating?
text: Imagine your tummy needs lots of different kinds of special building blocks to grow big and strong, like red blocks, blue blocks, and yellow blocks. When you eat one yummy food, like a red apple, your brain says, 'Yay, we got some red blocks!' But if you keep eating *only* red apples, your brain starts to think, 'Hmm, we have enough red blocks now, but we still need blue and yellow blocks!' So, even though the red apple is still super yummy, your brain makes it feel a little less exciting so you'll want to try something else, like a banana (yellow blocks!) or some broccoli (green blocks!). It's like your brain is a smart helper making sure you eat a rainbow of foods to get *all* the important building blocks your body needs, not just one kind!

title: If a woman's half-sister were to have children, what relation would ones grandchildren have with the others children, if any at all? Is there such a thing as half-nieces or nephew's, or am I completely off target?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special grown-up friend who is your half-sister. That means you both have one parent who is the same, like sharing one big toy car but not the

title: How does alcohol in hand sanitizer kill bacterial cells but not our own cells?
text: Okay, imagine tiny, tiny bad guys called germs that live on your hands and can make you sick. These germs are like little water balloons with very thin skin. When you put hand sanitizer on, the alcohol in it is like a special, super-strong water that makes those tiny water balloons pop! They just burst open and can't bother you anymore. But *you* are made of cells too, lots and lots of them! Your cells are much stronger, like bouncy balls or little houses with thick, tough walls. The alcohol is not strong enough to pop *your* strong cells. It just sits on your skin and maybe makes it feel a little dry, but it can't get inside your strong cells to make them pop like the germs' thin balloons. So it kills the tiny bad guys, but your strong cells are safe!

title: What is happening when you forget a word, but you know the meaning?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super big toy box, and inside it, you have all your toys and all their names. Each toy is like a meaning – you know exactly what it is, how it works, and what it does, like knowing what a bouncy ball is for. Now, each toy also has a special name, like "bouncy ball." Sometimes, you know exactly which toy you want to talk about – the round one that jumps high – but for a tiny moment, its name tag (the word "bouncy ball") just hides behind another toy! Your brain knows where the toy (the meaning) is and what it does, but the little path to find its name (the word) is a bit busy or playing hide-and-seek for a second. It's still there in your toy box, you just need a moment for the name to pop out and say hello!

title: Why do people say that you can break your neck if you crack it the wrong way? How does this happen?
text: People say that because your neck is like a tower of special building blocks that holds up your head, and inside those blocks is a super important "wire" that helps your whole body move and feel

title: Why do pilot cabin in planes have so many buttons and switches?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car, but super, super big, like a giant bus that can fly! That big flying bus has so many parts that need to work just right. There are big engines that push it, lights to see, doors to open, and even special parts on the wings that help it go up and down. Each little button and switch in the pilot's room is like a magic key that makes one of those parts do its special job. One button turns on the lights, another makes the engines go faster, another tells the wings what to do, and another helps them talk to people on the ground. The pilots need all those buttons to make sure the big flying bus is safe and happy, and flies exactly where it needs to go!

title: If the earth is revolving around the sun, and the sun orbits around the center of our galaxy and our galaxy is also moving, How fast are we actually going, all motions combined?
text: Okay, imagine you're on a tiny little toy car, and that car is driving really fast around a big circle on the floor. That's like our Earth going around the Sun! But wait, that whole floor with your toy car is actually inside a much bigger, faster train that's zooming around a giant track. That's like our Sun and all its planets going around the middle of our galaxy! And guess what? That whole super-fast train, with the floor and your toy car, is actually inside a super-duper rocket ship that's flying through space even faster! So, when you add up all those rides – your tiny car, the big train, and the super-duper rocket ship – we are going unbelievably, incredibly, super-duper fast, way faster than any car or plane you've ever seen, all at the same time! But because everything around us is moving at the same speed, it feels like we're just sitting still.

title: How can a member of the Commonwealth be considered independent but still have a constitutional monarchy with Queen Elizabeth II as the head of state?
text:
Imagine you have your very own room, and you get to decide what toys you play with and what games you want to play. You're independent in your room! But sometimes, a very special, kind grown-up, like your grandma, is called the "head of the family" because everyone loves her and she's been around a long, long time. She doesn't come into your room and tell you what toys to play with or how to play your games; you still decide all that important stuff yourself. She's just a special symbol of the family, like a lovely picture on the wall.

That's kind of how it works for some countries with Queen Elizabeth! They are grown-up countries, and they make all their own rules, choose their own leaders, and decide everything important for themselves – that's being independent! But they also think Queen Elizabeth is a very special, kind lady, like a wonderful grandma. So, they say, "She can be our special Queen, like a lovely symbol or a friendly face on a coin, to remind us of our history and our friendship with other countries in the Commonwealth club." But she doesn't actually tell them what to do or how to run their country; their own leaders do that. She's just a very important, friendly symbol!

title: When we whistle, how do we immediately match the pitch that we hear?
text: Imagine your mouth is like a special tiny instrument! When you hear a sound, your ears are like little listening helpers that tell your brain, "Hey, that sound is high, like a little bird!" or "That sound is low, like a big bear!" Your super-smart brain then quickly tells your mouth to change its shape just a tiny bit. If you want to make a high sound, you make the little hole your air comes out of smaller, like a tiny straw. If you want to make a low sound, you make the hole a little bigger, like blowing over a big bottle. We just listen very carefully and quickly make our mouth bigger or smaller until our whistle sounds exactly like the sound we heard, like a quick game of "copy that sound!"

title: What is the difference between a router and a modem?
text: Imagine your house needs water to drink and play with! The **modem** is like the special pipe that brings the water from the big, big pipes outside your house, all the way into your house. It's the first stop! Then, the **router** is like all the little pipes and faucets inside your house that take that water and share it with your kitchen sink, your bathtub, and even your toy water gun! It makes sure everyone inside gets a turn. So, the modem brings the internet water into your house, and the router shares it around to all your computers, tablets, and phones inside. You need both to have internet for all your toys!

title: How do we always know when someone is watching us?
text: That's a super cool question, but guess what? We actually don't *always* know when someone is watching us! Sometimes, it just feels like it, and it's like a lucky guess, like when you pick the right color crayon without even looking. Other times, maybe you heard a little shuffle, or saw a tiny bit of movement out of the corner of your eye, and your brain noticed it even before you did! It's not a magic power that tells us, but sometimes our brains are just really good at noticing small things, or we just happen to look at the same time someone else is looking at us. So it's more of a funny feeling or a happy coincidence!

title: How come Japanese law prohibits non-Japanese companies from acquiring Japanese businesses?
text: That's a super interesting question, but it's not quite right! Japan actually lets companies from other countries buy businesses in Japan. It's like when you have your special toys. Sometimes, your friends can play with them, but if it's a super important toy, maybe your grown-ups want to make sure it's played with nicely and kept safe. Japan wants to make sure its important businesses, especially ones that make things super special for the country or are part of its history, stay safe and sound. So, while companies from other places *can* buy them, there are sometimes grown-up rules and checks to make sure everyone is fair and happy, and that Japan's important things are looked after

title: Why do mentally challenged individuals and those with down syndrome have very similarly shaled heads/faces?
text: Imagine your body is like a super special toy, and you have a secret instruction book inside you (we call it DNA) that tells every single part of you how to grow, like your nose, your eyes, and your head! For people with Down syndrome, it's like their instruction book accidentally has an extra page, or a little bit of one page copied too many times. Because of this extra part in their instructions, when their face and head are growing, they often grow in a way that gives them some similar looks, like a flatter nose or eyes that go up a little bit. Sometimes, when someone's brain is growing a bit differently (which is what "mentally challenged" means, that their brain works in a special way), it can also be because there are other little differences in their instruction book too, not just an extra page like

title: With all of the pyramid schemes, or simply scams disguised as a job (receive and resend packages, etc.), how exactly can you determine the real career opportunities to the schemes?
text: Okay, imagine you want to help mommy or daddy clean your room. A real job is like when they give you a sticker or a cookie for helping! They don't ask *you* for a sticker or a cookie first, right? If someone says 'I have a job for you!' but then asks *you* to give *them* money first, or asks you to buy a whole bunch of toys just to start, that's like a pretend job, a trick! Real grown-ups get money because they do work, like building houses or teaching kids

title: How much harder was it to live into old age into your 90s before modern medical advances?
text: Imagine your body is like a toy, and sometimes it gets a little boo-boo or feels yucky inside. Today, when that happens, we have super doctors and magic potions (medicines!) that help fix you up super fast, like putting a band-aid on a scraped knee or giving you a special drink for a cough. But a long, long, long time ago, before we had all these amazing helpers, even a tiny boo-boo could become a really big problem, and if you got very sick, there weren't many ways to make you better. So, making it all the way to 90 years old was like trying to find a unicorn! It almost never happened because it was so, so, so much harder to keep your body healthy and strong for that many years without all the wonderful doctor helpers and magic medicines we have now.

title: How does smoking make someone's voice deeper/raspier?
text: Imagine your voice is made by two tiny, stretchy rubber bands inside your throat, called vocal cords. When you talk, air blows past them, and they wiggle super fast, like when you pluck a guitar string, and that makes the sound of your voice! Now, when someone smokes, it's like blowing yucky, hot, sticky smoke right over those delicate rubber bands. The smoke makes them feel grumpy and puffy, like when your finger gets a little swollen after a bee sting. When your vocal cords are puffy and a little bit thicker, they don't wiggle as easily or as fast as before. It's like trying to make a high-pitched sound on a thick, floppy rubber band instead of a thin, tight one – the sound comes out lower and a bit rougher, like a growl instead of a squeak! That's why their voice can sound deeper and scratchy, like a rusty door hinge.

title: How come we get all snotty when we cry?
text: When you cry, your eyes make lots and lots of water, like a little faucet turned on! There's a tiny, secret tunnel, like a little slide, that goes from your eyes right down into your nose. When you cry just a little, your nose can drink up all that water. But when you cry a big, big waterfall, there's too much water for your nose to drink! So, all that extra water mixes with the little bit of sticky stuff (boogers!) already in your nose and makes it all runny and snotty, because it has nowhere else to go but out!

title: How is Ajit Pai's previous job at Verizon not considered a conflict of interest?
text: Imagine Ajit Pai used to work at a big company like a giant toy store called Verizon, where his job was to help that toy store sell lots of toys and make money. Then, he got a very important new job as a referee for *all* the toy stores, making sure everyone plays fair and follows the rules for how they sell things like internet and phone calls. Some grown-ups worry that because he used to work for Verizon, he might still be extra nice to them when he's being a referee, which is what we call a "conflict of interest"—like if your mom was the referee for your soccer game, she might be extra nice to you!

title: What is RAM and why is it important for computers?
text:
Imagine your computer is like you, and it has a super big toy box where it keeps *all* its games and pictures – that's like its long-term memory. But when your computer wants to play with a game or show you a picture, it takes it out of the big toy box and puts it on a special, super-fast play mat right in front of it. That play mat is **RAM**! It's like a temporary table where your computer puts all the toys it's playing with *right now*.

**Why is it important?** Well, if your computer only had a tiny play mat (not much RAM), it could only play with one or two toys at a time, and it would be slow if it kept having to put toys back in the big box and get new ones out. But with a bigger play mat (more RAM), your computer can have lots of games and apps open at the same time, ready to go! It can quickly switch from your drawing app to a video, then to a game, all without waiting or getting grumpy. So, RAM helps your computer play lots of games and do many things super fast, just like having a big, clear space to do all your important playing!

title: If an internet provider like Comcast charges extra to view a website, such as URL_1 , could Reddit change their URL to something like i URL_1 (and moving URL_0 to simply redirect) to bypass Comcast's pay-filters?
text: Okay, imagine the internet is like a big road, and Comcast is like the grown-up who drives the bus to take you to different houses (websites). Sometimes, that grown-up says, "To go to *that specific house* (URL_1), you have to pay me extra money." Now, if the people who live in that house try to be sneaky and just change the number on their door from "House 1" to "House i1," the bus driver (Comcast) would still know it's the very same house! That's because they don't just look at the number on the door; they know *where* the house is on the street, or even *who lives inside*. So, changing the name of the house wouldn't trick the bus driver into letting you go there for free. It's like trying to trick your mom by calling your broccoli "super trees" – she still knows it's broccoli!

title: How do pop rocks pop??
text: Okay, imagine Pop Rocks are like tiny, super special candies! When they make them, they trap teeny-tiny bubbles of air, like the bubbles in your soda, but super, super small and hidden inside the candy. They get stuck in there really tight! Then, when you put the candy in your mouth, your warm spit starts to melt it a little bit. As the candy melts away, those little air bubbles break open all at once! And when they break, the air inside rushes out really fast, and *pop!* That's what makes the fun popping feeling and sound on your tongue, like a tiny party happening right in your mouth!

An **HDD** (that's short for Hard Disk Drive) is like a

title: why do younger people start off enjoying very sweet food, but as we age, very bitter, tangy foods become more preferable?
text: When you're a little person like you, your body is like a tiny car that needs lots and lots of super yummy fuel to grow super big and strong! Sweet foods, like candy and yummy fruit, are like super quick, easy fuel, and your body knows this is good for growing, so it tells your tongue, 'Yum yum!' But some foods taste a little yucky at first, like really sour lemons or a tiny bit bitter broccoli. That's because, a long, long time ago, some bitter or super sour things in nature could make people sick, so your tongue learned to say, 'Uh oh, maybe be careful with this!' It's like a little warning signal. As you get bigger and bigger, your body doesn't need *quite* as much super-fast fuel all the time, and your brain gets super smart! You learn that things like coffee (which is a bit bitter) or pickles (which are tangy) are actually yummy and safe, even if they don't taste sweet. You learn to like the different, grown-up tastes, and they become fun for your tongue to

title: How exactly does currency “move” between banks, individuals, companies, etc. when processed electronically and without the use of any actual physical currency (cash)?
text: Imagine money isn't like the coins in your piggy bank, but more like points in a super big game! When you have money in the bank, it's like your name has a certain number of points next to it in a very, very special notebook that the bank keeps. When you want to send money to your friend, say for a toy, you tell your bank. Your bank then takes some points away from your name in their notebook and tells your friend's bank to add those same points to your friend's name in their notebook. It's like they just erase your number a little and write a bigger number for your friend. No actual coins or paper money ever move, just the numbers in the big notebooks change to show who has how many points! All the banks talk to each other really fast to make sure everyone's points are correct.

title: Why does bleach turn colors white, but white things yellow?
text: Okay, imagine your clothes have tiny, tiny paint dots that make them red or blue or green. Bleach is like a little magic cleaner that eats up all those tiny paint dots! When all the colorful dots are gone, what's left is just plain white, because there's no color to see anymore. Now, for your white shirts, they're super-duper white because they have special invisible sparkles that make them extra, extra bright. But sometimes, when bleach tries to clean them, it can accidentally make those special sparkles a little bit tired, or even leave behind a tiny, tiny whisper of its own yellowish color, so your super-duper white shirt ends up looking a little bit yellowish instead of extra bright white.

title: If we observe distant galaxies as they existed x-years-ago (because of light's speed), how do we know that deep space "now" isn't just a wasteland of emptiness/black holes?

title: Why was the best plan of battle on D-day to send thousands of men to almost certain death?
text: Imagine there were some really mean bullies who took over a big part of the playground, and they wouldn't let anyone play safely. The good guys, who wanted to make everyone safe again, knew they had to go to the bullies' strong fort (that's like the beach) and make them leave. But the bullies knew the good guys were coming, so they put lots of traps and guards everywhere. If only a few good guys went, the bullies would easily stop them all. So, the grown-ups in charge made a super sad but important choice: they knew that if they sent *lots* and *lots* of good guys all at the same time, even though many would get hurt trying to get past the traps and guards, *enough* of them would still make it through to get inside the fort. It was the only way to be strong enough to beat the bullies and make the whole playground safe for everyone again, even though it was very, very brave and very sad for many of the good guys.

title: Why does wellbeing lower drug-abuse rates?
text: Imagine you have a super fun day! You played with all your favorite toys, ate yummy snacks, got big hugs, and laughed with your friends. When you have all these good things, your "happy bucket" is full, right? You feel safe, loved, and have lots of fun, so you don't need to look for anything else to make you feel good. Now, sometimes grown-ups might feel sad, lonely, or like something is missing from their happy bucket. They might feel like they don't have enough fun things or hugs. When their happy bucket is empty, they might try a special "grown-up candy" that makes them feel funny for a little bit, but then it makes them even sadder or sick later, and they want more and more even though it's not good for them. But if grown-ups have lots of good things, like kind friends, fun jobs, healthy food, and feel loved, their happy bucket is full! They don't need to look for that "grown-up candy" because they already have so much good stuff making them feel happy and safe. So, when people have lots of good things in their lives, they don't need to try things that might make them feel bad later.

title: Why do you sometimes wake up more tired with more sleep, and more energetic with less sleep?
text: Imagine your body is like a little car that goes on a special sleep journey every night, stopping at different garages to get fixed up. There are easy-fix garages and really deep-fix garages. When you sleep for a very long time but wake up in the middle of a super deep fix (like when your engine is almost completely taken apart!), your body feels grumpy and confused, even though it had lots of time. It's like someone pulling you out of a really comfy bed when you were deep in a dream! But sometimes, you sleep for a shorter time, but you wake up just as your car is finishing a quick fix and ready to drive. That feels much better because you woke up at the perfect moment, just when your body was naturally ready to go again, like waking up when the sun peeks in your window. So, it's not always about how long you sleep, but *when* you wake up in your body's special fixing-up circle!

title: Why aren’t we frantically planting seagrass everywhere since it stores more CO2 than an equivalent area of rainforest? Seems easier than haggling with locals to replant rainforest.
text: Imagine seagrass is like a super special plant that helps clean up the air, even better than big trees! That sounds amazing, right? But just like you can't grow a sunflower on your

title: Why do, on occasion, temperatures of -2 Celsius in some regions feel colder than temperatures of +3 Celsius in other reasons?
text: Sometimes, even if the number on the thermometer says it's a little bit warmer, it can still feel super duper cold! Imagine you have a nice warm invisible blanket all around your body. If the wind is blowing really hard, it's like a big giant fan trying to blow your warm blanket away, making you feel chilly even if the air isn't super cold. Brrr! And if the air is wet, like after it rains or near a big lake, it makes the cold feel like it's sneaking right into your skin and clothes much faster. It's like if you touch a wet towel versus a dry towel – the wet one feels colder, even if they've been in the same room. So, if it's a little bit warmer but super windy and wet, those two things together can make you feel way colder than a day that's a bit colder but very still and dry. It's all about how your body *feels* the cold, not just the number!

title: Why do some pimples take longer to pop fully?
text: Okay, imagine your skin is like a playground, and sometimes a tiny little bump, a pimple, shows up! Inside that pimple is like a little secret cave filled with yucky, gooey stuff – like oily goo, tiny bits of old skin, and super-duper tiny germs. Now, sometimes this yucky goo is right at the very top of the cave, like a little bit of mud right by the entrance. When it's like that, it's super easy for it to come out quickly, *poof*! But other times, the yucky goo is hiding much deeper inside the cave, or maybe it's super thick and sticky like peanut butter, and there's a lot of it! It takes much longer for your body to push all that deep, sticky goo all the way up to the surface and out of the cave. So, some pimples are like easy-to-reach mud puddles, and others are like secret, deep treasure chests of goo that need more time to open up!

title: speaking vs singing into a mic?
text: Okay, imagine your microphone is like a friendly ear that wants to hear what you're saying or singing! When you *speak* into it, like when you tell your teddy bear a story, your voice is usually soft and smooth. The mic just makes that nice, regular voice bigger so everyone can hear you clearly. But when you *sing* into it, like when you sing your favorite 'Wheels on the Bus' song, your voice does lots of fun things! It goes up high and down low, it gets a little louder sometimes, and it makes pretty melodies. The mic loves to catch all those special up-and-down, high-and-low, pretty sounds you make when you sing, and it makes them sound super cool and big for everyone to enjoy! So speaking is like walking nicely, and singing is like doing a happy dance with your voice!

title: What direct effects does testosterone have on the male mind and body?
text: Okay, imagine there's a special magic juice inside boys called testosterone! This juice does super cool things. It helps your muscles get big and strong so you can run fast and play all day. It helps your bones grow tall, and it's what makes your voice get deep, like your daddy's, when you're bigger. It also helps grow hair in places like your face (for a beard one day!). Inside your head, it's like a little spark that helps you feel strong and brave, and gives you lots of energy to play and explore. It's part of what makes boys, boys!

title: How can you drink water in countries with temperature less than 0°C ?
text: When it's super, super cold outside, like when the number is less than zero, water gets sleepy and turns into hard ice, just like the ice cubes in your freezer! But don't worry, people still get to drink water. Inside our houses, it's warm and cozy, so the water stays awake and runny in the taps. Sometimes, the pipes that bring water to houses are buried deep, deep underground, like a warm worm in the dirt, and it's not as cold down there, so the water doesn't freeze. And if you find some ice and you want to drink it, you can bring it inside where it's warm, or a grown-up can put it on a warm stove, and it will wake up and turn back into water for you to drink!

title: If your vehicle is titled and licensed in the same state, then why do license plates expire?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car has a special sticker that says it's okay to play with it outside. Even if you live in the same house, your grown-ups might want to check on your toy car every year to make sure it's still yours, that it's not broken, and maybe ask for a tiny bit of money to help buy new batteries for all the toys! That's kind of like why big cars have stickers on their license plates that expire. The grown-ups who run the state want to make sure your car is still safe to drive, that it still belongs to you, and they ask for a little bit of money each year to help fix roads and bridges for all the cars. So, when the sticker expires, it's just a reminder to do those things again so you can get a new, fresh sticker to show your car is still good to go!

title: Why do so many lottery winners end up broke?
text: Imagine you suddenly got a *giant* bucket, bigger than you, filled with *all the candy and toys in the world*! Wow! But if you eat all the candy at once, and break all the toys playing too hard, or give *all* of them away to your friends without keeping any for yourself, then soon, your giant bucket would be empty again, and you wouldn't have any candy or toys left for tomorrow. It's the same with grown-up money. When people win a *super duper* lot of money, they sometimes get so excited they buy *everything* they ever wanted really fast, or give too much away, or just don't know how to make that big pile of money last for a long, long time. So, even though they had so much at first, it can all disappear really fast, like a bubble popping!

title: is there a chemical reason we don’t make banana jam or jelly? Or is it just some weird flavour preference that the whole world seems to share?
text: Okay, imagine jam needs two special superhero helpers to get all wobbly and firm, like jello! One helper is called "Pectin Power" and it's like super sticky glue. The other helper is "Sour Zing," like a tiny bit of lemon juice. Bananas, even though they're super yummy, don't have much Pectin Power inside them, especially when they're nice and ripe. And they're not very sour, so they don't have much Sour Zing either! So, it's really hard for them to turn into that wobbly, firm jam we love. Plus, when you cook bananas for a long, long time, they can get a bit brown and lose their yummy banana taste, turning more into a mush than a clear, jiggly jam. That's why we usually eat them fresh or in bread instead!

title: Why do you not cry from onions while wearing contacts?
text: Okay, imagine an onion has a tiny invisible "ouchy" spray that floats into the air when you cut it. When that spray touches your eyes, your eyes say "Uh oh! Something ouchy is here!" and they make lots of water, like a tiny shower, to wash the ouchy away. That's why you cry! But when you wear special clear "shields" called contacts right on your eyes, those shields catch most of the invisible ouchy spray *before* it can touch your actual eye. It's like your contacts are tiny invisible goggles that protect your eyes, so your eyes don't feel the ouchy stuff as much and don't need to make a big shower, so you don't cry!
