text: Imagine your fridge is like a special house for your food, and its job is to keep everything inside super chilly so it doesn't go yucky! It doesn't actually *make* cold, which is a funny thought. Instead, it's like a tiny magic vacuum cleaner that sucks all the warmth out of the air inside. There's a special cold juice inside tiny pipes all around your fridge, and this juice gets really cold and slurps up all the heat from your milk and snacks. Then, that juice takes all the warmth it just ate and goes to the back of the fridge, where it lets go of all that heat (that's why the back can feel a little warm!). After it drops off the heat, it gets super cold again and rushes back inside to slurp up more warmth. It keeps doing this over and over again, like a busy little heat-gobbler, making sure your food stays nice and cool all the time!

title: Why does our vision sometimes go distorted when we stand up to fast? The blur effect...
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big house, and your brain is the boss in the top room, and your eyes are the windows up there. Blood is like the special juice that makes everything work, especially for the boss and the windows! When you're lying down or sitting, the juice is all over the house. But if you stand up super fast, the juice quickly rushes down to your feet for a second, like water going down a slide! So, for a tiny moment, the windows (your eyes) don't get enough juice, and they get a little fuzzy or dark, like when the lights flicker. But don't worry, your body is super smart and quickly sends the juice back up to your brain and eyes, and then everything goes back to normal and clear again!

title: If pictures are stored as a bunch of numbers, why can't you just create random new pictures by changing some of the numbers?
text: You're so smart to know that pictures are like big lists of numbers! Each number tells the computer exactly what color each tiny little dot in the picture should be. But if you just randomly change some of those numbers, it's like if you had a big coloring book and just closed your eyes and scribbled all over the pages. Would it make a beautiful new picture, or just a big, colorful mess? Usually, it makes a mess! To make a *new* picture that looks like something cool, you have to know *which* numbers to change and *how* to change them, like an artist knows exactly where to put each color. Just random changes usually make a silly, broken picture because the computer doesn't know what you're trying to draw!

title: Why does every muscle is our body need rest after a short period of exertion, yet our heart can pump rigorously for 80-100 years straight?
text: Imagine your arms and legs are like toy cars that use up their energy really fast when they go zoom! They get tired and need to stop and rest to fill up their "energy tank" again. But your heart is a super special muscle, like a very gentle, quiet pump that has its own magic, never-ending battery! Instead of big, tiring pushes like when you run, it does lots and lots of smaller, steady squeezes to send blood all over your body, even when you're sleeping. It's built in a super clever way to keep going and going without getting tired like your other muscles, because its job is just too important to ever take a break!

title: What is a Fractional Reserve?
text: Imagine you have a big piggy bank, and your friends give you their coins to keep safe. A fractional reserve is like if you only kept *some* of their coins in your piggy bank, and you let other friends borrow the *rest* of the coins to buy candy or a toy. You know that not *all* your friends will want their coins back at the exact same time, so it's okay to let some coins go out and play. But you always make sure to keep a few coins in your piggy bank, just in case one of your friends comes and says, "Can I have my coin back now?" Banks do this with grown-up money! When you put your money in the bank, they keep a little bit safe in their vault (that's the "fraction" part), but they lend most of it out to other people who want to buy a house or a car. They know everyone won't ask for all their money back at once, and this way, the money can go out and help other people too!

title: Why has natural selection not removed people with nut allergies, lactose intolerant and so on?
text: Okay, imagine nature is like a big game where the best players get to stay and have little baby players. If you're really good at finding food and not getting hurt, you get to have lots of babies who are also good at those things. Now, some people have tummies that get grumpy with certain foods like milk or nuts, or their bodies get super itchy. A long, long time ago, if eating a nut made you so sick you couldn't find food or run away from a tiger, then you might not have babies. But usually, even if your tummy gets a bit grumpy or you get itchy, it doesn't stop you from growing up big and strong, going to school, and having your own babies when you're a grown-up. Plus, sometimes, if a nut was actually super poisonous, having a body that said "NO!" really fast would be a good thing! And today, we have doctors and special medicines that help people with grumpy tummies or itchy bodies feel much better, so they can still grow up strong and healthy and have their own families. So, because these things usually don't stop people from growing up and having babies, they just stick around!

title: What are the benefits to holding votes in the middle of the night?
text: Imagine you want to sneak an extra cookie before bedtime, but you know your grown-ups might say no! If you try to get the cookie when everyone is busy or even sleeping, it's easier to do it without lots of people watching you, right? It's kind of like that for grown-ups who make rules. Sometimes, if they want to vote on something that some people might not be happy about, or if they just want to get it done super fast without lots of people talking about it right away, they might do it when most people are asleep, like in the middle of the night. That way, not as many people are watching on TV or talking about it, and it can be easier for them to finish their work quickly, especially if they are tired too and just want to go home!

title: In movies, ads, photos, etc. doctors are wearing a headband with a silver/chrome circle. What is that and what is it’s use?
text: You know how sometimes it's dark under your bed and you can't find your favorite toy? You need a flashlight, right? Well, doctors sometimes need to look inside tiny, dark places in your body, like your ear or your nose, to make sure everything is okay. That shiny circle on their head is like a super special, tiny flashlight that helps them shine a bright light exactly where they need it, so they can see super clearly and help you feel better!

title: Why does listening to music while doing chores or generally unenjoyable things make them bearable, or sometimes even entertaining?
text: Imagine your brain is like a little person inside your head. When you're doing something boring, like picking up all your toys, that little person might feel a bit grumpy or sleepy because it's not very exciting. But then, when you put on some happy music, it's like giving that little person a fun song to dance to! Suddenly, your brain is busy listening to the beat and the words, and it's having a good time. Because your brain is busy having fun with the music, it doesn't think as much about how boring picking up toys is. It's like the music is a super fun friend that helps your brain forget about the yucky part, and then the job doesn't feel so bad anymore, and sometimes it even feels like a party!

title: What makes a fluid either compressible or non-compressible?
text:
Okay, imagine you have a big box, and inside are tiny, tiny invisible LEGO bricks that make up everything.

When the LEGO bricks are super far apart, like they're playing hide-and-seek in a giant room with lots and lots of empty space between them, you can push on the box and squish it smaller! All those bricks just move closer together because there was so much empty room. That's like air, and that makes it **compressible** – you can squish it!

But if the box is already packed super full of LEGO bricks, and they're all holding hands and there's almost no empty space left between them, when you try to push on the box, it won't get much smaller. They're already as close as they can get! That's like water, and that makes it mostly **non-compressible** – you can't really squish it because there's no space for the tiny pieces to move into.

title: Is there a reason why birds kamikaze into my window?
text: Oh no, it's so sad when a bird bonks into your window! It's not because they want to, sweetie, it's because windows are like tricky invisible walls for them. Imagine you're running super fast and suddenly there's a clear wall you can't see – you might bump right into it! Birds fly really quickly, and they can't see the glass. Sometimes, your window is also like a big shiny mirror, and it shows the sky or the trees from outside. So, the bird thinks, "Yay, more sky to fly through!" or "Look, a lovely tree to land on!" and accidentally flies right into the reflection. Other times, they might see their own reflection and think it's another bird, so they try to fly to it to play or tell it to go away. It's just a big, confusing trick for them because they don't know the glass is there!

title: What is the role of Gaddafi's death in todays slavery in Libya?
text: Imagine Libya was like a big playground, and Gaddafi was like the head teacher who was always there, making sure everyone mostly followed the rules, even if some kids didn't always like him. When he was there, he made sure no really, really mean bullies could hurt other kids too much. But then, Gaddafi went away forever. When the head teacher was gone, suddenly there was no one strong enough to keep all the big kids in line. Everyone started fighting over who should be in charge of the playground, and it got very messy and noisy. Because it was so messy and there were no strong grown-ups watching, some really, really bad people snuck in. They found other people who were trying to cross the playground to go somewhere else, and these bad people tricked them or forced them to work for free, like a very unfair game where they couldn't go home or play. This very bad thing is called slavery, and it started to happen more because there was no strong head teacher (Gaddafi) to stop the bad people and keep the rules in place.

title: Why are 9mm bullets less dangerous than 7.62 or even 5.56 ones? Shouldn’t they deal more damage with bigger size?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big, heavy apple, and then you have a smaller, pointy carrot. If you just push the apple, it might make a big thud. But if you

title: How do the foam cutouts in a recording studio mute out sound?
text: Imagine sound is like a little bouncy ball! When you throw a bouncy ball at a hard wall, it bounces right back to you, right? That's what sound does in a room with hard walls – it bounces all over the place, making lots of echoes and making it hard to hear just one sound clearly. Now, imagine you have a big, soft pillow or a fluffy carpet. If you throw that bouncy ball at the pillow, what happens? It just sinks in and stops bouncing! That's exactly what the special foam cutouts in a recording studio do. They are super soft and squishy, so when the sound bouncy balls hit them, instead of bouncing back and making echoes, the foam just "eats" them up. It catches the sound and stops it from bouncing around, making the room much quieter and helping the microphones hear only the sound they want, without all the confusing echoes.

title: Can we scale lasers up indefinitely with the only issue being enough power and/or money? Can we in theory make a deathstar laser if we just had enough of our current resources?
text: Imagine your toy flashlight. You can make it brighter by putting in bigger batteries, right? And if you wanted a *super* bright flashlight, you'd need *lots* of big batteries and it would cost a lot of your piggy bank money. Lasers are kind of like super-duper flashlights! We can make them stronger and stronger by giving them more "juice" (that's power!) and using

title: How does the police force work in the UK?
text: Imagine grown-ups who are like superheroes, but instead of capes, they wear special uniforms! In the UK, these helpers are called the police. Their job is to keep everyone safe, just like your parents keep you safe. If someone is doing something naughty, like taking someone else's toy without asking, or if someone is lost, the police come to help. They drive special cars with flashing lights and sometimes have friendly dogs too! Each town and city has its own group of police helpers, but they all work together to make sure everyone follows the rules and stays happy and safe. If you ever need help, or see something that looks wrong, a grown-up can call them, and they'll be there to make things better.

title: Why don’t we freeze at night?
text: You know how the sun is like a giant warm hug during the day? Well, when the sun goes to sleep, the ground and the air remember that warm hug for a long, long time! It's like when you have a warm bath, the water doesn't get super cold right away, right? It stays warm for a bit. And guess what? Our bodies are super clever and have a special heater inside that keeps us nice and toasty! Plus, we wear cozy pajamas and snuggle under warm blankets, and our houses are like big, comfy cocoons that keep the cold out. So, even when the sun is sleeping, the world isn't *super* cold right away, and we have lots of ways to stay warm and cozy!

title: How do sodium-acetate heat pads work?
text: Imagine you have a special bag with a super sleepy juice inside. This juice really wants to be hard, like a candy, but it's pretending to be a liquid. Inside the bag, there's a tiny metal button, like a secret switch. When you bend that button, it's like waking up the sleepy juice! All at once, the juice remembers it wants to be hard, and it quickly snaps into a solid, like magic. When it does that, it gets super cozy and warm, just like when you rub your hands together really fast! To make it sleepy juice again for next time, you put the whole bag in a pot of hot water, like giving it a warm bath. The hot water melts it back into the sleepy juice, ready to be clicked warm again!

title: Why does 6’ seem so much taller to us than 5’9” when the 6’ man is less than 5% taller than the 5’9” man?
text: Imagine you have two towers of blocks. One tower is pretty tall, and the other tower is just a tiny bit taller. Even though they're not super, super different, your eyes can still see that one is a little bit higher up, right? For grownups, 6 feet is like a special, magic number that means "really, really tall!" When someone reaches that 6-foot mark, it feels like they've crossed into a special club of very tall people, even if they were just a tiny bit shorter before. So, our brains get excited about that "6" and make it feel like a much bigger jump than it really is, just like when you get one more cookie, it feels like a big deal!

title: what is the chemistry of photography?
text: Imagine your camera film or special paper has super tiny, sleepy little bits of silver on it, like invisible glitter! When you take a picture, the light from what you see zooms onto this film. The light gives those sleepy silver bits a little tickle, and some of them wake up and change, but you still can't see anything yet – it's like a secret! Then, you put the film into a special liquid, like a magic bath called 'developer.' This bath finds all the silver bits that woke up from the light's tickle and makes them turn dark, showing you the picture! The sleepy bits that light didn't tickle stay clear. Last, you put it in another special liquid called 'fixer.' This liquid is like a superhero protector! It washes away

title: Why is astronaut Scott Kelly’s body suffering severe health issues after 300+ days in space?
text: Imagine your body is like a house that's built to stand up perfectly on Earth because there's an invisible pull called gravity that keeps everything steady. But when Scott Kelly went to space for a

title: How does the heat of the sun reach earth even though space is a cold void? How does it reach us through space?
text: Imagine the sun is like a super-duper bright, giant flashlight in the sky! It doesn't send out warm air like a blow dryer. Instead, it sends out tiny, super-fast little light packets, kind of like invisible speedy messengers. These light messengers don't need air or anything else to zoom through space. They just zip, zip, zip, all the way from the sun to Earth! Space is mostly empty, so there's nothing for these little light messengers to warm up on their journey, which is why space stays super cold. But when these speedy light messengers finally reach our Earth, they bump into our planet and turn into warmth, making our world nice and toasty for us!

title: How does Google Maps show satellite maps of other planets and moons?
text: Okay, imagine Google Maps for Earth is like a super big book of pictures of your house, your park, and everywhere on our planet, taken by special cameras in the sky! But Google can't send its own cameras to other planets like Mars or our Moon, because they're super, super far away. So, what happens is that clever scientists send special robot cameras, like little space photographers, all the way to Mars or the Moon! These robot cameras fly around and take lots and lots of pictures of what those places look like. Then, they send those pictures back to Earth. Google is like a super helpful friend who collects all those amazing pictures that the space robots took. They put all the pictures together, like a giant puzzle, to make a map so you can zoom in and see what Mars or the Moon looks like, even though you can't fly there yourself! So, Google doesn't take the pictures of other planets, they just show us the cool pictures other space robots have already taken.

title: why is it that if you refresh/go back/etc. on some websites it will save information you entered but not on others?
text: Imagine you're drawing a picture! Sometimes, you draw on a magic whiteboard. It's fun, but if you wipe the board (that's like refreshing the website) or leave

title: What exactly happens when you pass out from pain?
text: Imagine your body is like a busy house, and your brain is the boss in charge. When you feel a super-duper big ouchy pain, it's like a really loud, surprising noise in the house! The boss (your brain) gets so overwhelmed and says, "Whoa, this is too much for me right now! I need a quick break to make the noise stop!" To take that break, your body quickly sends a little less "food" (which is special blood) up to your brain for just a tiny moment. Because your brain doesn't have enough food to keep everything working perfectly, you gently go "sleepy-bye" for a few seconds and might fall down. It's like your body's way of pressing a "reset" button, so you can rest from the big pain for a moment, and then when you wake up, your brain is ready to be the boss again!

title: What are different poisons made of to make them more or less poisonous? Mostly on a molecular level and happens to the body on a cellular level when poisoned?(i.e. Ricin)
text: Imagine your body is like a giant house made of millions and millions of tiny, tiny rooms called cells, and inside each room are even tinier little tools and workers doing important jobs to keep your

title: When you remove a tumor, does it leave a gap in the organ/tissue it was removed from?
text: Imagine your organ is like a soft, squishy pillow, and a tumor is like a little hard lump that grew inside the pillow where it shouldn't be. When the doctor takes the bad lump out, yes, for a little bit, there's an empty space, like a little hole where the lump used to be. But your body is super clever and works very hard to fix things! It's like if you had a small hole in your play-doh and you squished the play-doh around to make it smooth again, or like when you get a cut on your knee and it heals up, sometimes leaving a little line called a scar. Your body tries to fill that space with new tissue to make it strong and smooth again, so it doesn't stay an empty hole forever.

title: Why does adding money into an economy affect inflation? Why can't prices remain fixed and incomes rise?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special toy store, but there are only 10 super cool toys in it. If everyone suddenly gets a whole big bucket of shiny coins (that's like money

title: How does the moon appear bigger on some days and smaller on others if its orbit remains the same?
text: Imagine you have a balloon, and you hold it super close to your face – it looks really, really big, right? But if you walk across the room and hold the same balloon far away, it looks much smaller! The balloon didn't get bigger or smaller itself, it just changed how far away it was from your eyes. The moon does something like that! Even though it always goes around our Earth, its path isn't a perfect, perfectly round circle like a hoop. It's a little bit like a squishy oval or a slightly wobbly circle. So, sometimes the moon is on the part of its path that brings it a little bit closer to us, and when it's closer, it looks bigger and brighter in the sky. Other times, it's on the part of its path that takes it a little bit farther away, and when it's farther, it looks a bit smaller. It's still the same moon, just sometimes a little closer for a big hug, and sometimes a little farther away waving hello!

title: How are space stations cooled?
text: Imagine you're playing super hard and get really warm, but you can't open a window or turn on a fan. That's a bit like a space station! The sun makes it very hot, and all the people and computers inside make even more heat. On Earth, we use air to cool things down, like blowing on your hot soup. But in space, there's no air to blow! So, the space station has special big, flat, white 'cooling panels' that stick out, like big white ears. Inside these panels, there's a special liquid that gets warm from all the heat inside the station. When this warm liquid goes into those big white panels, the panels let the heat 'jump off' and float away into the super-duper cold space. It's like the panels are giving the heat a ride away from the station, keeping it nice and comfy for the astronauts, not too hot and not too cold!

title: What is the difference between a normal derivative and deriving on a particular point of a function?
text:
Imagine you're on a big, curvy slide at the playground!

*   **A "normal derivative"** is like a special instruction book that tells you *how steep the slide is everywhere*. It's a rule that says, "If you are *here*, the slide is *this* steep. If you are *there*, it's *that* steep." It's a general recipe for the whole slide, showing how its steepness changes from top to bottom.

*   **Deriving on a particular point** is like picking *one exact spot* on the slide, maybe right where your bottom is right now, and saying, "Okay, *right here*, how steep is it *just for me*?" You're using the instruction book (the normal derivative) to find out the steepness at that *one special place* you chose.

So, the "normal derivative" gives you the *way* to find the steepness anywhere, and "deriving on a particular point" is actually *doing it* for one specific spot you point to.

title: Why do we take fever suppressors, like Tylenol, when we have a fever, why don’t we just leave the fever and let the high temperatures kill the bacteria?
text: Imagine your body is like a superhero castle, and when bad germs try to get in, your body turns up the heat, like a special heater, to make the germs uncomfortable and help fight them off! That's what a fever is. It's your body trying to be strong. But sometimes, if the heater goes *way* too high, it makes *you* feel super yucky and tired, even though it's trying to help. It's like when your bathwater gets too hot, it's not fun anymore! So, a medicine like Tylenol is like a little fan that gently turns down the heater just a tiny bit. It helps you feel more comfortable and less yucky, so you can rest and your body can still fight the germs without getting too hot for *you*. Your body is still working hard to get rid of the bad guys, we just help it do it without making you feel so poorly.

title: Why do we die in old age? What makes the body/mind stop working when we're old? Why could we not live eternally with pacemakers implemented?
text: Imagine your body is like a super cool toy car, and you play with it every single day! When you're little, it's shiny and new, and it zooms everywhere. But after many, many years of playing, the wheels might get wobbly, the paint might chip, and some parts inside might get a bit rusty or tired. Your body's tiny building blocks, called cells, are like those car parts. When we're young, they're really good at fixing themselves and staying strong. But as we get super old, they get tired, and they don'

title: When we lose a game, why does our body feel a sense of failure even though it's not real? Why does our body accept failure at all? What's the point of such a negative emotion?
text: Imagine you really, really wanted to build a super tall tower with blocks, and then it all tumbled down! Even if it's just blocks, your tummy might feel a little squishy or your eyes might feel like crying, right? That's because your brain and body work together. When you play a game, you try hard and you really want to win, because winning feels like a big, happy high-five! So, when you don't win, your body feels a little sad or squishy inside, not because it's a 'real' danger like a monster, but because you put your

title: How does an AED work?
text: Imagine your heart is like a drum that goes *thump-thump-thump* to pump blood all around your body. Sometimes, if someone is very sick, their heart gets confused and starts wiggling super fast instead of beating nicely, like a drum that's just rattling instead of making a clear sound. An AED is a very smart, talking box with sticky pads. You put the sticky pads on the person's chest, and the box listens very carefully to their heart. If it hears the heart wiggling in that confused way, it knows it needs help! So, it tells you to stand back, and then it gives a quick, gentle *zap* – like a tiny static shock – to the heart. This little zap helps the heart remember how to beat *thump-thump-thump* properly again, like pressing a reset button to help it get back on track. It only zaps if the heart really needs it, so it's super helpful and safe!

title: Why do countries import oil when they at the same time export oil ?
text: Imagine you have a big box of yummy cookies (that's your country's oil!). You have lots and lots of chocolate chip cookies, and you can sell them to your friends. But maybe you really, really need some special oatmeal raisin cookies to make a very specific cake, and your friend next door has a whole box of them. So, you give your friend some of your chocolate chip cookies (that's exporting!) and then your friend gives you some of their oatmeal raisin cookies (that's importing!). You both have cookies, but you needed a different kind, or maybe it was just easier to get the oatmeal raisin ones from your friend right then instead of trying to make them yourself or get them from very far away. Countries do the same thing with oil! Some oil is good for making gasoline for cars, other oil is good for making plastic, and some places just have a lot of one kind and need a different kind, or it's just closer to get it from a neighbor.

title: What is that smell right after a good sneeze?
text: When you sneeze, it's like your nose takes a super-big, fast breath! Imagine your nose is like a little vacuum cleaner, and when you sneeze, it suddenly sucks in a huge whoosh of air really, really fast. That big whoosh doesn't make a brand new smell, but it really stirs up all the tiny smell bits that were already floating around in the air right inside your nose and around your face. So, for just a little moment after your sneeze, your nose gets a super-duper strong sniff of all those everyday smells that were already there, making them feel extra noticeable and sometimes a little different. It's like your nose just got a super-powered boost to smell everything around you for a quick second!

title: Why does autotune sound so bad in 2017?
text: Imagine your voice is like a little car driving on a road. Sometimes, your car might wobble a tiny bit off the perfect line when you sing. Autotune is like a magic helper hand that gently nudges your car back onto the perfect line so it drives super straight and smooth. When grown-ups use just a tiny bit of the helper hand, you don't even notice it, and the singing sounds really pretty and perfect! But sometimes, especially around 2017, grown-ups would make the magic helper hand push *really* hard and *really* fast, like it's yanking the car all over the place. Then, instead of sounding like a smooth car, your voice starts to sound like a robot talking or a wobbly toy, which can sound a bit funny or even "bad" to our ears because it doesn't sound like a real person singing anymore. They did it because it was a new, cool sound they wanted to try!

title: Why do college basketball players who are injured and out for a game or two, sit on the bench in street clothes?
text: Imagine your friend got a little boo-boo on their leg and can't run around and play tag right now. Even though they can't play, they still want to be with all their friends and watch them have fun, right? They wouldn't put on their running shoes if they can't run! It's the same for basketball players. If they have a little injury and can't jump and run on the court, they can't wear their special uniform because uniforms are only for playing. But they still love their team and want to cheer for their friends and learn by watching, so they wear their regular, comfy clothes and sit close to the game!

title: Is there any advantage to put the power buttons on the side of laptops or embedding them into the keyboards?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car! If the button to make it go is on the side, you have to really mean to push it, right? It's safe from you accidentally bumping it when you're just holding the car. That's why some computers put their "on/off" button on the side – it makes it harder for grown-ups to accidentally turn off their important work or your fun cartoon if they just bump the keyboard or move the computer around. If the button is *inside* the keyboard with all the letter buttons, it might look super neat and tidy, but sometimes grown-ups might accidentally push it when they're typing really fast, like "oops!" and turn the computer off by mistake! So, putting it on the side is mostly so you don't accidentally turn off the computer when you don't want to.

title: In nature, why is it the generally the responsibility of the male to prove its fitness to the female? Is the offspring not just as susceptible to poor genes being passed from the female?
text: Okay, imagine a mommy bird and a daddy bird. Mommy bird has to lay a big egg, sit on it to keep it warm, and then when the baby bird hatches, she has

title: why does heat sometimes soften and sometimes harden metals? For instance, smithing metals makes them easier to bend, but factories heat metal in a furnace to harden it into shape.
text: Imagine metal is made of tiny, tiny LEGO bricks all stuck together. When a blacksmith puts metal in a super-duper hot fire, it's like making the LEGO bricks all jiggly and loose. They can slide past each other really easily, so the blacksmith can smash and push them to make a new shape, like magic play-doh! But in a factory, sometimes they heat the metal up just enough, and then cool it down super,

title: How does the U.S. government read the FCC comments?
text: Imagine the government is like a grown-up trying to make new rules for things like your TV shows or your phone. They want to know what everyone thinks about these rules! So, they have a special suggestion box, called FCC comments, where grown-ups can write little notes saying if they like or don't like a rule. Lots and lots of people send in their notes – it's like a giant pile of drawings and letters! The people in the government don't read every single note like a bedtime story, because there are just too many. Instead, some grown-ups look at a bunch of them to see if many people are saying the same thing, like "we like this!" or "we don't like that!" And sometimes, they even have super smart computers that help count how many people said what, like counting how many kids want chocolate milk versus juice. They do all this to try and make the best rules for everyone, just like your mommy or daddy listens to you to make good rules for your house.

title: How do screens produce the color black if it’s, physically speaking, just the absence of light?
text: Okay, imagine your screen is like a big wall covered in millions of super tiny little flashlights! Each little flashlight can make red, green, or blue light, and by mixing them up, they make all the colors you see. When the screen wants to show you something black, it's actually super easy! It just tells all those tiny flashlights in that spot to turn completely off. So, if there's no light coming from those little flashlights, that part of the screen looks dark, or black, just like when you turn off all the lights in your room at bedtime!

title: Why and how does a Anti-Static wrist band protect and prevent our electronics from being damaged?
text: Imagine you have a super invisible tickle monster on your hand, and sometimes when you touch things, it gives a tiny, surprising 'zap!' That's called static electricity. Inside your computer are super, super tiny roads and houses for electricity to play, like a tiny ant farm. If your tickle monster zaps those tiny roads, it's like a big, big splash of water on a tiny ant house – it can break them because it's too much! The anti-static wristband is like a special slide for your invisible tickle monster. You wear it on your arm, and it has a long string that clips to something safe, like the computer's metal box. So, if you have any tickles, they don't jump into the computer to break the tiny roads. Instead, they quickly slide down the string and away from your body, keeping all the tiny computer parts safe and happy!

title: Can hardware work without drivers?
text: Imagine you have a super cool new toy, like a robot! The robot is like the "hardware." Now, for the robot to actually *do* anything – walk, talk, light up – it needs special instructions. These instructions tell *you* how to make it work, or sometimes they're like a secret language only the robot understands. In computers, these special instructions are called "drivers." If your computer doesn't have the right instruction sheet (the driver) for your new robot (the hardware), it won't know how to play with it, how to make it move, or even how to say "hello." So, most of the time, no, your computer needs those special instructions (drivers) to understand and talk to all its cool toys (hardware) and make them work properly. Without them, it's just a fancy piece of plastic that doesn't do much!

title: How do you determine the rate heat will expand an object?
text: Imagine your favorite toy car. When it gets warm, like when you leave it in the sunshine, it gets a tiny, tiny bit bigger, like it's taking a big stretch

title: Why do we pay for internet at home by speed, but for mobile internet by usage?
text: Okay, imagine your home internet is like a special super-duper water pipe that goes right into your house. You pay for how *wide* that pipe is. A wider pipe means more water (which is like your games and videos) can rush through *at the same time*, making everything go super fast! The company built this big, strong pipe just for your house, so they charge you for how big and fast it is, not for every drop of water you use. Now, your phone internet is different.

title: Why couldn't taxes be the same for every level of income? Why do there have to be brackets?
text: Imagine everyone has a piggy bank, and the grown-ups need some money from everyone's piggy banks to buy important things for *everyone*, like roads to ride your bike on, schools to learn in, and doctors to help when you're sick. If everyone had to give the *exact same amount* of money, like 5 shiny coins, it would be super hard for a kid who only has 6 coins in their piggy bank! They'd be left with almost nothing. But for a kid who has 100 coins, giving 5 coins is easy-peasy! So, to make it fair, grown-ups decided it's better if kids who have *a lot* of coins share a little bit more, and kids who have *only a few* coins share just a tiny bit. That way, everyone can still have enough left for their own treats. The "brackets" are like different steps on a staircase for your money. If you earn a little bit of money, that first bit is on the first step, and you share just a tiny bit of it. If you earn *more* money, the *new* money you earn goes to the next step, where you share a little bit more of *that new money*. It's not like *

title: Why are text and disclaimers in ads/commercials allowed to be so small?
text: Imagine when your grown-up tells you, "You can have a cookie, *but* only after you finish your peas!" The "finish your peas" part is like a rule they have to tell you. Well, grown-up companies making commercials also have rules they *have* to tell you, like if a super cool toy needs batteries you buy separately, or if a yummy snack is only a special offer for a little bit. They want to show you the fun, exciting part so you'll want to buy it, so they make the "rule" part super, super tiny and quick. They still told you, like your grown-up still said "peas," but they just put it in a whisper-small voice so it doesn't get in the way of the big, exciting picture they want you to see! The grown-ups who make the rules say it's okay as long as the information *is* there, even if it's just a tiny little secret message for grown-ups who look very, very closely.

title: What starts the pumping of the human heart and how does it keep going?
text: Imagine your heart is a super special muscle that needs to squeeze, squeeze, squeeze to push your blood all around your body, like a little pump! But how does it know when to start and keep going? Well, inside your heart, there's a tiny, super important spot that's like a little drummer. This drummer makes a tiny little *zap* all by itself, like a tiny spark! When that spark happens, it sends a message to all the other parts of your heart, telling them, "Okay everyone, it's time to squeeze!" So, your heart squeezes. Then, just a little bit later, that tiny drummer makes *another* tiny zap, and your heart squeezes again! It just keeps making those little zaps, over and over, all day and all night, even when you're sleeping. It's like your heart has its own special clock and power source right inside it, making sure it never forgets to pump!

title: Why do red clothes appear gray / black underneath red lights?
text: Imagine light is like tiny colorful sprinkles, like a rainbow! Your red shirt is super special because it loves red sprinkles and bounces them right back to your eyes, so you see red. It eats up all the other colors, like blue or green sprinkles. Now, when you shine a

title: What is happening when a video lags and loses quality but continues to play?
text: Imagine your video is like a super-fast flipbook of drawings, and your internet is like a mailman bringing all those drawings to your screen very, very quickly. When the video lags and looks fuzzy, it's like the mailman is going super slow because there's too much traffic on the road, or he has too many other packages to deliver! So, your screen doesn't get the drawings fast enough, which makes it pause or stutter (that's the lag!). And because the mailman is trying his best to keep up, sometimes he just quickly grabs fewer drawings or ones that are a little smudged, so your screen can still show *something*, even if it's not as clear or pretty as usual

title: What are protection rings?
text: Imagine your computer is like a big house with different rooms. Some rooms are super important, like the grown-up's office where they keep all the special, breakable things that make the whole house work. Other rooms are like your playroom, where you can play with your toys and maybe make a bit of a mess, and it's okay. Protection rings are like invisible fences or special rules for these rooms. The most important room (called Ring 0) is where the computer's 'brain' lives, the one that knows how to make *everything* work. Only super careful and important helpers are allowed

title: Why do movies have different release dates in different countries?
text: Imagine a super fun new cartoon movie is like a giant, yummy cake! When the cake is baked, it needs to travel to different birthday parties all over the world. It takes time to carefully send

title: why do tortillas cook flat on one side, and inflate rapidly on the other?
text: Imagine your yummy, flat tortilla has tiny, tiny drops of water hiding inside it. When you put one side on the super hot pan, that side gets cooked and makes a strong, flat skin, like the outside of a cracker, and the water inside starts to get really warm. Then, when you flip it over, the *other* side starts to cook too, and all the warm water inside the tortilla turns into invisible air puffs (we call it steam!). These air puffs want to get out, but the cooked parts of the tortilla are strong like two thin walls. So, the air puffs get trapped in the middle and push the two walls apart, making the tortilla puff up like a little balloon!

title: Why is there a sensation of travelling, like being on a car or riding a train, after consuming alcohol?
text: Imagine you have a tiny little helper inside your ear that's super good at telling your brain if you're standing still or doing a spin, kind of like a tiny level that always knows if you're straight. When you drink alcohol, it's like a mischievous little trickster that sneaks into that helper. It makes the special water inside that helper all wobbly and makes the helper send confused messages to your brain. So, even if you're lying super still in your bed, your brain gets these mixed-up messages from your ear helper that say, "Whoa! We're spinning! We're moving!" And that's why it feels like you're on a wobbly car ride or a spinning teacup, even when you're not moving at all!

title: If the common cold tends to be a different virus each time(hence why you can't necessarily prevent it), why do you have nearly the same symptoms each time?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a super cool house, and sometimes little invisible "germ monsters" try to sneak in! There are lots and lots of different kinds of these germ monsters – some are spiky, some are round, some are wiggly, but they all want to play in your nose and throat. That's why you can't stop every single one, because there are so many different kinds your body hasn't met yet! But here's the funny thing: even though the germ monsters look different, your body's super-defender heroes always fight them in the same way when they're in your nose or throat. So, whether it's a spiky monster or a round monster, your body's heroes say, "Time to make the nose runny to wash them out!" and "Time to make you cough to push them away!" So, you feel the same stuff – the runny nose, the cough, the sore throat – not because the monsters are the same, but because your body always uses its favorite tricks to kick *any* monster out of those same places!

title: Why do balloons heat up when stretched and cool down when relaxed again?
text: Imagine the balloon is full of super tiny, super bouncy little invisible balls, like a playground full of kids! When you stretch the balloon, you're squishing all those tiny bouncy balls into a much smaller space. When they're all squished together, they bump into each other a *lot* more, like when all your friends are trying to fit into one small fort. All that bumping and squishing makes them wiggle really fast, and when things wiggle super fast, they feel warm, like when you rub your hands together! But when you let go of the balloon and it gets big again, all those tiny bouncy balls get lots of room to spread out. They don't bump into each other as much anymore, so they stop wiggling so fast, and that makes the balloon feel cool again, like when you stop rubbing your hands and they cool down.

title: Why, when cooling foods in water, do we have to bring it to boil first, then lower to a simmer before putting the ingredients into the water?
text: Imagine the water in your pot has tiny, invisible little germs that we don't want in our yummy food! So, first, we make the water super, super hot and bubbly – that'

title: Why do small stripes show up distorted when displayed on a screen in a picture or video?
text: Okay, imagine your screen is like a big LEGO board, and every tiny little bump on the board is a little light that can turn on or off to make a picture. Now, imagine you have a picture of a zebra with super-duper thin stripes. When the screen tries to show those very thin stripes using its own little LEGO bumps, sometimes the stripes don't fit perfectly on the bumps. It's like trying to draw a perfectly straight, thin line using really big, bumpy crayons on a bumpy paper. The line ends up looking all wiggly, wavy, or even makes new, funny, bigger stripes that weren't there in the real picture! The screen is just trying its best to draw the tiny stripes with its own bigger "drawing tools" and sometimes it gets a little confused and makes new, squiggly patterns by accident.

title: How can cups stack within eachother without the cup getting smaller the higher you go?
text: Imagine your cups are like little hats for each other! Even though they all look like they're getting smaller when you stack them up, they're actually all the same exact size. It's because cups are a special shape: they're a little bit wider at the top and a little bit skinnier at the bottom. So, when you put one cup on top of another, the skinnier bottom of the top cup slides right into the wider top of the cup below it. It's like the top cup sits on the *edge* of the bottom cup, not all the way down to the very bottom. That way, they all stay their same big size, but they can snuggle together and make a tall, happy tower!

title: why do cyclones have names? And who names them? Why don’t earthquakes, tsunamis, etc. are not named?
text: Imagine you have lots of friends, and they all have names so you know exactly who you're talking about, right? Well, cyclones are like really, really big spinning storms that can last for

title: How does the salt-and-ice challenge work?
text: Imagine you have a super cold ice cube, like the ones in your drink. When you put a little bit of salt on that ice cube, it's like the salt tells the ice, "Hey, get even colder! Faster!" So, the ice gets way, way, *way* colder than it normally would, super quickly. If you put your hand on that super-duper cold ice with salt, it gets so cold, so fast, it can actually hurt your skin really badly, like getting a burn, even though it's cold! That's why it's a very dangerous thing to do and not a fun game at all.

title: Why do downloads, file transfers and renders always seem to linger on 99% longer than any other percentage?
text: Imagine you're building a super big LEGO castle! You put all the big blocks together really fast, and your castle grows super quickly. That's like when your computer gets almost all of the new toy (file) ready. But then, for the very last part, you have to find all the tiny special flags, little windows, and make sure every single piece is perfectly in place and strong, so your castle doesn't fall down. Sometimes, the computer is also doing a super important check to make sure all the parts are there and everything is perfect and safe for you to play with. So, even though it looks like there's only a tiny bit left, it's often the careful, final tidy-up and check-up time to

title: Why is it that when a limb falls asleep, sometimes it’s kind of painful (like pins and needles) and sometimes it’s gentle (like a sort of dull buzzing)?
text: Okay, imagine your arm or leg has tiny little "wires" inside that send messages to your brain, like how your toy remote sends messages to your car. These wires need "food

title: Why does coffee make some people sleepy?
text: Okay, imagine your brain has little sleepy dust catchers, and when enough sleepy dust lands on them, your brain says, "Time to rest!" Coffee has a special trick: it sits on

title: Why is it that when you're cutting something in a sawing motion back and forth, it is easier to cut then just pushing down?
text: Imagine you have a super yummy cookie. If you try to eat the whole cookie in one giant bite, it's really hard, right? You might even choke! But if you take tiny little nibbles, one after another, it's much, much easier to eat the whole thing. A saw is kind of like that! It has lots and lots of tiny little teeth, like tiny little mouths. When you move the saw back and forth, each tiny tooth takes a super small nibble out of the wood, one after another, and all those tiny nibbles together make a big cut, which is easy peasy! But if you just push the saw straight down, all those teeth try to take one GIANT bite all at once, and that's just too much work for them, so it feels much harder, like trying to eat that whole cookie in one big go!

title: When you turn a bowl of soup, why do the contents not turn with the bowl?
text: Okay, imagine your soup is a little bit stubborn! When you turn the bowl really fast, the bowl moves, but the soup inside wants to keep doing what it was already doing – which was sitting still. It takes a tiny, tiny moment for the bowl to push the soup and make it start turning too. That's why it looks like the bowl moves first, and the soup just stays put for a second before it catches up and starts to swirl!

title: How does a spray dryer work to produce a powder from a liquid?
text: Okay, imagine you have a yummy juice, but you want to turn it into a dry powder you can keep in a jar! First, we take your juice and make it spray out of a tiny, tiny nozzle, like a super-duper water gun that makes really, really tiny little juice raindrops, almost like a misty cloud. Then, these tiny juice raindrops fly into a very big, warm room. This room has a big, gentle hairdryer blowing warm air everywhere! Just like a hairdryer dries your wet hair very fast, this warm air quickly sucks all the water right out of those tiny juice raindrops. Poof! All the water goes away into the air, and what's left behind is just the dry, powdery part of the juice. Because it's dry and light, it floats down to the bottom of the room, and we can scoop it up as a nice powder! So, it's like tiny juice sprays, warm air eats the water, and then you get powder!

title: How do they get Cafeïne out of regular coffee making it decaf coffee ?
text: Imagine coffee beans are like tiny little sleeping seeds that have a special 'wake-up' juice inside them, called caffeine. Some grown-ups love the taste of coffee but don't want that wake-up juice, so they take it out! They give the coffee beans a special bath, sometimes just with water, or with other special liquids that are really good at grabbing onto only the wake-up juice. It's like when you wash your hands and the dirt goes away with the water, but your hands stay! The special liquid takes the caffeine away, leaving the yummy coffee taste mostly behind in the beans. Then, when they make coffee from these beans, it still tastes like coffee, but it doesn't have the wake-up juice anymore – that's decaf!

title: How is time only an illusion according to Einstein? "For us believing physicists, the distinction between past, present and future is only a stubbornly persistent illusion."
text: Imagine you have a really, really long drawing on a piece of paper. One end of the drawing is "yesterday," the middle is "today," and the other end is "tomorrow." When *you* look at it, you feel like you're only seeing "today" right now, and then you move your eyes to see "tomorrow." But the whole drawing, the *whole picture*, is already there all at once, right? Nobody is making the "yesterday" part disappear when you look at "today." Einstein thought time was a bit like that drawing. All the "days" are already there, all laid out, like all the parts of the drawing. It's just *us* who feel like we're moving through it one moment at a time, like we're walking along the drawing. But the drawing itself isn't changing; it's just *our* walk through it that makes it feel like things are moving from past to future. The past isn't gone, and the future isn't not-there yet. It's all just... there, like the whole picture. Our feeling of "now" moving is just a trick our brain plays, like a persistent illusion, making us think only "now" is real.

title: How do they program computers to play at different elo strengths in chess?
text:
Imagine the computer is like a friend who loves to play chess, but you can tell your friend how much to try! When grown-ups make the computer play chess, they give it rules, like "how to move the knight" or "how to win." But they can also tell its special computer brain how much to *think*.

If you want the computer to play *easy*, they tell its brain, "Hey, only look one or two moves ahead, don't worry too much about what might happen way, way later! And sometimes, it's okay to pick a move that's just 'good enough' instead of the very best move." It's like telling its brain to be a little bit sleepy or not try super hard.

But if you want the computer to play *hard*, they tell its brain, "Okay, now really use your super-duper smart brain! Look many, many moves ahead, like counting to ten or even twenty! And always, always try to find the absolute best move, even if it takes a little longer to think really hard." So, the grown-ups just change how much the computer's 'brain' is allowed to think and how far ahead it looks to make it play like a beginner or a super chess champion!

title: why do professional basketball teams score more points in a game than college basketball teams, but college football teams score more than professional football?
text:
Okay, imagine basketball is like throwing a ball into a big hoop, and football is like trying to carry a ball to the end of a field!

In **basketball**, the grown-up

title: Why do deep-water fish need eyes and what do they use them for?
text: Imagine you're in your room at night, and it's super, super dark, but then someone leaves a tiny night light on. Even though it's mostly dark, you can still see a little bit, right? Deep-water fish live in a place that's mostly super, super dark, like your room at night, but not *always* totally dark. Sometimes, a tiny, tiny bit of light from way, way up high can still sneak down, or even cooler, some other fish or little creatures make their own sparkly lights, like tiny underwater fireflies! So, these fish have eyes, even though they're special eyes that are really good at seeing just those super tiny bits of light. They use their eyes to see if there's a yummy snack swimming by that's glowing, or to spot a big, hungry fish that might want to eat *them* before it gets too close, or even to find other fish friends that are glowing in the dark!

title: What changes does your body go through when training to hold your breath for a long time?
text:
Okay, imagine your body is like a little submarine that wants to stay underwater for a very, very long time! When you practice holding your breath, your body starts to get really clever.

First, your lungs, which are like two big balloons inside you, learn to hold more air, like making your balloon bigger so it can fit more party air! This means you have more "air juice" stored up. Then, your body learns to be super good at using that air juice. It's like you have a yummy snack, and instead of eating it all super fast, you learn to take tiny bites so it lasts a very, very long time. Your muscles, which are like little engines, learn to run on less air for a bit. Also, when you hold your breath, a little alarm in your body usually goes off saying "WHOA, time to breathe!" That alarm is triggered by something called "yucky air" (carbon dioxide) building up. But when you practice, your body gets used to that "yucky air" feeling, like getting used to a tickle that doesn't bother you anymore. So the alarm doesn't ring as fast. And guess what? Your heart, which is like a little pump, starts to slow down a bit, like a car driving slower to save its gas. This helps your body use its air juice even more slowly. So, your body becomes like a super-duper breath-holding champion, storing more air, using it carefully, and not getting scared by the "yucky air" as quickly!

title: How can news outlets and others report on accusations? Even to the point they ruin peoples lives and careers before being found guilty...
text: Imagine the news people are like grown-ups who tell everyone what's happening, kind of like when someone says your brother took the last cookie. They're allowed to tell this story because in our country, grown-ups believe it's important for everyone to know what people are saying, especially if it's about big things or important people. So, if someone says another grown-up did something wrong, the news can tell everyone about that accusation. But here's the tricky part: just because someone *says* another person did something bad, doesn't mean it's true! It's like how you might accuse your brother of eating the cookie, but maybe he didn't. When the news tells everyone about an accusation, sometimes it makes

title: How can medications change one's personality?
text: Imagine your brain is like the super important control center for your whole body, and it has lots of tiny little helpers that send messages to each other. These messages tell you to be happy, sad, sleepy, or full of energy, and how you feel and act because of these messages is what makes up your personality – what makes you *you*! Sometimes, these little helpers get a bit mixed up, or maybe there aren't enough happy helpers sending messages, or too many worried helpers. When you take medicine, it's like sending in a special team to help those little helpers in your brain. The medicine helps them send the right messages more clearly, or it brings in more happy helpers if you need them. So, when your brain's messages are working better and more balanced, you might start to feel and act a little different – maybe calmer, happier, or less worried – and that can make your personality seem a bit different too, like a brighter, smoother version of you!

title: Why does the perception of sound inside a shower differ so greatly between someone inside the shower and those not (IE singing)?
text: Okay, imagine your voice is like a bouncy ball! When you sing in a big room, your voice-ball flies away and disappears pretty fast. But a shower is like a small, special box with hard, shiny walls, like your bath tiles! When you sing in there, your voice-ball hits those hard walls and bounces back to your ears super-duper fast, over and over again! This makes your voice sound bigger and stronger and kinda makes it feel like you're a super singer to *you* because all those quick bounces make your voice sound fuller. But for someone outside the shower, they only hear the bits of your voice that manage to wiggle their way out after all that bouncing, and by then, it doesn't sound as special or clear to them as it does to *you* when you're surrounded by all those happy bouncing sounds!

title: What causes light bulbs to spontaneously explode?
text: Imagine your light bulb is like a tiny glass house with a super-thin, special wire inside. This wire gets super, super hot, like a tiny sun, to make light for you! Sometimes, this special wire gets really old and tired, like an old rubber band that finally snaps. When it breaks, it makes a little spark and a tiny *pop!* sound, and sometimes that makes the glass break a little too. Other times, maybe too much electricity (like too much juice going into a straw super fast!) suddenly rushes to the wire, making it super-duper hot all at once! This sudden heat can make the air inside push very hard on the glass, or if the glass already had a tiny, tiny boo-boo (a crack you can't even see), that boo-boo gets bigger really fast and the whole glass house goes *POP!* It's mostly because the super hot wire gets old and breaks, or because the glass gets too hot too fast, just like a balloon pops if it gets too much air or has a tiny hole.

title: What does dialing 1 before an area code really do?
text: Imagine your phone number is like your house address, and your area code is like the town your house is in! When you want to call a friend who lives in your *own* town (the same area code), you just tell the phone their house number. But if you want to call a friend who lives in a *different* town, far away (a different area code), you have to tell the phone, "Hey, this friend is in a different town!" The '1' is like saying, "This call is going to a different town!" It helps the phone know to send your voice on a longer trip to that other town so you can talk to your friend there.

title: Why dont the eyeballs of animals like snow leopards that thrive at -30 degrees freeze over? Do they just blink every millisecond?
text: Imagine your whole body is like a super warm, cozy blanket, even your face! Snow leopards have very warm bodies, so their eyeballs get some of that nice warmth too. Plus, their eyes have special, super slippery water (we call them tears!), but it's not like regular water. This special eye-water has tiny helpers in it that make it super hard for it to turn into ice, kind of like a special magic potion that says "No freezing allowed!" They do blink, just like you do, but not super fast every second. They blink to spread that warm, slippery eye-water all over their eyes to keep them clean and happy and safe from the cold, so they can see all the snowy mountains!

title: Why aren't there veins in the meat we eat?
text: Okay, imagine a yummy steak or chicken drumstick is like a toy car made of muscles, which helps the animal move! Inside the animal, it has lots of tiny roads called veins and arteries that carry blood, just like how roads carry cars to different places. But before the meat comes to our plate, grown-ups do a very important job: they gently drain out all the blood from the animal, like letting all the water out of a garden hose. So, when the blood is gone, the veins become empty, flat, and super thin, almost like invisible little threads! They're not bright red anymore because there's no blood inside. Plus, the part we eat is mostly the strong muscle, not the tiny, empty roads.

title: why are some electric toothbrushes cheap and others in triple figures ? Do they actually provide a oral hygienic difference?
text: Imagine toothbrushes are like toys! Some toys are super simple, like a plain car you just push. They still do their job, which is to roll! A cheap electric toothbrush is a bit like that – it wiggles really fast to clean your teeth, and that's already way better than just wiggling your own brush. But then some toys are super fancy,

title: what is it about meat going bad that means it can no longer be eaten after being cooked? Doesn't the heat just kill any bad bacteria?
text: When you cook meat, it's like giving all the tiny invisible "bad guys" (germs) a super hot bath, and they go *poof*! Most of them are gone. But even after they're gone, sometimes they leave behind their tiny "poop" or "yucky stuff" in the meat. This "yucky stuff" can still make your tummy feel ouchy, even if the bad guys aren't there anymore. And guess what? If you leave the cooked meat out for a long, long time, new invisible bad guys can come flying in and start making *new* messes and new "poop" on your yummy food. That's why even cooked meat can get yucky and make you sick if it sits out too long, because of the old messes left behind or new bad guys coming to visit!

title: How can businesses immediately tell you that your card has been declined? Are all card readers connected to the internet and what is the universal network they’re all connected to?
text: Imagine your card reader is like a super-fast walkie-talkie! When you swipe your card, that walkie-talkie immediately sends a tiny, quick message through invisible roads (which we call the internet!) to your bank's computer. Your bank's computer then looks inside your special "money box" (your account) to see if you have enough shiny coins for what you want to buy. If you don't have enough coins, or if something else is wrong, your bank's computer sends a super-fast "no, not right now!" message back to the walkie-talkie. That's why the grown-up at the store knows right away – it's like a quick game of "yes" or "no" between the walkie-talkie and your bank! Yes, almost all these walkie-talkies are connected to those invisible roads (the internet) to send their messages quickly. There isn't just one big universal road, but many roads that all connect together, like a giant map of roads all over the world that helps all the banks talk to each other.

title: Why Does DNA Form A Helix?
text: Imagine your DNA is like a super long ladder, but it's a bit wiggly! The sides of the ladder are made of sugar and phosphate, and the steps in the middle are made of special little pieces called 'letters' that always like to hold hands in pairs (A always holds hands with T, and C always holds hands with G). Now, here's the secret: when these 'letter' friends hold hands to make each step of the ladder, they don't sit perfectly flat and straight. They're a little bit tilted or angled, like they're leaning into each other a tiny bit. Because every single step on this super long ladder has that tiny little lean, when you put millions and millions of them together, the whole ladder naturally starts to spin and twist around, just like a spiral slide at the park! It twists because that's the most comfortable and strong way for all those little leaning parts to fit together, making it super sturdy and happy.

title: why does the heart never need rest?
text: Your heart is like a super-duper special pump inside you! It's not like the muscles in your legs or arms that get tired when you run and play a lot and need a long nap. Your heart is made of very special, strong stuff that *loves* to work all the time. It actually takes tiny, tiny little naps, super-fast, in between each time it squeezes to push your blood around. So, it's always working, but it gets just enough little winks of rest in between each beat to keep going and going and going, like a tireless little engine that makes sure all of you gets the yummy blood it needs to play and grow big and strong!

title: How do goats have such good balance/fearlessness for jumping on precarious ledges?
text: Goats are like super-athletes of the mountains! Their feet are super special, like they have sticky shoes with two toes that can spread out to grab onto tiny bumps, almost like little hands. This helps them balance really well, even on tiny edges. Their legs are super strong, like springs, so they can jump far and land softly. And their eyes are on the sides of their heads, so they can see almost all around them to find the best spots. They've also been doing this for a very, very long time, generation after generation, so they're naturally good at it and not scared because they know their bodies can do it. They climb up high to find yummy green snacks that other animals can't reach, and sometimes to stay safe from big, hungry animals on the ground. It's like a fun game for them, and they're just really, really good at it!

title: Why does it feel so much colder outside in humid climates versus dry climates?
text: Okay, imagine when you get out of the bath or the swimming pool, you feel extra, extra cold, right? That's because the water on your skin makes the cold air feel even colder and takes your warmth away super fast! Well, when the air outside is "humid," it means there are lots and lots of super tiny, invisible water droplets floating all around in the air, kind of like a super light mist you can't even see. These tiny water bits are like little helpers for the cold air, making it much better at grabbing the warm cuddles from your body and taking them away really quickly. So, even if the thermometer says it's the same cold temperature, all those tiny water bits in humid air help the cold air steal your warmth much faster, making you feel extra, extra chilly and shiver more! Dry air doesn't have those water helpers, so it's not as good at stealing your warmth, and you don't feel quite as cold.

title: Symmetry makes a face pretty, what makes a voice pretty?
text: You know how a pretty face is like when both sides match up super nicely, like a butterfly's wings? Well, a pretty voice is a bit like a super nice song your mouth makes! It's not too loud (like a shout!) and not too quiet (like a secret whisper you can't hear). It's not too high (like a squeaky toy!) and not too low (like a monster's growl!). It's smooth, not bumpy or scratchy, so every word is easy to understand. And it sounds kind and friendly, like someone telling you a happy story. So, a pretty voice is one that feels comfy and warm in your ears, like a gentle hug for your brain!

title: How does the genotyping process that 23andMe use work?
text: Imagine your body has a super special instruction book inside it, called DNA. This book tells your body everything, like what color your eyes are or if you'll have freckles! When you want 23andMe to tell you cool things about your book, you spit a little bit into a tube. That spit has tiny, tiny pieces of your special book in it. They take your spit to a science lab, which is like a big kitchen for scientists. In the lab, they have a super clever machine, kind of like a magic magnifying glass that only looks for very specific words or sentences in your instruction book. It doesn't read the whole book, just the parts that are interesting for things like your family history or if you like sweet things. The machine shines a light on your DNA pieces and sees which special words are there. Then, they send you a message on the computer to tell you what special words they found in your book and what those words mean about you!

title: How was the Playstation 3 able to perform so well with only 256MB of RAM?
text: Imagine your brain has a little table where you put the toys you're playing with *right now*. The PlayStation 3 was super clever because it didn't just have one small table; it had *two* small tables! One table (256MB) was for the game's rules and how it worked, and the *other* table (another 256MB) was *just* for making the pictures look super pretty on your TV. So, it had dedicated places for different jobs. Plus, the people who made the games were like super-smart chefs who knew exactly how to cook a delicious meal using only the ingredients (memory) the PS3 had, without wasting anything. And unlike your computer that might be doing lots of things at once, the PS3 was like a super-focused kid: it only had one job, playing the game, so all its brainpower and table space went into making that game awesome!

title: Why do certain sounds ‘go through’ us?
text: Imagine sounds are like invisible pushes and pulls in the air, like tiny little waves. When you hear a sound, those waves tickle the inside of your ears, and your brain tells you what it is. But some sounds, especially big, rumbly ones like a giant drum or a big truck driving by, don't just tickle your ears. They're like really strong, slow pushes that are big enough to make your whole body wiggle a little bit! Think of it like this: if someone gently taps your arm, you only feel it on your arm. But if a grown-up gives you a big, friendly hug, you feel that all over your body, right? Those big, rumbly sounds are like the big hugs of sound waves – they're so strong and big that they make your chest, your tummy, and even your bones feel the wiggles, not just your ears. That's why it feels like they 'go through' you!

title: Why is it that so many of us humans have this fascination for violence (at least to some extent) even when we may deem it unethical?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super curious little explorer! Sometimes, it likes to peek at big, exciting, or even a little bit scary things, like a roaring dinosaur in a book, even though you know it's not real and can't stomp on you. Our brains are always trying to learn how the world works, and that includes understanding things that are a bit dangerous or powerful, but from a safe distance. So, when we watch pretend fights in movies or play games where characters are strong, it's like our brain is saying, 'Hmm, what would happen if...?' It's a safe way to understand big feelings, learn about good guys and bad guys, and see how people solve problems, all without anyone getting real boo-boos. It makes our hearts beat fast, which can be exciting, just like going on a big, fast slide! But even though it's fun to watch pretend, our grown-up brains know that being kind and gentle in real life is always the best way to be, because we don't want to make anyone sad or hurt.

title: why do distant objects appear greyish blue?
text: Imagine the sun shines all sorts of colors, like a rainbow! Now, between you and very far away things, there's lots and lots of air. This air has tiny, tiny bits in it, like invisible dust and water sprinkles. When the sun's light tries to travel through this air, the blue color of light is super bouncy and gets scattered and bounced around *way more* than all the other colors. This is why the sky looks blue! So, when you look at something super far away, like a big mountain, you're looking through a *huge* amount of that air that's bouncing blue light everywhere. All that bounced blue light from the air gets mixed up with the colors of the faraway thing, almost like the air is putting a thin, hazy blue blanket over it. That's why those distant things look a little bit blue or grey, because you're mostly seeing all the blue light that the air is bouncing into your eyes, right in front of the actual object!

title: Why are spray deodorants or any spray cold and not room temperature?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super squishy toy car inside a tiny box. It really, really wants to stretch out and be big! When you open the box, *whoosh*, it pops out and quickly gets big, right? Well, inside your spray can, there's a special liquid that's all squished up and really wants to be a gas, like the air you breathe. When you press the button, you make a tiny hole, and *poof*, that liquid rushes out super fast! As it rushes out, it quickly turns into a gas and gets much, much bigger. To do all that growing so fast, it needs energy, and it "borrows" that energy from the air around it and from your skin, which is warm. When something takes away warmth, it makes everything feel cold! That's why it feels chilly – it's just the liquid getting big and gas-like very, very quickly and taking the warmth with it.

title: How do erasable pens work?
text: Okay, imagine your regular pen makes a colorful mark that stays there forever, right? Erasable pens are super tricky! Their ink is like a secret magic trick. Inside the ink, there's the color you see, and there's also a special secret thing that doesn't like getting warm. When you write, the color shows up. But then, when you use the special eraser on the pen, it doesn't rub the ink away like a pencil. Instead, when you rub it, the eraser makes the paper a little bit warm. When that special ink gets warm, the secret thing inside tells the color to hide! Poof! The color just disappears because it got too warm. So, the ink is still there, but it turns invisible when it gets warm from the rubbing!

title: How does “I want my lawyer” work when being interrogated?
text: Imagine you're playing, and a grown-up asks you a lot of questions about something, like if you ate a cookie before dinner. If you feel confused or scared, you can say, "I want my special helper!" (That's like saying "I want my lawyer!"). When you say that magic phrase, the grown-ups have to stop asking you questions right away. They can't ask you any more about the cookie until your special helper comes. Your helper is like a very smart friend who knows all the rules and can help you understand what's happening, making sure everything is fair and safe for you. They will talk for you or help you know what to say, so you don't have to feel confused or scared anymore.

title: How does a sexual assault case proceed in court? With all of the "he-said," "she-said" how do they get to the bottom of the incident, both on the prosecution and defense side?
text: Imagine you and your friend are playing, and one of you says the other took their favorite toy, but the other friend says, "No, I didn't!" Grown-ups

title: Given the brutality of World War 2, how have relations between the major Allied and Axis powers continued to be so positive? Why are the alliances between the U.S. and Japan/Germany, in particular, so strong? What was different about WW2 from other wars that prevented ongoing tension/conflict?
text: Imagine you had a really, really big fight with some friends on the playground, like the biggest, loudest fight ever! After it was all over, everyone was super tired and sad, and some people got hurt. But then, the friends who started the trouble (like Germany and Japan) said they were really, truly sorry and promised they would never, ever be mean again. And the other friends (like America) saw that they really meant it, so they reached out a hand and helped them clean up the mess and build new, even better sandcastles together. They even found a *new* problem they all needed to work on together, like a big bully who wasn't part of their first fight, so it made sense to be friends and help each other. They realized that working together and being kind made everyone much happier and safer than fighting. So, instead of staying mad, they decided to be the best of friends, sharing toys, helping each other when they fell, and making sure everyone played nicely. They learned that after a big, sad fight, it's much better to forgive, help each other, and become friends to make sure everyone is safe and happy for a very long time.

title: What are the similarites and differences of the various rates dV/dr, dV/dh, dr/dV, dr/dh, dh/dV, dh/dr, dV/dt, dh/dt, dr/dt?
text:
Okay, imagine you have your favorite play-doh!

All these funny "d-V over d-r" words are like asking how much one thing changes if you just poke another thing

title: What is the point of having a spoiler on a car?
text: Imagine your toy car is zooming super-duper fast, like a rocket! When real cars go that fast, sometimes they want to lift up a tiny bit, like a paper airplane trying to fly. That's not good because we want the wheels to stay stuck to the road so the car can turn and stop safely.
