It takes many, many, many generations – like a super long time, longer than you can count – for an animal to learn to live with people and be happy, and bats just haven't gone on that journey with us like dogs and cats did a super long time ago.

title: Why aren’t all food jars manufactured to be as easy to open as a plastic salsa jar?
text: Imagine some foods, like yummy jam or crunchy pickles, want to sleep for a very, very long time without getting yucky. To keep them safe and fresh for months and months, we give them a super tight hug with their lid – like a special blanket that no air can sneak under! That's why those jars are sometimes a little hard to open, because that tight hug keeps the food sleeping soundly. But your salsa often gets eaten pretty quickly, right? So it doesn't need to sleep for quite as long, and its lid is like a lighter blanket, super easy to take off because you'll eat it all up before it even thinks about going to a long sleep!

title: Why do video games all have such similar bugs?
text: Imagine all your favorite video games are like big, cool houses that people build. A lot of the time, the people who make these games use the same special tools, like the same kind of LEGO

title: How do bands make money from streaming sites like Spotify, pandora or YouTube?
text: Imagine Spotify is like a giant playground full of all the songs in the world, and you can play any song you want! Some grown-ups pay a little bit of money every month to play without commercials, and some just listen with commercials playing. Spotify takes all that money, like a big piggy bank. Now, when you listen to a band's song, Spotify takes a super tiny, tiny coin from its big piggy bank and puts it in the band's piggy bank. It's like if you eat one grape, the farmer gets a super tiny bit of money for that one grape. So, for a band to get enough coins to buy a new toy or make a new song, lots and lots and lots of people need to listen to their music over and over again. A special grown-up helper (like a record company) usually gets the coins first and then gives some to the band, but it all starts with you listening!

title: Why do some plants require more shade than others?
text: Imagine the sun is like a really big, bright flashlight in the sky! It helps plants get energy to grow, just like food helps you grow big and strong. But just like how some kids love playing outside in the super bright sunshine all day, and other kids might get a little too hot or get a sunburn and need to play in the shade for a bit, plants are kind of the same! Some plants are super tough and have special leaves that are like built-in sunglasses, so they love lots and lots of sun. They drink up all that light and get super happy. But other plants have more delicate leaves, like a baby's skin, and too much sun makes them feel very hot and tired, and their leaves might even get crispy! So, those plants need a cozy, shady spot, like under a big tree or an umbrella, to keep them cool and safe so they can still grow without getting too much of that bright light. They still need a little bit of sun, but not a whole lot!

title: Why is it illegal to feed polar bears?
text: Okay, imagine a big, fluffy white bear that lives where it's super cold! These bears are wild animals, and it's their job to find their own food, like fish, all by themselves. If people start giving them yummy snacks, the bears might get confused and think that people are like a giant food truck! Then, they might come too close to people's houses looking for more snacks, and that can be really scary and dangerous for both the bear and the people. Also, if they get used to getting food from us, they might forget how to hunt for themselves, which is how they stay strong and healthy. So, we don't feed them because we want them to stay safe, strong, and wild, and we want people to stay safe too! It's like letting a bird find its own worms instead of always giving it bread – it's better for them in the long run.

title: Why does cheap alcohol give me a significantly worse hangover than good alcohol?
text:
Imagine you have two kinds of juice. One is super pure, just squished fruit. The other has lots of extra sugar and weird colors mixed in, right? When you drink the super pure juice, your tummy is happy. But if you drink too much of the juice with all the extra stuff, your tummy has to work super hard to clean it all out.

It's kind of like that with grown-up drinks. "Good" drinks are more like the super pure juice; they have less of the extra, yucky stuff that makes your body work super hard. "Cheap" drinks often have more of that extra, yucky stuff. So, when your body has to work extra, extra hard to clean out all those extra yucky bits from the cheap drink, it gets super tired and feels much more yucky the next day, which is what we call a hangover! It's not just the amount of grown-up drink you have, but also how much extra messy stuff is inside it that makes your body grumpy.

title: Why do airlines make you put your phone in airplane mode/turned off despite it being repeatedly proven to have no interference to the aircraft?
text: Okay, imagine your phone is like a tiny little walkie-talkie, always trying to talk to its friends (the phone towers) on the ground. Airplanes are like super-duper sensitive walkie-talkies that need to listen very carefully to special messages from other big walkie-talkies (control towers) to know where to go and stay safe. A long, long time ago, when phones were newer, grown-ups worried that if lots and lots of tiny phone walkie-talkies were all trying to talk at once, it *might* make it harder for the airplane's super-sensitive walkie-talkie to hear its important messages. Even though now we know it's probably okay and your phone won't really bother the airplane's big ears, the rules were made a long time ago to be super, super safe, just in case. And because flying is so important and we want to be extra careful everyone is safe, they just keep the old rule, like always wearing your seatbelt, even if you're just going a little bit down the road! It's better to be extra safe than even a tiny bit sorry.

title: Why do military paratroopers use round umbrella-like parachutes, and not the rectangular ones, like sport/recreational skydivers?
text: Okay, imagine you have two different kinds of magical blankets that help you float down from the sky! The soldiers use the big, round ones because they are like simple, strong umbrellas. Their job is to get lots and lots of soldiers down to the ground safely, all at once, even if they're carrying heavy backpacks. They don't need to steer them much, just land softly and reliably. But the people who jump for fun use the rectangular ones because those are like little wings! They let you steer and zoom around in the sky, like a little airplane, and land exactly where you want, which is super fun for playing games in the air. So, one is for getting a big job done safely and simply, and the other is for having lots of fun and doing cool tricks!

title: Why are the rules for elections for federal offices allowed to vary between different US states?
text: Imagine our whole country is like a very big school, and inside this big school, there are many different classrooms, which we call "states." When it's time to pick a "Head Teacher" for the whole school (that's like the President!) or some "Big Helpers" who work for everyone in the whole school (like Senators and Representatives!), the big rulebook for our country says: "Hey, each classroom (each state) can decide some of the little rules about *how* they pick their helpers and how they help pick the Head Teacher." So, one classroom might decide to pick their helper on a Tuesday morning, and another classroom might pick theirs on a Wednesday afternoon. One classroom might use a special box to put names in, and another might raise hands. They all still pick people for the big school

title: If influenza is always mutating, why does getting a flu shot help? Doesn't the shot only prevent attacks from a certain strain?
text: Okay, imagine the flu is like a sneaky monster that wants to make you feel yucky! This monster likes to play dress-up, so every year it changes its costume a little bit – maybe a different hat or a new pair of shoes. The flu shot is like showing your body a picture of what we *think* the monster will look like this year. Even if the monster changes its hat a tiny bit, your body has already seen a picture of it and knows what to look for! So, your body is super ready to fight it off. It might not be *exactly* the same monster, but it's usually close enough that your body can still say, "Hey! I know you!" and fight it much better, so you don't get as super-duper sick, or maybe not sick at all!

title: Why does alcohol damage a filter so much more than water and how?
text: Okay, imagine your filter is like a super-duper tiny net, made of very thin strings, meant to catch tiny things. Water is like lots and lots of very smooth, tiny marbles. When the marbles roll through the net, they just slip right past the strings, and the net stays perfectly fine. But alcohol is a bit different! It's also made of tiny parts, but some of its parts are like sticky little hands or tiny magnets. When these sticky hands or magnets go near the net, they can grab onto the tiny strings of the filter. If they grab too much, they can make the strings weak, or even pull them apart, making the holes bigger or breaking the net a little bit. Sometimes, alcohol can even make the filter's strings feel soft and squishy, like they're melting a tiny bit, which breaks them even more. So water just slides through, but alcohol tries to hold on and can make the net sad and broken.

title: Why does hot water make dish soap so intense and cold water make it all disappear?
text: Okay, imagine the sticky, yucky food on your plate is like super sleepy, gooey mud. When you use hot water, it's like giving that mud a warm hug!

title: How come units of area are squared?
text: Okay, imagine you have your favorite blanket, and you want to know how much floor space it covers. That's its "area"! When we measure how long something is, like your height, we just use a ruler and say "it's 5 'centimeters' long" (or 'feet' if you're big!). But when we want to know how much flat space something takes up, we don't just measure one way. Instead, we imagine covering the whole blanket with tiny, perfect little square crackers. If your blanket is 3 crackers long and 2 crackers wide, you'd have 3 rows of 2 crackers, which means 6 crackers in total! So, we say the blanket's area is "6 square crackers." We say "squared" because when we make a square, we have to measure how long it is (one way) AND how wide it is (the other way). It's like measuring in two directions at once to fill up all that flat space! So, instead of just "centimeters" (for length), we say "square centimeters" because we're counting how many little squares fit inside.

title: What does a "double mickey mouse" in the artery mean?
text: Imagine your body has lots of tiny tubes, like little hoses, that carry red juice (that's your blood!) all around to help you run and play. These special hoses are called arteries. Sometimes, doctors take a special picture of these tubes inside you, like a magical photo. On this picture, when they look at a certain big tube and its little helper tubes next to it, it can sometimes look just like Mickey Mouse's head with his two big ears! The head is the big tube, and the ears are the little helper tubes. So, when doctors say "double Mickey Mouse," it just means they see *two* of these Mickey Mouse shapes right next to each other on the picture. It's like finding two Mickey Mouse balloons floating together! It helps the doctor know something special about those tubes in your body, like maybe there are two tubes where they usually only see one, and that helps them understand how your amazing body is working.

title: Why is it easier for snow to stay some places than others?
text: Imagine snow is like a little ice cream cone! It loves to be super cold, just like your ice cream. If it gets warm, like when the sun shines on it, it gets sad and melts into water, boo hoo! So, snow likes to hide in places where the sun can't find it, like under a big tree or behind a tall wall, because those spots stay nice and chilly. It also doesn't like the wind, because the wind can be a bit of a bully and blow the snow away, just like it can blow your hat off! And sometimes, snow likes to stick to bumpy things, like grass or cracks in the sidewalk, because it's harder for it to slide off there compared to a super smooth slide. So, snow stays longer where it's cold, hidden from the sun, away from the windy bullies, and has lots of bumpy spots to hold onto!

title: What makes full-motion video "full"?
text: Imagine you're drawing a picture of a running dog. If you draw just a few pictures, like one dog here and then one dog over there, and you flip them, the dog looks like it's jumping, right? It's not smooth. But if you draw LOTS and LOTS of pictures, showing the dog moving just a tiny, tiny bit in each one, and then you flip those pictures super, super fast – whoosh! – it looks like the dog is really running smoothly, just like magic! So, "full" motion video just means there are so many of those tiny pictures, shown so fast, that everything looks super smooth and real, like you're watching it happen for real, not like a jumpy cartoon.

title: Why is email free to use? How do they make up the costs to running servers, staffing etc...
text: Imagine email is like sending super-fast letters to your friends, but you don't need to buy any stamps! The grown-ups who give you your email mostly make their money in other clever ways. Sometimes, it's like when you watch a cartoon on TV, and they show you a quick ad for a yummy snack or a cool toy in between. The email people do that too – they show you little pictures or words that are like ads in your email space, and the companies who want to sell those things pay the email people for it. Also, if you want a super-duper giant mailbox that holds way, way more letters than anyone else's, sometimes you have to pay a tiny bit extra for that special big space. But for a normal, regular mailbox, it's totally free! And sometimes, the email people have other cool games or computer programs, and they hope that if you use their free email, you'll also try their other stuff too, which helps them make money. It's like giving away a little bit of candy so you'll come to their big party!

title: What happens in the brain during different states of consciousness (sleep, coma, passed out, "unconscious" etc)?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper amazing house with lots of lights and people inside! When you're awake, all the lights are on, and everyone is busy running around, playing, talking, and learning new things. It's a very busy party! When you go to sleep, it's like bedtime for your brain house. Most of the lights turn off, and everyone goes to bed to rest. Some people might still be dreaming quietly in their rooms, but it's much calmer and quieter, getting ready for a new day. If you pass out, it's like a tiny, super quick power blink in your brain house – all the lights just flicker off for a second because maybe the house didn't get enough power (like yummy food and air!), and then they pop right back on! But if someone is in a coma, it's like the main power switch for the whole brain house got really stuck and broken. All the lights are off, and it's very, very quiet inside, almost like everyone is in a super, super deep sleep that's hard to wake up from, even though the house is still working to keep your body breathing and warm

title: How are beakers and graduated cylinders not affected by chemical reactions?
text: Imagine you have some play-doh, and you mix different colors together – that's like chemicals wanting to change and play! But the cups we use in science, the beakers and graduated cylinders, are made of a super strong, special kind of glass. This glass is like a very quiet, grown-up friend who doesn't want to play with the play-doh. It just wants to hold the play-doh and watch it change, but it doesn't want to change itself. So, even when the chemicals are busy changing each other, the glass stays tough and doesn't join the game, keeping everything safe inside.

title: How are fetal genetic abnormalities determined through the testing of the mother’s blood?
text: Okay, imagine your mommy has a special river of blood flowing inside her. When a baby is growing inside mommy's tummy, little, tiny, tiny pieces of the baby's own special building

title: What prevents pain from coming back after pain killers wear off?
text: Painkillers don't actually stop the pain from coming back forever, like magic! They're more like a special quiet button for your body's "ouchie" alarm. When you take them, the button gets pressed, and the alarm stops ringing for a little while, so you don't feel the ouchie. But the button doesn't fix *why* the alarm was ringing in the first place, like if you scraped your knee or have a headache. When the quiet button wears off (because the medicine goes away), the alarm might start ringing again if your body isn't all better yet. The only reason the pain *doesn't* come back is if, while the quiet button was pressed, your body had enough time to fix itself! So, your scraped knee might have healed a bit, or your headache just

title: In the chess games between Google's AlphaZero and Stockfish 8, why is each game different? Why isn't each game just the same every time
text: Imagine two super-smart robots playing a game of chess. They know all the rules, just like you know how to build with LEGOs! These robots are so good that they can see *all* the possible ways to move the pieces and what might happen next. Sometimes, there are many different moves that all look *just as good* to the robot. When that happens, the robot might pick one of those good moves, and the next time it plays, it might pick a *different* equally good move. It's like if you have five red LEGO bricks and you need to pick one – you might pick the first one you see, or the one next to it. Even though both are good, picking a different one changes what your tower looks like! So, because they have so many good choices and sometimes pick a slightly different one, the whole game changes and becomes new every time, even for super-smart robots!

title: How did early humans survive in cold weather before the invention of clothes?
text: Imagine it's a super chilly day and you don't have your warm coat! What would you do? Very, very long ago, people had to figure this out too. First, they tried not to be in the *coldest* places; they'd move to areas where the sun shone more or where it wasn't frosty all the time. When it *did* get cold, they'd find cozy spots to hide, just like you might hide under a blanket. They'd go into **caves**, which were like big, rocky houses that blocked the wind, or find big trees to shelter under. The most amazing thing they learned was how to make **fire**! Fire is like a warm, glowing friend, and they would sit super close to it to get toasty. And just like you might hug your friends or family when you're cold, they would **huddle together** in big groups. All their bodies made a lot of warmth when they were close, like a big group hug! They also ate yummy, fatty foods, which helped their bodies stay warm from the inside, kind of like how fuel keeps a car running. So, they used caves, fire, snuggled together, and moved to warmer spots to stay safe from the cold!

title: why do soccer fields look bigger when watching games in Europe then watching games in the US, even though (I think) they’re the same size?
text: You're super smart to notice that! You're right, most soccer fields are like big rectangles, and they're usually about the same size, no matter if the game is in Europe or America. But the way we *see* them on TV can make them look different! Imagine a magic camera that shows you the game. In Europe, sometimes the cameras are placed a little bit further away, or higher up in the big stadiums. When the camera is further away, it can show *more* of the field all at once, so it makes the field look super wide and long, like you're seeing the whole big picture! It makes the players look a little smaller, and the grass look like there's so much more of it, making the field *feel* bigger. In America, sometimes the cameras are a little closer to the field, or not quite as high up. When the camera is closer,

title: How is it possible that when talking on the phone, person A can suddenly lose signal and not hear person B, but Person B can hear person A perfectly well?
text: Imagine you and your friend are talking using two separate sets of invisible strings, like two tiny roads for your voices! One string road takes your voice *to* your friend, and a different string road brings your friend's voice *to* you. Sometimes, the road that brings your friend's voice *to you* gets a little wobbly or blocked, maybe because you walked into a spot where the invisible voice-cars can't drive easily *to you*. But the other road, the one carrying *your* voice to your friend, is still perfectly clear and strong! So, your voice can still zoom all the way to them, but their voice can't zoom back to you because that specific road is a bit stuck. It's like one road is closed, but the other road is still open for cars to go the other way.

title: What is the exact purpose of a hunger strike?
text: Imagine you really, really want someone important to listen to you, like when you want a new toy or you think something isn't fair, but they just aren't listening. A hunger strike is when a grown-up decides, "I am going to stop eating my food." Not because they don't like food, but because they are showing how super, super serious they are about something they want to change or something they believe in. It's like they are saying, "I care about this so much, I'm even willing to not eat, just so you will finally pay attention to me and make things better." They hope that by not eating, the important people will get worried and listen to what they have to say.

title: Why is there no measuring unit for darkness?
text: Imagine you have a big box of toys. We can count how many toys are in the box, right? One toy, two toys, three toys! That's like light – we can measure how much light there is with a special light-ruler. Now, what if the box is completely empty? There are no toys in it! You don't count "zero toys" as if it's a *kind* of toy, you just say "there are no toys." Darkness is like that empty box. It's not a *thing* itself, it's just when there's *no light* at all. So instead of measuring "darkness," we just measure how much light there *isn't*! If our light-ruler says there's no light, then it's totally dark!

title: How is an ultra-sound tech able to calculate the weight of an unborn baby?
text: Imagine you have a super special camera that can see inside your mommy's tummy, like magic! The nice person (the ultrasound tech) uses that camera to look at the baby on their screen. They use a special ruler on the screen to measure different parts of the baby, like how big its head is, how round its tummy is, and how long its leg bone is. Once they have those numbers, they put them into a special computer game, and the computer has a secret recipe that uses those measurements to make a really good guess about how much the baby weighs, almost like guessing how much water is in a balloon just by looking at how big it is!

title: If graphene is so great, why isn't it be used in anything?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper special superhero blanket! It's so thin you can barely see it, super strong so it won't rip, and it can even help electricity zoom really fast. That's kind of like graphene – it's amazing and has lots of superpowers! But, just like it's really hard to bake one tiny, perfect

title: Why do older people have such problems with technology?
text: Imagine when you got a brand new toy that moved or made sounds. It was super exciting, right? But maybe you had to learn how to make it work. Well, for your grandparents, when they were little kids like you, there were no phones or computers like we have now! Their toys were different. So, when these new gadgets came along, it was like someone gave them a brand new, super complicated toy every single day! When you're a grown-up, your brain is already full of lots of important things it knows, and it's a little harder to learn completely new stuff really, really fast. Plus, sometimes the buttons are tiny, or the words are small, and it's easy to get mixed up or accidentally press the wrong thing, which can be a bit frustrating or even a little scary, just like when your favorite toy doesn't work right. It's not because they're not smart; it's just that they grew up in a different time, and these new things are like learning a whole new secret language!

title: How do we actually find out how old something is? Lets say the dinosaur skeleton or just a human body that we find in a glacier?
text: Imagine the Earth is like a giant, yummy layer cake, with lots of different colored layers of dirt and rocks stacked up over a super long time. When we find a dinosaur, we look at which layer of the cake it's hiding in. Some of these rock layers have tiny,

title: How do gorillas/chimps etc get so strong when the vast majority of the mass in their diet is fruit and vegetables?
text: Okay, imagine gorillas and chimps are like super-duper construction workers, and plants are like their favorite LEGO bricks! Even though they eat mostly yummy fruits, leaves, and veggies, these plants have special tiny building blocks inside them that their bodies are really, really good at finding and using. Their tummies are like magic factories that take all those plant building blocks and stick them together perfectly to make huge, strong muscles. They also eat a whole lot of plants all day long, which gives them tons and tons of these special muscle-making LEGOs. Plus, they climb and play all the time, which helps their muscles grow even bigger and stronger, just like when you run and jump and play outside!

title: how come putting water on your face makes it dryer?
text: Imagine your face has a special, invisible, comfy blanket made of tiny, slippery oils that keeps it soft and happy. When you splash water on your face, it makes a little puddle. But then, the air around you, like an invisible thirsty monster, starts to drink up all that water, making it disappear! When the water goes away, it's a little bit like a tiny, mischievous friend, and it takes some of your comfy oil blanket with it. So, when some of that protective oil is gone, your face can feel a little bit bare and dry, just like if you took off a warm sweater on a cool day!

title: Best angle of shots to minimize the splash damage when peeing into a toilet?
text: Okay, imagine your pee is like water from a tiny hose! If you point your hose straight down into the water in the toilet, it goes SPLASH, like when you jump into a pool. And if you point it straight at the super hard, shiny side of the toilet, it bounces off and goes SPLASH too, like throwing a ball at a wall. The best secret is to point your stream at the *side* of the toilet bowl, just above the water, so it can gently slide down into the water like a little slide. Or, you can aim it *at* the water, but make it go in at a super sleepy, flat angle, not straight down! That way, it goes in super quietly, like a secret, and doesn't get pee-pee water on the floor!

title: How do cords get tangled?
text: Imagine your cords are like long, floppy spaghetti noodles! When you put them in a drawer, a bag, or even just leave them on the floor, they don't stay perfectly still. They wiggle and jiggle around a little bit, especially if you move the bag or drawer. As they wiggle, one part of the noodle might accidentally go over another part, or even under it, like when you cross your arms. If this happens a few times, and they get squished or moved again, those parts get stuck together in a knot, just like when your shoelaces get all tangled up when you run around! They don't try to get tangled, it just happens because they're long and wiggly and love to move around when you're not looking.

title: In a zero gravity environment, would a 10kg, solid metal sphere be more difficult to throw than, say, a baseball? And would it accelerate less given the same force behind the throw?
text: Imagine you're an astronaut floating in space! There's no 'down,' so things don't fall, but some things still have more 'stuff' packed inside them. That big metal ball has way, way more 'stuff' inside it than a tiny baseball. So yes, even though neither of them is 'falling,' it would be much, much harder to push that big metal ball and get it moving compared to the baseball. It's like trying to push a giant, sleepy elephant compared to pushing a little fluffy feather – even if they're both floating! And if you push the metal ball and the baseball with the *exact same push* from your hand, the little baseball would zoom away super fast, but the big metal ball would only move a tiny, tiny bit. That's because the big ball has so much 'stuff' that it doesn't want to move quickly, even with your push.

title: Why does yawning limit our hearing so much?
text: Imagine your ear has a secret little tunnel inside that connects it all the way to your throat, like a special tube! When you yawn really big, your mouth opens super wide and all the muscles in your face and throat stretch and move a lot. This big stretch makes that little tunnel open up for a moment! When that tunnel opens, the air pressure inside your ear changes really quickly, and it's harder for the sounds from outside to get through clearly, kind of like when you put your hands over your ears a tiny bit. It's just a quick change because everything is moving and stretching, and then it goes back to normal when your yawn is over!

title: Why do bladeless fans have a large open space in the middle?
text: Okay, imagine your fan wants to give you a big, cool hug of air! Regular fans have spinny arms (blades) that push the air. But your bladeless fan is a bit like a magic trick! Inside the bottom part, there's a secret little engine that sucks in air, like when you sip juice with a straw. It pushes that air *really fast* up into the ring, and then the air squirts out from a super tiny, invisible slit all around the inside of the ring. Now, here's the clever part: when that fast air shoots out, it's like a strong invisible hand that *grabs* all the other air from the big hole in the middle, and even the air from behind the fan, and pulls it along for the ride! So, the big hole is there so the fast air can pull lots and lots more air through it, making a much bigger, cooler breeze for you, even though you don't see any spinny blades!

title: How come having the sun visible in your peripheral vision doesn’t permanently damage your vision?
text: Imagine your eyes have a very special, super-duper sensitive spot right in the middle, like a tiny bullseye, that helps you see things super clearly, like your favorite toy! The sun is like a giant, super-duper bright lightbulb in the sky. If you look straight at that bright lightbulb, all its super strong light goes right onto that tiny, sensitive bullseye, and it can get too hot and hurt it, like touching a hot stove! Ouchie! But when the sun is just a little bit to the side, in your 'side-seeing' (that's peripheral vision!), it's like the light is shining *next* to your bullseye, not directly *on* it. Only a tiny bit of the sun's light, like just a few gentle sprinkles, goes into the other parts of your eye, which are much stronger and not as sensitive. They're like the tough skin on your arm instead of your super sensitive fingertips! So, because the super strong

title: Freshman here- why wouldn’t everybody apply to as many colleges as possible?
text: Okay, imagine you want to play with toys. You have a few favorite toys, right? And maybe some other toys you like a little bit. If you tried to play with *all* the toys in the whole wide world, it would be super hard! First, it takes a lot of time to even *look* at all the toys and decide if you like them. Then, each toy might need a special little 'ticket' to play with it, and those tickets cost money, like when Mommy buys you a special treat. You only have so many tickets! Also, you really want to pick the toys that make you happiest and help you learn the most fun things, not just *any* toy. So, people usually pick a few toys they really, really want to play with, and spend their time and tickets on those, instead of trying to play with *all* of them and getting super tired and not having enough tickets for the ones they truly love!

title: Why do we care about the national debt?
text: Imagine your mommy and daddy have a big piggy bank for all the family's things, like food, toys, and going to the park. Sometimes, they want to buy something really big, like a new car or build a super cool treehouse, but they don't have enough money in their piggy bank right now. So, they ask a friend or a bank to lend them some money. This is kind of like the government borrowing money, and that's the national debt! We care about it because if mommy and daddy borrow *too* much money, they have to spend a lot of their weekly allowance just paying back their friends, plus a little extra for saying 'thank you' for borrowing. If they spend too much on paying back old loans, there might not be enough money left for new toys, yummy snacks, or fixing your bike. And if they keep borrowing and borrowing and it gets super, super big, it might mean that when *you* grow up, you have to help pay for it, or maybe things at the store become more expensive. So

title: How does glass shatter when run under super hot water or in a dishwasher?
text: Okay, imagine your glass cup is like a sleepy monster. When you put it in super, super hot water, the outside of the monster suddenly wakes up and gets warm really fast,

title: Why is plant protein less bioavalible than animal protein?
text:
Imagine your body is like a builder making a super cool LEGO castle! To build it, you need lots of different kinds of LEGO bricks, right? These bricks are called "protein."

When you eat animal food, like chicken or eggs, it's like getting a big box of LEGOs that has *all* the special bricks you need, and they're super easy to pull out and use for your castle. Your body can grab almost all of them!

But when you eat plant food, like beans or nuts, it's like getting a box where maybe a few of the *special* LEGO bricks you really need are missing, or sometimes the bricks are stuck inside super strong little bags that are hard for your body to open. So, even if there are lots of bricks in the box, your body might not be able to get as many out to build your castle as easily as it could from the animal box. That's why animal protein is a bit easier for your body to use!

title: How does your body produce blood?
text: Okay, imagine your bones are like big, strong houses inside your body! Inside these houses, there's a super special, soft, squishy part called "bone marrow" – it's like a busy, busy factory! This factory has amazing little worker bees, super special ones, that know how to make all the different parts of your blood. Some worker bees make the red juice that's like tiny delivery trucks carrying air all over your body so you can run and play. Other worker bees make the white juice that's like little soldiers, fighting off any yucky germs that try to make you sick. And some make tiny little pieces that are like mini band-aids to help stop a cut from bleeding. Your body is always, always making new blood in this factory to keep you strong and healthy, all day and all night!

title: What's the deal with the clothing brand Supreme?
text: Imagine there's a special club that makes super cool clothes, like t-shirts and hats, called Supreme. They don't make a lot of each thing, so it's like when

title: How long does it take from the slaughtering a cow, to me being able to pick up the meat at my supermarket? Also, what exactly goes on during that time?
text: Okay, imagine the cow lives on a big farm. When it's time for the cow to become yummy meat for our dinner, it goes to a special place. First, the cow becomes big pieces of meat. Then, these big pieces need to take a long, cold nap in a giant fridge, kind of like how you need to sleep to grow big and strong! This long nap, called "aging," makes the meat super soft and tasty, and it takes about **a whole week or even a little more** for the meat to get just right. While it's napping, smart people make sure it's safe and ready. After its nap,

title: Why is Eggnog not sold year round?
text: Imagine your favorite special toy, like a Christmas tree ornament! You only get to play with it for a little while around Christmas, right? Eggnog is kind of like that. It's a special, yummy, creamy drink that tastes like a cozy hug, and it makes people think of happy holidays like Christmas and New Year's. Because it's so rich and sweet, most grown-ups only want to drink it when it's cold outside and they're feeling extra festive. If it was around all year, it wouldn't feel so special anymore, and people might get tired of it, just like you might get tired of eating cake every single day! So, the stores only bring it out when everyone is ready for a little holiday magic in a cup.

title: Why does massages relieve body ache when it adds pressure to the already sore muscle or joint?
text: Imagine your muscles are like little sponges, and sometimes when you play a lot or bump yourself, they get a bit squished or have some sticky, yucky feelings stuck inside that make them ache. When someone gives you a massage, it's like they're gently squeezing that sponge. This gentle squeeze helps push out the old, yucky feelings that are stuck and make it hurt. And then, when they let go, fresh, good stuff, like new juice for your muscles, can rush in to help clean everything up and make it feel much better. It also tells your body to relax and not feel so ouchy, like a warm hug for your tired muscle!

title: How can the FCC force a vote?
text: Imagine the FCC is like a group of grown-ups who make rules about things like your TV, radio, and the internet, just like your parents make rules for your house. They don't

title: How do creams that you put on your skin help muscles?
text: Okay, imagine your muscle feels a bit ouchy, like it's tired from running around! When you put special cream on your skin, it's like a gentle trick. The cream doesn't go all the way inside your muscle to fix it directly. Instead, it has tiny, clever bits that make your skin feel warm, or cool, or a little tingly. This new feeling on your skin is so interesting that your brain gets busy thinking about *that* feeling, and it kind of forgets about the ouchy in your muscle for a little while, making you feel better! Sometimes, that warm or cool feeling also helps tiny little rivers under your skin open up a bit, letting more helper trucks (which are like good blood) come to the area to bring nice things to your muscle. So, the cream gives your skin a nice, distracting hug, which helps your muscle feel happier while it's doing its own job of getting strong again!

title: Why do some people have sparkling eyes (in contrast to "blank" inexpressive eyes)?
text: Imagine your eyes are like two little shiny marbles! They have a super thin, clear layer of wet stuff on them, like a tiny puddle, which helps them see and keeps them healthy. When you're super happy, excited, or curious, your eyes get a little bit wider, and that wet layer catches the light just right, making them sparkle like tiny diamonds! It's like when the sun shines on a puddle and makes it glisten. But when someone is feeling quiet, tired, or just thinking very hard, their eyes might not be as wide open, or the light doesn't bounce off them in the same sparkly way, so they look a bit calmer or more sleepy. So, sparkling eyes are often just happy, wide-open eyes catching the light!

title: Why are humans the only species that communicate using words? Are there other animals that have the capability to create/form words?
text: You know how you can say "cookie" or "I love you" with your mouth? That's because your mouth, your tongue, and a special part in your throat are super

title: How did we come up with the asteroid theory for dinosaur extinction?
text: Imagine the dinosaurs were playing happily, and then *poof*, they were all gone! Grown-ups (scientists) were like, "Hmm, what happened?" They looked for clues, like a detective looking for puzzle pieces. First, they found a very, very thin layer of special dust, like a tiny stripe, all over the world, exactly where the dinosaur bones stopped showing up in the ground. This dust was super special because it had something called iridium in it, which is mostly found in space rocks, not much on Earth! So, they thought, "Maybe a big space rock hit us!" Then, they found a giant, super-duper big hole in the ground, hidden under the ocean and land in a place called Mexico, and it was *exactly* the same age as that special dust layer! So, they put all the clues together: a giant space rock (an asteroid) came crashing down from the sky with a huge *BAM*, made that big hole, threw all that space dust everywhere, and made the world change so much that the dinosaurs couldn't live anymore.

title: why do eyes roll back when people die? Or is that made up?
text: That's mostly something you see in movies, like when a cartoon character faints! When someone dies, their body stops working, and all the little muscles that help hold your eyes exactly where you want them to look also stop working. So, your eyes just kind of relax and might drift a little bit in any direction—maybe slightly up, or to the side, or just stay still. It's not like they're rolling around on purpose, just like when your toys stop moving when their batteries run out. Sometimes the eyelids relax too and might open a little bit.

title: How come you have that break in your voice that separates falsetto and normal voice?
text: Imagine your voice is like a special stretchy rubber band inside your throat! When you talk normally, that rubber band is kind of thick and wobbly. But when you sing super high, like a squeaky mouse or a tiny bird, your voice makes that same rubber band get super, super thin and stretched tight, like a tiny string! The "break" in your voice happens when your voice is trying to switch from being thick and wobbly to being super thin and tight. It's like when you try to change gears on a bike, and sometimes it makes a little clunk before it goes smoothly into the next gear. Your voice just needs a tiny moment to figure out how to make that big stretch!

title: And non-american by the way,how did New York City get so populated compared to other US cities and why does it stay so populated ?
text: Imagine New York City is like a super popular playground! A long, long time ago, it was really easy for big ships to sail right up to New York because it's on the water and has a great big "parking spot" for boats. So, people from all over the world who wanted to start a new life in America would get off their ships there first, making it a busy first stop. And because so many people were arriving, lots of important jobs started there, like making things in factories and selling stuff in big shops. It was like the first big place where lots of new things were happening, so more and more people kept coming, like everyone wanting to play at the coolest playground. Now, why does it stay so full? Well, it's still like that super popular playground! There are so many different kinds of "games" to play (which are like jobs for grown-ups) – some people make movies, some work with big numbers, some cook amazing food, and some make art. There's a job for almost everyone! Plus, there are tons of fun things to see and do, like big parks, museums with dinosaurs, and exciting shows, and it's easy to get around on a big underground train called the subway. All these exciting things make it a very busy place where lots of people want to live and visit, so it just keeps growing and staying full!

title: Why did the 1892 Populist Party in the United States demand inflation through free and unlimited coinage of silver (what was its benefits)?
text:
Imagine money is like shiny coins you use to buy toys or candy. Long, long ago, most money was made of *gold* coins, and gold was super hard to find, like a tiny bit of sparkly treasure. This meant there weren't many coins around, so each coin was worth a lot, and everything felt expensive.

Now, pretend you're a farmer, and you borrowed a bunch of these shiny gold coins to buy your tractor or seeds. You owe a lot of coins back! But when you sell your apples or corn, people don't have many coins to give you because there are so few around. It's super hard to get enough coins to pay back your debt.

The Populist Party, who were mostly farmers and regular folks, had an idea! They said, "Hey, there's lots and lots of *silver*! It's not

title: How can a film that grosses higher profits than the budget it took to make it still sometimes be considered a financial flop?
text: Imagine you have a super fun lemonade stand! You spend $5 to buy lemons, sugar, and cups (that's like the movie's budget to make it). Then, you sell

title: Why can't some functions be integrated?
text: Imagine you have a magic machine that can change toys into other toys. Integration is like trying to figure out what the *original* toy looked like before the machine changed it. Most of the time

title: why do milk alternatives [soy almond etc] get called milk and not *name* water?
text: Imagine you have a super-duper blender, like the one mommy uses! If you put some almonds (those crunchy nuts!) or some soybeans (like little beans) and a lot of water in it, and blend it all up really, really fast, it doesn't look like clear water anymore, does it? It turns white and a little bit creamy, just like cow's milk! And when you pour it on your cereal, or drink it, it *feels* and *tastes* more like milk than plain water. So, even though it started with water and almonds or soybeans, we call it almond 'milk' or soy 'milk' because it acts like milk for our tummies

title: Why do things creak when you moved/touched it after not touching/moving it for a long time?
text: Imagine your toy box, or your bed, or even a door, is made of lots and lots of tiny, tiny LEGO bricks all stuck together. When you don't touch it for a long, long time, these LEGO bricks get really comfy and cozy in their spots, like they're sleeping soundly. Their little edges might even get a tiny bit sticky from being together for so long. Then, when you finally push or move it, all those sleepy LEGO bricks suddenly have to wake up and slide past each other! That little 'creak' sound is like them stretching and saying 'ooooh, I'm moving!' as they pull apart from being cozy and start to slide around again. It's just the sound of all those tiny pieces wiggling free!

title: What does it mean to have something notarized?
text: Imagine you have a super important drawing, like a map to your secret cookie stash! And you want to make sure *everyone* knows it's *your* map and that *you* really drew it, so no one can say "No, that's not their map!" When you get something "notarized," it's kind of like that. A special grown-up, called a "notary" (say "NO-tuh-ree"), helps make sure your important papers are extra, extra true. Here's how it works: You bring your important paper to the notary. The notary looks at your grown-up ID (like a special card with your picture) to make sure you are *you*, and not someone pretending to be you. Then, the notary watches you sign the paper with your own hand. After you sign, the notary puts their own special stamp or sticker on the paper. It's like their magic "this is super true!" sticker. So, when a paper is notarized, it means a special grown-up saw you sign it and checked that it was really you. It makes the paper super official and helps everyone know it's not a trick, and that what's on it is really what you said or did. It's like a grown-up promise that everyone can trust.

title: How does a pool table know to return the white ball when it's sunk, but keeps the coloured balls?
text: Okay, imagine the pool table has a secret trick! When the balls fall into the holes, they roll down a little slide. But the white ball is a tiny, tiny bit smaller than all the colorful balls. So, there's a special secret hole on the slide that's *just* the right size for the white ball to fall through! The colorful balls are too big for that secret hole, so they just keep rolling to the basket where you pick them up. But the little white ball, because it's smaller, tumbles through its secret hole and rolls down a different path, all the way to a special spot where you can grab it easily to play again! It's like the table knows the white ball is special because of its size.

title: How does my penis know I’m looking at something sexual?
text: That's a super interesting question! Your penis doesn't actually 'see' or 'know' anything by itself. It's like your brain is the boss of your whole body, like the captain of a spaceship. When your eyes see something that makes your brain feel really excited or happy in a grown-up way, or even if you just think exciting thoughts, your brain sends a super-fast message, like a secret signal, all the way down to your penis. This message tells your penis to fill up with a little extra blood, kind of like blowing up a tiny balloon. When it fills up, it gets bigger and harder, and that's why it stands up! So, it's really your brain sending the message, not your penis knowing by itself.

title: Considering how inept the pinky finger is, why do humans actually need it?
text: Even though your pinky finger might seem super tiny and not very strong by itself, it's actually a really important helper! Imagine you're trying to hold a big cup of juice or climb on the monkey bars. If your pinky finger wasn't there, or if it just floated away, your hand wouldn't be able to grab things as tightly. It helps make your grip much stronger, like a little anchor for your hand, especially when you're squeezing something. All your fingers work together like a team, and the pinky makes sure the whole team can hold on better and squeeze harder!

title: How can we so distinctly remember things that never actually happened?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super-duper special storybook where it tries to draw pictures and write down everything that happens to you. But sometimes, your brain gets a little mixed up! Maybe someone told you a story so many times, or you thought about something a lot, or you saw a picture that made you imagine it, and your brain accidentally drew that picture and wrote that story in your book, even though *you* weren't really there when it happened. It's like your brain is trying really hard to fill in the blanks or make a good story, and sometimes it uses a pretend picture instead of a real one. And because your brain is so good at making stories feel real, you might think that pretend picture is a true memory, even though it's just a story your brain made up or borrowed!

title: why does even a little bit of heat aggravate a (fresh) burn wound?
text: Okay, imagine your skin is like a super-duper sensitive shield that protects you. When you get a burn, it's like a tiny part of your shield got really, really hot and is now very, very hurt and angry. It has little alarm bells inside that are already screaming 'Ouch! Oouch! Ouch!' super loud because it's damaged. Now, if you put even a tiny bit more heat on that angry, hurt spot, it's like someone is gently poking a very sore boo-boo. The alarm bells that were already ringing super loud get even *louder*! The hurt spot is still trying its best to fix itself, and it's super sensitive to *anything* that reminds it of the hot thing that hurt it in the first place, even if it's just a little bit warm. It just wants to be cool and left alone so it can heal.

title: How do deep space spacecraft such as Voyager orient themselves to point in a specific direction?

title: How do Snowflakes get that cool pattern?
text: Imagine tiny, tiny water drops high up in the sky, like little invisible raindrops. When it gets super, super cold up there, these tiny drops freeze into a tiny, tiny piece of ice. This little ice piece is like a baby snowflake! As this baby snowflake starts to fall down from the sky, it passes through clouds that have more invisible water vapor (like super cold mist). This cold mist sticks to the baby snowflake and freezes onto its edges. Because water likes to freeze in a special way that makes six arms, it starts to grow out with six little arms. As it falls and falls, more and more cold mist sticks to these arms, and new little icy bits grow on them, making all sorts of squiggly lines and patterns. Every snowflake takes a slightly different path down from the sky, bumping into different amounts of cold mist and air, so each one grows its own special, beautiful pattern, like tiny frozen works of art!

title: how does DNA trace ancestry?
text: Imagine your body is like a super special toy, and inside you have a tiny instruction book called DNA. This book has all the secrets about you, like your eye color or if you'll be tall. When you were made, you got half of your instruction book from your mommy and half from your daddy. And guess what? Your mommy got half of hers from her mommy and daddy, and your daddy got half of his from his mommy and daddy, and so on, all the way back to your great-great-great-great-grandparents! Now, the super cool part is that people who come from the same places in the world, like a long, long, long time ago, often have very similar little secret marks or pictures in their instruction books. It's like a special family stamp that many people from the same old village or country might have. So, when scientists look at your instruction book, they look for these secret marks. They compare your marks to a giant collection of marks from people all over the world. If your marks look a lot like the marks from people who have always lived in, say, a certain part of Africa, or a specific country in Europe, then they can say, 'Aha! It looks like some of your super old family came from there!' It's like finding clues in your special book that tell us where your family's journey started many, many years ago.

title: Why can we HEAR our joints crack? How does sound escape the inside of our body?
text: Okay, imagine your joints, like your knees or fingers, have a special super slippery juice inside them, which helps your bones move smoothly. This juice has tiny, tiny bubbles in it, kind of like the fizz in your juice or soda! When you stretch or bend your joint, you make a little more room, and sometimes those tiny bubbles pop really fast. That pop makes a sound! Now, how does the sound get out of your body? Well, sound is just tiny wiggles, like when you drop a pebble in a puddle and it makes ripples. When the bubble pops inside your joint, it makes little wiggles. These wiggles travel through your bones, through your squishy muscles, and all the way to your skin, and then they wiggle the air outside your body. Your ears catch those air wiggles, and that's how you hear the crack! It's like making a noise under a big blanket – the sound still wiggles its way out so you can hear it!

title: why does ESPN keep writing articles on what shoes NBA players wear?
text: Okay, imagine your favorite basketball player is like a superhero! You know how superheroes have special outfits? Well, basketball players have super cool, colorful shoes! Lots of kids and grown-ups look at their favorite player and think, 'Wow, I want shoes just like those!' Big shoe companies, who make the shoes, want *everyone* to buy their shoes, so they give the basketball players lots of money to wear *their* special shoes. ESPN is like a big TV channel and website that tells everyone about sports, and they know that lots of people think those shoes are super cool! So, when ESPN writes about the shoes, it makes more kids and grown-ups see them and maybe want to buy them, which makes the shoe companies happy, and it's also a fun thing for fans to talk about, just like talking about a superhero's cool new power!

title: How does an athlete using smelling salts work?
text: Imagine you're playing super hard, and you're a little sleepy, or maybe you just got a booboo and feel a bit wobbly. Smelling salts are like a special, super-duper stinky smell in a tiny bottle! When an athlete takes a little sniff, that really strong smell goes right up their nose and gives their brain a big, sudden 'WAKE UP!' tickle. It doesn't make them stronger or faster, but it makes them feel super alert and ready to go again, just like if someone loudly clapped their hands and made you jump a little. It just helps them shake off the sleepy or wobbly feeling for a little bit so they can focus on their game!

title: Why are babies so flexible?
text: Imagine your bones are like super strong, hard sticks now, right? But when you were a tiny baby, your bones weren't hard sticks yet! They were more like soft, squishy jelly or bendy rubber. And instead of one big, hard bone, babies have lots and lots of little soft bones, and some parts are made of a bouncy, bendy stuff called cartilage – think of the tip of your nose or your ear, how it can wiggle! This makes babies super duper flexible, like a little noodle, so they can curl up small and learn to move and wiggle all over the place. As you got bigger, those soft bones got harder and grew together, making you strong for running and jumping!

title: Why is plastic such a good insulator on windows in the winter?
text: Okay, imagine your window is like a big hole that lets all the warm air from your house run outside to play in the snow, and all the super cold air from outside sneak in. Brrr! When you put the plastic on your window, it makes a little invisible bubble of air right between the plastic and the window glass. This air is like a super soft, fluffy blanket! Blankets are good at keeping you warm because they trap your body heat, right? Well, this air blanket traps the warm air inside your house and doesn't let it run away so easily, and it also stops the sneaky cold air from coming in. So, your house stays toasty warm, just like you stay warm under your cozy blanket!

title: How do words get mapped to concepts within the brain?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a super-duper big playroom with thousands and thousands of toy boxes! Each toy box has a different "idea" or "picture" inside it – like one toy box has the idea of a fluffy dog, another has the idea of a yummy apple, and another has the idea of running fast. When you hear a grown-up say the word "dog," your brain quickly runs to the toy box that has the fluffy dog picture! It's like the word "dog" is a special sticker or label that we put on that specific toy box. The more you hear the word "dog" while you see or think about a real dog, the stronger that sticker sticks to that toy box, so your brain gets super good at finding the right idea very, very fast! It just connects the sound to the picture in your head.

title: Why does the bathroom get steamy when the water is well below the boiling point?
text: Imagine your warm bath water is like a big pool full of super happy, bouncy tiny water friends! When the water is warm, these tiny water friends get so excited they jump out of the water and fly all around the bathroom, but they're so small you can't even see them. The air in the bathroom is like a big playground for them. But then, when these invisible flying water friends touch something cold, like the mirror or the walls, they get a little bit chilly and want to huddle together to keep warm. When they huddle, they become tiny, tiny little water dots that you *can* see, like a very light, friendly cloud. That's what we call steam! It's not because the water is super duper hot like a boiling kettle, but just because the warm, invisible water friends are meeting the cooler air and getting cozy together.

title: why do plastic wrappers tear much easier after an initial cut?
text: Imagine your plastic wrapper is like a super long line of tiny, tiny invisible friends all holding hands. When you try to pull it without a cut, you're pulling on *all* of them at once, and they are super strong together! But when you make a little snip with scissors, it's like you broke the hands of just two friends in the middle. Now, when you pull again, all the 'pulling power' doesn't go to everyone evenly; it goes *right to the ends* of where you cut, to those two friends who are now at the very front of the broken line. They can't hold on as well by themselves because all the pulling force gets squished into that tiny spot, and poof, the tear zooms right through!

title: Why can't Canadians watch certain American programs (like Saturday Night Live) online?
text: Imagine your favorite cartoon show. The grown-ups who make that show have special rules about where it can be watched, just like some toys are only sold in certain stores, maybe only in Canada or only in America. For a show like Saturday Night Live, the people who own it make special deals that say, "Okay, this internet place can show our show, but *only* to people whose computers are in America." Even though the internet feels like it's everywhere, it's super smart and knows if your computer is in Canada or America, like a magic map. So, if a TV channel in Canada wants to show SNL, they have to buy their *own* special permission to show it to you, because the American internet places only have permission for America.

So, the shoes one runner wears might be a tiny bit different from another runner's shoes because they like how they feel on *their* feet, helping *them* run their very fastest. title: Why do some people develop a mental illness during childhood instead of when they are older? Are there different factors involved?
text: Imagine your brain is like a super special computer that helps you think, feel, and play! title: Why is there a wait period between when we eat and when we feel full?
text: Imagine your tummy is like a little house for your food. When you put yummy food in, your tummy doesn't instantly know if it's full or not! It needs a little bit of time to squish the food around and send a tiny message, like a little bird flying all the way up to your brain, which is like the boss of your whole body. That little bird says, "Hey boss, I think we've had enough food down here!" It takes a few minutes for that message-bird to fly all the way up and for your brain to get it and say, "Okay, stop eating now!" So, you keep eating a little bit while that message is still on its way, which is why you feel full a little *after* you've put enough food in your tummy.

title: Remember when point and shoot cameras had a flash that made a high pitched tone when you turned it on? What made that sound? What was the purpose of that sound?
text: That high-pitched sound was like your camera saying, "Whew! I'm working really hard to get ready!" Inside the camera, there's a special little battery that needs to gather up a lot of power super fast to make a really bright flash of light. The sound was the tiny parts inside buzzing and whirring as they were collecting all that power and getting it ready, kind of like a little pump filling up a balloon with light! The purpose of the sound was like a "ding!" or a "ready!" signal, letting you know, "Okay, I've got all the light I need! You can push the button now and get a super bright picture!"

title: what's the difference between a $4 bottle of honey and a $15 jar of honey? What am I missing out on by buying the cheaper honey?
text: Okay, imagine you have two bowls of yummy, sweet honey! The cheap honey, the $4 one, is sometimes like a big bowl of sugar water that someone put just a little bit of honey in, just enough to make it taste sweet. Or maybe it's honey from lots and lots of different places all mixed up. It's still sweet, but it doesn't have a very strong, special honey taste. The $15 honey is like a bowl full of *only* honey, straight from the bees who worked super hard to make it from special flowers, all from one farm. It tastes much stronger, more flowery, and really special! So, when you buy the cheaper honey, you're mostly missing out on that super special, strong, pure honey taste, and knowing exactly where those busy bees made it.

title: how do we make different notes when we whistle?
text: When you whistle, you're blowing air out through a tiny, special shape you make with your lips and tongue, like making a little tunnel for the air. To make different notes, you just change the size of that tunnel! If you make the tunnel bigger and wider, the air wiggles slower and makes a low, deep sound, like a big bear. But if you make the tunnel really small and tight, the air has to squeeze out super fast and wiggles quickly, making a high, squeaky sound, like a tiny mouse! So, your mouth is like a magical instrument, and by changing its shape, you tell the air how fast to wiggle and what note to sing!

title: What is a laser printer doing when it is making all those noises but not printing?
text: Imagine your printer is like a little chef in a kitchen. Before it can make your yummy picture-food, it needs to get its oven super hot, because it uses heat to stick the colors on the paper! So, those noises are it warming up its oven and getting all its tiny kitchen helpers (little robot parts) ready and in place. Sometimes, it's also listening very carefully to the computer, waiting for the computer to tell it exactly *what* picture or words to cook up. It's getting ready to do its job, even if the paper isn't coming out yet!

title: How Blue Whales eat/swallow and what would happen if a human was diving nearby?
text: Imagine a blue whale is like a super-duper giant vacuum cleaner in the ocean! It doesn't eat big fish or people, it eats teeny-tiny shrimp called krill, like little sprinkles. It opens its mouth super, super wide, like a huge scoop, and gulps in a whole swimming pool full of water and all the tiny shrimp inside. It doesn't have teeth, but instead, it has giant combs inside its mouth, like a big brush, called baleen. When it closes its mouth, it pushes all the water out through the combs, and all the little shrimp get stuck inside, like when you strain pasta! Then, it just licks all the stuck shrimp off its combs and swallows them. Its throat is actually very tiny, only big enough for the little shrimp, not for a big person or a big fish. So, if a human was swimming nearby and got accidentally sucked into its mouth with all the water, it would be a very scary, very wet ride! You'd just get pushed right back out with all the water through the combs because the whale's throat is too small for you to fit. The whale wouldn't even know you were there because it's only looking for its tiny shrimp snacks!

title: Which countries don't rely on the US for their internet?
text: Imagine the internet is like a super big spiderweb that connects everyone's houses all over the world. To talk to someone far away, your message travels along these web strings. No country *has* to send *all* their messages through just one other country's strings! Countries that are really big and have lots of people, like China, Russia, or even lots of countries in Europe working together, have built their *own* super big, super fast strings and special computers. This means they have their *own* direct paths to talk to lots of other places without always needing to go through the strings that pass through the United States. title: Why does a hot shower make my skin dry?
text: Okay, imagine your skin has a special, invisible, slightly oily blanket all over it. This blanket is super important because it helps keep all the nice, soft water *inside* your skin, like a fence keeping water in a pool. When you take a super hot shower, that hot water is like a very strong cleaner! It washes away that special oily blanket. And once that blanket is gone, all the water inside your skin can easily escape and fly away into the air. When the water leaves, your skin feels all dry and sometimes a bit itchy, like a thirsty flower that needs a drink!

But for *you*, your timer feels totally normal! This is what "time is relative" means – how fast your timer ticks depends on how fast you're moving. title: Why do so few people live in the Canadian Territories like the Yukon but Alaska has a much larger population with similar climate and geography?
text: Imagine two big, cold, snowy playgrounds, like the Yukon and Alaska. They look kind of the same, right? Lots of trees and mountains! Now, in Alaska, it's like someone found a giant treasure chest full of black, gooey syrup called oil. This oil was super important for making cars go and houses warm! So, lots of grown-ups moved there to dig up the oil because it was a really good job. Also, the American army built big bases there to keep everyone safe, so more people moved there for those jobs too. And it was a bit easier for them to get trucks and cars to Alaska from the rest of America. But in the Yukon, they didn't find as much of that super special oil, or as many big army bases. People found some gold a long, long time ago, but not enough to make *lots* and *lots* of people stay forever. It's also a bit harder to get to the Yukon from the main part of Canada because there aren't as many big roads going all the way up there. So, even though it's beautiful, not as many grown-ups moved there because there weren't as many super big jobs or easy ways to live close to everything else. It's still a wonderful place, just a bit quieter!

title: Why is almost every country in debt?
text: Imagine your country is like a really, really big family, and it needs money to buy lots of important things for everyone, like building schools so you can learn, making roads so cars can drive, and having hospitals when people get sick. Sometimes, even though the country gets money from people (like when your parents earn money), it doesn't have *all* the money it needs *right now* to buy *everything* really fast. Maybe they want to build a super-duper new playground *and* fix all the bumpy roads *this year*! That costs a lot! So, what do they do? They borrow money! Just like your mommy or daddy might borrow money from the bank to buy a house, or you might borrow a toy from a friend and promise to give it back later. The country borrows money from other countries, or from big banks, or even from grown-ups inside the country who have extra money. They borrow it so they can build all those important things *now* instead of waiting a super long time. They promise to pay it back slowly, little by little, over many years. Almost every country does this because it helps them make things better for all the people who live there, even if they have to pay a little extra back later.

title: If all human cells replace themselves every 7 years, why can scars remain on you body your entire life?
text: Imagine your skin is like a super cool blanket made of tiny, tiny building blocks. Most of these blocks get old and fall off, and new, fresh ones come to take their place, like changing your socks! But when you get a big owie, like a cut, your body is super smart and wants to fix it really, really fast so no bad germs get in. So, it uses a special, super-strong, quick-fix kind of glue and different building blocks to patch it up. This patch is like a special, tough sticker. Even when the little blocks in that sticker get old and fall off, your body remembers, "Hey, this spot needs the special tough sticker!" So, it keeps making *more* of the tough sticker material, not the soft, regular blanket material. That's why it stays there forever – it's your body's special way of remembering where it had to be extra brave and fix a big boo-boo!

title: What is Pi-Hole, what does it do?
text: Imagine your internet is like a big road that brings pictures and videos to your tablet or computer. Sometimes, on this road, there are annoying billboards and people trying to sell you toys you don't want – those are ads! Pi-Hole is like a super-smart police officer standing right at the start of your road. When an ad tries to come down your road to your tablet, the Pi-Hole police officer says, "Nope! You can't come in here!" and stops it right away. So, only the good pictures and videos get to your tablet, and everything works faster and without those yucky, annoying ads getting in the way. It's like having a clean, clear road just for your fun stuff!

title: Why is there a "feels like" temperature? Shouldn't that just be the temperature?
text: That's a super smart question! Imagine you have a warm blanket all around you, right? The air outside has a temperature, like how hot or cold the air is. But sometimes, when the wind blows really hard, it's like someone is pulling away your warm blanket a little bit, even if the air itself didn't get colder. So, the wind makes you feel colder than the thermometer says. And other times, when it's super sticky outside, like when you've been running and are all sweaty, your body wants to cool down by letting your sweat dry. But if the air is too sticky, your sweat can't dry easily, and you feel much hotter than the thermometer says. So, the "feels like" temperature is like a secret message that tells you how your body will *really* feel because of the wind pushing your warm blanket away or the sticky air making it hard for you to cool down, even if the air's actual temperature stays the same.

title: . How did climate change become a partisan issue?
text: Imagine you and your friend are playing with blocks, and a grown-up scientist comes and says, "Uh oh, if you keep piling blocks like that, the whole tower might fall over and make a big mess!" Now, some grown-ups (let's call them Team Green) say, "Oh no, the scientist is right! We need to stop piling blocks so high and maybe use different, safer blocks!" They really trust the scientist. But other grown-ups (let's call them Team Red) say, "Hmm, I don't know. That tower looks fine to me! And besides, if we stop piling blocks, the people who *make* the blocks and *sell* the blocks might not have jobs anymore, and we don't want that! Also, it's a lot of work to change how we play." They don't want to believe the scientist, or they worry about other things. Soon, because the grown-ups on Team Green kept saying "We need to change!" and the grown-ups on Team Red kept saying "No we don't, or it's too hard!", it became like a big game where everyone picked a team. And once you pick a team, it's hard to change your mind because you want to stick with your friends on your team. So, instead of everyone listening to the scientist together, they started arguing because they were on different teams.

title: How do brands manufacturing non-concentrated, natural fruit juice keep the taste constant?
text: Imagine you have a big basket of apples. Some are super sweet, some are a little sour, right? If you just make juice from one apple, it might taste a bit different every time! So, what big juice companies do is collect juice from *lots* and *lots* of different fruits. Then, they mix all that juice together in a giant jug, like when you mix different colors of paint to get just the right shade. title: What is the benefit of having the bathroom light switch outside of the bathroom?
text: Imagine you just washed your hands, and they are super wet, like after playing with a water balloon! Electricity (that makes the light work) and water don't like to be together very much, and sometimes if your wet hand touches an electric switch, it can give you a little 'ouchy' shock. So, putting the light switch *outside* the bathroom means you can turn the light on *before* you even go in, or turn it off *after* you come out and your hands are all dry. It's like a grown-up way to keep you extra safe from those 'ouchy' shocks when your hands are wet!

title: How PICC lines don’t do any damage (poking/scraping) to the heart and/or veins when you move around?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super long, super soft, bendy straw that goes inside your arm. It goes through a squishy tunnel (that's your vein!) all the way to a big open space near your heart, but it doesn't actually go *into* your heart. Now, because both the straw and the tunnel inside you are very soft and wiggly, they just bend and move together like best friends when you move your arm or body. It's like having a soft noodle in a big, squishy balloon – when the balloon moves, the noodle just wiggles and bends along with it, without poking or hurting anything because everything is so gentle and flexible!

title: Why are there holes in Swiss Cheese?
text: Okay, imagine you're making a yummy cake, but instead of cake, it's cheese! When people make Swiss cheese, they put in tiny, tiny helpers, like invisible little bakers. These little helpers love to eat special things in the milk. And when they eat, sometimes they get a little burpy, just like you might after drinking soda! These burps are little bubbles of air. The cheese is soft and squishy when it's first made, so the burps get stuck inside and push the cheese apart, making little rooms. When the cheese is all grown up and ready to eat, those little rooms are the holes you see!

title: What is the difference between a daily, bi-weekly, and monthly contact lens?
text:
Imagine your contact lenses are like tiny, clear helpers for your eyes so you can see super well!
