When mommy lies on her back, that big, heavy balloon and the baby can push down on a special tube inside mommy's tummy that carries important blood and food to her heart and to the baby. If that tube gets squished, it's like stepping on a garden hose –

title: What causes water to "tornado" down the drain/sink/toilet?
text: Imagine your bathtub is full of water, and then *whoosh*, you pull the plug! The water wants to go down the hole to freedom. But instead of just falling straight, the water starts to push and bump into each other, and they all decide it's more fun to go around in a big circle, like when you spin around until you're dizzy! As they get closer and closer to the tiny hole, they get super excited and spin faster and faster, just like a toy top spins super fast right in the middle. This fast spinning makes that swirly, twirly shape that looks like a tiny water tornado, helping all the water rush down the drain really quick! It's just the water having a fun, fast ride down the hole.

title: How do polaroid pictures work?
text: Imagine your Polaroid camera is like a special box that takes a quick peek at the world. When you press the button, it quickly takes a tiny peek! Then, a little piece of paper comes out, and it looks all blank, right? But inside that paper, there are super tiny packets of special colorful goo, like secret paint. When the paper comes out, those packets get squished open and the colorful goo starts to spread out and mix. It's like magic paint that slowly draws the picture you just saw, right there on the paper, all by itself! You just have to be patient for a little bit while the goo paints your picture.

title: Why does a li-ion/lipo battery explode when shorted out?
text: Imagine your battery is like a juice box full of special power juice for your toys. When you use it normally, the juice flows nicely through your toy to make it work. But if you accidentally make a super-duper shortcut, like touching the two ends of a jump rope together really fast, all the power juice tries to rush out at once through that tiny shortcut! When all that juice rushes out super fast, it gets incredibly, incredibly hot, like when you rub your hands together super fast until they're really warm, but way, way hotter! Inside the battery, there's special goopy stuff that helps the juice move. This goopy stuff doesn't like getting super hot. When it gets too hot too quickly from the super-fast shortcut, it gets very angry, puffs up really big, and can even catch fire with a loud pop! That's why it looks like it explodes – because the super-fast hot shortcut made everything inside get too hot and puffy all at once

title: Why the hell do phones have to have a "minimum charge" before they turn on, can't they just draw power directly from the source?
text: Imagine your phone is like a sleepy little robot, and its battery is like its tummy where it keeps all its energy snacks. When its tummy is totally, totally empty, the robot is so sleepy it can't even open its eyes or wiggle its fingers! Even if you plug it in (that's like giving it a juice box), it needs to put a *tiny* bit of juice into its tummy first, just enough to say "Okay, I can start waking up now!" Turning on is a very big job for the phone, like getting ready for school – it needs energy for its brain, its screen, and all its parts to start working all at once. If it tried to do all that *and* fill its tummy from zero at the same time, it would be too much work and it would just get confused and stay sleepy. So, it needs that little bit of snack in its tummy first, then it can use the new juice to finish waking up and play!

title: Why did Video Games only work on Channel 3?
text: Okay, imagine your TV is like a big ear, and it can listen to many different people talking at the same time, but each person has their own special number, like a phone number. TV shows like cartoons or news talk on numbers like 2, 5, 7, 9. Your video game box (like your old Nintendo!) was like a little person who wanted to talk to your TV, but it only knew how to talk on *one special number*, which was usually number 3 (or sometimes number 4 if 3 was already busy with a TV show!). So, for your TV's ear to hear the game and show you the pictures, you had to make sure your TV's ear was *listening on number 3*. If it was listening on number 5, it would hear the cartoon instead of your game! It's like if you want to talk to your friend on the phone, you have to dial *their* number, not someone else's. The game only had one number it knew how to call!

title: Does the cliche "Don't talk, save your strength" have any actual merit to it?
text: Imagine your body has a special juice box filled with energy! Everything you do, like running or playing, takes a little sip from your juice box. Talking also takes a super, super tiny sip, like a little drop, almost so small you wouldn't even notice it! Most of the time, you have so much juice in your box that talking doesn't make you tired at all. You can talk and talk and still have lots of energy to play. But sometimes, when someone is super, super sick or hurt, their body is working extra hard to get better. It's like their juice box is almost empty, and every single tiny drop is super important for getting well. So, in those very special times, saving even that tiny, tiny drop of energy used for talking can help their body use all its power to heal and feel better faster. It's like saying, "Let's save every drop of juice for the most important job!" But for most of us, most of the time, talking is totally fine and won't make you tired.

title: Animators of Reddit, when producing an animated film, do the voice actors read all their lines first and the animation is made to match the actors' lines, or is the film animated first with the voices second to match the animation?
text: Imagine you're going to sing a song, but someone else is going to draw a picture of you singing it! It's much easier if you sing the song first, "La la la!" and then the person draws your mouth moving exactly when you sing "la la la." If they drew your mouth moving first, and then you tried to sing, it would be super tricky to make your words fit into those drawn mouth shapes! So, usually, the voice actors talk and make all their sounds first, and then the animators draw all the pictures to make the characters look like they're really talking and making those sounds. It helps them make sure the cartoon character's mouth moves perfectly with the words! Sometimes, for a big funny jump or a special song, they might draw a little bit first, but mostly, it's voices first!

title: Why can't we use diesel in a petrol engine and vice versa? For that matter, why can't we use any combustible fuel in any internal combustion engine?
text:
Imagine your car's engine is like a special tummy, and fuel is its food!

**Petrol engine:** This tummy likes very light, fizzy soda (petrol). It has a special little light-bulb (called a spark plug) that goes *zap!* to tell the soda exactly when to make a little "poof" and push the car. If you give it thick, sticky honey (diesel), the little light-bulb isn't strong enough to make the honey go "

title: How does glue not stick to the inside of the bottle?
text: Imagine glue is like a secret potion that only gets sticky when it feels the air, kind of like how your wet clothes need air to dry. Inside its bottle, there's hardly any

title: How do waterless toilets work? How do they not smell constantly?
text: Imagine your regular toilet uses a big splash of water to make your potty go "whoosh!" down a water slide. Waterless toilets are different because they don't use any water at all

title: What is 'Optimistic Nihilism'?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big, empty box. Some grown-ups might say, "This box doesn't have a special job, it's just a box." That's a bit like the "nihilism" part – thinking that maybe life doesn't have a super important, pre-set job for us. But then, the "optimistic" part comes in! You can say, "Well, if it's just an empty box, then *I* can make it into anything I want! I can turn it into a house for my teddy bear, a car for my toys, or even a spaceship to go to the moon!" So, optimistic nihilism is like saying: "Even if nobody told us what life is *supposed* to be for, that's actually super cool! Because it means *we* get to decide what makes us happy, what fun things we want to do, and what kind of amazing adventures we want to have while we're here." It's like having a blank canvas and getting to paint whatever makes *you* smile!

title: How come when you have a fever and your temperature is so high you feel cold?
text: Imagine your body has a special thermostat, like the one that controls the temperature in your house. Normally, it's set to a comfy temperature. But when you get sick, little germ "bad guys" trick your thermostat into thinking it needs to be set much, much higher! So, even though your body is already getting super hot inside trying to reach that new high setting, your brain thinks, "Gosh, I'm not hot enough yet! I need to warm up even more!" That's why you shiver and get goosebumps, trying to make yourself warmer, and that makes you feel cold on the outside, even though you're actually burning up inside!

title: Why are the simple sugars in fruit considered to be better for you than those found in candy?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a little house that needs energy to play! Both fruit and candy have sugar, which is like a special kind of energy power-up. When you eat candy, it's like getting a big, super-fast burst of energy that makes you zoom around for a little bit, but then it runs out really quickly, and that's all it gives you. But when you eat fruit, it also has that energy power-up (sugar!), but it comes with lots of tiny helpers and special spongy stuff called fiber. These helpers make sure your body gets the energy slowly and steadily, so you don't zoom out too fast. The spongy stuff also helps your tummy feel full and happy for longer, and the tiny helpers make your body strong and healthy! So, fruit gives you good energy plus lots of extra good things, while candy just gives you a quick, fast energy burst with nothing else helpful.

title: Why is sweat colourless and not yellow like urine?
text: Sweat is like your body's little water sprinkler when you get hot from running and playing! It's mostly just clean water, like the water you drink, with a tiny bit of salt mixed in, which you can't even see. Since water is clear, your sweat is clear too, because its job is just to help you cool down. Pee-pee (urine) is different! Your body uses all the good parts of the food and drinks you have, and then it puts all the leftover yucky stuff it doesn't need anymore into your pee-pee to send it out. Some of that yucky stuff has a special yellow colour, which makes your pee-pee yellow, because its job is to get rid of all the things your body doesn't want to keep inside.

title: If cinemas now get movies as a Digital Copy how come they dont get copied and leaked online well before the DVD release date?
text: Imagine a movie is like a super special, secret toy! When it goes to the cinema, it's not just a simple picture you can easily copy. It's like a very, very big, fancy toy that only works with a giant, special play-machine that lives inside the cinema. This special play-machine is super smart and has lots of rules. It makes sure no one can just press a button and make a copy. Even if someone tried to sneaky-copy it, the movie has invisible 'stamps' all over it, like secret glitter, that would tell everyone exactly *which* cinema it came from! And the cinema people are super careful, like grown-ups guarding a very important treasure, so it stays safe

title: How does a progressive web app(PWA) work?
text: Imagine your favorite website, like a place where you watch cartoons or play simple games. Usually, you need to open a special 'internet' door (a browser) to go there. But a Progressive Web App is like a *super special* website that can learn to be a bit like an app on your phone or tablet! It can put its own little

title: How do cinemagraphs work?
text: Imagine you have a magic picture! Most of the picture is totally still, like when Mommy takes a photo of you. But one tiny little part of the picture, like your hair or a little toy, keeps wiggling and moving, over and over again, like a super short movie loop! It's like someone took a video, then they picked just one small part of it to keep playing, and made all the rest of the video stand perfectly still like a frozen picture. So you get a picture that's mostly still, but has a little secret movement!

title: How was mail delivered in the 18th century if there weren't exact addresses?
text: Imagine a very, very long time ago, even before your grandpa was born! Back then, houses didn't have numbers like yours does, and there weren't lots of streets. So, when someone wanted to send a letter, they couldn't just write '123 Main Street.' Instead, they'd write things like 'To Farmer John, who lives by the big red barn near the river in the town of Springfield.' The person delivering the mail (maybe on a horse!) would take all the letters to a special building in the town called the post office. Everyone in the town knew each other really well, so the people at the post office would often know exactly who Farmer John was and where his big red barn was! Sometimes, Farmer John would even go to the post office himself every few days to ask, 'Do I have any letters today?' It was like a big game of knowing your neighbors and helping each other find things!

title: Why can't wild animals who have been injured and rehabilitated by wildlife be released back to the wild instead of kept in zoos, aquariums, or sanctuaries?
text: Imagine a little bird who broke its wing really, really bad. Kind people helped it get all better, but maybe its wing can't fly super fast or super high anymore, like it needs to catch bugs or get away from a hungry cat. Or maybe, while it was getting better, it got very used to people giving it yummy seeds, and it forgot how to find its own food or be scared of big, noisy humans. If we put it back outside, it might not be able to find enough food, or it might get hurt again because it doesn't remember to be careful. That would be very sad! So, for animals who can't be super wild and safe all by themselves anymore, special places like zoos or sanctuaries give them a safe home where they get food and care, so they can live a happy life without having to worry about being hurt or hungry.

title: How do music synthesizers work?
text: Imagine sound is like jiggling jelly! When you sing or play a toy piano, you make the air jiggle in a special way that your ears hear. A music synthesizer is like a magic box that doesn't need strings or drums to make sounds. Instead, it has tiny electric wiggles inside! It's like having little machines that can make these electric wiggles go fast or slow (which makes high or low sounds), or make them bumpy or smooth (which changes what the sound feels like, like a flute or a buzzy bee). Then, you can use buttons and knobs to tell the box to make the wiggles start loud and then quiet, or start soft and then get loud, just like painting a sound picture. So, it's like a chef who can cook up any kind of sound-jelly you can imagine, all by playing with electricity!

title: Why do amphetamines suppress appetite?
text: Imagine your brain is like the boss of your whole body, and it has a special job to tell your tummy when it's hungry. Now, amphetamines are like a super-duper exciting candy for your brain! When your brain gets this special candy, it gets really, really busy and excited, like when you're playing your favorite game and you're so focused on catching the bad guy that you completely forget it's dinner time. Because your brain is so busy running around and feeling all that "go-go-go" energy, it gets too distracted to remember its job of telling your tummy, "Hey, I'm hungry! Let's eat!"

title: Are there climate equivelents in the southern hemisphere to northern hemisphere locations?
text: Yes, kind of! Imagine our big round Earth. The sun shines on it, and places that are about the same distance from the middle line (we call it the equator) usually get similar amounts of sun. So, if you go a certain way up from the middle and find a warm, sunny place, you might find another warm, sunny place if you go the same way down from the middle. But it's not like a perfect copy! Our Earth has lots

title: How do we pasteurize eggs without cooking them?
text: Imagine there are super tiny, invisible bad guys living on and in the eggshell, and sometimes a few inside too, that can give you a tummy ache. When you cook an egg, it gets super hot and hard, and those bad guys all go away. But what if we just want to make them go away without making the egg hard? We give the eggs a super long, warm bath, just like you take a warm bath! It's not hot enough to cook your skin, right? It's just warm and comfy. They keep the eggs in this warm bath for a special long time, and that warm bath is just the right temperature to make all those invisible bad guys go to sleep forever, but it's not hot enough to make the egg gooey and hard inside. So the egg still looks and feels like a regular egg, but now it's super safe to eat because the bad guys are all gone!

title: Why does food sometimes pop in the microwave as if it was very hot, but still come out cold?
text: Imagine your food is like a playground with lots of tiny water kids inside. The microwave is like a special magic light that makes *some* of those water kids wiggle and dance super-duper fast! When they wiggle really fast, they get super hot. Sometimes, a super hot wiggling water kid gets stuck inside a little pocket and pushes so hard to get out that it makes a loud "POP!" sound, like a tiny balloon bursting! That's why you hear the noise. But the magic light doesn't make *all* the water kids wiggle at the same time. So, while some parts of your food have super hot, popping water kids, other parts are still sleepy and cold because the magic light didn't shine on them yet.

title: How does Chinese water torture work?
text: Imagine you're lying down, and someone puts just one tiny little drop of water right on your forehead, over and over again, in the exact same spot. At first, it might feel like a little tickle, like a tiny raindrop. But then, it just keeps happening: drip... drip... drip... It never stops, and you can't make it stop. It's not like a big owie that hurts your body, but it gets super, super annoying because it never goes away. Your brain gets really tired and confused trying to wait for the next drop that always comes, and it makes you feel like you can't do anything about it, which is a very yucky and scary feeling, even though it's just water.

title: how does spray insulation foam work and turn from spray to foam?
text: Imagine your house needs a super cozy blanket to stay warm in winter and cool in summer! Spray foam is like that special blanket. When it's in the can, it's a liquid, like sticky paint. But inside that liquid, there are tiny, tiny things that are super excited to meet the air. When you spray it out, it's like opening a soda bottle – all those excited tiny things suddenly have space, and they puff up really fast, making millions of little bubbles! These bubbles get stuck together, turning the liquid into a big, puffy cloud, just like a giant marshmallow. Then, it gets hard and stays puffy, making a thick, bubbly wall that traps air, and that trapped air is what keeps your house feeling just right, like a warm hug in winter and a cool breeze in summer!

title: Why is film grain considered good?
text: Imagine your favorite drawing, but instead of perfectly smooth colors, it has tiny, tiny sprinkles of sugar all over it. That's kind of like film grain! When grown-ups used old cameras, the pictures weren't super smooth like the ones on a tablet today. They had these little tiny dots, like sand, that made up the picture. Some grown-ups really love these tiny dots because they make the picture feel special. It makes it look like a real, handmade drawing, not a perfect, shiny computer picture. It also makes them think of old, happy memories, like watching classic cartoons or looking at old family photos. It adds a cozy, warm feeling, like a soft blanket, and makes the picture feel more "alive" and interesting, not just flat and plain. So, even though it's not perfectly smooth, those little sprinkles make the picture feel more real and beautiful to many people!

title: Why are some allergies much more common than others?
text: Imagine your body has tiny little guards that protect you from yucky germs and things that can make you sick. An allergy is when these guards get a little bit confused and think something totally safe,

title: - When does a body determine its dominant side? How does it do this and can it be changed with outside influences?
text: Your body starts to figure out if you're going to be a super righty or a super lefty when you're a tiny baby growing inside your mommy, and then even more when you start doing things like grabbing toys, drawing pictures, or throwing a ball. It's like your brain is a little boss, and it just kind of decides which hand or foot it likes to make extra, extra good at tricky things. It's not really something you choose, your brain just naturally finds a comfy spot for one side, like it feels just right. And even though grown-ups used

title: what actually happens in our bodies that gives us the feeling of tiredness or sleepyness?
text: Imagine your body is like a busy little robot that plays and learns all day long! To do all that cool stuff, your robot uses up its special energy, kind of like how your toy car needs batteries. As it uses energy, it makes a tiny bit of "sleepy dust" that slowly builds up in your brain, like sand in an hourglass. When there's enough sleepy dust, your brain gets a message saying, "Whoa, little robot! You've been super busy, and your energy batteries are getting low! Time to rest and recharge!" Your brain also has a special little clock inside that knows when it gets dark outside, and it tells your body, "Hey, it's nighttime, time for all little robots to power down and get ready for a fresh new day!" So, you feel sleepy because your body needs to rest, clean out that sleepy dust, and fill up its energy batteries again!

title: probably a dumb question but here goes. If someone has lice why exactly can't they just dip their head in water and drown the lice?
text: That's a super smart idea! You're right, we need to breathe air to live, and if we stay underwater too long, we can't breathe. But lice are super tricky little bugs! They can hold their breath for a very, very long time, like for many hours! Imagine you try to hold your breath – you can do it for a little bit, right? Lice can do it for so long that even if you kept your head underwater for a long time, they would just wait until you came back up and then start breathing again. So, water isn't enough to get rid of them because they're just too good at holding their breath!

title: What are jewels in analog watches for?
text: Imagine your watch is like a tiny playground with lots of little spinning wheels and gears inside, making it tick-tock! If these little wheels just rubbed against each other or the watch's body, they would get sticky, slow down, and wear out really fast, like trying to slide down a bumpy rock. So, clever grown-ups put in special, super-duper smooth and hard little stones, called "jewels" (they're usually tiny rubies, but not the expensive kind you wear on a necklace!). These jewels are like super slippery slides for the tiny spinning parts. They make sure everything can spin and move super easily without getting stuck or worn out, which helps your watch tell the right time and last for a very, very long time!

title: How does the brush bring shine to a shoe after polishing and conditioning?
text: Imagine your shoe has tiny, tiny bumps, like a road that isn't perfectly flat. When you put the polish and conditioner on, it's like putting a super thin, soft, waxy blanket over those bumps. It makes the shoe look nice, but it's still a little bit messy, like a blanket just thrown on your bed. Now, when you take your brush and rub it really fast on the shoe, it's like magic! The brush pushes that soft blanket all around, making it super, super flat and even, like when you smooth out your bed blanket perfectly. And because you're

title: Why does sound travel faster in warm temperature?
text: Sound is like a little wiggle or a push that travels through the air. The air is made of super tiny, invisible friends called molecules. When you make a sound, you push one tiny friend, and that friend bumps the next one, and they all bump each other super fast, like a chain reaction! When it's warm outside, those tiny air friends are already super excited and jiggly! They're not standing still; they're already dancing and wiggling around a lot. So, when the sound wiggle comes along

title: How is food flavoring made?
text: Imagine you want your yummy cookie to taste like a super sweet strawberry! Sometimes, grown-ups can squish real strawberries and take out their special yummy juice, and that's one way to get the strawberry taste. But other times, smart grown-ups are like magic chefs! They look at a real strawberry and figure out all the tiny, invisible bits that make it smell and taste like a strawberry. Then, they find other safe, yummy things that have those exact same tiny invisible bits, and they mix them all together in a special bottle. It's like they're making a secret recipe for just the *smell* and *taste* of strawberry, so your cookie can be yummy and strawberry-flavored even if there isn't a whole strawberry in it! So, it's either from squishing real things or from super smart grown-ups mixing special taste-drops in a bottle to make food extra delicious!

title: How do people like Jeff Bezos—with high net worth tied up in assets and company shares—afford to pay for huge purchases like the Washington Post, private jets, luxury homes, etc.?
text: Imagine you have a super, super big toy box, and inside it are lots of amazing, expensive toys like a giant LEGO castle, a fancy dollhouse, and maybe even a pretend race

title: Why are 3d models used for games, in a T-Pose when not in use or before an animation ?
text: Imagine your favorite toy doll or action figure! Sometimes, when you first take it out of the box, or when it's just waiting to play, its arms are sticking straight out to the sides, like the letter 'T'. That's kind of like a T-pose for the computer people. It's like a starting position for everything. It's the easiest way for the computer to measure all the parts, like the arms and legs, to make sure they are exactly the right size and in the right place, like drawing a person with simple lines first. And from that simple 'T' shape, it's super easy to then bend the arms to wave hello, or run, or jump, or do anything else you want them to do, just like bending your doll's arms from its starting spot! It's like a blank canvas that's ready for all the fun moving parts.

title: What is mRNA? What is it’s potential and far along in development is it?
text: Imagine your body is like a super amazing LEGO castle, and it needs instructions to build new things or fix parts. mRNA is like a special, tiny instruction note that tells your LEGO castle exactly what to build – maybe a tiny shield to protect against bad monsters (germs), or a little helper tool to fix a broken part of the castle. It's like a quick message that says, 'Hey body, build this!' The super cool thing about mRNA is that it can teach your body to make lots of different helpful things, not just one! We already used these special instruction notes to help your body build helper shields against a really tricky cough (that was the COVID-19 vaccine!), so we know it works really well! Now, grown-ups are trying to use these instruction notes to make helper shields for lots of other yucky germs, and even to help fix problems inside your body that make you sick. So, it's not just an idea anymore – it's already helping people, and lots more amazing uses are being built right now!

title: Why does reheated food taste different than freshly cooked food?
text: Okay, imagine your yummy food is like a brand new toy! It's perfect and shiny. When you eat it right away, it's super good. But then, if you put it away and bring it out later to play with again, it's still fun, but maybe a little bit different, right? Maybe a tiny scratch or it's not as shiny. Food is like that! When it sits, even in the fridge, the air and time change it a little bit, like how a fresh apple turns a little brown if you leave it out. Then, when you warm it up again, it's like cooking it a second time! Some of the water goes away, making it a bit dry, and the yummy smells and tastes get mixed up differently, making some stronger and some weaker, or even making new ones. So, it's still your food, and it can still be yummy, but it's just a little bit of a different adventure for your mouth because it's been on a little journey since it was first made!

title: How can a food illness get traced back to a restaurant or a specific item being purchased?
text: Imagine lots of people, like you and your friends, all get a tummy ache at the same time! Special grown-ups, kind of like detectives, try to figure out why. They ask everyone lots and lots of questions: "Where did you eat?" "What did you eat?" "When did you eat?" It's like asking all your friends what toy they played with right before they got sticky hands. If many, many people say, "I ate yummy chicken at *that* restaurant!" or "I ate the same type of cookie!", that's a super big clue! Sometimes, they can even look at the actual food or where it was made, like looking super close at your toy to see if there's a tiny bit of dirt on it that made someone sneeze. By putting all these clues together, like solving a puzzle, they can figure out exactly which restaurant or which yummy food made everyone sick, so they can tell everyone to be careful and make sure it doesn't happen again.

title: - Why do our eyes become bloodshot when we're tired?
text: Imagine your eyes have super tiny, tiny roads inside them, so small you can barely see them, and these roads carry little helpers (like water and food) to keep your eyes happy and clean. When you're super tired, like after a long day of playing and running around, your eyes get a bit dry and sleepy too, and they feel like they need extra help! So, your body sends a message: "Hey, eyes need more helpers!" To send more helpers, those tiny roads in your eyes get a little bit bigger, like when you make a road wider for more cars. And guess what? Those roads have red stuff inside them (that's your blood!). When the roads get bigger, you can see the red stuff more easily, and that's why your eyes look a little red and sleepy, like they've been working really hard and need a good rest!

title: How is burning wood different from rotting wood in terms of their carbon footprints?
text: Imagine wood is like a little sponge holding special air-food inside it. When you burn wood, like in a campfire, it gets super hot and makes big puffs of smoke and fire. All that special air-food rushes out into the sky *really, really fast*, like a big whoosh! That's a big carbon footprint happening all at once. But when wood rots, it's like tiny bugs and nature slowly eat it up and turn it back into dirt. The special air-food still goes into the sky, but it goes out *very, very slowly*, like little tiny whispers over a long, long time. So, both burning and rotting put the air-food back into the sky, but burning does it all at once in a big rush, making the sky feel full faster, while rotting does it slowly, little by little.

title: how do eye dilation drops inhibit the parasympathetic nervous system?
text: Okay, imagine your eye has a little black dot in the middle called a pupil. This pupil is like a tiny window that lets light into your eye so you can see. Sometimes, your body has a special helper team, let's call them the 'calm down and make things small' team, and their job is to tell that little window to get smaller, especially when it's bright outside. When the eye doctor gives you special drops, those drops are like a little 'shhh!' to that 'calm down and make things small' team. They tell the team to take a break and not do their job for a little while. So, because that team isn't working to make your pupil small, your pupil just stays big and open, like a wide-open door. This helps the eye doctor shine a light and see way, way inside your eye much better, like looking into a big, open room!

title: What is happening to the body/brain of a person who has taken a dose of LSD? How does LSD cause hallucinations?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a super-duper control room inside your head, with lots of tiny little workers called messengers who tell you what you see, what you hear, and how you feel. When someone takes something called LSD, it's like a mischievous little trickster sneaks into that control room! It makes the messengers get all mixed up and send silly, wrong signals to each other. So, instead of seeing just your red ball, your brain might suddenly think the ball is glowing with rainbow colors, or that it's singing a song! Your eyes and ears are working just fine, but your brain is making up new pictures and sounds that aren't really there, because the messengers are playing tricks. It's like having a very wild, colorful dream, but you're wide awake! Your body usually feels okay, maybe a bit wobbly or your tummy feels funny, but the biggest changes

title: What makes a scientific study a good one? what are the best practices?
text: Imagine you want to know if eating your carrots makes you jump super high, like a bunny! A good scientific study is like playing a very careful game of "find out." First, you need to ask a super clear question, like "Do *my* carrots make *me* jump higher?" Then, you need to watch very, very carefully. You don't just eat one carrot and say "YES!" You try it for a few days, and maybe you also try *not* eating carrots for a few days, and you see if your jumps feel different. The most important thing is to only change *one* thing at a time. So, if you're trying to see if carrots make you jump high, you don't also suddenly start practicing jumping all day or eat five chocolate bars! You keep everything else the same. You also need to do it many, many times, not just once, to make sure it wasn't a magic trick

title: What is an enterprise architect?
text: Okay, imagine a really, really big company is like a super giant house, or even a whole little town! It has lots of different rooms (like different departments), and lots of different things

title: Why did variolation/inoculation of smallpox acquired from sores have a less severe infection than naturally acquired smallpox?
text: Imagine your body is like a strong castle, and germs are like little bad guys trying to get in and make you sick. When someone with smallpox breathes near you, it's like a *huge army* of bad guys flying right into your castle's front door – your nose and mouth! They get inside super fast, especially into your soft, important parts like your lungs, and they start making trouble everywhere all at once. This makes you feel very, very sick, like a really big battle is happening inside. But with variolation, it was different. A doctor would take just a tiny, tiny bit of the sick stuff from a little spot on someone's skin, and they would just make a little scratch on *your* arm. This is like letting in only a *few* bad guys through a secret, tiny side door in your castle wall. Your castle's guards (your body's special helpers) see these few bad guys coming on your skin first. Skin is a strong wall! It's not as easy for them to get deep inside and spread quickly

title: Why do most hard candies just shrink down as you suck on them but peppermints get all porous and full of holes?
text: Okay, imagine your regular hard candy is like one big, solid block of sugar, like a smooth, shiny rock. When you suck on it, your yummy spit just slowly licks away the outside, making it smaller and smaller, like a big ice cube melting evenly. But a peppermint is different! It's made of lots and lots of tiny little sugar crystals, like a pile of super tiny sugar grains all squished together. Think of it like a crunchy cookie or a sandcastle. There are tiny little air pockets and gaps all between those grains. So when your spit touches a peppermint, it not only dissolves the outside, but it also sneaks into all those tiny little gaps and starts dissolving the sugar *inside* too! As the sugar inside the gaps disappears, it leaves behind empty spaces, making the peppermint feel all bumpy, crumbly, and full of holes, like a sponge. It's like the little sugar grains holding it together just float away, leaving holes behind!

title: What is unique about sunlight that our bodies need to produce Vitamin D?
text: Imagine the sun sends down tiny, invisible super-powers with its light, like little sparks you can't see! When these special sun-sparks touch your skin, your body gets super excited and uses them to make something really important called Vitamin D. Vitamin D is like the special food that makes your bones strong, strong, strong, like a superhero's bones! Regular lights in your house don't have these special sun-sparks, so they can't help your body make that super bone-food. Only the sunshine has that magic touch!

title: Why does twisting a damp sponge get more water out than just squeezing it, without having to apply anywhere near as much force?
text:
Okay, imagine your sponge is like a big bouncy house with lots and lots of tiny little rooms inside, and the water is like little kids playing in all those rooms.

When you just **squeeze** the sponge, it's like you're only pushing down on the top of the bouncy house. Some kids run out, but lots of them just squish into other rooms or hide in the corners, and you have to push really, really hard to get most of them to leave.

But when you **twist** the sponge, it's like you're squishing and twisting the whole bouncy house from *all* sides at once! All the little rooms get squeezed and changed shape much more, so the kids can't hide anymore. The twisting motion makes

title: Now that it’s back in season, where’s the flu been?
text: Imagine the flu is a tiny, invisible tickle-monster that loves to play hide-and-seek and makes you feel a bit yucky. When it's warm and sunny outside, everyone is playing far apart in the park, so the tickle-monster has a hard time jumping from one kid to another to make them sick. It's still around, maybe playing hide-and-seek with just a few people, or it went on a long vacation to a place where it was cold. But when it gets chilly and we all go inside to play close together, the tickle-monster gets super excited! It's like a big party where it can easily jump from one friend to another, making lots of people feel yucky. So, it wasn't really gone, it was just waiting for everyone to come inside where it's easier to play its tickle-monster game!

title: What causes depression and how do we stop it?
text: Imagine your brain is like a special control room inside your head that makes all your feelings, like happy, sad, excited, and sleepy. When someone has depression, it's like their brain's control room is having a bit of a tricky time making enough happy feelings, or maybe it's making too many sad feelings, and it just feels really, really tired for a long, long time. It's not their fault at all, just like it's not a toy's fault if its batteries run low. Sometimes big sad things can make it happen, and sometimes it just happens all by itself, like when you get a cold even if no one sneez

title: What are Lagrange points and how do they work?
text: Okay, imagine you have two super-duper strong friends, like a giant Sun and a big Earth, and they both have invisible ropes (that's called gravity!) that they use to pull on everything. Now, there are five super special, secret spots in space, like hidden parking spots. If you put a toy car, or a satellite, or even a little astronaut in one of these spots, it would just stay there, perfectly still! That's because the Sun's pull and the Earth's pull are exactly, perfectly balanced at these five spots. It's like neither friend is pulling harder than the other, so the toy car just floats peacefully, happy in its special parking spot without having to use any fuel to stay put!

title: Why do medications tend to give us the same common side effects (ie nausea, dry mouth etc.)?
text:
Okay, imagine your body is like a big house with lots of different rooms, and each room does a special job, like your tummy room, your mouth room, or your head room. When you're sick, it's like one of the rooms isn't working right.

The medicine is like a tiny, helpful worker whose main job is to go straight to the broken room and fix it. It's super good at its main job! But sometimes, on its way to fix the main problem, this little worker might accidentally bump into a light switch in the tummy room (making you feel like you need to throw up) or accidentally turn off the water faucet in the mouth room (making your mouth feel dry).

Since lots of different medicine workers have to travel through similar hallways in your house or might accidentally hit the same kinds of switches, many of them cause those *same* little bumps and spills. It's not their main job, just a little oopsie they make while trying to do the really important work of making you feel better!

title: If blood only flows through our veins and arteries, why do small cuts that don't sever any of either still draw blood?
text: Imagine your body is like a big city, and your blood travels on roads. Some roads are super big highways (those are your arteries and veins), but there are also millions and millions of super tiny little alleyways and tiny paths, so small you can barely see them, that connect all the big roads to every single part of your body, even your tippy-toes! These tiny paths are called capillaries. When you get a little scratch, you're not usually breaking one of the big highways or main streets, but you *are* breaking some of those super tiny alleyways. And even though they're tiny, they still have blood in them, so a little bit of blood comes out, like a tiny leak from a small water pipe, until your body puts a little bandage on it inside to make it stop.
